list.item: First issue published by Perseus Digital Library on 07th April 2011

entry.sense: The twenty-fifth letter of the alphabet; called nuwnN: it is one of the class termed caloqiy-apN [or liquids]; and is a letter of augmentation.
n- with teshdeed, and preceded by a fat-hah, is sometimes redundantly affixed to a word at the end of a verse: see an ex. voce taw-N.
n, the sign of the dual, with damm, in one dial., instead of kesr, see xaXiyfN.
See also SaAdN.
As a numeral, it denotes fifty.

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. naOonaOahu He fed him, or nourished him, well. (Ḳ.)
He restrained him, or turned him back, (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ,) from a thing that he desired to do. (El-Umawee, Ṣ.)

naOonaOa fiI Alr-aOoIi, inf. n. naOonaOapN and munaOonaOapN; [the latter an unusual form of inf. n.;] and tanaOonaOa↓; He was weak, (M, Ḳ,) or confused; (Ṣ;) and not firm or sound, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in his judgment, or opinion. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
naOonaOa fiI AlOamori He was weak in the affair. (Ṣ.)
naOonaOa Eanohu, and tanaOonaOa↓, He was unable to do it. (Ḳ.)
naOonaOa, inf. n. naOonaOapN; (AA;) and tanaOonaOa↓; (Ṣ;) He was weak, feeble, or remiss. (AA, Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2: see R. Q. 1 in three places.
naOonaON and naOonaMCN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuWonuwCN↓ and munaOonaON↓ Weak; cowardly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naOonaON One who frequently turns about, or rolls, the pupil, or black part, of his eye. (Ḳ.)
naOonaOapN: see the verb.
Weakness. (AA, Ṣ.)

TuwbaI limano maAta fiI Aln-OnOpi [Good betide him who hath died in (the time of) weakness!] i. e., in the first of El-Islám, before it acquired strength, (Ṣ,) and its adherents and assistants multiplied. (TA.)
naOonaMCN, nuWonuwCN and munaOonaON: see naOonaON.

hom.sense: 1. naOata, aor. _i {yanoOitu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) contr. to analogy, like yarojiE, (TA,) and _a, (Ḳ,) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) inf. n. naYiytN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure faEiylN, because it signifies a sound, like OaniynN, (TA,) and naOotN, (Ḳ,) contr. to analogy, because the verb is intrans., (TA,) He (a man, Ṣ) moaned; or breathed violently, or with moaning; or uttered his voice or breath with moaning; syn. Oan-a, (Ṣ, TA) and nahata: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it signifies he uttered a louder sound than such as is termed OaniynN. (Ḳ.)
naOatahu He envied him; (Ḳ;) [as also naOadahu].
naOata, inf. n. naOotN, He walked, or went, at a slow pace. (L.)

entry.sense: naO-LtN i. q. nah-aAtN: (Ṣ:) Aln-aO-Ltu The lion. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naOaja fiI AlOaroDi, aor. _a {yanoOaju}, inf. n. nuWuwjN, He went, went away, departed, or set forth journeying, through the land, or earth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naOaja Alxabaru The news, tidings, or information, went, or went away, through the land. (T.)
naOajati Alr-iyHu, aor. _a {yanoOaju}, inf. n. naYiyjN, The wind became in a state of commotion: blew with a swift course, and with a sound. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naOajati Alr-iyHu AlmawoDiEa The wind passed swiftly over the place. (TA.)
nuYija Alqawomu (like EuniIa [pass. in form but neut. in signification] TA) The people experienced, or suffered, a swift and sounding wind. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See an ex. voce manoOajN.]
naOajati AlUibilu fiI sayorihaA [The camels were swift in their pace]. (TA.)
naOajati Alr-aAYiHapu i. q. Eaj-at, [app., The odour diffused itself strongly or powerfully]. (TA.)
naOaja, (aor. _a {yanoOaju}, inf. n. naOojN, TA,) It (an owl) uttered a moaning cry; or hooted; syn. naOama: (Ḳ:) and in like manner a man. (TA.)
naOaja, (aor. _a {yanoOaju} and _i {yanoOiju}, inf. n. naOojN and nuWaAjN, TA,) He (a bull) lowed. (Ḳ.)
naOaja UilaI Qll-ehi, (aor. _a {yanoOaju} TA,) He humbled, or abased, himself, with earnestness, in supplication, to God. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naYija He ate weakly, or feebly. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: riyHN naWuwjN Wind in a state of commotion: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) swift in its course, and making a sound: pl. nawaAYiju. (TA.)

hom.sense: naO-LjN Quick; swift. (TA.)
Aln-aO-Lju The lion: (Ḳ:) so called because of his quick leaping, or springing. (TA.)
naO-LjN A bull that lows much. (TA.)
A man having a high voice. (TA.)

entry.sense: naAYijaAtN [Birds of the kind called] haAm uttering cries. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) [In the CK, for hAm is put hawaAm-. See an ex. voce manoOajN.]
Also, Winds blowing violently: (TA:) pl. nawaAYiju. (A.)
OudoEu rab-aka biOanoOaji maA taqodiru Ealayohi Supplicate thy Lord with the utmost humility, or abasement, and earnestness, of which thou art capable. (TA, from a trad.)

manoOajN [A place where a wind blows with a swift course and with a sound]. Ex.
watunoOaju Alr-ukobaAnu kul-a manoOaji
bihi naYiyju kul-i riyHK sayohaji . (Ṣ.)

[A place where birds of the kind called haAm utter their cries]. Ex.
waQt-axacatohu Aln-aAYijaAtu↓ manoOajaA
(TA [but quoted in the Ṣ as an ex. of mnOj in the former sense].)

HadiyvN manoWuwjN i. q. maEoTuwfN [app. A distorted story]: (Ḳ:) so explained by ISk, as occurring in the following verse:
qado Ealima AlOaHomaMCu waAlOazaAwiyjo
Oano layosa Eanohun-a HadiyvN manoWuwjo . (TA.)
1. naOadatohu daAhiyapN, (aor. _a {yanoOadu} A, inf. n. naOodN, L,) A calamity befell him: (Ḳ:) or pressed heavily upon him, and distressed him. (A.)
See naOata.
naMdN and naMdaI↓ (Ṣ, L. Ḳ) and naWuwdN↓ (L, Ḳ) A calamity: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) pl. of the second, naMYidu. (L.)
daAhiyapN naMdN, and naMdaI↓, and naWuwdN↓, (A, L,) A calamity that presses heavily, and distresses. (A.)
naMdaI: see naMdN.
naWuwdN: see naMdN.

hom.sense: 1. naOaXahu, aor. _a {yanoOaXu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. naOoXN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He postponed, delayed, or retarded, it, syn. Oax-arahu; (Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ,*) namely, an affair. (Ṣ, M.)
He made it (a thing) to be distant, or remote; put it at a distance; put it, or sent it, away, or far away. (TA.)

naOoXN also signifies The taking, or reaching, [a thing,] absolutely, or with the hand, or with the extended hand; (A, Ḳ;) and so tanaAWuXN↓, (Mṣb,) and tanaAwuXN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and nawoXN: (IDrd, TA:) or tanaAWuXN↓, with C, signifies the taking from a distant place; and without C, the taking from a near place. (Th, TA.) You say, naOaXotuhu, inf. n. naOoXN, I took it, or reached it, absolutely, or with my hand, or with my extended hand. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xxxiv. 51,] waOan-aI lahumu Qlt-anaAWuXu↓, and Alt-anaAwuXu, with and without C, accord. to different readers: (TA:) with C, the word is from Aln-awoXu, the w being changed to C because of the ḍammeh; [so that the meaning is, But how shall the attaining of belief be possible to them?] (Zj, Bḍ;*) or from naOaXotu as signifying taOaxarotu [see 6 below]; so that the meaning is the reaching [or attaining] from afar: (Bḍ:) or from naYiyXN, meaning, “motion in a state of slowness or tardiness:” (Zj:) or it is from naOaXotu AlX-aIoCa, (Bḍ,) inf. n. naOoXN, (IB, TA,) signifying I sought, or sought for or after, the thing: (IB, Bḍ:) [so that the above phrase in the Ḳur. may be rendered But how shall the seeking of belief be possible to them?]

It also signifies, (namely naOoXN,) The taking [a thing]: and seizing violently: (A, Ḳ:) or taking in a violent seizure: you say, naOaXahu, inf. n. naOoXN, he took him, or it, in a violent seizure. (TA.)

6. tanaMCaXa He, or it, became, or remained, behind; became delayed, or retarded; it became postponed; syn. taOax-ara; (Ṣ;) and so naOaXa↓, said of a man; (Bḍ, xxxiv. 51;) and AntOX↓, (Ṣ, TA,) said of an affair. (Ṣ.)
He, or it, became distant, or remote; or he went, removed, retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, or far away; (Ṣ, TA;) as also AntOX↓. (TA.)
See also 1, in three places.

entry.sense: 8: see 6, in two places.

naWuwXN Strong; overcoming; or prevailing; (Ḳ;) possessing might or strength, courage, valour, or prowess. (TA.) You say also, qadarN naWuwXN An overcoming decree; as also naw-aAXN. (TA.) See also art. nwX.

hom.sense: faEalahu naYiyXFA He did it lastly, or latterly, or last of all. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And jaMCa naYiyXFA He came lastly, or latterly, or last of all: (A:) or slowly, tardily, or late. (TA.) And laHiqanaA naYiyXFA mina Aln-ahaAri He overtook us after the day had declined; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) i. e., he held back from us, and then followed us in haste, fearing escape. (TA.)
naYiyXN also signifies Motion in a state of slowness or tardiness. (Zj.)
Th also explains naYiyXN as signifying Distant or remote. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. nab-a, aor. _i {yanobibu}, inf. n. nabiybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nab-N and nubaAbN; and nabonaba↓; He (a goat) uttered a sound, or cry, [or rattled,] and was excited by desire of the female: (Ṣ:) or uttered a sound, or cry, [or rattled,] when excited by desire of the female, (Ḳ,) or at rutting-time. (TA.) laA tanib-uwA EinodiI nabiyba Alt-uyuwsi † Do not cry out [in my presence like as he-goats rattle at rutting-time]. Said by ʼOmar to some persons who had come to make a complaint to him. (TA.)
[Hence,] nab-a † He desired sexual intercourse. (TA.)
nab-a Eatuwduhu † He was proud, or behaved proudly, and magnified himself. (Ḳ.)
2. nb-b, inf. n. tanobiybN, It (a plant) produced a knotted stem. (Ḳ.)
Uin-iI OaraI AlX-ar-a nab-aba † [Verily I see evil, or the evil, to have grown, like a plant producing knotted stems]. (TA.)
4. Anbbhu Tuwlu AlEuzobapi † [Length of celibacy made him to be desirous of sexual intercourse]. (TA.)

Anb-, inf. n. UinobaAbN, if not a mistake for Anbt, inf. n. AnbAt, meaning “he became pubescent,” probably signifies He was excited, and uttered libidinous sounds, with the desire of sexual intercourse. (TA.) See R. Q. 1.
5. tnb-b It (water) was made to flow; or was set a flowing. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1: see 1.
nabonaba ‡ He (a man, TA) talked nonsense, (and uttered libidinous sounds, TA,) in concubitu: (Ḳ:) implying his acting like a he-goat at rutting-time. (TA.)
He prolonged his work, to do it well. (Ḳ.)
nab-apN A disagreeable, or abominable, smell. (Ḳ.) Probably a mistake for ban-apN; and therefore not mentioned by the leading lexicographers. (TA.)
nub-iI-N A table (maAYidap) made of palm-leaves. (Ḳ, voce bat-iIN, q. v.)
OanobubN or OunobubN: see OunobuwbN and OunobuwbapN.
OunobuwbN see OunbuwbapN.
Ounobuwbu qaronK † That part of a horn that is above the knotty portion, to the extremity: [i. e., the smooth part]. (TA:)
OunobuwbN ‡ The spout, or tube, of a jug. (TA.)
† A pipe of a tank, or cistern, through which the water flows: either from tanab-aba, or from OunobuwbN as signifying “an internodal portion” of a reed, or cane. (TA.)

OanaAbiybu Alr-iYapi ‡ The [bronchi, or] air-passages of the lungs. (Ḳ.) OanobubN↓ or OunobubN is said to signify the same, in an instance mentioned by IAạr, in which a poet speaks of the substance resembling lights which a camel in heat protrudes from his mouth, and which is called giylap, as coming forth bayona AlOanobubi: in which case, the word, if Oanobub, may be a pl., regularly Oanub-, of which the sing. is nab-N; or, if with ḍammeh to the hemzeh, it may be a contraction of Ounobuwb, used as a coll. gen. n., in a pl. sense. (TA.)
OunobuwbN A way, or road. (Ḳ.) [Ex.] Uilozami AlOunobuwba Keep to the way, or road. (Aṣ.)

Ounobuwbu jabalK ‡ A track, or streak, (TariyqapN,) in a mountain, (Ḳ,) appearing distinctly therein: of the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) Ex. cahaba fiI kul-i AnbwbK [He went along every track of the mountain, or mountains]. (TA.) [As a coll. gen. n., used in the pl. sense: ex.] Málik Ibn-Khalid El-Khuzá'ee says,
fiI raOosi XaAhiqapK OunobuwbuhaA xuDorN
[On the top of a lofty mountain, the streaks of which are green]. (TA.)
OunobuwbN ‡ A row of trees (Ḳ), &c. (TA.) [See OusokuwbN.]
OunobuwbN An elevated tract of land: (Ḳ:) one that is fine (rqyq) and elevated: pl. OanaAbiybu. (TA.)

OunobuwbapN An internodal portion of a reed or cane; such a portion thereof as intervenes between two joints, or knots: (Lth, Ṣ:) i. q. kaEobN, [which signifies as above, and also a joint, or knot,] with reference to a reed, or cane, or a spear-shaft: (Ḳ:) as also OunobuwbN↓ (Lth, Ḳ) and OunobubN↓, which latter is probably a contraction: (Ḳ:) [see below:] or the pl. of Anbwbp is OunobuwbN and OanaAbiybu: (Ṣ:) [or Anbwb is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is Anbwbp, and the pl. AnAbyb: see also art. Anb].
[Hence,] AijoEali AlOamora OunobuwbapF waAHidapF Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr. in TA in art. bOj.)
[Also, A sheath of a plant. See OumoSuwxapN.]
[And Any kind of tube. See qaSabN.]

hom.sense: 1. nabaOa. (Ḳ,) inf. n. naboCN, (TA,) He uttered a low voice, or sound: or he (a dog) cried, or barked. (Ḳ.) [See nabaHa.]
nabaOa, aor. _a {yanobaOu}, inf. n. naboCN and nubuwoCN, He was exalted, or elevated.
nabaOa Ealayohimo, (Ḳ,) inf. n. naboCN and nubuwoCN, (Ṣ,) He assaulted them; came forth upon them: (Ḳ:) like nabaEa and nabaha: he came upon them. (AZ, Ṣ.) [See also naAbiYN.]
nabaOa He went forth from a land to another land. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See naAbiYN.]

nabaOato bihi AlOaroDu i. q. jaMCato bh, The land brought, or led him: (Ṣ, L:) [accord. to Golius, The land brought, or produced, it: but it is a phrase well known to the learned among the Arabs in the present day, as similar to naAdaAhu turaAbuhu “his dust, or earth, (i. e. the place of his burial,) called him:” and the explanation which I have given is confirmed by the citation, in the Ṣ, of the following verse, of Hanash Ibn-Málik, immediately after nbOt bh in the sense of jACt bh:]
fanafosaka OaHorizo faUin-a AlHutuw
fa yanobaOona biAlmaroCi fiI kul-i waAdo
[Then take good care of thyself; for deaths (of various kinds) bring (or lead) a man into every valley (or place): i. e., fate brings him to the place where he is destined to be buried, whereever it be]. (Ṣ.)
nabaOa, aor. _a {yanobaOu}: see 4.

entry.sense: 2. nb-O: see 4.
3. nAbOhu He acquainted or informed him, and the latter did the same. (Ḳ.)
Also, simply, He acquainted or informed him. (TA.)
naAbaOahumo He quitted their neighbourhood; withdrew to a distance from them. (Ḳ.) [See also art. nbw.]

hom.sense: 4. AnbOhu Uiy-aAhu, and bihi, (and Eanohu, Ṣ, Ḳ, art. kwd;) and nb-Ohu↓ (Ṣ,* Ḳ) and nabaOahu↓, (Ṣ,* TA,) each followed by Ay-Ah or bh; (TA;) He informed him, or told him, of it: (Ḳ:) or these verbs, followed by Ay-Ah, signify he made him to know it; and followed by bh, he informed him, or told him, of it. (TA.)

Es-Semeen says, that AnbO and nb-O and Axbr and xb-r, when they convey the meaning of knowledge, are triply transitive, or may govern three objective complements, the greatest number that any verb can govern: (TA:) [ex. OanobaOotu zayodFA EamorFA qaAYimFA I acquainted Zeyd that ʼAmr was standing].

It is also said, that nb-O↓ has a more intensive signification than AnbO: ex. mano OanobaOaka hecaA qaAla nab-aOaniI AlEaliymu Alxabiyru [Who hath acquainted thee with this? He said, The Knowing, the Intelligent (God), hath apprized me: Ḳur, lxvi. 3]. (TA.)
Sb has mentioned OanaA OanabuWuka [for AnA OanobaWuka] as used for the sake of conformity in sound with a preceding word. (M, TA.) [See art. jwO.]
ramaI faOanobaOa He cast, or shot, but did not split, or cleave, or make a slight cut, or scratch: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, did not penetrate. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tnb-O, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said to have been pronounced with C universally; (Sb, Ṣ;) but in the L, tnb-I; (TA;) He arrogated to himself the gift of prophecy, or office of a prophet. (L, Ḳ.)
10. AstnbO Aln-abaOa He sought, or searched after, information, or news. (Ḳ.)
wayasotanobiYuwnaka OaHaq-N huwa (in the Ḳur, x. 54) means And they will ask thee to inform them, [saying,] Is it true? (Bḍ.)

nabaON Information; a piece of information; intelligence; an announcement; news; tidings; a piece of news; an account; a narrative, or narration; a story: or what is related from another or others: syn. xabarN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is generally held to be syn. with xabarN; but accord. to Er-Rághib, signifies an announcement of great utility, from which results either knowledge or a predominance of opinion, and true: (TA:) pl. OanobaMCu. (Ḳ.)
Aln-abaOu AlEaZiymu [Ḳur, lxxviii. 2,] accord. to some, The Ḳur-án: others say, the resurrection: and others, the case of the Prophet. (TA.)
AlOanobaMCu, in the Ḳur, xxviii. 66, (faEamiyato Ealayohimu AlOanobaMCu) signifies The allegations, pleas, or excuses. (TA.)
naboOapN An eminence, or protuberance, in the earth, or ground. (TA.)
naboOapN A low voice, or sound: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the cry, or barking, of dogs. (Ḳ.)

nabiIoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) pronounced with C in the dial. of the people of Mekkeh, (Ṣ,) whose pronunciation of it is disapproved by Sb on account of its uncommonness; (TA;) by others, nabiI-N, without C; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) A prophet: (TA:) of the measure faEiylN used in the sense of the measure mufoEl [i. e. mufoEilN or mafoEalN] (IB) or faAEilN (Ṣ, Es-Sunoosee) or mafoEuwlN; (Es-Sunoosee) i. e., who acquaints or informs mankind, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or who is acquainted or informed, respecting God and things unseen: or accord. to some, it is derived from nabowapN and nabaAwapN signifying “elevation;” (see art. nbw;) in which case it is originally without C: or, accord. to others, from nabiIoCN in a sense given below; that of “a conspicuous way.” (TA.) It is a less special word than rasuwlN [when thereby is meant an apostle of God]; for every rswl is a nbI-, but not every nbI- is a rswl. (TA.) Pl. OanobiyaMCu (Ṣ, Ḳ, without C, because the C is changed into I in the sing., Ṣ,) and nubaOLCu (Ṣ, Ḳ, like kuramaMCu [pl. of kariymN] TA,) and OanobaMCN [Ḳ, these two preserving the original radical C] and nabiy-uwna, (Ḳ,) without C: (TA:) but some pronounced the first and last of these pls., in the Ḳur-án, with C; though the more approved pronunciation is without C. (TA.) The dim. is nubay-YN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with those who make the pl. nubaOLCN [or OanobaMCN]; but with those who make the pl. OanobiyaMC, it is nubaI-N. (Ḳ.)

An Arab of the desert said to Moḥammad, yaA nabiIoCa Qll-ehi, and the latter disapproved of his pronouncing nbIC in this case with C, because, as it signifies An emigrant, he meant thereby to call him an emigrant from Mekkeh to El-Medeeneh. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

nabiIoCN A conspicuous, an evident, or a clear, way. (Ḳ.) Hence, accord. to some, the apostle [or rather prophet] is so called, because he is the conspicuous, evident, way, that conducts to God. (MF.)
nabiIoCN and naAbiYN↓ An elevated, or a protuberant, or gibbous, place. (Ḳ.)
Hence it is said in a trad., laA tuSal-uwA EalaI Aln-abiIoCi [Pray not upon the place that is elevated, or protuberant]. (Ḳ.)

nubuwoCapN, (Ḳ, in the CK nubuw-ap) in which the C is sometimes softened in pronunciation, and sometimes [or rather generally] changed into w which is incorporated into the preceding w so that the word is written and pronounced nubuw-apN, (TA,) Prophecy; the gift of prophecy; the office, or function, of a prophet. (MA, Ḳ.) Dim. nubay-iYapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naAbiYN act. part. n. of nabaOa.
A bull [app. a vaworN waHoXiI-N] that goes forth from one land or country to another. (TA.)
A torrent that comes forth from another land or tract. (Ṣ.)
A man coming forth unexpectedly from an unknown quarter. (Ṣ, A.)
[See also nabiIoCN.]
halo Einodakumo naAbiYapu xabarK, i. q. jaAYibapu xabarK, [Have ye any current news? or … news from a distant place?, &c.: see jAYbp]. (A.)

1. nabata, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanobutu}, inf. n. nabotN and nabaAtN; [which two ns. see mentioned as substs.;] and tnb-t↓; (M;) and Anbt↓; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) [respecting which last see below;] It (a thing, M, or a leguminous [or other] plant, Ṣ, Ḳ,) grew; grew forth; sprouted; vegetated; or germinated. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) Aṣ disallows Anbt↓ in this sense; but AO allows it, alleging the words of Zuheyr, Hat-aI UicaA Oanobata↓ Albaqolu [Until, when the leguminous plants grew]. nabata and Oanobata↓ are said to be like maTarati Als-amMCu and OamoTarat. In the Ḳur, xxiii. 20, Ibn-Ketheer, Aboo-ʼAmr and El-Hadremee read tunobitu: others, tanobutu: but ISd says, that, accord. to the former reading, some hold b, which follows tunobitu, to be redundant; and others hold that maA tunobutu is understood after tunobitu. Fr holds them to be syn. (TA.)
nabata EalaIa HaAlapK HasanapK He, or it, grew in a good manner, condition, or state. (L.)
nabata, inf. n. nubuwtN, ‡ It (a girl's breast) became swelling, prominent, or protuberant. (Ḳ.)
nabatati AlOaroDu, and Oanobatat↓, The land produced, or gave growth to, plants, or herbage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
2. nb-t, inf. n. tanobiytN, ‡ He fed or nourished, or reared or brought up, a child: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he nourished a girl, and nursed her up well, hoping that she might profit excellently. (TA.)
nab-ito Oajalaka bayona Eayonayoka [‡ Plant the term of thy life before (lit. between) thine eyes; i. e., keep it ever before thee]. (Ṣ.)
nb-t, inf. n. tanobiytN, He planted a tree. (M, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He sowed seed, (M,) or grain. (A.)
4. Anbthu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UinobaAtN [for which nabaAtN occurs, as shown below], (TA,) He (God) caused it, or made it, (a plant) to grow, vegetate, or germinate. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Anbt, inf. n. UinobaAotN; for which inf. n. nabaAtN occurs in the Ḳur, iii. 32; and lxxi. 16; ‡ He (God) caused a child to grow. (TA.)
See 1.
Anbt His (a boy's) hair of the pubes grew forth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) he having nearly attained the age of puberty. (TA.) He (a boy) became hairy: and in like manner a girl. (Mṣb.)
5: see 1.

10. Astnbthu [He endeavoured to make it grow, or vegetate, or germinate]. (TA, art. bls.) Astnbthu bAlbacori [He grew it, or raised it, by means of seed], and biAln-awaI [by means of date-stones], and bAlgarosi [by means of planting]. (Mgh, art. Hrv.)

nabotN and nabaAtN↓ [properly coll. gen. ns.] are syn., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [signifying A plant, a herb: and plants, herbs, or herbage:] whatever God causes to grow, vegetate, or germinate, in the earth: (Lth:) the latter is an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Lth:) or it is a subst. which is used in the place of an inf. n. of Oanobata: (Fr:) n. un. of the former nabotapN; (AḤn;) [and of the latter nabaAtapN of which the pl. nabaAtaAtN is mentioned in the Ḳ in this art., and frequently occurs in other works].
Oaholu bayotK waOaholu nabotK A people of the highest rank, or nobility, and a people whose property has grown to the most flourishing state by means of their own exertions. (L, from a trad.)
nibotapN The manner, form, state, or condition, in which a thing grows, or germinates. (L.)
Uin-ahu laHasanu Aln-ibotapi Verily he, or it, is of a goodly manner, &c., of growth. (L.)
nabaAtN: see nabotN.

suk-ar nabaAt [Sugar-candy; so called in the present day;] an admirable kind of sugar, of which are made pieces resembling crystal, intensely white and lustrous: app. Persian, and post-classical. (MF.)

xabiytN nabiytN Vile, and contemptible, or despicable: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) said of a man, and of a thing. (TA.) In some copies of the Ḳ, and in the L, instead of HaqiyrN, we read faqiyrN, [accord. to which, the meaning is vile, and poor]. (TA.)

nabiytapN sing. of nabaAYitu, which latter signifies the ridges that are raised along the edges of rivulets such as are called fulojaAn (in the CK, falojaAn) to retain the water: AlnbAYt being expl. by OaEoDaAdu AlfulojaAni: so in the L, &c.: in several copies of the Ḳ we read, in the place of AEDAd, AgSAn: but this is a mistake. (TA.)
naAbitN kul-i XaIoCK What is fresh, or new, of anything, when it is growing forth small. (TA.)
nabatato lahumo naAbitapN There grew up unto them young offspring, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that became conjoined to the old, and increased their number. (TA.) Dim. nuwayobitapN. (L.)
Uin-a baniI fulaAnK lanaAbitapu Xar-K [Verily the sons of such a one are an evil offspring]. (Ṣ.)
maA OaHosana naAbitapa baniI fulaAnK How good is the manner, condition, or state, in which grow (maA tanobutu Ealayohi, see 1,) the camels, &c., (OamowaAl) and children of the sons of such a one!
naAbitapN (TA) and nawaAbitu [pl. of the former] (Ṣ, Ḳ) Inexperienced young men. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, hecaA qawolu Aln-aAbitapi, and Aln-awaAbiti, This is the saying of inexperienced young men. (TA.)
Aln-awaAbitu The name of a certain sect who introduced strange innovations in El-Islám. (A, TA.) El-Jáhidh couples them with the raAfiDap. (MF.)
manobatN: see manobitN.

manobitN ‡ Origin, or race, [from which a man springs;] syn. OaSolN. (L.) So in the phrase Uin-ahu lafiI manobiti SidoqK ‡ [Verily he belongs to an excellent race; is of an excellent origin]: and so in the phrase fiI Oakorami AlmanaAbiti [of the most generous of origins, or races.] (TA.)

manobitN A place in which plants, or herbs, grow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) dev. from the constant course of speech: analogically it should be manobatN↓: (Ḳ:) as the aor. of the verb from which it is derived is not yanobitu, with kesreh: but there are other examples like it; as masjidN and maToliEN, &c.: manobatN↓, however, also sometimes occurs. (TA.) [Pl. manaAbitu.]
OaroDN minobaAtN [Land abounding with plants, or herbage]. (Ḳ, voce raHabapN, &c.)
manobuwtN (contr. to analogy, Ṣ, [for munobatN,]) A plant caused to grow, or germinate. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mutanab-itN Firmly rooted; syn. mutaOaS-ilN. (TA.)

tanobiytN and tinobiytN↓, (Ḳ,) the latter so written, not as being so originally, but for the sake of agreement in sound [with respect to the first and second vowels], (AḤei,) a subst., signifying What grows or germinates, of slender (i. e. small, TA,) trees, [or shrubs,] and large: (Ḳ:) ex.,
bayodaMCu lamo yanobuto bihaA tanobiytu
[A desert in which there grew not aught of shrubs or of large trees]: (TA:) young shoots of palmtrees: (IḲṭṭ:) the prickles and branches that are cut off from a palm-tree, to lighten it. (AḤn, as from 'Eesa Ibn-ʼOmar.)
Pieces of the hump of a camel. (L.)
tinobiyvN: see tanobiyvN.

yanobuwtN [coll. gen. n.] A certain species of trees: (Ṣ:) poppy-plants; syn. Xajaru AlxaXoxaAX: and other trees of a large kind: or the trees called xr-wb [see below]: (Ḳ:) or a kind of thorny trees, having branches and leaves, with a fruit of the kind called jirow, i. e., round; called in 'Omán gAf: n. un. with p {yanobuwtapN}: AḤn says that there are two species of ynbwt; one of these is a kind of thorny and short trees, also called xar-uwb [q. v.] having a fruit resembling a bubble, in which are red grains, having an astringent effect upon the bowels, used as a medicine; the other species is a large species of trees: ISd says, An Arab of the desert, of the tribe of Rabeea, described to me the ynbwtp as [a tree] resembling a large apple-tree, the leaves of which are smaller than those of the apple, having a fruit smaller than the zuEoruwr, intensely black and intensely sweet, with grains, or stones, which are put into scales, or balances: [evidently meaning the carob, or locust-tree, (see xar-uwb,) whence our term “carob,” applied to a small weight, the twenty-fourth part of a grain]. (L [See gaAfN and furofuwrN].)

hom.sense: 1. nabava, aor. _u {yanobuvu}, inf. n. nabovN; (and Antbv↓, Ḳ;) i. q. nabaXa; (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., He dug with the hand. (AZ, Ṣ.)
nabava, aor. _u {yanobuvu}, inf. n. nabovN, He took forth, or dug out, dust, or earth, from a well or a river. (L.)

nabavuwA Eani AlOamori ‡ They searched, or sought, for, or after, the thing; inquired respecting it; sought for information respecting it; searched into, inquired into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it. (TA.)
nabava, [aor. _u {yanobuvu},] inf. n. nabovN, ‡ He was angry. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tanaAbavuwA Eani AlOasoraAri ‡ They searched into each other's secrets. (A.)
8. Antbv: see 1.
He took; received into his hand. (Ḳ.)
He tucked up the skirts of his shirt, or the like, when sitting on the ground. (Ḳ.)
It (sawiyq or the like) increased in size (rabaA) in the water: (Ḳ:) as also Antbc. (TA.)
10. Astnbv OaxaAhu Eano sir-ihi ‡ He examined his brother respecting his secret. (A.)
nabavN A trace, vestige, or mark: (Ḳ:) a trace, or mark, of digging: (A:) pl. OanobaAvN. (TA.)
maA raOayotu lahu EayonFA walaA nabavFA I saw not the man himself, or the thing itself, nor any trace of him, or it. (L.)
See nabiyvN.

hom.sense: nabiyvN The dust that an animal digs up with its feet in running. (IAạr.)
nabiyvapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nabiyvN and nabavN↓ (L) The dust, or earth, that is taken forth, or dug out, from a well or a river: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) pl. of the first, nabaAYivu. (A.)
nabiyvN and manobuwvN↓ Earth, or dust, taken forth, or dug out, from a well or a river. (L.)
nabyvapu↓ sabuEK Flesh-meat buried by a beast of prey against the time of want. (IAth, from a trad.)

nabiyvN A species of sea-fish; accord. to IAạr; but it is also said, on his authority, that it is called yanobiyvN; therefore it seems that one of these two words is a mistake for the other, or that they are two dial. forms. See also bayoniyvN, in art. bnv. (TA.)
xabiyvN nabiyvN ‡ Very bad, evil, wicked, or corrupt: (Ḳ:) applied to a man: (TA:) the latter word is an imitation sequent to the former. (Ṣ, and some copies of the Ḳ.)
OabodaI nabiyvapa Alqawomi, and nabaAYivahumo, ‡ [He revealed the elicited secret of the people, and their elicited secrets]. (A.)
bayonahumo XaHonaMCu wanabaAYivu ‡ [Between them are enmity and secrets elicited]. (A.)

entry.sense: nabiyvapN: see nabiyv.
OanobuwvapN A certain game (played by children, TA,) in which something is buried in a hole dug in the ground, and he who takes it forth wins the game. (Ḳ.)
manobuwvN: see nabiyvN.
Zaharato manaAbivuhumo walamo taxofa xabaAYivuhumo ‡ [The occasions for the scrutiny of their conduct appeared, and their evil qualities were not hidden]. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. nabaja, aor. _u {yanobuju}, inf. n. nabiyjN, He uttered a loud, or vehement voice, or cry. (TA.)
nabaja, inf. n. nabojN, Pepedit, certo modo: (TA:) inf. n. nubaAjN, crepitum ventris emisit; pepedit. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nabaja, inf. n. nabaAjN and nabiyjN, He (a dog) barked; i. q. nabaHa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nabaja He mixed up, or beat up, fresh milk, with a nab-aAjap, until it became froth, in which state it is eaten with dates, taken up with three fingers. Only the Benoo-Asad did this. (IKh.)
nabaja He mixed up sawiyq, &c. (TA.)

entry.sense: nabiyjN and manobuwjN↓ Milk mixed up, or beaten up, in the manner explained voce nabaja. (IKh.)
nabiyjN and naAbijapN↓ A kind of food of the Arabs in the time of paganism, (in seasons of dearth, or famine, TA,) made by mixing up, and beating up, soft camel's hair (wabar) with milk. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: nab-aAjN Loud, or vehement, in voice, or cry. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nab-aAjN and nubaAjiI-N↓ A dog that barks much; (Ḳ;) a loud-barking dog. (Ṣ.) [See nab-aAHN.]
nab-aAjN [The wooden implement called] a mijodaH, for [mixing up] sawiyq (Ḳ) &c.; (TA;) also called mixowaDN and mizohafN. (El-Mufaddal.) [See also nab-aAjapN.]

entry.sense: Aln-ab-aAjapu The anus; syn. AlUisotu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
kacabato nab-aAjatuhu Pepedit. (Ṣ.)

nab-aAjapN A wooden implement at the end of which is a thing resembling a falokap [or the round head of a spindle], with which fresh milk is mixed up, or beaten up, in the manner explained voce nabaja. (IKh.) [See also nab-aAjN.]
nubaAjiI-N: see nab-aAjN.
naAbijapN: see nabiyjN.

OanobajN and OanobijN↓ The fruit of a certain Indian tree, (Ḳ,) which is preserved, or made into a confection, with honey; in form like the peach, with the head edged (muHar-af); [but this seems rather to apply to a kind mentioned below, resembling the almond;] it is brought to El-'Irák; and has within it a stone like that of the peach: (L:) an arabicized word, from [the Persian] Oanobo [or Oanabo]. (Ḳ.)
Hence OanobijaAtN↓, (L,) with kesreh to the b, Medical confections: app. an arabicized word: (Ṣ:) or confections, or preserves, made with honey, of the Outoruj- and Uiholiylaj and the like. (L.)

Accord. to AḤn, Anbj is the name of Certain trees abounding in Arabia, in the districts of 'Omán; planted; they are of two kinds; one of these has a fruit resembling the almond, which is sweet from the commencement of its growth; the other has a fruit in appearance like the Damask plum (Uij-aAS), is at first sour, and then becomes sweet when ripe: each has a stone, and has a sweet odour: the fruit of the sour kind is pressed down in jars, or earthern pots, [HibaAb: so I read for jbAb:] while fresh, and kept until it attains to a ripe state, when it becomes as though it were the banana, in its odour and taste: the tree grows great so as to become like the walnut (jawoz), which it resembles also in its leaves: and when it attains to perfection, the sweet [fruit] is yellow; and the bitter, [or sour,] red. (L.)
OanobijN: see OanobajN.

OanobajaAnN Dough that has become in a state of fermentation, and inflated, or swollen, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and sour: (TA:) in some books written with x; but heard from the Arabs with j, accord. to Aboo-Saʼeed and Abu-l-Ghowth and others: (Ṣ:) there is no word like it except OarowanaAnN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OanobajaAniI-N: see manobajaAniI-N.
Also, A mess of broken, or crumbled, bread, (variyd,) in which is [some degree of] heat. (Ḳ.)

kisaMCN manobajaAniI-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter word being formed after the manner of maxobaraAniI-N and manoZaraAniI-N, (Ṣ,) and OanobajaAniI-N↓, rel. ns. of manobijN, each with fet-ḥah to the b, contr. to analogy, (Ḳ,) the latter disallowed by IḲt, but occurring in a trad. and in poetry, and not to be disallowed because contr. to analogy, since there are many such rel. ns., as marowaziI-N and raAziI-N, &c., (TA,) A certain kind of ksAC, so called in relation to a place named manobijN: (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) or ksAC OanobajaAniI-N, and OanobijaAniI-N, which latter form is related by IAth as the one retained in the memory, a certain kind of ksAC, so called in relation to a place named AnbjAn; of wool, having a nap, or pile, without a border; one of the meanest kinds of coarse garments: its A, accord. to some, is an augmentative letter. (TA.)
manobuwjN: see nabiyjN.

1. nabaHa, aor. _i {yanobiHu} and _a {yanobaHu}, [the former of which, accord. to the Mṣb, seems to be more common,] inf. n. naboHN and nabiyHN and nubaAHN and nibaAHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nubuwHN (L,) and tanobaAHN, (Ḳ,) the last having an intensive and frequentative signification, (TA,) He (a dog, Ṣ, L, Ḳ) barked. (L.)

Also, (sometimes, Ṣ,) ‡ said of a gazelle, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) when he has advanced in years, and his horns have branched forth: (T:) and ‡ of a he-goat, (Ḳ,) in coupling-time: (L:) and ‡ of a serpent; (Ḳ;) meaning he uttered a cry, or sound: (L:) also ‡ of a hoopoe, (hudohud,) inf. n. nubaAHN, signifying it uttered a harsh cry, by reason of age: (L:) and ‡ of a lion, inf. n. nubaAHN, signifying he uttered a cry (L, Ḳ) like the barking of a whelp. (Aboo-Kheyreh, L.)
nabaHahi Alkalobu and nabaHa Ealayohi, (T, Mṣb,) and nAbHhu↓, (T,) The dog barked at him. (Mṣb.)
fulaAnN laA yuEowaI walaA yunobaHu † [Such a one is not howled at nor barked at]: i. e., by reason of his weakness, no account is taken of him, and neither good nor evil is said to him. (L.)
nabaHa ‡ He (a poet) satirized. (A.)
nabaHatoniI kilaAbuka ‡ Thy revilings reached, or overtook, me. (L.)
3: see 1.

4. AnbHhu and AstnbHhu↓, He made him (a dog) to bark: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) AstnbH↓ Alkaloba he excited, or induced, the dog to bark: said of man when, having lost his way, he imitates the bark of that animal, in order that a dog may hear him, and, imagining him to be a dog, may bark, and so guide him. (L.) Said also of a guest, [or one who would be a guest, and who desires to guide himself to a place of entertainment]. (A.) [See an ex. cited, from the poet El-Akhtal, voce Uirodab-N.]
nubuwHN ‡ The clamour, confused noise, or mixture of voices, of a tribe, (Ṣ,) or of a people, (Ḳ,) and the barkings of their dogs, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the cries of their other animals. (A.)

Subsequently put in the place of ‡ Multitude, and might, or power: (Ṣ:) and signifying ‡ a numerous assembly. (Ḳ.) El-Akhtal says,
Uin-a AlEaraArapa waAln-ubuwHa lidaArimK
[Verily strength, or eminence, or lordship, and multitude, and might, or power, belong to Dárim]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: nab-aAHN A dog that barks much. (A.)
nab-aAHN A man (L) having a vehement, or loud, voice. (L, Ḳ.)
nub-aAHN↓, with ḍammeh, (Ḳ,) or nab-aAHN (as in the L) ‡ A hoopoe (hudohud) that cooes (yuqaroqir) much. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
nab-aAHN ‡ A gazelle that cries much, or often: (IAạr:) and naboHaMCu↓ the same applied to the female. (AA, Ḳ.)

nab-aAHN White, small [shells such as are called] Sadaf: (TA:) small, white [shells such as are called] manaAqif, of Mekkeh, (T, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. brought from Mekkeh: (TA:) put into [necklaces such as are called] qalaAYid (Ḳ, TA) and wuXuH, and used for repelling the [evil] eye: (TA:) n. un. with p {nab-aAHapN}. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: nub-aAHN: see nab-aAHN.
nubaAHiI-N A dog having a loud bark. (Lḥ.)
kalobN naAbiHN A barking dog: pl. kilaAbN nawaAbiHu, and nub-aHN, and nubuwHN. (L.)
naboHaMCu: see nab-aAHN.
rajulN manobuwHN A man likened to a dog. (L.)
‡ A man reviled. (L.)
4. Anbx He sowed in a land such as is called naboxaMC. (Ḳ, TA.)
nabxN The small-pox; (Ṣ;) in an absolute sense: (TA:) or the small-pox of sheep or goats, &c., (Ḳ,)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nubaxN↓, (Ḳ,) Blisters, or pustules that fill with water, on the hand, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) occasioned by work: (Ḳ:) when they break, or dry up, the hand becomes callous by work: [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {nabxapN}. (TA.)
Also nabaxN↓ Marks of fire, [or blisters occasioned by burning,] upon the body.
nabaxN: see naboxN.

naboxaMCu A hill, or mound, such as is called Oakamap: (Ṣ:) or elevated ground: (TA:) or elevated and loose ground, not consisting of sand, but of hard and stony earth: (Th, Ḳ:) pl. nabaAxaI: (Ḳ:) it has a broken pl. of the class proper to substs. because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.)
naAbixapN A proud, a haughty, or an imperious, man: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. nawaAbixu. (Ṣ.)
A speaker. (Ḳ.)
Oanobaxu Rude, coarse, rough, gross; (Ḳ;) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)
turaAbN Oanobaxu Dust of a dusky colour, and abundant. (L, Ḳ.) [See an ex. voce habay-axN, art. hbx.]

hom.sense: 1. nabacahu, aor. _i {yanobicu}, inf. n. nabocN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He cast, threw, or flung, it away, as a thing esteemed of no account or importance: this is the original signification; and in this sense it is mostly used in the Ḳur-án: (Er-Rághib:) he cast, threw, or flung, it (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb. Ḳ) from his hand, (Ṣ, L,) before him or behind him: (L, Ḳ:) and he cast, threw, or flung, it far away, or to a distance: (L:) and (so in the L; but in the Ḳ, or) he cast, threw, or flung it in any manner: (L, Ḳ:) nb-c↓ has teshdeed given to it to denote frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects. (Ṣ, A, L.)
nabaca xaAtamahu He threw his signet from his hand. (L, from a trad.)
fanabacuwhu waraMCa Zuhuwrihimo (Ḳur, iii. 184) ‡ [lit., And they cast it behind their backs;] means and they did not observe it; (namely, their covenant;) they disregarded it. (Beyd.)

nabocN is both by act and by word; having for its objects both substances and accidents: (L:) you say nabaca AlEahoda ‡ He dissolved the league, or covenant, and cast it from him to him with whom he had made it: (A, L, Mṣb:*) and nabaca kul-u fariyqK minohumaA UilaI SaAHbh AlEahoda Al-aciI tahaAdanaA Ealayohi ‡ [Each party of them cast from him, to the other, the league, or covenant, by which they had made a truce; i. e., each party of them rejected it, or renounced it, to the other]: (T:) and nabaca UilaI AlEaduw-i, and nAbchu↓, ‡ He cast from him the league, or covenant, to the enemy, and dissolved it: and tanaAbacuwA↓ ‡ They mutually cast from themselves the league, or covenant, and dissolved it. (A.) See also 3.
nabaca OamoriI waraMCi Zahorihi ‡ [lit., He cast my affair behind his back; meaning,] he did not perform my affair; (A;) he neglected it. (Mṣb.)
nabacato fulaAnapu qawolFA maliyHFA ‡ Such a woman threw out a goodly, beautiful, or pretty, saying. (A.)
nabacotu Uiloyhi Als-alaAma, and Alt-aHiy-apa, ‡ I threw to him the salutation. (A.)

nubicotu bikacaA ‡ [I had such a thing as it were thrown to me; I had it thrown in my way;] I had it offered, or presented, to me, the meeting with it being appointed, or prepared; as also rumiytu bihi. (A.)
lil-ehi Oum-N nabacato bika ‡ [To God (be attributed the excellence of) the mother that brought thee forth!] (A.)
nabaca He threw forth earth or dust [in digging a hole, &c.]; as also nabava. (A.) See also nabiycapN.

nabaca He threw dates or raisins into a bag or skin, and poured water upon them, and left the liquor until it fermented and became intoxicating: (T:) [or, simply, he steeped dates or raisins in water; for the beverage thus made, called nabayc, was not always left until it became intoxicating, as is shown by several trads.]

nabaca nabiycFA, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, &c.,) the most usual form of the verb, (Ḳz,) aor. _i {yanobicu}, only; (MF;) and nb-chu↓, (A, L, Ḳ,) and Anbchu↓, (L, Ḳ,) a form used by the vulgar, (Ṣ, IDrst,) and rejected by Th and others, but mentioned, on the authority of Er-Ruásee, by Fr, who says that he had not heard it from the Arabs, but that the authority of its transmitter is worthy of reliance, (TA,) and Antbchu↓; (L, Ḳ;) ‡ He made beverage of the kind called nabiyc. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)

Also, nabaca tamorFA, (Lḥ, IAth, L,) and EinabFA, (IAth, L,) and Anbchu↓, but this is seldom used, (Kutr, Lḥ, ISk, and others, and L,) and Antbchu↓, (L,) ‡ He made, of the dates, and of the grapes, beverage of the kind called nabiyc; (Lḥ, L;) he left the dates, and the grapes, in water, that it might become beverage of the kind so called. (IAth, L.)
Also, Antbc↓ ‡ He made for himself that beverage. (A.)
fulaAnN yanobicu EalaI-a ‡ Such a one boils against me like [the beverage called] nabiyc. (A.)
nabaca, [aor. _i {yanobicu},] (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. nabocN (L, Ḳ) and nabacaAnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It (a vein) pulsed; (L, Ḳ;) a dial. form of nabaDa. (Ṣ, L.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

3. nAbchu, inf. n. munaAbacapN, He bargained with him by saying, Throw thou to me the garment, or piece of cloth, (AʼObeyd, L, Ḳ,) or other article of merchandise, (AʼObeyd, L,) or I will throw it to thee, and the sale shall become binding, or settled, or concluded, for such a sum: (A' Obeyd, L, Ḳ:) or, by throwing to another a garment, or piece of cloth, the other doing the like: (Lḥ, L, Ḳ:) or, by saying, When thou throwest thy commodity, or when I throw my commodity, the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded, for such a sum: (Mṣb:) or, by saying, When I throw it to thee, or when thou throwest it to me, the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded: (Mgh, art. lms:) or, by saying, When I throw the pebble (L, Ḳ) to thee, (L,) the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded: (L, Ḳ:) or by another's throwing a pebble to him: (L:) bayoEu AlmunaAbacapi and bayoEu AlHaSaApi and bayoEu UiloqaMCi AlHajari signify the same; (Mgh;) as also bayoEu AlUiloqaMCi: (A:) such bargaining is forbidden. (L.)

naAbacahumu AlHaroba, and nabaca↓ Uilayohimu AlHaroba, He retired from them to a place aside, or apart, in war, for a just purpose, (liloHaq-i, in the ʼEyn for war, liloHarobi, TT,) they doing the like: (Lth, T, L:) or these two phrases, followed by EalaI sawaMCK, are used when there is between two parties at variance a covenant, or league, or a truce, after fighting, and they desire to dissolve the league, or covenant, and each party casts it from him (yanobicuhu) to the other: thus, faQnobico Uilayohimo EalaI sawaMCK, in the Ḳur, [viii. 60, lit., cast thou from thee, to them, their league, or covenant, in an equitable, or just, manner,] means, announce thou to them that thou hast dissolved the league between thee and them, so that they may have equal knowledge with thee of the dissolving thereof and of the returning to war: (T, L:)
ElI swAC here signifies ElI AlHaq-i waAlEadoli: (Lḥ:) naAbacahu AlHaroba also signifies he made war with him openly; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb;) and is syn. with nabaca Uilayohi AlHaroba: (L:) and naAbacuwhumo EalaI sawaMCK they made war with them openly, in an equitable manner, declaring their hostile intention, so that it was equally known to their enemies and themselves. (L.) See also 1.
naAbacotuhumo ‡ I acted contrarily to, or differently from, or adversely to, them; or was, or became, contrary to, or different from, or adverse to, them; syn. xaAlafotuhumo. (Mṣb.)
4: see 1.
6: see 1.
8. Antbc ‡ He went, withdrew, or retired, aside, or apart, from others; separated himself from others. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
Antbct makaAnFA (Ḳur, xix. 16,) ‡ She withdrew, or retired, to a place apart from her family, (L, Mṣb,) far away. (Mṣb.)
Ainotabaca Eano qawomihi He withdrew, or retired, from his people. (M.)
Aintbc naAHiyapF He went aside. (T.) See 1.
And see Ainotabava in art. nbv.

nabocN ‡ A little; a small quantity; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) mina AlmaAli of wealth, or property; (Ṣ, A, L;) as also nubocapN↓ [which is a word much used though I find it explained in few lexicons]; (L, TA;) because what is little is thrown away, and disregarded: (A:) and in like manner, of herbage, and of rain, and of hoariness or hoary hair, (Ṣ, A, L,), &c.: (L:) and a small number of men: (A, L:) and the latter word, a piece, or portion, of a thing, such as a perfume: (L:) pl. of the former, OanobaAcN: (L, Ḳ:) [and of the latter, nubacN.]
OanobaAcN mina Aln-aAsi (Ḳ,* TA) ‡ The refuse of the people; (TA;) mixed people of the baser sort. (Ḳ, TA.)
bayonanaA wabayona baniI fulaAnK nabocapN: see jacobapN.
jalasa nabocapF, and nubocapF↓, ‡ He sat aside, or apart. (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
nubocapN: see nabocN:
and nabocapN.
nabiycN Cast, thrown, or flung, [&c.; see 1;] (Ḳ;) i. q. manobuwcN. (L.) But see below.
nabiycapN↓ The earth or dust that is thrown forth from a hole or the like that is dug; as also nabiyvapN: pl. nabaAYicN. (A,* L.) Yaạḳoob asserts, that the c is a substitute for v. (L.)

nabiycN ‡ A kind of beverage, made of dates, and of raisins; i. e., must; and of honey; i. e., mead; and of wheat, and of barley, &c.; i. e. wort: (L:) or made of dates, or of raisins, which one throws (yanobicu, i. e. yaToraH, whence its appellation,) into a vessel or skin of water, and leaves until it ferments (yafuwr, T, L, or yagoliI, Mgh) and becomes intoxicating, or not so long as to become intoxicating: before it has become so, it is a lawful beverage: (T, L:) whether intoxicating or not, it is thus called: (L:) or it is thus called because it is left (yunobacu, i. e., yutoraku,) until it becomes strong; (Mṣb;) being expressed juice, or the like, that is left (nubica) [for a time to acquire strength]: (L, Ḳ:) it is said that this word is originally of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, but that it has become obsolete in this latter sense, and, applied to the beverage, is used as though it were a primitive substantive, as is shown by the form of its pl., (M, F,) which is OanobicapN; (Ṣ, L, MF;) for a word of the measure fEyl in the sense of the measure mfEwl has not this form of pl.: (MF:) wine expressed from grapes is also called nabiycN, like as nbyc is also called xamorN: [nabiycN is a coll. gen. n., and its n. un. is with p:] nabiycapN signifies some nabiyc; lit., a portion thereof. (Mṣb, art. xmr.) See also mizorN. (L.)
nabiycapN: see nabiycF, and manobuwcN.

hom.sense: nab-aAcN [One who throws things away often, or quickly]. See Oax-aAcN.
nab-aAcN [One who makes, or sells, the beverage called nabyc]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. skr.)

entry.sense: minobacapN A pillow, or cushion; (Lḥ, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) upon which one reclines, or sits: so called because it is thrown upon the ground to be sat upon: (L:) pl. manaAbicu. (A.) Ex. tarab-aEuwA EalaI AlmanaAbici [They sat cross-legged upon the pillows, or cushions]. (A.)

manobuwcN A child cast out by its mother (T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) in the road, (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) on the occasion of her bringing it forth, and which a Muslim picks up and maintains; whether a bastard or lawfully begotten; (T, L;) a foundling: (L, Ḳ:) such may not be called a bastard because its kin may be established: (T, L:) also, † a bastard; (L, Ḳ;) because such is cast away in the road: (L:) fem. manobuwcapN (L) and nabiycapN↓: (A, L:) pl. masc. manobuwcuwna and manaAbicapN; (L;) and pl: of nbycp, nabaAYicu. (A.)
manobuwcapN and nabiycapN↓ † A ewe or other animal (L) that is not eaten, by reason of its leanness: (L, Ḳ:) so called because it is cast away. (L.)

Sal-aI EalaI qabori manobuwcK He (Moḥammad) prayed upon the tomb of a foundling: or, accord. to another reading ElI qaborK manobuwcK, meaning, upon a tomb apart, (L,) or distant, (Ḳ,) from other tombs; (L, Ḳ;) like an expression occurring in another trad., mar-a biqaborK munotabicK↓ he passed by a tomb apart from other tombs. (L.)
hwa munotabicu Ald-aAri ‡ He is far from his house. (A.)
munotabicN and mutanab-icN↓ [A man, &c.,] aside, or apart, or separate, from others; (L;) [See also manobuwdN: and see a verse of Lebeed, voce OaSolN.]
mutanab-icN: see munotabicN.

1. nabara, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanobiru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naborN, (Ṣ,) He, (a man, Ṣ, A,) or it, (anything, T,) raised, or elevated, a thing: (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or naborN signifies specially the raising of the voice: (MF, from the first part of the Keshsháf:) or the rising of the voice; so with the Arabs; and one says nabara Alr-ajulu, inf. n. naborapN, meaning, the man spoke in a high tone: (IAmb:) and nabara, inf. n. naborapN, he (a man) uttered a sound: (A:) and [the inf. n.] naborapN, signifies the crying out, or shouting, from fright, or fear: (T, Ḳ:) and naborapu Almugan-iI, the singer's raising his voice from a low to a high pitch. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nabara AlHarofa, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanobiru}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. naborN, (Ṣ, M,) He pronounced the letter with hemz (hamoz). (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.) qurayoXN laA tanobiru [The tribe of Kureysh] do not pronounce with hemz. (Ṣ.) A man said to the Prophet, yaA nabiIoCa Qll-ehi [O Prophet of God]; and he said laA tanobiro yiQsomiI, i. e. Pronounce not thou my name with hemz: (M:) for the tribe of Kureysh did not pronounce with hemz. (TA.) And when El-Mahdee performed the pilgrimage, he preferred El-Kisáee to recite the prayers in El-Medeeneh, and the people of that city disapproved of his pronouncing with hemz, asking him wherefore he did so in reciting the Ḳur-án in the mosque of the Apostle of God. (TA.)
8. Antbr It (a heap of wheat) rose, by additions. (T.)
It (the body, M, Ḳ, and a wound, T, A) swelled; became swollen. (T, M, A, Ḳ.)
It (the mouth, TA,) became blistered, or vesicated. (Ḳ, TA.) And Antbrt yaduhu His arm, or hand, became blistered. (Ṣ, A.)
He (the Oamiyr, M, and the xaTiyb, Ḳ) ascended the minobar [or pulpit]. (M, Ḳ.)

niborN sing. of OanobaArN, (T, Ṣ,) which signifies Heaps, syn. OakodaAsN, (M, Ḳ,) or a collection, (M, Ṣ,) of TaEaAm, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, MṢ,) meaning of wheat, and of barley, [or other corn,] and of dates: (MṢ:) or [in the TA, and] granaries (OahoraMC) of TaEaAm: [in the present day, a granary:] what is called huroIN being also called niborN because the TEAm, when poured in its place, rises: and the pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of AnbAr] is OanaAbiyru. (T.)

OanobaArN also signifies A merchant's magazine, or chamber, (bayot,) in which he puts together, in order, or piles up, his goods. (M, Ḳ.) [In the Ḳ, it is added, that the sing. is niborN: but this addition seems to be misplaced: for AnbAr in the last of the senses here explained, as well as when applied to a granary. and to a collection of TEAm, appears to be a pl. without a sing.]
naborapN Anything rising from a thing. (M, A, Ḳ.)
A swelling in the body. (M, Ḳ.)
I. q. hamozapN [meaning the sound, or the character, so called]. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
minobarN The pulpit of the xaATib [in a mosque]: (M, TA:) so called because of its height: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) [pl. manaAbiru.]
munab-arN: see manobuwrN.
manobuwrN Pronounced with hemz (hamoz). (T.) qaSaAYidu manobuwrapN, and munab-arapN↓, i. q. mahomuwzapN [i. e. Poems of which the verses end with hemz].

1. nabazahu, aor. _i {yanobizu}, inf. n. nabozN, He called him, or named him, by a by-name, surname, or nickname; he by-named him, surnamed him, or nicknamed him; syn. laq-abahu; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) mostly signifying he called him, or named him, by a nickname, a name of reproach, or an opprobrious appellation; (TA;) as also nb-zhu↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects: you say, fulaAnN yunab-izu↓ biAlS-aboyaAni Such a one by-names, surnames, or [rather] nicknames, the children; syn. yulaq-ibohumo. (Ṣ.)
Aln-abozu is also syn. with All-amozu; (Ḳ;) or is like the latter: (TA;) [i. e., nabazahu also signifies He upbraided, or reproached, him; or the like.]
2: see 1, in two places.

6. tnAbzwA, (Mṣb, Ḳ,*) or tnAbzwA biQloOaloqaAbi, (Ṣ,) They called one another by by-names, surnames, or [rather] nicknames: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or they upbraided, reproached, or reviled, one another; (Ḳ, TA;) calling one another by names of reproach. (TA.) So in the Ḳur, xlix. 11; where the doing so is forbidden. (TA.)

nabazN, [or, accord. to the Mṣb, it seems to be nabozN, for it is there said to be an inf. n. used as a subst., but this form I have never met with elsewhere,] A by-name; or surname; or nickname; syn. laqabN; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) mostly, the latter; i. e., a name of reproach; an opprobrious appellation: (TA:) but Kh, [makes it, contr. to common usage, to signify a proper name; for he] says, that names are of two kinds; OasomaMCu nabazK, such as zayodN and Eamoruw; and OasomaMCu EaAm-K, such as farasN and rajulN and the like: (TA:) pl. OanobaAzN. (Ṣ.)
nabizN Ignoble, or mean, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) in his grounds of pretension to respect, or his rank or quality, and in his natural disposition. (Ḳ.)
rajulN nubazapN A man who is much accustomed to call others by by-names, surnames, or [rather] nicknames. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. nabaXa, aor. _u {yanobuXu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. naboXN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) He took, drew, or pulled, out, or forth, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a thing, (Mṣb, TA,) [as] a leguminous plant, (Ṣ,) or a thing buried, (Mgh,) or a thing after burial, (TA,) [as] a corpse; (Ṣ, TA;) whence nab-aAXN, q. v.: (Ṣ, Mgh:) he made a thing that was concealed or covered to come out or forth, or to become apparent. (A, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] huwa yanobuXu liEiyaAlihi, (A, TA,) inf, n. as above, (Ḳ, TA,) ‡ He draws forth sustenance hence and thence for his family, or household: (A:) or ‡ he gains, or earns, or seeks sustenance, for them. (Ḳ,* TA.)

And huwa yanobuXu AlOasoraAra, (A, TA,) and AlHadiyva, inf. n. as above, (Ḳ, TA,) ‡ He draws forth, or elicits, secrets, and discourse, narration, or information: (Ḳ,* TA:) or nabaXotu Als-ir-a signifies † I divulged the secret. (Mṣb.)
And UinotabaXa↓ AlEuruwqa ‡ He drew forth, or extracted, the veins. (A.)
Also, He removed, a thing from over another thing which it covered or concealed; (A, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) and earth from a thing beneath it: (A, Mṣb:*) whence nab-aAXN, q. v. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And hence, nabaXa Alqabora [He uncovered, or he rifled, or ransacked, the grave]. (A, Mgh, Mṣb.)
Also, He dug with the hand; as also nabava. (AZ, in Ṣ, art. nbv.)

entry.sense: 5. huwa yatanab-aXu Eani AlOasoraAri [app. † He endeavours to draw forth or elicit, or he searches out, secrets]. (TA.)
8: see 1.
nibaAXapN The trade, or occupation, of the nab-aAX. (TA.)
[nabiyXapN Earth extracted from a well or burrow or the like. Hence,] nabiyXapu AlyarobuwEi [The earth extracted by the jerboa in making its burrow]. (T in art. dm.)
nab-aAXN One who rifles, or ransacks, graves; who takes forth the dead from them; or who uncovers graves. (Mgh, Mṣb.) See 1, in two places.

OanobuwXN A thing that is taken, drawn, or pulled, out, or forth: (Lḥ:) the lower part of leguminous plants taken, drawn, or pulled, out, or forth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or trees pulled out by the trunk and roots: (Ḳ:) as also OunobuwXapN↓: (TA:) or ↓both signify what is torn out by the rain: (AHeyth:) pl. OanaAbiyXu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the pl. of both the above words. (AHeyth.)
Also, Full-grown unripe dates that are pierced with thorns in order that they may ripen. (TA.)
And the pl. signifies Small arrows. (Ṣgh.) Some say that this pl. has no singular. (MF.)
OunobuwXapN: see OunobuwXN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. nabaDa, aor. _i {yanobiDu}, inf. n. naboDN and nabaDaAnN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and nabiyDN, (so in a copy of the Ṣ,) It (a vein, or an artery,) pulsed, or beat, (TA,) [or throbbed;] was, or became, in a state of motion, or agitation. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] mA nabaDa lahu Eiroqu EaSabiy-apK ‡ [No party-spirit, or zeal in the cause of his party, became roused, or excited, in him;] he did not aid his people, or party, against oppression; was not angry, or zealous, for them, and did not defend them. (A, TA.)
And nabaDa naAbiDuhu↓ ‡ His anger became roused, or excited. (A, TA.)
[Hence also,] nabaDati AlOamoEaMCu, aor. as above, [in the L, written _u, but this is doubtless a mistake,] † The bowels became in a state of commotion. (TA.)
And nabaDa Albaroqu † The lightning flashed lightly, or slightly, (Ḳ, TA,) like the naboD of a vein or an artery. (TA.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2: see 4, in two places.
4. OanobaDati AlHum-aI Eiroqahu The fever made his vein, or artery, to pulse, beat, (TA,) [throb,] or become in a state of motion or agitation. (A, TA.*)

AnbD Alqawosa, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh,) like OanoDabahaA, (Lth, T, M,) but the former is the more approved; (Lth, ʼEyn;) and AnbD EanohaA; (A, Mgh;) or AnbD fiyhaA; (AḤn, Ḳ;) and nb-D↓ fyhA, inf. n. tanobyDN; (AḤn, TA;) in the Ḳ, nabaDa↓ fiyhaA, which is a mistake; (TA;) [He twanged the bow;] he made the bow to give a sound: (AḤn, Ḳ:) or he put the string of the bow in motion, [or made it to vibrate,] (A, Ḳ,) or pulled it, (T, Ṣ, M, Mgh,) and then let it go, (Ṣ, Mgh,) in order that it might twang, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or produce a sound: (T, M, Mgh:) and AnbD biAlowatari (Ṣ, A, Mgh) signifies the same: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or he took the string of the bow with the ends of his two fingers, and then let it go so that it might fall against the handle of the bow: (Jm:) and AnbD Alwatara he pulled the string of the bow without an arrow, and then let it go: (Yaạḳoob:) or he pulled the string of the bow, and then let it go so that he heard it give a sound. (Lḥ.) Hence the proverb, UinobaADu bigayori tawotiyri, (Ṣ,) or mino Eayori tawotiyrK, (A,) [Twanging the bow without fastening, or binding, or bracing, the string; meaning ‡ threatening without the means of execution]: applied to him who pretends to that which he has not the means of performing. (A, TA.) [See also art. wtr.] And a poet says,
laOaromiyan-aka ramoyFA gayora tanobiyDi↓
[I will assuredly shoot thee with a shooting, not a mere twanging]: meaning, my pulling [of the bow] shall not be a threatening, but execution. (TA.)
You say also, OanobaDa Aln-ad-aAfu minobaDatahu [The separater and loosener of cotton by means of the bow and mallet made his mallet to cause the string of the bow to vibrate]. (A, TA.)
naboDN [an inf. n. used as a subst., signifying The pulse].
Also, A pulsing vein, or artery: as in the saying jas-a AlT-abiybu naboDahu [The physician felt his pulsing vein, or artery: or his pulse]: but it is more chaste to say manobiDahu↓ q. v. (TA.)
See also nabaDN.

[It is also used as an epithet. You say,] fuWaAdN naboDN, as also nabaDN↓, and nabiDN↓, (Ṣgh Ḳ,) and nabiyDN↓, (A, TA,) ‡ A heart that is sharp in intellect, clever, acute, (A, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) and very brisk or lively or sprightly or prompt. (A, TA.)

maA bihi HabaDN walaA nabaDN, (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and HaboDN wlA naboDN↓, (Ṣgh,) There is not in him any motion: (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or sound, or voice, nor pulsation: (AA, in Ṣ, art. HbD:) or strength: (IDrd:) with fet-ḥ to the second letter, only used in a negative phrase: (L:) Aṣ says, I know not what is AlHabaDu, (Ṣ in art. HbD,) or AlHaboDu. (TA.)
fuWaAdN nabaDN: see naboDN.
nabiDN: see naboDN.
naboDapN [A single pulsation]. You say, raOayotu wamoDapa baroqK kanaboDapi EiroqK [I saw a slight flash of lightning, like a single pulsation of an artery]. (A, TA.)
nabiyDN: see naboDN.

naAbiDN [part. n. of 1]. You say, maA daAma fiI-a EurayoqN naAbiDN lamo Oaxoculoka [As long as there remains in me a little artery pulsing, I will not abstain, or hold back, from aiding thee]; i. e., ‡ as long as I remain alive. (A, TA.)
[Hence,] ‡ Anger. (Lth, A, Ḳ.) See 1, where an ex. is given.
† An archer: lit. one who has a twanging. (Mgh.)

manobiDu Alqalobi The place where one sees the heart pulsing, (TA,) or in motion; (A, Ḳ;) and where one perceives the gentle sound of its [pulsation, or] motion. (A, O.) You say, jas-a AlT-abiybu manobiDahu [The physician felt his place of pulsation], and manaAbiDahumo [their places of pulsation]. (A, TA.)
maA yuEorafu lahu manobiDu EasalapK means ‡ He has no origin [known]; like maDoribu EasalapK; (A, TA;) nor any people [to whom he belongs]. (TA.)
wajaEN munobiDN [A pain causing pulsation, or throbbing]. (L, TA.)

minobaDN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or minobaDapN↓, (A,) The wooden mallet with which one separates and loosens cotton by striking with it the string of a bow; syn. minodafN, like miHobaDN; (Ṣ;) or minodafapN: (A, Ḳ:) manaAbiDu is said by Kh to occur in poetry as [its pl.,] meaning manaAdifu. (Ṣ.)
minobaDapN: see what next precedes.

hom.sense: 1. nabaTa, aor. _u {yanobuTu} and _i {yanobiTu}, inf. n. nubuwTN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naboTN, (Ḳ,) It (water) welled, or issued forth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

hom.sense: 4. AnbT He (a digger) reached the water: (AA, Ṣ:) or reached the first that appeared of the water of a well, (Ḳ, TA,) and produced it, or fetched it out, by his labour. (TA.) And AnbT fiI EaDoraMCa He produced, or fetched out, by labour, water from good clay, or from clay containing no sand. (TA.)

[It is also trans.: you say,] AnbT Alr-akiy-apa; and AstnbThA↓; (M, Ḳ;) and nb-ThA↓; (IAạr, M, TA;) in the Ḳ tnb-ThA↓; (TA;) and nabaTahaA↓, (M, Ḳ [in the CK with teshdeed to the b]) aor. _i {yanobiTu}, (TA,) inf. n. naboTN; (M;) He produced, or fetched out, by his labour [in digging], the water of the well; syn. OamaAhahaA; (M, Ḳ;) and of the first, (TA,) and last, (TA,) [or rather of all,] Astxrj maMCahaA. (Ḳ, TA.) And AnbT AlmaMCa, inf. n. UinobaATN; and AstnbThu↓; He (a digger [of a well]) produced, or fetched out, by his labour, or work, the water. (Mṣb.)
See also 10, in five places.
UinobaATN also signifies The producing an effect, or making an impression; syn. taOvyrN. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
5: see 4:
and 10.

tnb-T also signifies He affected to be like, or imitated, the nabaT [or Nabathæans]: or he asserted himself to be related to them. (Ḳ, TA.) [Compare 10, in the last of the senses assigned to it below.]
10. AstnbT: see 4, in two places: its primary signification is [that mentioned above,] from nabaTN signifying the “water that comes forth from a well when it is first dug.” (Zj.)

And hence, (Zj,) He drew out, or forth; extracted; educed; produced; elicited; fetched out by labour or art; got out; or extorted; syn. Asotaxoraja; (Zj, Ṣ;) a thing: (Zj:) and † He made anything to appear after occultation; as also AnbT↓; (B;) [i. e. he brought it to light:] and AusotunobiTa † it (anything) was made apparent, after occultation; as also OunobiTa↓: (Ḳ:) or the latter, [simply,] † it was made apparent. (L.) And [hence] ‡ He (a lawyer) elicited (Astxrj) an occult, or esoteric, doctrine of law, by his intelligence, and his labour, or study: (Ḳ, TA:) or you say AstnbThu, meaning † he elicited it (Astxrjhu), namely a judicial sentence, by labour, or study; as also AnbThu↓, inf. n. UinobaATN: (Mṣb:) or † he searched out the knowledge of it. (Jel. iv. 85.) And AstnbT minohu EilomFA, and xayorFA, and maAlFA, ‡ He drew forth, elicited, or extorted, (Astxrj,) from him knowledge, and good, or wealth, and property. (TA.) And nibaATN↓ [app. an inf. n. of naAbaTa] signifies the same as UisotinobaAT HadiytK † The drawing forth, or eliciting, (UisotaxoraAj) of discourse. (TA.) And tnb-T↓ AlkalaAma, accord. to the Ḳ, or, accord. to Ṣgh, on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád, AntbThu↓, (TA,) † He drew forth, or elicited, (Astxrj,) speech. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ.) And AnbT↓ AlEiloma ‡ He revealed knowledge, and spread it among men. (TA.)
AstnbT Alfarasa † He sought to obtain offspring from the mare: occurring in a trad.: but accord. to one relation, it is UisotaboTanahaA, meaning, “he sought what was in her belly.” (TA.)

He (a man) became a [naturalized] nabaTiI- [or Nabathæan]. (Ṣ,* TA.) It is said by Eiyoob Ibn-El-Kirreeyeh, Oaholu EumaAna EarabN QsotanobaTuwA waOaholu AlbaHorayoni nabiyTN QsotaEorabuwA [The people of 'Omán are Arabs who became naturalized Nabathæans, and the people of El-Bahreyn are Nabathæans who became naturalized Arabs]. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also 5.]

nabaTN What first appears of the water of a well (IDrd, Ḳ) when it is dug; (IDrd;) as also nuboTapN↓: (Ḳ:) or the water that comes forth from a well when it is first dug: (Zj:) or the water that issues forth from the bottom of a well when it is dug; (Ṣ, accord. to one copy;) or this is termed nabiyTN↓: (Ṣ, accord. to another copy; and TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OanobaATN and [of mult.] nubuwTN. (TA.)

[Hence the saying,] fulaAnN qariybu Alv-araI baEiydu Aln-abaTi † Such a one's promising is near, [but] his fulfilling is remote: i. e. he promises, but does not fulfil. (IAạr.) And flAn laA yudoraku nabaTuhu, (TA,) and laA yudoraku lahu nabaTN, (ISd, TA,) ‡ Such a one's depth is not known, (Ḳ,* TA,) and the extent of his knowledge: (TA:) or such a one's depth is not known; meaning that he is cunning, or possessing intelligence mixed with craft and forecast. (ISd, TA.) And fulaAnN laA yunaAlu nabaTuhu † Such a one is invincible, and inaccessible to his enemy. (TA.)
nabaTN also signifies A well of which the water has been produced, or fetched out, by labour [of the digger]. (Ṣ, TA.)
And What oozes, or exudes, from a mountain, as though it were sweat, coming forth from the sides of the rock. (TA.)

Aln-abaTu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Aln-abiyTu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AlOanobaATu, (Ḳ,) the last is a pl. (AAF, Ṣ, Mṣb) of the first, (AAF,) and the second is [a quasi-pl. n.] like kaliybN, (AAF, L,) [The Nabathæans;] a people who alight and abide in the baTaAYiH [see OaboTaHu] between the two 'Iráks: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a people (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb) who alight and abide, (T, TA,) or who used to alight and abide, (Mṣb,) in the sawaAd (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb) of El-'Irák: (M, Mgh, Mṣb:) afterwards applied to mixed people; or people of the lowest or basest or meanest sort; or the refuse of men; and the vulgar sort thereof: (Mṣb:)
the people to whom these appellations properly apply were called nabaT because of their fetching out by labour (liQsotinobaATihimo) what comes forth from the lands: (TA:) [for they were distinguished for agriculture; and hence their proper appellations are used as equivalent to “clowns,” or “boors:” but a derivation commonly obtaining with us is that from Nebaioth the son of Ishmael:] the n. un. is nubaATiI-N↓, (Yaạḳoob, IAạr, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and nabaATiI-N↓, (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like yamaAniI-N, (Ṣ,) and nibaATiI-N↓, (Ḳ,) and nabaATK↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like yamaAnK, (Ṣ,) and nabaTiI-N↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like yamaniI-N, (Ṣ,) but this is disallowed by IAạr, (Mgh, TA,) and, accord. to Lth, nabaTaAniI-N↓, but this [also] is disallowed by IAạr. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: nuboTapN: see nabaTN.
nabaTiI-N: see nabaTN.
nabaTaAniI-N: see nabaTN.
nabaATN: see nabaTN.
nabiyTN and Aln-abiyTN: see nabaTN.
nabaATiI-N and nubaATiI-N and nibaATiI-N: see nabaTN.

nabahorajN i. q. bahorajN, q. v. (TA). [The place in which it is mentioned in the Ḳ shows that F regards the n as a radical letter; and though it is said in the TA that its being so is doubtful, he is right accord. to those who hold that every letter of an arabicized word is to be regarded as a radical if it, or a letter for which it is substituted, is found in the original.]
1. nat-a, [aor. _i {yanotitu},] inf. n. naviytN, i. q. kat-, inf. n. katiytN; (Ḳ;) and nafata, inf. n. nafiytN: (L, Ḳ:) [It (a cooking-pot) boiled:, &c.]
nat-a manoxiruhu gaDabFA His nostril became inflated, or swollen, by reason of anger. (Ḳ.)
2. nt-t He explained news, tidings, or a report. (Ḳ.)
5: See R. Q. 1.
R. Q. 1. natonata (in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ tanat-ata↓, [and so in the CK,] but the former is the more correct, TA) He (a man, L) became dirty (tqc-r) after having been clean. (IAạr, L, Ḳ.)
nut-apN A small hollow, or cavity, in [stones of the kind called] SafowaAnN, (Ḳ,) in which the rain-water collects. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. nataOa, aor. _a {yanotaOu}, inf. n. natoCN and nutuwoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It swelled; swelled up; rose; grew up. (Ḳ.) Said of a plant, &c. (Ṣ.)
nataOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nutuwoCN, (TA,) It protruded, or projected, from its place, without becoming separated. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nataOa It (an ulcer, or a wound,) swelled. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It (a girl's breast) swelled forth, or became prominent, or protuberant. (TA.)
nataOato She (a girl) grew up, (Ṣ,) and became marriageable. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nataOa Ealayohimo, inf. n. natoCN, He rose, or exalted himself, above them. (TA.)
[You say,] taHoqiruhu wayanotaOu Thou despisest him, and he riseth, or exalteth himself: (Ṣ:) or
he emulateth thee: or

he becometh great. A proverb, said of him who does not manifest his character or design by outward appearance, but keeps it secret: or of him who advances and exalts himself by his cunning, while thou thinkest him senseless, or negligent. Accord. to some, it is tHqrh wyanotuw, without C: see art. ntw. (TA.)
nataOa He went up from the country or land to another. (TA.)
tanaOa Ealayohimo He came upon them; syn. UiT-alaEa. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. AnttO He rose, or exalted himself. (Ḳ.)
AnttO lahu He encountered him; met him; opposed himself to him. (Ḳ, TA: the verb is explained in the Ḳ by UinobaraI.)
1. nataba, aor. _u {yanotubu}, inf. n. nutuwbN, It swelled forth; became prominent, or protuberant. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Said of a girl's breast. (Ṣ.)

1. nataja, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yanotuju}, (as in the L, [but I believe this to be a mistake,]) or _i, (accord. to the Mṣb, MṢ, MF,) inf. n. natojN; (Ṣ;) and Antj↓; (A;) He assisted a she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) [and a mare, see nutijato,] and a ewe or she-goat (Mṣb) [or other quadruped], in bringing forth; delivered her of her young one; acting to her as a midwife does to a woman. (T, Mṣb, &c.) The original form of expression is natajahaA waladFA He assisted her in bringing forth a young one; delivered her of a young one. (Mṣb.) El-Kumeyt has used the form Ainotataja↓ in the sense of nataja: but it is not commonly current in Arabic. (TA.) AḤn mentions the saying UicaA naMCati Aljabohapu nat-aju↓ Aln-aAsu wawal-aduwA waQjotuniIa Oaw-alu AlkamoOapi [When El-Jebhah (the tenth of the Mansions of the Moon) sets antiheliacally, (for the setting, not the rising, is here meant, and this it did, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, on the 11th of February,) the people assist their beasts, much, or frequently, in bringing forth, and deliver them, and the first of the truffles are gathered]. Thus he relates the saying, with teshdeed to the v of ntj, to denote frequency of the act. (L.)

nutijato, pass. in form, [but neut. in signification,] inf. n. nitaAjN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and tanojN; (TA;) and Ounotijato↓, (Ḳ,) also pass. in form; and some say natajato, but this is rare, and not heard by IAạr; (TA;) and some, also, say Oanotajato↓, (Lth, Kr,) but Az holds this to be a mistake; (TA;) She (a camel, IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c., and a mare, IAạr, and a sheep or goat or other quadruped, Mṣb) brought forth: (T, Mṣb, TA:) or one does not say nutijati AlX-aApu unless a man assist at the bringing forth. (Lth.) Thus one suppresses the objective complement of the verb. And one also says tunijati Aln-aAqapu waladFA The she-camel brought forth a young one: and in like manner one says of a ewe or a she-goat: and sometimes, with the same meaning, natajati AlnAqp wldA, in the act. form. (Mṣb.) One also says tanaAtajati↓ AlUibilu The camels brought forth. (A.) [You say,] nataja Alqawomu, (Lth,) and Oanotaja↓, (L,) The people's camels or sheep or goats brought forth: (Lth, L:) or OanotajuwA↓ they had pregnant camels bringing forth. (Ḳ.) One may also say nutija Alwaladu, meaning The young one of a she-camel, &c., [see nutijato, above,] was brought forth, or born. (Mṣb.) See 4.
[Hence,] Alr-iyHu tunotiju Als-aHaAba ‡ [The wind assists the clouds in the discharging of their rain; i. e., draws forth the rain from the clouds.] (A, L.)
[nutija It was produced, it resulted, or was a natural consequence.]
2: see 1.

4. Oanotajato She (a camel, Ṣ, and a mare, Ṣ, Ḳ, or other solid-hoofed animal, Mṣb,) became pregnant: (T:) and so natajato↓, said of a she-camel, (Mṣb,) or other beast; but this is rare: (EsSarakustee, Mṣb:) or attained to the time of bringing forth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or became evidently pregnant: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Mṣb:) accord. to IAạr, Ounotijato, in the pass. form, signifies she (a mare, and a camel,) became near to the time of bringing forth; and he had not heard Oanotajato, in the act. form. (TA.)
See 1 and 8.

Oanotaja or Ounotija (?) ‡ It produced a thing as its fruit, or result. Ex. AlEajozu waAlt-awaAniI tazaAwajaA faOanotajaA Alfaqora Impotence and remissness combined together, and produced, as their result, poverty. (A, L.)
And hecihi Almuqad-imapu laA tunotiju taniyjapF SaAdiqapF This preamble will not produce a praiseworthy result. (A.)
5. tnt-jt She (a camel) breathed hard (tzH-rt) that her young one might come forth. (Ḳ.)
6: see 1.

8. Ainotatajato (L, Ḳ, TA: in the CK Oanotajato) She (a camel) went away at random, and brought forth in a place unknown: (Ḳ:) or she brought forth by herself, unassisted by any one; (Yaạḳoob, L;) as also Oanotajato↓. (L.)
nitaAjN: see nutijato.

[Also, an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n., like HamolN in the sense of maHomuwlN, &c., What is brought forth by a camel, &c.; and what are brought forth by camels, &c., collectively; a brood thereof; its, or their, increase, or offspring; as is plainly shown in the lexicons, &c., in many passages: for ex., see XaroxN, and difoCN: also applied, in the TA art. bTn, to the young in the belly of a mare].

natuwjN, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) a rare form of epithet from a verb of the measure OafoEala, (Kr,) and munotijN↓, (AZ, TA,) or the latter is not allowable, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and natiyjN↓, (Kr,) A she-camel, (Ṣ, Kr,) or a mare, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or other solid-hoofed animal, (Mṣb,) pregnant: (Lth:) or that has attained to the time of bringing forth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or evidently pregnant: (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or near to the time of bringing forth, and big-bellied. (AZ.)
[See also manotuwjapN.]
natiyjN: see natuwjN.
natiyjapN A young one of a she-camel, &c. [see nataja and nutijato] brought forth. (Mṣb.)

ntiyjapN † Any produce, fruit, result, or natural consequence, of a thing: (KL:) [the sum of a speech or saying: a necessary inference: the conclusion of an argument or of a syllogism: pl. nataAYiju.] You say, hecihi natiyjapN mn nataAYij karamika ‡ [This is one of the fruits, or results, of thy generosity]. (A.) [For another ex. see 4.]

humaA natiyjapN They are both of one age: said of two sheep. (Yoo, Ṣ.) ganamu fulaAnK nataAYiju The sheep, or goats, of such a one are of one age. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) hecaA Alwaladu natiyju waladiI ‡ This child is one born in the same month, or year, as my child. (A.)
naAtijN A man assisting a she-camel, &c. [see nataja] in bringing forth; delivering her; or one who assists her in bringing forth; who delivers her. (Mṣb, TA.)
manotijN The time at which a she-camel, (Ṣ,) or a mare, (Ḳ,) brings forth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. Oatati Aln-aAqapu EalaI manotijihaA The she-camel arrived at the time of her bringing forth. (Ṣ.)
munotijN: see natawjN.
qaEada munotijFA ‡ He sat accomplishing a want of nature. (A.)
minotajapN The anus; syn. AisotN; as also minovajapN. (Ḳ.)
manotuwjapN A she-camel, &c., [see nataja] assisted in bringing forth; delivered. (Mṣb, TA.)

Also, A she-camel [&c., see nutijato,] bringing forth; (T;) and so, accord. to Kr, natuwjN↓, which, he says, is the only epithet of this measure from a verb of the measure fuEila, except batuwlN: (TA:) pl. manaAtiyju: ex. nuwqN mnAtyju she-camels bringing forth. (A.)
1. nataHa, aor. _i {yanotiHu}, inf. n. natoHN, He, or it, sweated. (L.)
nataHa, aor. _i {yanotiHu}, inf. n. natoHN and nutuwHN, It (a leathern vessel, or skin,) sweated, or exuded moisture, (Ṣ, L,) as when a skin sweats with the butter that is in it. (L.)
nataHa, aor. _?, inf. n. natoHN and nutuwjN, It (sweat) exuded (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) from the skin, (L, Ḳ,) or from the roots of the hair; (T, L;) and grease, from a skin; and moisture, from the soil. (L, Ḳ.)
[And said of moisture, It percolated: see an ex. voce Eariqa.]
fulaAnN yanotiHu natiyHa AlHamiyti ‡ [Such a one sweats like a butter-skin]: said of one who is fat. (A.)
tanaHato ciforaI AlbaEiyri EaraqFA The camel's protuberance behind his ear dripped with sweat, by reason of his journeying during a vehemently hot summer-day. (L.)
nataHati AldumuwEu, inf. n. natoHN, † The tears flowed. (MF.)

nataHahu It (heat, L, Ḳ, and some other thing, L,) made him to sweat. (L, Ḳ.) [Its aor. seems to be yanotaHu; and MF thinks that, in an instance which follows, it may be written with A after the t by poetic licence.] F observes, that J has fallen into three errors with respect to AinotaAHa; [saying that AlAinotiyaAHu (in the place of which is put, in some copies of the Ṣ, AlAinotitaAHu, as is mentioned in the TA,) is like Aln-atoHu,] and citing these words of Dhu-r-Rummeh, describing a camel making his voice to reciprocate in the XiqoXiqap,
raqoXaMCu tanotaAHu All-ugaAma AlmuzobidaA
first, because the root of the present art. is sound, so that AlAntyAH has no place in it; secondly, because this word has no meaning (in this art. TA); and thirdly, because the [correct] reading is tamotaAHu, meaning “casts forth” the froth of the mouth. Neither IB nor IM has animadverted on J in this case. MF, however, observes, that one relation of a verse, &c., does not impugn the correctness of another relation that differs from it; and that perhaps the n of tntAH is a substitute for m; such substitution being frequent; [as in the case of UinotataHa;] or that the A is what is termed Oalifu UiXobaAEK, and added for the sake of the metre. (TA.)
8. AinotataHa: see AimotataHa, in art. mtH.
natoHN Sweat. (Ḳ.)
See what follows.
nutuwHN The gums of trees: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) one should not say nutuwEN, (Ṣ,) as is commonly said: (TA:) it is doubtful whether its sing. be natoHN, or of some other form. (MF.)
niHoIN nat-aAHN A butter-skin that sweats much. (A.)
minotaHapN The podex.: or the anus: syn. UisotN. (L, Ḳ.)
yanotuwHN A certain bird, (L, Ḳ,) bald-headed, found in sandy tracts. (L.)
manaAtiHu AlEaraqi The pores through which the sweat exudes. (Ṣ.)

1. nataxa, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanotixu}, (Ḳ, JK,) or _a, (L, JK,) inf. n. natoxN, (Ṣ, L,) He pulled a thing out, or up, or off; removed it from its place; displaced it. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) He extracted, or pulled out, a tooth: (Ṣ, L:) and, a thorn from his foot (Ṣ, L) with an instrument called minotaAxN, or minotaAxaAni: (L:) or he extracted in a general sense. (L.) It (a hawk, or falcon, L, Ḳ, and a vulture, L,) pulled off, or tore off, or snatched away, flesh (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) with its bill: (Ṣ, L:) and a raven, or crow, in like manner, a sore upon the back of a camel. (L.)
nutixa mino OaSoHaAbhi ‡ He was removed, or taken away, from his companions. (A.) nataxatohu Almaniy-apu mino bayona qawomihi ‡ Death removed him from among his people. (A.)
See also naxata.
minotaAxN An instrument with which thorns are extracted from the foot; syn. minoqaAXN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) minotaAxaAni the same, having two extremities. (Az, L.) See minatoAXN.

1. natara, aor. _u {yanoturu}, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. natorN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He pulled a thing, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) [as, for instance,] a garment, or piece of cloth, (A,) and his cakar, which a man is required to do three times after bawol, (Ṣ, TA,) hard, or with vehemence. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
He drew a bow vehemently: (Ḳ,* TA:) he drew the bow-string strongly; (TA;) or so that the bow nearly broke. (A.)
He rent a garment, or piece of cloth, with his fingers or with his teeth. (M, Ḳ.) And [in like manner,] natarati AlqisiI-u OawotaArahaA The bows broke their strings. (IḲṭṭ.)
He snatched a thing unawares. (Ḳ,* TḲ.)
He acted ungently, roughly, harshly, or violently, (Ḳ,* TA,) in an affair. (TA.)
natara fiI maXoyihi, (T, M,) inf. n. as above, (T,) He (a man) was as though he were pulling, in his walking: (T:) he leaned in his walking; as also Anttr↓. (M.)
