8. Anttr It became pulled (M, Ḳ) hard, or with vehemence. (M.)
See also 1, last signification.

10. Astntr mino bawolihi He pulled his cakar so as to express the remains of his bawol, in purifying himself in the manner termed UisotinojaMC; (M,* A, Ḳ,*) being earnestly desirous and careful to perform this act [fully]. (A, Ḳ.)

TaEonN natorN A thrusting, or piercing, in which extraordinary force or energy is exerted, (M, Ḳ,) as though pulling vehemently that by which the weapon passes in the person thrust, or pierced: app. an inf. n. used as an epithet: (M:) or a thrusting, or piercing, that is like a snatching unawares. (ISk, T, Ṣ.) The saying of ʼAlee, recorded in a trad., UiToEanuwA Aln-atora has been explained as meaning Thrust ye, or pierce ye, with extraordinary force or energy: and as though snatching unawares. (TA.) [See art. saEorN.] Accord. to IAạr, (T,) TaEonapN natorapN signifies A thrust that passes through. (T, Ḳ.)
natorapN A hard, or vehement, pull: (Mṣb:) pl. nataraAtN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
See natorN.
qawosN naAtirapN A bow that breaks its string, by reason of its hardness: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. nawaAtiru: (Ṣ:) or qisiI-N nawaAtiru signifies bows having the strings broken. (M.)
[munaAtarapF, in the Ḳ, I suspect to be a mistake for munaAbarapF]

1. nataXa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanotiXu}, inf. n. natoXN, (A, Ḳ,) He extracted; or drew, or pulled, out, or forth; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) a thing, (Ṣ,) or a thorn, (A, Ḳ,) and the like, (Ḳ,) and hair, (TA,) with the minotaAX: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) he plucked out hair or the like. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
He plucked, or pulled, flesh, and the like, by pinching it with his fingers, (Lth, Ḳ,) and by taking hold upon it with his teeth. (Lth, TA.)
nataXa AljaraAdu AlOaroDa, aor. and inf. n. as above, The locusts ate the herbage of the earth. (TA.)
maA nataXotu mino fulaAnK XayoYFA I did not obtain, (Ṣ,) or take, (A,) from such a one anything. (Ṣ, A.)
huwayanotiXu liEiyaAlihi, (Lḥ, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) ‡ He gains, or earns, or seeks sustenance, for his family, or house-hold. (Lḥ, Ḳ,* TA.)
huwa yanotiXu mino kul-i EilomK † He takes [or acquires] of every science. (A,* TA.)
maA OaHaca Uil-aA natoXFA He took not save a little. (TA.)

minotaAXN [A kind of tweezers;] an instrument with which one extracts, or draws or pulls out or forth, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) a thing (Ṣ,) or a thorn, (A, Ḳ,) and the like, (Ḳ,) and hair; (TA;) i. q. minoqaAXN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
1. nav-a, [aor. _i {yanovivu},] inf. n. nv-N, It (a bone) distilled, or let flow, the oily matter that was in it: (TA:) [as also mav-a].
nav-a,, aor. _i {yanovivu}, inf. n. naviyvN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nav-N; (Ṣ;) and navonava↓; (Ḳ;) It (a skin) exuded (Ṣ, Ḳ) the clarified butter that was in it: like mav-a. (TA.)
waOanota taniv-u naviyva AlHamiyti (accord. to one reading, nav-a AlHmyt, TA) And thou sweatest like the butter-skin. (Ṣ, from a trad.)

nav-a, aor. _i {yanovivu}, inf. n. naviyvN, He sweated by reason of fatness, and appeared as though he were anointed: as also mav-a: (TA:) or he sweated by reason of his bigness, and his abundance of flesh. (AʼObeyd.)
nav-a, (so in the TA,) [aor. _u {yanovuvu},] or navonava↓, (so in the Ḳ,) He wiped his hand (Ḳ) with a napkin: as also mav-a. (TA.)
nav-a, [aor. _u {yanovuvu},] He anointed a wound: as also mav-a. (TA.)

nav-a, aor. _u {yanovuvu}, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) and _i, (M, L, Ḳ,) the latter [which deviates from a constant rule] thought by MF to be a mistake, he not knowing any authority for it except the Ḳ, and disallowed by the T, (TA,) inf. n. nav-N; (Ṣ;) and nv-v↓, inf. n. tanoviyvN; (TA;) He divulged, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or spread, dispersed, disseminated, (TA,) news, tidings, or information, (Ḳ,) or what was talked of: (Ṣ, TA:) like bav-a: or he spread what should rather be concealed than spread. (TA.) [See also navaA.]
2: see 1.
R. Q. 1. navonava He sweated much. (Ḳ.)
See 1.
nav-N A wall (HaAYiT) that is moist, or damp, (Ḳ,) and flaccid. (TA.)
kalaAmN gav-N nav-N [Very bad, or corrupt speech]: nv- is here an imitative sequent to gv-. (Ḳ.)
nivaAvN Ointment with which a wound is anointed. (Ḳ.)
naviyvapN The moisture exuded by a skin, such as is called ziq-N or siqaACN. (Ḳ.)

nav-aAvN and manav-N↓ [A man who is in the habit of divulging, or spreading, dispersing, or disseminating, news, tidings, or information, or what is talked of, or what should rather be concealed]. (Th.)

naAv-N One who traduces the Muslims behind their backs, but saying of them what is true, and mentioning their vices, or faults: pl. nuv-aAvN: (AA:) [the pl. only is mentioned in the Ḳ, and explained as signifying persons who traduce others behind their backs, but saying of them what is true].
manav-N: see nav-aAvN.
minav-apN A small portion of wool with which one anoints (Ḳ) a wound. (TA.)
navita, aor. _a {yanovatu}, [inf. n. navatN,] It (flesh-meat) became changed, or altered, and stank: formed by transposition from vanita: (Ḳ:) and so a wound. (TA.)
livapN navitapN A gum that is flabby and bleeding: and in like manner XafapN, a lip: (TA:) [as also vanitapN].

1. navara, aor. _u {yanovuru}, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and _i, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. navorN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nivaArN, (M, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) He scattered a thing, sprinkled it, strewed it, dispersed it, or threw it dispersedly, (Lth, T, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) with his hand; (Lth, T;) as, for instance, grain, (Lth, T,) and fruit and the like, (Mṣb,) walnuts and almonds and sugar, (Lth, T,) and pearls, &c.; (A;) as also nv-r↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoviyrN; (TA;) [or the latter is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action; or its application to many objects: see manovuwrN.]
navarati Aln-axolapu ‡ The palm-tree [scattered or] shook off its unripe dates. (A.)
wajaOahu fanavara OamoEaMCahu ‡ [He smote him with a knife and scattered his intestines]. (M, A.)
laOanovuran-aka navora AlkariXi ‡ [I will assuredly scatter thine intestines like as one scatters the contents of the stomach of a ruminant beast]: said in threatening. (A.)

navara waladFA ‡ He (a man, M) had many children born to him. (M, Ḳ, TA.) And navarati AlmaroOapu baTonahaA, (T, A, Mgh TA,) and caA baTonihaA, (T, Mgh, TA,) and kariXahaA, (A, in art. krX,) ‡ The woman brought forth many children; (T, A, in art. krX;) scattered children; llz-awoji to the husband. (Mgh.)
natara AlkalaAma ‡ He spoke, or talked, much. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
navara qiraACatahu ‡ He hastened, or was quick, in his reading, or reciting. (A.)

navara, aor. _i {yanoviru}, inf. n. naviyrN, ‡ He (a beast of carriage, M, Ḳ, and a camel, M, and an ass, T) sneezed [app. so as to scatter the moisture in his nostrils]: (T, M, Ḳ, TA:) or did with his nose what is like sneezing: (T:) he (an ass, and a sheep or goat) sneezed, and expelled what annoyed or hurt him, from his nose: (A:) or navarato she (a ewe or goat) ejected from her nose what annoyed or hurt her. (Ṣ.) And navara, (Fr, T, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _i {yanoviru}, (T, IAth,) inf. n. navorN (T, Mgh) [and app. naviyrN, as above], ‡ He [a man] blew his nose; ejected the mucus from his nose; syn. AmotaxaTa; (IAth;) as also Astnvr↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. mxT:) and he ejected what was in his nose, of mucus, and of that which annoyed or hurt him, in performing the ablution termed wuDuwoC; (Ṣgh, TA;) as also Oanovara↓, accord. to some: (TA:) or Oanovara↓ signifies he ejected what was in his nose; or he emitted his breath from his nose; or he introduced the water into his nose; as also Antvr↓ and Astnvr↓: (Ḳ:) but this last explanation is outweighed in authority; the form Anvr↓ is disallowed by the leading lexicologists; and the author of the Ḳ, in respect of this form, follows Ṣgh, without due consideration: (TA:) [accord. to the more approved opinion,] navara signifies he scattered what was in his nose by the breath; as also Antvr↓ and Astnvr↓: (Ṣ:) or, as some of the learned say, he snuffed up water, and then ejected what was in it, of anything annoying or hurting, or of mucus; as also Astnvr↓: (IAạr, T, Mgh:) or Astnvr↓ (T, M, IAth, Ḳ) and Antvr↓, (Ḳ,) he snuffed up water, and then ejected it (T, M, IAth, Ḳ) by the breath of the nose: (T, M, Ḳ:) accord. to some, navara and Astnvr↓ signify he (a person performing wuDuwoC) snuffed up water: but others say that the latter signifies he ejected what was in his nose, of mucus, &c.; agreeably with a trad. to be cited below: (Mṣb:) IAạr says, that Astnvr↓ signifies he snuffed up water, and put in motion the navorap, or end of the nose, in purification: (T [in the Mgh, this explanation is ascribed to Fr:]) and Fr, that navara and Antvr↓ and Astnvr↓ signify he put in motion the navorap, in purification. (T.) It is said of Moḥammad, kaAna yasotanoXiqu valaAvFA fiI kul-i mar-apK yasotanoviru [He used to snuff up water three times, every time ejecting it;, &c.] and this indicates that Astnvr↓ differs from AstnXq. (T, Mgh, Mṣb.) And it is said in a trad., UicaA QsotanoXaqota faQnovuro, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and faQnoviro, with the conjunctive A, and with damm and kesr to the v, (Mṣb,) When thou snuffest up water, scatter what is in thy nose by the breath; (Ṣ;) or eject what is in thy nose, of mucus, &c.: (Mṣb:) or, as AʼObeyd relates it, faOanoviro↓; inf. n. UinovaArN: (Mṣb:) or, as he relates it UicaA tawaD-aAta faOanoviro, with the disjunctive A; and he does not explain it; but the lexicologists do not allow Oanovara↓, from AlUinovaAru; one only says, navara and Antvr↓ and Astnvr↓. (T.) No instance of Astnvr↓ used transitively has been heard, except in a trad. of El-Ḥasan Ibn-ʼAlee, Aisotanovara↓ Oanofahu [He ejected the contents of his nose; or he blew his nose]; as though the root [navara] were regarded in it, or as though it were made to import the meaning of naq-aI. (Mgh.)
2. nav-ara see 1, first signification.
3. [nAvrhu He contended with him in scattering, strewing, or dispersing, a thing or things. And hence,]
raOayotuhu yunaAviruhu Ald-ur-a [lit., I saw him contending with him in scattering pearls: meaning,] ‡ I saw him holding a disputation, or colloquy, with him, in beautiful, or elegant, language. (A.)

hom.sense: 4. Anvr as syn. with navara and Astnvr and Antvr: see 1, latter half,

Anvrhu ‡ He made his nose to bleed; syn. OaroEafahu. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, TaEanahu faOanovarahu ‡ [He pierced him and made his nose to bleed]: (Ṣ:) and Darabahu faOanovarahu [He smote him and made his nose to bleed]. (A.)

‡ He threw him down upon his navorap, (M, A, TA,) i. e., (TA,) [upon the end of his nose: or] upon his xayoXuwm. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, TaEanahu faOanovarahu Eano farasih ‡ [He pierced him and threw him down upon the end of his nose from his horse]. (M, A.*)

entry.sense: 5: see 8.
6: see 8.

hom.sense: 8. Antvr (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and ntAvr↓ (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and tnv-r↓ (M, Ḳ) It became scattered, strewn, dispersed, or thrown dispersedly: (Ṣ,* M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or the second more properly signifies it became scattered,, &c., by degrees, gradually, or part after part; resembling tasaAqaTa, &c.: and the third, being quasi-pass. of 2, denotes muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action; or its application to many things.] You say, Antvrt AlkawaAkibu † The stars became dispersed: or became scattered like grain. (TA.) And AntvrwA and tnv-rwA↓ ‡ [They (meaning men) became as though they were scattered by the hand]. (A.) [And tnAvr↓ AlX-aEaru, and Alwaraqu, † The hair, and the leaves, fell off, and became scattered, by degrees.] And tnAvr↓ Alqawomu ‡ The people fell sick and died [one after another]: (M, Ḳ:*) or you say mariDuwA fatanaAvaruwA↓ mawotFA [they fell sick and became separated by death, one after another]. (A.)
See also 1, latter half, throughout.

entry.sense: 10. Uisotanovara see 1, latter half, throughout.
navorN ‡ [Prose: so accord. to general usage: and] rhyming prose: contr. of naZomN: so called as being likened to [scattered pearls, or] scattered grain. (TA.)

hom.sense: navarN: see nuvaArN: and nivaArN: and munotavirN.
‡ Loquacity, (M, TA,) and the divulging of secrets. (TA.)

entry.sense: navirN ‡ Loquacious; one who talks much: as also minovarN↓ (M, Ḳ) and nayovuraAnN↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or vainly or frivolously loquacious, and a divulger of secrets: (A:) fem. navirapN only. (M.)

hom.sense: navorapN [A single act of scattering, strewing, dispersing, or throwing dispersedly, with the hand. And hence,]

‡ A sneeze: (Ḳ:) or the like thereof; peculiar to a beast of carriage (Ṣ) [or other beast, and a fish, as appears from what here follows.] It is said in a trad. (A, TA) of Kaab, (TA,) AljaraAdu navorapu HuwtK (A, TA) ‡ The locust is [produced by] the sneeze of a fish: or, as in a trad. of I’Ab, navorapu AlHuwti the sneeze of the fish. (TA.) [From this it is inferred that the locust is, like fish, lawful to be captured by one in a state of UiHoraAm.]

‡ The end of the nose: (IAạr, T:) or i. q., xayoXuwmN: (A:) or the xyXwm with what is next to it: (M, Ḳ:) and (M, A; but in the Ḳ, or) the interstice that is between the two mustaches, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) against the partition between the two nostrils: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) so [in a man and] in the lion: (Ṣ, M:) or the nose or the lion. (M.)

Hence, (T, &c.,) Aln-avorapu, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and navorapu AlOasadi, (T, A,) ‡ Two stars, between which is the space of a span, (XborN, [said in several law-books to be the twelfth part of a rumoH, and therefore twenty-two minutes and a half, accord. to modern usage; but there is reason to believe that ancient usage differed from the modern with respect to both these measures, and was not precise nor uniform;]) and in [or between] which is a particle (laToxN) of white, as though it were a portion of cloud; it is the nose of Leo, [which the Arabs extended far beyond the limits which it has upon our globes, (see Alc-iraAEu,)] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and is a Mansion of the Moon: (Ṣ:) [app. the Aselli; Asellus Boreus and Asellus Australis; two small stars in Cancer, between which is a little cloud or nebula, called Præsepe: (see Pliny, l. xviii. c. 35:)] a certain star or asterism, which is of the stars or asterisms of Leo, and which is a Mansion of the Moon: (M:) [app. meaning the same, or Præsepe:] or a certain star in the sky, as though it were a particle (laTox) of cloud, over against two small stars, in the science of astronomy pertaining to the sign of Cancer [though accord. to the Arabs belonging to Leo]: (T:) [app. Præsepe; the two small stars adjacent to it being the Aselli:] a certain star, as though it were a particle (laToxN) of cloud; so called because it appears as though the lion had ejected if from his nose: (A:) [app. meaning the same:]
in the Megista [of Ptolemy] it is mentioned by the name of the manger [i. e., Præsepe], and the name of the two small [for Almnyrp in my copy of Ḳzw, I read AlSfyrp,] stars is the two asses [i. e., the Aselli]: (Ḳzw, Description of Cancer:) or the nose and nostrils of the lion, consisting of three obscure stars, near together: AlT-arofu is [before them, and is] the two eyes of the lion, consisting of two stars, before which is Aljabohapu, consisting of four stars: (AHeyth:) [app. meaning the Aselli together with Præsepe:] three stars, near together; the nose of the lion; [app. meaning the same;] which compose the Eighth Mansion of the Moon: (Ḳzw, Description of the Mansions of the Moon:) [these descriptions apply to this Mansion of the Moon accord. to those who make Aln-awoC to signify “the heliacal rising:” see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:] or the bright star [app. meaning b] in Cancer: (Ḳzw, Description of Cancer:) [this agrees with the place of the Eighth Mansion of the Moon accord. to those who make Aln-awoC to signify “the anti-heliacal setting:” see again manaAzilu Alqamar.] The Arabs say UicaA TalaEati Aln-avorapu qanaOati Albusorapu, meaning, When Alnvrp rises [heliacally], the unripe date begins to have its redness intermixed with blackness: its rising is very soon after that of AlX-iEoraI [or Sirius: about the epoch of the Flight, it rose heliacally, in central Arabia, on the 17th of July, O. Ṣ.; and Sirius, on the 13th of the same month]. (M.)

entry.sense: nuvaArN What becomes scattered, strewn, or dispersed, of, or from, a thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also nuvaArapN↓, (M, Ḳ,) and navarN↓, (Ḳ, [but see munotavirN,]) and, as some say, nivaArN↓: (Mṣb:) so the nuvaArap↓ of wheat, and of barley, and the like: (Lḥ, M:) or nuvaArN signifies the crumbs of bread, and of everything, that become scattered around the table: (T:) or the crumbs of the table that become scattered around: as also nuvaArapN↓: (A:) or this last, what becomes scattered from the table, and is eaten in the hope of obtaining a recompense [for preventing its being thrown away or trodden under foot]. (Lḥ, M, Ḳ.*)

nivaArN, with kesr, a subst. from navara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) signifying The act of scattering, strewing, dispersing, or throwing dispersedly, [anything,] (Lth, T, A, Mṣb,) [and particularly fruits and the like, such as] walnuts and almonds and sugar [and money, &c., on festive occasions,] and grain. (Lth, T.) You say Xahidotu nivaAra fulaAnK I was present at, or I witnessed, such a one's scattering (Lth, T, A) of fruits, &c. (Lth, T.) And kun-aA fiI nivaArihi We were at his scattering. (A.)

Also, What is scattered, strewn, dispersed, or thrown dispersedly, (A, Mṣb, TA,) of such things as sugar and fruits and the like, (A, TA,) [and money, &c., on festive occasions;] a subst., (A, TA,) in the sense of manovuwrN, (A, Mṣb, TA,) like kitaAbN in the sense of makotuwbN; (Mṣb;) as also navarN↓. (A, TA.) [See also munotavarN.] You say OaSanotu mina Aln-ivaAri I obtained [somewhat] of the scattered [sugar or fruits, &c.]. (Mṣb.) And maA OaSabonaA mino navari fulaAnK XayoYFA We did not obtain aught of such a one's scattered things, such as sugar and fruit. (TA.)
Accord. to some, i. q. nuvaArN in the first of the senses explained above. (Mṣb.)
navuwrN ‡ A female, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or woman, (M,) having numerous offspring: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) and so a male, (M,) or man. (TA.)
‡ A ewe, or she-goat, (TA,) having a wide orifice to the teat: (Ḳ, TA:) as though she scattered the milk. (TA.)
See also naAvirN.
naviyrN: see manovuwrN.
nuvaArapN: see nuvaArN, in three places.
naAvirN (A) and minovaArN↓ (A, Ḳ) ‡ A palm-tree (naxolapN) that shakes off its unripe dates: (A:) or of which the unripe dates become scattered. (Ḳ.)

And the former, ‡ A sheep or goat that coughs, so that something becomes scattered from its nose; as also naAfirN: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or a sheep or goat that ejects from its nose what resembles worms; as also navuwrN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or that sneezes, and ejects from its nose what annoys or hurts it, resembling worms. (TA.)
nayovuraAnN: see navirN.
minovarN: see navirN.
dur-N munav-arN Pearls scattered, or strewn, much. (Ṣ, TA.) See manovuwrN.
minovaArN: see naAvirN.

dur-N manovuwrN, and naviyrN↓, Pearls scattered, strewn, dispersed, or thrown dispersedly, with the hand. (A,* TA.) See also munotavirN, and munav-arN. You say kaOan-a lafoZahu Ald-ur-u Aln-aviyru↓ [As though his speech were scattered pearls]. (A.)
lahu kariXN manovuwrapN ‡ He has [numerous] young children. (A, art. krX.)
Also manovuwrN A kind of sweet-smelling flower; (TA;) [the gilliflower: so called in the present day: see also xiyriI-N.]
See also xaXoxaAXN.

munotavirN In a scattered or strewn state; in a state of dispersion; (M;) as also mutanaAvirN↓, (TA,) and navarN↓, which last is applied to a thing and to things. (M.) See also nivaArN, and nuvaArN, and manovuwrN. You say dur-N mutanaAvirN↓ [Pearls in a scattered state]. (TA.)
mutanaAvirN: see munotavirN.

1. naj-a, aor. _i {yanojiju}, inf. n. najiyjN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naj-N, (TA,) It (a wound, or an ulcer) flowed with its contents [namely purulent matter, or blood]: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or exuded its contents: and in like manner, it (the back of a beast) flowed with purulent matter: and it (the ear) flowed with blood and purulent matter. (TA.)
maj-a and naj-a, (in the TA, art. mj, it is said maj-a and baj-a,) accord. to IAạr, are syn. (TA) naj-a AlX-aIoCa mino fiyhi, inf. n. naj-N, signifies i. q. maj-ahu. (TA.)

R. Q. 1. najonaja AlOamora, (inf. n. najonajapN, Ṣ,) He agitated the thing, or affair, to and fro, in his mind, (Ṣ,) and did not execute it; (TA;) he thought upon the thing, or affair, but did not determine upon it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See R. Q. 2.

najonaja AlUibila He drove back the camels from the water: (L:) or he drove them back time after time to the tank, or cistern; expl. by rad-adahaA ElI AlHawoDi: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [but EalaI, meaning here to, seems to be a mistake for Ean, from]. Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
Hat-aI UicaA lamo yajido waEolFA wanajonajahaA
maxaAfapa Alr-amoIi Hat-aI kul-uhaA hiymu
[Until, when he finds not a place of refuge, and drives them back from the water, (accord. to the explanation in the L,) fearing to be shot at, so that all of them are thirsting]. (Ṣ.)
najonaja He moved about [a thing; in the Ṣ, on the authority of AʼObeyd, a man], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and turned over and over. (TA.)
One says, najonijo Oamoraka falaEal-aka tajidu UilaI Alxuruwj sabiylFA [Turn the thing over and over in thy mind, and perhaps thou wilt find a way of egress, or escape]. (TA.)
najonaja, (inf. n. najonajapN, Ṣ,) He went round about in fright, or fear. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
najonaja All-uqomaha He moved the morsel to and fro in his mouth, and did not swallow it; like lajolaja. (Aboo-Turáb.)
R. Q. 2. tanajonaja He was in a state of commotion, or agitated, and confounded, perplexed, or amazed. (Ḳ.)
tnjnj fiI raOoyihi, and najonaja fiyhi↓, He was confounded, or perplexed, and agitated, in his judgment, or opinion. (TA.)
tanajonaja laHomuhu His flesh became much and flabby. (Ṣ.) Accord. to F, this is a mistake for tabajobaja; but Hr agrees herein with J. (TA.)

1. najaOahu, aor. _a {yanojaOu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. najoCN (so in the Ṣ: in the TA, najoOapN: [but this I think a mistake:]); and AntjOh↓ (Lḥ, Ḳ) and tnj-Oh↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He affected him, or it, by an evil, or a malignant, eye. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
8: see 1.
najuWu AlEayoni, and najuwoCu AlEyn, and najiYu↓ AlEyn, and najiIoCu AlEyn, Having an evil, or a malignant, eye; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and powerfully affecting therewith. (Ḳ.)
najiYN and najiIoCN; and najuwoCN: see najuWu AlEayoni.

najoOapN An affecting with an evil, or a malignant, eye: (Ks:) force, or eagerness, of look: (Ks, IAth, Ṣ:) lust, or desire, or a hankering after a thing. (Ks, Ḳ.) Ex. rud-uwA najoOapa Als-aAYili biAll-uqomapi (Ṣ) Avert the beggar's evil eye; (Ks;) or the force, or eagerness, of his look at thy food, or at thee; (Ṣ;) or his lust; or accomplish his desire, and avert his eye from thy food, in compassion for him; (TA;) do this by giving him a morsel. (Ṣ.)
rud-a Eanoka najoOapa hecaA AlX-aIoCi Avert from thee the desire of this thing. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. najaba AlX-ajarapa, aor. _i {yanojibu} and _u {yanojubu}, inf. n. najobN, He took off the bark of the stem, or trunk, of the tree: (Ṣ:) or najabahu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and nj-bh↓, inf. n. tanojiybN; and Antjbh↓; He took off its bark; barked it. (ISd, Ḳ.) See najabN.

najuba, aor. _u {yanojubu}, inf. n. najaAbapN, He was generous, noble, or liberal, &c.: [see najiybN]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) He, or it, was excellent, or choice. (MA.) [Said of a horse and the like, He was generous, excellent, strong, light, or swift.]
naAjabahu fanajabahu: see 3.

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
3. naAjabahu fanajabahu↓ [He vied with him, or strove to surpass him, in generosity, nobleness, or liberality; and he surpassed him therein.] (TA, art. xyr.)

4. Anjb He begot a generous, noble, or liberal, child; such as is termed najiybN. (Ṣ.) [This verb, being coupled in the Ḳ with najuba, might be imagined syn. therewith; but this, accord. to the TA, is not the case.] El-Aạshà says,
Oanojaba OazomaAna waAlidaAhu bihi
Uico najalaAhu faniEoma maA najalaA . (Ṣ) He begot a generous son in the times when his parents (rejoiced) in him, when they produced him; and excellent was that which they produced. Accord. to one reading, the second word is Oay-aAma: and Oay-aAmu waAlidayohi is also read in place of AzmAn wAldAh; in which case, Ay-aAm is fig. the agent of Anjb. (TA.)
Anjbt is said of a woman, in the same sense. (TA.) See also Anxb.

Anjb [as also Anxb] He begot a cowardly child: (from najabN, the “bark” of a tree: TA:) thus the verb bears two contr. significations: (Ḳ:) or the two significations are not necessarily contr.; for a courageous man may be not generous, or liberal; and a generous, or liberal, man may be not courageous. (MF.)
8. Antjbhu He selected him; chose him; (Ṣ;) preferred him above others. (TA.) See also Antxb.
See 1.
cahaba yanotajibu He went to collect [the kind of bark called] najabN. (TA.)

A poet says,
yaA Oay-uhaA Alz-aAEimu Oan-iI Oajotalibo
waOan-aniI gayora EiDaAhiI Oanotajibo
meaning, O thou who assertest that I take the verses of other poets and appropriate them to myself, and, and as it were, take the bark of other trees than my own 'idáh, to tan therewith... (TA.) [See EiDaAhu.]
najobN: see najiybN.

najabN The bark (liHaMC) of trees: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the rind of the roots thereof: or of what is hard thereof. (Ḳ.) The soft peel of branches is not thus called; nor is the rind of roots called qiXor, but njb: n. un. najabapN. (TA.)
najobapu namolapK A bite of an ant. So in a trad., accord. to one reading: accord. to another reading, it is naxobap. Both these words are given by IAth on the authority of Z. (TA.)
nujabapN and najabapN: see najiybN.

najiybN A generous, noble, liberal, man; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) one distinguished by rank or quality, nobility or eminence, reputation or note or consideration; (Ḳ;) excellent; of great worth in his kind; one who is like his father in generosity and actions: (TA:) as also najobN↓ (Ḳ) [explained as signifying “liberal, generous”] and nujabapN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or you call a man njyb when he is generous, noble, or liberal; but when he is unequalled among his people in generosity, &c., you say huwa najabapu↓ qawomihi, in measure like Halamap: (El-'Alam Es-Sakháwee:) [but MF doubts the correctness of this measure; and seems to think that the correct word is nujabap↓:] hw nujabapu↓ Alqawomi is said of a man when he is the man, among them, who is distinguished by generosity, &c.: (Ṣ:) pl. nujabaMCu and OanojaAbN and nujubN. (Ḳ.)

najiybN Excellent, as an epithet applied to any animal; (IAth;) a generous, excellent, camel or horse; one of high breed; (ISd;) a strong, light, swift, camel: (TA:) you say naAqapN najiybapN as well as nAqp najiybN: (Ḳ:) pl. najaAYibu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nujubN. (Ṣ.)

najaAYibu AlquroMni The most excellent, and the purest, parts of the Ḳur-án. Of such is the suwrapu AlOanoEaAm. (TA.) In like manner, nawaAjibuhu↓ The heart thereof that has [as it were] no najab [or bark] upon it: or the best, or most excellent, thereof. (Ḳ.)
nawaAjibu: see what next precedes.
munojibN A man who begets generous, noble, or liberal, children; such as are termed nujabaACu. (Ḳ.) In like manner, AimoraOapN munojibapN, and minojaAbN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. of the latter manaAjiybu. (Ṣ.)
mnjAb↓ also signifies A woman who has generous, noble, or liberal, children; such as are termed njbMC. (TA.)
minojaAbN A weak man: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. manaAjiybu. (TA.) See munojibN, and also minoxaAbN.
minojaAbN An arrow that has neither feathers nor head; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ;) that is trimmed, shaped, or pared, but has neither feathers nor head. (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, Ḳ.)
minojaAbN An iron with which a fire is stirred. (Ḳ.)

manojuwbN A vessel that is capacious within: (Ḳ:) a capacious vessel of the kind called qadaHN: (Ṣ:) or wide, or capacious, in the bottom: i. q. manojuwfN, which, accord. to ISd, is the correct word; but others say that the b and f may be interchangeable. (TA.)
jilodN manojuwbN A hide tanned with the bark of the trunk of the TaloH. (Ṣ.)

siqaACN mnjwbN A skin tanned with the same: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or with [the kind of bark called] najabN: (Ḳ:) as also najabiI-N (Ṣ, Ḳ) and minojabN: (Aboo-Mis-hal, Ḳ:) but the last is disapproved by ISd, because it is of the measure mifoEalN, which is not used in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (TA.)
munotajabN Select; chosen; choice: (Ḳ:) an epithet applied to anything. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. najava, aor. _u {yanojuvu}, inf. n. najovN; and tnj-v↓; (TA;) and Antjv↓ and Astnjv↓; (Ḳ;) He extracted, drew out, or caused to come forth, (Ḳ, TA,) a thing: apparently more especially used with reference to what is talked of, or news, tidings, or the like. (TA.)

najava Eanohu, aor. _u {yanojuvu} (and nj-v↓, inf. n. tanojyvN, TA,) and tnj-v↓; He searched, or sought, for, or after, it; inquired respecting it; sought for information respecting it; searched into, inquired into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it; i. e. an affair. (Aṣ.)
najava qaborFA, [aor. _u {yanojuvu},] inf. n. najovN, He dug up the contents of a grave. (TA, form a trad.)

fulaAnN yanojuvu baniI fulaAnK, (inf. n. najovN, L,) Such a one seduces, misleads, or leads astray, (yasotagowiI, Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ, or, accord. to AʼObeyd, yasotaEowiI, with the unpointed E, i. e., summons, by a cry, to sedition, or the like, Ṣ,) and implores aid of, the sons of such a one. (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See 10 in art. Ew.]

entry.sense: 5. tnj-v AlOaxobaAra He searched, or sought, for, or after, news, or tidings. (TA.) [See also 1.]
6. tanaAjavuwA [They revealed secrets, one to another]: tanaAjuvN signifies the same as tabaAv-N, (Ḳ,) and tabaAHuvN. (TA.)
tanaAjavuwA [They searched, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, together]: tanaAjuvN signifies the same as tabaAHuvN. (TA.)
8. Antjv He, or it, became inflated. (Ḳ.)
Antjv His fatness became apparent. (Ḳ.) One says AntHvt AlX-aApu The ewe became fat. (TA.)
See also 1.
10. Astnjv XayoYFA He exposed himself to a thing; or ventured upon it: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) he devoted himself eagerly to it, and set about it, or commenced it. (TA.)
See also 1.
nujovN and nujuvN↓ A coat of mail; syn. diroEN. (Ḳ.)
Also, (or nujuvN↓, Ṣ,) The pericardium; syn. gilaAfu Alqalobi: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OanojaAvN. (Ṣ.)
The house (bayot) of a man: pl. OanojaAvN. (Ḳ.)
najivN: see naj-aAvN.
nujuvN: see nujovN.

hom.sense: najiyvN ‡ A hidden secret. (Ḳ.)
See baHiyvN.
badaA najiyvu Alqawomi The secret of the people, which they concealed, became apparent, or revealed. (Fr, Ṣ.)
OataAnaA najiyvu Alqawomi The affair of the people, which they kept secret, came to our knowledge. (TA.)
See najiyovapN.
najiyvN What attains its utmost aim (mA blg), of praise, or of an encomium. (TA.)
najiyvN A butt at which one shoots, or casts, consisting of earth collected together: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or earth that is taken forth, and of which a butt is constructed, to shoot at, or cast at. (TA.)
OamorN lahu najiyvN An affair that has an evil end, conclusion, issue, or result. (TA.)
najiyvN A certain leguminous plant. (Ḳ.)
najiyvN Slow; tardy. (Ḳ.) [See labiyvN.]
najiyvapN (and najiyvN↓, TA) The dust, or earth, that is taken forth, or dug out, from a well; (Ṣ;) i. q. nabiyvapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
najyvapN What has become apparent, or manifest, of that which is foul, or disgraceful, of news, tidings, or information. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
najiyvapN Endeavour; effort: (Ḳ:) as also nakiyvapN. (TA.) So in the phrase buligato najiyvatuhu [His utmost endeavour, or effort, was exerted, or employed]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: naj-aAvN and najivN↓ One who is in the habit of searching, or seeking, for, or after, things; of inquiring respecting them; of seeking for information respecting them; searching into, inquiring into, investigating, scrutinizing or examining, them: (Ḳ:) a man who searches after news, diligently, or with labour, or perseverance, or time after time, and elicits it; (Aṣ;) as also naj-aAvN Eani AlOaxobaAri. (TA.)

najaHa, aor. _a {yanojaHu}; (Mṣb;) and AnjH↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UinojaAHN; (Mṣb;) He succeeded; he attained, or accomplished, his want, or wants, or the thing, or things, that he wanted. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
[You say,] maA OafolaHa fulaAnN walaA OanojaHa↓ Such a one did not prosper, or succeed, nor attain, or accomplish, his want, or wants. (Ṣ.)
najaHa Oamoruhu His affair became easy. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4: See 1.

OanojaHotu HaAjatahu, (Ṣ,) and OanojaHotuhaA lahu, (TA,) I accomplished for him his want. (Ṣ, TA.) OanojaHa Qll-ehu HaAjatahu God accomplished for him his want: (Ḳ:) or, helped him to attain, or accomplish, it. (TA.)
[So, OanojaHa Qll-ehu saEoyahu God made, or may God make, his work to succeed, prosper, or have a good issue or result.]
OnjH bihi He, or it, overcame him. (Ḳ.) Ex. UicaA rumota AlbaATila OanojaHa bika ‡ If thou seek what is vain, it will overcome thee. (A.)
5. tnj-H AlHaAjapa, and AstnjHhA↓, He sought, asked, or demanded, the accomplishment of the want, or thing needed, from him who had promised him; syn. tanaj-azahaA. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AstnjH↓ Qll-eha [He sought, or begged, of God, success, or the accomplishment of his want]. (A.) See an ex. voce EamalN.

6. tanaAjaHato OaHolaAmuhu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) tnAjHt Ealayohi AHlAmh (ISd) ‡ His dreams followed one another with truth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the truth of his dreams was continuous: (ISd:) or he had consecutive true dreams. (A, L.)

nujoHN and najaAHN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) two substs., the former from najaHa and the latter from OanojaHa, (Mṣb,) Success; or the attainment, or accomplishment, of one's wants, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or, of a thing. (Ḳ.) [See an ex. voce saraAHN.]
najaAHN: see nujoHN.
raOoIN najiyHN Right counsel, advice, or opinion. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
sayorN najiyHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and naAjiHN↓, (Ḳ,) ‡ A vehement pace: (Ḳ:) a quick pace. (Ṣ.)
makaAnN najiyHN, and naAjiHN↓, † A near place; syn. waXiykN. (L.)
nahoDN najiyHN ‡ An energetic rising, or raising of one's self. (L.) [You say,] nahaDa fiI hecaA AlOamor nahoDFA najiyHFA ‡ He rose quickly to employ himself in this affair. (A.)
See munojiHN.
najaAHapN Patience. (Ḳ.)
nafosN najiyHapN A patient mind. (Ḳ.)
maA nafosiI Eanohu binajiyHapK My mind does not patiently refrain from it. (L.)
OamorN naAjiHN An easy affair. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See najiyHN.
munojiHN A man who attains, or accomplishes, his want, or wants; pl. manaAjiHu and manaAjiyHu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also najiyHN↓. (L, Ḳ.)

manaAjiHu [a pl. of which the sing. is app. manojaHapN, meaning, acc. to analogy, A cause of success, or of the attainment, or accomplishment, of one's wants, or of a thing: see an ex. voce mabaAjiHu.] (A, TA, art. bjH.)

hom.sense: 1. najadahu, aor. _u {yanojudu}, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. najodN, (L, Ḳ,) He overcame, conquered, subdued, overpowered, prevailed over, or surpassed, him. (AO, Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
najada raOoyahu fiI AlOumuwri, inf. n. najodN, He exerted his judgment in affairs. (Sh, L.)

najuda, (Ṣ, M, &c.,) [aor. _u {yanojudu},] inf. n. najaAdapN (M, L, Ḳ) and najodapN, (Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (M, L,) He (a man, Ṣ, L,) was, or became, courageous, (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and sharp, or vigorous and effective, in those affairs which others lack power or ability to accomplish: (M, L, Ḳ:) or, very valiant: or, quick in assenting to that which he was called or invited to do, whether it were good or evil. (M, L.) See also 10, and 4.
najida, aor. _a {yanojadu}, inf. n. najadN; (Ṣ, L;) or nujida, like EuniIa, inf. n. najodN; (Ḳ;) He became [overcome,] afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, by sorrow, grief, or anxiety. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

najida, aor. _a {yanojadu}, (Ṣ, L,) and _u, which is extr., (L,) [or properly the aor. of najuda,] inf. n. najadN, (Ṣ, L,) He (a man, Ṣ) sweated, by reason of work, or of sorrow, grief, or anxiety: (Ṣ, L:) and Oanojada↓ he (a man, TA) sweated. (Ḳ.)
nujida EaraqFA, (Ḳ,) or najuda EaraqFA, (L,) He, (L,) or it, namely the body, (Ḳ,) flowed with sweat. (L, Ḳ.)

najida, aor. _a {yanojadu}, (TA,) inf. n. najadN (Ḳ) He was, or became, stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; not penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs; soft, without strength, or sturdiness, and without endurance: and weary, or fatigued. (Ḳ, TA.)
najuda He became terrified, or frightened. (L.)
najada, (aor. _u {yanojudu} L,) inf. n. nujuwdN, It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, apparent, manifest, plain, or evident. (L, Ḳ.)
najada, aor. _u {yanojudu}, inf. n. nujuwdN, It (a road) was, or became, apparent, manifest, conspicous, or plain. (L.)
OaEoTaAhu AlOaroDa bimaA najada minohaA He gave him the land with what came forth from it. (L.)

2. nj-dhu Ald-ahoru, (inf. n. tanojiydN, Ḳ,) Time, or habit, or fortune, tried, or proved, him, and taught him, (Ṣ, L,) and rendered him expert, or experienced, and well informed, (L,) or firm, or sound, in judgment: (Ḳ:) as also nj-ch, which is more approved. (L.)
nj-d, inf. n. tanojiydN, He ran; syn. EadaA. (Ḳ.)

nj-d, inf. n. tanojiydN, He ornamented, or decorated, a house or tent (byt) with the articles of furniture called nujuwd, pl. of najodN: (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ:*) [and, accord. to present usage, he manufactured beds and the like, and pillows; and teased, separated, or loosened, cotton, for stuffing beds, &c., with the bow and mallet: see also naj-aAdN].

entry.sense: 3. nAjdhu He went forth to him to fight, or combat. (A.)
nAjdt AlUibila She (a camel) vied with the other camels in abundance of milk: she yielded abundance of milk when the other camels had little. (L, Ḳ.*)
See 4.

hom.sense: 4. Anjd, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UinojaAdN; (L;) and najada↓, aor. _u {yanojudu}; (Mṣb;) and nAjd↓, inf. n. munaAjadapN; (Ṣ, L;) He aided, or assisted, another: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) he succoured him. (L.)
Anjdhu Ealayohi He aided, or assisted, him against him. (L.)
Anjd Ald-aEowapa (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) He answered, or complied with, the call, prayer, or invitation. (L, Ḳ.) And Anjdhu Ald-aEowapa He answered, or complied with, his call, prayer, or invitation. (M, L.)
Anjd He was, or became, or drew, near to his family, or wife; expl. by qaruba mino Oaholihi. (Lḥ, ISd, Ḳ.)
Anjdt Als-amaMCu The sky became clear. (Ḳ.)
Anjd (L, Ḳ) and tnj-d↓ (Ḳ) He, or it, (a person, or thing, L, both said of such a thing as a mountain, TA,) became high, or lofty. (L, Ḳ.)
gaAra waOanojada † He became famous in the low countries and in the high. (A.)

Anjd, (inf. n. UinojaAdN, L,) He entered upon the country of Nejd: (Ṣ, L:) or he came to Nejd, or to high land or country: (L, Ḳ:) or he went thither: (L:) or he went forth to, or towards, it. (Lḥ, ISd, L, Ḳ.)
Oanojada mano raOaI HaDanaA, a proverb, He enters Nejd who sees Hadan, which is the name of a mountain; i. e., in going up from El-Ghowr, or El-Ghór. (Ṣ, L.)

entry.sense: 5. tnj-d: see 4.
He swore a big oath. (L.)
10. Astnjdhu He asked, or desired, of him aid, or assistance, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,*) and succour. (L.)
Astnjd He (a man) became strong after having been weak, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or sick. (TA.)
Astnjd Ealayohi, (Ṣ, L,) and bihi, (L, TA,) He became emboldened against him, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and clave to him, (L,) after having regarded him with awe, or fear. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
Astnjd He became courageous after having been cowardly. (A.) See also najuda.

hom.sense: najodN High, or elevated, land or country: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or hard, and rugged, and elevated, or high, table-land: only stony and rugged, or hard, elevated land, like a mountain, standing over against one and intercepting his view of what is behind it, but not very high, is thus called: (L:) pl. OanojudN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) a pl. of pauc., (TA,) and OanojaAdN, (L, Ḳ,) [also a pl. of pauc.,] and nijaAdN and nujuwdN (Ṣ. L, Ḳ) and nujudN; (IAạr, L, Ḳ;) and pl. of nujuwdN, OanojidapN; [another pl. of pauc.;] (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or this is a mistake, and it is pl. of nijaAdN, like as OaHomirapN is pl. of HimaArN; or it is a pl. deviating from common rule. (IB, L.) You say OuEolu haAtiyka Aln-ijaAda Ascend thou these high lands; and haAcaAka Aln-ijaAda this high land, making it singular. (L.)

najodN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, &c.,) and najudN, (Ḳ,) the latter of the dial. of Hudheyl, (Akh,) of the masc. gender, [The high land, or country;] a division of the country of the Arabs; opposed to Algaworu, [or the low country,] i. e., Tihámeh; all the high land from Tihámeh to the land of El-'Irák; (Ṣ, L;) above it are Tihámeh and El-Yemen, and below it El-'Irák and Esh-Shám; (Ḳ;) it begins, towards El-Ḥijáz, at Dhát-'Irk, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and ends at Sawád of El-'Irák, and hence it is said to form no part of El-Ḥijáz: (Mṣb:) or it comprises all that is beyond the moat, or fosse, which Kisrà made to the Sawád of El-'Irák until one inclines to the Harrah (AlHar-ap), when he is in El-Ḥijáz; (El-Báhilee, T, L, Mṣb;) and it extends to the east of El-Ghowr, or El-Ghór; which is all the tract of which the torrents flow westwards: Tihámeh extends from Dhát-'Irk to the distance of two days' journey beyond Mekkeh: the tract beyond this, westward, is Ghowr, or Ghór; and beyond this, southwards, is Es-Saráh, as far as the frontiers of El-Yemen: (El-Báhilee, L:) or, as the Arabs of the desert have been heard to say, the country which one enters when, journeying upwards, he leaves behind him 'Ijliz, which is above El-Karyateyn, and which he quits when he descends from the mountain-roads of Dhát- 'Irk, where he enters Tihámeh, and when he meets with the stony tracts termed HiraAr in Nejd, where El-Ḥijáz commences: (Aṣ, L:) or the high country from Batn-er-Rummeh to the mountain-roads of Dhát-'Irk: (ISk, L:) or the country from El-'Odheyb to Dhát-'Irk, and to El-Yemámeh, and to El-Yemen, and to the two mountains of Teiyi, and from El-Mirbed to Wejreh: Dhât-'Irk is the beginning of Tihámeh, extending to the sea and Juddeh: El-Medeeneh is not of Tihámeh nor of Nejd, but of El-Ḥijáz, higher than El-Ghowr, or El-Ghór, and lower than Nejd. (IAạr, L.)
najodN An elevated road: (Ṣ:) or an elevated and conspicuous road. (L, Ḳ.) A road in a mountain. (L.) [Hence Tal-aAEu AlOanojudi, expl. below, and in art. TlE.]
hadayonaAhu Aln-ajodayoni [Ḳur, xc. 10] We have shown him the two ways; the way of good and that of evil: (Beyd, Jel, L:) or the two conspicuous ways: (L:)
or We have given him the two breasts; (Beyd, L;) for najodN also signifies a woman's breast; (L, Ḳ;) the belly beneath it being like the [country called] gawor. (TA.)
OamaA wanajodayohaA maA faEalota celika Now, by her two breasts, didst thou not that? A form of oath of the Arabs. (MF.)
najodN and naAjidN↓ A thing, or an affair, apparent, manifest, plain, or evident. (L.)

huwa Tal-aAEu OanojudK, and Tl-AE OanojidapK, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and Tl-AE nijaAdK, (L, Ḳ,) and AlOanojudi, (Ḳ, art. TlE,) and AlnijaAdi, (L, Ḳ,) ‡ He is one who surmounts difficult affairs: (A:) or he is one who manages affairs thoroughly, (L, Ḳ,) and masters them: (L:) or he is a man expert in affairs, who surmounts and masters them by his knowledge and experience and excellent judgment: or, who aims at lofty things: (Ḳ, art. TlE:) or he is one who rises to eminences, or to lofty things or circumstances, or to the means of attaining such things: (Ṣ:) as also Tal-aAEu Alv-anaAyaA. (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. TlE.) See najidN, and munaAjidN.

najodN, sing. of nujuwdN (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and of nijaAdN, (L, Ḳ,) which signify The articles of household farniture and the like (mtAE) with which a house or tent (byt) is ornamented, or decorated; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L;) the carpets and beds or other things that are spread, and the pillows, used for that purpose: (L, Ḳ:) the cloths or stuffs used for this purpose, with which the walls are hung, and which are spread; (L;) the curtains which are hung upon the walls: (A:) and OanojaAdN, pl. of najodN, household furniture, consisting of such things as are spread, and pillows, and curtains. (L.)
najodN A skilful, or an expert, guide of the way. (L, Ḳ.)
najodN, (Ḳ,) or nujudN↓, (L,) A place in which are no trees. (L, Ḳ.)
najodN A kind of tree resembling the Xuborum (L, Ḳ) in its colour and manner of growth and its thorns. (L.)
najadN Sweat, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) by reason of work, or of sorrow, grief, or anxiety, &c. (L.)

Aln-ajadaAtu A certain sect of the Khárijees, (Ṣ, L,) of those called the Harooreeyeh; (L;) the companions, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or followers, (L,) of Nejdeh Ibn-'Ámir (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) El-Harooree (L) El-Hanafee, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) of the Benoo-Ḥaneefeh; (TA;) also called Aln-ajodiy-apu↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: najudN: see najicN.

najidN and najudN↓ and najiydN↓ (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and najodN↓ (M, L, Ḳ) A courageous man, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) sharp, or vigorous and effective, in those affairs which others lack power or ability to accomplish: (M, L, Ḳ:) or courageous and strong: (Mṣb:) or very valiant: or quick in assenting to that which he is called or invited to do, whether it be good or evil: (M, L:) pl. of najudN, OanojaAdN, like as OayoqaAZN is pl. of yaquZN; (Ṣ, L;) or this is pl. of najodN and najidN; (Sb, M, L;) and not of najiydN: (M, L:) the pl. of this last is nujudN and nujadaMCu. (Ṣ, L.)
Aln-ajiydu↓ The lion: (Ḳ:) so called because of his courage. (TA.)
najidN fiI AlHaAjapi A man quick in accomplishing that which is wanted, or needed. (Ṣ, L.)

najidN and manojuwdN↓ (L) and najiydN↓ (TA) and naAjidN↓, in which last the A is perhaps inserted by poetic licence, (L,) Sweating, by reason of work, or of sorrow, grief, or anxiety, &c. (L, TA.) See also manojuwdN.
nujudN: see najodN.

najodapN, a simple subst. (M, L,) Courage, (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and sharpness, or vigour and effectiveness, in those affairs which others lack power or ability to accomplish: (M, L:) or courage with steadiness, and calmness in awaiting fearlessly death, victory, or martyrdom: (EshShiháb [El-Khafájee]:) or great valour: or quickness in assenting to that which one is called or invited to do, whether it be good or evil. (M, L.)
cuw najodapK A man possessing valour. (Ṣ, L.) See munaAjidN.
najodapN Fight; combat; battle. (L, Ḳ.)
Terror; fright. (L, Ḳ.)
Difficulty; distress; affliction; adversity: (Lḥ, Ṣ,* L, Mṣb,* Ḳ:*) pl. najadaAtN (Mṣb.) Ex. laAqaI fulaAnN najodapF Such a one experienced difficulty, distress, trouble, or adversity. (Lḥ, Ṣ, L.)
See also a saying of Sakhr-el-Ghei, and a citation from a trad., voce risolN.
najodapN Aid; assistance. (Mṣb.)
huwa Qbonu najodatihaA ‡ He is ignorant thereof: contr. of hw Abn bajodatihaA. By njdp is meant an allusion to Nejdeh El-Harooree. (A.) See najadN.
nijodapN, with kesr, Trial, or affliction, (balaACN) [experienced] in wars. (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee] and TA.)
Aln-ajodiy-apu: see najadN.
nijaAdN The suspensory cords or strings of a sword: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the part thereof that lies upon the shoulder. (L.)
Tawiylu Aln-ijaAdi [lit., Having long suspensory cords or strings to his sword,] means ‡ a man of tall stature: for when a man is tall his njAd must be long. (L.)

hom.sense: najuwdN, applied to a she-ass, and to a she-camel, Long-necked: (L, Ḳ:) or, so applied, (Ḳ,) or specially to a she-ass, (L,) or to a wild she-ass, (Ṣ,) that does not become pregnant: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) but Sh says, that this meaning is disapproved; and that the correct meaning is tall, applied to a she-ass: (L:) or tall; overpeering: (Ṣ, L:) or high and great: from najodN [signifying “high or elevated land”]: (Aṣ, L:) pl. nujudN. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

Also, applied to a she-camel, Sharp; spirited; vigorous: (L, Ḳ:) a correct meaning thus applied: (Sh:) or strong: (R:) one that precedes, or outgoes, others: (L, Ḳ:) or strong in spirit: (L:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)

Also, so applied, Abounding with milk: (L, Ḳ:) and, that vies with the other camels in abundance of milk, (L, Ḳ,) and surpasses them therein, (L,) or yields abundance when they have little: (Ḳ:) [but for UicaA gazurona, in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands, meaning “when they yield abundance of milk,” I read AcA garazona:] pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
Also, so applied, That lies down upon a high, or elevated, place: (Ḳ:) or that will not lie down save upon high ground: (L:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)

Also, An intelligent woman; sharp, or quick, in intellect: (Ḳ:) possessing judgment; as though she exerted her judgment in affairs: a strange meaning in which the word is used in a trad.: (Sh, L:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
See manojuwdN, and munaAjidN.
najuwdN One who works in shaking and spreading and stuffing and arranging [those articles of household furniture which are called] nujuwd [pl. of najodN]. (M, L.) See also naj-aAdN.

entry.sense: najiydN: see najidN, and munojuwdN.

naj-aAdN One who manufactures (yuEaAlij) beds and the like, and pillows; and sews them: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) [and, accord. to present usage, who teases, separates, or loosens, cotton, for stuffing beds, &c., with the bow and mallet: as also munaj-idN↓:] one who ornaments, or decorates, houses, and beds and the like, and carpets. (AHeyth, L.) See also najuwdN.

naAjidN and manojuwdN↓ Stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; not penetrating, sharp, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs; soft, without strength, or sturdiness, and without endurance: and weary, or fatigued. (TA.)
See najidN.
naAjidapN, sing. of nawaAjidu (L,) which signifies Streaks of fat (L, Ḳ) upon the shoulders of a camel: occurring in a trad.: so called because of their elevation. (L.)
naAjuwdN Wine: (Aṣ, L, Ḳ:) or excellent wine: or the first wine that comes forth when the clay is removed from the mouth of the jar: (Aṣ, L:) of the masc. gender. (L.)

A wine-vessel: (Ḳ:) any vessel into which wine is put, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) such as a baATiyap, (L,) or a jafonap &c.: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L:) or a wine-cup, or a cup of wine; syn. kaOosN: (L:) or a vessel in which wine is cleared; (A;) a clarifier, or strainer for wine; syn. raAwuwqN; (Lth, L;) which last is the meaning that most assign to the word. (TA.)
Saffron. (Aṣ, L, Ḳ.)
Blood. (Aṣ, L, Ḳ.)
minojadN A small mountain (Ḳ, [in the CK, for jubayol is put Hubayol,]) overlooking a valley. (TA.)

minojadN A kind of ornament, (L, Ḳ,) worn by women, (L,) adorned with gems, or jewels, (L, Ḳ,) one over another: (L:) a necklace of pearls and gold, or of cloves, a span in breadth, extending from the neck to the part beneath the breasts, and lying upon the place of the nijaAd; (L, Ḳ;) i. e. of the njAd of a man's sword: from naj-ada Albayota: (L:) pl. manaAjidu. (L, Ḳ.)
minojadapN A light staff or stick with which a beast of carriage is urged on. (Ḳ.)
A stick, or wooden instrument, with which wool is teased, or separated, i. q. minodafN (?) (TA,) and with which the Haqiybap of a camel's saddle is stuffed. (Ḳ, TA.)
minojaAdN A man who aids, or assists, much or well. (Lḥ, L.)
manojuwdN Overcome; conquered; subdued; overpowered: and fatigued. (L.)
manojuwdN and najiydN↓ (and najuwdN↓ applied to a female, R,) Afflicted, distressed, or oppressed, by sorrow, grief or anxiety. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) See also najidN.
munojuwdN In a state of perishing or destruction. (L, Ḳ.)
See naAjidN.

munaj-adN, as also munaj-acN, (Ṣ, L,) which latter is the more approved, (L,) A man tried and strengthened by experience; expert, or experienced; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) who has had experience in affairs, and has estimated and understood them, and become well informed. (L.)
munaj-idN: see naj-aAdN.
munaAjidN A fighter; a combatant. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
An aider; an assistant; (Ḳ;) [and so, app., najodN↓ and najodapN↓ and najuwdN↓, mentioned in the A].

hom.sense: 1. najacahu, aor. _a {yanojacu}, (TḲ,) [or _u, accord. to the rule of the Ḳ,] inf. n. najocN, (L, Ḳ,) He bit him, or it, (L, Ḳ,) with the naAjic, which is the tooth next behind the canine tooth: [but see this word:] (L:) or, with the nawaAjic.
najacahu (inf. n. najocN, TḲ,) ‡ He importuned him in asking: najocN sigfies also vehement speaking. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
2. nj-chu † It (experience) strengthened him: (A:) or tried and strengthened him. (Ṣ, L.) Suheym Ibn-Wetheel says,
wanaj-acaniI mudaAwarapu AlX-uWuwni
[And the applying myself to the management of affairs has tried and strengthened me]. (Ṣ, L.) See 3, in art. dwr. And see nij-d.

nAjic sing. of nawaAjicu, which signifies The furthest of the OaDoraAs [or molar teeth], (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a man; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) which are four in number, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) next after the OaroHaCF; (L;) also called OaDoraAsu AlHulumi, [or the teeth of puberty, and OaDoraAsu AlEaqoli, or the wisdom-teeth,] (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Mṣb,) because they grow after the attaining to puberty, and the completion of the intellectual faculties: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) or all the ADrAs [or molar-teeth]: or the teeth next behind the canine teeth: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) altogether four in number: (L, Mṣb:) or the canine teeth: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) which last, accord. to Th, (L, Mṣb,) or the last but one, accord. to IAth, (L,) is the signification meant in the trad. (respecting Moḥammad, L.) DaHika Hat-aI badato nawaAjicuhu [He laughed so that his nwAjc appeared]; (L, Mṣb;) because Moḥammad's utmost laugh was slight; or this is a hyperbolical expression, not meant to be literally understood; for the signification of nwAjc most commonly obtaining is the first of those given above: (L:) the phrase also signifies he laughed violently, or immoderately: (Ṣ, L:) the term nwAjc is also sometimes used in relation to the horse, (Ṣ, L,) or a solid-hoofed animal, as well as man; (Bári', Mṣb;) and they are [termed] the OanoyaAb in a soft-footed animal such as the camel; and the sawaAlig in a cloven-hoofed animal. (Ṣ, L.) See also sin-N.
EaD-uwA EalayohaA biAln-awaAjici ‡ They held her fast. as one holds fast in biting with all his grinders. (L, from a trad.)
OabodaI naAjicahu † He was immoderate in his laughter: and, in his anger. (A.)

EaD- EalaI naAjicihi † He attained to the age of puberty; or of manly vigour; or of firmness, or soundness, of judgment: (A, L, Ḳ:*) and he bacame patient, and firm, vigorous, or hardy, in the management of affairs. (L.)
balaga fiI AlEilomi wagayorihi binaAjicihi † He made his knowledge, &c., sound, or firm. (A.)
badato nawaAjicuhu His nwAjc appeared by reason of anger or of laughter. (L.)

munaj-acN † A man (Ṣ, L) tried and strengthened by experience; expert, or experienced: (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or (so in the L; in the Ḳ, and) who has experienced probations, trials, or calamities, (Lḥ, L, Ḳ,) and thus become a vigorous manager of affairs. (TA.) See also munaj-adN.
manaAjicu [Moles]: used as pl. of julocN, (L, Ḳ,) and of xulodN. (L, Ḳ, &c., art. xld.)

hom.sense: najara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yanojuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. najorN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He worked wood as a carpenter; cut or hewed it; formed or fashioned it by cutting; cut it out; hewed it out; shaped it out; syn. naHata; (Lth, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) or, as some say, qaTaEa. (TA.)

najarato, (TA,) [aor. as above, accord. to the rule of the Ḳ,] inf. n. najorN, (Ḳ,) She (a woman) made, or prepared, the kind of food called najiyrap, (Ḳ,* TA,) for her children, and her pastors. (TA.)

entry.sense:
najorN † The shape, or form, of a man [or beast]; his appearance, or external state or condition: (TA:) † species; distinctive quality or property; syn. lawonN; as also nijaArN↓ and nujaArN↓: (Ṣ, TA:) ‡ nature; natural or native disposition or temper or other quality or property; (A, TA;) of a man [&c.]; as also nijaArN↓ or nujaArN↓: (A [in my copy of the A written erroneously najaArN:]) his place of growth; as also njAr: (A:) origin; syn. OaSolN; as also nijaArN↓ and nujaArN: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) grounds of pretension to respect; rank or quality, nobility, honourableness, or estimableness; syn. HasabN↓; (Ṣ,* TA;) as also nijaArN↓ (Ṣ,* Mṣb, TA) and nujaArN↓: (Ṣ, TA:) generosity of mind or spirit (A.) It is said in the prov.,
kul-N nijaAri UibilK nijaAruhaA↓
wanaAru Uiboli AlEaAlamiyna naAruhaA
Every species of camels is their species: (Ṣ:) or every origin, &c.: (Ḳ:) [and every mark of the camels of the various peoples of the world is their mark: (the latter hemistich is omitted in the Ṣ, Ḳ, but inserted in the TA:)] the camels here mentioned by the poet were stolen from among a variety of camels, and comprised every species [with every mark]. (TA.) The proverb is applied to him who confounds things; (Ṣ;) and means, he has in him every sort of disposition, and has no opinion in which he is settled. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 317. See also naArN.]

najoraAnN The piece of wood in which is the foot of a door: (Ḳ:) or the piece of wood upon which the foot of a door turns: (Ṣ:) or the foot of a door, upon which it turns: (A:) or the darowanod [a Persian word signifying a bolt, and a hook,] of a door. (IAạr, TA.) [Chald. נַגְרָא vectis, pessulus: (Golius:) which suggests that the original signification may be that assigned by IAạr: but the first and second and third are alone agreeable with the following verse.] AO, cites this ex.:
Sababotu AlmaMCa fiI Aln-ajoraAni Hat-aI
tarakotu AlbaAba layosa lahu Sariyru
[I poured water into, or upon, the njrAn, so that I made the door to have no creaking]. (Ṣ.)
nujaArN and nijaArN: see najorN, throughout.
nujaArapN [Cuttings, chips, parings, shavings, or the like, of wood;] what is cut, or hewn, (Ḳ, TA,) from wood, (TA,) when it is worked by the carpenter. (TA.)
nijaArapN The art of carpentry. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
najiyrapN Milk mixed with flour: or with clarified butter: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Abu-l-Ghamr El-Kilábee, fresh milk to which clarified butter is added. (Ṣ.) See HariyrapN.
naj-aArN A carpenter. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

OanojarN The anchor of a ship, (A, Ḳ,) composed of pieces of wood, (Ḳ, TA,) which are put with their heads in contrary directions, and the middles of which are bound together in one place, after which, (TA,) molten lead is poured between them, so that they become like a rock; (Ḳ, TA;) the heads of the pieces of wood project, and to these are tied ropes; then it is lowered in the water, (TA,) and when it becomes fast, the ship becomes fast: (Ḳ, TA:) it is a Persian word, (TA,) arabicized, from lanokaro: (Ḳ, TA:) [or from the Greek ἄγκυρα:] accord. to the T, a word of the dial. of El-'Irák. (TA.) You say huwa Oavoqalu mino OanojarK He is heavier than an anchor. (A.)
UinojaArN: see Uij-aArN.
manojuwrN Wood worked, cut, hewed, formed, or fashioned by the carpenter. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. najiza, aor. _a {yanojazu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. najazN; (Ṣ;) and najaza, aor. _u {yanojuzu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. najozN; (TḲ;) It (a thing, Ṣ, TA,) came to an end; came to nought; perished, passed away: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) in these senses, the former is the more chaste, and has been so generally used that the latter has been said to be not allowable; but both have been heard. (TA.) It (a speech or discourse) finished, (Ḳ, TA,) and became complete. (TA.) He (a man) died: (Ṣ:) occurring in a verse of En-Nábighah Edh-Dhubyánee: as related by J, najiza; but as related by AʼObeyd, najaza. (TA.)

najaza AlwaEodu, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanojuzu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. najozN; (Mṣb;) and najiza, aor. _a {yanojazu}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. najazN; (TḲ;) The promise came to pass, and was accomplished: (A, Mgh:) or the promise was prompt, or quick, in taking effect: (Mṣb:) or the thing promised (TḲ) came, arrived, or became present: (Ḳ, TA:) in this sense, the former is the more chaste; but both have been heard. (TA.)
najaza is also trans.: see 4, in four places.

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

3. nAjzhu, (Mgh,) or nAjzhu AlqitaAla, (A,) inf. n. munaAjazapN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) He fought him: (Ḳ:) or he went, or came, out, or forth, in the field, to fight him, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and fought him: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or he (a horseman) went, or came, out, or forth, into the field, to fight him, (another horseman,) and they strove together until each of them slew the other, or until one of them was slain: (TA:) and tanaAjuzN↓ signifies the same as munaAjazapN: (Ḳ:) you say, tanaAjaza Alqawomu, meaning, The people contended together in the mutual shedding of blood; as though they hastened in doing so. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] Uino rumota AlmuHaAjazaho faqabola AlmunaAjazaho [If thou desire the reciprocal prevention of fighting, and the making of peace, let it be before fighting]: (A:) or AlmuHaAjazaho qabola AlmunaAjazaho (Ṣ, Ḳ) [the reciprocal prevention of fighting, and] the making of peace, [should be] before the striving together, (AlmuEaAlajap, as in the CK,) or hastening, (AlmuEaAlajap, as in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA, and, accord. to the latter, AlmusaAraEap,) in fighting: (Ḳ, TA:) a proverb: (Ṣ, TA:) relating to the prudence of him who hastens to flee from him whom he has not power to withstand: (Ḳ:) or applied to him who seeks peace after fighting. (AʼObeyd, Ḳ.)
Also, He contended with him in an altercation; disputed with him; litigated with him. (TA.)

4. Anjz HaAjatahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UinojaAzN; (TA;) and najazahaA↓, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanojuzu}, inf. n. najozN (ISk, Ṣ) and najaAzN, or this is a subst. in the sense of UinojaAzN, like EaTaMCN in that of UiEoTaMCN; (Ḥar, p. 326;) He accomplished his want: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and naj-azotuhu↓ HaAjatahu I accomplished for him his want. (A.)

Anjz AlwaEoda, (A, Mgh, CK,) and najazahu↓, (Ṣ,) He fulfilled, or performed, the promise: (Ṣ,* A,* Mgh, CK:) or he made the promise to be prompt, or quick, in taking effect. (Mṣb.) You say also, Anjz EalaI-a AlmawoEida He fulfilled to me the promise; (Ḳ, accord. to the TA;) as also najaza↓ bihi: (TA:) and najazotuhu↓ bihi I made it to be prompt, or quick in taking effect to him. (Mṣb.) [Hence the saying,] Oanojaza Hur-N maA waEada (Ṣ, Ḳ) An ingenuous man fulfils what he promises: a proverb: (TA:) alluding to the fulfilment of a promise: and sometimes, to the asking, or demanding, the fulfilment thereof: El-Hárith the son of ʼAmr said to Sakhr the son of Nahshal, “Shall I guide thee to booty and one fifth of it be for me?” and he answered, “Yes:” so he guided him to some people from El-Yemen, and Sakhr made a sudden attack upon them, and engaged with them in conflict, and overcame, and obtained booty; and when he turned back, El-Hárith said to him the above words, and Sakhr fulfilled his promise to him. (Ḳ.)
Anjz EalaI Alqatiyli He hastened and completed, or made certain, the slaughter of the slain man; i. q. Oajohaza Ealayohi. (Abu-l-Mikdám Es-Sulamee and Ḳ.)
5: see 10, in five places.
6: see 3.

10. Astnjz HaAjatahu, and tnj-zhA↓, He sought, or asked, or demanded, the accomplishment of his want, from him who had promised him; (Mṣb;) syn. UisotanojaHahaA. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Astnjz AlwaEoda, and tnj-zhA↓, (Mgh,) or AlEidapa, (Ḳ,) He sought, or asked, or demanded, the fulfilment of the promise: (Mgh, Ḳ:) and tnj-zhu↓ AlEidapa he asked of him the fulfilment of the promise. (TA.) Hence, tanaj-uzu↓ AlbaraAMti The demanding and receiving of immunities. (Mgh.) You say also, Uisotanojazotu minohu kitaAbFA, and tanaj-azotuhu, [app. meaning, I sought, or asked, or demanded, of him the finishing, or completion, of a writing, or letter, or book.] (A.)
najozN and nujozN↓ are syn. You say, Oanota EalaI najozi HaAjatika, and nujozi↓ HaAjatika, Thou art on the point of accomplishing thy want. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nujozN: see najozN.
najiyzN: see naAjizN, in three places.
najiyzapN A recompense. You say, laOunojizan-a najiyzataka I will assuredly pay thy recompense. (TA.)
naAjizN Coming to an end; coming to nought; perishing; passing away. (TA.)
[Complete: accomplished.]
A promise that has been fulfilled; as also najiyzN↓: (TA:) or that has come to pass, and is accomplished. (A, Mgh.)

Present; ready; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) as also najiyzN↓: (Ḳ:) and ↓both, promptly, or quickly, done, or given. (TA.) You say, biEotuhu naAjizFA binaAjizK (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb) [I sold it, or I sold to him,] present, or ready, [merchandise,] for present, or ready, [money,] (TA,) like yadFA biyadK, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) i. e., taEojiylFA bitaEojiylK. (Ṣ.) And laA yubaAEu gaAYibN binaAjizK, meaning, A debt to be paid at a future time shall not be sold for ready money. (Mgh.) And naAjizN binaAjizK is a proverb, [meaning Ready merchandise with ready money,] like yadN biyadK, and EaAjilN biEaAjilK. (TA.) It is said in a trad., biyEuwA HaADirFA binaAjizK [Sell ye present merchandise for ready money]. (Ṣ.) And a poet ('Abeed Ibn-El-Abras, TA, art. klO,) says,
waUicaA tubaAXiruka Alhumuw
mu faUin-ahaA kaAlK wanaAjizo ; (Ṣ, TA, ubi supra;) [And when griefs attend thee, know that] they are, some, debts to be payed at future periods, and some, payments in ready money. (TA, ubi supra.) The saying [of ʼAbd-Allah Ibn-'Ámir El-Kurashee, owner of a horse named Esh-Shamoos, (TA, art. Xms,)]
jaroIa AlX-amuwsi naAjizFA binaAjizi [app. meaning, Quickly as the running of EshShamoos; ready with ready, or prompt with prompt;] is explained by IAạr, as meaning, Thou hast given an evil recompense and I have recompensed thee in like manner: or, as he says in one place, this is said when one does a thing and thou dost the like thereof; he not being able to go beyond thee in word or in deed. (TA.) [Respecting this saying, Freytag says, in his Arab. Prov., i. 305, (where, for naAjizFA we find naAjizN,) that it applies to him who is equal to the execution of the things which he undertakes, as well good as bad: and that jaraI is to be supplied before jaroIa.]

hom.sense: 1. najisa, aor. _a {yanojasu}; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and najasa, aor. _u {yanojusu}; (Mṣb;) and najusa, aor. _u {yanojusu}, (Ḳ,) accord. to some, but the books of good repute are silent respecting this last; (Mṣb;) inf. n. najasN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) of the first; (Mṣb;) and najaAsapN, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst. [as the verb najusa to which by rule it should belong is not of good authority]; (Mṣb;) It was, or became, unclean, dirty, filthy, or impure; (Mṣb;) [i. e.,] contr. of Tahara, or Tahura: (Mṣb, Ḳ:*) najaAsap is of two kinds; one kind is perceived by sense; and one kind is perceived by the mind; of which latter kind is that which is attributed, in the Ḳur, ix. 28, to those who assert God to have associates: (Er-Rághib, B:) but in this latter sense, it is said by Z, to be tropical. (TA.) [See also najaAsapN below.] You also say, (of a garment, A, Mṣb,) tnj-s↓, meaning, It was, or became, rendered unclean, dirty, filthy, or impure. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
najosN, [app. an inf. n. of which the verb is najasa,] The making a child's Euwdap [or amulet, of any of the kinds described below, voce tanojiysN]. (TA.)

2. nj-shu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanojiysN, (TA,) He rendered him, or it, unclean, dirty, filthy, or impure; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Anjshu↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) El-Ḥasan said of a man who married a woman with whom he had committed fornication, huwa OanojasahaA↓ fahuwa OaHaq-u bihaA [He defiled her, therefore he is most worthy of her]. (A, TA.*)
naj-asatohu Alc-unuwbu ‡ [Sins, or crimes, defiled him]. (A, TA.)
nj-s lahu, and nj-shu, He charmed him; or fortified him by a charm or an amulet [of any of the kinds described below, voce tanojiysN, q. v.]; syn. Eaw-acahu. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 2, in two places.

hom.sense: 5. tnj-s: see najisa.

He did a deed whereby to become free from uncleanness, dirt, filth, or impurity; (Ḳ;) like as you say taOav-ama and taHar-aja and taHan-ava, meaning, he did a deed whereby to become free from crime, sin, &c. (TA.)

entry.sense: najosN: see najisN.
nijosN: see najisN.
najasN: see najisN.
najusN: see najisN.

hom.sense: najisN and najasN↓ (Ṣ, A, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and najusN↓ and najosN↓ and nijosN↓ (A, O, Ḳ) Unclean, dirty, filthy, or impure: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the last of these is only used when the word is preceded or followed by rijosN: (ISd:) or only when it is preceded by rijosN: (Fr, Ṣ,* and Ḥar in the Durrat-el-Ghowwáṣ:) but this remark correctly applies only to the greater number of instances: (M, F:) the second of the above five forms is an inf. n. used as an epithet; (A, Mṣb;) and is [therefore] used as sing. and dual. and pl. and masc. and fem., without variation: (TA:) [and the first and last are also used as pls., as will be seen below; but when so used, I suppose qawomN or some other coll. gen. n. to be understood:] the pl. [of every one of the other forms] is OanojaAsN (A, Mṣb, TA) and [of the fourth and fifth, and perhaps of the first and third also, though I do not remember similar instances,] nijosapN. (TA.) [See also najaAsapN, below.] najisN and najosN↓ [&c.], applied to a man, signify Unclean,, &c., [both properly and tropically]. (TA.) [The two following examples are said in the A to be tropical.] Aln-aAsu OajonaAsN waOakovaruhumo OanojaAsN ‡ [Men are of several kinds, and most of them are unclean.] (A, TA.) And Uin-amaA QlomuXorikuwna najasN ‡ [Verily the associaters of others with God are but unclean], said in the Ḳur, [ix. 28,] (Ṣ, A, TA,) or najisN, or nijosN↓, accord. to certain readers. (TA.)
Also, all the above forms, A man having an incurable disease. (TA.)
See also naAjisN.

entry.sense: nujusN: see munaj-isN.
nijaAsN: see tanojiysN.
najiysN: see naAjisN.
najaAsapN: see 1: Uncleanness, dirtiness, filthiness, or impurity. (Mṣb.)
In the conventional language of the law, A particular uncleanness, of such a kind as renders prayer invalid; as urine, and blood, and wine. (Mṣb.)
daMCN naAjisN and najiysN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and najisN↓ (TA) An incurable disease: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or a disease that baffles the munaj-isuwn. (A.) See munaj-isN.
Oanojasu [More, and most, unclean, dirty, filthy, or impure]. You say, laA taraI Oanojasa mina AlkaAfiri ‡ [Thou wilt not see any one more unclean than the unbeliever]. (A, TA.)

tanojiysN The name of a thing, either something unclean, or bones of the dead, or a menstruous rag, which used to be hung upon him for whom there was a fear of the jinn's, or genii's, being attached to him: (Ḳ:) or the hanging of some such thing upon such a person, as a child or any other; for they used to say that the jinn would not approach those things: (TA:) or a thing which the Arabs used to do, as an amulet, to drive away thereby the [evil] eye: (Ṣ:) munaj-isapN↓ also is the name of a kind of amulet: (IAạr:) and nijaAsN↓ is syn. with taEowiycN; [by which may be meant either that it signifies an amulet, or that it is a quasi-inf. n. of 2; for it is said that] it is app. a subst. from naj-asa lahu, or naj-asahu, as signifying Eaw-acahu. (IAạr.) See also 2.

hom.sense: munaj-isN One who hangs, upon him for whom there is fear, unclean things, such as bones of the dead, and the like, to drive away the jinn, or genii; because these beings shun such things; (Ṣ,* A, TA;) one who fortifies by charms or amulets [of the kinds above mentioned]; syn, muEaw-icN: (Ḳ:) pl. munaj-isuwna: (A:) and nujusN↓ [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned] is syn. with muEaw-icuwna. (IAạr.)
Also, A little piece of skin that is put upon the notch [which is the place] of the bow-string. (TA.)

entry.sense: munaj-isapN: see tanojiysN.

hom.sense: 1. najaXa, aor. _u {yanojuXu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. najoXN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He concealed himself. (Mṣb.)

[And hence, He pursued game, or objects of the chase: (see naAjiXN:) or] he roused game, or objects of the chase, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and scared them from place to place. (TA.) You say also, najaXuwA Ealayohi AlS-ayoda, meaning, They scared the chase, or game, towards him, and drove and collected it to him. (TA.)

He searched after a thing, and roused it. (Sh, AʼObeyd, Ḳ.) This, accord. to Sh, is the primary signification: [but accord. to Fei, the primary signification is the first given above:] and hence the saying in a trad., laA taToluEu AlX-amosu Hat-aI tanojusuhaA valevumiAYapK wasit-uwna malakFA The sun does not rise until three hundred and sixty angels rouse it. (TA.)
He drew forth, educed, or elicited. (Ḳ.)
He collected together (Ṣ, Ḳ) camels [&c.] after a state of dispersion. (Ṣ.)
He drove vehemently. (TA.)

najaXa, aor. _u {yanojuXu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. najoXN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and najaXN, [which is the form generally used by the professors of practical law,] (ISh, Mgh, Ṣgh, TA,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) He demanded the sale of an article of merchandise for more than its price, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) not meaning to purchase it, (Mgh, Mṣb,) in order that another might see him and fall into the snare thus laid for him: and in like manner it is used with respect to marriage, [i. e., with respect to dowers,] and other things: (A, Mgh, Mṣb:) and the doing thus is forbidden: (Mgh:) it is from najaXa signifying “he roused” game: (Mgh:) or from the same verb signifying “he concealed himself;” because he who does so conceals his intention: (Mṣb:) or he augmented the price of an article of merchandise, not desiring to purchase it, but in order that another might hear him and augment in the same manner: (AʼObeyd, L:) or he outbade in a sale, in order that another might fall into a snare, he himself not wanting the thing: (Ṣ:) or he augmented the price of an article of merchandise, or praised it, in order that another might see that, and be deceived by him: (Ibráheem El-Ḥarbee:) or he praised an article of merchandise belonging to another in order that he might sell it, or dispraised it in order that it might not be easy for him to sell it: (ISh:) or he concurred with a man desiring to sell a thing, by praising him: (Abu-l-Khattáb, Ḳ:) or he bargained with a man desiring to sell a thing, offering him a large price, in order that another might see him and fall into a snare: or he scared people from one thing to another: (Ḳ:) also, he praised a thing; or praised it exceedingly, or for that which was not in it, or excessively and falsely; syn. madaHa XayoYFA and OaToraAhu: and he invented, or forged, a lie. (TA.) It is said in a trad., (Ṣ,) laA tanaAjaXuwA↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) i. e., Ye shall not practise najoX, or najaX: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or tanaAjuXN↓ signifies the bidding one against another, successively increasing their offers, in a sale, or other case; (Ḳ;) for it sometimes signifies the doing so in the case of a dowry, in order that the doing so may be heard, and the amount may consequently be augmented: (TA:) and Sh mentions, with respect to tanaAjuXN↓, on the authority of Aboo-Saʼeed, another thing, which is allowable, namely, [that it signifies the conspiring to promote the marriage of] the woman who has been married and divorced time after time; and [the sale of] the article of merchandise that has been bought time after time and then sold. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6: see 1, last part.
najaXN, said to be a subst. from najaXa: see 1.
najuwXN: see naAjiXN.
najiyXN: see naAjiXN.

hom.sense: najaAXiI-N and nijaAXiI-N: see naAjiXN.

Aln-ajaAXiI, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) the form preferred by El-Fárábee, (Mgh,) and Aln-ajaAXiI-u, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is the more common, (Mṣb,) but the former is the more chaste, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) and [Aln-ijaAXiI and Aln-ijaAXiI-u] with kesr to the n, which is said to be the more chaste, (Ḳ,) and is preferred by Th, (TA,) but teshdeed of the j is a mistake, (Mgh, MF,) The name of the King of the Abyssinians; (IDrd, Ṣ;) like as one says kisoraI and qayoSarN; and Abyssinian word: (IDrd:)
or a certain King of the Abyssinians, whose name was OaSoHamapu; (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [as is commonly said; but authors differ respecting his name;] and IḲt says, that AlnjAXI is in Coptic ASHmp, meaning “a gift:” (TA:) or originally the proper name of an individual, and afterwards a common title. (MF.)

entry.sense: naj-aAXN: see naAjiXN, in four places.
naj-aAXiI-N: see naAjiXN, in two places.

hom.sense: naAjiXN A pursuer, or capturer, or insnarer, of game, or objects of the chase; (Mṣb;) as also najiyXN↓ and naj-aAXN↓; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) because he conceals himself: (Mṣb:) or [naAjiXN and] naj-aAXN↓ and najuwXN↓ signify one who rouses the game, or objects of the chase; (Az, TA;) and so minojaXN↓ and minojaAXN↓: (L:) or naAjiXN and najaAXiI-N↓ (Akh, Ḳ) [and nijaAXiI-N↓ accord. to some copies of the Ḳ] and minojaAXN↓ (Az, Ḳ) one who rouses them in order that they may pass by the pursuer, or capturer, or insnarer, thereof: (Akh, Az, Ḳ:) or naAjiXN signifies one who scares them towards him, and drives and collects them to him: (Ṣ, A, TA:) and naj-aAXN↓ one who drives vehemently; (TA;) or one who urges camels; (A;) or who collects them after a state of dispersion: (Ṣ:) and naj-aAXiI-N↓ [with teshdeed to the j as well as to the I,] one who drives, or urges, travelling-camels and other beasts of carriage, in the market-place, to elicit their qualities of pace: (AA, TA:) and this last also signifies [absolutely] one who draws forth, or elicits, a thing. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
Also, One who practises najoX, or najaX, in an affair of buying and selling: (Mṣb, TA:*) [see 1:] and naj-aAXN↓ one who does so much, or often. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: minojaXN: see naAjiXN.
minojaAXN: see naAjiXN; in two places.
qawolN manojuwXN A saying drawn forth, or elicited: (TA:) and a forged saying, in which is falsehood. (IAạr, TA.)
UinojaASN: see art. OjS.

1. naH-a, aor. _i {yanoHiHu}, inf. n. naHiyHN, He (a man) reiterated a sound, or made it to reciprocate, (rad-adahu,) in his inside: (Ṣ, L:) or his voice was reiterated, or made to reciprocate, (tarad-ada,) in his inside; as also naHonaHa↓ and tanaHonaHa↓: (Ḳ:) [each of these verbs, of which the last seems to be the most common, signifies, as is implied in the L, &c., and accord. to present usage, he made a reiterated humming in his throat, like a slight coughing, or, as some say, more violent than coughing; as is often done by a niggard when he is asked for a thing:] Alt-anaHonuHu is well known, (Ṣ,) and Aln-aHonaHapu is like it; (Lth, Ṣ;) it is [the making a sound, or sounds, in the throat,] slighter than coughing; and is the pretence of the niggard: (Lth:) or it is more violent than coughing; as also Aln-aHiyHu. (L.) See also Hir-apN.
[Hence, from the sound employed,] naH-a,, aor. _u {yanoHuHu}, He incited, or urged on, a camel. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1: See naH-a.
naHonaHahu He repulsed him (namely an asker, or a beggar, L) in a foul, or an abominable, manner. (L, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 2: see naH-a.
naHaAHapN Niggardliness; avarice. (Ḳ.)
Also, contr., Liberality; bounty; munificence; generosity. (Ḳ.)

XaHiyHN naHiyHN [Very niggardly, or avaricious]: the latter word is an imitative sequent: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it is a corroborative syn. of the former: (MF:) as though meaning one who when asked for something, disliking to give it, has recourse to a pretence, and makes a reiterated breathing [or humming in his throat] as a feint to hide his unwillingness. (L.) [See also naHaAniHapN.]
naHonaHN: see naHaAniHapN.

naHaAniHapN Niggardly, or avaricious, men: base, ungenerous, mean, or sordid, men, who make a reiterated humming in the throat (yatanaHonaHawna) when they are asked for something: (A:) pl. of naHonaHN↓: or a pl. having no sing. (TA.) [See also naHiyHN.]

hom.sense: 1. naHaba, aor. _u {yanoHubu}, inf. n. naHobN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and nH-b↓, inf. n. tanoHiybN; (A;) He vowed; made a vow; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) put himself under an obligation to do a thing. (A.)

naHaba, aor. _a {yanoHabu}, inf. n. naHobN, He laid a bet, or wager; betted, or wagered. (Ḳ.) [The explanation of the inf. n. by muraAhanapN, in the Ḳ, seems to imply that it is the same as 3; but this appears to be doubtful.]

naHaba, aor. _i {yanoHibu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or _a, (Ḳ,) inf. n. naHiybN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or this is a subst., (Mṣb,) and naHobN; (Ḳ;) and AntHb↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) ‡ He raised his voice with weeping, or wailing; wept, or wailed, loud; (Ṣ;) wept, or wailed, most violently; (M, Ḳ;) wept, or wailed, with prolonged voice. (TA.)
naHaba, aor. _i {yanoHibu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nuHaAbN (Ṣ) and naHobN (Ḳ) He (a camel, Ṣ) had a cough, or coughed. (Ṣ Ḳ.)

naHaba, [aor. _a {yanoHabu},] inf. n. naHobN, He went, travelled, or journeyed, at a quick pace: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or with a light pace: (Ḳ:) with much exertion and perseverance. (TA.) [The inf. n. only is mentioned, and said, in the Ṣ, to be syn. with naEobN.]
2: see 1.

nH-bwA, inf. n. tanoHiybN, ‡ They strove, or exerted themselves, in their work; worked with energy: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or they went on, travelled, or journeyed, (with energy, TA,) until they came near to the water: (Ḳ:) they made a hard journey by night, in order to arrive at the water on the morrow. (Ṣ.)
naH-abonaA sayoranaA We pursued our journey laboriously, or with energy. (TA.)
nH-b Als-afaru fulaAnFA † The journey harassed such a one, (Ḳ,) being long. (TA.)
nH-b EalaI OamorK, and fiI OamorK, ‡ He applied himself to a thing, or set about it, and adhered to it. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. nAHbhu, (inf. n. munaAHabapN, TA,) He laid a bet, or wager, with him, (Ḳ,) EalaI OamorK respecting a thing. (TA.)
naAHayotuhu UilaI falaAnK I cited him, or invited him, to submit our case to such a one as judge; I cited him before such a one as judge. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nAHbth I contended with him, or disputed with him, for glory, or honour, or superiority in glorious or honourable qualities and the like, (Ḳ,) before a judge, or umpire. (TA.)
