Talhah said to Ibn-ʼAbbás, halo laka fiI Oano OunaAHibaka watarofaEa Aln-abiI-a (Ṣ) [or tarofaEu AlnbI: for I find it stated in the margin of a copy of the Ṣ, that J left the final letter of trfE without a vowel point, either fet-ḥah or ḍammeh:] Wilt thou that I contend with thee, or dispute with thee, for glory, or honour, and that thou enumerate thine excellencies and the honour which thou derivest from thine ancestors, &c., I doing the like, and that thou put the Prophet out of the question, not mentioning thy relationship to him, since this excellence is conceded to thee? (AM.)
6. tnAHbwA They appointed together a time, liloqitaAli for fighting; and sometimes for other purposes. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1.
He sighed vehemently; (Ḳ;) wept and sighed vehemently. (TA.)

hom.sense: naHobN A vow. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

qaDaI naHobahu He died: or he was slain in an expedition undertaken for the sake of God's religion: originally meaning he accomplished his vow: see Ḳur, xxxiii. 23: (Mṣb:) as though he had constrained himself [by a vow] to fight until he died: (TA:) or it signifies he ended his term, or period of life; ended his days: (Fr, Zj:) [or he finished his time: (as implied in the Ṣ): or he yielded his soul: or he accomplished his want:] from significations given below. (TA.)

naHobN A great bet, or wager: syn. xaTarN EaZiymN. (Ḳ.) So in the following verse of Jereer:
biTixofapa jaAladonaA Almuluwka waxayolunaA
EaXiy-apa bisoTaAmK jarayona EalaI naHobi
[In Tikhfeh we contended with the sword with the kings; and our horses, in the evening of Bistám, ran for a great bet]. (TA.)
naHobN A proof; a demonstration; an evidence: syn. burohaAnN. (Ḳ.)
A necessity; want; needful thing; an object of want or need: syn. HaAjapN. (Ḳ.) See qaDaI naHobahu.
‡ Death. (Ḳ.) See qaDaI naHobahu, above.
A term; fixed period; the period of life. (Ḳ.) See qaDaI naHobahu, above.
The soul: syn. nafosN. (AO, Ḳ.)
Mind; purpose; aspiration; desire; ambition: syn. him-apN. (Ḳ.)
ximosN naHobN A laborious journey: syn. daAYibN. (Ṣ.)
sayorN naHobN, (TA,) and syr munaH-ibN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ A quick pace, or journey. (Ḳ, TA.)
The same epithets are likewise applied, in the same sense, to a man. (TA.)
naHobN A quick (or light, Ḳ,) pace, or mode of going, travelling, or journeying, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) with much exertion and perseverance. (TA.)

saAra fulaAnN EalaI naHobK Such a one went on, travelled, or journeyed, with energy; [lit., for a great bet, or wager;] as though he had laid a [great] bet, and therefore strove, or exerted himself. (Ṣ.)
naHobN Length. (AA, Ḳ.)
ywm nHb [so in the TA: perhaps, yawomu naHobK, but more probably yawomN naHobN] A long day. (Er-Riyáshee.)
naHobN A space of time: a time. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See qaDaI naHobahu, above.
Sleep: syn. nawomN. (L, Ḳ: in some copies of the Ḳ, yawomN TA.)
Fatness. (Ḳ.)
I. q. Xid-apN [Vehemence; violence;, &c.: or distress; difficulty; adversity;, &c.]. (Ḳ.)
A game of hazard: syn. qimaArN. (Ḳ.)
A great camel. (Ḳ.) Perhaps a mistake for najobN. (TA.)

entry.sense: nuHobapN ‡ i. q. quroEapN [A lot used in sortilege: or lots collectively: or sortilege itself;] (Ḳ;) from naAHabaha “he cited him before a judge;” “he contended with him for glory;” and “he laid a bet, or wager, with him;” because it is, as it were, a judge, or that which decides, in a case of sortilege. (TA.)

lawo Ealima Aln-aAsu maA fiI AlSaf-i AlOaw-ali laQqotataluwA Ealayohi wamaA taqad-amuwA Uil-aA binuHobapK [If men knew what advantage is attained by being in the first row of the congregation in the mosque, they would fight for it, and not advance but by lot]. (TA, from a trad.)
nuHaAbN A cough that attacks camels: as also quHaAbN and nuHaAzN. (Az from AZ.) See 1.
naAHibapN ‡ A weeping, or wailing, woman: pl. nawaAHibu. (TA.)

saAra sayorFA munaH-ibFA He proceeded, or journeyed, in a direct course, not desiring [to pursue] any other: as though he had made a vow to do so. El-Kumeyt says,
taxacona binaA EaroDa AlfalaApi waTuwlahaA
kamaA SaAra Eano yumonaI yadayohi AlmunaH-ibu
By AlmnH-b is meant the man. ISd says, Th cites this verse, and says in explanation of it, This was a man who swore, saying, If I do not overcome, I will cut off my hand. He seems to consider it as implying the signification of vowing. So in the L. But it requires consideration. (TA.)
sironaA UilayohaA valaAva layaAlK munaH-ibaAtK We proceeded, or journeyed, thither during three nights of laborious travelling. (TA.)

1. naHata, aor. _i {yanoHitu}, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) contr. to analogy, (TA,) and _a, (L, Ḳ,) which is the form preferred by IJ, because of the guttural letter, but this is disputed by MF, (TA,) and _u, (Ḳ,) which is the form of weakest authority, (TA,) inf. n. naHotN, (Ṣ,) He cut, or hewed; formed, or fashioned, by cutting; cut out, hewed out, or shaped out; chipped: syn. baraI: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he worked wood and the like as a carpenter; syn. najara: he pared, peeled, barked, or deprived of its outer covering by paring, abrasure, or wearing away the exterior: he sawed. (L.) [See also laHata.] Accord. to some, the operation termed nHt is only performed upon something hard and strong, as stone and wood and the like. (MF.) [AntHt↓ seems to signify He cut,, &c., for himself:] you say, AinotaHito mina AlxaXabi maA yakofiyka lilowaquwdi [Cut, or hew, for thyself, of the wood, what will suffice thee for fuel]: (A.)

naHata bayotFA fiI Aljabali, aor. _i {yanoHitu} and _a {yanoHatu}, inf. n. naHotN, He cut out, or hewed out, a house in the mountain. In the Ḳur, xv. 82, El-Ḥasan [El-Basree] reads yanoHatuwna. (Mṣb.) [Accord. to the Ḳ, his reading is yanoHaAtuwna, (in the CK, tanoHaAtuwna,) but this I find nowhere else, and I believe it to be a mistake.]
nuHita EalaI Alkarami ‡ [He was fashioned after the model of generosity; made by nature generous]. (A.)
naHata Inivit puellam: (Ḳ:) as also laHata; but the latter is the better known. (TA.)
naHata, inf. n. naHotN, ‡ He beat, struck, or smote, him with a staff, or stick: (TA:) [as also laHata].
naHata He threw him down prostrate. (Ḳ.)
naHata bilisaAnihi ‡ He blamed; reprehended; reviled a man. (L.) [See also laHata.]
naHata ‡ It (a journey, or travel,) emaciated a camel: (Ḳ:) it made a man less; made him thin, or slender. (TA.)
naHata, (TA,) [aor. _i {yanoHitu} and _a {yanoHatu}?] inf. n. naHiytN and naHiytapN, He sighed aloud: the inf. ns. syn. with naYiytN and zaHiyrN. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1.

AntHt It (wood or the like) was [cut, or hewn; formed, or fashioned, by cutting; cut out, hewed out, or shaped out; chipped;] worked by a carpenter: [pared, peeled, barked, or deprived of its outer covering: sawn]. (L.)
AntHt manaAsimuhu ‡ His (a camel's) mnAsm [i. e. toes or feet] were worn, abraded, wasted, lessened, or attenuated. (L.)

hom.sense: naHotN and naHaAtN↓ (Ḳ) and naHiytapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) ‡ Nature; natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other property; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a particular cast, or fashion, of constitution, after which a man is [as it were] cut out [by the Creator]: (TA:) and the first, the source, or origin, from which one is [as it were] cut out: [see also manoHatN↓]. (Lḥ.)
Alkaramu mino naHotihi Generosity is [a part] of his nature; or, [derived] from his source. or origin. (Lḥ.)
hawu Eajiybu Aln-aHoti He is of a wonderful nature. (TA.)
hawu kariymu Aln-aHiytapi↓ He is generous in nature, or disposition. (AZ.)
barodN naHotN Unmixed [i. e. sever] cold: (Ḳ:) but this is said to be a corruption of baHotN. (TA.) [See also laHotN.]
naHiytN A comb: syn. muXoTN or maXoTN. (So in different copies of the Ḳ.)

HaAfirN naHiytN A hoof of which the edges have gone [or become abraded, been worn away]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [and so HAfr manoHawtN↓, occurring in the Ḳ in art. Hk, where, in its place in the Ṣ, we find HAfr naHiytN.]
naHiytN ‡ An emaciated camel: (Ḳ:) a camel whose feet are worn, abraded, or wasted. (L.)
naHiytapN↓ A [portion of the] trunk of a tree, which is hewn out, and hollowed, in the form of a jar such as is called Hub-, for bees: pl. nuHutN. (L.)
naHiytN Anything bad; what is bad of anything. (L.)
naHiytN One who introduces himself among a people, and lives with them, not being of their race. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: naHaAtN: see naHotN.
nuHaAtapN Cuttings, chips, parings, and the like, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of wood [&c.]. (TA.)
naHiytapN: see naHotN and naHiytN.
manoHatN ‡ The source, or origin, of a man, [from which he is, as it were, cut out]: pl. manaAHitu. (TA.) See also naHotN.
huwa mino manoHati SidoqK He is of an excellent source, or origin. (A.)
humo kiraAmu AlmanaAHiti They are of generous sources, or origins. (A.)
minoHatN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and minoHaAtN↓ (Mṣb, TA) An implement with which one performs the operation of cutting, hewing, and the like; (Ṣ, Ḳ, L;) an adz, or addice. (Mṣb.)
minoHaAtN: see minoHatN.
farasN munaH-atu AlHawaAfiri [A horse having the hoofs much worn.] (IDrd, Ḳ, art. Hk.)

hom.sense: manoHuwtN: see naHiytN.
A word compounded of two [or more] words; such as basomala, Hamodala, Hawoqala, Hasobala, &c. (Mṣb, TA, art. bsml.)

entry.sense: naHiyvN dial. form of naHiyfN: (Kr:) ISd thinks the v to be a substitute for f. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. naHara, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanoHaru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. naHorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and manoHarN (Mṣb) and tanoHaArN [an intensive form], (Ḳ,) He stabbed, or stuck, (A, Ḳ,) a camel, (A, TA,) or a beast, (Mṣb,) [but generally the former,] in his naHor, (A,) or in his manoHar, (TA,) where the windpipe (Huloquwm) commences in the uppermost part of the breast; (Ḳ, TA;) [i. e., in the lab-ap; for] naHorN in the lab-ap is like caboHN in the throat. (Ṣ.) [Hence,] yawomN Aln-aHori [The day of the stabbing of the camels, &c.]; (Ḳ;) and Eiydu Aln-aHori [the festival of the stabbing of the camels, &c.]; (Mṣb;) the tenth of [the month] Dhu-l-Hijjeh; (Ḳ;) because then the camels and cows and bulls brought as offerings to Mekkeh, for sacrifice, are stabbed. (TA.)
He slew. (TA.)
naHarahu, aor. and inf. ns. as above, He hit, or hurt, his naHor. (Ḳ.) You say naHarotu Alr-ajula I hit, or hurt, the naHor of the man. (Ṣ.)

[Hence,] naHara AlOumuwra EilomFA ‡ [He mastered affairs, or the affairs, by knowledge, or science]: (A): he knew affairs soundly, or thoroughly. (Ḥar, 2nd ed. of Paris, p. 95, Com.) And yanoHaru AlEiloma naHorFA ‡ [He masters knowledge, or science, indeed]. (A, Ḳ.) Jereer was asked respecting the Islámee poets, and answered, naboEapu AlX-uEaraMCi lilofarazodaqi [meaning, “The bow,” or “the arrow, of the poets belongs to El-Farezdaḳ;” applying the term nbEp in this manner because bows and arrows were made of the tree called naboE]: so it was said, “Then what hast thou left for thyself?” and he answered, OanaA naHarotu AlX-iEora naHorFA ‡ [I have mastered poetry indeed]. (A.) You say also, naHarotu AlX-aIoCa EilomFA † I knew the thing thoroughly, or superlatively well; as also qatalotuhu EilomFA. (Bḍ in iv. 156.)
[Hence also,] naHara AlS-alaApa ‡ He performed, or recited, the prayer in the first part of its time. (TA.)
naHarahumu Qll-ehu, occurring in a trad., may mean either † May God hasten to do them good, or may God slay them. (IAth.)

[Hence also,] naHarotu Alr-ajula, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. naHorN, (A,) ‡ I became opposite to the man; syn. Sirotu fiI naHorihi; (Ṣ;) I faced, or fronted, him; syn. qaAbalotuhu. (A, TA.) And naHara Ald-aAru Ald-aAra, [or naHarat,] (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanoHaru}, (TA,) ‡ The house faced, or fronted, the house; (Ḳ, TA;) as also naAHarat↓. (TA.) And diyaAruhumo tanoHaru AlT-ariyqa ‡ Their houses face, or front, the road. (A.) [See also 6.] And Abu-lGheyth says, that the last night of the month, with its day, is called Aln-aHiyrapu for this reason, liOan-ahaA tanoHaru AlX-ahora Ql-aciI baEodahaA, i. e., Because it becomes opposite to the month that is after it: or because it reaches the first part of the month that is after it. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1, near the end.

hom.sense: 6. tanaAHaruwA fiI AlqitaAli (Ṣ, TA) They stabbed one another in the naHor, or slew one another, in fight. Here the verb is used in its proper sense. (TA.)

[Hence,] tanaAHara Alqawomu EalaI AlOamori, (A, Ḳ,) and AntHrwA↓ Ealayohi, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) ‡ The people were mutually niggardly, or tenacious, or avaricious, of the thing, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) so that they almost slew one another. (Ḳ,* TA.)

Ald-aAraAni tatanaAHaraAni ‡ The two houses face, or front, each other. (Ḳ.) [The like is also said in the A.] Fr. says, I have heard some of the Arabs say manaAziluhumo tanaAHaru, [for tatanaAHaru,] ‡ Their places of abode face, or front, one another; this is opposite to this. (TA.)

8. AntHr He (a man, Ṣ) stabbed himself in the naHor, (Ṣ,) or slew himself. (Ḳ.) It is said in a proverb, suriqa Als-aAriqu faQnotaHara [The robber was robbed, and in consequence slew himself]: (Ṣ:) or saraqa Als-aAriqu faQnotaHara [app. meaning, ‡ The robber robbed, and so occasioned his own slaughter: for it is said that the verb is here used tropically]. (TA; and so in a copy of the Ṣ, and of the A.) [The former reading, which I prefer, is given in Freytag's Arab. Prov, q. v., vol. i. p. 618.]
‡ It (a cloud) burst with much water. (A.)
See also 6.

Aln-aHoru, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or naHoru AlS-adori, (A, Ḳ,) The uppermost part of the breast, or chest; (A, Ḳ;) as also AlmunoHuwru↓: (Sb, IB, Ḳ:) or the place of the collar or necklace: (A, Ḳ:) or that part of the breast or chest which is the place of the collar or necklace; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) so accord. to AʼObeyd: (TA, art. trb:) which is also called AlmanoHaru↓: (Ṣ:) or the breast or bosom or chest itself: (TA:) or Aln-uHuwru, the pl., is also applied to the breasts or chests: (Mṣb:) and Aln-aHoru, (A,) or AlmanoHaru↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) also signifies the part in which a camel is stabbed, or stuck; (A, TA; where the windpipe (Huloquwm) commences, in the uppermost part of the breast: (TA:) or the place where the hadoI [or animal brought as an offering to Mekkeh or to the Kaabeh or to the Haram, such as a camel, cow, bull, sheep, or goat, to be sacrificed,] &c., is stabbed, or stuck: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the place, in the throat, where a beast is stabbed, or stuck: Mṣb:) naHorN is masc., (Lḥ, Ḳ,) only: (Lḥ:) [or sometimes fem.: see an ex., voce tariba:] its pl. is nuHuwrN, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) only: (TA:) and the pl. of manoHarN↓ is manaAHiru. (A.)

naHorN also signifies ‡ The first, the first part, or the commencement, of the day; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and of the month, (Ḳ,) as also naAHirN↓; (TA;) and of the Zahiyrap, which is when the sun has reached its highest point, [especially in summer,] as though it had reached the naHorN, as also naAHirapN↓: (TA:) pl. nuHuwrN. (Ḳ.) You say jaMCa fiI naHori Aln-ahaAri, &c., ‡ He came in the first part of the day,, &c. (TA.) See also naHiyrapN.

Also, qaEada fulaAnN fiI naHori fulaAnK ‡ Such a one sat in front of such a one; facing him; opposite to him. (A.) And SaAra fiI naHorihi [‡ He, or it, became in front of, or opposite to, him, or it]. (Ṣ.) And hecaA binaHori hecaA ‡ This is in front of, facing, or opposite to, this. (Fr, TA.)

entry.sense: niHorN: see niHoriyrN.
laqiytuhu SaHorapF baHorapF naHorapF, with tenween, † I met him in open view. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) See baHorap and SaHorap.

niHoriyrN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and niHorN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ Soundly, or thoroughly, learned; (Ṣ;) or skilled or skilful, intelligent, experienced, (A, Ḳ, TA,) or, as some say, (TA,) sound in what he does, skilful and intelligent, knowing and skilful in everything: because he masters (yanoHaru) knowledge or science: (A, Ḳ, TA:) pl. of the former, naHaAriyru. (A.)

hom.sense: naHiyrN A camel [or other beast] stabbed, or stuck, (Ḳ. TA,) in the manoHar, (TA,) where the windpipe (Huloquwm) commences, in the uppermost part of the breast; (Ḳ, TA;) and manoHuwrN↓ signifies [the same: and] slaughtered: (TA:) the former is masc. and fem., and the fem. is also naHiyrapN: (TA:) pl. of nHyr, (Ḳ,) and of nHyrp, (TA,) naHoraI and nuHaraMCu and naHaAYiru. (Ḳ, TA.)
‡ A son devoted to be sacrificed: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (Mgh.)

Aln-aHiyrapu↓ ‡ The first day of the month; [as also, app., naHoru↓ AlX-ahori, and naAHiratuhu↓, and naHiyratuhu↓:] or the last thereof; (Ḳ;) as also Aln-aAHiru↓: (TA:) or the last night thereof; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Aln-aHiyrN: (Ḳ:) or the last night thereof with its day [i. e. the day immediately following]; as also Aln-aAHirapu↓; because it becomes opposite to that which is next after it, or because it reaches to the first part thereof [or of the following month]: (Abu-l-Gheyth, Ṣ:)
pl. nawaAHiru (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naAHiraAtN, (Ḳ,) both extr. [as pls. of naHiyrapN, but reg. as pls. of naAHirapN], (TA,) [and app. naHaAYiru, being agreeable with rule as pl. of naHiyrapN: or] naHaAYiru AlX-ahori signifies i. q. nuHuwruhu: see naHorN. (TA.) You say also jaMCa fiI naHori AlX-ahori, and naAHiratihi, and naHiyratihi, ‡ [app. signifying He came on the first day of the month.] And maA OaraAhu Uil-aA fiI nuHuwri AlX-uhuwri, and nawaAHirihaA, and naHaAYirihaA, ‡ [app., I see him not save on the first days of the months.] (A.)

entry.sense: naHiyrapN: see naHiyrN.
naH-aArN: see minoHaArN.

hom.sense: naAHrN and naAHirapN: see naHorN and naHiyrN.
nawaAHiru AlOaroDi, [pl. of naAHirapN,] ‡ The parts facing, in front of, or opposite to, the earth or land. (TA.)

entry.sense: AlmanoHaru: see Aln-aHoru, in two places.

hom.sense: manoHuwrN: see naHiyrN.
‡ Faced, or fronted. (TA.)

entry.sense: Almunoxuwru: see Aln-aHoru.

1. naHisa, aor. _a {yanoHasu}; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and naHusa, aor. _u {yanoHusu}; (Ḳ;) and naHisu, like [its contr.] suEida; (Bḍ, xvii. 30;) inf. n. [of the first] naHasN and [of the second] nuHuwsapN; (TA;) He, or it, was, or became, unprosperous, unfortunate, inauspicious, or unlucky: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) said of a man, (A, Bḍ,) and of a star, (TA,) or other thing. (Ṣ, TA.)
4. OanoHasati Aln-aAru The fire had much nuHaAs, i. e., smoke. (IḲṭṭ.)
6: see 8.
8. AntHs He became overthrown, or subverted; as also tnAHs↓. And the former is also said of a man's jad- [or good fortune]. (A, TA.)

naHosN Unprosperousness, unfortunateness, inauspiciousness, or unluckiness; contr. of saEodN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) of stars, and of other things:pl. [of pauc.] OanoHusN and [of mult.] nuHuwsN; (TA;) and manaAHisu is an irreg. pl. of the same, (TA,) syn. with maXaAYimu, (IDrd, Ḳ, TA,) which is in like manner an irreg. pl. of XuWomN. (TA.) [In Ḥar, p. 375, a doubt is expressed respecting manaAHisu, as to its being a pl. of naHosN; but only from ignorance of their being any authority for its being so: it may, however, be pl. of manoHasapN, and not of naHosN.] In the Ḳur, [liv. 19,] some read, fI yawomi naHosK [In a day of unprosperousness]: others read nHs as an epithet. (Ṣ.) See naHisN.
Also, Difficulty, distress, trouble, or fatigue; harm, injury, or evil state or condition; syn. jahodN and Dur-N: pl. OanoHusN. (TA.)

naHisN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and naHosN↓ (Ṣ, A) and naHiysN↓ (TA) and naHuwsN↓ and munoHuwsN↓ (A, TA) Unprosperous, unfortunate, inauspicious, or unlucky. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) You say, rajulN naHisN and naHosN (A) and manoHuwsN (A, TA) [An unprosperous man]: pl. of the last, manaAHiysu. (TA.) And yawomN naHosN (Ṣ, A, TA) [and naHisN] and naHuwsN (A, TA) and naHiysN and manoHuwsN (TA) [An unprosperous day]: and in the pl., Oay-aAmN naHosN, [which seems to indicate that naHosN is originally an inf. n.,] (TA,) and naHosapN, and naHosaAtN, which is pl. of naHosapN, (Az, TA,) and naHisapN, (Ḳ,) and [its pl.] naHisaAtN, (Ṣ, TA,) and naHiysapN, (Ḳ.) [and app. naAHisapN↓,] and [its pl.] nawaAHisu. (TA.) In the Ḳur, [liv. 19,] some read, fiI yawomK naHosK↓ [In an unprosperous day], as well as fiI yawomi naHosK: (Ṣ, TA:) and AA reads [in the Ḳur, xli. 15,] fiI Oay-aAmK naHosaAtK: and naHisaAtK is another reading. (TA.) You also say, EaAmN naAHisN↓ and naHiysN↓, meaning, ‡ A year of dearth or drought or sterility: (IDrd, Ḳ:) so they assert. (IDrd.) And Aln-aHosaAni↓ is an appellation of The two planets Saturn and Mars: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) like as [the contr.] Als-aEodaAni is applied to Venus and Mercury. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

hom.sense: naHaAsN: see nuHaAsN:
and niHaAsN.

nuHaAsN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and niHaAsN↓ (Fr, Ḳ) and naHaAsN↓, (Ḳ,) the last, (TA,) or all, (Ḳ,) on the authority of Abu-l-ʼAbbás El-Kawáshee, (Ḳ,) a word of well-known meaning; (Ṣ;) Copper: and brass; syn. qiTorN: (Ḳ:) or SuforN: (Ibn-Buzurj:) or a species of Sufor intensely red: (TA:) a chaste Arabic word. (TA.)

Also, Fire: (IF, Ḳ:) and the sparks that fall from brass (Sufor), or from iron, when it is beaten (AO, Ḳ) with the hammer: (TA:) or nuHaAsN signifies smoke: so in the Ḳur, lv. 35: (Fr, Az, Bḍ, and others; accord. to Az, all the interpreters of the Ḳur.; and it is wonderful that the author of the Ḳ has omitted this signification: TA:) but some say that it is niHaAsN↓ signifies the smoke of Sufor; and nuHaAsN signifies Sufor itself: (Ibn-Buzurj:) or the latter signifies smoke in which is no flame: (Ṣ, Jel:) or smoke that rises high, and of which the heat is weak, and which is free from flame: (AḤn:) or molten Sufor: (Bḍ:) and some read nuHusN, which is the pl. (Bḍ.)
See also niHaAsN.

niHaAsN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and nuHaAsN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naHaAsN↓ (Ḳ, but excluded by the TA) Nature; natural, or native, disposition or temper or other quality or property: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) and origin: (Ṣ, A, TA:) or that to which the origin of a thing reaches. (IAạr, Ḳ.) You say, fulaAnN kariymu Aln-iHaAsi, (Ṣ, A,) and Aln-uHaAsi↓, (Ṣ,) Such a one is generous of nature,, &c., and origin. (Ṣ, A.)
See also nuHaAsN, in two places.

entry.sense: naHuwsN: see naHisN, throughout.
naHiysN: see naHisN, throughout.
[naH-aAsN A worker of copper or brass: a coppersmith.]
naAHisN: see naHisN, in two places.
manHasN A place of unprosperousness, unfortunateness, inauspiciousness, or unluckiness: pl. manaAHisu. (Ḥar, p. 374.)
manoHasapN [A cause of unprosperousness, unfortunateness, inauspiciousness, or unluckiness: pl., accord. to rule, manaAHisu]. (A, TA, art. tEs.)
manoHawsN: see naHisN, in three places.
manaAHisu: see naHosN, manoHasN, and manoHasapN.
1. nax-a, [aor., accord. to analogy, _i,] inf. n. nax-N; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and naxonaxa↓; (IAạr, Ḳ;) He went, or journeyed, vehemently. (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nax-a, aor. _u {yanoxuxu}, (L,) inf. n. nax-a, (Ṣ, L,) He drove, and urged, and chid, camels: (L:) he drove vehemently. (Th, Ṣ.)

nax-a biAlUibili, (Lth,)) [aor. _u {yanoxuxu},] inf. n. nax-N; (Lth, Ḳ;) and naxonaxa↓ bihaA; (AM;) and naxonaxahaA; (Lth;) He chid the camels by the cry of Uix-o Uix-o (or Uixo Uixo, as in the CK and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ: in the L written once Ax- Ax-, and twice Axo Axo:) in order that they might lie down upon their breasts, with folded legs: (Lth, AM, L, Ḳ:) you say nax-a bihaA nax-FA XadiydFA, and nax-apF XadiydapF, he did so vehemently. (Lth.)
Also, nxnx↓, (inf. n. naxonaxapN, Lth,) He made a camel to lie down upon its breast, with folded legs- (IAạr, Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nax-a AlUibila, and nax-a bihaA, [aor. _u {yanoxuxu},] inf. n. nax-N, He made the camels to lie down near by the collector of the alms required by the law, called Sadaqap, that he might take them in payment of those alms. (L.)
R. Q. 1: see 1.
R. Q. 2. tanaxonaxa It (a camel) lay down upon its breast, with its legs folded. (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, tnxnxt She, (a camel,) lying upon her breast, with her legs folded, raised her breast from the ground. (L.)

nax-N, [originally an inf. n., then used in the sense of a pass. part. n.,] Camels that are made to lie down near by the collector of the alms required by the law, called Sadaqap, that he may take them in payment of those alms. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nux-N and nuxaAxapN↓ (in the CK naxaAxapN) i. q. mux-N [Marrow, &c.]. (Ḳ.)
hecaA mino nux-i qalobiI, and nxAxpi↓ qalobiI, i. q. mn muH-i qlbI, and mux-atihi, q. v. (TA.)

nax-apN or nux-apN↓ or nix-apN↓, as occurring in the following words of a trad., layosa fiI Alnx-pi SadaqapN, [No alms are required by the law in the case of....,] is variously explained. (TA.) It is said that nax-apN signifies Slaves, (AO, Az, Ṣ, Ḳ,) men and women: (AO, Az:) also, a [single] male slave: (ISh:) also, working bulls or cows; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so nux-apN: (Ḳ:) Th says that this is the correct meaning, because it is from nax-N, signifying the “act of driving vehemently;” and Ks says that this is its meaning, but that it is only nux-apN, with damm: (Ṣ:) also, asses, HumurN, [in the CK, xamorN,] (IAạr, L, Ḳ,) collectively; (L;) and so nux-apN (L, Ḳ) and nix-apN: (Ḳ:) also, [animals] reared in houses or tents: (Ḳ:) also, whatever are employed in labour, of camels, and bulls or cows, and asses, and slaves; as also nux-apN: (Aboo-Saʼeed:) also, pastors; and so nux-apN: also, drivers, leaders, or attendants, of camels: (Ḳ:) also, the taking of a deenár for himself by the collector of the alms required by the law, called Sadaqap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) after he has finished receiving those alms: (Ṣ:) also, the deenár itself so taken is thus called. (Ḳ.) In all these senses the word nx-p is explained in the above trad. (TA.)
nux-apN and nix-apN: see nax-apN throughout.
nuxaAxapN: see nux-N.

hom.sense: 1. naxaba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanoxabu}, (Ṣ,) or _u, (Ḳ,) inf. n. naxob; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Antxb↓; (Ṣ;) He drew, or took, out, or forth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) syn. of the latter verb AntzE, (Ṣ,) in a trans. sense. (TA.)
naxaba AlS-ayoda He (a hawk) tore out the heart of the game. (TA.)
naxaba, aor. _a {yanoxabu} and _u {yanoxubu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. naxobN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Inivit feminam: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so accord. to some, in an absolute sense: (ISd:) or inivit feminam peculiari quodam modo. (ISd, Ḳ.)
naxaba, aor. _u {yanoxubu}, inf. n. naxobN, It (an ant, or a louse, TA) bit. (Ḳ.)
nuxibN He was cowardly, and his intellect quitted him; syn. hubita. (Ṣ, art. hbt.)
kal-amotuhu fanuxiba Ean-iI I spoke to him, and he was unable to reply to me: syn. kal-a Eano jawaAbiI. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Anxb (as also Anjb, TA) He begot a cowardly son: (Ḳ:) from manoxuwbN. (TA.)
Anxb He begot a brave, or courageous, son: (Ḳ:) from nuxabapN. (TA.) Thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.) See also Anjb.
5: see 8.
8: See 1.

Antxbhu [and tnx-bhu↓, as is shown by a verse cited in art. sqb, conj. 4,] He chose, selected, or preferred, him, or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. Antxb mina Alqawomi miAYap rajulK He chose, or selected, from the people a hundred men. (TA, from a trad.)
10. Astnxbt Congressum viri concupivit femina. (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: naxobN, (Ḳ,) or naxobapN↓, (L, confirmed by the citation of two examples in verse,) and manoxabapN↓ (Ḳ) and yanoxuwbapN (L) The podex: syn. UisotN. (L, Ḳ.)
naxobN Foramen vulvæ feræ: syn. xrq Alvfr. (TA.)
naxobapN Foramen pudendi: syn. xrq Aljld. (Nh.)
naxobN Cowardice; weakness of heart. (TA.) See naxibN.
naxobN A large draught; i. q. Pers. duwsotokaAniI [dóst-kánee]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: naxabN: see naxibN.

naxibN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naxobN↓ and naxobapN↓ (so accord. to the TA: in the CK nuxobapN:) and nuxobapN↓ (in the CK nuxabapN↓) and nixab-N↓ and nixib-N↓ (Ḳ) and naxiybN↓ and manoxuwbN↓ and munotaxabN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and yanoxuwbN↓, (Ḳ,) to which the CK adds naxabN↓, A cowardly man; a coward; as though his heart were drawn out; (Ṣ;) i. e., having no heart. (TA.) qalobN naxiybN↓ [A cowardly heart]: nxyb signifies a coward, who has no heart: or, accord. to some, one who acts corruptly. (TA.) Pl. (of nxyb↓, TA,) nuxubN: (Ḳ:) of mnxwb↓, manoxuwbuwna, and sometimes, in poetry, accord. to IAth, manaAxibu: and Aboo-Bekr mentions nxbAt as a pl. of nxbp. (TA.)

hom.sense: naxobapN: see naxobN and naxibN.
naxobapu namolapK, and najobapu nmlp, q. v., A bite of an ant. Both these modes of writing the word are mentioned by IAth on the authority of Z.

entry.sense: nuxobapN: see naxibN and nuxabapN.

nuxabapN (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuxobapN↓ (AM, Ḳ), the former the more approved word, (TA,) Chosen; choice; select; preferred; excellent; best: or what is chosen, &c.: (Ḳ:) i. q. nujabapN, q. v.: (Ṣ:) pl. of the former nuxabN. (Ṣ.) Ex. jaACa fI nuxabi OaSoHaAbihi He came with the best of his companions. (Ṣ.) nxbpu AlmataAEi The choice part of the goods, or utensils, &c.; what was drawn, or taken, out from them. (TA.)
A company, or troop, chosen, or selected, and drawn out, from the men. Ex., from a trad., xarajonaA fiI Aln-uxabapi We went forth with the chosen band. (TA.)
See naxibN.
nixab-N and nixib-N and naxiybN: see naxibN.
nixaAbN The skin of the heart. (TA.)
manoxabapN: see naxobN.
minoxaAbN syn. with minojaAbN; (TA;) A weak man, in whom is no good: (Ḳ:) pl. manaAxiybu, and sometimes, in poetry, manaAxibu. (TA.)
manoxuwbN Lean; meagre; emaciated. (Ḳ.)
See naxibN.
munotaxabN: see naxibN.
yanoxuwbN: see naxibN.
yanoxuwbapN: see naxobN.

hom.sense: 1. naxata, inf. n. naxotN, He pecked, or picked up, and pulled off, or tore off, and snatched away, with his beak; syn. naqara and nataxa, (Ḳ,) formed by transposition. (TA.)
naxata, [aor. _u {yanoxutu},] inf. n. naxotN, He took a date, or two dates, from a bag or other receptacle for travelling-provisions, &c. (Ḳ.)
naxata, [aor. _u {yanoxutu},] inf. n. naxotN, He plucked out; syn. natafa. (IAth, L.)
See 2.

entry.sense: 2. nix-t lifulaAnK, as also sx-t lahu, He went to the utmost length (AstqSI) in speaking to such a one. So in the Nawádir. (Az, L.) [Accord. to the Ḳ, naxata↓, inf. n. naxotN.]
naxotapN namolapK A bite of an ant. So in a trad., accord. to one reading: accord. to another reading, it is najobapu [q. v.]. (L.)

1. naxaja Ald-alowa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and naxaja bihaA, (TA,) aor. _a {yanoxaju}, inf. n. naxojN, (Ḳ,) He agitated, or moved about, the bucket; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a dial. form of maxaja; (Ṣ;) or, accord. to Yaạḳoob, its n is substituted for m: he moved about the bucket in the well in order that it might fill. (TA.)
naxaja, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanoxaju} (Ḳ) and _u {yanoxuju}, (L,) inf. n. naxojN, (Ḳ,) Inivit feminam. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

naxiyjapN, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, accord. to some, najiyjN, without p, (TA,) or, as some say, najiyxapN, and (says J) I know not which is right, (Ṣ,) Thin butter which comes forth from the skin when it is carried on a camel, after the first butter has been taken forth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naxara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoxuru} (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i {yanoxiru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naxiyrN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and naxorN, (CK, but omitted in MṢ. copies of the Ḳ,) said of a horse, (Aṣ, TA,) and of an ass, (A, TA,) and of a man, (TA,) [He snorted; and he snored;] he made a sound, or noise, with the nose; (Ṣ;) he made a sound, or noise, from his nose; he prolonged the breath from the xayaAXiym [or air-passages of the nose]; (Mṣb;) he made a sound, or noise, from his xyAXym, as though it were a musical note issuing convulsively; (TA;) he uttered a prolonged sound, or noise, from his xyAXym: (A, Ḳ:) the sound which horses make, termed naxiyrN, is from the nostrils; that termed XaxiyrN, from the mouth; and that termed kariyrN, from the chest. (Aṣ, in TA, art. Xxr.) You also say of a woman naxarato, aor. _u {yanoxuru} and _i {yanoxiru}, (L,) or _a, (so in the TA,) meaning, She made the same noise, [i. e., she snorted,] in the act of concubitus, as though she were possessed. (L, TA.)

naxira, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanoxaru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. naxarN, (Mṣb,) It (a thing, Ṣ, or a bone, Mṣb, TA, and wood, TA) became old and wasted and crumbling; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) it became old and wasted and soft, crumbling when touched. (TA.)

entry.sense: naxirN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and naAxirN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) A bone, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and wood, (TA,) old and wasted and crumbling; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) old and wasted and soft, crumbling when touched: (TA:) fem. of each with p {naxirapN and naAxirapN}: (Ḳ:) or the former signifies a bone old and wasted: (Ḳ:) and the latter, a hollow bone, having a hole passing through it, (Ḳ, TA,) whence comes, when the wind blows, a sound like that which is termed naxiyrN; [see naxara;] (TA;) a bone into which the wind enters and whence it then issues with the sound so termed; (Ṣ;) a bone, and wood, in which the wind makes the sound so termed. (A.) Of the two readings, in the Ḳur, [lxxix. 11,] EiZaAmFA naAxirapF and EiZaAmFA naxirapF, Fr prefers the former, as agreeable in form with the words ending the other verses; and he says that naAxirapN and naxirapN are the same in meaning, like TaAmiEN and TamiEN. (TA.)

hom.sense: nuxorapN ‡ A vehement blowing of the wind. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

Also, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and nuxarapN↓, (Ṣ,) The fore part of the nose, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., the head thereof, [or the flexible part,] of a man, (TA,) and of a horse, and of an ass, and of a pig, (Ṣ,) and of a sheep or goat, and of a she-camel: (TA:) or the hole thereof; (Ḳ;) i. q. manoxirN↓: (A:) or the part between the two nostrils: or the end, or tip, of the nose: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, the nose itself: (A, TA:) whence the saying, (TA,) hXm nuxoratahu He broke his nose. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: nuxarapN: see nuxorapN.

hom.sense: naAxirN Making the sound termed naxiyrN: see 1. (TA.)
maA bihaA naAxirN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., biAld-aAri, (A,) ‡ There is not any one in it, (El-Báhilee, Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., in the house. (A.)
See also naxirN.

entry.sense: manojarN, munoxurN and minoxirN: see manoxirN.
manoxirN, [the most common form,] originally, The place of the sound termed naxiyrN. See 1. (Mṣb.)

And hence, (Mṣb,) The hold of the nose; the nostril; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also minoxirN↓, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with kesr to the m to agree with the vowel of the x, like as they say minotinN [for munotinN], (Ṣ, Mṣb,) both of which words are extr., as mifoEilN is not one of the [regular] measures, (Ṣ,) and it is said that there is no word of this measure beside these two, (Mṣb,) or minoxirN↓ is for minoxiyrN↓, and in like manner minotinN is for minotiynN, which is the original form, (T, TA,) and minoxarN↓ and munoxurN↓ (Ḳ) and munoxuwrN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like EuSofuwrN (Mṣb) and mulomuwlN, (Ḳ, [in the CK, erroneously, malomuwl]) which last is [said to be] of the dial. of Teiyi, (Mṣb,) and said to occur in a verse of Gheylán, but IB says that the right reading is manoHuwr, with H, syn. with naHorN: (Ṣgh, in art. nHr; and L, in the present art.) pl. manaAxiru and manaAxiyru; (Mṣb;) [the latter irreg., unless pl. of minoxiyrN or munoxuwrN.]
minoxaArN A man who makes the sound termed naxiyrN [see naxara] in the act of concubitus: (TA:) and a woman who does so in that act, as though she were possessed. (Ḳ.)
munoxuwrN: see manoxirN.
minoxiyrN: see manoxirN.
Q. 1. naxoraba It (a canker-worm) pierced holes in, or eroded, a tree. (Ḳ.) IJ derives this verb from xaraAbN, (TA,) q. v.

nuxoruwbN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) mentioned in the Ḳ without description of its measure because there is no Arabic word of the measure faEoluwlo; but some prefer it being written naxoruwbN, [as it is in the CK,] asserting its n to be augmentative, so that its measure is nafoEuwlN, as IAạr holds, asserting it to be derived from xaraAbN; (TA;) A fissure, or cleft, in a stone. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, [so in the TA: in the CK and a MṢ. copy, or,] A hole, perforation, or bore, in anything. (Ḳ.) Pl. naxaAriybu. (Ṣ.)
Also, the pl., The holes, or cells, prepared with wax for the bees to deposit their honey therein: (Ḳ:) holes like the cells of wasps. (L.)

naxorabuwtN [i. q. taxorabuwtN] An excellent, nimble, or agile, she-camel. Some say that its n is augmentative, and its radical letters are xrb; but its derivation from xaraAbN is not apparent; therefore its n should be considered as radical. (AḤei.)
XajarapN munaxoribapN, and munaxorabapN, A tree that is old and pierced with holes. (Ḳ.)

1. naxasahu, aor. _u {yanoxusu}, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and _a, (Lḥ, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and _i, (Lḥ, TA,) inf. n. naxosN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He goaded, or pricked, him, namely, a beast, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with a stick (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the like, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the hinder part, or the side, (A, Ḳ,) so that he became excited. (Mṣb.)
naxasa bihi He goaded his beast. (Mgh.)
naxasuwA bihi, (A, L, TA,) or naxasuwhu, (Ḳ,) They goaded his (a man's) beast, and drove him (the man) away; (A, L, TA;) they drove him away, goading his camel with him. (Ḳ.)
And naxasa biAlr-ajuli † He excited, or roused, the man, and disquieted, or disturbed, him. (L, TA.)

You say also, Oanoxasa↓ bihi, meaning, OaboEadahu ‡ [He put him, or sent him, away, or far away]. (A, TA.) [Or perhaps the right reading is Uinoxaso bihi,] meaning, OaboEidohu [Put thou him, or send thou him, away, or far away: as seems to be indicated by what immediately follows in those two works and here.] And takal-ama fanaxasuwA bihi ‡ [app. meaning He spoke, and they put him away]. (A, TA.)
4: see 1.
nixaAsapN and naxaAsapN The trade of selling beasts: and the trade of selling slaves. (Ḳ.)
nax-aAsN A goader of beasts. (Mṣb.)

And hence, (Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb,) A seller of beasts; (Ḳ;) one who acts as a broker for the sale of beasts (Mgh, Mṣb) and the like: (Mṣb:) and a seller of slaves: (Ḳ;) sometimes used in the latter sense: (TA:) a genuine Arabic word. (IDrd.)

1. nad-a, aor. _i {yanodidu}, inf. n. nad-N (Ṣ, M, A, &c.,) and nidaAdN and nuduwdN (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and nadiydN; (M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and tnAd-↓; (M, L;) He (a camel) took fright, or shied, and fled, or ran away at random, or became refractory, and went away at random; or ran away, or broke loose, and went hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness. (Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.) See also 6, below.
Also nad-a, contr., It (a people) assembled. ('Ináyeh, MF.)
nad-a It (a word) deviated from the constant course of speech; like Xac-a; as some say; as mentioned by El-Fárisee: but it is not of good authority, nor agreeable with the usage of Sb. (M, L.)

hom.sense: 2: see 4.
nd-d, inf. n. tanodiydN, He raised his voice. (L.)
nd-d He raised his voice in saying of another that which he (the latter) disliked. (Lth, in L, art. Xyd.) See 4 in art. Xyd.
nd-d bihi, (inf. n. tanodiydN, L.) He declared, or exposed, his vices, or faults; (M, L, Ḳ;) in verse or prose; (M, L;) he rendered him notorious, or infamous. (AZ, Ṣ, L.)
He made him to hear what was bad, evil, abominable, or foul: (AZ, T, M, L, Ḳ.) he reviled him. (AZ, T, L.)

entry.sense: 3. nAd-hu He opposed him, oppugned him. (L, Ḳ.)
4. And- and nd-d↓ He dispersed camels. (M, L, Ḳ.)

6. tnAd-wA They dispersed themselves, and betook themselves away. (Ḳ.) [See also 1.] Hence, yawomu Alt-anaAd-i (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) [The day of men's dispersing themselves, and betaking themselves in different directions], applied to the day of resurrection: (M, L:) so in the Ḳur, [xl. 34,] accord. to the reading of some; (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ;) namely El-ʼAbbás and others: (Ḳ:) Az says, accord. to the reading of Eḍ-Ḍaḥḥák only: (L:) others read Alt-anaAdi; which may also be from nd-; one of the dáls being changed into I, and being then elided: (T, L:) or this may be from Aln-idaMCu: (M:) or ywm AltnAd- may mean the day of men's assembling themselves together, from nad-a signifying “it (a people) assembled.” ('Ináyeh MF.)

hom.sense: nad-N (and nid-N↓, M, L,) A certain kind of perfume, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) with which one fumigates: (Lth, M, L:) a certain wood with which one fumigates: (Mṣb:) or, as some say, i. q. gaAliyapN: or, as Z says, in the Rabeea el-Abrár, a compound of aloes-wood aromatized with musk and ambergris and nAn: (TA:) or (accord. to Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà, T, L) ambergris, EanobarN: (T, L:) or EabiyrN [i. e., either saffron, or a certain mixture of perfumes: so in the copy of the T used by the author of the TT, if correctly transcribed by him:] it is not Arabic: (Ṣ:) or is thought by IDrd to be not genuine Arabic: (M, L,) many of the lexicologists, however, hold it to be genuine Arabic; and it occurs in verses of old poets; (MF;) but this does not prove that it is not an arabicized word. (TA.)
nad-N A high hill; (Ḳ;) a hill rising high into the sky: (Ṣ, L:) of the dial. of El-Yemen: (L:) a great hill (Oakamap) of clay or loam. (Ḳ.)

nid-N and nadiydN↓ and nadiydapN↓ A like (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) of a person or thing: (L:) or a like of a thing by participation of substance; a more special term than mivolN, which signifies “a like by participation of anything:” (the ḳádee Zekereeyà, MF:) or a thing which does, or may, supply, the place of another thing: (TA:) or a like that is contrary, or opposed, to another thing; (Mṣb;) that opposes it (yunaHAd-uhu, i. e., yuxaAlifuhu,) in its circumstances; (L;) syn. with Did-N and XibohN: (Akh:) and hence the first is applied to an idol; a thing taken as an object of worship instead of the true God: (L:) pl. of the first, OanodaAdN; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and of the second, nudadaMCu; and of the third, nadaAYidu. (Ḳ.) You say, huwa nid-u fulaAnK, and nadiyduhu, and nadyidatohu, He is the like of such a one: (L:) and hiIa nid-u fulaAnapa, (ISh, L, Ḳ,) She is the like of such a female; (ISh, L;) but not nid-u fulaAnK. (ISh, L, Ḳ.) You also say huwa nid-iI, and nadiydiI, meaning He is my opponent with respect to the course that I would pursue, contending with me for a different course. (AHeyth, T, L.)
See nad-N.

entry.sense: naduwdN A she-camel wont to take fright, or shy, and run away, at random;, &c.: see 1. (M, L.)
nadiydN and nadiydapN: see nid-N.

hom.sense: naAd-N, act. part. n. of nad-a, A camel taking fright, or shying, and running away, at random;, &c.: pl. nidaAdN: (Mṣb, TA:) and quasi pl. n. nadadN; (L;) signifying camels in a state of dispersion. (L, Ḳ.)
layosa lahu naAd-N He has not any means of subsistence: (Ḳ:) app. meaning live stock; from nad-a, said of a camel. (TA.)
[See also XaAc-N, and AaXac-ahu.]

entry.sense: TayorN OanaAdiydu, and yanaAdiydu, Birds in a state of dispersion: (M, L:) [like OabaAdiydu and yabaAdiydu or tabaAdiydu: see an ex. in art. bd].
cahabuwA OanaAdiyda, and yanaAdiydu, (L, and some copies of the Ḳ,) or tanaAdiyda, (as in other copies of the Ḳ,) They (a people, L) became dispersed in every direction. (L, Ḳ.)
munad-a A voice raised high in calling. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. nadaOa, aor. _a {yanodaOu}, He hated a thing: or it is a mistake for nacaOa. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nadaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanodaOu}, inf. n. nadoCN (TA) He cast flesh-meat into the fire: (Ḳ:) or he buried it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a cake of bread, (Ṣ,) in hot ashes, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) that it might become thoroughly cooked, or baked. (Ṣ.)
nadaOa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. nadoCN, (TA,) He frightened. (Ḳ.)
nadaOa He cast a person upon the ground. (Ḳ.)
nadaOa Ealayohimo He came forth upon them. (Ḳ.)
nadaOa Almal-apa He made, or prepared, the kind of fire called ml-p. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: Q. Q. 1. nawodaOa, inf. n. nawodaOapN, He ran, with a slack pace: syn. EadaA. (Ḳ.)
nadoOapN: see nudoOapN.

hom.sense: nudoOapN and nadoOapN↓ Abundance of wealth, or of camels, or sheep, &c.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like nudohapN and nadohapN: (Ṣ:) by some explained as consisting of twenty sheep or goats. (MF.)
Also, both words, The rainbow: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) also called nadiIoCN↓. (Ḳ.)

Also, both words, A redness in the clouds towards the setting or rising of the sun: (Ḳ:) or a redness by the side of the sun at its rising or setting: (TA:) or, by the side of the place of its rising or setting: (T:) also called nadiIoCN↓. (Ḳ.)
Also, both words, A halo, or circle, round the sun or moon. (Ḳ.)

Also, the former word, nudoOapN, ‡ A streak in flesh-meat, differing in colour from the rest: (Ḳ:) such a streak in the flesh of a slaughtered camel: (T:) and, in the dual, two streaks inside the two thighs, having over them a thin, white, sinewy substance, resembling a spider's web, divided, one from the other, by a single muscle, and thus appearing like two muscles: asserted by more than one to be tropical. (TA.)
What is above the navel, in a horse. (Ḳ.)

A woollen thing, (TA,) also called durojap, which is stuffed into the tuel of a she-camel, [and into her vulva, as explained voce durojap,] and which is afterwards taken out when she has taken a liking for another camel's colt, (Ḳ,) or for the stuffed skin of a camel's colt prepared for her. (IAạr.) [See durojap for a more full explanation.]
One of several parts or portions of scattered herbage: (like nufoOapN: TA:) also called nudaOapN↓: pl. nudaON. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: nudaOapN: see preceding sentence.

nadiIoCN, a subst., like TabiyxN, [or rather an epithet in which the quality of a substantive predominates,] Flesh-meat, or bread, cooked, or baked, by being buried in hot ashes. (IAth, Ṣ.) laHomN nadiIoCN Flesh-meat cooked, or baked, &c. (TA.)
[See also nadoOapN, in two places.]

hom.sense: 1. nadabahu liloOamori, (Ṣ,) or UilaI AlOamori, aor. _u {yanodubu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. nadobN; (Mṣb, TA;) and Antdbh↓ llAmr; this latter verb being used transitively as well as intransitively; (Mṣb;) He, or it, called, summoned, or invited, him to the thing; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and instigated, incited, or urged, him to it: (Ḳ.) i. e., to war, succour, &c. (TA.)
[You say,] maA nadabaniI UilaI maA faEalotu Uil-aA Aln-uSoHu laka ‡ Nothing incited me to do what I have done but sincerity towards thee. (TA.)

nadaba Almay-ita, (aor. _u {yanodubu}, inf. n. nadobN, Ṣ,) ‡ He wailed for, wept for, or deplored the loss of, the dead man, and enumerated his good qualities and actions. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) nadabuti Almy-b ‡ She (a wailing woman) called upon the dead man, praising him, and saying waAfulaAnaAhu and waAhanaAhu, Alas for such a one! and Alas for thee! (M) or she, as it were, called upon the dead man, enumerating his good qualities and actions, as though he heard her. (Mṣb.) It is said that the action is peculiarly that of women; and that the verb is derived from nadabahu, “he called him” to do a thing; or from nadabN, “a scar,” because the wailer mentions the memorials of him who has gone; or perhaps from nadobN, “lightness, or activity.” (MF.)
nadiba, aor. _a {yanodabu}; (inf. n. nadabN, TA;) and Andb↓; It (a wound) had a hardened scar, such as is termed nadabap. (Ḳ.)

nadiba, aor. _a {yanodabu}, inf. n. nadabN [so accord. to the TA, agreeably with analogy; but in the CK and a MṢ. copy, nadobN; whence, and from the form of the latter of the two inf. ns. here following, it seems not improbable that the verb may be also written nadaba;] and nuduwbapN and nuduwbN, It (the back) had upon it scars, such as are termed nuduwb. (Ḳ.)
naduba, aor. _u {yanodubu}, inf. n. nadaAbapN, (TA,) He was light, or active, (and quick, TA,) in the accomplishment of affairs, or wants: he was clever, ingenious, or acute in mind; excellent. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. nd-b He took, got, or won, a bet, wager, or stake. (L.)
See 1.

hom.sense: 4. Andbhu It (a wound) made, or left, a scar upon him. (Ḳ.)
He made a scar upon his skin. (TA.)
See badabN.
Andb biZahorihi, and fI Zhrh, He, or it, left scars (nuduwb) upon his back. (TA.)
Oanodabatohu AlHaAjapu UinodaAbFA XadiydFA ‡ The thing, or want, made a severe impression upon him. (TA.)
Andb nafosahu, and binafosihi, He exposed himself to peril. (Ḳ.)
See 1.
8. Antdb lahu He answered, or complied with, or obeyed, his call, summons, or invitation, (Ṣ,) and hastened to him, when called to war, succour, &c. (TA.)

Antdb Qll-ehu limano xaraja fiI sabiylihi (occurring in a trad., TA,) God answereth his prayer for forgiveness [who goeth forth to fight for the sake of his religion]: or is surety, or guarantee, for him: or hasteneth to grant him a good recompense: or graciously maketh his completion of that [recompense] to him necessary and sure. (Ḳ.)
AntdbwA Uilayohi They hastened to him, either at his call, or summons, or of their own accord. (TA.)
xuco maA Antdb Take thou what is easily attainable; what offers itself without difficulty: (AA, Ḳ:) as also mA Antdm. (TA.)
Antdb lahu He opposed him in his speech. (Ḳ.)

Uiy-aAkumo wariDaAEa Als-awoCi faUin-ahu laA bud-a mino Oano yanotadiba Beware of giving your children to a bad nurse; for it [that is the evil consequence, or the bad qualities that will be acquired,] will inevitably appear some day. Said by ʼOmar. (TA.)

nadobN A man who is light, or active, (and quick, TA,) in the accomplishment of an affair, or a want; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also minodabaI↓ (Ḳ) and minodibaI↓: (TA:) a man who, when he is sent to accomplish a great, or an important, affair, finds it light to him: (A:) clever, ingenious, or acute in mind; excellent: pl. nuduwbN and nudabaACu: (Ḳ:) the former agreeable with analogy; the latter formed from the imaginary sing. nadiybN; like sumaHaACu, pl. of samoHN. (TA.)
nadobN, as applied to a horse, Sharp-spirited; (Lth, Ṣ;) contr. of baliydN (Lth) excellent. (TA.)
nadobN Lightness, or activity. (MF.)
OaraAka nadobFA fiI AlHawaAYiji [I see thee to be clever in accomplishing affairs, or wants.] (A.)
See nadabN.

nadabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and, by poetical licence, nadobN↓, (MF,) The scar, (Ṣ,) or scars, (Ḳ,) of a wound, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) not rising above the surrounding skin: (Ṣ:) accord. to the Ḳ, pl. nadabapN [which is written in several MṢ. copies of the Ḳ nadobapN; and so in the CK; but this, accord. to the TA, is incorrect;] but it is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is nadabapN, like as XajarapN is that of XajarN: (MF:) pl. OanodaAbN and nuduwbN: (Ḳ:) the former of nadabN agreeably with analogy: the latter dev. with respect to analogy; or pl. of nadobN. (MF.)
nadabN is also applied, in a trad., to the ‡ Marks made by Moses' smiting the stone [from which, thereupon, water flowed forth]; these marks being thus likened to the scars of wounds. (TA.)

nadabN is also employed to signify ‡ Scars upon men's reputation. A poet says,
qawomN saOatoruku fiI OaEoraADihimo nadabaA
A people upon whose reputation I will leave scars, the effects of my satires. (TA.)

nadabN The direction in which one shoots an arrow or arrows: syn. riXoqN. (So in the Ṣ and the CK and several MṢ. copies of the Ḳ: in other copies, raXoqN The act of shooting an arrow or arrows. Both these readings are correct accord. to the TA. See below.) UirotamaI nadabFA Oawo nadabayoni He shot an arrow or arrows in one direction or in two directions: syn. wajohFA Oawo wajohayoni. (TA.)

nadabunaA yawoma kacaA (said by those who are to contend at a shooting-match, TA,) The day of our commencing shooting shall be such a day. (Ḳ.) [This confirms the assertion in the TA, that nadabN is syn. with raXoqN, as well as with riXoqN. In the Turk. Ḳ, in the place of yawoma QbotidaAYinaA, we find ywm QnotidaAbinaA; and Freytag adopts the latter reading; but I find no other authority for it.]
nadabN A bet, wager, stake, or thing wagered; what is staked at a shooting match, or a race, and taken by the winner: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* L:) pl. OanodaAbN. (Mṣb.) So in the following phrases.
bayonahumo nadabN [Between them is a bet, or wager].
OaqaAma fulaAnN EalaI nadabK [Such a one stood to a bet, wager, or stake]. (TA.)

'Orweh says,
Oayaholiku muEotam-N wazayodN walamo Ouqimo
EalaI nacabK yawomFA waliI nafosu muxoTiri
[Shall Moatemm and Zeyd perish, and I not stand to a stake, some day, when I have the soul of one who makes his life a stake to his adversary and sallies forth against him?] These two were his ancestors. (Ṣ.) Or, accord. to Az, who reads Oataholiku, they were two tribes. (TA.)

entry.sense: nadibN: see nadiybN.
nadobapN [a fem. epithet] Any camel's foot, or hoof, [meaning any camel, or hoofed beast,] that does not remain in one state. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: nudobapN, a subst., A call; a summons; an invitation to do a thing. (Mṣb.)
nudobapN: a subst., ‡ The act of wailing for, weeping for, lamenting, or deploring the loss of, one who is dead, as described in the explanations of nadaba Almy-t, and badabatoh. (Ṣ, Ḳ, M, Mṣb.)
[haMCu Aln-adobapi The h of lamentation].
EarabiI-N nudobapN An Arabian of chaste speech; (Ḳ;) eloquent. (TA.)

entry.sense: nadiybN, (Ḳ,) or nadibN↓, (L,) A back having upon it scars, such as are termed nuduwb: (L, Ḳ:) the former epithet is also applied in the same sense to a wound: and, so applied, is also explained by the word manoduwbN: (TA:) [app. meaning that will be wailed for, or deplored; i. e., fatal].

naAdibapN ‡ A wailing woman; or one wailing for, weeping for, or deploring the loss of, one who is dead, as described in the explanations of nadaba Almy-t, and nadabatohu: (M, Mṣb:) pl. nawaAdibu. (Mṣb.)
Aln-ad-aAbataAni a name given to Two bad marks in horses. (TA.)

manodabN A place to which one is called, summoned, or invited. Hence baAbu Almanodabi [The Strait Báb el-Mendeb, or The Strait of the Place of Summons:] so called because a certain king summoned a number of men to break through the mountain there, which originally opposed a barrier to the sea, in order to drown his enemy; and this they did, thus overwhelming with the waters many cities and towns with their inhabitants, and forming the sea which intervenes between El-Yemen and Abyssinia, and which extends to 'Eydháb and Kuseyr [&c.]. (Yaakoot.) This king was Alexander the Greek! (TA.) [It is probable that the appearance of the Strait gave rise to this story, and thus to its name: but it is also probable that the name may signify The Strait of the Place of Wailing for the Dead; as many perish who go forth from it.]
manodabaI and minodibaI: see nadobN.
munad-abN: see manoduwbN.
manoduwbN One sent to do a thing; a messenger; an envoy; an ambassador. (TA.)
fulaAnN manoduwbN liOamorK EaZiymK, and munad-abN↓ lahu, Such a one is sent to do a great thing; or to perform an important affair. (A.)
munad-abapN↓ an appellation, given by the people of Mekkeh to their Envoys, or ambassadors, to the palace of the Khaleefeh. (TA.)
manoduwbN Desired; sought; sought after; as the name of a certain horse it is thus explained: from nadabN, as signifying “a pledge that is given on the occasion of a race.” (L.)

manoduwbN: see nadaba Almy-t: A thing bewailed, [or complained of as painful,] with the exclamation of yaA or waA. O! or Alas! (KT.) [The name of the thing thus bewailed, or complained of, has always an A of prolongation and h annexed to it, or the A only.]

manoduwbN, originally manoduwbN Uilayohi, A thing to the performance of which one is called, summoned, or invited: (Mṣb:) [hence,] approved: (Ḳ:) a signification verified by the doctors of practical law: (TA:) a thing the doing of which is more excellent than the leaving it undone, in the eye of the prescriber of the law, but which it is allowable to leave undone. (KT.) [Freytag, in quoting the original words, omits fiEoluhu before rAjHFA.]

Hence the saying of Umm-Selemeh to 'Aïsheh, (when she desired to go forth to El-Basrah, TA,) qado jamaEa AlquroMnu cayolaki falaA tanodaHiyhi, i. e., [The Ḳur-án hath drawn together, or contracted, thy skirt; therefore] do not widen it, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or do not spread it abroad, (L,) by thy going forth to El-Basrah: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) the pronoun h refers to the word cyl: the speaker alluded to the words of the Ḳur-án, [xxxiii. 33,] waqarona fiI buyuwutikun-a walaA tabar-ajona. (L.) Accord. to one relation, the last words are lA tabodaHiyhi, i. e., do not open it. (Ṣ.)
nadaHati Aln-aEaAmapu OunoduwHapF The ostrich excavated and made wide a hollow place for her eggs. (A.)
Oatoraba fanadaHa He became possessed of wealth like the dust, and enlarged his mode of life, and scattered his property. A proverb. (MF, from Meyd.)
2: see 1.
3. nAdHhu He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in multitude, or abundance. (R.)

5. tn-dHt Alganamu min m-araAbiDihaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or fiI maraAbiDihaA, (A, L, &c.,) and AntdHt↓, (TA,) The sheep, or goats, became dispersed from, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in, (A, L, &c.,) their nightly restingplaces, and became distended by repletion. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.)
8: see 5.

9. UinodaH-a baTonuhu, inf. n. UinodiHaAHN, His belly became distended by reason of repletion. (Ṣ.) This, says IB, is its proper art., not art. dH. (TA, art. dH, in which J also mentions it.) F says, that J is in error in mentioning this verb, as also in mentioning UinodaAHa baTonuhu, inf. n. UinodiyaAHN, in the present art.; the proper place of the former being in art. dH; and that of the latter, in art. dwH: but MF says, that J has merely mentioned them here because of the resemblance of their radical letters and significations to the radical letters and significations belonging to this art. (TA.)

hom.sense: nadoHN and nudoHN↓ (Ḳ) and manoduwHapN↓ and munotadaHN↓ (Ṣ) Spaciousness; roominess; width; ampleness (L, Ḳ.)

Also, nudoHN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nadoHN and nadoHapN↓ and nudoHapN↓ and manoduwHapN↓ and munotadaHN↓ (Ḳ) A spacious, roomy, wide, or ample, tract of land; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OaroDN manoduwHapN: (L:) and munotadaHN↓ a spacious, roomy, wide, or ample, place: (Ṣ:) pl. (of the first and second words, TA) OanodaAHN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and pl. of mndwHp, manaAdiyHu, and by poetic licence manaAdiHu; (TA;) which is allowable also in other cases than those of poetical licence: (MF;) and it (mnAdH) also signifies deserts; or waterless deserts. (Ṣ.)
Also waAdK naAdiHN↓ A wide valley. (L.)
laka fiI hecihi Ald-aAri munotadaHN↓ Thou hast ample space, or room, in this house. (A.)

liI Eano hecaA QloOamori manoduwHapN↓, and munotadaHN↓, I have ample scope, freedom, or liberty, to avoid this thing, or affair: (Ṣ, L:) or I have that which renders me in no need of this thing, or affair. (L.)

Uin-a fiI AlmaEaAriyDi lamanoduwHapF↓ Eani Alkacibi, [a trad.,] Verily, in oblique, indirect, ambiguous, or equivocal, modes of speech, is ample scope, freedom, or liberty, to avoid lying: (Ṣ, L:) or, that which renders one in no need of lying: (L:) one should not say munoduwHap, (TA,) nor mamoduwHap. (Ṣ.)
nadoHN and nudoHN↓ also signify Multitude; copiousness; abundance. (L, Ḳ.)
Also, The face of a mountain, or part which faces the spectator, above its foot, or base; (Ḳ;) its side, or extremity, which inclines to width: (TA:) pl. OanodaAHN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: nidoHN A heavy thing; syn. viqolN. (Ḳ.)
Also, A thing that one sees from afar. (Ḳ.)

dictScrap.title: nudoHN / nadoHapN / nudoHapN / naAdiHN / munoduwHapN / munotadaHN

entry.sense: nudoHN, nadoHapN, nudoHapN, naAdiHN, munoduwHapN, munotadaHN: see nadoHN.
OunoduwHapN A wide hollow place excavated by an ostrich for her eggs. (A.)

1. nadara, (T, Ṣ, M, &c.,) aor. _u {yanoduru}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. nadorN, (Ṣ,) or nuduwrN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [which latter is the more common, if not the only right, form,] It fell, (T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or went, or came, out, or forth, from another thing, or from other things, (Mṣb,) or from amid a thing, (T,) or from the inside of a thing, (T, M, Ḳ,) or from among things, so as to be apparent, or standing out to view; (M, Ḳ;) it fell, and became apart, fell off, fell out, or went, or came, out, or forth, from the generality of things, or the general assemblage, main body, bulk, or common mass, to which it pertained, or from other things: (Ṣ, TA:) or, [in some cases,] simply, it fell, or dropped. (TA.)

nadara mino qawomihi He went forth [and became separated] from his people. (Mṣb.) And nadara mino bayotihi He went forth from his house or tent. (A.) I heard one say to his wife, OunoduriI [Go thou forth and be separate: app. meaning, be thou divorced]. (Z, in the A, immediately following what here immediately precedes.)

nadara AlEaZomu, (A,) or nadara mino mawoDiEihi, (Mṣb,) The bone became dislocated or displaced. (A, Mṣb.) It is said of a man, in a trad., EaD-a yada Mxara fanadara vaniy-atahu [or, accord. to another relation, nadarato, meaning, He bit the arm, or hand, of another, and his central incisor dropped out]. (TA.)
nadara TaAYirN Eano XajarapK A bird dropped and alighted from a tree. (TA.)
nadara naAdirN mina Aljabali A prominence projected, or jutted out, from the mountain. (A.)

OaSaAba AlmaTaru AlHaXiyXa fanadara Alr-uTobu The rain fell upon the dry herbage and the fresh herbage came forth. (A.) And nadara Aln-abaAtu The plant put forth its leaves (M, Ḳ) from its uppermost branches. (M.) And nadarati AlX-ajarapu The tree produced its xuwSap [q. v.]; (M, Ḳ;) which is the case when the camels are able to pasture upon them: (M:) or became green. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

nadara fiI EilomK, or faDolK, (IḲṭṭ,) and fI faDolihi, (Mṣb,) ‡ He outwent others [or became extraordinary] (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb) in knowledge or science, or in excellence, (IḲṭṭ,) and in his excellence. (Mṣb.)

nadura AlkalaAmu, ‡ inf. n. nadaraApN, (Mṣb, TA,) ‡ The speech, or language, was extraordinary or strange, [with respect to usage or analogy or both]: (TA:) it was the contr. of chaste: (Mz, 13th nwE:) [but this explanation requires restriction; for what is extraordinary with respect to usage is the contr. of chaste; but many a word that is extraordinary with respect to analogy is more chaste than a cognate word agreeable with analogy: hence the above phrase is also explained as signifying] the speech, or language, was chaste and good. (Mṣb.)

4. Andrhu, trans. of nadara, He made it to fall, or to go, or come, out, or forth, from another thing, or from other things; [&c.: see 1:] (Mṣb:) he made it to fall. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
You say, Daraba yadahu baAls-ayofi faOanodarahaA [He struck his arm, or hand, with the sword, and made it to fall.] (Ṣ.) And Anodara mina AlHisaAbi kacaA † [He made such a thing to fall out, he threw it out, from the reckoning]. (Ṣ.) And Oanodara AlbikaArapa fiI Ald-iyapi ‡ He threw out, or rejected, the young camels in the mulct for homicide. (A.) [See also 6.] And Oanodara Eanohu mino maAlihi kacaA ‡ He took forth (Oaxoraja) from him, of his property, such a thing. (M, Ḳ, TA.) And Oanodarotu yada fulaAnK Eano maAliI ‡ I caused [the hand of] such a one to cease from freely disposing of my property. (A.)
Andr He said, or did, something extraordinary, or strange. (IḲṭṭ.)

6. tnAdrwA [They mutually threw out, or rejected, a thing from a reckoning]. A poet (namely Aboo-Kebeer El-Hudhálee, TA) says,
waUicaA AlkumaApu tanaAdaruwA TaEona AlkulaI
nadora AlbikaArapi fiI AljazaMCi AlmuDoEafi
[When the courageous men covered with arms mutually throw out from the reckoning the piercing of the kidneys, as the young camels fall out from the reckoning in the doubled compensation]: he says, that their blood is suffered to be shed unrevenged, like as the young camels are thrown out from the account in the mulct for homicide: (Ṣ, TA:) meaning, that the pierced kidneys are thrown out from the reckoning, like as the young camel is thrown out, and not reckoned, in the mulct for homicide that is doubled time after time. (IB, TA.)
fulaAnN yatanaAdaru EalayonaA (A, TA) ‡ Such a one comes to us [rarely, or] sometimes. (TA.)

10. Astndrt AlUibilu The camels sought after the leaves that had come forth upon the uppermost branches of the plants, to eat them, and applied themselves diligently to them: (M:) [or you say,] Astndrt Aln-abaAta they sought after the plants, to eat them, and applied themselves diligently to them. (TA.) And AlmaAlu yasotanodiru Alr-uToba [The camels] seek after the fresh herbage leisurely, and by degrees, or repeatedly. (A.) [The original signification of Astndr seems to be He desired to find a thing or things in a separate or scattered state; or to single out.]
AstndrwA Oavarahu ‡ They tracked his footsteps. (A.)
nadorapN and nudorapN↓, with fet-ḥ and damm, are substs. from nadara, [signifiying The state of being apart from, or out of, the generality, or main body;, &c.:]

[and hence, ‡ Extraordinariness; rareness.] (Mṣb.) You say, laA yakuwnu celika Uil-aA fiI Aln-adorapi, or fI Aln-udorapi↓, and Al-A naAdirFA↓, (Mṣb,) and laA yaqaEu celika Uil-aA fiI Aln-udorapi, (A,) ‡ That will not be, (Mṣb,) and that will not happen, (A,) save [extraordinarily; or rarely; or once] in, or during, the space of [several] days; syn. fiymaA bayona AlOay-aAmi. (Mṣb.) And Uin-amaA yakuwnu celika fiI Aln-adorapi baEoda Aln-adorapi ‡ That is, or will be, only once in whiles. (TA.) And laqiyahu nadorapF, (M, Ḳ,) and fiI Aln-adorapi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and fI Aln-adarapi↓, (Ṣ, TA,) and fI Aln-udayorapi↓, (TA,) and nadaraI↓ (M, Ḳ) and fI nadaraI, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Aln-adaraI, (M, Ḳ,) and fI Aln-adaraI, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) ‡ He met him [once] in, or during, the space of [several] days; syn. bayona AlOay-aAmi, (M, Ḳ,) or fiymaA bayona AlOay-aAmi. (Ṣ.)
Also nadorapN A piece of gold, (Ḳ,) and of silver, (TA,) found in the mine. (Ḳ.) See also XacorN.
nudorapN: see nadorapN.
nadarapN: see nadorapN.
nadaraI: see nadorapN.
naqadahu maAYapF nadaraI He produced [or payed] to him a hundred out of his property. (M, Ḳ.)
nudayorapN: see nadorapN.
naAdirN [act. part. n. of nadara; Falling, or going, or coming, out, or forth, from another thing;, &c.: see 1].
A wild ass going, or coming, forth from the mountain. (TA.)
A prominence, or projecting part, of a mountain. (A,* Mṣb.)

[What remains here and there upon the ground, of rain, i. e., of rain-water: n. un. with p {naAdirapN}: pl. of the latter, nawaAdiru.] You say, Xaribati AlUibilu mino naAdiri AlmaTari, and nawaAdirihi, [The camels drank of what remained here and there upon the ground, of the water of the rain.] (A.)

‡ Extraordinary; strange; rare; unusual; applied to speech or language [and to a word and any other thing: fem. and n. un. with p {naAdirapN}: pl. of the latter as above: see nadara, and nadura]: (A:) or very extraordinary, strange, rare, or unusual, applied to speech or language; and in like manner naAdirapN [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates] applied to a word: pl. of the latter as above: (Mz, 13th nawoE:) [see muT-aridN:] or nawaAdiru AlkalaAmi signifies what deviate from the generality of words or speech or language. (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ.) You say also, fulaAnN naAdirapu Alz-amaAni, meaning, ‡ Such a one is the unequalled of the age. (Ḳ,* TA.) [And naAdirapN, used in this manner as a subst., signifies ‡ Any extraordinary, strange, rare, or unusual, thing, or saying: pl. as above.] See muDoHikaAtN.
laA yakuwnu celika Uil-aA naAdirFA: see nadorapN.

OanodarN i. q. bayodarN [A place in which wheat or grain is trodden out]; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) in the dial. of the people of Syria: (Ṣ, M:) or, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to Kr, (M,) reaped wheat collected together; or wheat collected together in the place where it is trodden out: (M, Ḳ:) pl. OanaAdiru. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. nacara EalaI nafosihi, (Yoo, Akh, T, Ṣ, M, A,* Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanociru} and _u {yanocuru}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. nacorN (Yoo, Akh, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and nucuwrN, (M, Ḳ,) [He made a vow; imposed upon himself a vow; Oano yafoEala kacaA that he would do such a thing; either absolutely, or conditionally, as will be explained below;] he made [a future action] binding, or obligatory, on himself; (T, M, A, Ḳ;) as also Antcr↓. (Ḳ.) And Antcr↓ nacorFA signifies the same as nacara [He vowed a vow]. (Ṣgh.) You say also nacarotu maAliI, aor. _u {yanocuru} [and _i as implied in the Ḳ] inf. n. nacorN, [I vowed my property; made a vow to give it.] (Yoo, Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ.*) And nacarotu lil-ehi kacaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanocuru} and _i {yanociru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. nacorN, (Mṣb,) I made it binding, or obligatory, on myself, [i. e., I vowed,] of my own free will, to do or to give such a thing to God; namely, some religious service, or an alms, &c.: (TA:) or nacorN signifies the promising conditionally; as when one says, “Such a thing shall be obligatory on me if God restore to health my sick [son or other]:” this is termed nacorN: but the saying “I impose upon myself the giving a deenár as alms,” is not so termed. (Ḳ.) The doing this is repeatedly forbidden in traditions: but what is meant thereby is, one's doing so in the belief that he may attain by it something which God has not decreed to betide him, or that he may divert from himself something decreed to befall him: yet if he do so, fulfilment is obligatory on him. (IAth.) You say also, nacara Alwalada, (M, Ḳ,) and nacaratohu, (M,) He (the father, M, Ḳ) and she (the mother, M) appointed the child [by a vow] to be a minister or servant to the church, (M, Ḳ,) or to a place appropriated to religious services or exercises, or acts of devotion: (TA:) so in the Ḳur, iii. 31. (M.)

nacira biAlX-aIoCi, aor. _a {yanocaru}, (M, IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. nacarN (M, IḲṭṭ) and nacaArapN and nicaArapN, (IḲṭṭ,) or, as some assert, it has no inf. n., like EasaI, &c., the Arabs being content to use in its stead Oano followed by the verb, as is said in the 'Ináyeh, on the Ḳur, chap. xiv., (MF,) He knew of the thing: (Mṣb:) or he knew of the thing and was cautious of it or on his guard against it or in fear of it. (M, Ḳ.) You say also nacira Alqawomu bAlEaduw-i (Ṣ, A) The people knew of the enemy: (Ṣ:) or knew of the enemy and prepared themselves for them: (A:) or knew of the enemy and were cautious of them or on their guard against them or in fear of them. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., Uinocari Alqawoma Have thou knowledge of the people and be cautious of them or on thy guard against them or in fear of them. (TA.)

entry.sense:
4. Oanocarotuhu biAlOamori, (M, Ḳ,) and Ancrth AlX-aIoCa, (Mṣb,) inf. n. UinocaArN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nucorN (M, Ḳ) the latter accord. to Kr, but correctly it is a simple subst., (M,) and nucurN, (T, Ḳ,) or this is pl. of naciyrN, (T,) and nacorN, (Ḳ,) accord. to Lh and Kr, (TA,) [but this is properly a simple subst.,] and naciyrN, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to Zj, (M,) or Ez-Zejjájee, (TA,) but this should rather be regarded as a simple subst., (T, M,) I informed him, or advised him, of the thing: (M, Ḳ, TA:) this is the primary signification: (TA:)
and [I warned him of the thing;] I cautioned him, or put him on his guard, against the thing, and put him in fear, (M,* Ḳ,) in my communication or announcement: (Ḳ:) in this sense the verb is used in the Ḳur, xl. 18: (M, TA:) or I announced to him the thing, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) generally in a case of putting in fear the person addressed, or frightening him, (Mṣb,) or never otherwise than in such a case: (Ṣ:) and thus the verb is used in the Ḳur, ubi supra., waOanocrohum yawoma MlAzifapi [And warn them and put them in fear of the day of the approaching event, the day of resurrection] meaning, put them in fear of its punishment: (Mṣb:) and Oanocazotuhu bikacaA I informed him, or advised him, of such a thing. (Mṣb.) Ancrhu also signifies He (a spy) informed him, or advised him, of the state of the enemy: in the copies of the Ḳ, nacarahu; but this is a mistake. (TA.) And you say, Oanocarotu Alqawoma masiyra AlEadur-i Uilayohimo I informed the people of the march of the enemy towards them, to put them on their guard. (T.) And Oanocarotu Alqawoma biAlEaduw-i, and Oanocarotuhumu AlEaduw-a, signify the same. (A.) It is said in a proverb, qado OaEocara mano Oanocara, meaning, He hath become excused, and averted from himself the blame of men, who hath warned thee that he will punish thee for a future evil deed proceeding from thee, if thou then do the evil deed and he punish thee. (T.) See also OaEocara, in two places: and see EucorN.

6. tnAcr Alqawomu The people warned, or cautioned, one another, or put one another in fear, (M, Ḳ,) of a terrifying evil. (TA.) You say tnAcr Alqawomu kacaA The people warned one another, (Ṣ,) and put one another in fear, of such a thing. (Ṣ, A.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely, En-Nábighah, (T, TA,) describing a serpent, (T,) and his being threatened by En-Noamán so that he passed the night as though he had been stung, turning over and over upon his bed, (TA,)
tanaAcarahaA Alr-aAquwna mino suwoCi sam-ihaA
tuTal-iquhu TaworFA waTaworFA turaAjiEu
[Of which the charmers have warned one another, and put one another in fear, on account of the evil nature of its poison, which it discharges one time and one time draws back]. (T, Ṣ, TA.)
8: see nacara {1}, in two places.
10. Astncr Uilayohi He offered warning to him (A, TA, art. Ecr.) See AstEcr.

hom.sense:
nacorN A vow, which a man makes to be binding, or obligatory, on himself; (T, M,* Ḳ,* TA;) [either absolutely, or conditionally: (see nacara:)] pl. nucuwrN: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:*) and in the following verse of Ibn-Aḥmar, some say that nucur is pl. of nacorN, like as ruhunN is pl. of rahonN; but others say that it is pl. of naciyrN in the sense of manocuwrN:
kamo duwna layolaI mino tanuwfiy-apK
lam-aAEapK tunocaru fiyhaA Aln-ucuro
[How many a waterless desert glistening with the mirage, in which vows, or things vowed, are vowed, lie in the way to Leylà!]. (Ṣ.)

Also, ‡ The mulct for an intentional wound; used in this sense by Esh-Sháfiʼee, (T, TA,) and of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz; (TA;) i. q. OaroXN, (T, A, Ḳ, TA,) which is of the dial. of the people of El-'Irák: (T, TA:) pl. nucuwrN: (T, A, Ḳ:) said by Aboo-Nahshal to be only for wounds, small and great. (T, Ḳ.*) You say, liI qibala fulaAnK nacorN, (T, TṢ, L,) or Einoda fulaAnK, (Ḳ,) ‡ A mulct for a wound is owed to me. (T, Ḳ, &c.) And OaEoTayotuhu nacora juroHihi ‡ I gave him the mulct for his wound. (A.) Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer says that it is thus called liOan-ahu nucira fiyhi, i. e., because it is made binding, or obligatory, for it; [namely, for the wound;] from the phrase nacarotu ElaI nafosiI. (T, TA.)
[A votive offering].
See also nucorN.

entry.sense: nucorN (M) and nucurN↓ (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) [and nacorN↓ (see 4)] and naciyrN↓ (Ṣ, M) and naciyrapN↓ (M) and nicaArapN↓ (Esh-Sháfiʼee, Ḳ) and nucoraI↓ (Ḳ) are substs. in the sense of UinocaArN [meaning An informing, or advising, of a thing: and a warning, or cautioning, and putting one on his guard, against a thing, and putting one in fear of a thing;, &c.: (see 4:)] (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or a putting one in fear in announcing a thing. (TA.) EucorFA Oawo nucorFA and EucurFA Oawo nucurFA, accord. to different readings, in the Ḳur, lxxvii. 6, put in the accus. case as causal complements, signify liloUiEocaAri waQloUinocaAri [For excusing and warning]. (Zj, T.) [See also art. Ecr.] And in like manner, nucuri↓, in the Ḳur, liv. 16, &c., signifies UinocaAriI. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And so naciyri↓, in the Ḳur, lxvii. 17. (T, M.) Hence also the saying of the Arabs, EucoraAka laA nucoraAka, meaning, OaEociru walaA tunociro [i. e. Do thou that for which thou wilt be excused, by inflicting punishment when it is deserved, and do not merely warn and put in fear]. (TA.)
nucurN: see nucorN.
nucoraI: see nucorN.

hom.sense: naciyrN i. q. munocirN↓, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as also naciyrapN↓; (M;) i. e. [One who gives information, or advice, of a thing, or things: and one who warns;] one who cautions; (M, TA;) and who puts in fear: (TA:) one who gives notice to a people of an enemy, or other thing, that has come upon them; (TA;) a spy who gives notice, to a people, of an enemy, to put them on their guard; (A;) and in like manner naciyrapN↓, a spy who informs an army of the state of the enemy: (T, Ḳ:) naciyrN is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufoEilN: (M, L:) or its verb was nacara, but this has become obsolete: (T:) its pl. is nucurN; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) occurring in the Ḳur, liv. 23, [&c.]. (TA.)
[Hence,] Abw munocirK The cock (Ḥar. p. 644).
[And also,] Aln-aciyru The apostle: (M, Ḳ:) so in the Ḳur, xxxv. 34, accord. to Th: (M:) the prophet Moḥammad: (T, Ḳ:) so, accord. to most of the expositors, in that verse of the Ḳur. (T.)
Hoariness, or whiteness of the hair: (T, M, Ḳ:) so, accord. to some, in the verse of the Ḳur, last referred to: (T, M:) but the explanation immediately preceding is more probable. (T.)
The sound of a bow: (AḤn, M, Ḳ:) because it warns, or frightens, (yunodiru,) that which is shot at. (AḤn, M.)
I. q. manocuwrN [i. e. Vowed]: pl. nucurN. (Ṣ.) See nacorN.
See also nucorN.

entry.sense: nicaArapN: see nucorN.

hom.sense: naciyrapN [A votive gift;] that which he gives who makes a vow. (M, Ḳ.)

A child appointed by the father (M, Ḳ) and mother (M) [by a vow] to be a minister, or servant to the church, (M, Ḳ,) or to a place appropriated to religious services, or exercises, or acts of devotion: (T:) pl. nacaAYiru. (T.)
See also naciyrN, in two places.
And see nucorN.

entry.sense: naAcirN: see munac-irN.
munocirN: see naciyrN.
manocuwrN: see naciyrN.
fulaAnN munac-irN UilaI-a biEiyonihi, and naAcirN↓, Such a one is looking at me hard or intently, and making his eye prominent. (T, in TA, art. znr.)
mutanaAcarN [A thing of which people warn or caution one another, or of which they put one another in fear]: applied to a disease [&c.]. (TA, art. xbr voce xayobaraI.)
[Hence,] AlmutanaAcaru † The lion. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
1. nacula, inf. n. nacaAlapN, He was, or became, low, base, vile, ignoble, mean, sordid, or contemptible, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in all his circumstances. (Ḳ.)
nacolN A man vile, or mean, and despised in all his circumstances. (Ḳ.)

Q. Q. 1. Alr-iyHu tunayoribu Alt-uraAba fawoqahu, or EalaI AlOaroDi, (TA,) inf. n. nayorabapN, (TA,) The wind lays the dust upon it, or upon the ground, in cross, wavy lines: syn. tanosijuhu. (Ḳ.) Hence nayoraba AlkalaAm. (TA.)
nayoraba He forged [speech, or language]: syn. nasaja. (Ḳ.) You say huwa yunayoribu Alqawola. (TA.)
nayoraba He mixed, or confounded, speech, [introducing what was false with that which was true]. (Ḳ.)
nayoraba He uttered a malicious and mischievous misrepresentation, a calumny, or slander. (Ḳ.)

nayorabN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nayorabapN↓ (as in several copies of the Ḳ, [and I am inclined to think that this is the correct reading, as it may certainly be correctly used in the sense here given, being properly an inf. n., agreeably with analogy,]) or manorabapN↓ (as in others, which is said in the TA to be the correct word, and to be given on the authority of AA, [but it exhibits an incongruity of letters: see 1:]) Mischief; malicious and mischievous misrepresentation, calumny, or slander. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nayorabN A strong man. (Ḳ.)
nayorabaI A calamity; a misfortune. (Ḳ.)
nayorabapN and manorabapN: see nayorabN.
1. naraja He thrashed wheat, or corn, with a naworaj. (TA.)

naworajN (L, Ḳ) and nayorajN↓ and nuwrajN↓, the last of the dial. of El-Yemen, and a word of which there is not the like in Arabic, (L,) A thrashinginstrument, or that with which heaps of wheat, or corn, are thrashed, whether of wood or of iron; (L, Ḳ;) or, of iron and wood; (Sifr es-Sa'ádeh;) [a kind of drag, used, in Egypt and Arabia and some other countries of Western Asia, for the purpose of separating the grain of wheat and barley, &c. and cutting the straw, which serves as fodder; it is a machine in the form of a chair fixed upon a sledge, which moves upon small iron wheels, or thin circular plates, generally eleven, fixed to three thick axle-trees, four to the foremost, the same number to the hindmost, and three to the intermediate axle-tree: this machine is drawn, in a circle, by a pair of cows or bulls, their driver being seated upon it, over the corn:] pl. [of the first and last words] nawaAriju. (TA.)
Also, the first and second, A ploughshare. (Ḳ.)
nuwrajN and nayorajN: see naworajN

naAranojN A well-known fruit; [the orange; citrus aurantium; of which there are two species common in the gardens of the East, one sweet, and the other bitter:] and arabicized word, from [the Persian] naAranoko [also called naArinoj]. (Ḳ.)
narojisN and nirojisN [The Narcissus]: see art. rjs. The former is mentioned by ISd in art. rjs: the latter, in the present art. (TA.)

narodN [The game of tricktrack, backgammon, or tables: and, app., a pair of tables and other apparatus with which that game is played:] a certain thing with which one plays; (M, L;) well known: (M, L, Ḳ:) a Persian word, (M, L,) arabicized: (M, L:) also called narodaXiyrN, (M, L, Ḳ,) because invented (as some say, TA) by Ardasheer the son of Bábak, (Ḳ,) a Persian king. (TA.) It is said in a trad., that he who plays at this game is as though he plunged his hand into the flesh and blood of the pig. (L.)
naworuwzN: see what follows.

nayoruwzN, an arabicized word, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) from naworuwzo, (A, Ḳ,) which in Persian; meaning “new day;” (TA;) and naworuwzN↓; but the former, which is of the measure fayoEuwlN, is the better in repute, because fawoEuwlN is not the measure of an Arabic word; (Mṣb;) The first day of the year; New-year's-day: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) with the Persians, when the sun enters Aries: and with the Copts, the first of [the month] Toot [the ancient Thoth, or the tenth of September, N. Ṣ., excepting when immediately following their leap-year, which is when our next ensuing year is a leap-year]. (Mṣb, TA.) The word nyrwz is said to have been first used in the time of the 'Abbásee Khaleefehs; but it is related to have been used in the time of ʼAlee. (TA.)
