hom.sense: 1. naz-ati AlOaroDu, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanozizu}, inf. n. naz-N; (Mṣb;) and Anz-t↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) The ground, or land, had water exuding, or oozing, from it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or had much flowing moisture: (Mṣb:) or became [abundant in] manaAbiE [or places welling forth water], as in the TṢ and the Ḳ, or manaAqiE [or places of stagnant water] by reason of the naz-. (TA.)
[naz-ato bihi AlbiTonapu: see niTonap.]
naz-a,, aor. _i {yanozizu}, inf. n. naziyzN, He (an antelope, Ṣ,) ran: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he (an ostrich, and an antelope,) leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded. (A.)
He (an antelope, Ṣ,) uttered a cry, or cries. (Ibn-El-Jarráh, Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, first signification.

hom.sense: naz-N and niz-N↓ Water that exudes, or oozes, from the ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or flowing moisture: (Mṣb:) the latter is the better word; and is [said to be] Persian, arabicized: (TA:) the former is an inf. n. used as a subst. (Mṣb.)
[The pl. is nuzuwzN, occurring in the TA in art. Ecw.]
[Hence, perhaps,] naz-N also signifies † liberal, bountiful, or munificent. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
Also, naz-N Much, or many. (Ḳ.)
A man (AʼObeyd, Ṣ) light, or active, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or light in spirit, (TA,) sharp in mind, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ,) clever, or ingenious, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) and intel-ligent. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
Light, inconstant, fickle, or unsteady: (Ḳ:) an epithet of dispraise. (TA.)

A man (TA) much, or often, in motion; as also minaz-N↓: (Ḳ:) a man, (A,) and an ostrich, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) that does not remain still in one place: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or that is quick, or swift, and does not remain still in one place: (TA:) or an ostrich, and an antelope, that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds: (A:) and a light, or an active, camel; (TA;) and so naz-apN, applied to a she-camel. (Ṣ, TA.)
Light dust. (TA.)
niz-u↓ Xar-K, and naziyzuhu↓, i. q. liz-uhu and laziyzuhu. (TA, art. lz.)

entry.sense: niz-N: see naz-N.
naziyzN: see naz-N, last sentence.
naAz-N: fem. with p {naAz-apN}: see naz-N.
minaz-N A child's cradle: (A, Ḳ:) because of its frequent motion. (TA.)
See also naz-N.
1. nazaOa bayonahumo, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanozaOu}, inf. n. nazoCN and nuzuwoCN, (Ṣ,) He excited discord between them: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) like nazaEa. (TA.)
nazaOahu EalaI SaAHibihi He incited, or urged, him against his companion. (Ḳ,* TA.)
maA nazaOaka EalaI hecaA What incited, urged, or induced, thee to this? (Ks, Ṣ.)
nazaOa Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nazoCN, (Ṣ,) He made an attack, or assault, upon him; syn. Hamala. (Ks, Ṣ. Ḳ.)
nazaOahu Eano qawolihi He turned him back from what he had said. (Ḳ,* TA.)
nuziYa bihi, like EuniIa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] He was addicted, or devoted, to it; desirous of it. (TA.)

Uin-aka laA tadoriI EalaAma yunozaOu harimuka, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) thus thou sayest, addressing thyself, when a man has been pursuing a good or an evil way, and turned from it to another way, or accord. to some copies of the Ṣ, bima instead of EalaAma, [which is for EalaI maA;] (TA;) Verily thou knowest not to what thing thy mind will become addicted, or devoted: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. e., to what thy state will come. (Ḳ.) In one copy of the Ḳ, haramuka thine old age, is put instead of harimuka. (TA.)
naziIoC An inciter, instigator, or exciter. (TA.)
rajulN naz-aMCN [A man much addicted, or devoted, to a thing; very desirous of it]. (TA.) [See naziYa.]
manozuwoCN bihi Addicted, or devoted, to it; desirous of it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. nazaba, aor. _i {yanozibu}, inf. n. naziybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nazobN and nuzaAbN (Ḳ) He (an antelope) uttered a cry, or sound, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) at rutting-time. (Ṣ.) Used with reference to the buck and the doe; (Ḳ;) or the buck only. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

6. tnAzbwA i. q. tnAbzwA. (Ḳ.) Accord. to IHsh and others, this verb has not been heard [from the Arabs of the classical ages], but only the subst. nazabN, which is therefore decided to be a transp. form of nabazN. (TA.)
nazabN A surname; a nickname; a name of reproach; an opprobrious appellation: syn. laqaba: (Ḳ:) i. q. nabazN. (TA.) See 6.
nayozabN A buck-antelope; and a bull. (Ḳ.) [By the latter is probably meant the kind of antelope called baqaru AlwaHoXi.]

hom.sense: 1. nazaHa, aor. _a {yanozaHu} and _i {yanoziHu}, inf. n. nazoHN and nuzuwHN; (Ḳ;) and AntzH↓; (TA;) He, or it, (a thing, TA,) became distant, or remote. (Ḳ.)
nazaHati Ald-aAru, inf. n. nuzuwHN, The house, or dwelling, became distant, or remote. (Ṣ.)
nuziHa bifulaAnK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a verb like EuniIa, [pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (Ḳ,) Such a one became far removed from his dwelling-place. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nazaHa AlbiYora, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanozaHu} (Mṣb) and _i {yanoziHu}, (TA,) inf. n. nazoHN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and nuzuwHN; (Mṣb;) and OanozaHahaA↓; (Ḳ;) He drew forth all the water of the well; exhausted it entirely: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or he drew from it until little water remained in it; nearly exhausted it. (Ḳ.)
nazaHati AlbiYoru, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanozaHu}, (TA,) inf. n. nazaHN (Ḳ) and nuzuwHN, (TA,) The well became entirely exhausted: (A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, became nearly exhausted. (Ḳ.) See 4.
qado nazaHotaniI † Thou hast exhausted me of what I had, or possessed. (L, from a trad.)

entry.sense: 4. OanozaHa Alqawomu, (L, and so in some copies of the Ḳ, [agreeable with analogy,]) or nazaHa↓, (so in other copies of the Ḳ,) The people had the water of their wells entirely, or nearly, exhausted. (L, Ḳ.) See 1.
8: see 1.
Xar-uka saroHN waxayoruka nazoHN ‡ [Thy wickedness ranges abroad unrestrained, and] thy goodness is little. (A.)
nazaHN: see naAziHN.
Also, Turbid water. (Ḳ.)
nuzuHN and nazuwHN and naziyHN: see naAziHN.

hom.sense: naAziHN and nuzuHN↓ and nazuwHN↓ and naziyHN↓ A thing, (Ḳ,) or dwelling, (TA,) distant, or remote. (Ḳ.) baladN naAziHN A distant, or remote, town, or country: (Ṣ:) and daArN naAziHapN a distant, or remote, house, or dwelling. (Mṣb.)

qawomN manaAziyHu↓ A distant, or remote, people. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And UiyilN mnAzyH Camels from distant regions. (A.) ISd says, that it is pl. of minozaAHN↓, meaning That comes to the water from a distant place. (L.)

naAziHN and nuzuHN↓ and nazuwHN↓ A well entirely exhausted: or nearly exhausted: (Ḳ:) or biYorN nazuwHN↓ signifies a well containing little water: pl. nuzuHN: (Ṣ:) and biYorN nazaHN↓, nazaHN being of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, a well containing no water; and it is allowable to say manozuwHapN: (Mṣb:) or a well of which the water has been exhausted: (so in some copies of the Ṣ, and the like in the Nh:) or a well of which most of the water has been drawn forth. (So in other copies of the Ṣ, and in the Ḳ.) See an ex., voce mudaArapN, art. dwr.

entry.sense: minozaHapN A bucket (Ḳ) with which water is drawn; (TA;) and the like thereof. (Ḳ.)
minozaAHN and manaAziyHu: see naAziHN.

Ant bimunotazaHK mino kacaA ‡ Thou art far removed from such a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ *;) and, by poetic licence, bimunotazaAHK, with Oalif UiXobaAE. (Ṣ.) Ex. Oanota mina Ald-am-i bimunotazaHK ‡ Thou art far removed from blame. (A.)

hom.sense: 1. nazura, aor. _u {yanozuru}, inf. n. nazaArapN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nuzuwrN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and nuzuwrapN, (Ḳ,) or nuzorapN, as in the M and L, and perhaps one of these last two forms is a mistake for the other, (TA,) It was, or became, little, or small, in quantity or number; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) paltry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable. (Ṣ, TA.) See also 5.
Also, inf. n. nazaArapN, He (a man) was, or became, possessed of little good, or little wealth. (AZ.)
nazarato, inf. n. nazorN, She (a camel) had little milk. (TA.)
nazarahu, aor. _u {yanozuru}, (TA,) inf. n. nazorN, (Ḳ,) He despised, and deemed little, him, or it. (Ḳ.* TA.) See also 2.
He smote him with the [evil] eye. (Fr, in TA, art. Xzr.)

nazarahu, (Aṣ, A,) aor. _u {yanozuru}, (Aṣ,) inf. n. nazorN, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) He drew forth, or got out, what he had, by little and little: (Aṣ:) he importuned him, or pressed him, in asking (A, Ḳ) a matter of science or a gift. (A.) You say also, fulaAnN laA yuEoTiI Hat-aI yunozara, (A, Ḳ,) or yunaz-ara↓, (so in two copies of the Ṣ,) Such a one will not give until he is importuned, or pressed, (A, Ḳ,) and despised. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
2. nz-rhu, inf. n. tanoziyrN; (Ḳ;) or nazarahu↓, aor. _u {yanozuru}, inf. n. nazorN; (Mṣb;) He made it little, or small, in quantity; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, a gift; as also Oanozarahu↓. (Ḳ.)
Also nz-rhu He gave him a little, small, paltry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable, gift. (TA.) [It seems to be implied in the TA, that Oanozarahu↓ also has this signification.]
See also 1, last signification.

entry.sense: 4. Anzrhu: see 2, in two places.
Also, He (God) caused him to be possessed of little good, or little wealth. (AZ.)
5. tnz-r i. q. taqal-ala, (Ḳ,) i. e., It became diminished, or rendered little or small in quantity. (TḲ.) See also nazura.
He asserted himself to be related to the tribe of Nizár: (Ḳ:) or he made himself like that tribe: or he introduced himself among them, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) not being one of them. (TA.)

hom.sense: nazorN, applied to anything, (TA,) little, or small, in quantity or number; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) paltry, mean, contemptible, or inconsiderable: (Ṣ, TA:) as also naziyrN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and nazuwrN↓ (Mṣb) and manozuwrN↓: (Ḳ:) or the last signifies little, or small, in quantity, applied to a gift, (Ṣ, TA,) and to food; (TA;) or a gift made little, or small, in quantity: (Mṣb:) and nazorN and manozuwrN↓ a gift obtained by importunity or pressing: and gayoru manozuwrN↓ a gift given without its being asked for; without importunity or pressing. (TA.) It is also applied to speech: thus the speech of Moḥammad is described as faSolN laA nazorN walaA hacorN [Distinct;] not little, or scanty, so as to indicate impotence, nor much and corrupt: (Ḳ:) or not little nor much. (TA, art. hcr.)
A man possessing little, or no, good, or goodness; little, or no, wealth; and so fazorN; as also manozuwrN↓. (AZ.)
maA jiYota Uil-aA nazorFA Thou hast not come otherwise than slowly, tardily, or late. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: nazirapN: see nazuwrN.
nizaArN The quality, in a she-camel, of scarcely ever conceiving except against her will. (TA.)
nazuwrN Any thing little, or small, in quantity or number. (Ḳ.) See also nazorN.

A woman having few children; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in like manner applied to a bird; (Ṣ, TA;) as also nazirapN↓, with kesr to the z, applied to a woman: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former, nuzurN: (TA:) or the former epithet signifies having little milk; (Ḳ;) applied in this sense to a she-camel. (TA.) A she-camel having wide orifices to her teats. (L, voce ftwH.)
Of little speech; that speaks not until importuned, or pressed. (En-Naḍr.)
A she-camel whose young one has died, and that affects the young one of another, (Ḳ, TA,) but whose milk comes not save scantily. (TA.)
A she-camel (TA) that scarcely ever conceives except against her will: (Ḳ:) a mare slow to conceive. (L.)
naziyzN: see nazorN.
manozuwrN: see nazorN; in five places.

nasonaAsN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nisonaAsN (Ḳ) A kind of creatures (xaloq [an appellation often applied particularly to human beings]) whereof [every] one jumps, or hops, upon one leg: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is related in a trad., that a tribe of 'Ád disobeyed their apostle, and that God thereupon transformed them into nasonaAs, every man of them having a [single] arm and a [single] leg, [consisting] of one half [of a human being], hopping like as the bird hops, and pasturing like as beasts pasture; (Ḳ;) and these are found in the islands of China: (TA:) or, as some say, these have become extinct; (Ḳ;) for a transformed being lives not more than three days, as the learned have established; (TA;) and what exist now, of this make, are a distinct class of creatures: (Ḳ:) or they are of three kinds; naAsN and nasonaAsN and nasaAnisu; (Ḳ;) and the second of these are the baser sort; (TA;) or the nsAns are the females of them, (Ḳ,) as Aboo-Saʼeed Ed-Dareer says; (TA;) or they are of higher rank than the nsnAs, (Ḳ,) as is said in the O: (TA:) or the nsnAs are [the peoples called] Yájooj and Májooj: (IAạr, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a certain people of the sons of Adam: (Ḳ:) or certain creatures in the form of men, (M, Ḳ,) so called because of the weakness of their make, from nasonasapN, which signifies weakness, (M,) differing from men in some things, and not of them: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to what is said [by some], a certain beast, reckoned among wild animals, that is hunted and eaten, having the form of a man with one eye and leg and arm, and that speaks like man: (Kr, M:) or a species of marine animal: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to El-Mesʼoodee, an animal like a man having one eye, that comes forth from the water, and speaks, and, when it gets a man within its power, kills him: or, as is related in the mjAlsp, on the authority of Ibn-Is-ḥáḳ, certain creatures (xaloqN) in El-Yemen: Abn Alrqys says, that they are of the sons of Sám the son of Sám, brothers of 'Ád and Thamood, not possessing reason, living in the salt-water (AlAjAj) on the coast of the Sea of India: the Arabs hunt them, and speak to them, and they speak the Arabic language, and propagate one with another, and poetize, or versify, and name themselves by the names of the Arabs: (TA:) [in the present day, this appellation is applied to a pigmy: and also, to an ape:] Es-Suyootee says, in the Deewán el-Hayawán, as to the animal which the vulgar call nsnAs, it is a species of apes or monkeys, not living in water, and the eating of which is unlawful: but as to the marine animal, some hold it to be lawful; whereas the sheykh Aboo-Hámid holds the eating of the nsnAs [of any kind] to be unlawful, because it has the form of the sons of Adam. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, cahaba Aln-aAsu wabaqiIa Aln-asonaAsu [The men have gone, and the nsnAs remain]. Being asked who were the nsnAs, he answered, Those who affect to be like men but are not men. (TA.) [For the verb ns-, &c.: see Supplement.]

hom.sense: 1. nasaOa, aor. _a {yanosaOu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nasoCN; (Ṣ;) and ns-O↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanosiYapN, (Ṣ,) He chid (Ṣ, Ḳ) a camel (Ṣ), &c. (L) he urged, or drove, it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nasaOa, aor. _a {yanosaOu}, inf. n. nasoCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and manosaOapN (Ḳ) [and nasuwoCN, mentioned in the TA, art. wDO;] and AnsO↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He postponed, or delayed, a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ. Explained in the Ṣ, Ḳ by Oax-ara, and in the Ḳ by kalaOa, also, both of which words, accord. to the TA, are syn.) [See an ex. of the use of AnsA, without a final C, in art. Eqb, voce Euqobap.]

nasaOa Qll-ehu fI Oajalihi, and AnsO↓ Qll-ehu Oajalahu, God postponed the end of his life; i. e., prolonged his life: (so in the Fṣ:) accord. to IḲṭṭ, nsO Qll-ehu Ajlh, and AnsO↓ fI Ajlh. (TA.) All of these four modes of expression are allowable: (MF:) as also ns-O↓ Qll-eh Ajlh: (Z:) and nasaOahu Qll-eh fI Ajlh, and OanosaOahu↓ Qll-eh Oajalahu. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
OunosiYa lahu fiI Eumurihi, His life was prolonged. (TA, from a trad.)
nasaOa AlUibila, inf. n. nasoCN, He delayed or deferred the watering of the camels; or kept them from water beyond the accustomed time. (L.)
nasaOa fiI ZimoCi AlUibili, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nasoCN, (Ṣ,) He increased the time between the two drinkings, or waterings, of the camels, by a day: (A:) or by a day, or two days, or more. (A, L, Ḳ.)
nasaOa AlUibila Eani AlHawoDi He kept back, or put back, or drove back, the camels from the tank, or cistern. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)
maAlahu nasaOahu Qll-ehu What aileth him! May God render him ignominious! (Kr, L,) or put him backward! (L.) Whom he puts backward, He renders ignominious. (L.)
nasaOa, inf. n. nasoCN, He sold a thing with postponement of the payment; he sold it upon credit. (TA.)
nasaOahu AlbayoEa, and AnsOahu↓ AlbyE, He made the sale to him to be on credit. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) AnsOahu↓ AlmabiyEa He postponed for him the period of the payment of the price of the thing sold. (A.)
nasaOa Eanohu dayonahu, inf. n. nasaMCN; (Akh, Ṣ;) and AnsOhu↓ dynh, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) and AnsOhu↓ Ald-ayona; (Akh, Ṣ;) He postponed for him the period of the payment of his debt. (Ṣ, TA.)

nusiYato, a verb like EuniIa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in sense,] aor. tunosaOu, inf. n. nasoCN, Her menstrual discharge was later than its usual time, and it was therefore hoped that she was pregnant: (Kh, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or her menstrual discharge was later than its usual time, and her pregnancy commenced: (TA:) or she began to be pregnant: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or she conceived. (Aṣ.)
nasaOa All-abana, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) inf. n. nasoCN, (TA,) He mixed the milk with water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
nsO lahu All-abana, and nsOhu All-bn, He mixed the milk with water for him. (TA.)
nasaOahu He gave him to drink nasoC, q. v.; (Ḳ;) i. e. wine, or milk. (TA.)
nasaOato She (an antelope) licked her young one just after its birth. (Ḳ.)
nasaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nasoCN, (Ṣ,) It (a camel, sheep, &c.,) became fat: (TA:) or began to grow fat; when its soft hair (wabar), after falling off, began to grow again. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
4: see 1.
AnsOhu He granted him a delay of payment, or granted him credit, in a sale, or in the case of a debt. (A.)
OanosaOotu surobatiI I made my way to lead me far off. (Ṣ.) [See art. srb.]
5: see 8.
8. AntsO It was postponed, or delayed; syn. taOax-ara. (A.)
AntsO He (a camel, Ṣ,) went far off in the pasture. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
It (a party of people) went far off. (TA.)

AntsO Eanohu He retired, or withdrew far off, from him or it. (Ṣ.) QnotasuwA and tanas-awA occur in two readings of a trad., for QnotasiYuwA, (which is the correct reading,) in this sense. (TA.) [Hence it appears that tns-O↓, accord. to some, also signifies he retired,, &c.]
10. AstnsOhu He asked him to postpone or to grant him a delay in, the payment of his debt. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also 1.]
AstnsOhu AlbayoEa He asked him to make the sale to be on credit, or for payment at a future period. (A.)
AstnsO gariymahu He asked his creditor to grant him a delay in the payment of his debt. (A.)

hom.sense: nasoCN and nusoCN↓ and nisoCN↓ A woman who is supposed to be pregnant; (Ḳ;) as also nasuwoCN↓ (A, Ḳ) and nusuwoCN↓: (A:) or in whom pregnancy has appeared: (Ḳ:) or, nasoCN (Ḳ) and nasuwoCN↓, (TA,) as also nasiIoCN↓, accord. to J and IM, but this is rejected by F, (TA,) a woman whose menstrual discharge is later than its usual time, and who is therefore hoped to be pregnant: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [of nsC] OanosaMCN and nusuwoCN: and nisowapN nisaMCN is also said; and sometimes the sing. (nasoCN), being originally an inf. n., is used as a pl. (TA.)
nasoCN and nasiIoCN↓ Thin, watery, milk: (Ḳ:) or milk mixed with water. (T, Ṣ.) [See 1.]

Also, both words, (TA,) or the former only; (Ḳ, MF;) but nisiIoCN↓ is quoted in this sense, from IAạr, who is said to have pronounced it thus, erroneously, for nasiIoCN; (TA;) Wine; (IAạr;) drink that dispels the reason. (Ḳ.)
nasoCN Fatness: or its commencement; (Ḳ;) its completeness, (consequent upon eating dry food, being called UiqotiraArN. Ṣ.)
jaraI Aln-asoCu fI Ald-awaAb-i, (Ṣ,) or maAra, (TA,) [Fatness, or its commencement, ran through the beasts of carriage].

entry.sense: nisoCN One who mixes, or converses, with others: ex. huwa nisoCu nisaMCK He is one who mixes, or converses, with women. (Ḳ.)
See nasoCN.
nusoCN and nasuwoCN and nusuwoCN and nasiIoCN and nisiIoCN: see nasoCN.
nasaMCN Length of life. (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

The Fakeeh of the Arabs [El-Hárith Ibn-Keledeh, as said in the Mz, close of 39th nwE, where the following is quoted,] says, mano sar-ahu Aln-asaMCu walaA nasaMCa faloyuxaf-ifi Alr-idaMCa waloyubaAkiri AlgadaMCa waloyuWax-iri AlEaXaMCa waloyuqil-a giXoyaAna Aln-isaMCi [Let him whom length of life rejoiceth (but there is no long endurance in life) lighten his debts, and make his morning-meal early, and delay his evening-meal, and take little enjoyment in women]: (Ṣ,* TA:) AlrdAC here means debt. (T, M, TA, in art. rdI, where this saying is cited with some variations.)
nasiIoCN, of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Ṣ,) A month which the Arabs, in the time of paganism, postponed: (Ḳ:) the doing of which is forbidden in the Ḳur, ix. 37. (Ṣ.)

Also, as an inf. n. of nasaOa, (which it is also said to be in the L,) The postponing of a month: i. e., the postponing of the sacredness of a month; transferring it to another month. When the Arabs returned from Mina, [after the accomplishment of the pilgrimage,] it was customary for a man of the tribe of Kináneh to arise and say, OanaA Al-aciI laA yurad-u liI qaDaMCN [“I am he whose decree is not to be rejected”]; (Ṣ;) or Uin-iI laA OuHaAbu walaA OuEaAbu walaA yurad-u qawoliI, or wlA yrd- maA qaDayotu bihi; [“Verily I am not to be accused of a sin, nor am I to be charged with a fault, nor is my saying, (or decree,) to be rejected;”] (TA;) whereupon they would say, OanosiYonaA XahorFA [“Postpone for us a month”]; i. e., “Postpone for us the sacredness of El-Mo- harram, and transfer it to Safar:” for they disliked that three months during which they might not make predatory expeditions should come upon them consecutively, as their subsistence was obtained by such expeditions: so he made El-Moharram free from restriction to them. (Ṣ.) [But this, as appears from what is said in the Ḳur, ix. 37, was not done every year.] The tribes of Teiyi and Khath'am did not observe the sacred months; therefore the naAsiY (or postponer) proclaimed it lawful to slay them therein, when they were aggressors. (TA.)

[The term nasiIoC appears also to have been applied to The postponement of the time of the pilgrimage; which was another custom of the Pagan Arabs, mentioned under this word in the TA.] The Arabs, liking that the day of their return from pilgrimage should always be at one season of the year, postponed it every year eleven days; at the same time keeping sacred the two months in which the pilgrimage took place, and the month next after those two, and also the month of Rejeb, at whatever season this fell. (TA.) [For the same purpose, at one time, they used to intercalate a month in the third and sixth and eight of every eight years. See Ḳur, ix. 36, where the prohibition of this custom is implied; and Sale's Prel. Disc., § vii.].
See nasoCN.

nasiIoCN (Ḳ, TA) and nasiyoYapN↓ and nusoOapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like kuloOapN, (Ṣ,) A postponement, or delay, as to the time of the payment of a debt, or of the price of a thing sold, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) The first is a subst.; (Ḳ;) and also an inf. n.; (L;) [and each of the others seems to be sometimes used as such].
baAEahu binasiyoYapK↓, and binusoOapK↓, (as also bikuloOapK, Ṣ,) He sold it on credit; for payment to be made at a future period. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
nasiyoYapN: see nasiIoCN.
Also, A debt of which the payment is deferred by the creditor to a future period. (TA.)
A sale upon credit, in which the payment is deferred to a certain, or definite, period. (TA.)

hom.sense: naAsiYN, pl. nasaOapN (Ṣ) and naAsiYuwna, (TA,) One whose office it was to perform the act called nasiIoC; i. e., the postponing of a month: (Ṣ, TA:) he was also called qalam-asN, pl. qalaAmisu. (TA.)
naAsiYN Anything fat: or beginning to grow fat: in the Ḳ it is said, kul-u naAsiYK samiynN: in the L, kl- smyn nAsY, which is more proper. (TA.)
manosaOapN: see 1.
Silapu Alr-aHimi mavoraApN fiI AlmaAli manosaOapN fiI AlOavari [Union with kindred is a means of multiplying wealth, a means of prolonging one's memorial]. (TA, from a trad.)
See minosaOapN.

entry.sense: minosaOapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and manosaOapN↓, (Ḳ,) and also without C, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A staff, or stick: so called because a beast is urged or driven with it: (Ḳ:) a pastor's great staff. (TA.) For minosaOatahu, in the Ḳur, xxxiv. 13, some read mino saOatihi; i. e. “from, or of, the end of his staff;” sOap originally signifying the “bent part at each end of a bow;” (Fr, TA, &c.;) and being here used tropically. (TA.) This reading is disapproved by the author of the Ḳ. but is supported by good authorities. (TA.)
munotasaON An interval; a distance; a space. (Ṣ.) Uin-a liI Eanoka lamunotasaON Verily I am far from thee. (Ṣ.)

1. nasabahu, aor. _u {yanosubu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nasobN and nisobapN; (Ṣ;) and aor. _i {yanosibu}, inf. n. nasabN and nisobapN; (Ḳ, TA;) He mentioned his [i. e. another's] relationship, [lineage, or genealogy]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) saying, He is such a one, the son of such a one; or He is of such a tribe, or city; or of such an art, or such a trade; and the like. (Lb. T.)
nasabahu, aor. _u {yanosubu}, inf. n. nasobN, He traced up his [i. e. another's] lineage to his greatest ancestor. (TA.)
nasabahu, [aor. _u {yanosubu}?,] He asked him to mention, or tell him, his relationship, [lineage, or genealogy]. (Ḳ.)
jalasotu Uilayohi fanasabaniI qaQnotasabotu↓ Uilayohi ‡ [I sat by him, and he asked me to tell him my lineage; so I mentioned my lineage to him]. (A.)
nasabatonaA faQnotasabonaA↓ lahaA [She asked us to tell her our lineage; so we mentioned our lineage to her]. (IAạr, from a trad.)
nasabahu AlI fulaAnK He asserted him to be related to such a one: and he referred his lineage, or origin, to such a one.
He referred the origin or derivation of his name to such a one.
He attributed, or ascribed, it to such a one. See, for ex. Sad-aqa and kac-aba in the Mṣb.
nasabahu UilaI kacaA ‡ He referred its origin, or the origin or derivation of its name, to such a thing.
[He attributed, or ascribed, it to such a thing.]

nasabahu UilaI fulaAnK He named him, or called him, in relation, or reference, to such a one; meaning an ancestor: and in like manner, in relation, or reference, to a tribe, a town or district, an art or trade, &c. See nisobapN.
nasabahu UlaI kcaA ‡ He named it, or called it, in relation, or reference, to such a thing.

nasaba Uilayohi kacaA, and, by inversion, nasabahu UilaI kacaA, (see Ṣ and Ḳ, in art. jhl, &c.) ‡ He attributed or imputed to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, such a thing; namely, a fault, &c. [Both phrases are often used as signifying thus by classical writers, and in the present day.]

nasaba biAlomaroOapi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanosibu}, (Ṣ,) and _u, (L,) inf. n. nasiybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nasabN and manosabapN, (Ḳ,) i. q. Xab-aba bihaA; q. v.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He mentioned the woman in an amatory manner, in the beginning [or prelude] of a poem: (TA, voce Xb-b:) he mentioned the woman in amatory language, in the beginning of a qaSiydap, and then turned to the object of praise: [for it is a general rule to commence a qSydp in praise of a king, or hero, or the like, with nsyb; the transition from this is termed Alt-axal-uSu: see also AiqotaDaba:] (IKh:) he mentioned the woman in his poem, describing her as characterized by beauty and youth, &c.: (Lb:) or describing her as characterized by good qualities, whether truly or falsely. (Z.)
This phrase and nasaba Alr-ajula both signify description; the latter signifying “he described the man with relation to his father, or his city or country, or the like;” and the former phrase, he described the woman as characterized by beauty and youth and love or affection, &c. (IDrst.) nasiybN is also employed to signify the describing of the places where the objects of love have taken up their abode in the season of the rabiyE and at other times, and the lover's longing to meet them and be united with them, and what else is comprised in the signification of the words taXobiybN and gazalN. (MF.) [See gazila, and gazalN.]
3. nAsbhu He shared with him in relationship. (TA.)
fulaAnN yunaAsibu fulaAnFA Such a one is related to, or a relation of, such a one. (Ṣ.)
nAsbh, inf. n. munaAsabapN, ‡ He, or it, bore relation to, resembled, was similar to, conformable to, analogous to, correspondent to, suitable to, befitted, him or it. (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb.) See also nisobapN.
4. Ansbti Alr-iyHu The wind was violent, and drove along the dust and pebbles: (Ḳ:) [as also AnXbt].

5. tns-b He asserted himself to be a relation, or kinsman, or to be related, [Uilayoka] to thee. Hence the proverb, Alqariybu mano taqar-aba laA mano tanas-aba: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. e. He is [indeed] an ally who allies himself by affection and friendship: not he who asserts himself to be a kinsman. (TA.)

6. tnAsbwA ‡ They were mutually, or reciprocally, related; resembled one another; were similar, conformable, analogous, correspondent, or suitable, one to another; befitted one another. (TA.) See also nisobapN.
[And tnAsb It was suitable in its parts, proportionate, symmetrical, or uniform.]
8: See 10 and 1.

Antsb UilaI Oabiyhi He asserted his relationship to his father, whether truly or falsely; (Ṣ;) [saying, I am the son of such a one: as was generally done by a champion when he sallied forth to challenge].
Antsb Uilayohi It (a voice) was attributed, or ascribed, to him. (TA, art. gnv.)

10. Astnsb (Ḳ) and Antsb↓ (TA) He mentioned his [i. e. his own] relationship, [lineage, or genealogy]. (Ḳ.) One says to a man, in asking him respecting his relationship, &c., Uisotanosibo lanaA OaIo Uinotasibo lanaA Hat-aI naEorifaka [Mention thy relationship, or lineage, to us, that we may know thee]. (AZ.)
Q. Q. 1. nayosaba bayonahumaA, inf. n. nayosabapN, He went to and fro between them two with malicious and mischievous misrepresentations, calumnies, or slanders, &c. (L, Ḳ.)
nasobN: see nasabN.

nasabN and nisobahN↓ and nusoyapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) Relationship; relation; kindred; consanguinity; [family; race; lineage; parentage; pedigree; genealogy; origin; reputed relationship or lineage or origin;] (Ḳ;) with respect to father and mother; (ISk;) or with respect to fathers only: (Ḳ:) pl. of the first, OanosaAbN; (Ṣ;) of the ↓second, nisabN; and of the ↓third, nusabN. (Mṣb.) The first, by poetical license, is contracted into nasobN↓. (T.) [You say,] bayonahumaA nasabN Between them is relationship; said whether they may lawfully marry one another, or not. (Mṣb.) See nasiybN.
nisobapN ‡ Relation; proportion; comparison; with respect to quantity, or measure, and the like. See nasabN.

sense.hi: In proportion to such a thing.

entry.sense: nisobapu AlEaXarapi UilaI AlmiAYapi The proportion of ten to a hundred is [that of a tenth]. (Mṣb.)
[You also say biAln-isobapi UilaI kacaA In relation to, or in comparison with, such a thing.]

nisobapN A name of relation to a father, mother, tribe, town or district, art or trade, &c.: [as EalawiI-N, faATimiI-N, quraXiI-N, mak-iI-N, jawohariI-N:] ending with I-. A more general name of this kind should precede a more particular one: thus you say AlquraXiI-u AlhaAXimiI-u: and it is better that a name of relation to a tribe should precede one of relation to a town or the like: thus you say AlquraXiI-u Almak-iI-u. It is said that the Arabs originally called themselves by such names only in relation to tribes; and that, when they took up their abodes in cultivated lands and in cities, they borrowed names of relation to towns and the like from the Persians and Copts. (Mṣb.)

nisobapN (TA) and munaAsabapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and tanaAsubN↓ (TA) ‡ Resemblance; similarity; conformity; analogy; correspondence; suitableness; fitness. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) Ex. bayona AlX-ayoYayoni nsbpN, and mnAsbpN↓, and tnAsbN↓, Between the two things is a resemblance, &c. bayonahumaA nsbpN qariybapN. Between them two is a near resemblance, &c. (TA.) [nisobapN Hukomiy-apN The relation of a predicate to its subject (in books on logic).]
nusobapN: see nasabN.
nasiybN i. q. munaAsibN↓, [A sharer in relationship; one who becomes a sharer in relationship by marriage]: (Ḳ:) pl. nusabaACu and OanosibaACu. (TA.)

nasiybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and manosuwbN↓ (Ḳ) One related; a relation; a kinsman. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say fulaAnN nasiybiI [Such a one is my relation]: and humo OanosibaAYiI [They are my relations]. (TA.) nasabN↓, also, is used for cuw nasabK [A relation, or kinsman]; and means a male, or female, relation; (Jel, xxv. 56;) and for cawuw nasabK [relations, or kinsmen]. (Bḍ, ibid.) [See also SihorN.]
nasiybN and manosuwbN↓ A man of rank, or quality, or the like, and of family, or lineage. (TA.)
nasiybN naAsbN↓ [An elegant amatory mentioning of a woman, or of women, in the beginning of a poem] is a phrase like XaEorN XaAEirN. (Ḳ.) See Oanosabu.

nas-aAbN (Ḳ) and nas-aAbapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Skilful in genealogy: (Ḳ:) [or rather, the former signifies very skilful in genealogies; or a great genealogist:] the latter, possessing the utmost knowledge in genealogies; or a most skilful genealogist: [this being of a doubly intensive form;] the p being annexed to render the epithet one of excessive praise: (Ṣ:) pl. of the former nas-aAbuwna, and of the latter nas-aAbaAtN: (TA:) you say EinodiI valaAvapu ns-AbAtK, meaning vlAvp rijaAlK ns-AbAtK. (Ṣ.)
nas-aAbapN: see nas-aAbN.
naAsibN: see nasiybN.

nayosabN A straight, or direct, and conspicuous, or open, road, or way: (Ḳ:) or narrow road, or way: (TA:) as also nayosabaAnN↓: (Ḳ:) some say nayosamN, which is a dial. form: (TA:) or nysb signifies the traces of a road, or way. (Ḳ.)

Also nayosabN Ants that appear like a road; (Ṣ;) ants following one another uninterruptedly. (Ḳ.) Dukeyn Ibn-Rejà says,
EayonFA taraI Aln-aAsa UilayohaA nayosabaA
[A source to which thou seest the people (repairing like) ants proceeding in uninterrupted succession]. (Ṣ.)
Also, the track of ants, (ISd, Ḳ,) and of a serpent, and of wild asses going to their watering-places. (TA.)
nayosabaAnN: see nayosabN.

hecaA AlX-iEoru Oanosabu This poetry is more, or most. elegant in what is termed nasiyb. see 2: (Ḳ:) as though they had said nasiybN naAsibN, like XiEorN XaAEirN, to give intensiveness to the signification, and thence formed the word Oanosabu. (TA.)
xaT-N manosuwbN [A] regular [hand-writing]: syn. cuw qaAEidapK: (TA:) [properly, named in relation to its author, &c.]
XiEorN manosuwbN Poetry, or a poem, in which is nasiyb, [or an amatory mention of a woman, or women, in its beginning]: pl. manaAsiybu. (Ḳ.) See nasiybN.
munaAsibN: see nasiybN.
munaAsabapN and tanaAsubN: see nisobapN.
1. nasaja, aor. _i {yanosiju}, inf. n. nasojN, He, or it, drew, collected, or gathered, together a thing: drew and joined, or adjoined, one thing to another. This is the primary signification. (L.)

nasajati Alr-iyHu Alwaraqa wAlhaXiyma The wind gathered together the leaves and the dry fragments of plants. Hence, accord. to some, nasaja Alv-awoba, because the weaver adjoins the warp to the woof. (TA.)
nasajati Alr-iyHu Alt-uraAba ‡ The wind drew the dust together. (TA.)

nasajati Alr-iyHu AlmaMCa, and Alr-amola, and Alt-uraAba, and rasoma Ald-aAri, ‡ The wind made rippling lines, in cross directions, upon the water, and the sand, and the dust, and [with dust] upon the traces of the dwelling. (A.) [And so] Uinotasajato↓ TaraAYiqu kaQloHubuki ‡ Rippling lines were made, in cross directions, by the wind, upon the water, (Ṣ,* A,) and the sand, and the dust, and the traces of the dwelling. (A.)

nasajati Alr-iyHu Alr-aboEa ‡ The wind, blowing in cross directions, obliterated the traces of the place where persons had alighted, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [by covering it with dust or sand in such a manner as that it might be likened to a web].
nasaja ‡ It (a spider) wove, or spun, its web. (A.)
nasaja Alv-awoba, aor. _i {yanosiju} and _u {yanosuju}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nasojN, (Ṣ,) He wove the piece of cloth, or the garment. (TA, &c.) And nasaja sayorFA He plaited a thong. (TA, in art. nsE.)
nasaja AlX-iEora ‡ He wove, or composed verses. (TA.)
nasaja AlkalaAma ‡ He (a liar, TA,) forged speech. (Ḳ.)
Also, ‡ He explained, or expounded, language; syn. lax-aSahu. (Ḳ.)
nasajati Aln-aAqapu fiI sayorihaA ‡ The she-camel moved her legs quickly in going along. (TA.)
8. Antsj It became drawn, collected, or gathered, together: became drawn and joined, or adjoined, to another thing. (L.) See 1.
Antsj It (a piece of cloth, or a garment,) became woven. (TA.)
nasoju AlEanokabuwti ‡ The spider's web. (A.)
See nasyjN.
nusujN Prayer-carpets; carpets upon which prayer is performed; syn. saj-aAdaAtN. (IAạr, Th, Ḳ.)

nasuwjN ‡ A she-camel that moves her legs quickly in going along: (TA:) or a she-camel whose load that she carries does not shake about: (Ḳ:) so in all the copies of the Ḳ; but accord. to more than one of the leading lexicologists, a she-camel whose load, and saddle, are unsteady upon her, and shaking about: (TA:) and a she-camel that makes her load to shift forward to her kaAhil, [or the part of the back next the neck,] by reason of the vehemence of her pace. (ISh, Ḳ.)
nasiyjN and nasojN↓ [the latter originally an inf. n.] i. q. manosuwjN, Woven. (Mṣb, TA.) [And hence both, as substs., signify A web.] So nasiyjapN↓ a web, a thing woven. (Ṣ, Ḳ. art. Trq.)

huwa nasiyju waHodihi (an indeterminate expression, Hishám and Fr, in L, art. wHd, q. v.,) ‡ He is unequalled, unique, or an only one of his kind, in knowledge, &c.: for when a garment, or piece of cloth, is of a high quality, no other is woven of exactly the same kind. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) It is only said in praise of a person. (TA.) [Opposed to Euyayoru waHodihi.]
vawobN nasoju↓ Alyamani A garment, or piece of cloth, the texture of El-Yemen. (Mṣb.)
nasoju↓ Algayovi ‡ [The texture of the rain]; meaning the plants, or herbage. (TA.)
nasaAjapN A kind of miloHafap, with which a person envelops himself. App. thus called by what is originally an inf. n. (L, from a trad.).
nisaAjapN The art of weaving. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nasiyjapN: see nasiyjN.
nas-aAjN [in some copies of the Ḳ, naAsijN↓, the act. part. n. of nasaja,] A weaver. (Ḳ.)
nas-aAjN also, A manufacturer of coats of mail. (Ḳ)
nas-aAjN also, ‡ A liar; (Ḳ;) a forger of lies. (TA.)
naAsijN: see nas-aAjN.
manosijN and manosaxN A place where the art of weaving is practised. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See minosajN.

minosajN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and minosijN (TA) [A weaver's loom;] the apparatus upon which the web is stretched to be woven; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the wood and apparatus used in the art of weaving, upon which the web is stretched to be woven: (M:) or, specially, the Haf-; (TA;) i. e. the stay of a weaver's loom; syn. Haf-N: (TḲ:) [in the present day, applied to a frame for weaving: and to one for embroidering].

minosajN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and manosijN↓ (TA) [The wither of a horse: or the lower part thereof: or the part below the withers:] the prominent part from the branches of the shoulder-blades to the lower part of the neck and to the even part of the back; as also HaArikN: behind it is the kaAhil: (AʼObeyd:) or in a horse, the same as the kAhl in a man, and the HArk in a camel: (TA:) or the part of a horse below the HArk [which latter is the withers, or the upper part thereof]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the swelling part of the kaAvibap [or withers] of a beast, at the place where the mane terminates, beneath the pommel of the saddle: (T:) said to be so called because the sinews of the neck extend towards the back, and those of the back towards the neck, and are woven together upon the shoulder-blades: (TA:) or the extremity of the mane: (A:) or the part between the mane and the place where the shoulder-blades unite: pl. manaAsiju. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. nasaHa, aor. _a {yanosaHu}, (inf. n. nasoHN, Ṣ,) He dispersed and removed dust; syn. OacoraI. (Ḳ, and some copies of the Ṣ.)
nasiHa, aor. _a {yanosaHu}, (inf. n. nasaHN, Ṣ,) He coveted; syn. TamiEa. (Ḳ, and some copies of the Ṣ.)

entry.sense: minosaAHN A thing with which dust is dispersed and removed. (Ḳ.)

1. nasaxa, aor. _a {yanosaxu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. nasoxN; and Antsx↓; (L;) He, or it, annulled, superseded, obliterated, effaced, or cancelled, (L, Ḳ,) a thing, biXaIoCK Mxara by another thing. (L.) It annulled, or superseded, a thing, and took the place of it. (L.) Ex. nasaxati AlX-amosu AlZ-ila, and Antsxth↓, ‡ The sun annulled, or superseded, the shade, (Ṣ, L,) and took the place of it. (L.) nasaxa AlX-ayobu AlX-abaAba ‡ Hoariness took the place of youth. (A, Mṣb.) Also, nasaxa He annulled, superseded, abolished, or made void, a thing, substituting for it another thing. (Ḳ.) Ex. nasaxa MyapF He (God) abrogated, annulled, or superseded, the verse of the Ḳur-án, (Lth, Fr, Ṣ, L,) substituting for it another; (Lth, Fr, L;) biQloMyapi by the [i. e. another] verse: (Ṣ:) or he changed it by substituting for it another: nasaxa signifying he changed a thing by substituting for it another thing. (IAạr, L.) [See also 4.] Legal nasox, or abrogation, may respect the letter and the force of command, or one of these; whether the command have been performed, as is generally the case, or have not been performed, as in the case of the sacrifice of Ishmael, [or, as some of the Muslims say, agreeably with the Bible narrative, Isaac,] for Abraham was commanded to sacrifice him, and then the command was abrogated before its execution. (Mṣb.)

Also, nasaxa He, or it, changed, or altered, a thing. (Ḳ.) Ex. nasaxati Alr-iyHu MvaAra Ald-aAri The wind changed, or altered, [or, it may also be rendered, obliterated, or effaced,] the traces of the dwelling. (Ṣ.)

nasaxahu He transformed him, or metamorphosed him, into a worse, or more foul, or more ugly, shape; i. q. masaxahu: (Ḳ:) ex. nasaxahu Qll-ehu qirodFA God transformed him into an ape. (Fr, Aboo-Saʼeed.)

[Also, as used in post-classical, and perhaps in classical, times, He (God) caused his soul to pass into the body of another man.]
The connexion of the soul of a human being, after its departure from the body, with the body of another human being, is termed nasoxN; with the body of a beast, masoxN; with a plant, fasoxN; and with an inanimate and not-increasing body, rasoxN. (Marginal note in a copy of the KT.) [But see 1 (last sentence) in art. fsx. See also 6.]
nasaxa He transferred a thing from one place to another, it remaining the same: (TA:) he transferred what was in a bee-hive to another [hive or place]. (Ḳ.)

nasaxa AlkitaAba, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanosaxu}, inf. n. nasoxN; (Mṣb;) and Antsxhu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Astnsxhu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) are syn., (Ṣ,) signifying He copied, or transcribed, the writing, or book, (T, Mṣb, Ḳ,) letter for letter. (T.)
maA nasaxahu waUin-amaA masaxahu [He has not copied it, but only corrupted it by changing the diacritical points and altering the meanings]. (A.)
nasotanosixu↓, in the Ḳur, xlv. 28, signifies We set down, or register, and preserve: (Jel:) or We command to be transcribed and to be set down, or registered. (T.)
3: see 6.

4. Ansx He (God) made a verse of the Ḳur-án to be abrogated, annulled, or superseded, by another verse: (Z, MF:) or found it to be so; like OaHomadahu “he found him, or it, to be praised, or praiseworthy.” (AAF.) In the Ḳur, ii. 100, Ibn-'Ámir reads maA nunosixo for mA nanosaxo. (TA.) [See also 1.]
6. tnAsxt AlOaXoyaMCu The things succeeded one another, one taking the place of another. (L.)
tnAsxt Alquruwnu, (A, Mṣb,) and AlOazominapu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ The times succeeded, one in the place of another; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) one passing away after another. (Ḳ.)

tnAsxt Alwaravapu, ‡ [The heirs died, one after another, and so cancelled their rights to inheritance]. (A.) tanaAsuxN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and manaAsuxapN↓ (Ḳ) in the case of an inheritance, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or with respect to the fixed primary portions of an inheritance assigned by the Ḳur-án, is The dying of heirs after other heirs while the original inheritance remains undivided. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
tnAsx It became changed from one state to another. (L.)

tnAsxt AlOarowaAHu ‡ [The souls transmigrated]. (MF.) tanaAsuxN, [The transmigration of the soul from one human body to another, is thus explained;] the connexion of the soul with the body after its separation from another body, without the intervention (taxal-ul) of any time between the two connexions, by reason of the essential love subsisting between the soul and the body. (KT; in some copies of which tHl-l is put for txl-l.) [See also 1.]
nusoxapN A copy, or transcript: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) so called because it supplies the place of the original: (L:) pl. nusaxN. (Mṣb.)
Also, A copy, or an original, from which a transcript is made: (L:) [pl. as above].
nusaxiy-apN: see nasiyxapN.
balodapN nasiyxapN, and nusaxiy-apN↓, A distant town, or district, or country. (Ḳ.)
[A transverse or cross wind. See nay-iHap in art. nwH.]
naAsixN and munotasixN↓ A copier, or transcriber, of a writing or writings, or of a book or books. (L.)

MyapN naAsixapN A verse of the Ḳur-án that abrogates, annuls, or supersedes, another verse. (Ṣ.) [See 1.] [And so,] MyapN manosuwxapN↓ A verse of the Ḳur-án that is abrogated, annulled, or superseded, by another verse. (Ṣ.)

[naAsixN An epithet applied to a particle, (namely, Uin-a and the like, and maA and lA,) or a verb, (namely, the abstract kaAn and the like, and kaAda and the like, and Zan-a and the like,) which effects a change of the grammatical form, or of the meaning, in a nominal proposition before which it is placed. Alxuruwfu AlnAsixapu liloUibotidaMCi The particles which annul the quality of the inchoative.]
Alt-anaAsuxiy-apu (Ḳ) ‡ The sect which holds the doctrine of tanaAsuxu AlOarowaAHi [or the transmigration of souls], and denies the resurrection. (MF.)
manosuwxN and munotasaxN↓ A writing, or book, copied, or transcribed. (Mṣb.)
See naAsixN.
munotasaxN: see manosuwxN.
munotasixN: see naAsixN.

hom.sense: 1. nasara, aor. _u {yanosuru} (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and _i {yanosiru}, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. nasorN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) He (a bird, M, Ḳ, or a hawk or falcon, Ṣ, [or other bird, see nasorN below,]) plucked flesh (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) with his beak. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, nasarahu biminosarihi, meaning, He (a hawk or falcon [or other bird]) plucked his flesh with his beak. (A.)
[Hence,] nasarahu ‡ He blamed him; found fault with him; spoke evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, saying of him what would grieve him if he heard it. (A.)

entry.sense: 10. Astnsr He (the bagaAv [or ignoble bird, or most ignoble of birds,] S, M) became a nasor [or vulture]: (M:) or became like the nasor (Ṣ, Ḳ) in strength. (Ḳ.) Hence the proverb, Uin-a AlbagaAva biOaroDinaA yasotanosiru [Verily the most ignoble bird, or most ignoble birds, in our land becomes like the vulture, or become like vultures]: (Ṣ, M:) meaning, the weak among us becomes strong. (Ṣ.) See also art. bgv.

hom.sense: nasorN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and sometimes nisorN↓ [agreeably with the modern general pronunciation] and nusorN↓, (Sheykh-el-Islám Zekereeyà, in his Comm. on the Expos. of Bḍ,) but this is very strange, (MF,) [The vulture; app. any vulture, whatever be its species or variety, known to the Arabs, except the raxam, or aquiline vulture; and said to be applied by some of the Arabs to the eagle; (see also nusaAriy-apN;) agreeing with the Hebrew נֶשֶׁר, which is plainly applied to the former bird in Micah, i. 16, and probably in other instances;] a certain bird, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known; (A, Mṣb;) so called because it plucks (yanosuru) a thing, and swallows it, (A, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or, and pulls it out (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or, and chases and captures it; (so in some copies of the Ḳ; the various readings being wayabotaliEuhu and wayaqotaliEuhu and wayaqotaniSuhu;) it is said that it has no mixolab [or talon], but only the Zufor [or nail], like that of the domestic cock and hen, and of the crow and the like, and of the raxamap [or aquiline vulture]: (Ṣ:) the bird called in Persian karokaXo, which eats carcases until it is unable to fly, and is said to live a thousand years: (Ḳzw:) AḤn asserts, that the nsr is a bird of the description called EitaAq; [which is a term applied to birds of prey, and to noble birds, (in a sense wider than that in which this appellation is used in English falconry,) and especially to eagles;] but [ISd says] I know not how that is: (M:) pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) OanosurN and (of mult., Ṣ) nusuwrN. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Aln-asoru AlwaAqiEu † [The Falling, or Alighting, Vulture,] and Aln-asoru AlT-aAYiru † [The Flying Vulture,] are two stars or asterisms, (Ṣ,* M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) well-known, (M,) which together are called Aln-asoraAni [the Two Vultures], (M, A,) and each of which alone is called Aln-asoru (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nasorN; (M;) being likened to the bird so named: (M:) the former is the bright star [a] in the constellation AlX-aloyaAqu [or Lyra] likened by the Arabs to a vulture (nsr) that has contracted its wings to itself, as though it had alighted upon something: and the latter consists of the three well-known stars [a and b and g] in the constellation AlEuqaAbu [or Aquila]: (Ḳzw:) [The former rose heliacally, about the epoch of the Flight, in central Arabia, on the 25th of November, O. Ṣ., with the Eighteenth Mansion of the Moon, which is a of Scorpio; and the latter, on the 28th of December, O. Ṣ.: and both set, together, anti-heliacally, at that period and in that part, on the 24th of July, O. Ṣ. See nawoCN, and dabuwrN.]

nasorN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb) and Aln-asoru, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) the latter occurring in a verse cited in art. Ez, (Ṣ,) A certain idol, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) belonging to Dhu-l-Kelaa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the land of Himyer, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) as yaguwvu did to Medhhij, and yaEuwqu to Hemdán, of the idols of the people of Noah, (Ṣ,) all of which are mentioned in the Ḳur, lxxii. 22 and 23: (Ṣ, M:) or a certain good man, who lived between Adam and Noah, and of whom, after his death, was made an image, which, after a long time, became an object of worship; like wad-N and suwaAEN and yaguwvu, and yaEuwqu, mentioned therewith in the Ḳur, ubi supra. (Bḍ.)

Also, nasorN [The frog, or frush, of the hoof of a horse or ass or mule; thus called in the present day;] a portion of tough flesh, [or rather a horny substance,] in the bTon [or sole] of the solid hoof, as though it were a datestone, [which it resembles in substance,] or a pebble: (Ṣ:) or the flesh of the solid hoof, which the poets liken to date-stones: (T:) or a portion of flesh, (Ḳ,) or of hard flesh, (M,) in the baATin [or sole, or inner part,] of the solid hoof, (M, Ḳ, TA,) as though it were a pebble, or a date-stone, (TA:) or what rises in the bATn of the hoof of the horse, from, or of, the upper part thereof: (M, Ḳ:) or the bATn itself of the solid hoof: (M:) pl. nusuwrN, (M, Ḳ,) which Aboo-Saʼeed explains as signifying the prominences in the baTon [or sole] of the solid hoof, which are likened to date-stones because of their hardness, and which do not touch the ground. (TA.) Hence the saying, HaAfirN Sulobu Aln-usuwri [A solid hoof hard in the frog: the sing. and pl. being used indiscriminately]. (TA.)

entry.sense: nusorN: see nasorN, first signification.
nisorN: see nasorN, first signification.

nisoriynN [The wild rose, dog-rose, eglantine, or sweet brier: so in the present day: and, accord. to Spreng., Hist. Rei Herb., cited by Freytag, the jonquil:] a well-known rose; (Ḳ;) a well-known sweet-smelling flower; (Mṣb;) a species of sweetsmelling flower; (M;) a Persian word, (M, Mṣb,) arabicized: (Mṣb:) of the measure fiEoliyl; and, if so, the [final] n is radical: or of the measure fiEliynN; and if so, that letter is augmentative: Az says, I know not whether it be Arabic or not. (Mṣb.)
nusaAriy-apN The eagle; syn. EuqaAbN: (IAạr, Ḳ:) likened to the nasor. (IAạr, TA.) [Hence it appears that, accord. to IAạr, the nasor is not the eagle.]

naAsuwrN (also written with S, Ṣ, Mṣb,) A certain disease that happens in the inner angles of the eyes, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with an incessant defluxion therefrom: (Ṣ, TA:) and sometimes it happens also in the part around the anus: and in the gum: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or it signifies also a certain disease in the part around the anus: and a certain disease in the gum: (Ḳ:) and is an arabicized word [from the Persian]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) nawaASiyr, pl. of naASuwrN, accord. to certain of the physicians, is a term applied to deep ulcers in the anus, at the extremity of the gut. (Mṣb, art. nSr.)

Also, A vein constantly becoming recrudescent, (EiroqN gabirN,) with an incessant defluxion; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) corrupt within; whenever its upper part heals, breaking forth again with corruption. (TA.) See also garobN.

hom.sense: minosarN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and manosirN↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the former only, (AZ,) The beak of a bird (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) of prey; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or of a hawk or falcon; (A;) that of any other bird being called minoqaArN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

[Hence,] ↓both words also signify † A portion of an army that goes before the main army: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [likened to the beak of a bird of prey; as the side bodies are likened to the wings:] and a troop of horse or horsemen in number from thirty to forty: or from forty to fifty: or from forty to sixty: (M, Ḳ:) or from a hundred to two hundred: (M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a troop of horse or horsemen: (El-Farábee, Mṣb:) or an army that does not pass by anything without snatching it away. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: manosirN: see minosarN, throughout.

hom.sense: 1. naX-a, aor. _i {yanoXiXu}, (A, TA,) inf. n. naXiyXN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and naX-N, (TA,) It (said of water, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, and of other things, Ṣ, Ḳ, such as wine, and flesh-meat, TA) made a sound in boiling, estuating, or fermenting: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and it (anything) made a sound like that of boiling, estuating, or fermenting; or of beginning to do so: and it (water) made a sound in pouring forth. (TA.) You say also, naX-ati Alqidoru, (TA,) inf. n. naXiyXN; (IDrd, Ḳ;) and naXonaXat↓, (TA,) inf. n. naXonaXapN; (IDrd, Ḳ;) The cooking-pot made a sound in boiling: (IDrd, Ḳ:) or began to boil, and so made a sound. (TA.) And naX-a AlmaACu fiI kuwzK jadiydK [The water made a sound in a new earthen mug]: (A:) or naX-a Alkuwzu Aljadiydu fiI AlmaMCi The new [earthen] mug made a sound in the water. (Mgh.) And naXonaXa↓ Ald-iroEu The coat of mail made a sound, (Ḳ,) or clinking. (Fr.)

Also, It (wine, A, Mgh, or the beverage called nabiyc, TA,) estuated, or fermented: (A, Mgh, TA:) or naXiyXN signifies the beginning to estuate, or ferment, of the first of expressed juice [of grapes or dates, &c.]. (TA.)
naX-ati All-aHomapu, inf. n. naX-N, The piece of flesh-meat dripped. (Sh, from certain of the Kilábees.)

Also naX-a,, aor. _i {yanoXiXu}, inf. n. naXiyXN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naX-N, (TA,) said of a pool of water left by a torrent, Its water began to sink into the earth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or its water dried up, and sank into the earth. (TA.) It (water upon the surface of the ground) dried up. (TA.) It (a full-grown unripe date) lost its moisture. (TA.)

naX-a Ald-uhona bAlr-ayoHaAni [aor., app., _u,] He infused the oil, or other ointment, with perfume, by boiling it with sweet-smelling plants until it made a sound in boiling. (TA.) [See also saliyxapN.]
naX-a Alc-ubaAba [aor., accord. to analogy, _u, but vulgarly, in the present day, _i,] He drove [or whisked] a way the flies. (TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 1. naXonaXa, see 1. in two places. See also XinoXinapN.

naX-N The half of an Ouwqiy-ap [or ounce]; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. e., twenty dirhems; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the Awqy-p being forty dirhems; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and five dirhems being called nawaApN: (Ṣ:) or the weight of a date-stone (nwAp) of gold: or the weight of five dirhems: or the quarter of an Awqy-p: (TA:) and the half of anything; (IAạr, Sh, Az, Mgh, Mṣb;) as, for instance, of a dirhem, and of a cake of bread. (IAạr, Sh, Az, Mgh.)
naXaAXapN: see naX-aAXapN.
OaroDN naXiyXapN and naXonaAXapN↓ Salt land that produces no herbage. (IDrd, Ḳ.)

sabaHapN naX-aAXapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and naXaAXapN↓, (Az, TA,) A tract of salt land of which the moisture [or, as in a copy of the A, the earth,] does not dry up, nor its pasture, or herbage, grow: (A, Ḳ:) or what appears of the water of salt lands, and begins to sink therein, so that it becomes salt. (Ṣ.)
naXonaAXapN: see naXiyXapN.
manaX-u Als-aAHili The part of the shore of a sea or great river from which the water has retired. (A.)
minaX-apN [A fly-whisk;] a thing with which the flies are driven a way. (TA.)
duhonN manoXuwXN Oil, or other ointment, infused with perfume, (Ḳ, TA,) by boiling it with sweetsmelling plants until it makes a sound in boiling. (TA) [See also saliyxapN.]

1. naXaOa, aor. _a {yanoXaOu}; and naXuWa, aor. _u {yanoXuOu}; inf. n. naXoCN and nuXuwoCN and naXaMCN and naXoOapN and naXaMCapN; He lived; (Ḳ;) and (accord. to Sh) he rose, or became elevated, or high. (TA.)
[It rose.]
Aln-aXoOapu AlOuxoraI, or Aln-aXaMCapu, [Ḳur, liii. 48,] The resurrection: [lit., the other life]. (TA.)
Aln-aXoOapu AlMxirapu, or Aln-aXaMCapu, [Ḳur, xxix. 19, the same: lit., the latter life]. (TA.) [See also naXoOapN below.]
naXaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naXoCN and naXaMCN (TA) and nuXuwoCN; (Ṣ;) He grew up, (Ḳ,) and became a youth, or young man. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See naAXiYN.]
naXaOotu fiI baniI fulaAnK, (Ṣ,) and manoXaYiI fI bnI flAn, (TA.) I grew up, and became a young man, among the sons of such a one. (Ṣ, TA.)
naXaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naXoCN and nuXuwoCN, (TA,) It (a cloud) rose, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and appeared: said of its first beginning. (TA.)
naXaOa He arose. (TA.)
[It became produced; it originated; Eano from another thing. See 4.]
It happened, occurred, or came to pass. (TA.)
naXaOa lahu raOoIN [An opinion occurred to him, or arose in his mind]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. bdw.)
2. nuX-iYa and OunoXiYa↓ are syn., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [signifying He was reared, made to grow, or grow up, and to become a young man.] See 4.

hom.sense: 4. AnXO He (i. e. God) raised the clouds. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AnXO EalamFA He set up a beacon, or sign of the way, in a desert or highway: (TA:) and so AstnXO↓ EalamFA He set up a beacon, or sign of the way. (A.)
AnXOhu, inf. n. UinoXaMCN, He (i. e. God) caused him to attain the age of manhood, or nearly that age. (TA.) See 2.
AnXO and nXO↓ [so TA: app. nX-O:] He (i. e. God) created; produced; originated. (Ṣ.) AnXO Qll-ehu Alxaloqa God originated the creation. (TA.)
OanoXaOotuhu I originated it; brought it into being or existence; made it, or produced it, for the first time, it not having been before. (Mṣb.)
AnXO He founded or began to build, a house [&c.]. (Ḳ.)
He framed or constructed, a proverb, or phrase. (TA.)
He composed language [such as an ode or the like]. (TA.)
He recited poetry, or a xuTobap, well. (IAạr.)
He forged a tradition, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and attributed it [to the Prophet]. (Lth)
AnXO, followed by an aor., He began (Ṣ, Ḳ) to relate, (Ḳ,) or say, (TA,) or do. (Ṣ.)
AnXO minohu He went forth from it. (Ḳ.) Ex. mino Oayona OanoXaOota, Whence hast thou come forth? (TA.)
AnXOt Aln-aAqapu The she-camel conceived: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)
AnXO Ealayohi He came to, advanced to, or approached him or it. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tnX-O liHaAjatihi He rose and went to accomplish his affair, or business. (AA, Ḳ.)
tnX-O EaAdiyFA He arose and went running to accomplish his affair. (AA.)

hom.sense: yasotanoXiYu Alr-iyHa He scents the wind: said of a wolf: (ISk, Ṣ:) and AstnXO AlOaxobaAra He sought, or searched after, news: (Ḳ, TA:) in both instances, with and without C; (Ṣ,* L;) being derived from naXiytu Alr-iyHa (Ṣ, L) and rajulN naXoyaAnu liloxabari: [see also musotanoXiYap.] (L.)
UisotanoXaOotuhu qaSiydapF [I requested him to compose, or, perhaps, to recite an ode, or the like]. (A.)

entry.sense: naXoCN and naXiIoCN↓ Risen clouds: (Ḳ:) or the first that rises of them: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or their first appearance: (ex. lihecaA Als-aHaAbi naXoCN HasanN These clouds have a good first appearance:) or clouds when they appear like a piece of drapery (mulaMCap) spread out. (TA.)
naXoCN The exhalation, or odour, of wine. (IAạr.) [See 10.]
See naAXiYN.
Also, The young ones of camels: (Kr, Ḳ:) pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] naXaON. (Ḳ.)
naXoOapN and naXaMCapN↓ A creation; an original production. (Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-'Ala, Ṣ) [See also 1.]
See naXiyoYapN.
naXaMCapN: see what precedes.
naXiIoCN: see naXoCN.
naXiyoYapN The first part that is made of a tank, or cistern. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
baAdiI Aln-XyoYp A tank, or cistern, of which the water is dried up, and the bottom apparent. (Ṣ.)
Also, nXyYp The stone that is placed in the bottom of a tank, or cistern. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

The earth that is behind the naSaAYib, (Ḳ,) which are the stones that are set up around the tank, the interstices between which stones are filled up with kneaded clay: (TA:) or it is said to signify what is constructed round the tank; also called OaEoDaAdN. (TA.)
nXyYpu AlbiYori The earth that is taken forth from the well. (TA.)
naXiyoYapN What is fresh and green of the plant which is called, when dry, TariyfapN. (Ḳ,* TA.)

naAXiYN A young person past the age of puberty: (TA:) or a boy or girl past the age of childhood: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a comely young man: (IAạr:) or a youth who has attained the stature of a man: (AHeyth:) a girl, as well as a boy, is called thus; (TA;) and they also say, jaAriyapN naAXiYapN. (AA.) Pl. naXoCN and naXaON (Ṣ, Ḳ [or these two are rather quasi-pl. ns.,] or ↓the former is an inf. n. used as an epithet, Aboo-Moosa,) and naAXiYuwna (AHeyth) and nawAXiYu: (TA:) or the last is a pl. of nAXY as applied to a girl. (MF.) Lth says that naXoCN↓ signifies Young people; or youths; and is used in the sing. also: ex. huwa naXoCu sawoCK He is a bad youth: and he says that he had never heard nAXY used as an epithet for a girl. Fr says that the C of the pl. naXoCN is sometimes suppressed, and they say, in the nom. naXuw SdoqK [Excellent youths]; acc., naXaA Sdq; gen. naXiI Sdq. (TA.)
naAXiYN Clouds not completely collected together. Hence, it is said, is derived the expression naXaOa AlS-abiI-u; which is therefore tropical. (TA.)

naAXiYN Whatever happens (and, perhaps, appears TA,) in the night: pl. naAXiYapN; (Ḳ;) a strange form of pl. of a word of the measure qaAEilN: (M, F:) or naAXiYapN [see Ḳur, lxxiii. 6,] is an inf. n. (Ḳ) in the sense of qiyaAmN: (TA:) AM says, that nAXYpu All-ayoli signifies qyAm Allyl the rising in the night: (TA:) or nAXYp signifies the first part of the night, and of the day: or the first of the hours of the night: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a pious act of the night; i. e., performed in the night: (Ṣ:) or every hour of the night in which one rises: (Ḳ:) or every hour of the night: (Zj:) or a rising after a sleeping, (Ḳ,) in the first part of the night; (TA;) as also naXiyoYapN↓. (Ḳ.)
[manoXaON The place of origination of anything, properly and tropically; its source.]
munoXaON and musotanoXaON↓ A beacon, or sign of the way, raised and pointed. (Ḳ.) [See the verbs.]
Also, the former, An elevated hill.

AljawaAriI AlmsoXaMtu [Ḳur, lv. 24,] The ships with elevated sails: (Mujáhid, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to one reading, AlmunoXiYaAtu↓, The ships elevating their sails: (TA:) or, advancing and retiring; or coming and going: (Fr:) or, commencing their courses. (TA.)
naAqapN munoXiYN A she-camel that has conceived: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)
See munoXaON.
musotanoXaON: see munoXaON.

musotanoXiYapN, (Ḳ,) also without C, (TA,) A female diviner: (Ḳ:) so called because she seeks, or searches after, news: see the verb: or from AnXO “he originated:” (TA:) or musotanoXiYapu, without tenween, is the proper name of a certain female diviner, (T,) one of the Muwelledehs (muwal-adaAt) of Kureysh, in the time of Moḥammad. (TA.)

1. naXiba AlX-aIoCu fI AlX-aIoCi, aor. _a {yanoXabu}, inf. n. nuXuwbN (Ṣ) and naXabN (Ḳ, accord. to TA, &c.: in the CK naXobN:) and nuXobapN; (Ḳ;) and AntXb↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) [and tnX-b↓, q. v.]; The thing stuck fast in the thing. (Ṣ.) naXiba AlEaZomu fiyhi The bone stuck fast in him, or it; (TA;) would not pass through. (Ḳ.)
naXiba, aor. _a {yanoXabu}, inf. n. naXabN, It became caught, or entangled, fiI XaIoCK in a thing; as game in a net, or snare. (Lth.)
AXotarayotu simosimFA fanaXiba fiyhi rajulN [I bought some sesame, and a man seized it, or laid hold upon it, for himself]. (TA.)
naXibati AlHarobu bayonahumo, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. nuXuwbN, (A,) ‡ The war, or fight, became intricate and entangled (AXtbkt), between them. (TA.)
maA naXibotu OafoEalu kacaA ‡ I ceased not to do so. (Ḳ.)
maA naXibotu Oaquwluhu like maA Ealiqotu ‡ I did not cease saying it. (A.)
lamo yanoXabo Oano faEala kacaA ‡ He did not delay to do so; [he did so without delay]. (A.)
lamo yanoXabo waraqapu Oano maAta ‡ Warakah delayed not to die; [died without delay, or immediately;] lit., did not cling to anything else. Occurring in a trad. (IAth.)
naXibahu AlOamoru The thing was incumbent upon him: syn. lazimahu. (Ḳ.)
2. nX-bwA fiI qatoli EuvomaAna [They set about, or commenced, the slaughter of ʼOthmán]. (TA, from a trad.)
nX-b fiI AlX-aIoCi i. q. nX-m: (Ḳ:) mentioned by Lḥ, but as being of weak authority. (TA.)
See 4.
3. nAXbh AlHaroba † He waged open war with him; contended with him therein; [app., with pertinacity]. (Ṣ.)
nAXb Eaduw-ahu, inf. n. munaAXabapN, ‡ [He contended with his enemy with pertinacity]. (A.)
4. OanoXabotuhu fiyhi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and naX-abotuhu↓, (Ḳ,) I made it to stick fast in it, (Ṣ,) so that it would not pass through. (Ḳ.)
AnXb He (a fowler or the like) had game caught, or entangled, in his snare, or net. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He (a hawk) fixed his talons into his prey. (TA.)
AnXbti Alr-iyHu i. q. Ansbt, The wind was violent, and drove along the dust and pebbles. (Ḳ.)
5. tnX-b AlX-awoku biAlv-awobi The thorns caught in, or to, or laid hold upon, the garment. (Mṣb, art. Elq.)
tnX-b fiI qalobihi Hub-uhaA ‡ [Love of her took fast hold upon, or became fixed in, his heart]. (A.)
See 1.
6. tanaAXabuwA Hawolahu They drew themselves together, cleaving one to another, around him. (Ḳ,* TA.)
8: See 1.
Also, He collected fire-wood. (Ḳ.)
AntXb TaEaAmFA He collected together corn, and made for himself property (naXab) thereof. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: naXabN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naXabapN↓ and manoXabapN↓ Moveable and immoveable property; syn. maAlN and EaqaArN: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or the latter only: (Mṣb:) or fixed property, consisting of animate and inanimate things; [or live stock and land, &c.; or land, &c. with its live stock;] lit. vocal and mute, naATiq and SaAmit: (Ḳ:) or nXb is a term mostly applied to immoveable property, such as houses and land; whereas mAl is a term mostly applied to moveable property, such as silver and gold coin, &c.: but this latter term is sometimes applied to all that a man possesses; and sometimes especially, or particularly, to camels. (TA.) See also 8. [You say,] lkumo nasabN wamaA lakumo naXabN maA Oanotumo Uil-aA xaXabN [Ye have (good) lineage; but ye have not fixed property: ye are nothing but logs of wood]. (A, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ: in the CK, with the pron. of the third pers., and with Uino in place of the latter mA.)
naXabN A certain tree, of which bows are made, (Ḳ,) one of the trees of the desert. (TA.)

kunotu mar-apF nuXobapF faSirotu Alyawoma EuqobapN I was once such that, when I clung to a man, he experienced evil from me; but now I have reverted from being such through weakness. (IAạr, Ḳ.*) [See also art. Eqb.] A proverb. Said by El-Hárith Ibn-Bedr El-Ghudánee. Applied in the case of him who has become abased after having been great or powerful. MF observes, that nXbp as syn. with EaliqN is properly written naXabapN↓; and that it is altered here to assimilate it to Euqobap: but it will be seen that nuXobapN is explained in the Ḳ, in another instance in this art. in a sense suitable to it in this proverb. (TA.)

nuXobapN [A holdfast. And hence,] ‡ A man who, when he is involved, or engaged, in an affair, can scarcely be extricated, or disengaged, from it; (A, Ḳ;) or who is unable to accomplish it: (TA:) one who, when charged with, or accused of, a vice, or fault, or the like, will scarcely forsake it. (L.) [See an explanation of a verse cited voce EuSobN.]
nuXobapu a proper name of The wolf. (Ḳ.) Imperfectly declinable. (TA.)

entry.sense: naXabapN: see naXabN, and nuXobapN.
naX-aAbN A maker of arrows. (Ḳ.) See naAXibN.
nuX-aAbN coll. gen. n., Arrows: syn. sihaAmN, (Ṣ,) or nabolN: (Ḳ:) n. un. with p {nuX-aAbapN}: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. naXaAXiybu: (TA:) from naXiba “it stuck fast” in a thing. (Mṣb.)
naAXibN Sticking fast in a thing. (Mṣb.)

Possessing arrows. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) A word of the same kind as laAbinN and taAmirN: (Mṣb:) after the manner of a relative noun; having no corresponding verb from which to be formed. (TA.) qawomN naAXibapN [A people, or party, possessing arrows]. (Ṣ.)
Also, qawomN naAXibapN, (TA,) and naX-aAbapN↓, (Ḳ,) A people shooting, or who shoot, arrows. (Ḳ, TA.)

naAXibapu AlmaHaAli The pulley that sticks fast, or will not run. A poet says,
watiloka banuw EadiI-K qado taOal-awoA
fayaA EajabFA linaAXibapi AlmaHaAli
[And those, the sons of 'Adee, fell short of what they should do, or delayed: and I wonder at the pulley that sticks fast, and will not run!] He compares them, in their holding back from aiding them, [see art. Alw,] to the pulley that will not run. So explained by IAạr, and the L. In the Ḳ explained imperfectly. (TA.)
manoXabN A place whence one cannot extricate himself. Ex. naXiba manoXaba sawoCK ‡ He fell into an evil, or a misfortune, from which he could not deliver, or extricate himself. (A, Ḳ.)
manoXabN [An instrument by which a thing is made to catch, or stick fast: pl. manaAXibu]. [Hence,] manaAXibu qufolK [The catches of a lock]. (AʼObeyd, in TA, voce faraAXN, q. v.)
minoXabN Tough, or dry, bad, unripe dates; syn. busoru AlxaXowi: pl. manaAXibu. (Ḳ.)
OatawonaA bixaXowK minoXabK yaOoxucu biAloHaloqi [They brought us tough, or dry, bad, unripe dates, that choked, or stuck in the throat]. (IAạr.)
manoXabapN: see naXabN.
munaX-abN A garment of the kind called burod figured with the forms of arrows: (Ḳ:) or figured with a pattern resembling the notches of arrows. (A.)
1. naXaja, aor. _i {yanoXiju}, inf. n. naXiyjN and nuXuwjN, It (water) made a sound [in running] upon the ground. (L.)

naXaja, aor. _i {yanoXiju}, inf. n. naXiyjN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naXojN, (Ṣ,) He sobbed: (L:) he became choked with weeping, without raising, or prolonging, his voice therein: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he wept like a child when he is beaten, when his weeping does not find egress, but is reciprocated in his chest: (AʼObeyd:) he became choked with weeping, on an occasion of fright, or fear. (T.)
naXaja, (Ḳ,) or naXaja biSawotihi, inf. n. naXiyjN, (Ṣ;) ‡ He (an ass) made his voice to reciprocate (Ṣ, Ḳ) in his chest: (Ṣ:) he brayed, (AʼObeyd,) on an occasion of fright, or fear. (TA.)
naXaja ‡ It (a cookingpot, and a skin, Ṣ, Ḳ, and a jar, or earthen pot, Ṣ) made a gurgling noise by the motion of its contents, as in boiling. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naXaja, (aor. _i {yanoXiju}, inf. n. naXiyjN, TA.) He (a singer) made a distinction, or an interval, (faSala,) between two sounds, and prolonged [the same]. (Ḳ.)
naXaja † It (a frog) made a reciprocating croaking. (Ḳ.)
naXajati AlT-aEonapu ‡ The stab made a [gurgling] sound within, on the coming forth of the blood. (TA.)
naXaja. aor. _i {yanoXiju}, inf. n. naXiyjN, He, or it, uttered, or made, a sound, or noise. (L.)
naXajN A channel in which water flows: pl. OanoXaAjN (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
EaborapN nuXujN A weeping that reciprocates in the throat, with sobbing. (L.)
naXiyjN The channel of a torrent: pl. OanoXaAjN. (L.)
1. naXaHa, aor. _a {yanoXaHu}, inf. n. naXoHN and nuXuwHN, He drank a little, (L,) less than what would satisfy him: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, contr., he drank until he was full: (L, Ḳ:) as also AntXH↓. (L.)
naXaHa He gave his camel a little water to drink: (L:) he watered horses so as to allay the vehemence of their thirst. (T, L, Ḳ.)
8: see 1.

naXuwHN A little water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Abu-n-Nejm says, describing asses,
Hat-aI UicaA maA gay-abato naXuwHaA , (Ṣ, L,) meaning Until, when they had taken into their bellies a little water: or nXwH signifies a drink less than suffices to satisfy. (L.)

1. naXada, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _u {yanoXudu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb., &c.,) inf. n. naXodN (L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and niXodapN and niXodaAnN, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) or these two are simple substs., (Mṣb,) He raised his voice in seeking for, or after, a stray-beast, or beast that had been lost; he called out and inquired respecting it; he cried it: (L:) or he sought for, or after, it: (Lḥ, AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and [in like manner] AnXd↓ he asked, or desired, to be directed to it. (M, L, Ḳ.)

Also, He made known, or gave information of, a stray-beast, or beast that had been lost; (Lḥ, AʼObeyd, M, L, Mṣb Ḳ;) and so AnXd↓: (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, IḲṭṭ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) thus the latter verb [as well as the former] bears two contr. significations. (M, Ḳ.) See also naAXidN.
naXada † He sought, sought for or after, or desired, a thing. (L.)
naXadahu † He asked, begged, or besought, him. (L.)
nuXida † He was asked, begged, or besought. (Ṣ, L.) See 6: and 4.
naXadahu, (aor. _u {yanoXudu} L,) inf. n. niXodapN [and naXodapN (see below)] and niXodaAnN; (L;) and nAXdhu↓, inf. n. munaAXadapN and niXaAdN; (M, L, Ḳ;) ‡ He adjured him. (M,* L,* Ḳ.)
naXadahu biQll-ehi ‡ He adjured him by God; (L, Ḳ;*) accord. to most of the grammarians and lexicologists, with a desire of conciliating him. (MF.)

naXadahu, (aor. _u {yanoXudu} T, Ṣ,) inf. n. naXodN, ‡ He said to him naXadotuka Qll-eha, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) which signifies I conjure, beg, or beseech, thee by God; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as though thou remindedst him of God, and he remembered; (Ṣ, L;) as also OanoXuduka Qll-eha, and biQll-ehi, (L,) and naAXadotuka↓ Qll-eha, (A, Mgh, L,) and bQll-eh: (Mgh, L, Mṣb:) originally, I conjure thee by God, raising my voice: (Et-Towsheeh:) or it signifies I remind thee of God, conjuring; and originally, I beseech of thee by God; the thing for which one conjures being preceded by Uil-aA or what is syn. therewith, [as lam-aA,] or by an interrogative or imperative or prohibitive: (MF:) or it signifies I remind thee of God, desiring to conciliate thee; as also naXadotuka biQll-ehi: (Mṣb:) or nXdtk Qll-eh, inf. n. niXodapN and naXodapN and niXodaAnN, signifies I adjure thee by God; as also OanoXadotuka↓ biQll-ehi; (M, L,) or this latter is erroneous: (Mgh, L:) and so signifies naXodaka Qll-eha; (M, L, Ḳ;) in which naXod is said to be originally naXodap, an inf. n. put in the place of the verb, or nXdk Qll-eh is a phrase of unpremeditated formation, like qaEodaka Qll-eha and Eamoraka Qll-eha; or this phrase, which occurs in a trad., may be incorrectly transmitted, and should perhaps be OanoXuduka Qll-eha: (IAth, L:) or naXadahu signifies he said to him naXadotuka biQll-ehi wAlr-aHimi [I conjure thee, or adjure thee, by God and relationship;, &c.]: (Lth, T, L:) I beg, or beseech, thee by God, and by relationship, raising my voice. (L.)
naXada He remembered God. (Ṣ, L.)
He knew, or was acquainted with, a person. (L, Ḳ.)
naXadahu Eahodahu, aor. _u {yanoXudu}, He reminded him of his compact, covenant, engagement, or promise. (Mgh.)
3. nAXdhu AlOamora, and fiI AlOamori ‡ He desired and asked of him the thing. (L.)
See 1.

4. AnXdhu, and AnXd lahu, † He answered him; gave him his assent, or consent, to that which he asked, begged, or besought. The A in this case is called Oalifu AlUizaAlapi: as though the verb meant he caused his raising of his voice (naXiydahu) to cease. (L.) See also 6: and 1.

AnXd, (inf. n. UinoXaAdN, A, Mṣb,) ‡ He recited poetry; (Ṣ,* A, L, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) properly, [he chanted it,] with a high voice; (L;) for the reciter [usually] raises his voice in reciting: (A:) he raised it in fame; as also naXada. (L.)
OanoXadaniI XiEorahu He recited to me his poetry. (Ṣ,* A.)
AnXd ‡ [He cited, or quoted, a verse, or verses. (The lexicons, &c., passim.)]
AnXd bihimo ‡ He satirized them. (L, Ḳ.)
AnXd † He gave. (Ṣ, L.) See 6.
5. tnX-d AlOaxobaAra ‡ He sought to learn news (A, Ḳ) without others knowing the same. (A.)
6. tnAXdwA ‡ They recited [poetry] one to another. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

El-Aạshà, in the following verse,
rab-iI kariymN laA yukad-iru niEomapF
waUicaA tunuwXida fiI AlmahaAriqi OanoXadaA
[My lord is generous; he does not sully a favour: and when he is asked, or begged, or besought, in papers, he gives], means, accord. to AO, that En-Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir, when asked, or begged, or besought, to write grants to poets (jawaAYiz), gave: tnwXd is here for nuXida, meaning suYila. (Ṣ, L.)
10. AstnXdhu AlX-iEora (Ṣ, A,* L, Ḳ;*) ‡ He asked or desired him to recite the poetry. (Ḳ.)
niXodapN and niXodaAnN↓ Search for, or after, a stray-beast. See also 1. (Mṣb.) Also, A making known, or informing respecting, a stray beast. See also 1. (Mṣb.)
niXodapN A voice; a cry; a sound. (Ḳ.)
niXodaAnN: see niXodapN.
naXiydN Elevation of the voice: (L, Ḳ:) or the voice itself. (L.)
‡ Poetry recited (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) by people, one to another; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) as also OunoXuwdapN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former, naXaAYidu; (TA;) and of the latter, OanaAXiydu. (A, Ḳ.)

naAXidN [act. part. n. of naXada] in the following verse of Aboo-Du-ád,
watuSiyxu OaHoyaAnFA kamaA Qso
tamaEa AlmuDil-u liSawoti naAXido
[And she listens sometimes like as he who has lost a beast gives ear to the voice of a nAXd], signifies a man making known, or giving information of, a stray-best: or, as some say, one seeking for, or after, a stray-beast; for he who has lost a beast desires to find one who, like himself, has lost one, that he may be consoled thereby. (Ṣ, M, L.) See art. Swx.
naAXiduwna Men who seek after straycamels, and take them, and confine them from their owners. (L.)
OunoXuwdapN: see naXiydN.
mutanaAXadN ‡ Poetry recited by people, one to another. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naXara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yanoXuru}, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. naXorN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He spread, spread out, or open, expanded, or unfolded, (Ṣ, TA,) a garment or piece of cloth (A, Mṣb, TA) or the like, (TA,) goods, &c., (Ṣ,) and a writing; (A;) contr. of TawaI; (A, Ḳ;) as also nX-r↓, inf. n. tanoXiyrN: (Ḳ, TA:) [or the latter is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects, as is shown by an explanation of its act. part. n., which see below. Hence laf-N wanaXorN: see art. lf.]

[He spread out, or, as we say, pricked up, his ears: and hence the saying,] naXara licelika AlOamori Oucunayohi, lit., He spread out his ears at that thing: meaning, ‡ he was covetous of that thing, or eager for it. (Ḥar. p. 206.) [See naAXirN, below.]
naXara Alxabara, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoXuru} and _i {yanoXiru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naXorN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He spread, or published, the news. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

Also naXara, aor. _u {yanoXuru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. naXorN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) [and nX-r↓, or this is with teshdeed for the purpose mentioned above;] He scattered, or dispersed, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) [people, &c.; or] sheep or goats, (Mṣb, TA,) and camels, (TA,) after confining them in the nightly resting-place. (Mṣb.)
He sprinkled water. (A.)
naXarati Alr-iyHu The wind blew in a misty or cloudy day [so as to disperse the mist or clouds]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

naXara Eanohu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. naXorN; (A;) and nX-r↓ Eanohu, (A, L, TA,) inf. n. tanoXiyrN; (Ṣ, A, L, TA;) and in like manner nX-rhu↓; (Ṣ, TA;) ‡ He charmed away from him sickness, (Ṣ,* A, L, Ḳ,*) and diabolical possession, or madness, (L, Ḳ,) by a nuXorap, i. e., a charm, or an amulet; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) as though he dispersed it from him: (A:)
and in like manner nX-rhu↓ he wrote for him a nuXorap. (Ṣ.) El-Kilábee says, faUicaA nuXira AlmasofuwEu kaAna kaOan-amaA OunoXiTa mino EiqaAlK ‡ [And when he who is smitten by the evil eye is charmed by a nuXorap, he is as though he were loosed from a bond]: i. e., it [the effect of the eye] departs from him speedily. (Ṣ [in two copies of which I find nuXira, as above; but in the TA, nuX-ira↓.]) And in a trad. it is said, naX-arahu↓ biqulo OaEuwcu birab-i Aln-aAsi ‡ He charmed away the effect of enchantment from him [by the words “Say I seek refuge in the Lord of men:” the commencement of the last chap. of the Ḳur-án]. (Ṣ.)

naXara, (El-Ḥasan, Zj, A, Ḳ.) aor. _u {yanoXuru}, (TA,) inf. n. naXorN and nuXuwrN; (Ḳ, TA;) or OanoXara↓; (I’Ab, Fr, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb;) or both; (A, Ḳ;) ‡ He (God, Ṣ, A, &c.) raised the dead to life; quickened them; revivified, or revived, them. (Zj, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) I’Ab reads [in the Ḳur, ii. 261,] kayofa nunoXiruhaA [How we will raise them to life], and adduces in his favour the words [in the Ḳur. lxxx. 22,] vum-a UicaA XaMCa OanoXarahu↓ ‡ [Then, when He pleaseth, He raiseth him to life]: El-Ḥasan reads nanoXuruhaA: [and others read nunoXizuhaA, with záy:] but Fr says, that El-Ḥasan holds it to refer to unfolding and folding, and that the proper way is to use AnXr [in this sense,] transitively, and naXara intransitively. (Ṣ, TA.) [See also TawaIa, which has the contr. meaning.]
Hence, OanoXara↓ Alr-aDaAEu AlEaZoma: i. q. OanoXaza, with záy: (Mṣb:) or ‡ The sucking strengthened the bone. (Mgh.)
