naXara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoXuru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. nuXuwrN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA) and naXorN, (Mṣb,) agreeably with what Fr says, (Ṣ,) signifies ‡ He (a dead person) lived after death; came to life again; revived; (Ṣ, TA;) or lived; came to life; (A, Mṣb;) as also AntXr↓. (A.) Hence yawomu Aln-uXuwri ‡ The day of resurrection. (Ṣ.)
naXara, (TA,) inf. n. naXorN, (Ḳ, TA,) ‡ It (herbage, or pasturage,) became green in consequence of rain in the end of summer after it had dried up. (TA.)
‡ It (a plant) began to grow forth in the ground. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, maA OaHosana naXorahaA ‡ How good is its first growth! (TA.)
† It (a tree) put forth its leaves. (Ḳ.)
† It (foliage) spread. (Ḳ.)

naXarati AlOaroDu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoXuru}, (TA,) inf. n. nuXuwrN, (Ḳ,) ‡ The land being rained upon in the end of summer, its herbage, or pasturage, became green after it had dried up: (Ṣ, TA:) or the land, being watered by the rain called Alr-abiyE, put forth its herbage. (A, Ḳ.) See naXorN.
naXara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yanoXuru}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. naXorN, (Ḳ,) ‡ [He sawed wood;] he cut (qaTaEa, Ṣ, or naHata, Ḳ) wood, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with a minoXaAr. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in five places, throughout the former half of the paragraph.
3. nAXrhu Alv-iyaAba [He spread, or unfolded, with him the garments or pieces of cloth]. (A.)
4: see 1, after the middle of the paragraph.
5: see 8, in two places.
6. tnAXrwA Alv-iyaAba [They spread, or unfolded, one with another, the garments, or pieces of cloth]. (A.)

hom.sense: 8. AntXr [quasi-pass. of 1,] It spread, expanded, or unfolded; it became spread, expanded, or unfolded; as also tnX-r↓: (Ḳ:) [or the latter, being quasi-pass. of 2, denotes muchness, &c.]
AntXrt Aln-axolapu The branches of the palm-tree spread forth. (Ḳ.) [And AntXrt AlOagoSaAnu The branches spread forth: and the branches straggled.]
AntXr Alxabaru ‡ The news spread, or became published, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) fiI Aln-aAsi among the people. (A.)
And AntXrt Alr-aAYiHapu † [The odour spread, or diffused itself.] (Ḳ in art. fwH;, &c.)
AntXr Aln-ahaAru † The day became long and extended: (Ḳ:) and so one says of other things. (TA.)

AntXr AlEaSabu † The sinews, or tendons, became inflated, or swollen, (Ḳ,) by reason of fatigue: (TA:) UinotiXaArN is a state of inflation, or swelling, in the sinews, or tendons, of a beast, occasioned by fatigue: (Ṣ:) AO says, that the sinew, or tendon, which becomes inflated, or swollen, is the EujaAyap, (Ṣ,* TA,) and that what is termed taHar-uku AlX-aZaI is similar to this affection, excepting in its not being so well endured by the horse: by another, or others, it is said, that AntXAr of the sinews, or tendons, of a beast, in his fore leg, is a breaking, and consequent displacement, of those sinews. (TA.)
AntXr cakarohu † His penis became erect. (TA.) [And hence,] AntXr Alr-ajulu ‡ The man became excited by lust. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AntXrwA fI AlOaroDi They became scattered, or dispersed, or they scattered, or dispersed, themselves, in the land, or earth. (A.)

AntXrt Alganama, (Mṣb, TA,) and AlUibilu, (Ḳ, TA,) The sheep or goats [and the camels] became scattered, or dispersed, after having been confined in their nightly resting-place: (Mṣb:) or the sheep or goats (TA) and the camels (Ḳ, TA) became scattered, or dispersed, through negligence of their pastor. (Ḳ, TA.)
AntXr AlOamoru † The state of things, or affairs, became dissolved, broken up, decomposed, disorganized, or unsettled; syn. taX-atata. (TA, art. Xt.)
See also 1, latter part of the paragraph.
AntXr also signifies He put himself in motion, and went on a journey. (TA, in art. bsr.)
AntXr Alc-iYbu fiI Alganami The wolf made an incursion among the sheep or goats. (TA in art. XE.)

entry.sense: 10. AstnXrhu He demanded, or desired, of him that he should unfold (Oano yanoXura) to him (Ealayohi) [a thing]. (A.)

hom.sense: naXorN used in the sense of an act. part. n.: see nAXirN.
And in the sense of a pass. or quasi-pass. part. n.: see naXarN.

A sweet odour: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) [because it spreads:] or odour in a more general sense; (A, Ḳ;) i. e., absolutely, whether sweet or stinking: (AʼObeyd:) or the odour of a woman's mouth, (ADk, A, Ḳ,) and of her nose, (ADk, TA,) and of her arm-pits (OaEoTaAf), after sleep. (ADk, A, Ḳ.)

‡ Herbage, or pasturage, which has dried up and then become green in consequence of rain in the end of summer or spring (see below, and see simaAkN): (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is bad for the pasturing animals when it first appears, and men flee from it with their camels, &c.; (Ṣ, TA;) which it affects with the [disease called] suhaAm when they pasture upon it at its first appearance: [see remarks on a verse cited in art. byD, voce baADa: and see another verse in art. jrb, voce Oajorabu:] AHn says, that it does not injure animals with the solid hoof; or if it do so, they leave it until it dries, and then its evil quality departs from it: it consists of leguminous plants and of [the herbage termed] EuXob; or, as some say, of the latter only: (TA:) [an ex. of the word is cited in art. jrb, voce Oajarobu:] or herbage, or pasturage, of which the upper part dries up and the lower part is moist and green: (Lth:) or herbage produced by the rain called Alr-abiyE: (A:) and what has come forth, of plants, or herbage. (TA.)
Life. (Ḳ.)

naXarN is of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Mṣb, TA,) syn. with manoXuwrN, like as qabaDN is with maqobuwDN, (Mgh,) and syn. with munotaXirN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [therefore signifying Spread, expanded, or unfolded: scattered, or dispersed,, &c.: and spreading, or being spread,, &c.: being scattered,, &c.:] and a thing that one has spread, expanded, or unfolded:, &c. (O, voce sabalN, q. v.)
You say AikotasaI AlbaAziI riyXFA naXarFA The hawk, or falcon, became clad in spreading and long feathers. (Ṣ, TA.)

And hence naXarN is applied to People in a scattered, or dispersed, state, not collected under one head, or chief; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also naXorN↓: (Ḳ:) and to sheep or goats in a scattered, or dispersed, state, after having been confined in their nightly resting-place: (Mṣb:) or sheep or goats, and camels, in a scattered, or dispersed, state, through the negligence of their pastor. (TA.) You say, raOayotu Alqawoma naXarFA I saw the people in a scattered, or dispersed, state. (Ṣ.) And jaMCa Alqawomu naXarFA The people came in a scattered, or dispersed, state. (TA.)

Hence also, naXaru AlmaMC What is sprinkled, of water, (Mgh, TA,) in the performance of the ablution termed AlwuDuwoC. (TA.)
It is said in a trad., Oatamoliku naXara AlmaMCi [Dost thou possess what is sprinkled of water?] (Ṣ;) or mano yamoliku naXara AlmaMCi [Who possesseth what is sprinkled of water?] (Mgh;) [app. meaning, that it is gone and cannot be recovered.]

And hence, Oall-ehum-a QDomumo naXariI † O God, compose what is discomposed, or disorganized, of my affairs: (Ḳ,* TA:) a phrase like lum-a XaEaviI. (TA.) ʼÁïsheh says, in a trad., describing her father, farad-a naXara AlUisolaAmi EalaI gar-ihi, meaning, † And he restored what was discomposed, or disorganized, [lit., what was unfolded,] of El-Islám, to its state in which it was in the time of the Apostle of God, [lit. to its fold, or plait;] alluding to cases of apostacy, and her father's sufficiency to treat them. (TA.)
See also naAXirN.

entry.sense: nuXorapN ‡ A charm, or an a mulet, (ruqoyapu, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) by which a sick person, and one possessed, or mad, is cured; (A,* L, Ḳ;) by which the malady is [as it were] dispersed from him. (L.) Moḥammad, being asked respecting that which is thus termed, answered, that it is of the work of the devil: and El-Ḥasan asserted it to be a kind of enchantment. (TA.)
naXuwrN: see naAXirN.
nuXaArapN ‡ [Saw-dust;] what falls from the minoXaAr [or saw]; (Ṣ;) what falls in naXor [or sawing]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: naAXirN act. part. n. of naXara.
kaAna yukab-iru naAXira AlOaSaAbiEi He (Moḥammad) used to say Oall-ehu Oakobaro spreading, or unfolding, his fingers: said to mean not making his hand a clenched fist. (Mgh.)

jaMCa naAXirFA Oucunayohi [He came spreading, or, as we say, pricking up, his ears: meaning,] ‡ he came in a state of covetousness, or eagerness. (IAạr, L.) [In a copy of the A, TaAYiEFA is erroneously put for TaAmiEFA.]

waQln-aAXiraAti naXorFA, in the Ḳur., [lxxvii. 3,] signifies And the angels, (TA,) or the winds, (Jel,) that do scatter the rain: (Jel, TA:) or the winds that do bring rain. (TA.) And riyHN naXuwrN↓, of which the pl. is riyaAHN nuXurN, signifies Wind that spreads [the clouds], or scatters [the rain]; (Ṣ; and Bḍ, vii. 55;) naXuwrN being syn. with naAXirN: (Bḍ:) or it signifies in a scattered state. (Jel, vii. 55.) [In the Ḳur, ubi supra,] yurosilu Alr-iyaAHa nuXurFA bayona yadaIo raHomatihi, and nuXorFA, and naXorFA↓, and naXarFA↓, [Sendeth the winds,, &c.,] (Ḳ,* TA,) all these being various readings, (TA,) nuXurFA is pl. of naXuwrN, (Bḍ, Ḳ,) in the sense of naAXirN; (Bḍ;) or the meaning is, in a state of dispersion before the rain; (Jel;) and nuXorFA is a contraction; (Bḍ, Ḳ;) and the third reading means ‡ quickening, or making to live, by spreading the clouds wherein is the rain, (Ḳ,) which is the life of everything, (TA,) naXorFA↓ being an inf. n. used as a denotative of state, in the sense of naAXiraAtK, or as an absolute objective complement [of yrsl], for UirosaAlN and naXorN are nearly alike; (Bḍ;) and the fourth is extr., (IJ, Ḳ,) and is said to mean munoXirapF naXarFA↓ [which is virtually the same as the third]: (Zj, Ḳ:) another reading is buXurFA, pl. of baXiyrapN, (TA,) or of baXuwrN; (TA, in art. bXr;) or nuXorFA, (Bḍ, Jel,) a contraction of buXurFA, (Bḍ,) pl. of baXiyrN. (Bḍ, Jel.)

OaroDN naAXirapN ‡ Land having herbage, or pasturage, which has dried up and then become green in consequence of rain in the end of summer: (Ṣ:) or having herbage produced by the rain called Alr-abiyE. (A.) See naXorN.

entry.sense: AlmanoXaru ‡ The place of resurrection. (TA.)
SuHufN munaX-arapN [Scattered, or much scattered, writings or the like] is with teshdeed to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects. (Ṣ, TA.)
minoXaArN ‡ [A saw;] a certain instrument for cutting wood. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
Also, [but less commonly], A wooden implement with prongs, [lit., fingers,] with which wheat and the like are winnowed. (Ḳ.)

manoXuwrN What is not sealed, [here meaning not closed with a seal,] of the writings of the Sultán [or of a viceroy]; (Ḳ;) i. e., what is now commonly known by the name of faromaAn: pl. manaAXiyru. (TA.)
† A man whose state of affairs is disorganised, or disordered. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naXazN, aor. _u {yanoXuzu} and _i {yanoXizu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. naXozN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or nuXuwzN, (Mṣb,) He rose, or raised himself, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) fiI AlmakaAni in the place, (Ṣ,) and fiI majolisihi in his sitting-place, (TA,) and Eano makaAnihi, (A,) or mino makaAnihi, (Mṣb,) from his place: (A, Mṣb:) or he rose a little in his sittingplace: (TA:) or he stood up after sitting. (TA.) Both forms of the aor. occur, accord. to different readings, (the former being the reading of the people of El-Ḥijáz, and the latter that of others, Fr, TA,) in the Ḳur, [lviii. 12,] waUicaA qiyla QnoXuzuwA faQnoXuzuwA, (Mṣb, TA,) meaning, accord. to Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, And when it is said, Rise ye and stand up, then do ye rise and stand up. (TA.) Accord. to IḲṭṭ, naXaza Alqawomu fiI majolisihimo signifies The people drew themselves together [in their sitting-place to make room] for those sitting with them: and also they rose from their sitting-place, and stood up. (TA.) You say also, naXaza biAlqawomi fiI AlxuSuwmapi, inf. n. nuXuwzN, He rose with the people for the purpose of contention, altercation, or litigation. (TA.)
He, or it, overtopped, or overlooked, an elevated piece of ground, and appeared. (TA.)
[It rose; rose from its place; was, or became, high or elevated, protuberant or prominent; it protruded.]
naXazato nafosuhu ‡ His soul, or spirit, or stomach, heaved, (A, Ḳ,) by reason of fright. (A, TA.)

Hence, from naXaza in the first of the senses explained above, (Mṣb,) or from naXozN, signifying “high, or elevated, ground,” (Aboo-Isḥáḳ, TA,) naXazati AlmaroOapu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or naXazato EalaI zawojihaA, (A, Mgh, TA,) or mino zawojihaA, (Mṣb,) and bizawojihaA, (TA,) aor. _? and _i, inf. n. nuXuwzN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ The woman, or wife, was, or became, disobedient to her husband, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and exalted herself against him, (TA,) and resisted him, or withstood him, (Mṣb,) and hated him, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and deserted him: (TA:) or she disliked him, or hated him, (Zj, Mgh, TA,) and was an evil companion to him. (Zj, TA.) And naXaza baEoluhaA EalayohaA, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or minohaA, aor. _u {yanoXuzu} and _i {yanoXizu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. nuXuwzN, (TA,) ‡ Her husband treated her injuriously, and was unkind to her, or estranged himself from her: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or forsook her, and was unkind to her, or estranged himself from her: (Mṣb:) or disliked her, or hated her, (Zj, Mgh, TA,) and was an evil companion to her. (Zj, TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AnXzhu He raised it, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely, a place, (Mṣb,) or a thing, (Ḳ,) from its place. (A, Ḳ.)

[Hence,] AnXz EiZaAma Almay-iti He [God] raised the bones of the dead to their places, and set them, or put them together, one upon another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur, [ii. 261,] waQnoZuro UilaI QloEiZaAmi kayofa nunoXizuhaA vum-a nakosuwhaA laHomFA [And look thou at the bones (of thine ass), how we raise them to their places,, &c., then we clothe them with flesh], accord. to the reading of Zeyd Ibn-Thábit; (Fr, Ṣ,* TA;) but the Koofees read [nunoXiruhaA] with rá: the former reading, however, accord. to Th, is preferred. (TA.) [See art. nXr.]
Hence also, AnXr Alr-aDaAEu AlEaZoma ‡ The sucking of the breast increased, or augmented, the bone: as also AnXrhu, with rá. (Mṣb.)

naXozN and naXazN↓ A high, or an elevated, place; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) as also naXaAzN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or high, or elevated, ground: (Zj, TA:) or high, or elevated, and hard, ground: (M, TA:) or what rises from a valley to the [adjacent] ground, and is not rugged: (TA:) pl. (of the first, Ṣ, Mṣb) nuXuwzN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and (of the second, Ṣ, TA, or of the first, Mṣb) niXaAzN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and (of the second, Ṣ, Mṣb,) OanoXaAzN. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, qaEada EalaI naXozK mina AlOaroDi, and naXazK, [He sat upon a high piece of ground.] (Mṣb.) And OuqoEudo ElI celika Aln-aXaAzi Sit thou upon that high place. (Ṣ.)
naXazN: see naXozN.
naXaAzN: see naXozN.

hom.sense: naAXizN Rising; or rising from its place; high, or elevated; protuberant, or prominent; protruding. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, qalobN naAXizN A heart rising from its place by reason of fright. (Ḳ, TA.) And tal-N naAXizN A high, or an elevated, mound, or hill: pl. [reg. of naAXizapN and irreg. of naAXizN] nawaAXizu. (TA.) And rakabN naAXizN A protuberant, high, pubes, or mons Veneris. (TA.) And laHomapN naAXizapN A piece of flesh elevated, or protuberant, upon the body. (TA.) And EiroqN naAXizN A vein constantly swollen and pulsating (A, Ḳ *) in consequence of disease (Ḳ, TA) or from some other cause. (TA.) And rajulN naAXizu Aljabohapi A man having a high, or prominent, forehead. (TA.) And UimoraOapN naAXizapu AlquSayoraI A woman large in the sides, having the qSyrI [or lowest of the ribs] with the flesh upon it, prominent. (IAạr, TA.)

Also, (A, TA,) or naAXizapN, (Mgh,) [but the former is the more common,] ‡ A woman disobedient to her husband, (Mgh, TA,) and exalting herself against him, (TA,) and hating him, (Mgh, TA,) and deserting him. (TA.) See 1. [The former epithet is also applied in like manner to a husband.]

1. naXiTa, aor. _a {yanoXaTu}, inf. n. naXaATN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and manoXaTN, (TA,) He (a man, Ṣ, TA, and a beast of carriage, TA,) was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, frisky, active, agile, prompt, and quick; syn. xaf-a, (Mṣb, TA,) and OasoraEa; (Mṣb;) contr. of kasila; (TA;) or pleased, cheerful, happy, or willing; to do work, &c.; (Lth, Ḳ;) or by reason of his work; (Mṣb;) as also tnX-T↓, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) liOamori kacaA [to do, or on account of, such a thing, or such an affair]. (Ṣ, TA.) You say also, naXiTa Uilayohi [He betook himself to him, or it, with briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, or the like]. (TA.)
[Hence, app.,] naXiTati Ald-aAb-apu The beast of carriage became fat. (Ḳ.)

naXaTa, aor. _i {yanoXiTu}, inf. n. naXoTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) He went forth from a place: (Ḳ:) he passed, or crossed, from one country or the like to another: (TA:) said, for instance, of a wild bull: (AO, IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and in like manner, a star, [meaning a planet,] from one sign of the zodiac to another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And naXaTati AlUibilu, aor. _i {yanoXiTu}, inf. n. naXoTN, The camels went, either in a right direction or otherwise. (TA.)

[Hence,] Alhumuwmu tanoXiTu biSaAHibihaA (Ṣ, TA) † Griefs, or disquietudes of mind, lead forth him who has them [from place to place]. (TA.) Himyán Ibn-Koháfeh says,
Oamosata humuwmiI tanoXiTu AlmanaAXiTaA
OalX-aOoma biI TaworFA waTaworFA waAsiTaA
[meaning tnXT bI AlI AlmnAXT, i. e., † My griefs, or disquietudes of mind, became such as to lead me forth to the places to which one goes forth, to Syria at one time, and at one time to Wásit]. (Ṣ.) You say also of a road, yanoXiTu mina AlT-ariyqi AlOaEoZami ‡ It goes forth from the main road, to the right, and to the left. (Lth, Ḳ.*) And naXTa bihimo TariyqN faOaxacuwhu ‡ [A road led them forth, and they took it]. (TA.)

naXaTa Ald-alowa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanoXiTu} (Ḳ,* TA) and _u {yanoXuTu}, (TA,) [inf. n. naXoTN,] He pulled out the bucket, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or pulled it up, (TA,) from the well, (Ṣ, TA,) without a pulley. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And hence, AlmalaAYikapu tanoXiTu AlOarowaAHa † The angels draw forth the souls like as the bucket is drawn forth from the well: (Zj:) and tanoXiTu nafosa AlmuWomini biqaboDihaA (Fr, L, Ḳ [in the CK taqobiDuhA]) which means, (Ḳ,) accord. to Ibn-'Aráfeh, (TA,) † they loose the soul of the believer gently. (Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence also,] one says of a she-camel, [likening the motion of her fore legs to that of the arms of a man pulling up a bucket from a well without a pulley,] Hasuna maA naXaTati Als-ayora, meaning † Good was her wide stretching out of her fore legs (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA) in her going along. (TA.)

naXaTa AlHabola, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoXuTu}, (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or _i, (Mṣb, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) inf. n. naXoTN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He tied the cord, or rope so as to form a knot; (Ḳ, TA;) as also nX-aThu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoXiyTN: (TA:) or he tied it in a knot such as is termed OunoXuwTap; (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also ↓the latter verb: (Ḥam, p. 742:) and naXaTa AlEuqodapa he tied the knot so as to form what is thus termed: (Mgh:) and naXaTa AlOunoXuwTapa he tied the knot thus termed. (TA.) [See also 4.]
naXaTa, and nuXiTa mino EiqaAlK: see 4.
2. nX-Thu, inf. n. atanoXiyTN, He, or it, rendered him naXiyT [i. e. brisk, lively, sprightly, frisky,, &c.]; (Ḳ;) as also AnXThu↓. (Yaạḳoob, Ḳ.)
See also 1, last sentence but one, in two places; and see 4.

4. AnXT, said of a man, (Ḳ,* TA,) or of a company of men, (Ṣ,) His, or their, beasts, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or family, (Ḳ,) were, or became, in a state of naXaAT [i. e. briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, friskiness,, &c.: see 1]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
As a trans. v.: see 2.
[Hence, app.,] It (herbage) rendered a beast fat. (Ṣ, TA.)

He loosed, untied, or undid, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a cord, or rope, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a knot such as is termed OunoXuwTap; (Mgh, Mṣb,) as also AntXT↓; and naXaTa↓; (Mgh;) and in like manner, the bond termed EiqaAl; (Mṣb;) and so, perhaps, nX-T↓: (Ḥam, p. 742:) he pulled a cord, or rope, until, or so that, it became loosed, untied, or undone; (TA;) as also AntXT↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) he caused the EiqaAl to become loosed, untied, or undone, by pulling its AnXwTp: (Ḳ,* TA:) he loosed, untied, or undid, a knot by a single pull. (TA.) You say also, AnXT AlbaEiyra He loosed, untied, or undid, the AnXwTp [of the EiqaAl] of the camel. (TA.) And AnXT AlbaEiyra mino EiqaAlihi He loosed the camel from his EiqaAl. (Mṣb.) [And hence the saying,] kaOan-amaA OunoXiTa mino EiqaAlK As though he were loosed [from a bond such as is called EiqaAl]: (Ṣ,* Mgh, TA:) a proverb, relating to an event's happening quickly; (Mgh;) or said of him who commences any work quickly; and of the sick when he recovers; and of a person who has swooned when he revives; and of a person sent to execute an affair, hastening his determination respecting it: (TA:) it is often related in a different manner, kAn-mA nuXiTa mn EqAl; but this is not correct. (IAth, TA.) [But see above, in this paragraph; and see 1, where a similar meaning is assigned to the unaugmented verb.]
He bound, or tied, him, or it, firmly, fastly, or strongly: so in the copies of the Ḳ; so that, if this be correct, the verb has two contr. significations. (TA.)
See also 8.
5: see 1, first sentence.
tnX-Tt fiI sayorihaA She (a camel) hastened, or was quick, in her going, or pace. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

tnX-T AlmafaAzapa ‡ He passed through, or over, the desert, (Ḳ, TA,) with swiftness, and with briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, or activity. (TA.) And tnX-Thu † He traversed it quickly, or swiftly. (IB, in TA, voce hirojaAbN.) And tnX-Tt AlOaroDa † She (a camel) traversed, or crossed, the land, like the naAXiT in her quickness, or her aim, with briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness. (TA.)
8. AntXT It (a cord, or rope,) became loosed, untied, or undone. (Ḥar, p. 361.)
† He (a man) became loosed from the tie of silence, (Ḥar, p. 360.; Mgh,) and from that of impotence. (Mgh [in which a doubt is expressed as to its being of classical authority].)
As a trans. v.: see 4, in two places.
He pulled, or drew, a thing. (TA.)

He seized a thing, took it hastily, or snatched it unawares: a meaning wrongly assigned in the Ḳ to AnXT↓. (TA.) You say also, AntXT AlmaAlu AlmaroEaI, (Sh, Ḳ,) and AlkalaOa, (Sh,) The camels, or sheep or goats, pulled up, or out, the herbage, with the teeth. (Sh, Ḳ.)
He scaled a fish; (Ḳ;) as though meaning he pulled off the scales thereof. (TA.)

entry.sense: nuXuTN [app. a pl. of naAXiTN↓] Persons untwisting cords, or ropes, in the time of undoing them for the purpose of their being twisted or plaited a second time. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

naXoTapN as used in the following saying, (Mgh,) AlX-ufoEapu kanaXoTapi AlEiqaAli The right termed XfEp is like the loosing of the bond called EqAl, in respect of the speediness with which it becomes of no effect, (Mgh, Mṣb,) by delay, (Mṣb,) is of the measure faEolapN from OanoXaTa, or from naXaTa in the sense of AnXT; or the meaning is, like the tying of the EqAl; i. e., it is of short duration; but the former explanation is the more apparently right. (Mgh.)
biYorN naXuwTN A well from which the bucket does not come forth until it is much pulled, (Aṣ, Ṣ, TA,) by reason of the distance of its bottom; (TA;) contr. of biYorN OanoXaATN. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: naAXiTN: see naXiyTN.
In a verse of Et-Tirimmáh, [see AstTrb,] naAXiTFA is used for XawoqFA naAziEFA [By reason of yearning, or longing, desire]. (Ḳ, in art. dd.)
A wild bull going forth from land to land, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or from country to country. (TA.)

Hence, (Ṣ,) Aln-aAXiTaAtu, as used in the Ḳur, lxxix. 2, meaning The stars [or planets] going forth from one sign of the zodiac to another: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or it means the stars that rise, then set: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or the angels that draw forth the souls like as the bucket is drawn forth from the well: (Zj, TA:) or the angels that loose the soul of the believer gently: (Fr,* Ibn-ʼArafeh, Ḳ:) or the believing souls that are brisk, lively, sprightly, or active, at death: (Ḳ,* TA:) or, as some say, [too fancifully,] the angels that ratify events; from naXaTa AlEuqodapa, q. v.; and as this signifies the tying of a knot which is easily undone, the thing's easiness to them is thus notified. (TA.)

‡ A road going forth from the main road, to the right, and to the left: (Lth, Ḳ *:) pl. nawaAXiTu: (TA:) which latter word is applied in like manner to water-courses (Ḳ, TA) going forth from the main water-course to the right and left. (TA.)
See also nuXuTN.

entry.sense: biYorN OanoXaATN, (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ, as on the authority of Aṣ, but in another copy of the Ṣ the A is without any vowel,) and biYorN UinoXaATN, (Ḳ, and, accord. to the TA, on the authority of Aṣ, and mentioned by IB on the authority of AʼObeyd,) A well of little depth, from which the bucket comes forth by means of a single pull: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the latter may be defended on the ground of considering UinoXaATN as originally an inf. n., of OanoXaTa signifying “he loosed, untied, or undid,” a knot “by a single pull.” (TA.)

OunoXuwTapN [A knot tied with a bow, or with a double bow, so as to form a kind of slip-knot; whence, in modern vulgar Arabic, Euqodap waXunayoTap, applied to such a tie; and XunayoTap, applied to a simple slip-knot;] a knot, or tie, which easily becomes undone, or untied, like that of the running band of a pair of drawers; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) a knot, or tie, which becomes undone when one of its two ends is pulled. (Mṣb, TA.) You say, maA EiqaAluka biOunosuwTapK, meaning † Thy love, or affection, is not weak, or frail. (Ṣ.)
manoXaTN A thing on account of which, or to do which, one is brisk, lively, sprightly, or active; or pleased, cheerful, or happy; and which one likes, or prefers, to do: opposed to makorahN. (TA.)
[manoXiTN A place to which one goes forth: pl. manaAXiTu. See an ex. of the pl., voce naXaTa.]
munoXiTN: see naXiyTN.
minoXaTN Having much naXaAT [i. e. briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, friskiness,, &c.: see 1]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. naS-a AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ,) aor. _u {yanoSuSu}, (Mgh,) inf. n. naS-N, (Mgh, TA,) He raised the thing; syn. rafaEahu [which is here to be understood, like the English equivalent by which I have rendered it, in several senses, as the sequel will show]. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.) This is the primary signification: (TA:) or, accord. to Aṣ, it is from naS-a Aln-aAqapa, q. v. infra. (Ṣ.) You say, naS-a AlEaruwsa, (M, Ḳ,) or naS-atohaA, (A, Mgh,) or naS-ahA Aln-isaMCu, (Mṣb,) aor. as above, (A, Mgh,) and so the inf. n., (Mṣb,) He, or she, or the women, raised, (A, Mṣb,) or seated, (Ḳ,) or raised and seated, (Mgh,) or showed, or displayed, (M,) the bride upon the minaS-ap, (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or upon the manaS-ap. (Mgh.) And naS-ati AlZ-aboyapu jiydahaA The doe-antelope raised, or elevated, her neck. (M, TA.) And nuS-a fulaAnN say-idFA ‡ Such a one was set up as a lord, or chief. (A, TA.) And naS-a AlmataAEa, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He put the furniture, or goods, or utensils, one upon another. (M, Ḳ.) Hence, (TA,) naS-a AlHadiyva, (M, Mṣb, TA,) or naS-ahu UilaI SaAHibihi, (A,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, Mṣb, TA,) ‡ He traced up, or ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the author thereof, resting it on his authority, by mentioning him, or mentioning, uninterruptedly, in ascending order, the persons by whom it had been handed down, up to the author; or mentioning the person who had related it to him from the author, if only one person intervened; syn. rafaEahu; (M, TA;) [i. e.] rafaEahu UilaI mano qaAlahu: (Mṣb:) IAạr says, (TA,) Aln-aS-u signifies AlUisonaAdu UilaI Alr-aYiysi AlOakobari ‡ [the tracing up, or ascribing, or attributing, a tradition, in the manner explained above, to the greatest person of authority, here meaning Moḥammad, or the author of the tradition]; (Ḳ, TA;) [i. e.] naS-u AlHadiyvi signifies UisonaAduhu warafoEuhu UilaI Alr-aYiysi AlOakobari. (Mgh.) You also say, naS-a AlHadiyva Uilayohi, (Ḳ,) or UilaI fulaAnK, (Ṣ,) ‡ He ascribed, or attributed, or traced up, the tradition to him, or to such a one, in the manner explained above; syn. rafaEahu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also OanaS-u.

naS-a AlX-aIoCa † He made the thing apparent, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed it, exhibited it, manifested it, evinced it, discovered it, or revealed it. (M,* Ḳ.) [The verb seems to be thus used because a thing is rendered conspicuous by being raised. See naS-a AlEaruwsa, above.]

[Hence, naS-a EalaI XaIoCK m-aA, aor. and inf. n. as above, ‡ He, or it, (generally said of a passage in the Ḳur. or a trad.,) made a statement, or a plain, explicit, unequivocal declaration, respecting some, or any, particular thing, not capable of application to any other thing: and he mentioned something, or anything, particularly, or specially; he particularized, or specified it by words; very frequently used in these senses: and such we are to understand from the saying] Aln-aS-u also signifies Alt-awoqiyfu waAlt-aEoyiynu EalaI XaIoCK m-aA: (Ḳ:) [for which I would rather read Aln-aS-a EalaI XaIoCK m-aA also signifies Alt-awoqiyfu waAlt-aEoyiynu: adding the observation that Altwqyf as syn. with AlnS- is restricted in art. wqf in the Ḳ to a special relation to the law: and that Aln-aS-u EalaI AlX-aIoCi is often found explained as signifying taEoyiynuhu; as, for instance, in p. 377 of Ḥar.:] these significations of Aln-aS-u are tropical, from that word as denoting “elevation” and “appearance.” (TA.) See also naS-N below.
[From naS-ahu signifying “he raised it,” and consequently “he made it apparent,” are derived several other significations, here following.]

yanuS-uhumo [app. for yanuS-u maA Einodahumo] occurs in a trad. respecting Heraclius, meaning † He elicits, and makes apparent, their opinion: (TA:) or naS-a Alr-ajula, (Ṣ, M, &c.,) inf. n. as above, (M,) signifies ‡ he went to the utmost point in questioning, or asking, the man respecting a thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) so as to elicit what he possessed [of information respecting it]; (Ṣ;) i. e. (TA) ‡ he importuned the man in questioning, or asking, and urged him to tell the utmost that he knew; (A, TA;) or † he questioned, or asked, the man respecting a thing so as to elicit the utmost that he possessed [of information respecting it], (M.) [See also 3.]

[In like manner you say,] naS-a Aln-aAqapa, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Ḳ,) and Ald-aAb-apa, (M, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, M,) He made the she-camel, and the beast, to exert herself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure, in going, or pace; or to go the pace termed marofuwE; syn. rafaEahaA fiI Als-ayori: (M, Mgh:) or he elicited her utmost pace; (Ḳ, TA;) from Aln-aS-u as signifying Alr-afoEu; for the phrase rafaEahaA fiI Als-ayori necessarily implies the eliciting the utmost of her celerity of pace: (TA:) or he went a vehement pace so as to elicit the utmost that she possessed [of celerity]: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or he put her in motion so as to elicit her utmost pace: (AʼObeyd, TA:) or he urged, or incited, her, and elicited her pace: (Mṣb:) naS-a, alone, also occurs in a trad., (M, Mṣb,) as meaning rafaEa naAqatahu: (M:) and naSonaSa↓ naAqatahu signifies the same as naS-ahaA. (IḲṭṭ, TA.) You do not say of a camel naS-a, making him the agent, and the verb intrans. (O,* TA.) [In the M, however, I find it said, that Aln-aS-u and Aln-aSiySu signify Als-ayoru AlX-adiydu; app. indicating that they are inf. ns., of which the verb is naS-a, aor., accord. to rule, _i, signifying He went a vehement pace, or vehemently: and Golius says, as on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof, that this verb is used intransitively, with naSiySN for its inf. n., as signifying valide incessit: but see naS-N below.]
[Hence, app.,] Aln-aS-u also signifies The urging or inciting [a beast]; syn. AlHav-u. (M.)

And naS-a AlX-aIoCa, (M, Ḳ,)) aor. _u {yanoSuSu}, inf. n. naS-N, (TA,) He moved the thing; put it in motion, or into a state of commotion; agitated it; stirred it; shook it; (M, Ḳ;) as also naSonaSahu↓. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, fulaAnN yanuS-u Oanofahu gaDabFA (Ḳ, TA [in the CK, incorrectly, yaniS-u,]) Such a one moves about his nose by reason of anger. (TA.) And naSonaSa↓ lisaAnahu He moved about his tongue; (Ṣ, M;) like naDonaDahu; (M;) which is a dial. form; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ;) the former being the original; the S not being, as some assert it to be, substituted for the D; for these two letters are not of the same kind so as to be commutable. (M.)
See also 8.

entry.sense: 2: see 3.

3. nAS-hu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. munaAS-apN, (TA,) He (a man, TA) went to the utmost length with him, (namely his creditor,) in reckoning, so as to omit nothing therein; (Ḳ, TA;) as also nS-Shu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoSiySN. (TA.) He (God) went to the utmost length with him, (namely a man,) in questioning and in reckoning. (TA.) [See also 1.]
6. tnAS- Alqawomu The people, or company of men, crowded, thronged, or pressed, together. (TA.)

hom.sense: 8. AntS- He, or it, (said of a camel's hump, Lth, TA,) became raised, or elevated, or high: (Ḳ, TA:) or (TA) became even and erect. (Lth, Ḳ,* TA.) [In a copy of the A, the verb in these senses, and relating to a camel's hump, is written naS-a.] You say also, AntS-t AlEaruwsu, (M, Ḳ,) or AntS-t ElI AlminaS-api, (A,) The bride became raised, (A,) or seated, (Ḳ,) or shown or displayed, (M,) upon the minaS-ap. (M, A, Ḳ.)
He (a man, TA) drew himself together; contracted himself; or shrank. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA.)

R. Q. 1. naSonaSa, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. naSonaSapN, (Sh, M,) He, or it, became in motion, or in a state of commotion; became agitated, stirred, or shaken; moved, or moved about,; bestirred himself or itself; shook. (Sh.) He (a man) shook in his walk, being erect. (M.) He (a camel) shook, or became in a state of commotion, in rising from the ground. (M.)

[Also,] said of a camel, it is like HaSoHaSa; (Ṣ;) i. e., it signifies (TA) He (the camel) fixed, or made firm or steady, his knees upon the ground, and put himself in motion, or in a state of commotion, previously to rising. (Lth, Ḳ, TA.) [See also naDonaDa.]
And He (a camel) made a hollow place in the ground with his breast, in order to lie down. (M, TA.)
naSonaSa used transitively, see 1, latter portion, in three places.

naS-N The end, or extremity, of anything; (Az, Ṣ, M;) the utmost, or extreme, extent, term, limit, point, or reach, of a thing: this is the primary signification. (Az, TA.) It is said in a trad., (Ṣ, M,) of ʼAlee, (Ṣ,) UicaA balaga Aln-isaMCu naS-a AlHiqaAqi faAlEaSabapu OawulaI bihaA mina AlOum-i, (Ṣ,* M, Ḳ,*) or naS-a AlHaqaAYiqi, (Ḳ,* TA,) but the former is that which is commonly known; (TA;) i. e. When women attain the period of mature intellect, (Mbr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and know the real natures of things, (Ḳ, art. Hq,) [then the male relations on the father's side have a better right to dispose of her in marriage than the mother;] meaning, when they attain to that age at which they are qualified to contend for their rights; [accord. to the former reading;] for this is what is termed AlHiqaAq: (Ḳ,* TA:) or when they attain to puberty: (Az, TA:) or when they attain to that period at which they become objects of contention for right; when every one of the guardians asserts himself to have the best right: (Ḳ:) or AlHqAq in the trad. is a metaphorical term, from the same word as applied to camels [when entering upon the fourth year]; (Ḳ,* TA;) and AlHqAYq, also, in this case, accord. to some, properly signifies the same, being a pl. of Hiq-apN; (TA in art. Hq;) and the meaning is, when they attain to the extreme term of childhood. (M, Ḳ.)

In the conventional language of men of science, it signifies ‡ A thing [or statement] plainly, or explicitly, declared, or made manifest, by God, and his Apostle; of the measure faEolN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Mṣb:) or a naS- of the Ḳur-án, and of the traditions, is an expression, or a phrase, or a sentence, indicating a particular meaning, not admitting any other than it: (TA:) so in the conventional language of the lawyers and the scholastic theologians: (MF, on the xuTobap of the Ḳ:) or a statute, or an ordinance, indicated by the manifest or plain meaning of words of the Ḳur-án, and of the Sunneh: from Aln-aS-u as denoting “elevation” and “appearance:” or, as some say, from naS-ahu as signifying “he elicited, and made apparent, his opinion.” (TA.) Hence, also, as used by the practical lawyers, it signifies ‡ An evidence, or a proof: (TA:) [and particularly a text of the Ḳur-án, or of the Sunneh, used as an authority in an argument, for proof of an assertion.] The pl. [in all these senses] is nuSuwSN. (Mṣb.)
[Also, † The text, or very words, of an author, book, writing, or passage: frequently used in this sense.]
Hardness, difficulty, or straitness, of an affair, or a state, or case. (M, TA.)

sayorN naS-N, and naSiySN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A vehement pace, in which a beast is made to exert itself to the full, or to the utmost, or beyond measure; or in which the utmost possible celerity is elicited; [this meaning seems to be indicated, though not expressed, in the Ṣ;] syn. jid-N rafiyEN: (Ḳ:) or, the former, as Az says, in one place, a kind of swift pace: or, as he says in another place, the utmost pace which a beast of carriage is able to attain: (TA:) or naS-N and naSiySN↓ signify a vehement pace or going. (M.) See 1.

entry.sense: naSiySN: see naS-N, last sentence, in two places.
hawu naS-aASu AlOanofi He is one who moves about his nose [much] by reason of anger. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
Hay-apN naSonaASN A serpent that moves about much. (Ḳ.) [See also naDonaADN.]

OanaS-u [a comparative and superlative epithet from naS-a AlHadiyva, q. v.]. ʼAmr Ibn-Deenár said, maA raOayotu rajulFA OanaS-a liloHadiyvi mina Alz-uhoriI-i I have not seen a man more skilled in tracing up, or ascribing, or attributing, a tradition to its author, in the manner explained above, (voce naS-a,) than Ez-Zuhree; i. q. OarofaEa lahu and Oasonada. (TA.)
manaS-apN: see what next follows, throughout.

minaS-apN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or manaS-apN↓, (Mgh,) The thing upon which a bride is raised (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ) and seated, (Mgh,) or shown or displayed, (M,) or upon which she stands (tqf [but this is probably a mistake for taqoEudu, i. e. sits,]) when displayed to the bridegroom, (Mṣb,) in order that she may be seen (M, Mgh) [and distinguished] from among the women; (Mgh;) being a chair, (Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) or couch; (TA;) or consisting of pieces of cloth raised, and carpets laid smoothly for a seat: (M:) written with kesr (Mṣb, Ḳ) as being an instrument, (Mṣb,) or with fet-ḥ [as being a place]: (Mgh:) accord. to some authorities, minaS-apN and manaS-apN seem to signify the same thing: (TA:) or the latter is the Hajalap [i. e. a kind of curtained canopy] (Ḳ, TA) over the minaS-ap: (TA:) from naS-a AlmataAEa, q. v. (Ḳ.)
It is said in a proverb, wuDiEa fulaAnN EalaI AlminaS-api † Such a one was exposed to disgrace and infamy: (TA:) or to the utmost disgrace and infamy. (M.)
1. naSaOahu, aor. _a {yanoSaOu}, He took him by the naASiyap [or forelock]: (Ḳ:) from naASiyapN: and therefore regarded by some as improperly mentioned in the Ḳ in this art. (MF.)
naSaOa, aor. _a {yanoSaOu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naSoCN, (TA,) He chid, (a camel, TA, or she-camel, Ṣ); syn. zajara. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naSaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He raised, or elevated, a thing: (Ks, AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) dial. form of naS-a. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. naSaba, aor. _u {yanoSubu}, inf. n. naSobN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and nS-b↓; (Ḳ;) He set up, put up, set upright, erected, a thing: (Ṣ:) he elevated, raised, reared, a thing. (Ḳ.)
He set up, a stone as a sign, or mark. (Mṣb.)
naSaba raOosahu He raised his head. (TA.)
naSiba, aor. _a {yanoSabu}, inf. n. naSabN, He (a goat) had erect ears. (Ṣ: the inf. n. only mentioned.)
naSabotu fulAanFA likacaA I set, or set up, such a one as an obstacle to such a thing, or as a butt for such a thing, like the butt of archers. (TA, art. ErD.)

nuSiba fulaAnN liEimaArapi Albaladi ‡ [Such a one was set up, or appointed, for the putting, or keeping, of the town, or district, in a flourishing or prosperous state, with respect to building, culture, population, &c.]. (A.)

naSaba, aor. _u {yanoSubu}, inf. n. naSobN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or naSaba naSoba AlEarabi, (Ṣ,) † He sang, or chanted, a kind of song, or chant, peculiar to the Arabs, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) of the description termed HudaAC, (Ḳ,) [by which camels are urged, or excited,] or a kind of song (Ḳ) resembling what is thus termed, (Ṣ,) but finer, or more delicate. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) What is termed naSobN is The kind of singing, or chanting, above described: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a kind of HudaAC resembling singing: (AA:) or a kind of modulation: (Sh:) or a kind of song, or chant, of the Arabs: (ISd:) or, of the Arabs of the desert: (TA:) or poetry such as is commonly recited, well regulated and set to an air: (Nh:) so called because, in [singing or chanting] it, the voice is raised, or elevated. (The Fáïk.)

naSaba AlHarofa, [aor. _i {yanoSibu}, (not _u,) inf. n. naSobN,] He wrote, or pronounced, the [final] letter with naSob; (Ṣ;) which is, in the case of the final inflection of a word, like fatoH in the non-inflection: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [i. e., he wrote it, or pronounced it, with BF or _a:] so called because the sound of a word of which the final letter is so pronounced rises to the highest cavity of the mouth. (Lth.) A conv. term of grammar. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) naSaba Alkalimapa [He wrote, or pronounced, the word with naSob, i. e., making its vowel of inflection BF or _a, &c., according to the rules of grammar:] he made the word to have fet-ḥah as its vowel of inflection. (Mṣb.)
naSaba lah AlHaroba, (inf. n. naSobN, TA,) He made war upon him: syn. waDaEa. (Ḳ.)
Of anything that is raised, and with which one goes to meet, or encounter, a thing, one says nuSiba, and of the agent, naSaba. (M, Ḳ.)
naSaba lahu, aor. _u {yanoSubu}, inf. n. naSobN, ‡ He acted with hostility, or enmity, towards him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also 3.
naSabotu lahu raOoyFA ‡ I gave him counsel from which he should not deviate. (A.)
naSaba, aor. _u {yanoSubu}, (inf. n. naSobN, TA,) He put down a thing: syn. waDaEa. Thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)
[He set, or put, absolutely: often used in this sense.]

naSaba Als-ayora, aor. _u {yanoSubu}, (inf. n. naSobN, TA,) † He strove, or exerted himself, unusually in his pace: (Ḳ:) or naSaba signifies he pursued his journey with diligence, or energy: (TA:) or he travelled on all the day, at a gentle pace: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he journeyed on all the night. (TA.) En-Naḍr says, Aln-aSobu is the first pace; then, Ald-ababu, [but see wasaja;] then, AlEanaqu; then, Alt-azay-udu; then, AlEasoju; then, Alr-atoku; then, Alwaxodu; then, Alhamolajapu. (TA.)
naSiba, aor. _a {yanoSabu}, inf. n. naSabN, He was fatigued, tired, or wearied, (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naSiba, inf. n. naSabN, He suffered difficulty, trouble, distress, or affliction. (TA.)
naSiba He strove; laboured; or toiled. (Ḳ.)

faUicaA faragota faQnoSabo [Ḳur, xciv. 7,] signifies And when thou shalt have finished thy prescribed prayers, fatigue thyself in supplication: (Ḳatádeh, Jel:) or when thou shalt have finished the obligatory prayers, fatigue thyself in the performance of the voluntary. (TA.) See naASibN.

entry.sense: 2. nS-bt Alxayolu McaAnahaA The horses erected their ears often, or exceedingly. The teshdeed is to render the signification frequentative or intensive. (Ṣ.)
See 1, and 3.

3. nASbh AlX-ar-a, (inf. n. munaASabapN, TA,) ‡ He made an open show of evil conduct, mischief, or malevolence, to him; (Ḳ;) and in like manner, of enmity, (TA,) and of war; (Ṣ, TA;) as also naSabahu↓, (Ḳ,) unaugmented. (TA: in the CK, nS-bh↓.) See also naSaba lahu.

hom.sense: 4. AnSbh He fatigued, tired, or wearied, him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it (an affair) fatigued him, &c.: (TA:) it (grief, or anxiety,) fatigued, tired, or wearied, him; (CK, TA;) as also naSiba lahu↓; (TA;) and perhaps naSabahu↓ is also used in this sense, with reference to grief, or anxiety. (Ḳ.) See 1.
AnSb AlHadiyva UilaI rasuwli Qll-ehi He ascribed, or attributed, the tradition to the Apostle of God; syn. Oasonadahu Uilayohi and rafaEahu. (TA.)
AnSbh He assigned him, or gave him, a naSiyb; i. e., a lot, or portion. (Ḳ.)
AnSb Als-ik-iyna He made, or put, a handle (niSaAb) to the knife. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5. tnS-bti AlOutunu Hawola AlHimaAri The she-asses stood round the he-ass. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 8.
6. tnASbwh They divided it into lots, or portions, among themselves. (TA.)

8. AntSb and tnS-b↓, quasi-pass. of naSaba and naS-aba, He, or it, became set up, put up, set upright, or erected; stood up, or upright, or erect; became elevated, raised, or reared: (Ḳ:) became even and erect. (TA, art. nS.)
He stood erect, raising his head. (TA.)
[It was, or became, erect, vertical, or perpendicular.]
[AntSb XaEaruhu His hair, being full-grown, stood out: see munotaSibN.]
AntSb (TA) and tnS-b↓ (Ḳ) ‡ It (dust) rose high. (Ḳ, TA.)
UinotaSibo Set up thy cooking-pot [upon the minoSab, or trivet,] to cook, said to a cook. (IAạr.)
AntSbt OaXonaAnuhu UilaI qud-aAmK [Its teeth stood out forwards: see munotaSibN:] said of a mouth. (TA, art. dfq.)
[AinotiSaAbN is often used absolutely as meaning An erection of the penis.]
AntSb AlHarofu The letter [meaning the final letter of a word] was written, or pronounced, with naSob: [see naSaba AlHarofa]. (Ṣ.)
naSobN: see naSaba, (of which it is the inf. n.,) throughout.

naSobN and naSaba↓ and nuSubN↓ and naSiybapN↓ A sign, or mark, set up to show the way; or a standard set up: syn. EalamN manoSuwbN: (Ḳ:) i. e., set up [as a sign] to a people: (TA:) or nuSubN is pl. of naSiybapN, like as sufunN is of safiynapN. (Lth, TA.) Also nuSobapN↓, A pole, or mast; syn. saAriyapN; (Ḳ;) set up to show the way: (TA:) also, OanaASiybu↓ and tanaASiybu↓ (pls. which have no sings., TA,) Signs, or marks, or stones, set up to show the way; syn. OaEolaAmN and SuwFI: (Ḳ:) stones set up on the tops of isolated small mountains, whereby travellers are to be directed: (TA:) also, yanoSuwbN↓ [pl. yanaASiybu] signifies A sign, or mark, set up to show the way in a desert. (Fr.) In the Ḳur, lxx., last verse but one, some read naSobK, meaning as above: others nuSubK, meaning “idols.” (Zj.)

naSobN also signifies A goal; or limit; syn. gaAyapN: (Ḳ:) or rather, some say that it has this signification [in the verse of the Ḳur. above referred to]; but the former meaning, of “a sign, &c.,” is the more correct. (TA.)
See also nuSobN and nuSubN, below.

naSobN, with respect to rhyme in a verse, is The being free from anything that would mar it, (Akh, Ḳ,) when the verse itself is not curtailed; for when the verse is curtailed, the term nSb is not applicable, though the rhyme be perfect: accord. to an explanation received from the Arabs: not one of the terms of Kh. (Akh.) Derived from AlAinotiSaAbu, as signifying “the standing erect; being tall; making one's self tall, by stretching the neck;” and therefore not applied to verse that is curtailed. (IJ, ISd.)
naSobN One who is set, or set up, as an obstacle to a thing, or as a butt for a thing, like the butt of archers. (TA, art. ErD.) See 1.
naSobN [A peculiar mode of singing, or chanting: or a peculiar kind of song, or chant]: (See 1.)

hecaA nuSobu EayoniI, and naSobu↓ EynI, or the latter is a barbarism, (Ḳ,) disallowed by Ḳṭ; but it is allowed by Mṭr; and said to have been heard from the Arabs [of the classical ages]; This is a conspicuous object of my eye; a thing in full view of my eye: said of a thing that is manifest, or conspicuous, [standing before one,] and even when it is lying, or thrown down. (TA.)
jaEalotuhu nSba EynI I made him, or it, a conspicuous object, or a thing in full view, of my eye. (TA.)

Mtr says, that naSob, in this case, is an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., and means an object [as it were set, or set up,] conspicuously seen of the eye, so as not to be forgotten, nor to be unheeded, nor to be placed behind the back, or uncared for, or disregarded. (MF.)
nuSobN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naSobN↓ and nuSubN↓ (Ḳ) Evil; (Ṣ;) trial; affliction; misfortune: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so in the Ḳur, xxxviii., 40: (Ṣ:) disease: (Ḳ:) affliction occasioned by disease. (Lth.) See also naSab.
niSobN: see naSiybN.
naSabN [as a subst.] Fatigue; weariness; toil.
Difficulty; trouble; distress; affliction. (TA.) See the verb: and see naSobN.
naSibN Diseased; sick; and in pain. (Ḳ.)
nuSubN: see naSobN.

nuSubN (Ḳ, Mṣb) and nuSobN↓ (Ḳ: accord. to the Ṣ, the latter is sometimes written nuSubN: [but it seems that nuSubN is the more common of the two words:]) and naSobN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb) What is set up and worshipped to the exclusion of, or in preference to, the true God: (Ṣ:) or anything that is so worshipped: (Ḳ:) or a stone that is set up and so worshipped: (Mṣb:) the pl. of nuSubN is OanoSaAbN: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or nuSubN is a pl. of naSobN, like as suqufN is of saqofN: (Mṣb:) or it is a pl. of which the sing. is niSaAbN; and it may be a sing., the pl. of which is OanoSaAbN: (Zj:) which last word, accord. to some, is syn. with OaSonaAmN: but others deny this; because ASnAm are figured and sculptured or painted; whereas AnSAb are of an opposite description. (Mṣb.) [See a verse cited in art. mwr.]

nuSubN, as occurring in the Ḳur, v. 4, signifies An idol; or a stone which the pagan Arabs set up, to sacrifice, or slay animals, before it, or by it, and which became red with the blood: (Ḳṭ:) or pl. of niSaAbN, and signifying idols. (Jel.)
OanoSaAbu AlHarami The limits of the sacred territory [of Mekkeh]; (Ḳ;) i. e., signs, or marks, set up there, whereby it might be known. (TA.) See also naSobN.
naSobapN A laying of a snare; meaning a plot, a stratagem, or an artifice. (TA.)
nuSobapN: see naSobN.
niSaAbN The place of sun-set; magiybu AlX-amosi; (Ḳ;) the place to which it returns. (TA.)
See manoSibN: and nuSubN
niSaAbN The handle of a knife; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) in which the siylaAn is set: (TA:) pl. nuSubN. (Ḳ.)

niSaAbN, of property, ‡ The amount which renders it incumbent on the possessor to pay the alms, or tax, called Alz-akaAp: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as two hundred dirhems, or five camels, (Ṣ,) [or twenty deenárs, or forty sheep or goats. (IbrD.)] So called as being the “source” whence the tax comes. (Mṣb.)

naSiybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and niSobN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ A share, or portion, or lot, syn. HaZ-N; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) of a thing; (Ṣ;) or of anything; (TA;) a set portion: (A:) [hence it appears to be in the sense of manoSuwbN what is set:] pl. of the former OanoSibaMCu and OanoSibapN (Ḳ, Mṣb) [the latter a pl. of pauc.], and nuSubN. (Mṣb.)
naSiybN A tank, or cistern. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A snare, or fowler's net, set, or set up: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) thus in the sense of manoSuwbN. (TA.) See also manoSuwbapN.

naSiybapN, (Ṣ,) or naSaAYibu, (Ḳ,) which latter is the pl. of the former, (TA,) Stones which are set up around a tank, or cistern, and the interstices of which are filled up with kneaded clay. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
haraqonaAhu fiI baAdiI Aln-aXiyoYapi dAvirK
qadiymK biEahodi AlmaMCi buqoEK naSaAYibuho
[We poured it out into an old cistern of which the water was dried up and the bottom apparent, which for a long time had contained no water, the stones set up around which, having their interstices filled up mith kneaded clay, were black and white]. (Ṣ.) The pron. in hrqnAh refers to a large bucket mentioned before. (TA.)
naSaAYibu is also explained by AʼObeyd as signifying Stones that are set up around a tank, or cistern, to mark the quantity of water with which the camels will be satisfied. (TA.) See naSobN.

ham-N naASibN i. q. munoSibN, Grief, or anxiety, that fatigues, tires, or wearies: (Ḳ:) after the manner of a rel. n.: (Sb, Ḳ:) meaning cuw naSabK; like taAmirN and laAbinN: or nASb is here an act. part. n. used in the sense of the pass. part. n. [manoSuwbN] followed by fiyhi; i. e. yunoSabu fiyhi, in which one is fatigued, tired, or wearied; like layolN naAYimN, meaning yunaAmu fiyhi, &c.: (Ṣ:) or the phrase naSabahu Alham-u, in the sense of OatoEabahu, has been heard; (Ḳ;) and nASb is its act. part. n. (TA.)
naSabN naASibN is also said to be a phrase of the same kind as mawotN maAYitN, and XiEorN XaAEirN; [therefore meaning Severe fatigue, or difficulty, or trouble, and the like]. (TA.)
Also EayoXN naASibN, and cuw manoSabapK↓, A fatiguing, laborious, or troublesome, life. (Ḳ.)

Aln-awaASibu, and Aln-aASibiy-apu↓, and Oaholu Aln-aSobi, Appellations of a sect who made it a matter of religious obligation to bear a violent hatred to ʼAlee (Ḳ) the son of Aboo-Tálib: (TA:) [so called] liOan-ahumo naSabuwA lahu because they acted with hostility, or enmity, towards him, (Ḳ,) and openly opposed him: they were a sect of the Khawárij, AlxawaAriju. (TA.)
naASibapu AlX-ujaAEi The eye of the serpent called XjAE, which it raises to look. (TA in art. XjE.)

By the expression kanaASibapi AlX-ujaAEi in the following words of the poet,
baSarN kanaASibapi AlX-ujaAEi AlmuroSidi
is meant Like the eye of the brave man, which he raises (yanoSubuhaA) to look at, or see, something. (TA.)
Aln-aASibiy-apu: see naASibN.
OanoSabu A goat having erect horns: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) fem. naSobaMCu. (Ṣ.)
naSobaMCu A she-camel having an elevated breast. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OacunN naSobaMCu An ear that is erect, and approaches the other ear. (TA.)

manoSibN [so accord. to the copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ in my hands, and the Mṣb, which states it to be of the same measure as masojidN, and the TA: written by Golius and Freytag manoSabN:] and niSaAbN↓ ‡ Origin; source; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb;) of anything; (TA;) that to which a person or thing is referred, as his or its source; syn. marojiEN; (Ḳ;) place where, or whence, a thing grows; (Mṣb;) place where a person or thing is set, or set up. (TA.)
Pl. [of the former, manaASibu, and] of the latter, nuSubN and OanoSibapN. (Az, Mṣb.)
lahu manoSibu SidoqK He has an excellent origin. (Mṣb.)
huwa yrojiE UilaI mnSbi SidoqK and niSAbi↓ Sdq, He traces back his lineage to an excellent origin. (TA.)
manoSibN † Rank, or quality, nobility, or eminence, and the like, absolutely, or derived from ancestry: syn. HasabN and XarafN: from the same word as signifying “origin, source, &c.” (Esh-Shiháb.)
lifulaAnK manoSibN To such a one pertains eminence of rank or station. (Mṣb.)
UimoraOapN caAtu mnSbK A woman of rank or quality, &c., (Hasab,) and of beauty: or of beauty alone; because alone it exalts her. (Mṣb.)

manoSibN, in the language of those of post-classical times, [and commonly pronounced, in the present day, manoSabN,] † A post, an office, a function, or a magistracy; as though meaning the place in which a man is set, set up, or elevated; (Shifà el-Ghaleel;) or in which he is set, or set up, to see, or observe, [or supervise]: (MF:) pl. manaASibu. (TA.)
[OarobaAbu AlmanaASibi † Functionaries; magistrates.]
See minoSabN.
minoSabN An iron thing (an iron trivet, TA,) upon which a cooking-pot is set up: (IAạr, Ḳ:) as also manoSibN↓. (MF.)
manoSabapN Fatigue, labour, or trouble: [or a cause of fatigue, &c.]. (Ḳ.) See naASibN.

manoSuwbapN, as an epithet, applied to a Xabakap or HibaAlap (A net or snare) set, or set up. And hence, as a subst., like daAb-apN and EajuwzN, † An artifice, a stratagem, a trick, a plot, a resource, or an expedient: or a stratagem in the game of chess. You say saw-aI fulaAnN mnSwbpF [Such a one framed a stratagem, or plot]. (Z.)
munaS-abN A horse of which the prevailing characteristic of his whole make is the erect position of his bones, so that he stands erect without needing to bend [his joints]. (TA.)
SafiyHN munaS-abN [Broad and thin stones] set up, one upon another. (Ṣ.)
vagorN munaS-abN Teeth, or fore teeth, of even growth; (Ḳ;) as though set up and made even. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce XanabN.]
varFI munaS-abN, accord. to the Ḳ, i. q. mujaE-adN; but this is a mistake; and the correct word is jaEodN, Soft moist earth; as in other books. (TA.)
munotaSibN ‡ Dust rising high. (Ṣ.)
† Hair full grown, and standing out. (TA, art. sbkr.)
OasonaAnN munotaSibapN UilaI xaArijK (Ṣ in art. dfq) or AlI qud-aAmK (JK in that art.) [Teeth standing out or forwards].
yanoSuwbN: see naSobN.
OanaASiybu: see naSobN.
tanaASiybu: see naSobN.

1. naSata, aor. _i {yanoSitu}, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. naSotN; (L;) and AnSt↓, inf. n. UinoSaAtN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) which latter is the more approved; (L;) and AntSt↓; (L, Ḳ;) He was silent: (L, Ḳ:) or he was silent and listened: (Ṣ:) or he was silent to listen: (L:) or he was silent as one listening: (Er-Rághib:) or he listened: (Mṣb:) or AntSb signifies he stood, or paused, listening. (Mṣb.)
OanoSatahu↓, and AnSt lahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Uilayohi, (Z,) and naSata lahu, (L,) He was silent, and listened to his speech. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)

hom.sense: 4. AnSthu He made him silent; silenced him. (Sh, Ḳ.)
AnSthu Ean-iI He made him to be silent, [and to abstain] from [speaking of, or to,] me. (Aṣ.)
See 1.
AnSt lil-ahowi He inclined to play, or sport. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1.
10. AstnSthu He asked him, or desired him, to be silent: (Ḳ:) or, to be silent and to listen to him. (TA.)
nuSotapN Silence: [or silence and listening, &c.] (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naSaHa lahu, and naSaHahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) but the former is the original mode of expression, (Lb,) and is the more chaste, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and the latter was scarcely ever used by the Arabs, (Fr,) aor. _a {yanoSaHu}, inf. n. nuSoHN and naSaAHapN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and naSiyHapN, (A, L, Mṣb,) or this last is a simple subst., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and niSaAHapN and naSoHN (L) and nuSuwHN (TA) and naSaAHiyapN; (Ḳ;) and nASHhu↓, inf. n. munaASaHapN; (MF;) He advised him, or counselled him, [in an absolute sense,] sincerely, honestly, or faithfully: and he so acted towards him: (Mṣb:) he directed him to that which was for his good, by words, or speech, which is the proper signification; or otherwise, which is a tropical signification: (Lb:) or he gave him good advice, or counsel; directed him to what was good: or he advised him, or counselled him, sedulously, or earnestly: or he acted sincerely, or honestly, to him, (MF,) or he was benevolent towards him; desired what was good for him. (Nh, MF.)
naSaHato lahu naSiyHatiI, inf. n. nuSuwHN, My advice, or counsel, or conduct, was sincere, honest, or faithful, to him. (L.)
naSaHato tawobatuhu, inf. n. nuSuwHN ‡ His repentance was, or became, true, or sincere, [&c.: see naSuwHN]. (A.)
jiYonaAka liln-aSaAHapi lamo naOoti lilr-aqaAHapi [We have come unto Thee for the purpose of sincere worship: we have not come for gain, or traffic: see art. rqH]. (Ṣ, art. rqH.)
naSaHa It (anything, Ṣ) was, or became, pure, unadulterated, or genuine. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naSaHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanoSaHu}, inf. n. naSoHN; (Ṣ;) and tnS-H↓; (Ḳ;) ‡ He sewed a garment, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a shirt: (TA:) or he sewed it well. (A.)
naSaHa Alr-iI-a, (inf. n. naSoHN, TA,) ‡ He (a man, TA,) drank until he was satisfied. (Ḳ.)
naSaHati AlUibilu AlX-uroba, aor. _a {yanoSaHu}, inf. n. nuSuwHN, ‡ The camels drank in good earnest. (IAạr, Ṣ.)
naSaHa Algayovu Albalada, (inf. n. naSoHN, TA,) ‡ The rain watered the district so that its herbage became close, without any bare part: (En-Naḍr, Ḳ:) or, watered it abundantly. (TA.)
naSaHa, aor. _a {yanoSaHu}, inf. n. naSoHN, He clarified honey. (MF.) But this is rejected by the author of the Ḳ in [the work entitled] the Basáïr. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. nASHhu, inf. n. munaASaHapN, [He advised him, or counselled him, with sincerity or faithfulness, &c., reciprocally: see also 1]. (A.)
4. AnSH He watered camels so as to satisfy them with drink. (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

5. tnS-H He was prodigal of nuSoH [i. e., sincere or faithful advice or counsel, &c.] Hence the saying of Aktham Ibn-Seyfee, Uiy-aAkumo wakavorapa Alt-anaS-uHi faUin-ahu yuwrivu Alt-uhamapi [Beware ye of being prodigal of sincere or faithful advice or counsel, for it occasions doubt, or suspicion, or evil opinion]. (L.)
tnS-H He affected to be like, or imitated, nuSaHaMC [i. e., those who advise, or counsel, sincerely, honestly, or faithfully, &c.: see naASiHN]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 1.
6. tnASHwA [They advised or counselled one another sincerely or faithfully, &c.: see 1]. (A, art. fDH.)

8. AntSH He accepted naSiyHap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or nuSoH, (TA,) [i. e., sincere, honest, or faithful, advice or counsel, &c.]. As an ex. of this signification the following is cited
yaquwlu QnotaSiHoniI Uin-aniI laka naASiHN
[He says, Accept my sincere advice, for I am to thee a sincere adviser]: (TA:) and UinotaSiHN kitaAba Qll-ehi Accept the sincere or faithful advice or counsel of the Book of God. (A.) But IB says, that the verb in this sense is intrans.; and that, when trans., it signifies He took a person as a naSiyH [a sincere or faithful adviser or counsellor, &c.]; whence the saying laA Ouriydu minoka nuSoHFA walaA QnotiSaAHA, i. e. laA Ouriydu minoka Oano tanoSaHaniI walaA Oano tat-axcaniI naSiyHFA [I do not desire of thee sincere or faithful advice, nor thy taking me as a sincere or faithful adviser]. (L.)
10. AstnSHhu, (Ṣ, L,) and AntSHhu↓, (L,) He reckoned him, or deemed him, nSiyHa, (Ṣ, L,) i. e., a sincere, faithful, or honest, adviser, or counsellor, or actor. (L.)

niSaAHN ‡ Thread (Ṣ, Ḳ) with which one sews: (Ṣ:) pl, nuSuHN (Ḳ, TA; in the CK nuSoHN;) and niSaAHapN: (Ḳ:) the kesreh and A in the latter are not those which are in the sing., and the p is added as a fem. sign of the pl. (TA.) [See also xayoTN.]

niSaAHaAtN Skins. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Aṣ cites as an ex. this verse of El-Aasha,
fataraI Alqawoma naXaAwaI kul-ahumo
mivolamaA mud-ato niSaAHaAtu Alr-ubaHo . (Ṣ, &c.) rbH here signifies, accord. to some, a young camel such as is called rubaEN: (Az;) or a lamb, or kid: (ISd:) or the bird called in Persian zAg. (TA.) [But see what follows.]

Also, (accord. to El-Muärrij, TA.) Snares, (as in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA) or cords, (as in other copies of the Ḳ) having loops (Halaq) made to them, which are set, and with which apes (qurwud) are caught; (Ḳ;) one of these animals being attached to one of the cords to attract others. (TA.) Agreeably with this signification some explain the verse of El-Aasha cited above; rubaHN, originally rubaAHN, signifying apes. (TA.)

tawobapN naSuwHN ‡ True, or sincere, repentance: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) from naSaHati AlUibilu AlX-uroba: (IAạr, Ṣ:) or [repentance that mends one's life;] form naSaHa Alv-awoba, agreeably with the saying of Moḥammad, “He who traduces the absent rends, and he who begs forgiveness of God mends:” [see rafaOa:] (Ṣ:) or such repentance that one returns not after it to that of which he repents: (Ḳ:) sincere repentance, after which one returns not to sin: so explained by Moḥammad himself: (TA:) or very sincere, or very honest repentance: (Zj:) faEuwlN being a measure of an intensive epithet, applicable alike to the masc. and fem.: (TA:) or repentance in which one does not purpose to return (Ḳ) to the sin of which he repents. (TA.) The people of El-Medeeneh read [in the Ḳur, lxvi., 8,] naSuwHFA: but some read nuSuwHFA, which is an inf. n. (Fr.)
naSiyHN: see naASiHN.

naSiyHapN, and inf. n., (L, Mṣb,) or a simple subst., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Sincere, honest, or faithful, advice, or counsel, and conduct: (Mṣb:) direction to that which is for the good of the person who is the object, by words, or speech, which is the proper signification; or otherwise, which is a tropical signification: (Lb:) or good advice or counsel; direction to what is good: or sedulousness, or earnestness, in advice or counsel: or sincere or honest conduct: (MF:) or benevolence; desire for what is good for the person who is the object: (Nh, MF:) [pl. naSaAYiHu]
naS-aAHN: see naASiHN.

hom.sense: naASiHN (act. part. n. of naSaHa) and naSiyHN↓ are syn., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) signifying One who advises, or counsels, sincerely, honestly, or faithfully: and who so acts; (Mṣb:) [who directs another to that which is for the good of the latter, by words, or speech; or otherwise: or who gives good advice, or counsel: or who advises, or counsels, sedulously, or earnestly: or who acts sincerely, or honestly: or benevolent; who desires what is good for another: see naSaHa lahu;] pl. of the former nuS-aHN and nuS-aAHN; (Ḳ;) and of the latter, nuSaHaMCu. (Ṣ.)

rajulN naASiHu Aljayobi ‡ A man pare, or sincere, of heart; (Ṣ;) in whom is no deceit, dishonesty, insincerity, or dissimulation: (Ḳ:) said to be an expression similar to TaAhiru Alv-awobi [q. v.]. (TA.) [See also art. jyb.]
naASiHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naS-aAHN↓ and naASiHiI-N (Ḳ) ‡ A sewer; a worker with the needle; a tailor. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naASiHN ‡ Pure, or clear, honey, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,), &c., like naASiEN (Aṣ, Ṣ). saqaAniI naASiHa AlEasali ‡ He gave me to drink white honey; or fine, or thin, white honey. (A.)
guyuwtN nawaASiHu ‡ Rains succeeding one another. (A.)

entry.sense: minoSaHN and minoSaHapN ‡ A needle, with which one sews. (L, Ḳ.) If thick, it is called XagiyzapN. (L.)
munoSaAHN: see manoSuwHN.

hom.sense: qamiySN manoSuwHN, (A, L,) and munoSaAHN↓, (A,) ‡ A shirt that is rent (A) and sewed. (L.) [See also mutanaS-aHN.]

OaroDN manoSuwHapN ‡ A land plentifully watered by rain, (Ḳ.) having its herbage closely conjoined, (ISd, Ḳ,) as though the spaces which were between the several portions of the herbage were closed up by sewing. (ISd.)

entry.sense: mutanaS-aHN ‡ Well sewed. (AA, Ḳ.) [See also manoSuwHN.]
Also ‡ A place, in a garment, repaired and sewed: (TA:) a patched place, or place of patching: (Ḳ:) a place for sewing; similar to mutaraq-aEN, q. v. (TA in art. rqE.)

1. naSarahu, (M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoSuru}, (M,) inf. n. naSorN (M, A, Ḳ) and nuSorapN, (A,) or this is a simple subst., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and nuSuwrN, (Ḳ,) [but see the verse of Khidásh in what follows,] He aided or assisted him, (M, Ḳ,) namely, a person wronged, misused, or treated unjustly or injuriously, (M. A, Ḳ,) against his enemy: (TA:) [he avenged him: (see the verse here following, and see 8:)] he supplied his want, or somewhat thereof (TA.) Kidásh Ibn-Zuheyr says.
faUino kunota taXokuw mino xaliylK maxaAnapF
ftiloka AljawaAziI EaqobuhaA wanuSuwruhaA
[And if thou complain of treachery from a friend. those requitals are its result and its avengers, or avengement]: here nuSuwr may be a pl. of naASirN. like XuhuwdN is of XaAhidN; or it may be an inf. n., like duxuwlN and xuruwjN. (M.) You say, taSarahu EalaI Eaduw-ihi, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and mino Eaduw-ihi, (A, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yanoSuru}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. naSorN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and nuSorapN, (A,) or this, as remarked above, is a simple subst., (Ṣ, Mṣb.) He (namely, God. Ṣ, A, or a man, Mṣb,) aided or assisted him, and strengthened him, against his enemy: (Mṣb:) [he avenged him of his enemy. (See 8.)] And naSarahu Qll-ehu God made him to be victorious, to conquer, or to overcome: so in the Ḳur, xxii. 15, where the pronoun relates to Moḥammad. (TA.) In the Ḳur, xlvii. 8. Uino tanoSuruwA Qll-eha yanoSurokumo means, If ye aid God's religion and his apostle, He will aid you against your enemy: (Bḍ, Jel) or if ye aid his servants,, &c.: or if ye keep his ordinances and aid his orders and comply with his commands and shun the things which He hath forbidden,, &c. (El-Basáïr.) And the trad. OunoSuro OaxaAka ZaAlim-aA Oawo maZoluwmFA is explained as meaning, Prevent thou thy brother from wronging when he is a wronger, and aid him against his wronger when he is wronged. (TA.) Also, naSarahu minohu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. naSorN and nuSorapN, (TA,) [or the latter in this sense, as in the cases above mentioned, is a simple subst.,] He served or Preserved him from him or it. (Ḳ.)

naSara Qll-ehu AlOaroDa God gave rain to the earth or land. (A.) And naSara Algayovu AlOaroDa (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) [aor. _u {yanoSuru},] inf. n. naSorN, (M,) ‡ The rain aided the earth or land: (Ṣ:) or watered it: (M:) or watered it generally and copiously, (Ḳ, TA,) and caused it to produce herbage: (TA:) and naSara Albalada ‡ it assisted the country to produce abundance of herbage: (TA:) and nuSirati AlOaroDo ‡ the earth or land was watered by rain. (Ṣ.)

Hence, naSarahu, aor. _u {yanoSuru}, inf. n. naSorN, ‡ He gave to him. (M.) An Arab of the desert [in the A a beggar] accosted a people saying, OunoSuruwniI naSarakumu Qll-ehu, meaning, ‡ Give ye to me: may God give to you. (M, A.)
naSarahu Qll-ehu also signifies † God bestowed upon him the means of subsistence, or the like; syn. razaqahu. (IḲṭṭ.)

2. nS-rhu, (inf. n. tanoSiyrN, Ḳ,) He made him a Christian. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., [relating to the natural disposition of a child to adopt the true faith,] faOabawaAhu yuhaw-idaAnihi wayunaS-iraAnihi [But his two parents make him a Jew or make him a Christian]. (Ṣ.)
3. [nASrhu He rendered reciprocal aid to him. See an ex. voce EaASara.]

hom.sense: 5. tnS-r He laboured, or strove, to aid, or assist; syn. EaAlaja Aln-aSora: (M, Ḳ:) not of the same category as taHal-ama [he endeavoured to acquire Hilom] and tbr-r [he endeavoured to characterize himself by bir-]. (M.)
He became a Christian. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 6. tnASrwA They aided or assisted one another: (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA:) they assisted one another to aid. (M, A, Ḳ, TA.)
tnASrt AlOaxobaAru ‡ The accounts, or tidings, confirmed, or verified, one another. (M, Ḳ, TA.)
8. AntSr He defended himself: (Bḍ, Jel, lv. 35:) he defended himself against his wronger, or injurer. (TA.)
AntSr minohu He exacted, or obtained, his right, or due, completely, from him, so that each of them became on a par with the other: (Az, TA:) he revenged himself upon him. (Az, Ṣ, M,* Mṣb, Ḳ.)
10. AstnSr He asked, sought, or desired, aid, or assistance. (M, Ḳ.) And AstnSrh He asked him to aid him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Ealayohi against him, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. against his enemy. (Ṣ, TA.)
‡ He begged; (Ḳ;) as though he asked for a gift, which is termed naSor. (TA.)

naSorN [used a subst.,] Aid or assistance, rendered to another, especially against an enemy: [avengement or another:] victory or conquest: (Bḍ, xxix. 9:) and nuSorapN↓ is a subst. from naSarahu [and therefore signifies the same]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or ↓the latter signifies good aid, or assistance: (M, Ḳ:) and ↓this same word, when the object is God, signifies aid of God's servants;, &c.; as explained above: see 1. (El-Basáïr.)
Spoil; plunder; booty. (Bḍ, ubi supra.)
‡ Rain; (A, TA;) as also nuSorapN↓: (TA:) in like manner as it is called fatoH: (A, TA:) or ↓the latter signifies a complete rain. (IAạr.)
[Hence,] ‡ A gift: (Ṣ, TA:) and naSaAYiru gifts. (M.)
See also naASirN.
nuSarN: see naASirN.
nuSorapN: see naSorN, in five places.
naSoriI-N: see naSoraAniI-N.
naSoraAnN: see naSoraAniI-N.

naSoraAniI-N, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and naSoraAnN↓, (M, A,) or this latter has not been used without the addition of the relative I, (Ṣ,) or it has been sometimes used, (M,) and naSoriI-N↓, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but we have not heard this used, (M,) [A Christian: or this is a secondary application, and the original meaning is a Nazarene:] fem. naSoraAniy-apN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and naSoraAnapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or the latter is used only by poetic licence: (IB:) naSaAraI↓ [applied to the Christians] is a rel. n. from naASirapu, [or Nazareth,] a town of Syria, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) also called naSoraAnapu, (Lth, IDrd, Ḳ,) or naSoraAnu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and naSuwriyapN, (M, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) without teshdeed, accord. to Ṣgh, (TA,) and nuSoriI-N and nuSoraI, (as in a copy of the M,) or naSoraI and naSorawapu: (TA:) so originally, and then applied to such as hold the religion of its inhabitants: (Mṣb:) this is the opinion of the lexicologists; but it is of weak authority, though admissible as there are other anomalous rel. ns.: (M:) or [so in Ḳ, but in the Ṣ, and] naSaAraI is pl. of naSoriI-N, (Kh, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as mahaAraI is pl. of mahoriI-N; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or of naSoraAnN (Kh, Ṣ, M) and naSoraAnapN, (Ṣ,) like as nadaAmaI is pl. of nadomaAnN (Kh, Ṣ, M) and nadomaAnapN; (Ṣ;) but more probably of naSoraAnN, because this word has been sometimes used, whereas we have not heard naSoriI-N used: (M:) and it is implied in the copies of the Ḳ, that OanoSaArN is pl. of naSoraAniI-N; but correctly, it is a pl. of naSoraAnN, without I, as is said in the TṢ, and the L, in both of which is mentioned the saying of the poet,
lam-aA raOayotu nabaTFA OanoSaAraA
[When I saw Nabatheans, Christians], meaning naSaAraI. (TA.)
Aln-aSoraAniy-apu The religion of the naSaAraI [or Christians]. (Ḳ, TA.)
naSuwrN One who aids, or assists, much or well. (TA in art. Eqrb.)

naSiyrN: see naASirN. It has the signification of the measure faAEilN or of the measure mafoEuwlN; for OaxawaAni naSiyraAni, occurring in a trad., means Two brothers, aiders of, and aided by, each other. (TA.)
naSaAraI: see naSoraAniI-N.
naSaAYiru: see naSorN.

naASirN act. part. n. of naSara, An aider or assister, especially against an enemy;, &c.; as also naSiyrN↓, (Ṣ,* M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and naSarN↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) pl. (of naSiyrN, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, and of naASirN, M,) OanoSaArN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of naASirN, M) nuS-aArN, (M, Ḳ,) and nuSuwrN may also be a pl. of the same, as occurring in the verse of Khidásh, cited above: (M:) and OanaASiyru is a pl. pl., being pl. of OanoSaArN: (TA:) and naSorN↓ is used as sing. and pl., (M, Ḳ,) being an inf. n. employed as an epithet, like EadolN. (M.)

AlOanoSaAru also signifies The Assistants of the Prophet; (M, Ḳ;) of [the tribes of] El-Ows and El-Khazraj; (TA;) being an epithet applied to them especially, (M, Ḳ,) and used as a subst., as though it were the name of a tribe, wherefore the rel. n. OanoSaAriI-N [which is used as sing.] is formed from it. (M.)
naASuwrN: see naAsuwrN.
OanoSaArN: see naSoraAniI-N:
and nASirN.
OanoSaAriI-N: see naASirN.
manoSuwrN [Aided or assisted, especially against an enemy,, &c.].
OaroDN manoSuwrapN ‡ Land watered by rain; rained upon. (Ṣ, A.)
musotanoSirN [Asking, seeking, or desiring, aid, or assistance].
‡ A beggar. (M.)

1. naD-a, aor. _i {yanoDiDu}, inf. n. naDiyDN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and naD-N, (Ḳ,) It (water) welled from a source, or spring: (TA:) or flowed: (TA:) or flowed, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or came forth, (Mgh, Mṣb,) by little and little, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) from stone or the like; (Mgh;) like baD-a: (A:) or exuded; or oozed forth, (A, Ḳ,) [like baD-a;] like as it does from stone. (TA.) You say also, saHaAbapN taniD-u biAlomaMCi A cloud flowing with water. (TA.) And riyHN taniD-u biAlomaMCi [app. A wind bringing rain]. (Ḳ.) And naD-ati Alqirobapu mino Xid-api AlmaloCi, (Ḳ,)) aor. _i {yanoDiDu}, inf. n. naDiyDN, (TA,) The water-skin slit, or burst, (Ḳ, TA,) and its water came forth, (TA,) in consequence of being very full. (Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence,] naD-a Uilayohi mino maEoruwfihi XaIoCN, aor. _i {yanoDiDu}, inf. n. naD-N [and naDiyDN], † Somewhat flowed to him from his bounty: but the verb is mostly thus used in negative phrases. (TA.) You say also, naD-a mino maEoruwfika nuDaADapN † A little of thy bounty [flowed forth]. (TA.) And naD-a lahu biXaIoCK † He did him a small benefit; as also baD-a. (Aṣ.)

Hence too, (Mgh,) naD-a, (IḲooṭ, Ṣ, A, &c.,) aor. _i {yanoDiDu}, inf. n. naDiyDN, (Ḳ,) also signifies ‡ It (a thing, IḲooṭ, Mṣb, or an affair, Ḳ) was, or became, within the power or reach; or possible; or easy of obtainment or attainment; or prepared, or ready; or produced; or apparent; or it presented itself; syn. Oamokana; (Ḳ, TA;) and tayas-ara; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) and HaSala; (IḲooṭ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) and Zahara. (Mgh.) You say, xuco maA naD-a ‡ Take thou, or receive thou, what hath become easy of obtainment or attainment: or prepared, or ready; or produced; or apparent; or what hath presented itself; syn. tayas-ara; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) and HaSala; (Mgh, TA;) laka to thee, or for thee; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, TA;) mino dayoni of a debt; (Ṣ;) or mn Ald-ayoni of the debt; (Mṣb;) or mn dayonika of thy debt; (A, Mgh;) or mn gariymika from thy debtor. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., xucuwA Sadaqapa maA naD-a mino OamowaAlihimo ‡ Take ye the poor-rate of what hath appeared, or presented itself, of their possessions; syn. Zahara, and HaSala. (Mgh.) You say also. naD-a Alv-amanu † The price was, or became, produced, or apparent, or prepared, or ready: was, or became, given in ready money, or promptly, or quickly, or in advance: syn. HaSala: and taEaj-ala. (Mṣb.) And maA taD-a biyadiI minohu XaIoCN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) i. e. mA HaSala † [Nothing became produced, or apparent,, &c., by my hand therefrom: or, accord. to AʼObeyd, or Aṣ, (see naD-a,) the verb in this instance seems to have the signification here next following] (Mṣb.) naD-a maAluhu also signifies ‡ His property became converted into money, or cash, after it had been a commodity, or commodities. (A, Mgh.*)
2: see R. Q. 1, in two places.

hom.sense: 4. AnD- He (a pastor, Ṣ) gave lambs or kids to drink a small quantity of milk. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
† He accomplished a want. (Ḳ.)
5: see 10, in two places.
tanaD-aDotu fulaAnFA † I excited, incited, urged, or instigated, such a one. (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.) [In one copy of the Ḳ, tanaDonaDotu↓.]

entry.sense: 10. AstnD- Alv-imaAda He sought repeatedly and perseveringly the [small quantities, or remains, termed] vimaAd of water, and took of them little by little. (TA [in which, however, Alv-imaAra is erroneously put for Alv-imaAda].)

[Hence,] huwa yasotaniD-u maEoruwfFA ‡ He seeks, or demands, bounty, or a benefit, as it were drop by drop; syn. yasotaqoTiruhu: (Ḳ, TA:) or extracts, or elicits, it: (TA:) or seeks, or demands, its accomplishment. (A, TA.) And huwa yasotaniD-u Haq-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or yanotaD-u↓ Hq-h, (so in a copy of the Mṣb,) † He seeks, or demands, the accomplishment of his right, or due, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and takes, or receives, (Ṣ,) part after part, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) mino fulaAnK from such a one: (Ṣ:) or extracts, or elicits, it, part after part. (Ḳ.) And tanD-aDotu↓ manohu Haq-iI [in one copy of the Ḳ tanaDonaDotu↓] † I took, or exacted, or received, fully, or wholly, from him, my right, or due, (Ḳ, TA,) part after part: (TA) [as also tanaD-aDotuhu minoh.] And tanaD-aDotu↓ AlHaAjapu [in one copy of the Ḳ tanaDonaDotu↓] A I sought, or demanded, the accomplishment of the want. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. naDonaDa, (Ḳ, TA,) or naD-aDu↓, (so in the CK,) said of a man, (TA,) † His naAD-, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. what was apparent of his property, (TA,) became much, or abundant. (Ḳ, TA.)

He moved about his tongue; as also taSonaSa; but the D in the former is not a substitute for the S in the latter, as some assert it to be: (L, TA:) the verb is used in this sense in speaking of a man; (TA:) and of a serpent; (Ṣ *, A, Ḳ;) inf. n. naDonaDapN: (Ṣ, but in one copy naDiyDapN:) and accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, naDonaDapN [the inf. n.] signifies the making, or uttering, of a sound: or the sound itself; (Sawot;) [app. by a motion of the tongue;] of the serpent; and hence, [accord. to some,] the epithet naDonaADN, as applied to a serpent: (TA:) or this epithet is from the phrase, (IAạr.) naSonaDa fulaAnFA, (IAạr, Ḳ,) naD-aDahu↓, (so in the CK,) He put such a one in motion, (IAạr,) and he disquieted, disturbed, or unsettled, him; or removed him from his place. (IAạr, Ḳ.) [In one place, in the TA, AsnD- minohu XayoYFA is made to signify the same; but this is doubtless a mistake, arising from an omission in transcription.] You say also, naDonaDa AlbaEiyru vafnaAth The camel moved about his vafinaAt [q. v.], and made them to be in contact with the ground; or this is [naSonaSa,] with S. (TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2: see 5:
and see also 10, in two places.

hom.sense: naD-N (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nAD-N↓ (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) ‡ Gold and silver coin or money; or deenárs and dirhems: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) such are called naAD-N↓ AlmaAl: (A, TA:) or the dirhem and deenár: (Ḳ:) of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) but accord. to AʼObeyd, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or Aṣ, (TA,) these are called naAD-N↓ only when converted into such after having been a commodity, or commodities; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because one says, maA naD-a biyadiI minohu XaIoCN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) i. e. maA HaSala: (Mṣb:) naD-N also signifies what is apparent, or produced, or prepared, or ready; and so naAD-N↓, particularly of property: (TA:) and ↓the latter, what has continuance, or endurance, of property, (Mṣb.) A man of much property is described as being Oakovaru Aln-aAsi naAD-FA↓ ‡ [The most abounding of men in gold and silver coin]. (TA.)
See also naDiyDN.

entry.sense: naDaDN Water upon sand beneath which is hard ground, from which whenever any exudes and collects, it is taken. (TA.)
biYorN naDuwDN A well of which the water flows by little and little: or oozes forth. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense: naDiyDN Water little in quantity: (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ.) pl. niDaADN; (Ṣ, O, L, TA; in the Ḳ, naDaAYiDu, which is a mistake. TA.) Also, A small quantity of milk. (Ṣ. Ḳ.)
rajulN naDiyDN All-aHomi † A man having little flesh; (Ḳ;) as also naD-uhu↓, and naDonaADuhu↓. (TA.)
