jaAWwA biOaquSaI naDiyDihimo, and naDiyDatihimo↓, They came with the most remote of their company; (O, Ḳ;) from Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)

entry.sense: nuDaADapN A remainder, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or small remainder, (A,) of water, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,), &c.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the last thereof: pl. naDaAYiSu and niDaADN. (TA.) [Hence,] nuDaADapu waladi Alr-ajuli ‡ The last of the children of the man: (AZ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) applied alike to the male and female and to two and more; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like EijozapN and kiborapN. (Ṣ.)
‡ A small thing: (A) what comes into one's hand, of a thing: a small benefit. (TA.)

hom.sense: naSiyDapN A small quantity of rain: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a weak rain: or a weak cloud: or one flowing with water: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaniD-apN and [of mult.] naDaAYiDu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A wind that brings rain. (taniD-u biAlomaMCi,) so that it flows: or a weak wind. (AʼObeyd, Ḳ.)
lqadN tarakovi AlUibilu AlmaMCa wahiIa caAtu naDiyDapK, and caAtu naDaAYiDa, The camels have left the water, having thirst; (Ṣ, Ḳ.;*) not having satisfied their thirst. (Ṣ.)

The sound of the roasting of flesh-meat upon heated stones: pl. naDaAYiDu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) ISd, however, says, I think that naDaAYDu is a sing., like xaXaArimu; but the sing. may be naDiyDapN. (TA.) [It seems to me not improbable that naDaAYiDu may in a mistranscription, for naDaAYiDu, pl. of the inf. n. naDonaDapN used as a subst.]
See also naDiyDN.
naDonaADN: see naDiyDN.

Hay-apN naDonaADN, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and naDonaADapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) A serpent that remains not still in a place, (IAạr, Ḳ,) by reason of its malignity and liveliness: (IAạr:) or that, when it bites, kills immediately: (Ḳ:) or that moves about its tongue, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) having put it forth; (Ḳ;) as also with S: [see naSonaASN:] (TA:) or that utters a sound, or sounds. (TA.) It is said that Dhu-r-Rummeh, being asked respecting the meaning of naDonADN, did nothing more than move about his tongue in his mouth; (Ṣ:) or put forth his tongue, and move it about, (IJ, O,) in his mouth, making a sign with it to him who asked him. (O.)

entry.sense: naDonaADapN: see faDofaADapN.
naADN ‡ A thing, or an affair, within one's power or reach [&c.: see 1, of which it is the part. n.]. (Ḳ.)
See also naD-N in six places.

hom.sense: 1. naDaba, aor. _u {yanoDubu}. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and also _i, (Mṣb,) which latter is strange, (MF,) inf. n. nuDuwbN; (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.;) and nD-b↓; (Ḳ;) It (water) sank into the earth; disappeared in the earth: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.:) and became low: (Ṣ:) became remote. (Ṣ, M.)
naDaba AlHawoDu, occurring in a verse cited by Th, [The water of the tank or cistern, sank into the earth]. (TA.)
naDabato Euyuwnu AlT-aAYifi [The sources of El-Táïf became dried up]. (A.)

maA naDaba Eanohu AlbaHoru wahuwa HaI-N famaAta fakuluwhu That from which the water of the sea has become exhausted, and has dried up, it being alive, and which has then died, eat ye it. (TA, from a trad.)

kun-aA EalaI XaATiYi Aln-ahori biAloOahowaAzi waqado naDaba Eanohu AlmaACu [We were on the bank of the river in El-Ahwáz, and the water had sunk, or receded, from it, leaving it dry]. (TA, from a trad.)
naDabato Eayonuhu, (aor. _u {yanoDubu}, inf. n. nuDuwbN, TA,) ‡ His eye sank, or became depressed, in the socket: or it is only said of the eye of a she-camel. (Ḳ.)
naDaba It (herbage and the like, that had been abundant,) became little, or scanty: (Ḳ:) or failed altogether. (TA.)

naDaba is met. used with reference to accidents [as it is properly with respect to substances]: thus it is said in a trad., naDaba Eumoruhu ‡ His life passed away, or ended. (IAth.) This is what F means by saying naDaba fulaAnN signifies maAta, ‡ Such a one died. (TA.)
naDaba xayoruhu, inf. n. nuDuwbN, ‡ His goodness, or beneficence, became little. (AZ.)
naDaba maACu wajohihi ‡ He was not ashamed. (TA.)
naDaba, (inf. n. nuDuwbN, TA,) ‡ It (a desert) was far-extending. (Ḳ.)
naDaba, inf. n. nuDuwbN, ‡ It (a people, or party,) was, or became, distant. (Ṣ.)
naDaba ‡ It (a people, or party,) strove, or used exertion, [app., in a journey.] (TA.)

naDaba, aor. _u {yanoDubu}, It (a thing, TA,) flowed, and ran (Ḳ.) By our saying “a thing,” we mean to exclude water, though water is included in the definition of a thing: so that we need not infer from what is said in the Ḳ that the verb bears two contr. significations. (TA.) [But this observation appears to me to be scarcely admissible.]

naDabati Ald-abarapu [in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands, written daborap] The sore on the back of a camel, &c. became severe. (Ḳ.) naDaba Ald-abaru ‡ The scar of the sore became severe and deep in the back. (A.)
naDaba Alv-awoba He pulled off the garment. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1
nD-bt, inf. n. tanoDiybN, She (a camel) had little milk; and her flow thereof became slow; (Ḳ;) and her milk was long in flowing again into her udder after each previous milking. (TA.)

4. AnDb Alqawosa He pulled the string of the bow, in order that it might make a sound: like OanobaDahaA: (Ḳ:) the former verb is [said to be] an original syn. of the latter; (TA;) [and if so, it has an inf. n., as shown below:] or he pulled the string of the bow, and then let it go, to make it twang: or he pulled the string of the bow without an arrow, and then let it go, to make it twang: (TA:) or he caused the bow to make a sound, or twang: (AḤn, L:) AnDb watara Alqawosi is the same as OanobaDahu, of which it is a transp. syn. (Ṣ.) AḤn, gives to it the inf. n. UinoDaAbN; and yet asserts it to be formed by transposition: but this is absurd; for verbs so formed have not inf. ns.; as mentioned by Sb and Aboo-ʼAlee and the rest of the skilful grammarians. (Abu-l-Ḥasan.) See qalaba.
gaDiyrN naADibN A pool of which the water has sunk into the earth. (A.)
[So] Eyn munaD-ibapN↓ A source of which the water has sunk into the earth; [a source that has become dried up]. (A.)
xaroqN naADibN ‡ [A deep hole: or a far extending desert]: syn. baEiydN. (Ṣ, TA.)
Uin-a fulaAnFA lanaADibu Alxayori ‡ Verily such a one is a person of little good, or beneficence. (AZ.)
naADibN ‡ Distant; remote: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) an epithet applied to water and anything. (TA.)
jaroIN naADibN † A far-extending run. (TA.)

tanoDubN, a coll. gen. n., [I find it said to have been written with tenween by J himself: but it appears to have been also used as a generic proper name; and as such, having the measure of a verb, it must be written tanoDubu, being imperfectly declinable:] A certain tree: the t is augmentative, because there is no word of the measure faEolulN; whereas there are words of the measure tafoEulu, as taqotulu and taxoruju: n. un. tanoDubapN: (Ṣ:) a certain tree of El-Ḥijáz: (Ḳ:) it grows large, in the form, or manner, of the saroH, having white and thick branches; and folds, such as are called HaZaAYir, are made of it: [this is the only meaning I can assign to the words whw mHtZr, supposing bihi to be omitted after mHnZr, though yuHonaZaru would be better:] its leaves are contracted; and it always appears as though it were dry and dusty, though growing: (TA:) its thorns are like those of the Eawosaj: (Ḳ, TA:) and it has a fruit [called magodN (L, Ḳ, art. mgd)] like small grapes, which is eaten, of a reddish colour: AḤn says, that its smoke is white, of the colour of dust; and that poets therefore liken dust to it: and in one place he says, that it is a large tree, without leaves [properly so called], which has a trunk, and from which grow thick boughs, with many branches; its leaves [if such they may be called] being only shoots, which are eaten by the camels and sheep and goats: Aboo-Naṣr says, that it is a tree having short thorns: not of the trees that grow on lofty mountains; frequented by chameleons: [see HirobaACN, in art. Hrb: and see an ex. in a verse cited voce saAqN:] ISd thinks that it is thus called because of its little sap: AM says, that it is a large tree, from which are cut tentpoles: (TA:) and Ibn-Selemeh says, that it is a tree from which arrows are made. (Ṣ.)
nuwqN kaqidaAHi Alt-anoDubi [She-camels like arrows made of the wood of the tendub]. (TA).
munaD-ibapN: see naASibN.

1. naDija, aor. _a {yanoDaju}, inf. n. nuDojN and naDojN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) or these are [properly] simple substs., (the former accord. to the L, and both accord. to the Mṣb,) and the inf. n. is naDajN, (Mṣb,) It (fruit, Alv-amaru, Ṣ, Ḳ, [in the CK Alt-amoru, or dates,] as grapes, and dates, TA, and flesh-meat, Ṣ, Ḳ, whether dried in the sun or roasted, TA, [or cooked in any way,]) attained to a perfect state of fitness for being used, or for being eaten: it (fruit) became ripe, or mature: it (flesh-meat) became thoroughly cooked. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) See 2. [And It (the skin of one tormented in Hell) became thoroughly burned: see Ḳur iv. 59.]
[It (an ulcer or the like) became ripe, or suppurated.]

hom.sense: 2. naD-ajati Aln-aAqapu biwaladihaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and naDajato↓ bihi, (Ḳ,) and naD-ajato waladahaA, (L,) ‡ She (a camel) exceeded the usual period of gestation by a month, or thereabout: (L:) or exceeded the year and did not bring forth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) was pregnant, and exceeded the year, counting from the time when she conceived, and did not bring forth. (Aṣ.) Th uses the expression nD-jt wldhA as signifying She (a woman) exceeded the usual period of gestation, namely nine months; or did so by a month: in which case the child is more strong for the delay. (TA.)
naD-ajati Aln-aAqapu bilabanihaA ‡ The she-camel attained the utmost point with her milk: but ISd thinks it a mistake for nD-jt bwldhA. (L.)
See 4.

entry.sense: 4. AnDj He rendered fruit, or flesh-meat, (whether dried in the sun or roasted, TA, [or cooked in any way],) perfectly fit for being used, or for being eaten: rendered ripe, or mature: thoroughly cooked: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it (the proper time) rendered fruit ripe, or mature; ripened, or matured it. (TA.)

AHn uses this verb in a strange manner, explaining the expression nabaAtN mahoruwoCN by the words Oal-aciI qado OanoDajahu Albarodu [meaning, a plant, or herbage, that is nipped, shrunk, shrivelled, or blasted, by the cold]: this is strange because UinoDaAj is an effect of heat; not of cold. (M.) [See OaHoraqa.]
OanoDijo raOoyaka ‡ [Mature thy judgment, or thine opinion]. (A.)

laA yunoDiju AlskuraAEa, (L,) or laA yasotanoDiju↓ kuraAEFA, (A,) [He does not thoroughly cook the slender part of the leg of a sheep, or the like]: i. e., he is weak, and of no use, or does not possess a competence. (L.)
[AnDj also signifies It matured, or caused to suppurate, an ulcer or the like; as also nD-j↓.]
naDoxN: see nuDojN.
nuDojN and naDojN↓: see 1.
As simple subst., in relation to fruit, or to flesh-meat. A perfect state of fitness for being used, or for being eaten. ripeness, or maturity: the state of being thoroughly cooked. (L, Mṣb.)

naDiyjN and naADijN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and munoDajN↓ (TA) Fruit, and flesh-meat, (whether dried in the sun or roasted, TA, [or cooked in any way,]) in a perfect state of fitness for being used, or for being eaten: ripe, or mature: thoroughly cooked: (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) pl. [of the first, and perhaps of the second also,] niDaAjN. (TA.)
naDiyju Alr-aOoIi ‡ A man of sound, [or mature] judgment. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OamorN munoDaju↓ ‡ [A matured affair; and affair soundly, or thoroughly, managed] (A.)
naADiju: see naDiyjN.
munoDajN: see naDiyjN.
munoDijN: see what follows.

munaD-ijN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and munoDijN↓ and each with p {munaD-ijapN}(L) ‡ A she-camel that exceeds the usual period of gestation by a month, or thereabout: (L:) or that exceeds the year and does not bring forth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. munaDijaAto (Ṣ) and munoDijaAtN. (L.) See an ex. voce qiraAbN.
[Also both, but the latter the more common, A suppurative medicine.]
minoDaAjN An iron instrument for roasting flesh-meat; syn. saf-awdN. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naDaHa, aor. _i {yanoDiHu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and _a, (Mṣb, MF,) inf. n. naDoHN, (Ṣ,) He sprinkled a house, or chamber, [with water]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he sprinkled it lightly: (TA:) naDoHN is like naDoxN; and sometimes these two words agree, and sometimes they differ: (Lth:) some say that they both signify any sprinkling: (TA:) or the former signifies what is intentional; and the latter, what is unintentional. (IAạr.) [See naDaxa.]
naDaHotu Ealayohi AlmaMCa, inf. n. naDoHN, [I sprinkled water, or the water, upon him]. (Aṣ.)
naDaHa, aor. _i {yanoDiHu}, and _a, inf. n. naDoHN, He moistened, or sprinkled, a garment, or piece of cloth. (Mṣb.)
OaSaAbahu naDoHN mino kacaA [A sprinkling of such a thing came upon him]. (TA.)
naDaHato biyawolihaA She (a camel) sprinkled her urine. (TA.)

naDaHa EaTaXahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanoDiHu}, inf. n. naDoHN, (Ṣ,) ‡ It (water, TA,) moistened [or allayed] his thirst, (Ṣ, TA,) and allayed it: (Ḳ. TA:) took it away: or almost took it away: (TA;) also (Ḳ) or naDaHa Alr-iIa, (TA,) he satisfied his thirst with drink: (Ḳ:) or he drank less than what would satisfy his thirst. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naDaHa AlmaMCu AlmaAla The water took away the thirst of the camels, &c.: or nearly did so. (T.)
naDaHa AlmaMCa He (a camel) carried water from a river or canal or well to irrigate standing corn or the like. (Mṣb.)
naDaHa He moistened a skin, in order that it might not break.
naDaHa Aljul-apa, aor. _a {yanoDaHu}, inf. n. naDoHN, He sprinkled the palm-leaf date-basket with water, in order that its dates might stick together: (L:) or he scattered forth its contents. (L, Ḳ.)
naDaHa (inf. n. naSoHN, Ṣ,) He watered palm-trees, (Ḳ,) and standing corn, &c., (TA,) by means of a camel carrying the water. (Ḳ.)
suqiI Alz-aroEu naDoHA The standing corn, &c. was watered by means of buckets, (dilaMCa and guruwb,) and camels carrying the water; not by means of a channel opened for that purpose. (TA.)
hecihi naxolu tunoDaHu These are palm-trees that are watered [by the means above mentioned]. (Ṣ.)
fulaAnN yasoqiI biAln-aDoH [Such a one waters palm-trees, &c. by the means above mentioned]. (Ṣ.)
yanoDiHu EalaI AlbaEiyri He drives the camel that carries the water for irrigation, watering palm-trees [&c.] (Ṣ)

naDaHuwhumo biAln-aboli, (inf. n. naDoHN, TA.) ‡ They shot at them [or sprinkled them] with arrows: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) they scattered arrows among them. like as water is sprinkled. (TA.) Moḥammad said to the archers at the battle of Ohod, AinoDiHuwA Ean-aA Alxayola ‡ Shoot ye at the horses and their riders with arrows [and so repel them from us]. (Ṣ,* TA.)

naDaHa farojahu, aor. _i {yanoDiHu} and _u {yanoDuHu}; (TA;) and AntDH↓ and AstnDH↓ [both of which are thus used as intrans.]: (Ḳ;) He sprinkled some water upon his pudendum after the ablution called AlwuDuwoC: (Ḳ:) as also AinotafaDa. (TA.)

naDaHa biAlbawoli EalaI faxicayohi He made [a little sprinkling of] urine to fall upon his thighs. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying in a trad., Aln-aDoxu mina Aln-aDoHi, meaning, that he upon whom falls a little sprinkling of urine, like the heads of needles, as explained by Z, must sprinkle the part with water, and is not required to wash it. (TA.)
naDaHatonaA Als-amaMCu The sky rained upon us. (L.)

naDaHa, [aor. _a {yanoDaHu},] He (a horse) sweated. (Mṣb.) naDaHa biAlEaraqi, inf. n. naDoHN and naDaHaAnN, He (a man, and a horse,) broke out with sweat: and in like manner, the protuberance behind a camel's ear; and the arm-pit or the like. (L) [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. Edw, conj. 3.]
yanoDaHu TybFA He diffuses the odour of perfume: lit., sweats it. (L, from a trad.)
naDaHa It (sweat) exuded, or came forth. (Mṣb.)

naDaHati Alqrobapu. (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AlxaAbiyapu, (Ṣ,) aor. _a {yanoDaHu}, inf. n. naDoHN and tan-aDaAHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [the latter of an intensive form,] The water-skin, and the jar. (being thin, TA,) sweated, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or exuded its water. (TA.)
naDaHa Aljabalu The mountain sweated water between its masses of rock. (TA)
naDaH AlX-ajaru, inf. n. naDoHN, (TA,) ‡ The trees began to break out with leaves. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naDaHa Alz-aroEu, and AnDH↓, † The standing corn became thick in its body, (TA,) and began to have the farinaceous substance in its grains, yet moist, or succulent, or tender. (Ḳ.)

taDaHati AlEayonu, (L, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanoDiHu}, inf. n. naDoHN: (L.;) and AntDHt↓, (L, Ḳ,) and nnD-Ht↓; (Ḳ;) The eye overflowed with tears: (L, Ḳ:) the eye filled with tears and the overflowed without stopping. (L.)
naDaHa, aor. _a {yanoDaHu} It (a sea, or great river,) flowed. (TA, art. tbr.)
AinoDaHuwA Alr-aHima bibilaAlihaA: see bilaAlN.

naDaHa Eano fulaAnK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanoDiHu}; (Ṣ;) and bADH↓ Eanohu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. munaADaHapu and niDaAHN; (TA;) ‡ He repelled from, and defended, such a one: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also maDaHa: (Shujáa:) and naDHa Alr-ajula he repelled from the man. (Kr.)
naDaHa Eano nafosihi ‡ He defended himself with an argument. a pled. or an allegation. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1.
4: see 1
AnDH EiroDahu † He aspersed his honour, or reputation: (Ḳ:) marred it; as also OamoDaHahu: (Shujáa Es-Sulamee:) made people to carp at it. (Khaleefeh.)
5: see 1 and 8.
raOayotahu yatanaD-aHu mim-aA qarifa bihi ‡ I saw him deny, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and declare himself clear of, (Ṣ,) that of which he was accused, or suspected. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)
tnD-H mino OamorK ‡ He pretended to be clear, or quit, of the thing. (TA.)
8. AntDH Ealayohimu AlmaMCu The water became sprinkled upon them. (Ṣ.)
AntDH Albawolu EalaI Alv-awobi The urine became sprinkled upon the garment. (Mṣb.)
AntDH biAln-aDuwHi He sprinkled himself with the kind of perfume called naDuwH. (L.) [And tnD-H↓ is used in similar sense in art. gsl in the Ḳ.] See 1.
naDoHN A rain between two rains; better than what is called Tal-; (L;) i. q. naDoHN, with respect to rain. (Sh.)
naDoHaAtN [or naDaHaAtN?] A slight, or scanty, scattered shower of rain. (L.)
Also naADiHN↓ Rain. (L.)
naDoHN † Perfume that is thin, like water: pl. nuDuwHN and OanoDiHapN: [see also naDuwHN:] what is thick, like xaluwq and gaAliyap, is called naDoxN. (L.)
A mark left by water, or anything thin, such as vinegar and the like: differing from naDoxN [q. v.]. (AA, in TA, art. nDx.)

naDaHN and naDiyHN↓ ‡ A watering-trough or tank; or so called because it moistens [or allays] the thirst of camels: (IAạr, Ṣ:) or a small watering-trough or tank: (TA:) or the latter a watering-trough or tank that is near to the well, so as to be filled with the bucket; and it may be large: (Lth:) pl. of the former OanoDaAHN; and of the latter nuDuHN. (Ṣ.)
naDaHu AlwuDuwoCi What is sprinkled in the performance of the ablution called AlwDwC. (L.) [See naDaHa farojahu.]
nuDaHiy-apN: see naDuwHN.
mazaAdapN naDuwHN A mzAdp that sweats, or exudes its water. (TA.)
naDuwHN ‡ A certain kind of perfume. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also naDoHN.]
qawosN naDuwHN, and nuDaHiy-apN↓, A bow that impels the arrow with force, or sends it far, and that scatters the arrows much; expl. by TaruwHN naD-aAHapN↓ liln-aboli. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
Aln-aDuwHu One of the names of The bow. (TA.)
naDiyHN Sweat. (Ṣ.)
See naDaHN.
naD-aAHN He who drives the camel that carries water from a well, &c., for irrigating land, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and waters palm-trees [&c.]. (Ṣ.)
See qawosN naDuwHN.
naD-aAHapN: see minoDaHapN

naADiHN ‡ A camel (Ṣ) or an ass or a bull (TA) upon which water is drawn (yasotaqaI Ealayohi) [from a well, &c.]: (Ṣ, TA:) a camel that carries water (yaHomilu AlmaMCa) from a river or canal or well to irrigate seed-produce; so called because it is a means of moistening [or allaying] thirst by the water which it carries: (Mṣb:) the female is called naADiHapN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and saAniyapN [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) pl. nawaADiHu. (Mṣb.)
Afterwards applied to Any camel: as in the following instance, occurring in a trad., OaToEimohu naADiHaka Give him thy camel to eat. (Mṣb.)
See naDoHN.

minoDaHapN (L, Ḳ) as also minoDaxapN, (IAạr, L,) vulg. naD-aAHapN↓, (Az,) i. q. zar-aAqapN, (IAạr, L, [in some copies of the Ḳ zur-aqp; in the CK zarAfap]) i. e. An instrument made of copper or brass for shooting forth naphtha [into a besieged place: mentioned in several histories]. (L.)

1. naDaxahu, aor. _a {yanoDaxu}, [and _i, see below], inf. n. naDoxN, He sprinkled him, or it, [with water, &c.]: or i. q. naDaHahu: (Ḳ:) AZ says, naDoxN signifies the act of sprinkling, like naDoHN; these two words being syn.: you say naDaxotu, aor. OanoDaxu: (Ṣ:) or the former signifies less than the latter: (Ḳ:) so most say: (L:) or the former signifies what is unintentional; and the latter, what is intentional: (IAạr, L:) Aṣ says, that the latter is the act of man: (L:) and the former, he says, signifies more than the latter, and has no pret. nor aor.: and Aboo-ʼOthmán Et-Towwazee says, that the former signifies the mark, or effect, that remains upon a garment or other thing, and that the act is termed naDoHN, with H unpointed: (Ṣ:) Aṣ says, that naDoxN has no verb nor act. part. n.; and AʼObeyd says, that it has no pret. nor aor. ascribed to any authority: or you say naDaxotu Alv-awoba, aor. _a {yanoDaxu} and _i {yanoDixu}, inf. n. naDoxN, I wetted the garment; and it signifies more than naDaHotu. (Mṣb.) nuDixato magaAbinuhaA, inf. n. naDaxaAnN, Her (a she-camel's) armpits were sprinkled with pitch. (Ṣ, L, from a verse of El-Katámee.) OaSaAbahu naDoxN mino kacaA A sprinkling, more [or less] than what is termed naDoHN, came upon him. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)

naDaxonaAhumo biAln-abol, (Yz, Ṣ,) and nDHnA Aln-abola fiyhimo, (Ḳ,) i. q. nDHnAhm, (Yz, Ṣ,) We [shot at them and] sprinkled them with arrows; or scattered arrows among them; (Yz, Ṣ, Ḳ;) meaning, our enemies. (Ḳ.)
naDaxa, (inf. n. naDoxN, L,) It (water) boiled forth vehemently (in gushing, L,) from its source, (L, Ḳ,) or boiled up vehemently. (Aboo-ʼAlee, L, Ḳ.)
3. nADxA, inf. n. munaADaxapN and niDaAxN, They sprinkled each other. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
8. AntDx It (water) became sprinkled. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
9. AnDx- and AnDAx-↓ It (water) poured out, or forth. (TA.)

naDoxN A mark, or effect, that remains upon a garment or other thing, (Aboo-ʼOthmán Et-Towwazee, Ṣ, Ḳ,) as the body, (TA,) from perfume, (Ḳ,) or mire, or a soil or pollution: (TA:) or from blood, and saffron, and mud, and the like: naDoHN being with water, and with anything thin, such as vinegar and the like. (AA.) [See also naDoHN.]
naDoxapN A rain; a shower of rain. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
gayovN naD-aAxN A copious rain. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
EayonN naD-aAxapN A copious spring of water: (Ṣ:) or a spring that boils forth, or gushes forth (Ṣ, Mṣb) copiously. (Mṣb.)
naD-aAxapu Alc-iforaI A she-camel that sweats copiously in the part called cfrI, behind the ear. (L.)
minoDaxapN, [in the TA mnDx,] vulgo naD-aAxapN, i. q. zur-aAqapN: (Ḳ, TA:) [in the CK, zaraAqap, which is a mistake: see minoDaHapN].

1. naDada, aor. _i {yanoDidu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. naDodN; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb;) and nD-d↓, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoDiydN; (Ṣ, L;) or the latter has an intensive signification; (Ṣ, L;) He put goods, household-goods, or commodities, (mataAE, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) one upon another: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or put, or set, them together, (T, A, L,) in regular order, or piled up: (A:) both verbs signify the same: (L, Ḳ:) or the latter, he put them one upon another [or side by side] compactly. (Ṣ, L.)

[You say,] naDadotu Allabina EalaI Almay-iti [I placed the crude bricks in order against the corpse, to support it; as it is laid upon its right side, or so inclined that the face is towards Mekkeh]. (L.)
2. nD-d, inf. n. tanoDiydN, He [God] made a person's teeth to be disposed in regular order. (A.)
See 1.
5. tnD-dt AlOasonaAnu The teeth were disposed in regular order. (A.)
8. AntDd, [quasi-pass. of 1, It was put, or set, one part upon, or beside, another, in regular order; was piled up, or became piled up]. (Ḳ, art. fqr.)
AntDd ‡ It (a people, A) remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place; (A, Ḳ;) and collected there. (A.)

naDadN Goods, household-goods, or commodities, put one upon another: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, put, or set, together, (A, L,) in regular order, or piled up: (A:) or the best thereof: (L, Ḳ:) or such things in general: but the first meaning is the most appropriate: (L:) pl. OanoDaAdN. (Ṣ, L.)
raOayotu naDadFA mina Alv-iyaAbi wAlfuruXi I saw a number of garments, or pieces of cloth, and of beds, or the like, put together in regular order, or piled up. (A.)
See naDiydapN.

naDadN A couch-frame, or a raised couch, (sariyr,) upon which goods, householdgoods, or commodities, are put one upon another, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or put, or set, together, in regular order, or piled up: (A, L:) or simply, a couchframe, or raised couch; (sryr;) so called because the things so termed are generally put upon it: (L, Mṣb:) or a miXojab, or a thing resembling this, upon which garments and household-goods are put, one upon another, or together. (L.)
naDadN ‡ Glory; honour; dignity; might; or power; (A;) eminence; or nobility. (Ḳ.)
naDadN ‡ Eminent; or noble: (L, Ḳ:) applied to a man: pl. OanoDaAdN. (L.)
Also, (A, L,) and the pl., (Ṣ, A, L,) ‡ A man's paternal and maternal uncles (Ṣ, A, L) preëminent in nobility. (Ṣ, L.)

Also, the pl., ‡ The party, or company, (L, Ḳ,) and number, (A, L, Ḳ,) and auxiliaries, or assistants, (A,) of a people, (L, Ḳ,) or of a man: (A:) and the sing. and pl., companies, or congregated bodies, of men. (A.)
naDadN ‡ A fat she-camel; (Ḳ;) likened to a couch-frame, or a raised couch, upon which are the things termed naDad; (TA;) as also naDuwdN↓. (Ḳ.)
OanoDaAdN, of mountains, Stones, such as are called janaAdil, one upon another. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) Also, of clouds, Portions piled up, one above another: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) sing. naDadN. (L.)
naDuwdN: see naDadN and naDiydN.

naDiydN and manoDuwdN↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and munaD-adN↓, [or the last has an intensive signification, as is shewn above,] Goods, household-goods, or commodities, (Ḳ,) put one upon another: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or put, or set, together, in regular order, or piled up: and the last, put one upon another, or side by side, compactly: see 1].

TaloEN naDiydN, in the Ḳur, [l. 10.] Spadices of palm-trees [having their flowers] compacted, or compactly disposed; (L;) yet in their envelopes; (Fr, L;) for when they have come forth therefrom they cease to be nDyd. (L.)
TaloHN manoDuwdN↓, in the Ḳur, [lvi. 28,] Gum-acacias having fruit or leaves closely set, one above another, from bottom to top, without their trunks being apparent below. (L.)

Xajaru Alxan-api naDiydN mino OaSolihaA UilaI faroEihaA The trees of paradise are closely set with leaves and fruit, one above another, from bottom to top, without having trunks apparent: (L, from a trad.:) and similarly naDuwdN↓ (Jel, lvi. 20.)
naDiydapN A pillow: and any stuffed article of household furniture: (L, Ḳ:) pl. naDaAYidu: and naDadN↓ is used as a coll. n. (L.)
manuDuwdN: see naDiydN.
dur-N munaD-adN Pearls arranged, or put together, in regular order. (A.)
See naDiydN.

hom.sense: 1. naDura, aor. _u {yanoDuru}; (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and naDara, aor. _u {yanoDuru} and naDira, aor. _a {yanoDaru}; (IAạr, Ṣ, A. Ḳ;) the last [also] mentioned by AʼObeyd; (Ṣ;) inf. n. naDaArapN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the first; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and nuDuwrN (Ḳ) and naDorapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) of the second, (Ṣ,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and naDorN, (TA,) [also of the second;] and naDarN, (Ḳ;) [of the third;] and OanoDara↓; (IAạr, L, Ḳ, TA;) It (a tree, A, Ḳ, and a plant, A, and foliage, TA, and a colour, Ḳ, and a face, IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and anything, TA,) was, or became, beautiful (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and bright: (Ṣ* [see naDorapN below]) or, when said of a face, tropically used, (A,) signifying as above: (TA:) or ‡ it was, or became, beautiful and fresh: or beautiful and fine-skinned, so that the blood appeared [through the skin]: syn. Hasuna wagaD-a: (A:) or pleasant: (Fr:) and AnDr↓, said of a tree, its foliage became green. (TA.)

[When said of a man, sometimes signifying He was, or became, in a state of enjoyment, or in a plentiful and pleasant and easy state of life; agreeably with a usage of naDara and naD-ara↓ and OanoDara↓ to be mentioned below. And in like manner, when said of life, it signifies It was, or became plentiful and pleasant and easy.]

naDarahu Qll-ehu, (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoDuru}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. naDorN; (TA;) and nD-rhu↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or this has an intensive signification; (Mṣb;) and AnDrhu↓; (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) when the pronoun relates to the face, (IAạr, Ṣ, A,) in which case it is tropical, (A,) [or to a tree, or colour, as is implied in the Ḳ,] God made it beautiful (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and bright. (Ṣ,* TA.)

When the pronoun relates to a man, the meaning (of the first of these three forms, as mentioned by En-Naḍr and Sh and in the Mgh and TA, and of the ↓second, as mentioned by Aṣ, and En-Naḍr and Sh, &c., and of the ↓third, as mentioned in the TA,) is God made him to have enjoyment, or plentiful and pleasant and easy life; syn. naE-amahu; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA;) or jaEalhu naADirFA [which signifies the same]: (AʼObeyd:) or naDarahu Qll-eh, (El-Azdee, Mgh,) and nD-rhu↓ Qll-eh, (El-Ḥasan El-Muäddib, TA:) signifies † God made his rank, or station, good (El-Azdee, El-Ḥasan El-Muäddib, Mgh, TA,) among mankind: (El-Ḥasan El-Muäddib, TA:) not relating to beauty of the face; (El-Azdee, El-Ḥasan El-Muäddib, Mgh, TA:) but is similar to the saying, OuTolubuwA AlHawaAYija UilaI HisaAni Alwujuwhi [which see explained in art. wjh]. (El-Ḥasan El-Muäddib, TA.) Aṣ cites this verse:
naD-ara Qll-ehu OaEoZumFA dafanuwhaA
bisijisotaAna TaloHapa AlT-alaHaAti
[May God grant enjoyment to bones which they have buried in Sijistán: (I mean) Talhat-et- Talahát]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., naDara Qll-ehu EabodFA samiEa maqaAlatiI fawaEaAhaA vum-a Oad-AhaA UilI mano yasomaEahaA, (Sh, Ṣ,* A,* Mgh,* TA,) or naD-ara↓, (Sh, Ṣ, in which latter we read QmoraOa in the place of EbdA, and A, in which we find mano in the place of EbdA, and Mgh; the reading nD-r↓ alone being given in the copies which I have of the Ṣ and A;) May God cause to have enjoyment, or a plentiful and pleasant and easy life, [the servant, or man, who hears what I say, and keeps it in mind, then conveys it to him who hears it:] (Ṣ, Mgh, in explanation of the latter reading, and TA, in explanation of both readings:) or † may God make to have a good rank or station, &c. (Mgh, in explanation of the former reading.)

entry.sense: 2. nD-rhu Qll-eh: see naDarahu {1}, throughout.

hom.sense: 4. AnDr: see naDura {1}, in two places.
AnDrhu Qll-ehu: see naDarahu {1}, throughout.

entry.sense: naDorN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nuDaArN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, [in the CK naDaAr] and TA) and naDiyrN↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OanoDaru↓ (Ḳ [without tenween, though this is not shown in the Ḳ, as it is originally an epithet, though it may be obsolete as an epithet,]) Gold: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also niDaArN↓: (Es-Sukkaree:) or silver; (Ḳ;) as also niSaArN↓: (Es-Sukkaree:) or generally the former: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] (of the first, Ṣ.) OanoDurN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and [of mult.] niDaArN: (Ḳ:) or (so accord. to the Ṣ and A, but in the Ḳ, and) nuDaArN↓ signifies what is pure, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) of gold, &c., (A,) or of native or unwrought gold or silver, (Lth, Ḳ,) and of wood, (Lth,) or of anything: (Ṣ:) and is used as an epithet, applied to gold (TA:) and naDorapN↓ [n. un. of naDorN] signifies a molten piece of gold. (TA.)
naDirN: see naADirN.

hom.sense: naDorapN Beauty (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and brightness: (Ṣ, TA:) so in the Ḳur, lxxvi. 11. (Jel.) [The above explanation in the Mṣb and Ḳ, “beauty,” is evidently imperfect. Accord. to the Mṣb, the word is a simple subst., not an inf. n.] † Pleasantness of countenance.

naDorapu ln-aEiymi † The beauty and brightness of aspect characteristic of enjoyment, or of a plentiful and pleasant and easy state of existence: so in the Ḳur, lxxx ii: 24: (Bḍ, Jel:) or the brightness, or glistening, and moisture (nadaA) [upon the skin] characteristic thereof. (Fr.)
Enjoyment; or a plentiful and pleasant and easy life; syn. naEomapN [in the CK niEomap]. (A, Ḳ.)
Richness; or competence or sufficiency. (A, Ḳ.)
Life. (A, Ḳ.)
See also naDorN.

entry.sense: nuDaArN: see naDorN; each in two places. See also garabN.
niDaArN: see naDorN; each in two places. See also garabN.

hom.sense: naDiyrN: see naADirN, in two places:
and see naDorN.

entry.sense:
naADirN (A, L, Ḳ) and naDiyrN↓ (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and naDirN↓, (A, L,) [being epithets from naDara and naDura and naDira, respectively,] and OanoDaru↓, accord. to the Ḳ, but in the place of this we find in the corresponding passage in the L the verb OanoDara, with the addition “is like naDara,” (TA,) Beautiful (Mṣb, Ḳ) and bright. (TA.)
So in the Ḳur, lxxv. 22, wujuwhN yawomaYicK naADirapN † Faces on that day shall be beautiful and bright: (Bḍ, Jel:) or shining by reason of enjoyment, or of a beautiful and pleasant and easy state of existence. (Fr.) [These epithets have also other, similar, significations, shown by explanations of naDura and its variations.] naADirN is coupled with gaD-N, as an epithet applied to a boy, (A,) and so naDiyrN↓; (TA,) and naADrapN with gaD-apN, applied to a girl, (A,) and so naDiyrapN; (TA;) and thus used are tropical. (A.)

naADirN also signifies Intense in greenness: (Ḳ:) you say OaxoDaru naADirN [intense, or bright, green], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like as you say OaSofaru faAqiEN and OaboyaDu naASiEN: (Ṣ:) and in like manner it is used as an intensive epithet applied to any colour: you say OaHomaru naADirN [intense, or bright, red], and OaSofaru naADirN [intense, or bright, yellow]: (Ḳ:) so says IAạr: (TA:) or OaxoDaru naASirN signifies smooth green, accord. to AʼObeyd, and Az adds, glistening in its clearness. (TA.)

hom.sense: OanoDaru: see naDorN:
and see naADirN.

entry.sense: [1. naTaOa bisaloHihi: see vTO.]
1. naTabahu (aor. _u {yanoTubu}, inf. n. naTobN, TA,) He struck [or fillipped] his ear with his finger. (Ḳ.) AnTb↓ Oucunahu, and Oanoqara, and bal-aTa, signify the same. (AA.)
3. naATabahumo, (inf. n. munaATabapN, TA,) He incited them against each other, (Ḳ,) and acted in an evil or mischievous manner towards them. (TA.)
4: see 1.
naTobapN i. q. naTomapN, i. e., A single act of piercing, or pecking, with the beak, of a cock, &c. (Az.)

niTaAbN The head. (Th, Ḳ.) Respecting the saying of El-Jo'eyd El-Murádee,
naHonu DarabonaAhu ElI niTaAbihi
ISk says, No one has explained it, and the reading better known is ElI taToyaAbihi, meaning “notwithstanding the sweetness (Tiyb) that was in him:” for the man spoken of was going in to a bride of the tribe of Murád: but accord. to some, nTAb here signifies The tendon of the neck; syn. Habolu AlEunuqi; so in the Ḳ, on the authority of Aboo-ʼAdnán alone; or Hbl AlEaAtiqi, accord. to IAạr, who cites this verse:
naHonu DarabonaAhu EalaI niTaAbihi
qulonaA bihi qulonaA bihi qulonaA bihi
[We smote him on the tendon of the upper part of his shoulders: we slew him: we slew him: we slew him]. qlnA bh signifies qatalonaAhu. (TA.)

naATibpN, and naATibN, sing. of nawaATibu in the following sense: (TA:) The holes that are made in a thing with which one clears, or clarifies, [i. e. strains, or filters], and through which what is cleared [or strained] passes forth: (Ḳ:) the holes of a strainer for wine, &c. (TA.)
See minoTabN.
minoTabN and minoTabapN and naATibN↓ A strainer; a colander. (Ḳ.)
manoTabapN Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (Ḳ:) an epithet applied to a man. (TA.)
1. naTaHahu, aor. _i {yanoTiHu} and _a {yanoTaHu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naToHN, (Ṣ,) He (a ram, Ṣ, L, and the like, L) smote him with his horn. (Ḳ.)

maA naTaHato fiyhi jam-aMCa caAtu qaronK [A horned animal did not smite with its horn for him a hornless ewe]: a proverb, said of him who has perished unavenged. (L.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 507.]
naTaHahu Eanohu ‡ He pushed him, or thrust him, away from him, and removed him. (A.)
3. naATaHaA, inf. n. niTaAHN (L, Mṣb) and munaATaHapN, (Mṣb,) They two (rams or he-goats) smote each other with their horns. (L.)
bayonahumaA niTaAHN ‡ [Between them two is a contention like that of two rams]; said of two learned men, and of two merchants. (A.)
jaraI lanaA fiI Als-uwqi niTaAHN ‡ [There happened to us in the market a contention like that of two rams]. (A.)
[naATaHahu He, or it, faced, or was or came opposite to him, or it]: niTaAHN is syn. with muqaAbalapN in the dial. of El-Ḥijáz. (TA.)
6: see 8.
tanaATaHati AlOamowaAju, and Als-uyuwlu, ‡ [The waves, and the torrents, conflicted, or dashed together.] (A.)
8. AntTHti AlkibaAXu, and tnATHt↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) The rams smote one another with their horns. (Ḳ.)

laA yanoTiHu fiyhaA EanozaAni [Two she-goats will not, in it, smite each other with their horns]: i. e., two weak persons will not encounter each other in it: alluding to a case in which there will not happen any discord or contention. (L, from a trad.)
naTuwHN: see naT-aAHN.
naTiyHN Smitten with the horn and so killed: fem. with p {naTiyHapN}: (L, Ḳ:) pl. naToHaI (L) and naTaAYiHu: (Lḥ, L:) you say also naEojapN naTiyHN, as well as nTyHp. (L.)

Also naTiyHapN A sheep or goat (Az) smitten with the horn and so killed. (Az, Ṣ,) and of which the flesh is therefore unlawful to be eaten: (Az:) the p is added because it is made a subst., not an epithet: (Az:) or because the quality of a subst. predominates in it, as in the case of fariysapN and OakiylapN and ramiy-apN. (Ṣ.)

naTiyHN and naATiHN↓ ‡ What comes to thee from before thee, (or faces thee, L,) of birds and wild animals (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) &c., which one rouses by throwing a stone or by crying out, and from the course of which one augurs evil or good: (L:) contr. of qaEiydN. (Ṣ.) [The nTyH or nATH↓ is of evil omen.]
Hence, (TA,) naTiyHN ‡ An unfortunate, or unlucky, man. (Ḳ.)

naTiyHN A horse having a blaze, or white mark on his face, extending to one of his ears, which is deemed unlucky: (L:) or a horse having on his forehead two circular or spiral curls of hair (daAYirataAni), which are disliked: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) if there be but one, it is called daAYirapu All-aTaApi; and this is not disliked; (Ṣ;) or it is called laTomapN; and the horse, laTiymN. (L.)

kaboXN naT-aAHN [A ram that smites much with his horn]: (Ṣ:) and naTuwHN↓ [signifies the same: and] is applied to a man [app. as meaning who pushes, thrusts, or repels, much, or vehemently]. (IAạr, TA in art. rds.)
daAYirapu Aln-aATiHi A certain circular or spiral curl of hair on a horse, which is deemed unlucky. (L.) [See naTiyHN.]

naATiHN ‡ A difficulty; a distressing event; an affliction; a calamity: pl. nawaATiHu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. OaSaAbahu naATiHN A difficulty, or distressing event, befell him. (Ṣ.) nawaATiHu Ald-ahori The difficulties, &c., of fortune. (Ṣ.)

Aln-aToHu waAln-aATiHu ‡ [The two stars called] AlX-araTaAni, [q. v.,] which are [the two stars in] the two horns of Aries: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [the first of the Mansions of the Moon: the latter is b, and the former a:] ISd says, that Aln-aToHu↓ is a star which is one of the Mansions of the Moon, and from [the auroral rising of] which one augurs evil: and IAạr says, that one says, naToHN and Aln-aToHu, without and with Al; and the like in the case of the name of any of the Mansions of the Moon. (TA.) The Arabs said UicaA TalaEa Aln-aToHu TaAba Als-aToHu ‡ [When En-Nat-h rises aurorally, the house-top becomes pleasant as a place on which to sit in the evening, or on which to sleep]. (A.)
maA lahu naATiHN walaA xaAbiTN He has neither sheep, or goat, nor camel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. naTara, (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yanoTuru}, (TA,) inf. n. naTorN (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and niTaArapN, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) He kept, or watched, vines, (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and palmtrees, (Ḳ,) and seed-produce. (TA.) See naTorapN and naATuwrN.
naTorapN, with the unpointed T, signifies The act of guarding, or watching with the eyes: and hence the word naATuwrN↓. (IAạr, Mṣb, TA.)

naToruwnN, with fet-ḥ, [Natron;] the Armenian baworaq, or buwraq; (thus differently written here in different copies of the Ḳ;) or [rather] the Egyptian buwraq: (Ḳ, art. brq:) the best kind [of bwrq] is the Armenian, which is soft, or fragile, light, and white: then the rose-coloured: and the strongest is the Ifreekee: there is a kind found in Egypt, in two places: one of these is in the western part of the country, in the neighbourhood of a district called Et-Tarráneh; and it is transparent, green and red; the green being the more in request; the other is in [the district called] El-Fákooseeyeh; and this is not so good as the former. (TA.) [See also baworaqN.]
nuT-aArN A scarecrow (xayaAlN) set up in the midst of seed-produce. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
naATirN: see naATuwrN.

naATuwrN A keeper, or watcher, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) of vines, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of palm-trees, (Ḳ,) and of seed-produce: (Mṣb, TA:) as also naATuwrapN↓ (El-Bári', Mṣb) and naATirN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. (of the first, TA) nawaATiyru (Az, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and (of the last, TA) niTaArN and nuTaraMCu and naTarapN: (Ḳ:) it is a foreign word, (OaEojamiI-N, Ḳ,) not pure Arabic, (TA,) of the dial. of the people of Es-Sawád: (Lth, Mṣb, TA:) Az says, I know not whether it be taken from the language of the people of Es-Sawád or be Arabic: (TA:) accord. to AḤn, it is Arabic: (TA:) and IAạr says, that it is from naTorapN, meaning as explained above: (Mṣb, TA:) IDrd says, that it is with Z, (A, Mṣb,) from Aln-aZaru; (A;) but in the language of the Nabatheans with T; (Mṣb;) that the Nabatheans change the former letter into T. (A.)
naATuwrapN: see naATuwrN.

1. naTisa, aor. _a {yanoTasu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naTasN, (Ṣ,) He was, or became, learned, or knowing, (Ḳ,) in affairs, and skilful therein: (TA:) or he exa mined things minutely, and attained the utmost knowledge of them. (Ṣ.)
4. maA OanoTasahu How intelligent and knowing is he in affairs! (TA.)

5. tnT-s He took extraordinary pains, or exceeded the usual bounds, in cleansing or purifying himself, or in removing himself far from unclean things or impurities: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or he shunned, or removed himself far from, unclean things: (M, A, Ḳ:) and he was dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice, and exact, syn. taOat-aqa, (Aṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) in cleanliness; (Ḳ;) and in speech, (A, Ḳ,) so as never to speak otherwise than chastely; (TA;) and in diet and apparel, (A, Ḳ,) so as never to eat or wear anything but what was clean, (A,) or so as never to eat anything but what was clean nor wear anything but what was good; (TA;) and in all affairs. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad. of ʼOmar, lawo laA Alt-anaT-asu maA baAlayotu Oal-aA Oagosila yadiI, (Ṣ, M,) i. e., Were it not for the being scrupulously nice and exact, I had not cared for my not washing my hand. (M.)
tnT-s fiyhi He examined it (anything) minutely. (A.)

tnT-s AlOaxobaAra, (Ṣ,) or Eani AlOaxobaAri, (M, A,) He searched, or sought, for, or after, news, or tidings; searched or inquired into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, news, or tidings. (Ṣ, M, A.)
naTosN: see naTisN, in two places.
naTusN: see naTisN, in four places.

naTisN Learned, or knowing; (A, Ḳ;) as also naTusN↓ (Ḳ) and naTosN↓ (A, Ḳ) and niTaAsiI-N↓ and naTaAsiI-N↓: (Ḳ:) or learned, or knowing, in affairs, and skilful therein: as also naTusN↓ and naTosN↓: (ISk, TA:) intelligent, or skilful, and scrupulously nice and exact (mutanaw-iqN), in affairs: (A:) or one who examines things minutely, and attains the utmost knowledge of them: as also naTusN↓ and mutanaT-isN↓: (Ṣ:) or learned, or knowing, in affairs: skilful in physic, &c.: as also naTusN↓ and niT-iysN↓ and niTaAsiI-N↓: (M:) or niT-ysN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA) and niTaAsiI-N↓ (Ṣ, TA) and naTaAsiI-N↓, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) a student of physic, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) who examines it minutely; (TA;) or learned, or knowing, in physic; in Greek nusoTaAs [γνώστης]: (A, TA:*) and mutanaT-isN↓ one who is dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact (mutanaw-iqN), and who chooses or selects [what is best]; (IAạr;) or any one who takes extraordinary pains, or exceeds the usual bounds, in a thing: (M:) also naTiysN↓, [without teshdeed,] a skilful man: (TA:) and nuTusN↓, [pl. of naTisN or naTusN or naTosN,] skilful physicians. (A, Ḳ.)

Also, One who shuns, or removes himself far from, unclean things; (Ḳ, TA;) who is scrupulously nice and exact (mutaOan-iqN) in affairs: (TA:) and naTisapN a woman who shuns, or removes herself far from, foul, evil, or unseemly, things: (AA, TA.) and nuTusN, [pl. of naTisN,] men who do thus: (Ḳ, TA:) and nuTasapN↓ a man who shuns much, or removes himself very far from, unclean things, and is very dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact (kaviyru Alt-Oan-uqi) in cleanliness, and in speech, and in diet and apparel, and in all affairs. (Ḳ,* TA.) See 5.
nuTusN: see naTisN, throughout.
nuTasapN: see naTisN, throughout.
naTiysN: see naTisN, throughout.
niTaAsiI-N and naTaAsiI-N: see naTisN, throughout.
niT-iysN: see naTisN, throughout.

naATisN, (accord. to one copy of the Ṣ, and the L, and the CK, and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) or naATuwsN↓, (accord. to the TA. as from the Ḳ,) or both, (accord. to one copy of the Ṣ,) A spy, who searches for news, or tidings, and then brings them. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, TA.)
naATuwsN: see naATsN.
mutanaT-isN: see naTisN, in two places.
naToXaAnu an imitative sequent to EaToXaAnu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) not used alone. (Ṣ, art. ETX.)

hom.sense:
1. naZara Uilayohi, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and naZarahu, (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoZuru}, (M, A, &c.,) and OanoTuwrN is substituted for OanoZuru in the dial. of certain Arabs, (IDrd, TṢ, Ḳ,) or, accord. to Lb, in the Bughyetel-Ámál, the w is here added only [by poetic license,] to make the sound of the ḍammeh full, agreeably with other instances; (TA;) and naZira Uilayohi, and naZirahu, aor. _a {yanoZaru}, (A, Ḳ,) the verb being like samiEa accord. to the correct copies of the Ḳ, [and so in the A,] but in one copy of the Ḳ, like Daraba; (TA;) inf. n. naZarN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and naZorN is allowable, as a contraction of the former, (Lth,) and naZaraAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and manoZarN (M, A, Ḳ) and manoZarapN and tanoZArN, (M, Ḳ,) [which last is an intensive form; He looked at, or towards, in order to see, him, or it;] he considered, or viewed, him or it with his eye; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) with the sight of the eye; (Mṣb;) [i. e. looked at him or it;] as also tnZ-rhu↓: (Ḳ:) and AntZrhu↓ signifies the same as tnZ-rhu and naZarahu [but app. in another sense, to be mentioned below, and not in the sense explained above, though the latter is implied in the TA; and the same may be meant when it is said that tnZ-r↓ is syn. with naZara, if this assertion, which I find in the M, have been copied without consideration, and be not confirmed by an example]: (TA:)
or naZara Uilayohi signifies he extended, or stretched, or raised, [or directed,] his sight towards him or it, whether he saw him or did not see him. (TA.) The usage of Aln-aZarN as relating to the sight is most common with the vulgar, but not with persons of distinction, who use it more in another sense, to be explained below. (TA.) You say, naZara Uilayohi naZorapF HulowapF [He looked at him, or towards him, with one sweet look.] (A.) And naZara fiI AlminoZaAri [He looked in the mirror]. (A.) And naZara fiI AlkitaAbi [He looked into, or inspected, the writing or book], (A, Mṣb,) which is for naZara Almakotuwba fiI AlkitaAbi [he looked at what was written in the writing or book], or has a different meaning to be explained below. (Mṣb.) And huwa yanoZuru Hawolahu [lit., He looks around him; meaning,] he looks much. (A.) [See also naZarN below.]
naZarati AlOaroDu, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) and naZarati AlOaroDu biEayonK, and biEayonayoni, (A,) ‡ The earth, or land, showed (A, Ṣgh, Ḳ) to the eye (Ṣgh, Ḳ) its plants or herbage. (A, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

naZara Uilayohi ‡ It looked towards, meaning faced, him or it. So in the Ḳur, [vii. 197,] wataraAhumo yanoZuruwna Uilayoka wahumo laA yuboSiruwna ‡ Thou seest them look towards thee, i. e., face thee, but they see not; referring to idols, accord. to AʼObeyd. (TA.) And you say, daAriI yanoZuru UilaI daAri fulaAnK ‡ My house faces the house of such a one. (Ṣ.) And naZara Uilayoka Aljabalu ‡ The mountain faced thee: (A:) as in the following ex.: UicaA Oaxacota fiI Tariyqi kacaA fanaZara Uilayoka Aljabalu faxuco Eano yamiynihi OawoyasaArihi ‡ [When thou takest such a road, and the mountain faces thee, then take thou the way by the right of it or the left of it.] (Ṣ.)

[Hence, perhaps,] naZara Ald-ahoru UilaI baniI fulaAnK faOaholakahumo [app. meaning, † Fortune opposed the sons of such a one and destroyed them]: (Ṣ [immediately following there the ex. which immediately precedes it here:]) or naZara Uilayohimu Ald-ahoru signifies ‡ Fortune destroyed them: (M, A:) but (says ISd) I am not certain of this. (M.)

Aln-aZaru also signifies † The turning the mind in various directions in order to perceive a thing [mentally], and the seeing a thing: and sometimes it means † the considering and investigating: [and as a subst., speculation, or intellectual examination:] and sometimes, † the knowledge that results from [speculation or] investigation. (El-Basáïr.) It is mostly used as relating to the intellect by persons of distinction; and as relating to the sight, most commonly by the vulgar. (TA.) [It is said that] when you say naZarotu Uilayohi, it means only [I looked at, or towards, him or it] with the eye: but when you say naZarotu fiI AlOamori, it may mean [† I looked into, inspected, examined, or investigated, the thing or affair] by thought and consideration, intellectually, or with the mind: (TA:) [this remark, however, is not altogether correct, as may be seen from what follows: the truth seems to be, that naZarahu and naZaraUilayohi may be used in the latter of these two senses, though naZara fiyhi is most common in this sense.] It is said in the Ḳur, [x. 101,] quli QnoZuruwA maA caA fiI Als-amewaAti † Say, Consider ye what is in the heavens. (TA.) And you say, naZara Uilayohi He saw it, and † thought upon it, and endeavoured to understand it, or to know its result. (TA.) [And He looked to it, or at it, or examined it, intellectually; regarded it; had a view to it.] And naZara fiyhi † He considered it: (TA:) or thought upon it; namely a writing or book; or when such is the object it may have another meaning, explained before; and an affair: and with this is held to accord the saying wafiyhi naZarN, q. v. infrà, voce naZarN: (Mṣb:) and ‡ he though upon it, measuring it, or comparing it. (M, Ḳ, TḲ. In the M and Ḳ, only the inf. n., naZara fiI OamowaAli AlOayotaAmi, of the verb in this sense is mentioned.) And fanaTara naZorapF fiI Aln-ujuwmi † He considered, or examined, [or estimated,] the possessions of the orphans, in order to know them. (Mṣb.) And similar to this is the phrase [in the Ḳur, xxxvii. 86,] Aln-aZaru, meaning, † And he examined the science of the stars: (Mṣb:) [or he took a mental view of the stars, as if to divine from them.] AlAiEotibaAru when used unrestrictedly by those who treat of scholastic theology means AlAiEotibaAru [† The thinking upon a thing, and endeavouring to understand it, or to know its result; or judging of what is hidden from what is apparent; or reasoning from analogy]. (MF.)
naZara bayonahumo, inf. n. naZarN, [app. for naZara fiI maA bayonahumo,] † He judged between them. (Ḳ.)
naZarato, (TA,) inf. n. naZarN, † She practised divination; (Ḳ,* TA;) which is a kind of examination with insight and skill. (TA, from a trad.)
OunoZuro liI fulaAnFA ‡ [look thou out for such a one for me;] seek thou for me such a one. (A, TA.)
OunoZuroniI † Listen thou to me. (M, Ḳ, TA [in the CK, erroneously, OunoTironiI.]) The verb [says ISd] has this meaning in the Ḳur, ii. 98. (M.)
OanaA OanoZuru UilaI Qll-ehi vum-a Uilayoka [lit., I look to God, then to thee; meaning,] ‡ I look for the bounty of God, then for thy bounty. (A.)

naZara Qll-ehu Uilayohi ‡ God chose him, and compassionated him, pitied him, or regarded him with mercy; because looking at another is indicative of love, and not doing so is indicative of hatred: (IAth:) or † God bestowed benefits upon him; poured blessings, or favours, upon him: (El-Basáïr:) and naZara lahumo ‡ he compassionated them, and aided them; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) and simply, he aided them: (Ḳ,* TA:) and naZara lahu † he accomplished his want, or that which he (another) wanted. (Mṣb.)
naZarahu is also syn. with UitonaZarahu↓, q. v.
Also syn. with OanoZarahu, q. v.

Also naZarahu, (Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. naZorN; (TA;) or naZ-arahu↓; (so in a copy of the M, and in the CK; but from the mention of the inf. n. in the TA, the former seems to be the right reading;) He sold it (a thing, M) with postponement of the payment; he sold it upon credit. (M,* Ḳ,* TA.) See also 4.
[In these last three acceptations, accord. to the A, the verb is used properly, not tropically.]

nuZira He was, or became, affected by what is termed a naZorap; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e., a stroke of an [evil] eye; (TA;) [or of an evil eye cast by a jinnee;] or a touch, or slight taint of insanity, from the jinn; (Ḳ;) or a swoon. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, last signification but one.
nZ-r fiyhi [He said of it fiyhi naZarN, q. v.]. (TA passim.)

3. naAZarahu fiI OamorK, inf. n. munaAZarapN, (T, Ṣ,*) ‡ He considered, or examined, or investigated, with him a thing or an affair, to see how they should do it: (T, TA:) he investigated, or examined, with him a thing, and emulated him, or vied with him, in doing so, each of them adducing his opinion: (TA:) [he held a discussion with him respecting a thing:] or naAZarahu is syn. with jaAdalahu: (Mṣb:) or mnAZrp signifies the examining mentally, or investigating, by two parties, the relation between two things, in order to evince the truth; (KT; and Kull, p. 342;) and sometimes with one's self; but mjAdlp signifies the disputing respecting a question of science for the purpose of convincing the opponent, whether what he says be wrong in itself or not. (Kull.)
Also nAZrhu [‡ He, or it, looked towards, or faced, him, or it; was opposite, or corresponded, to him or it. (See naZiyrN.)]
‡ He was, or became, like him: (A, Ḳ:) or like him in discourse or dialogue. (TA.)
jayoXN yunaAZiru OalofFA ‡ An army that is nearly equal to a thousand. (A.)

naAZara fulaAnFA bifulaAnK ‡ He made, or called, such a one like such a one. (Ḳ.) Hence the saying of Ez-Zuhree, (Ḳ,) Moḥammad Ibn-Shiháb, (TA,) laA tunaAZiro bikitaAbi Qll-ehi walaA bikalaAmi rasuwli Qll-ehi, i. e., Thou shalt not call anything like the book of God, nor like the words of the apostle of God: (AʼObeyd, T, Ḳ:) or thou shalt not compare anything, nor call anything like, to the book of God,, &c.: (A,) or thou shalt not apply [aught of] the book of God, nor the words of the apostle of God, as a proverb to a thing that happens: (AʼObeyd, T, Ḳ; in which last, we read liXaIoCK ligaraDK, in the place of the right reading, liXaIoCK yaEoriDu: TA:) for, as Ibráheem En-Nakha'ee says, they used to dislike the mentioning a verse of the Ḳur-án on the occasion of anything happening, of worldly events; (T;) as a person's saying to one who has come at a time desired by the former, (TA,) or to one named Moosà, who has come at a time desired, (Ḳ,) jiYota EalaI qadarK yaA muwsaI [Thou hast come at a time appointed, O Moosà: (Ḳur, xx. 42:)] (T, Ḳ:) and the like: (T:) but the first explanation is the most probable (TA, as from Az; but I do not find it in the T)

hom.sense: 4. OunoZira bihi ‡ [He, or it, was made like]. You say, maA kaAna hecaA naZiyrFA lihecaA walaqado OunoZira bihi ‡ [This was not like this, but has been made like]. (T, Ḳ:) like as you say, maA kaAna xaZiyrFA lahu walaqado OuxoTira bihi. (T.)

AnZrhu He postponed him; delayed him: (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) he granted him a delay or respite; let him alone, or left him, for a while: (T, TA:) as, for instance, a debtor, (T, Mṣb, TA,) and a man in difficult circumstances: (TA:) and naZarahu↓ signifies the same. (Mṣb.) You say, biEotuhu XayoYFA faOanoZarotuhu I sold to him a thing, and granted him a delay. (T.) And a person speaking says to him who hurries him, OanoZironI OabotaliEo riyqiI Grant me time to swallow my spittle. (T.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xv. 36 and xxxviii. 80,] faOanoZironiI UilaI yawomi yuboEavuwna Then delay me until the day when they shall be raised from the dead. (TA.) See also 8.
He sold to him a thing with postponement of the payment; he sold to him a thing upon credit. (M.) See also 1 last signification but one.
5: see 1, first signification.
See also 8.

entry.sense: 6. tnAZrA ‡ They faced each other. (Ḳ.) You say, tnAZrt Ald-aAraAni ‡ The two houses faced each other. (M.) And duwrunaA tanaAZaru, (Ṣ,) or tatanaAZaru, [which is the original form,] (A,) ‡ Our houses faced one another. (Ṣ, A.)
See also taraAwaDaA.

hom.sense: 8. AntZrh: see 1, first sentence.

He looked for him; expected him; awaited him; waited for him; watched for his presence; syn. Airotaqaba HuDuwrahu; (TA;) and taOan-aI Ealayohi; (M, Ḳ;) and naZarahu↓ (aor. _u {yanoZuru} T, &c., inf. n. naZarN Ṣ, Ḳ) signifies the same; (T, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so tnZr-hu↓, (M, A, Ḳ,) and OanoZarahu↓; (Zj, TA;) [but respecting the last two, see what is said below:] but when you say AntZr without any objective complement, the meaning is, [he waited; or] he paused, and acted or behaved with deliberation, or in a patient, or leisurely, manner. (Lth, T.) It is said in the Ḳur, [lvii. 13,] AunoZuruwnaA naqotbiso mino nuwrikumo Wait for us (AinotaZiruwnaA) that me may take of your light: and accord. to Zj, OanoZiruwnaA [which is another reading] is said to mean the same: or the latter means delay us: accord. to Fr, however, the Arabs say OanoZironiI meaning Wait thou for me (AinotaZironiI) a little, (T.) Alt-anaZ-uru↓ also signifies The expecting, or waiting for a thing: (TA:) or the expecting, or waiting for, a thing expected: (M, Ḳ, TA:) or tnZ-rhu↓ signifies he expected, or waited for, (AntZr,) him, or it, leisurely, and so AstnZrhu↓. (Ṣ.) You say also, AntZr bihi xayorFA Oawo Xar-aA (M, A, Ḳ, in art. rbS, in the last of which is added yaHul-N bihi) [He looked for expected, awaited, or waited for, something good or evil to befall him, or betide him]

entry.sense: 10. AstnZrhu: see 8, last signification but one.
He asked of him, or desired of him, a postponement, or delay. (M, A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: niZorN: see naZiyrN.

A man says to another, bayoEN, [or perhaps biyEN, like the word used in reply to it. here following and like xiTobN and nikoHN meaning, I sell,] and the other says, niZorN, meaning, Grant me a delay (OanoZironiI) that I may buy (OaXotariI) of thee. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: naZarN: see 1. [Used as a subst., as well as when used as an inf. n.,] it has no pl. (Sb, in TA, voce fikorN.)
DarabonaAhumo binaZar, and mino naZari, ‡ We saw them. (A, TA.)
bayonanaA naZarN ‡ Between us is the extent of a look in expect of nearness. (A, TA.)
HaI-N naZarN, (Ḳ,* TA,) and HaI-N jilaAlN wanaZarN, (Ṣ,) and HaI-N HilaAlN wariyaMCN wanaZarN, (A,) ‡ A tribe went together, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,*) of which the several portions see one another. (Ṣ, A.)

wafiyhi naZarN † But it requires consideration, by reason of its want of clearness, or perspicuity: (Mṣb:) [a phrase used to imply doubt, and also to insinuate politely that the words to which it relates are false, or wrong:] like fiyhi taOam-ulN. (MF, art. SfH.)

huwa bixayori Aln-aZaryoni, said in a trad., of one who has purchased a ewe or she-goat that has been kept from being milked for some days; meaning, † He has the option of adopting the better of the two things; he may either retain it or return it. (TA.)

naZorapN A look: a quick look or glance: (T:) pl. naZaraAtN. (A.) Hence the trad., laA tutobiEi Aln-aTorapa Aln-aZorapa faUin-a laka AlOuwolaI walayosato laka AlMxirapu [Thou shalt not make a look to follow a look; for the former is thine or right, lad the latter is not thine: i. e., when thou hast once looked at anything forbidden, unintentionally, thou shalt not look at it a second time]. (T, TA.) And the saying of a certain wise man, mano lamo taEomalo naZoratuhu lamo yaEomalo lisaAnuhu [He whose look does not produce an effect, his tongue does not produce an effect]; (T;) meaning, that he who is not restrained from a fault or offence by being looked at is not restrained by speech. (TA.)

A stroke of an [evil] eye: (TA:) a stroke of an [evil] eye by which one is affected from the jinn's looking at him; (T, Ṣ;*) as also safoEapN: (T;) or a touch, or a slight taint or infection of insanity. (TaAYifN,) from the jinn: or a swoon. (M, Ḳ.)
An alteration of the body or complexion by emaciation or hunger or travel, &c. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
Foulness; ugliness: (AA, TA:) evilness; or badness, of form or appearance; a fault: a defect; an imperfection. (M, Ḳ.)
† Reverence, veneration, awe, or fear, (IAạr, T, Ḳ,)
‡ Compassion, pity, merry. (IAạr, T, Ḳ,)

naZirapN A postponement; a delay. (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur. [ii. 280.] fanaZrapN UilaI mayosarapK [Then let there be a postponement, or delay, until he shall be in an easy state of circumstances]; (T, M, Mṣb) a. c., faUinoZaArN, (T,) or fataOoxiyrN: (Mṣb) and accord. to another reading, fanaAZirapN↓, like kaAcibapN, in the Ḳur, lvi. 2. (M.) You say also, baAEa minohu AlX-aIoCa binaZirapK He sold to him the thing with postponement of the payment, he sold to him the thing upon credit. (M.) And AiXotarayotuhu minohu binaZirapK, and biUinoZaArK, I bought a of him with postponement of the payment; I bought a of him upon credit. (T.)

naZariI-N † [Speculative knowledge or science; such as is acquired by study;] that of which the origination rests upon speculation. and acquisition by study; as the conception of the intellect or mind, and the assent of the mind or the position, that the world has had a beginning. (Ḳ, T.) [It is opposed to badiyhiIN and to SrwriI-N.]
sumoEun-apN nuZorun-apN, and vars. thereof: see in art. smE.
naZaAri, like qaTaAmi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) an imp. n., (T.) meaning, Wait thou: syn UinotaZiro. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

naZuwrN and naZuwrapN↓ and naAZuwrapN↓ and nuZiyrapN↓ A chief person, whether male or female, to whom one looks. (M, Ḳ.) You say, fulaAnN naZiyrapN↓ qawomihi, and naZuwrapu↓ qawomihi, Such a one is the person to whom his people look, (Fr, T, Ṣ,) and whom they imitate, or to whose example they conform. (Fr, T.) All these words are also used in a pl. sense: (M, Ḳ:) or [so in some copies of the Ḳ; but in others, and,] nZyrp and nZwrp have naZaAYiru for their pl., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) sometimes. (Ḳ.)
Also, naZuwrN A man who neglects not to look at, (M, L, Ḳ,) or to consider, (A,) that which, (M, A, L,) or him who, (Ḳ,) disquiets him, or renders him solicitous. (M, A, L, Ḳ.)

naZiyrN ‡ Looking to, or facing, another person or thing; opposite or corresponding to another person or thing; as also munaAZirN↓; syn. muqaAbilN. (A.) [Hence, naZiyru Als-amoti, and Aln-aZiyru, ‡ The nadir; the point opposite to the zenith.] naZiyruka signifies Oal-aciI yunaAZiruka, (M,) or AlcI tunaAZiruhu wayunaAZiruka, (T,) [which I suppose to mean ‡ He who looks towards, or faces, thee; who is opposite, or corresponds, to thee; or he towards whom thou lookest,, &c., and who looks towards thee,, &c.: though susceptible of other interpretations: see 3.]

‡ Like; a like; a similar person or thing: (AO, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) equal; an equal: (Mṣb:) applied to anything: (TA:) as also niZorN↓; (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ;) like nadiydN and nid-N; (AO, Ṣ;) and munaAZirN↓: (Ḳ:) fem. naZiyrapN: (T, M, A:) pl. masc., nuZaraMCu: (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and pl. fem. naZaAYiru, (T, A,) applied to words and to all things. (T.) You say, fulaAnN naZiyruka ‡ Such a one is thy like. (T.) And hecaA naZiyrN lihecaA, (T,) or naZiyru hecaA, (Mṣb,) ‡ This is the like of this, (T,) or the equal of this. (Mṣb.) And Eadadotu Uibila fulaAnK naZaAYira ‡ I counted, or numbered, the camels of such a one in pairs, or two by two; (Aṣ, T, Ḳ;*) if by looking at their aggregate, you say, EadadotuhaA jamaArFA. (Aṣ, T.)
naZuwrapN: see naZuwrN, in two places.
See also naZiyrapN.
naZiyrapN: see naZuwrN, in two places.
Also, A scout, or scouts; (T, Ṣgh, Ḳ;) and so naZuwrapN↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) pl. of both, naZaAYiru. (TA.)
Fem. of naZiyrN, q. v. (T, &c.). [And hence,] Aln-aZaAYiru [the pl.] The more excellent of men: (Ḳ,* TA:) because they resemble one another in dispositions and actions and sayings. (TA.)
naZ-aArN ‡ A horse (A, Ḳ) that raises his eye by reason of his sharpness of spirit: (A:) or sharpspirited, and raising his eye. (T, Ḳ.)
naZ-aArapN A people looking at a thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also manoZarapN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also minoZaArN.

hom.sense: naAZirN act. part. n. of naZara; Looking;, &c.: pl. nuZ-aArN. (Mṣb.)

Aln-aAZiru [The pupil, or apple, of the eye,] the smallest black of the eye, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) in which is [seen] what is termed UinosaAnu AlEayoni, (Ṣ,) [and] with which the man sees; (Mṣb;) the black spot in the eye; (M, Ḳ;) the clear black spot that is in the middle of the [main] black of the eye, with which the looker sees what he sees: or that part of the eye which resembles a mirror, in which, when one faces it, he sees his person: (TA:) or a duct (Eiroq) in the nose, wherein is the water of sight: (M, Ḳ:) [app. a loose description of the optic nerve:] or the sight itself: (M, Ḳ:) or the eye: (Ḳ:) or the eye is called Aln-aAZirapu↓; (Ṣ, A;*) the pl. of which is nawaAZiru. (A.)

Xadiydu Aln-aAZiri, (so in a copy of the M and of the A and in some copies of the Ḳ,) or sadiydu Aln-aAZiri, (so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) A man clear of suspicion, who looks with a full gaze: (M, Ḳ:) or clear of that with which he is upbraided. (A.)
Aln-aAZiraAni Two veins at the two edges of the nose, commencing from the inner angles of the eyes, towards the face. (Zj, in his Khalk el-Insán.)
Also, naAZirN † A guardian; a keeper; a watcher: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) and, as also naAZuwrN↓, i. q. naATuwrN, (Ḳ, TA,) [which last is] a word of the Nabathean dialect. (TA.)
[The dim. is nuwayoZirN.] You say, EuyayonatiI nuwayoZirapN UilaI Qll-ehi vum-a Uilayokumo ‡ My eye (lit. my little eye) is looking to God for His bounty, then to you for your bounty. (A.)

In the Ḳur, [lxxv. 23,] the words UilaI rab-ihaA naAZirapN have been explained as signifying Waiting for (munotaZirapN) their Lord: but this is a mistake; for the Arabs do not say naTarotu UilaI AlX-aIoCi in the sense of UinotaZarotuhu, but they say naZarotu fulaAnFA in that sense. (T.)
naAZirapN: see naAZirN.
See also naZirapN.

entry.sense: naAZuwrN: see naAZirN.
naAZuwrapN: see naZuwrN.
OanoZuwru for OanoZuru: see 1.

manoZarN [A place in which a thing is looked at]: a place, or state, in which one likes to be looked at. (T, A, TA.) You say, fulaAnN fiI manoZarK wamasomaEK wafiI riI-K wmaXobaEK ‡ Such a one is in a state in which he likes to be looked at and listened to [and in a state in which he is satisfied with drink and food]. (T, A, TA.) And laqado kunota Eano hecaA AlmaqaAmi bimanoZarK ‡ Thou wast in a state [in] which thou likedst [to be looked at], away from this place of abode. (T, TA.)

The aspect, or outward appearance, of a thing; opposite of maxobarN: (Ṣ, art. xbr:) [when used absolutely, a pleasing, or goodly, aspect; or beauty of aspect; as also manoZarapN↓: this is implied by the usage of manoZaraAniI-N, q. v., and is well known:] or what one looks at and is pleased by or displeased by; as also manoZarapN↓: (M, Ḳ:) or the former, a thing that pleases and rejoices the beholder when he looks at it: (T:) and ↓the latter, the aspect (manoZar) of a man when one looks at it and is pleased by it or displeased by it. (T, TA.*) You say, lahu manoZarN HasanN [He has a goodly aspect]. (A.) And AimoraOapN Hasanapu AlmanoZari, and AlmanoZarapi↓, [A woman goodly of aspect.] (Ṣ.) And manoZaruhu xayorN mino maxobarihi [His aspect is better than his internal state]. (Ṣ.) And Uin-ahu lacuw manoZarK bilaA maxobarK, (T,) and cuw manoZarapK↓ bilaA maxobarapK, (A,) [Verily he has a pleasing aspect without a pleasing internal state.]

manoZarapN A high place on which a person is stationed to watch; (Ṣ;) a place on the top of a mountain, where a person observes and watches the enemy: (T:) and manaAZiru [the pl.] eminences; or elevated parts of the earth; or high grounds: (M, Ḳ:) because one looks from them. (M.)

Its application to A certain separate place of a house, [generally an apartment on the groundfloor overlooking the court, and also a turret, or rather a belvedere, and any building, or apartment, commanding a view,] is vulgar. (TA.)
See also naZ-aArapN.
And see manoZarN, in five places.
manoZariI-N: see what next follows.

manoZaraAniI-N (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and manoZariI-N↓, (M, Ḳ,) the latter contr. to analogy, (M,) A man (M,) of goodly aspect. (M, Ḳ.) You say, rajulN manoZaraAniI-N maxobaraAniI-N [A man of goodly aspect and of pleasing internal, or intrinsic, qualities]; (Ṣ, A;) i. e., cuw manoZarK and cuw maxobarK. (TA, art. xbr.)
minoZaArN A mirror (A, Ḳ) in which the face is seen. (TA.)
Also, A telescope; a thing in which what is distant is seen [as though it were] near: vulgarly, naZ-aArapN↓. (TA.)

manoZuwrN A man looked at with an evil eye: (A, TA;) affected by what is termed a naZorap; (T, TA;) i. e., a stroke of an [evil] eye; [or of an evil eye cast by a jinnee; or a touch, or slight taint of insanity, from the jinn;] or a swoon. (TA.)
A person, (T,) or chief person, (A,) whose bounty is hoped for, (T, A,) and at whom eyes glance. (A.)
manoZuwrapN A woman in whom is a naZorap, meaning, a fault, defect, or imperfection. (Ḳ,* TA.)
munaAZirN: see naZiyrN.

1. naEaba, aor. _a {yanoEabu} and _i {yanoEibu}, inf. n. naEobN and naEiybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuEaAbN (Ḳ) and naEabaAnN and tanoEaAbN (Ṣ, Ḳ) He (a raven, or crow, guraAb,) uttered a cry, cried out, or croaked: (Ṣ:) or uttered the cry, or croak, that is asserted to be ominous of separation: [but see below:] or moved about his head without crying: (Mṣb:) he (a raven, or crow, or other animal,) cried out: or stretched out his neck, and moved about his head, in crying out. (Ḳ.) The naEiyb of the raven, or crow, is said to be ominous of good; and its naEiyq, of evil. (Kifáyet el-Mutaḥaffiḍh.)
naEiybN also signifies † The neighing of a horse. (TA.)
naEaba Ald-iyku ‡ [The cock crowed] is sometimes said, metaphorically. (Ṣ.)
naEaba AlmuWac-inu ‡ The chanter of the call to prayer stretched out his neck, and moved about his head, in his cry. (A, L, Ḳ.)

naEaba, aor. _a {yanoEabu}, inf. n. naEobN, He (a camel, Ḳ) went with a quick pace: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, with a certain kind of pace; (Ḳ:) or he (a camel) moved about his head, in proceeding at a quick rate; like a buxotiI camel, raising his head: (TA:) or, inf. n. naEabaAnN, he stretched out his neck. (A.) Accord. to some, naEobN signifies The moving of a she-camel's head forwards in her march, or pace. [Ṣ, accord to an excellent copy, in which the original words are thus given: yuqaAlu Uin-a Aln-aEoba taHar-uku raOosihaA Alx: in another copy tuHar-ku raOosahaA; making naEob an epithet of a she-camel that so moves her head.]
4. AnEb † He (a man) cried out, or stretched out his neck and moved about his head, in disturbances, broils, or the like: syn. naEaba fiI Alfitani. (TA.)
riyHN naEobN A rapid wind. (Ḳ.)
naEuwbN: see naAEibapN.

naE-aAbN The young one of a raven, or crow: syn faroxu guraAbK: or a raven, or crow, [absolutely]: syn. EuraAbN. In a prayer of David occur the words yaA raAziq Aln-aE-aAbi fiI EuX-ihi [O Sustainer of the young raven (or young crow) in his nest!]. It is said that the young raven (or young crow), when it comes forth from its egg, is white, like a lump of fat, and that the old bird, on seeing it, dislikes and abandons it; that thereupon God sends to it gnats, which light upon it on account of its foul greasy smell, and that it lives upon them until it is fledged and becomes black, when its parents return to it. (L.)
naE-aAbapN: see naAEibapN.

naAEibapN (Ḳ) and naEuwbN↓ and naE-aAbapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and minoEabN↓ (so in the correct copies of the Ḳ: in the L, minoEabapN: accord. to MF, munoEibN: TA) A swift she-camel: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. of the first, and of [the masc. epithet] nawaAEibu, naAEibN and nuE-abN: and of nEwb, nuEubN. (TA.) [The last pl. is the only one mentioned in the Ṣ, Ḳ, which do not point out its proper sing.] See also naEobN in 1.

minoEabN An excellent, fleet horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that stretches out his neck like the raven, or crow: and (or accord. to some, TA) one that follows his own way, heedless of the bridle, [app., lowering his head, and stretching out his neck,] syn. AlcI yasoTuw biraOosihi, (Ḳ,) without any increase in the rate of his run. (TA.)
See naAEibapN.
A stupid, or foolish, and clamourous man. (Ḳ.)

1. naEata, aor. _a {yanoEatu}, inf. n. naEotN; and AntEt↓; He described, or characterized, or designated, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a thing; (Ṣ;) syn. waSafa: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he described a thing by mentioning what was in it, or what it possessed; whereas, in the waSof of a thing one may exaggerate: (L:) [he distinguished a person or a thing by an epithet: and hence, he qualified a substantive by an epithet: and he used a word as an epithet] or he described a thing by mentioning what was in it that was good, or goodly; not with reference to what was bad. or foul, or ugly; unless by a straining of the meaning one say naEotN sawoCN; whereas waSafa is said with respect to what is good, or goodly and what is bad, or foul, or ugly: (IAth:) or naEata signifies he described by mentioning the make, or form, or other outward characteristic, as tallness and shortness; and waSafa respects action, as beating: or, accord. to Th, naEata signifies he described by mentioning something in some particular place in the body, such as lameness; whereas waSafa is used with respect to what is common to the whole, as greatness, and generosity; therefore God is an object of waSof, but not of naEot. (TA.)
naEata nafosuh bAloHayori [He described himself as possessing, or characterized by, or distinguished by, goodness.] (Mṣb.)
naEata, aor _u, inf. n. naEaAtapN, He (a man) was naturally endowed with powers of description, and skilful in the use of those powers. (TA.)
naEut, aor. _u {yanoEutu}, inf. n. naEaAnapN, He (a horse) was, or became, what is termed naEotN, i. e., generous, or fleet, &c. (L, Ḳ.)

naEata, (L,) or naEita, of the same measure as fariHa, (Ḳ,) He (a horse) affected, or endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be, or become, what is termed naEotN, i. e., generous, or fleet, &c. (L, Ḳ.) MF remarks that naEita, in this sense, is strange, as faEila is not a measure denoting takal-uf. (TA.)
4. AnEt His face became beautiful, or goodly, so that he was described (Ḳ) as characterized by beauty, (TA,) [or, so that he became distinguished by an epithet].

8. AntEt He, or it, was, or became, described: (TA:) [he, or it, was, or became, distinguished by an epithet: he, or it, was, or became, characterized, or distinguished, by that which made him to excel others of his kind: see naEotN]. See 1.
10. AstnEthu He asked him to describe him, or it. (T, Ḳ.)

naEotN An epithet; or that whereby a person or thing is described: [hence, an epithet whereby a substantive is qualified:] (TA:) pl. nuEuwtN: it has no other pl. than this. (ISd.) [Respecting distinctions said to exist between naEotN and waSofN or SifapN, see 1.] [You say,] lahu nuEuwtN wamanaAEitu jamiylapN [He has goodly epithets applied to him, and goodly qualities, or properties. which are causes, or occasions, of epithets]. (A.)
[kanaEoti kacaA, a phrase similar to kamaval kacaA, meaning Like such a thing. See an ex. voce sab-E.]
naEotN Anything excellent. (TA.)

[Hence,] farasN naEotN, and munotaEitN↓, and naEotapN↓, [in the CK, naEotat,] and naEytN↓, and naEiytpN↓, A generous, or a fleet, or swift, horse, that excels in running, and outstrips others. (Ḳ.) [And so] munotaEitN↓ A beast of carriage, or a man, characterized, or distinguished, by that which makes him to excel others of his kind. a horse at scribed as distinguished by generousness, or by fleetness, or swiftness, and by outstripping others (TA.)
naEotapN: see naEotN.
Eaboduka nuEotapN, or Oamatuka nuEotapN, Thy male slave or thy female slave, is of the highest quality. (Ḳ.) But in the A it is said, Eabaduka naEotN, and Oamatuka naEotapN. (TA.)
naEiytN A generous, excellent, surpassing, man. (TA.) See also naEotN.
naEiytapN: see naEotN,
naAEitN Describing; a describer: pl. nuE-aAtN. (TA.)
manoEuwtN [A person or thing described; distinguished by an epithet: and hence, a substantive qualified by an epithet].
manoEuwtN biAlokarami [Described as possessing, or characterized by, or distinguished by, generosity; distinguished by the epithet of generous]. (A.)
munotaEitN: see naEotN.

hom.sense: 4. AnEv fiI maAlihi He was prodigal of his wealth: (Ḳ:) or he scattered it: or it signifies qad-ama fiyhi. (L.)
AnEv He set about, or commenced fitting himself out, or equipping himself for journeying. (Ḳ.)
humo fiI UinoEaAvK (in the CḲ, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, OanoEaAvK,) They have striven, laboured, or exerted themselves, in their affair. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1.

hom.sense: 1. naEaja, aor. _u {yanoEuju}, inf. n. naEajN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuEuwjN, (Ḳ,) a verb similar to TalabN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoEuju}, inf. n. TalabN; (Ṣ;) so in the handwriting of J; (IB;) or, with reference to a colour, naEija, aor. _a {yanoEaju}, inf. n. naEajN, a verb like Saxiba, aor. _a {yanoEaju}, inf. n. SaxabN: (accord-to an insertion in a copy of the Ṣ read to IB, TA, [and so in one of M. Fresnel's copies of the Ṣ, and in a copy in my possession, and so in the L, in which both forms of the verb are given,]) He, or it, [a colour,] was of a clear, or pure white. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

naEija, aor. _a {yanoEaju}, inf. n. naEajN, He (a man, Az, or a camel, Ṣ) became fat: (T, Ṣ, Ḳ:) said by AA to occur in a poem of Dhu-r-Rummeh, but not found in his poetry by Sh, who deems it strange: Az, however, confirms it by the authority of an Arab of the desert; and adds, that it signifies he (a man) became fat and in good condition: and he increased, and became swollen, or inflated: and nahija is said to signify the same. (TA.)
naEija, aor. _a {yanoEaju}, inf. n. naEajN, He (a man, Ṣ) became heavy in the stomach (Alqalob) from eating mutton. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naEajato fiI sayorihaA, (inf. n. naEojN, L.) She (a camel) was quick, or swift, in her pace: (Ṣ, L:) she went with a certain pace: (L:) a dial. form of maEajato. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 4. OanoEaja Alqawomu The people's camels became fat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: naEijN [and OanoEaju↓] Of a pure white colour: (L:) [pl. of the latter nuEojN].
nisaMCN nuEoju AlmaHaAjiri duEoju Aln-awaAZiri [Women of a clear white colour in the parts around the eyes; intensely black and wide, in the eyes]. (A.)
naEijN A man heavy in the stomach (Alqalob) from eating mutton: pl. naEijuwna. (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: naEojapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and niEojapN↓, accord. to a reading of El-Ḥasan, waliI niEojapN waAHidapN, [Ḳur, xxxviii. 22,] (TA,) A ewe; the female of the sheep: (L, Ḳ:) also, the female of the wild bull: and, of the gazelle: and, of the wild sheep: (TA:) [but see below:] pl. niEaAjN and naEajaAtN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

naEojapu Alr-amoli The [wild] cow: pl. niEaAju Alr-amoli: no other wild animal but the cow (accord. to AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) is thus called: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [but see above]. The Arabs speak of gazelles as though they were goats, terming the male tayosN; and of wild bulls or cows as though they were sheep, terming the female naEojapN. (AAF.)
Also naEojapN ‡ A woman; as likewise XaApN. (TA.)
niEojapN: see naEojapN.

hom.sense: naAEijN A camel of beautiful colour, and highly esteemed. (TA.) naAEijapN A she-camel of beautiful colour: (TA:) or a white she-camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of generous race: (TA:) a swift she-camel: a she-camel upon which one hunts wild cows: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) such is of the kind called mahoriy-apN: (IJ:) or one that is light, or active: (TA:) pl. nawaAEiju. (Ṣ.)
naAEijapN also A woman of beautiful complexion, or colour. (TA.)
OaroDN naAEijapN Plain, or even, land, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) fertile, and producing the kind of tree called rimov. (Aboo-Kheyreh.)

entry.sense: OanoEaju: see naEijN.
