1. naEara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanoEiru} (Ṣ, Ḳ) and _a {yanoEaru}, (Ḳ,) [in the Mṣb, _u, but this I suppose to be an error in transcription,] the first of which is the most common, (Ḳ,) or the most common when the verb relates to a vein, accord. to Fr, as cited by Ṣgh, (TA,) inf. n. naEiyrN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nuEaArN, (A, Ḳ,) or this latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and naEorapN, (A,) [or this also is a simple subst.,] He (a man, Ḳ, or a beast of carriage, Mṣb,) uttered a sound, or noise, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with, (A, Ḳ,) or in, (Ṣ,) his xayoXuwm [or the innermost part of his nose]: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) but Az, says, I have not heard this explanation from any of the leading authorities. (TA.)

Also, (TA,) inf. n. naEiyrN, (Ḳ,) He called out, or cried out vehemently, in war, or in some evil case. (Ḳ,* TA.) And naEarato, inf. n. naEiyrN, She (a woman) clamoured, and acted in a foul or immodest manner. (TA.)

naEara AlEiroqu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or naEara AlEiroqu biAld-ami, (A,) aor. _i {yanoEiru}, (Fr, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) and _a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more common, (Fr, Ṣgh,) inf. n. naEorN, (Ṣ, TA,) or naEiyrN and nuEaArN, (as app. implied in the Ḳ, but perhaps not intended to be so,) ‡ The vein gushed with blood: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, (aor. _a {yanoEaru}, inf. n. nuEuwrN and naEiyrN, TA,) made a sound by reason of the blood coming forth: (Ḳ:) or gushed with blood, and made a sound at the coming forth of the blood. (A.)
naEorapN A sound, or noise, in the xayoXuwm [or innermost part of the nose]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [as also nuEaArN↓. (See 1.)]
naEaraAtN [the pl.] is also applied to The call of the muWac-in. (Ṣ.)
nuEoraI: see naAEirN.
nuEaArN: see naEorapN.
naEuwrN: see naAEirN.
naE-aArN and naE-aArapN: see naAEirN.

naAEirN Uttering a sound or noise [with, or in, the xayoXuwm, or innermost part of the nose]. (Sh.) And naE-aArN↓ Clamorous: (Ḳ, TA:) p↓, applied to a woman, and signifying the same: (A:) or, so applied, it signifies clamorous and foul, or immodest: (Ḳ:) and UimoraOapN gayoraI naEoraI↓ a [very jealous] clamorous woman; (Ḳ;) in which phrase, nErI may not be regarded as fem. of naEoraAnu, because [epithets of the measures] faEolaAnu and faEolaI come from verbs of the class of fariHa; not from those of the class of manaEa [or that of Daraba]. (Az, Ḳ.)
[And so] naE-aArN↓ One who drives away the beasts and cries out after them. (TA, art. zgq.)
You say also, OaToratu bihecaA SawotFA naE-aArFA↓ [lit., I made a clamorous voice to fly with this; meaning,] ‡ I published this. (A.)

Also naAEirN ‡ A vein flowing with blood: (Sh:) [or gushing with blood;, &c. (See its verb, above.)] And naE-aArN↓ ‡ A vein gushing with blood; and so naEuwrN↓: (Ṣ:) that does not cease to flow with blood; as also naEuwrN↓ (TA) and naAEuwrN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) and naE-aArN↓ applied to a wound signifies the same; as also taE-aArN, with t and E, and tag-aArN↓, with t and g: (IAạr, Az:) and naEuwrN↓ applied to a wound signifies ‡ making a sound by reason of the vehemence with which the blood comes forth. (TA.)

naAEuwrN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) or naAEuwrapN↓, (Ḳ,) A [machine of the kind called] duwlaAb [q. v.], (A, Ḳ,) or manojanuwn [q. v.], (Mgh, Mṣb,) with which water is drawn [for irrigation], (Ṣ,) and which is turned by water, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) and makes a noise, or [creaking] sound by [its revolving]: (Ṣ:) so called because of its naEiyr [or sound]: (A, Mgh, Mṣb:) [app. also any rotary machine for raising water to irrigate land: see Niebuhr's ' Voyage en Arabie, ' tome i., p. 220 et seq.:] it is used on the banks of the Euphrates (A, TA) and the 'Ásee: (TA:) pl. nawaAEiyru. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.)
And the former, The wing (janaAH) of a mill or mill-stone. (Ḳ.)
Also naAEuwrapN↓ A bucket with which water is raised. (Ḳ.)
See also naAEirN.
naAEuwrapN: see naAEuwrN.

1. naEasa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoEusu}, (Ṣ, M, and so in a copy of the B by the author of the Ḳ,) or _a, (A, Ḳ,) [the latter being agreeable with analogy,] inf. n. nuEaAsN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,* TA,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) [He drowsed; he was, or became, drowsy, or heavy with sleepiness: or he slumbered, or dozed:] the inf. n. is syn. with wasanN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or nuEaAsN↓ signifies languor in the senses, (Ḳ, TA,) arising from the heaviness [which is the prevenient sign] of sleep: (TA:) or the beginning of sleep: (M, art. wsn:) or its proper signification is, accord. to Az, (Mṣb, TA,) wasanN (Mṣb) or sinapN (TA) without sleep: (Mṣb, TA,) or sinapN is in the head, and nuEaAsN is in the eye: or snp is the vapour (ryH) of sleep which begins in the face, then is transmitted to the heart, and you say, of a man, yanoEasu, and then, yanaAmu. (Mṣb, art. nwm.)
It is said in a proverb, maTolN kanuEaAsi Alkalobi [A delaying of the payment, of a debt, or the like, like the drowsing, or slumbering, of the dog:] i. e. continual: (Ṣ, TA:) for the dog is characterized by much nEAs, and, as is said in the B, is accustomed to open his eyes [only] sufficiently for the purpose of guarding, and this he does time after time. (TA.)
naEasa, (TḲ,) inf. n. naEosN, (IAạr, Ḳ,) † It (a man's judgment, and his body,) was soft, and weak. (IAạr, Ḳ, TḲ.)
† It (a market) was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (Ḳ, TA.)
4. AnEs † He begat heavy, sluggish, lazy, indolent, or torpid, sons. (AA, Ḳ.)
6. tnAEs He feigned himself [drowsing, or slumbering, or] sleeping. (Ḳ,* TA.)
‡ It (lightning) became faint. (A, TA.)

naEosapN [A single fit of drowsiness: or of slumber:] a single movement of the head in drowsing or slumbering. (TA.) You say, rakabatohu naEosapN XadiydapN [A vehement fit of drowsiness, or of slumber, came upon him]. (A.) And naEasotu naEosapF waAHidapF [I drowsed, or slumbered, once]. (Ṣ.)
naEosaAnN: see naAEisN.
nuEaAsN: see 1.

naEuwsN A she-camel bountiful in yielding milk; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) that drowses, or slumbers, in yielding milk; (A;) or because, in yielding milk, she drowses, or slumbers: (Ṣ:) or having much milk, that drowses, or slumbers, when milked: (M:) or that closes her eyelid on being milked. (Az, TA.)
naE-aAsapN: see naAEisN.

naAEisN, part. n. of naEasa, [Drowsing, drowsy, or heavy with sleep: or slumbering, or dozing:] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also naEosaAnN↓; (Lth, Fr, Th, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but this latter is rare; (Fr, Th, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and by some disallowed: (TA:) fem. of the former with p {naAEisapN}: (Mṣb, TA:) and of the latter naEosaI, made to accord. with wasonaI, fem. of wasonaAnN; and this is best in poetry: (Lth, Mṣb, TA:) and naE-aAsapN↓ is also used as an epithet [in an intensive sense] applied to a female: (TA:) the pl. of naAEisN is nuE-asN; like rak-aEN, pl. of raAkiEN: and that of naAEisapN is nawaAEisu. (Mṣb.)
jad-uhu naAEisN ‡ [His good fortune is slumbering]. (A, TA.)

1. naEaXahu, aor. _a {yanoEaXu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. naEoXN, (Ṣ,) He (God) raised him; lifted him up; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AnEXhu↓; (Lth, Ks, Ḳ;) which is disallowed by ISk, who says that it is a vulgar word, and by J after him, but is correct; (TA;) and nE-Xhu↓, (AA, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoEiyXN: (AA, TA:) or He (God) set him up, or upright; as also AnEXhu↓: (Mṣb:) [see an ex. in a verse cited voce XamolN:] or be [app. a man] raised him, or lifted him up, after a stumble, or trip. (Sb.) You say also, naEaXotu AlX-ajarapa I set the tree upright, when it was leaning. (TA.) And naEaXa Tarufhu He raised his eye, or eyes. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)

[Hence,] aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He recovered him from his embarrassment, or difficulty: (A:) ‡ he restored him from a state of poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: (Ḳ, TA;) as also AnEXhu↓: (TA:) and ‡ he recovered him from a state of perdition or destruction. (TA.) And naEaXaka Qll-ehu ‡ May God restore thee from poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: or make thee to continue in life; preserve thee alive. (A.) And AnEXhu↓ † He set him up, and strengthened his heart. (TA.) And Alr-abiyEu yunoEXu Aln-aAsa ‡ (A, TA,) [The spring, or spring-herbage, or the season, or rain, called AlrbyE,] makes men to live and enjoy plenty of herbage or the like. (TA.)
[Hence also,] naEaXa Almay-ita, (Sh, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Sh,) and so the inf. n. (TA) ‡ He eulogized, or praised, the dead man, (Sh, Ḳ,) and exalted his praise, or fame, or honour. (Sh.)

naEaXuwA Almay-ita also signifies They carried the dead man upon the naEoX, q. v. (A [where this signification is indicated, but not expressed: it is shown, however, by an explanation of pass. part. n. (q. v. infra) in the TA.])
nuEiXa EalaI jinaAratihaA A naEoX [q. v.] was made for her bier. (Mgh, from a trad. of, or relating to, Fátimeh.)

hom.sense: 2. naE-Xhu: see 1.
Also, (Ḳ,) or nE-X lahu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tanoEiyXN, (Ḳ,) He said to him naEaXaka Qll-ehu [which see above, in 1, and also below, in 8]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in [some copies of] the Ṣ, naE-aXaka Allh. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in four places.

8. AntEX He rose; or became raised, or lifted up: (TA:) he rose after his stumble, or trip: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and in like manner you say of a bird, (A, TA,) meaning it rose [after falling or alighting], (TA,) and he raised his head. (TA.) Hence the saying, taEasa falA QnotaEaXa May he fall, having stumbled, or stumble and fall, and not rise [again]: a form of imprecation. (TA.) And hence the saying of ʼOmar, AinotaEiXo naEaXaka Qll-ehu Rise thou: may God raise thee: or nEXk Qll-eh has here one of the two meanings assigned to it before, in 1. (TA.)
[And hence,] ‡ He recovered, or became recovered, from his embarrassment, or difficulty. (A, TA.)

hom.sense: naEoXN A state of elevation, or exaltation. (Sh.) See 1.
A state of remaining; lastingness; endurance; permanence; or continuance; syn. baqaMCN. (Sh, Ḳ.)

[A kind of litter, or] a thing resembling a miHaf-ap, upon which the king used to be carried. when sick: (IDrd, Mṣb, Ḳ:) not the naEoX of a corpse. (IDrd, Mṣb.) This is said to be the primary application. (TA)

And hence, (TA,) A bier, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) when the corpse is upon it. for otherwise it is called sriyrN: (Ṣ, IAth, Mṣb:) it is called by the former name because of its height, or its being raised: (Ṣ, TA.) pl. nuEuwXN: (Mṣb:) also, a reticulated thing. (Az. Mgh, TA,) resembling a mHaf-p, (Mgh,) which is put as a cover over a [dead] woman when she is placed upon the bier; (Az, Mgh, TA;) but this is properly called HarajN, though people called is naEoXN, which is properly only the bier itself. (Az, TA.)

[And hence,] banaAtu naEoXi AlkuboraI [or banaAtu naEoXa AlkuboraI, together with naEoXN or naEoXu, constitute † The constellation of Ursa Major: or the principal stars thereof:] seven stars; whereof four [which are in the body] are called naEoXN [or naEoXu], and three [which are in the tail] are called banAtN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., bnAt nEX (TA:) and to like manner AlS-ugoraI, (Ḳ,) or bnAt nEX AlS-ugoraI [together with nEX AlS-ugoraI constitute † the constellation of Ursa Minor: or the principal stars thereof; seven in number; whereof the four in the body are called nEX, and the there in the tail are called bnAt]: (Ṣ:) [the former four] said to be likened to the bearers of a bier, because they form a square: (IDrd, TA:) [the bnAt being so called as being likened to damsels or to men (for bnAt is pl. of AibonN applied to an irrational thing as well as pl. of binotN) following a bier:] Sb and Fr agree that nEX is imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender: (Ṣ:) or it is perfectly decl. when indeterminate, but not when determinate [by having the epithet AlkuboraI or AlS-ugoraI added to it]: (Aboo-ʼAmr Ez-Záhid, Ḳ:) banw naEoXi also occurs, in poetry; (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ;) because a single one [of the stars thereof] is called Abonu naEoXi, (Lth, Ḳ,) being made to accord. in gender with kawokabN; but when they say valaAv or OarobaE, they say banaAt: (Lth, TA:) [this is agreeable with a general rule; accord. to which, banaAtN is the pl. of AibonN applied to anything but a human being:] the pl. of bnAt nEX is Aln-awaAEiXu; like as OabaAriSu is pl. of saAm-u OabaraSa. (L, TA.) See also nuEayoXN.

Also naEoXN A piece of wood, (Ḳ, TA,) of the length of twice the stature of a man, (TA,) upon the head of which is a piece of rag, (Ḳ, TA,) called HarajN, (TA,) with which young ostriches are hunted or captured. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: nuEayoXN [or nuEayoXu † The small star called] Als-uhaI, which is [by the star ζ] in the middle of banaAt naEoX. So in the saying, huwa OaxofaI mino nuEayoX fiI banaAti naEoX [He, or it, is more obscure than No'eysh among the Bená Naash]. (A, TA.)
Aln-awaAEiXu: see naEoXN, near the end.
manoEuwXN A corpse carried upon a naEoX, or bier. (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb.)
1. nagaba, aor. _a {yanogabu} and _u {yanogubu}, (inf. n. nagobN, TA,) He (a man, TA) swallowed saliva. (Ḳ.)
nagaba, (inf. n. nagobN, TA,) It (a bird) sipped water: you do not say of a bird Xariba. (Ḳ.)
nagaba He (a man) took in gulps, or gulped, in drinking: (Ḳ:) and likewise an ass. (TA.)
nagibotu mina AlUinaACi nugabFA, with kesr, I drank in gulps from the vessel. (ISk, Ṣ.)
nagobapN A hungering. (Ḳ.) A tribe's wanting food, or hungering: syn. UiqafoAru AlHaI-i. (Ḳ, as in some copies: [app. the right reading:] in other copies, OaqofaAr, which is pl. of qaforN. TA.)
See nugobapN.

hom.sense: nugobapN and nagobapN↓ A gulp; or as much as is swallowed at once; of water, &c.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or ↓the latter signifies a single act of gulping: (Ḳ:) differing from the former like as [its syn.] jaroEapN does from juroEapN: (TA:) pl. of the former nugabN: (Ṣ:) for which nugamN occurs in a verse. (TA.)

Ex. waAhFA maA OaboradahaA mino nugobapK maA OaboradahaA EalaI AlfuWaAdi taEosFA liloyadayoni waAlfami ‡ [Excellent! How cool a gulp is it! How cool is it to the heart! May the hands and mouth perish!] said on hearing of the death of an enemy, or of any trial or affliction that has befallen him. (A.)
nugobapN A foul action. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So in the following saying, maA jur-ibato Ealayohi nugobapN qaT-u [A foul action was never found to be chargeable upon him.] (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 1. nagata, aor. _a {yanogatu}, inf. n. nagotN, He pulled hair; syn. jacaba. (Ḳ.)
nagovN Lasting and vehement evil. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
waqaEonaA fiI nagovK We fell into lasting and vehement evil. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. nagirati Alqidoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) aor. _a {yanogaru}; and nagarat (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the A,) aor. _i {yanogiru}; and nagarat, aor. _a {yanogaru}; (Ḳ;) inf. n. nagarN (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ) [of the first] and nagorN (IḲṭṭ, TA) and nagaraAnN (Ḳ, TA) and nagiyrN, (TA,) The cooking-pot boiled; estuated; became in a state of violent commotion; syn. galat, (Aṣ, Ṣ, IḲṭṭ, A, L,) and faArat. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)

Hence, (TA,) nagira Alr-ajulu, (Ṣ,) or nagara, (so in a copy of the A,) ‡ The man became angry, or vehemently or most vehemently angry, or affected with latent anger without power to exercise it: (Ṣ, A:) or his inside boiled by reason of such anger: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) and nagira Ealayohi, aor. _a {yanogaru}; and nagara, aor. _i {yanogiru}; and nagara, aor. _a {yanogaru}; (Ḳ;) the first of which is the most common; (TA;) inf. n. nagarN [of the first] and nagarAnN; and tanag-ara↓; (Ḳ;) [after which last, in the CK, the word galaI, commencing the explanation, is omitted;] his inside boiled against him by reason of anger: (Ḳ:) or by reason of vehement or most vehement anger, or latent anger without power to exercise it: (TA:) or (so accord. to the TA; but in the Ḳ, and) tng-r↓ Ealayohi he became changed, or altered, to him, and threatened him with evil: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and nagira, aor. _a {yanogaru}, inf. n. nagarN, also signifies he held enmity in his heart, watching for an opportunity to indulge it; or he hid enmity and violent hatred in his heart; or he bore rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.
6. tanaAEurN i. q. tanaAkurN [app. meaning, ‡ The behaving with mutual enmity or hostility]. (Ḳ.)

nagirN ‡ [Angry or vehemently or most vehemently angry, or affected with latent anger without power to exercise it: as is implied in the Ṣ: or] having his inside boiling by reason of anger: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) and [it is said that] UimoraOapN nagirapN signifies a woman very jealous; syn. gayoraI: (Ḳ:) [but] it is related in a trad. of ʼAlee, that a woman came to him and told him that her husband had illicit intercourse with her female slave; whereupon he said, “If thou be speaker of truth, we stone him; and if thou be a speaker of falsehood, we whip thee:” and she said, rud-uwniI UilaI OaholiI gayoraI nagirapF, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning, [Restore ye me to my family, very jealous,] with my inside boiling by reason of anger, or vehement or most vehement anger, or latent anger without power to exercise it: this is the explanation given by Aṣ: and ISd says, that he holds ngrp to signify here angry, not very jealous; since it is related that an Arab said to a woman, OagyoraI Oanoti Oamo nagirapN [Art thou very jealous or angry?] (TA.)

nugarN Certain birds like sparrows, (Ṣ,) or a species of sparrows, (Mṣb,) with red beaks: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) n. un. with p {nugarapN}: (Ṣ:) or the young ones of sparrows: (Ḳ:) n. un. as above: (TA:) or the young ones of the sparrows; (Sh, Mṣb;) which you always see in a lean state: (Sh:) or [a species] of young sparrows: (TA:) or the bird called bulobul: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) it is said that the people of El-Medeeneh call the bulobul by the names of nugarN and Hum-arapN; and it is said to resemble the sparrow; and the fem. is with p {nugarapN}: (Mṣb:) or (TA; in the Ḳ, and) a species of the Hum-ar, (Ḳ, TA; in the CK, erroneously, Humur;) red in the beaks and in the lower parts of the OaHonaAk [or portions beneath the beaks]: (TA:) or the males thereof: (Ḳ:) pl. nigoraAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as SirodaAnN is pl. of SuradN. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) Its dim. is nugayorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) occurring in a trad.; yaA OabaA Eumayoro maA faEala Aln-ugayoro [O Aboo-ʼOmeyr, what did the little nughar?]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) said by Moḥammad to a little child of Aboo-Talhah El-Anṣáree, who had a bird, or birds, of this name, which died. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. nagiSa, aor. _a {yanogaSu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nagaSN, (Ṣ,) He (a man, Ṣ,) failed of having his desire fully accomplished: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but Lth says, that it is more commonly with teshdeed, i. e. nag-aSa↓, [unless this be a mistake for nug-iSa,] inf. n. tanogiySN. (TA.)
And in like manner, (Ṣ,) He (a camel) failed of having his full, or complete, draught, or drink. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And It (beverage) was imperfect, or defective. (Ḳ.)
See also 5.

nagaSN (L, Ḳ) and nagoSN (L, TA) [both inf. ns., the verb of the former being app. nagiSa, used intransitively, and that of the latter nagaSa, used transitively, followed by Uibilahu,] also signify The bringing one's camels to the drinking-trough, and, when they have drunk, turning them back, and bringing others; (Ḳ;) taking forth, from every two camels, a strong camel, and putting in its place a weak camel; and thus as it were, making their drinking troublesome. (TA.)

You say also, nagaSa Alr-ajulu Alr-ajula The man prevented the man from obtaining his share of water by interposing to hinder his camels from drinking: and in like manner, OanogaSahu↓ raEoyahu [He prevented him from obtaining his share of pasturage for his camels]: the verb in the latter instance being with A. (TA.)
See also 2.
2. ng-S EalayonaA He cut short a thing of which we loved to have much, or abundance. (IAạr, TA.)

ng-S Ealayohi; and nagaSa↓ Elyh, inf. n. nagoSN; but the former is the more common; He rendered [an affair, or circumstances, or a state,] troublesome, or perturbed, to him; syn. kad-ara. (IḲṭṭ, TA.) You say, ng-S Qll-ehu Ealayohi AlEayoXa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanogiySN; (Ṣ;) and ng-Shu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and AngS↓ Elyh AlEyX; (Ḳ;) God rendered life troublesome, or perturbed, to him; syn. kad-arahu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the first of these is the most common: (TA:) the second occurs in poetry; the pronoun in this relating to a man. (Akh, Ṣ, TA.)
See also nagiSa.

entry.sense: 4: see 1, last sentence:
and see also 2.

5. tng-St EiyXatuhu, (Ṣ,) or maEiyXatuhu, (Ḳ,) His state of life, (Ṣ,) or his means of subsistence, (Ḳ,) became troublesome, or perturbed, or attended with trouble; syn. takad-arato. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say also, nagiSa Oamoruhu, inf. n. nagaSN, [His affair, or case, became troublesome,, &c.;] (A;) [for] nagaSN↓ is syn. with tanag-uSN as signifying takad-urN (Ḥar, p. 273).
6. tnAgSt AlUibilu EalaI AlHawoDi The camels crowded, or pressed, together to the drinkingtrough. (Ks, Ḳ.*)
nugaSN is said to signify Things that prevent one from attaining an object of desire. (Ḥar, p. 273.)
munag-iSN Any one who cuts short a thing of which one loves to have more. (IAạr, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. nagaDa, aor. _i {yanogiDu}, (Ks, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and _u, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. nagoDN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nuguwDN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nagaDaAnN and nagaDN, (Ḳ,) It was or became, in a state of motion, commotion, agitation, or convulsion; it shook; shook about; wabbled; tottered; wagged; nodded; syn. taHar-aka, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AiDoTaraba, (A, Ḳ,) fiI QrotijaAfK; (TA;) as also AngD↓ (Mṣb, Ḳ) and tng-D↓: (Ḳ:) it is said of a man's head; (Ṣ, TA;) and also, (Ṣ, A,) with nagoDN and nagaDaAnN for its inf. ns., (Ṣ,) of a camel's saddle, (Ṣ, A,) and of the central incisor (Ṣ, TA) of a child, (Ṣ,) or of any tooth, as also ↓the last of the verbs above mentioned; (A;) and of other things; (Mṣb, TA;) nagoDN signifying any moving in a shaking or tremulous or convulsive manner (fiI QrotijaAfK); (Ṣ, TA;) and nagaDato and tanag-aDato↓, said of a tooth, being syn. with rajafato. (A.)
Also, inf. n. nagaDaAnN, He, or it, was, or became, disquieted, agitated, or violently agitated. (TA.)
nagaDuwA UilaI AlEaduw-i ‡ They rose and hastened and went forth to, or towards, the enemy. (A, TA.)

nagaDa also signifies † It (a thing, TA) was, or became, dense: (so in some copies of the Ḳ) or much in quantity: (so in other copies of the Ḳ:) or much in quantity, and dense. (TA.) And ‡ It (a cloud) was, or became, dense, and then became ready to rain, and was seen to move about, one part into another, without its going along: (Ṣ:) or was seen to become ready to rain, without motion, not travel-ling along: (A:) or it travelled along. (IF.) [See naAgiDN, below.]
nagaDa Oamoruhu † His affair, or case, was, or became, in a weak, or unsound, state; syn. wahaI. (TA.)
See also 4, in two places.
4. ngD: see 1.

AngDh He put it in a state of motion, commotion, agitation, or convulsion: shook it; shook it about; made it to wabble, or totter; wagged it; nodded it; as also nagaDahu↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and nagaDa↓ bihi: (A:) namely a thing: (Mṣb:) or his head; (Ṣ, A, TA;) in wonder; (A;) or as one in wonder at a thing; (Ṣ, TA;) or in disapproval of a thing told him; (AHeyth, TA;) or in derision; or as though asking the meaning of what was said, inclining to the speaker. (TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur, [xvii. 53,] fasayunogDuwna Uilayoka ruWuwsahumo (Ṣ, TA) And they will shake, or wag, their heads at thee, in derision. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in three places.
nagoDN One who shakes his head, and trembles in his gait: (Ḳ:) an inf. n. used as an epithet. (TA.)

A male ostrich that shakes his head: (Ṣ:) or nagoDN, as also nigoDN↓, is a name of the male ostrich; determinate; (Ḳ;) being a name of the species; like OusaAmapu: (TA:) so called because, when he hastens his gait, he moves up and down: (Lth:) or a name of the male ostrich that has a habit of going round about: (AHeyth, Ḳ:) and nagoDapN↓ [is the n. un., signifying] an ostrich. (TA.)
See also naAgiDN.
nugoDN: see naAgiDN, in three places.
nigoDN: see nagoDN.
nagoDapN A tree. (IḲt.)
See also nagoDN.
naguwDN A she-camel having a large hump: because, when it is large, it shakes, or quakes. (IF, Ḳ.)

nag-aADN [In a state of much motion, commotion, agitation, or convulsion; shaking, shaking about, wabbling, tottering, wagging, or nodding, much]. You say, UibilN nag-aADapN biriHaAlihaA [Camels jogging much with their saddles; or jogging much their saddles]. (A, TA.)
See also naAgiDN.

nag-aADu AlbaToni Wrinkled in the belly: an expression applied to Moḥammad, (Ḳ,) by ʼAlee, who thus explained it: because of the elevation of the wrinkled parts above the even surface of the belly: or it may be derived from guDuwnN, meaning “wrinkles” in the belly, by transposition of letters. (TA.)

naAgiDN [In a state of motion, commotion, or agitation, or convulsion; shaking; shaking about; wabbling; tottering; wagging; nodding: pl. nug-aDN]. You say, maHaAlN nug-aDN [Great pullysheaves in a state of motion,, &c.]. (Ṣ, TA.) And gayomN naAgiDN (Ḳ) and nag-aADN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) ‡ A cloud, or clouds, becoming dense, and then ready to rain, and seen to move about, one part into another, without going along: (Ṣ:) or in a state of motion, or commotion, one part after another, (Ḳ, TA,) not travelling along: (TA:) or seen to move about, one part into another, without going along. (L.)

Also, (Ṣ, E,) or naAgiDapN↓, (so in a copy of the A,) and nugoDN↓ and nugoSN↓ (A, Ḳ,) but this is rare, (TA,) A cartilage (Ṣ:) or the cartilage of the shoulder-blade: (A, Ḳ:) or the part thereof where it mores to and fro: (Ḳ:) or the upper part of the end of the cartilage of the shoulder-blade: (TA.) or the nugoD↓ of the shoulder-blade is the thin bone at the extremity thereof: (Sh:) or the nugoDaAni↓ are the parts of the root of the shoulder blade that move about in walking: (L:) and the naAgiD of a man is the base of the neck, where he moves about his head, (Sh)
naAgiDapN: see naAgiDN.
nufoOapN One of several parts, or portions, of scattered herbage: or one of several adjacent meadows (riyaAD), separated from, and rising above, the greater part of the pasture. pl. nufFA (Ḳ.)

1. nafatati Alqidoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor _i, inf. n. nfiytN (Ṣ) and nafotN and nafataAnN, (L,) The cooking-pot boiled: (Ḳ:) or threw forth what resembled arrows, by reason of [its vehement] boiling: (Ṣ, L:) [see also nafavat, and nafaTato] or [boiled so that] the broth, or gravy, stuck to its sides: (Ḳ:) or the broth boiled in the cooking pot, and what dried thereof stuck to the sides of the pot: (L:) you say [also] Alqidoru tanaAfatu↓, and tanaAfaTu, [for tatanaAftu and tatanaAfaTu]. (Ṣ, L [but in the latter, these two verbs are written without the syll. points].)
yanofitu gaDabFA, as also yanofiTu, † He boils with anger. (Ṣ:)
yanofitu Ealayohi gaDabFA, as also ynfT, † He boils against him with anger. (TA.)
Sadoruhu yanofitu biAloEadaAwapi ‡ [His breast boils with enmity]. (A.) [See also nafava.]

nafata, aor. _i {yanofitu}, inf. n. nafotN and nafataAnN (L, Ḳ) and nafiytN and nafaAtN, (L,) † He (a man, L) was angry: (Ḳ, L:) or nafataAnN resembles coughing: [so that the verb seems to signify he made a noise like coughing, by reason of anger:] (L:) or he blew in anger: (L:) or he blew, (nafaxa, as in the copies of the Ḳ in my hands,) or swelled, or became inflated, (Antfx, as in the TA,) by reason of anger. (Ḳ.)
nafata, (aor. _i {yanofitu} L,) inf. n. nafotN, It (flour or the like) had water poured upon it, and swelled, or became inflated, (tanaf-axa,) in consequence. (L, Ḳ.)
6: see 1.
mirojalN nafuwtN A cooking-pot throwing forth what resembles arrows, by reason of [its vehement] boiling:, &c. (Ṣ, L.)

nafiytapN A certain kind of food, thicker than what is called saxiynapN; (Ḳ;) i. q. HariyqapN; made by sprinkling flour upon water or milk, (fresh milk, L,) until it becomes swollen or inflated, (yanofit,) (Ṣ, L,) when it is supped, or sipped (ytHs-aI); (L;) it is thicker than saxiynap; the master of a family uses it plentifully for his household in times of scarcity: (Ṣ, L:) they only eat nfytp and sxynp in a time of straitness, and dearness, and leanness of the cattle: Az says, in art. Hcrq, sxynp is flour thrown upon water or milk, and cooked, and then eaten with dates or [here a word in the L is illegible; after which we read] and it is [what is called] HasaAC; and it is also called saxuwnapN: and nafiytapN and HariyqapN and HariyrapN and nafiyvapN are a kind of HsA, between thick and thin. (L.) [See also xaziyrN, and HariyqapN.]

1. nafava, aor. _i {yanofivu} and _u {yanofuvu}, inf. n. nafovN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nafavaAnN, (TA,) [He puffed; or blew, without spitting: or he sputtered, or blew forth a little spittle in minute scattered particles: or] he spat: or he [did as though he] spat without ejecting spittle: and nafava fI AlEuqodapi signifies he spat, ejecting a little spittle, upon the knot, in enchantment: (Mṣb:) or Aln-afovu is like Aln-afoxu, or blowing, and less than Alt-afolu, or spitting, or ejecting spittle from the mouth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or like blowing, with [the emission of] spittle: (Keshsháf;) or like blowing, as done in enchantment, without spittle: the action, if accompanied by spittle, being termed Altfl: this is the most correct explanation: ('Ináyeh:) or gentle blowing without spittle: (AlAckAr:) or more than blowing; or like blowing; but less than spitting: sometimes without spittle, thus differing from Altfl; and sometimes with a little spittle, thus differing from Alnfx: or the emitting wind from the mouth, together with a little spittle. (MF.)
laA bud-a lilomaSoduwri Oano yanofiva [He who has a disease in his chest must spit]. A proverb. (Ṣ.)
nafavahu mino fiyhi, aor. _i {yanofivu}, inf. n. nafovN, He ejected it from his mouth. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] nafava Qll-ehu AlX-aIoCi fiI Alqalobi ‡ God cast, or put, the thing into the heart. (Mṣb)
nafiva fiI ruwEiI kacaA ‡ Such a thing was inspired, or put, into my mind. (A.)
nafava fiI ruwEiI ‡ He (the Holy Spirit [Gabriel]) inspired, or cast, or put, into my mind, or heart. (Nh, from a trad.)
[You say,] lawo nafava Ealayoka fulaAnN qaT-araka [If such a one blew, or spat, upon thee, he would throw thee down upon thy side.]. Said to one who tries his strength with one superior to him. (A.)
nafava EalaI-a gaDabFA as though meaning He blew at me by reason of the violence of his anger. (L.) [See also nafata.]
AlHay-apu tanofivu Als-am-a UicaA nakazato [The serpent ejects venom from its mouth when it inflicts a wound with its nose]. (Ṣ.)
nafava It (a wound) emitted blood. (TA.)
[From the blowing or spitting upon the knots:] nafavahu, inf. n. nafovN, He enchanted him. (Mṣb.)

nafavati Alqidoru, aor. _i {yanofivu}, inf. n. nafiyvN and nafovN, The cooking-pot boiled: or, boiled, and threw forth what resembled arrows, by reason of the vehemence of its boiling. (Mṣb.) [See also nafatat.] It is when it begins to boil. (TA.)
nafovu AlX-ayoTaAni Poetry: (Ḳ, from a trad.:) called nfv because it is like a thing which a man spits, or blows, (yanofivu,) from his mouth, like incantation. (AʼObeyd.)
caA mino nafavaAti fulaAnK This is of the poetry of such a one. (TA.)
damN nafiyvN Blood emitted by a wound (Ṣ, Ḳ) or vein. (TA.)

miYonaAvN kaOan-ahaA nufaAvN [A plain land that produces many plants, or herbs, or much herbage,] as though blowing forth, or spitting forth, the pleats, or herbs. (L, from a trad.) [The correctness of nufaAvN is questioned by El-Khaṭṭábee. May it not be a mistake for naf-aAvN?]
nufaAvapN What one blows, or spits, (yanofivu,) from his mouth. (Ṣ.)
What a person having a disease in his chest blows forth or spits out, yanofivu. (Ḳ.)

What remains in one's mouth, of a siwaAk, or tooth-stick, and is spit out: (Ṣ:) a particle broken off (XaZiy-apN: so in the L, &c.: in the Ḳ, XaTiybapN:) from a swAk, or tooth-stick, remaining in the mouth, and spit out. (L, Ḳ.) One says, lawo saOalaniI nufaAvapa siwaAkK maA OaEoTayotuhu If he asked me for a particle of a tooth-stick, remaining in my mouth, I would not give him (it). (Ṣ.)
nafiyvapN A certain kind of food. (See nafiytap and waTiyoYap.)
naf-aAvN An enchanter; one who is in the habit of enchanting: fem. with p {naf-aAvapN}. (Mṣb.)

Aln-af-aAvaAtu fiI AlEuqadi [Ḳur, cxiii. 4,] The women who blow, without spitting, saying something at the same time, upon the knots which they tie in a thread, or string: (Jel:) meaning the enchantresses. (Ṣ, Ḳ, Jel.) [See a verse cited voce EaADihN.]
naAfivN Enchanting. (Mṣb.)
manofuwtN A man enchanted. (A.)
1. nafaja, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanofuju}, inf. n. nufuwjN; (Mṣb;) and Antfj↓; (TA;) It (a hare, Ṣ, Ḳ, or other animal, Mṣb) sprang up (Ṣ, Ḳ) from its hole; or leaped. (TA.)
nafaja; (TA;) and Anfj↓, (Ṣ,) inf. n. UinofaAjN; (Mṣb;) and Antfj↓; (TA;) He made a hare to spring up (Ṣ, &c.) from its hole; or to leap. (TA.)
nafaja, aor. _i {yanofiju} and _u {yanofuju}, inf. n. nufajN; and Antfj↓; It (a jerboa) ran: (M:) or slackened his run. (A.)
nafaja, and Antfj↓, and tnf-j↓, It (anything) rose; or became elevated, or exalted. (TA.)
nafaja, aor. _u {yanofuju}, inf. n. nafojN, He made anything to rise; or to become elevated, or exalted. (TA.)
nafajati Alfar-uwjapu The chicken came forth from its egg. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nafaja, (aor. _u {yanofuju}, inf. n. nafojN, Ṣ,) It (a woman's breast) heaved up her shift. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nafajati Alr-iyHu ‡ The wind came with force: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, suddenly. (TA.)
nafaja, inf. n. nafojN, He magnified, or made great, him, or it. (Mṣb, TA.) [And so,] Antfj↓ It became great. (TA.)

nafaja, aor. _u {yanofuju}, inf. n. nafojN; (Mṣb;) and Antfj↓, (TA,) and tnf-j↓; (Ḳ;) He boasted of that which he did not possess, (Mṣb,) and which was not in him: (TA:) or, of more than he possessed. (Ḳ.)
4: see 1, and 10.
5: see 1, in two places.
8. UinotafajaA HanobaA AlbaEiyri The sides of the camel became elevated, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or bulging,] and great, naturally. (TA.)
Hence the expression UinotifaAju AlOahil-api † [The swelling out of the new moons], in a trad. respecting the signs [of the last day]. (TA.)
See 1 throughout.
10. Astnfj (IAạr, M) and Anfj↓, (M,) He (a sportsman) drew forth a jerboa [&c. from its hole]. (M.)
Hence, (TA,) † He drew forth, and caused to appear, the anger of a person. (Ḳ.)
nafojN and nafaAjapN↓ ‡ [A boasting of that which one does not possess, or the like: see 1, and naf-aAjN]. (A.) [See also nafoxN.]
nufoju AlHaqiybapi A woman, (Ḳ,) and a man, (TA,) large in the buttocks: (Ḳ, TA:) or prominent therein. (TA in art. Hqb.)
nafojapN A single leap of a hare from the place where it has been lying. In a trad., a sedition, or disturbance, is likened to this in regard of the shortness of its duration. (TA.)
nafaAjapN: see nafojN and naf-aAjN.

nafiyjapN A bow (Ṣ, Ḳ) made of a piece of wood of the kind of tree called naboE; not known by Aboo-Saʼeed with H [in the place of j]. (Ṣ [so in the copies of that work which I am using, three in number: but in one copy, “except with H”].)
naAfijN: see naAfijapN.

hom.sense: naAfijapN The commencement of anything, (so in two copies of the Ṣ, and so in the Mṣb,) or of any wind, (so in one copy of the Ṣ,) that begins with vehemence, or violence: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or a wind that begins with vehemence: (Ḳ:) or, that comes with vehemence: (A:) Aṣ thinks it to be attended by cold: AḤn says, that sometimes the north wind rises upon people when they have been sleeping, and almost destroys them with cold at the close of the night, when the former part of the night has been warm: (TA:) or a wind that rises upon one suddenly and vehemently, when he is not aware: (Sh:) pl. nawaAfiju. (A.)
naAfijapN ‡ A cloud abounding with rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called from the same word as signifying “a wind that comes with vehemence:” (TA:) thus called by the name of the thing which is its cause. (Ṣ.)
naAfijapN The hinder part of a rib: (Ṣ:) or, of the ribs: (Ḳ:) as also naAfijN↓: (TA:) pl. nawaAfiju. (Ṣ.)
naAfijapN † Camels which a man inherits, and whereby his camels are increased in number. (TA.)

naAfijapN ‡ A daughter: so called because she in creases the property of her father by her dowry: (Ḳ:) or, that increases the property of her father: for he takes her dowry (consisting of camels, TA) and adds it to his property, (or camels, TA,) so that the amount becomes raised. (Ṣ.) The Arabs used to say, in the time of paganism, when a daughter was born to one of them, haniyoYA laka Aln-aAfijapu May she who is to increase thy property by her dowry be productive of enjoyment to thee! (Ṣ.)

naAfijapN A bag, follicle, or vesicle, of musk: (Ḳ:) pl. nawaAfiju: (Ṣ:) an arabicized word, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from [the Persian] naAfaho; and therefore some say that it is properly written naAfajapN: or, accord. to the Mṣb, it is Arabic, and a bag of musk is so called because of its high value, from nafajahu “he magnified him, or it:” but this requires consideration. (TA.) See faOorapu Almisoki, voce faOorN.

entry.sense: OnofajaAniI-N One who exaggerates, or exceeds the due bounds, in speech; (Ḳ;) and who boasts of that which he does not possess. (TA.)
manaAfiju Pieces of stuff with which women make their buttocks to appear large; syn EuZ-aAmaAtN. (Ḳ.)
munotafiju Aljanobayoni A man having elevated, [or bulging,] sides. (A.)
munotafijN A camel having prominent flanks. (TA.) See naf-aAjN.

hom.sense: 1. nafaHa, aor. _a {yanofaHu}, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. nafoHN (L, Ḳ) and nufuwHN (L) and nufaAHN and nafaHaAnN, (Ḳ,) It (perfume) diffused its odour. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

nafaHati Alr-iyHu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanofuHu}, inf. n. nafoHN, (Mṣb,) ‡ The wind blew: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or blew gently; began to be in a state of commotion: (A:) nafaHato and lafaHato are syn., except that the effect of Aln-afoH is greater than that of All-afoH: (Zj:) or, accord. to Aṣ, (Ṣ,) or IAạr, (TA,) nafoHN relates to a cold, or cool, wind; and lafoHN, to a hot wind: (Ṣ, TA.) [but see nafoHapN].
nafaHatohu Aljnwb bibarodihaA ‡ The south wind blew upon it with its cold, or coolness. (IB.)

nafaHa AlEiroqa, (aor. _a {yanofaHu}, inf. n. nafoHN, Ṣ,) ‡ The vein ejected, or spirted forth, blood. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And in like manner, nafaHati AlT-aEonapu biAld-ami ‡ The stab ejected, or spirted forth, blood. (TA.)
nafaHa All-abana nafoHapa ‡ He churned the milk once. (A.)

nafaHahu bAls-ayofi ‡ He struck him, or it, lightly, or slightly, with the sword: (A:) he reached, or hit, him, or it, (tanaAwalahu,) with the sword (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) from a distance, (Ṣ, L,) by a side-blow, XazorFA. (L.)
nafaHa, inf. n. nafoHN, He struck, smote, or beat. (L.) See 3.
nafaHa, inf. n. nafoHN, He threw, or cast. (L.)
nafaHa XayoYFA † He thrust, or pushed, or repelled, a thing from him. (L.)

nafaHati Ald-aAb-apu, aor. _a {yanofaHu}, inf. n. nafoHN, The horse, or the like, kicked, or struck, with its hind leg: (L:) or, with its hoof: (Mṣb:) or, with the extremity of its hoof: Aln-afoHu is said to be with one hind leg: and Alr-amoHu, with both hind legs together. (L.) nafaHati Aln-aAqapu The she-camel struck, or kicked, with her hind leg. (Ṣ.) OaboTala nafoHa Ald-aAb-api He made the kicking of the horse, or the like, with its hind leg, to be of no account; not to require anything to be paid by its owner. (L.) [See 3 in art. Eqb.]
nafaHahu biXaIoCK, (inf. n. nafoHN, Mṣb,) ‡ He gave him a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nafaHahu nafoHapF ‡ [He gave him a gift; or conferred upon him a favour]. (Ṣ.) [See an ex. voce Earabap.]

entry.sense: 3. naAfaHuwhumo (inf. n. munaAfaHapN, TA) ‡ They contended with them with swords face to face; or encountered them in war face to face, having before their faces neither shields nor anything else; syn. kaAfaHuwhumo: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) originally signifying they approached them in fight so near that the breath of each party reached the other (TA.)
nAfHhu ‡ He contended with him. (Ḳ.)
nAfH Eanohu; (Ṣ, A;) and nafaHa↓ Eanohu, (A,) inf. n. nafoHN. (IAạr;) ‡ He contended for him, or in defence of him; (Ṣ;) repelled from him, and defended him: (IAạr, A:) as also nADH. (TA.)

nafoHapN An odour, whether good or bad: or a plenteous odour; differing from nafoxapN, which is a slight odour: (AḤn, in L, art. nfx:) pl. nafaHaAtN. (L.) You say lahu nafoHapN Tay-ibapN, (Ṣ, L.) and xabiyvapN, (L,) It has a good, or sweet, and a bad, or foul, odour. (L.)
nafoHapN ‡ A blast, or breath, of wind. (Ḳ.)
nafoHapN mina AlS-abaA ‡ A pleasant and fragrant blast of the east wind. And nfHpN mino samuwmK ‡ A grievous blast of hot wind. (AHeyth.)
nafoHapN mina AlEacaAbi † A part, or portion, of punishment: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a grievous blast of punishment: (AHeyth:) or a most violent infliction of punishment. (L.)
nafoHapN Ald-ami ‡ The first gush of blood from a wound. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, L.)
nafoHapN ‡ A single churning (maHoDapN so in the A and TA: in. the CK and a MṢ copy of the Ḳ. maHoDap, with H unpointed:) of milk. (A, Ḳ.)
[See 1.]
nafoHpN ‡ A gift: (Mṣb:) [pl. nafaHaAtN].
lA tazaAlu lifulaAn nafaHaAtN mna AlmaEoruwfi (Ṣ, L) There cease not to be attributable to such a one acts of kindness, or favours. (L.)
tEar-aDuwA linafaHaAti raHomapi Qll-ehi ‡ (TA:) see art. ErD, voce taEar-aDa.

hom.sense: riyHN nafuwHN ‡ A wind that blows violently, and raises the dust. (L.)
yamaAniy-apN nafuwHN ‡ A south wind (Ṣ, IB) that blows coldly, or coolly (IB.)
daAb-apN nafuwHN A horse, or the like, that kicks with its kind leg: or, with the extremity of its hoof. (L.) [See 1.]
nafuwHN ‡ A she-camel whose milk comes forth without its being drawn from the teat: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and an udder that does not retain its milk. (AZ.) See naf-aAHN.

qawosN nfuwHN ‡ A bow that sends the arrow far; or that impels the arrow with force: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) as also nafiyHapN↓ (Ḳ) and minofaHapN↓: (TA:) each of which two words is a name for a bow: (Ṣ, with respect to the former, and TA, with respect to the latter:) pl. of the former nafuAYiHu: (Ṣ:) and nafyHpN↓ signifies a branch of the tree called naboE, of which a bow is made. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also nafiyjapN, with H.]

entry.sense: nafiyHapN: see nafuwHN.

hom.sense: misokN naf-aAHN [Musk that diffuses much odour or fragrance]. (A, art. xTr.)
TaEonapN naf-aAHapN ‡ A stab that ejects, or spirts forth, blood, much, or vehemently. (TA.) TaEonapN nafuwHN↓ ‡ A stab that ejects its blood quickly. (T.)
naf-aAHN ‡ One who gives many gifts. (TA.)

Aln-af-aAHu, (Ḳ,) or Aln-af-aAHu biAlxayori, (TA,) The Bestower of [many] benefits upon mankind, or the creation: (Ḳ:) an epithet applied to God; but disapproved by some, because not so applied in the Ḳur-án or the traditions.

entry.sense: naAfiHN Diffusing odour; fragrant. Ex. naAfijapN naAfiHapN A bag, or vesicle, of mush diffusing odour, or fragrant: pl. nawaAfiHu. (A.)

UinofaHapN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) said to be the most common form of the word, (TA,) for which one should not say OanofaHapN, (ISk,) but this is mentioned by Ibn-Et-Teiyánee and the author of the ʼEyn, (MF,) and sometimes it is written and pronounced UinofaH-apN, (Ḳ,) or this is the most common form, (Mṣb,) and most approved, (ISk,) and sometimes UinofiHapN, (Ḳ,) and minofaHapN↓, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and binofaHapN, (IAạr, Ḳ,) with b in the place of the m, (TA,) [The rennet, or rennet-bag, of a kid or lamb; i. e.] A substance that comes forth from the belly of a kid, containing coagulated milk which is termed libaOo, used as a means of converting fresh milk into cheese: (IDrst:) or a thing that is taken forth from the belly of a sucking-pig, (or lamb, Mṣb,) of a yellow colour, and squeezed in some cotton, (which is soaked, into milk, L, Mṣb,) whereupon it (i. e. the milk, MF) becomes thick, like cheese: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the stomach (kariX) of a lamb or kid before it eats: (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb:) when it eats, it is called kariX. (AZ, Ṣ.) F imputes inadvertence to J in his explaining AnfHp by the term kariX; but he does not explain it by this term absolutely; and F adds to his own explanation what makes it exactly the same as that of J, [except that he makes it relate to a kid only,] saying “when the kid eats, it,” that is the AnfHp, “is called kariX.” (MF.) None but a ruminating animal has an AnfHp. (Lth.) The pl. is OanaAfiHu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Any AnfHp, especially [that of] the hare, if hung upon the thumb of a person suffering from a fever, cures him. (Ḳ.)
UinofaHapN also signifies A kind of tree (Xajar) resembling the baAcinojaAn. (Ḳ.)
minofaHapN: see nafuwHN and UinfaHapN.

hom.sense: 1. nafaxa bifamihi, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanofuxu}, [accord, to Golius and Freytag, incorrectly, _a see Ḳur, iii. 43, &c.], inf. n. nafoxN; (Mṣb;) and nf-x↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tanofiyxN; (TA;) He blew with his mouth; sent forth wind from his mouth; (Ḳ;) this is done in taking rest, and in labour or exertion, and the like. (L.) nafaxa is mostly used as a neut. v.; but sometimes it is trans., as many have asserted: you say nafaxa AlS-uwra, as well as nafaxa fiyhi, He blew the trumpet, or blew into the trumpet: (MF, TA:) nafaxahu is a dial. form of nafaxa fiyhi: (Ṣ:) also, nafaxa fiI Aln-aAri [he blew the fire; or blew into the fire]: [see 8 (last sentence) in art. qwt:] and nafaxa fI Alz-iq-i [he blew into, or inflated, the skin]: and sometimes one says nafaxahu. (Mṣb.) nufoxuwA occurs in a verse of El-Katámee for nufixuwA. (Ṣ.)
nafaxa AlX-ayoTaAnu fiI Oanofihi † [The devil blew into his nose]: said of him who aspires to that which is not for him. (TA.)
nafaxa Xidoqayohi ‡ [He inflated, or puffed out, the sides of his mouth; meaning] he was proud, or affected pride. (A.)
nafaxahu, aor. _u {yanofuxu}, inf. n. nafoxN, It (food) inflated him, or filled him. (L.)
nafixa, aor. _a {yanofaxu}, inf. n. (L) nafaxN, (Ṣ, L,) He (a man, Ṣ, and a horse, L) had inflated testicles. (Ṣ, L.)
Also, He (a beast of carriage) had his pasterns inflated with wind. When a beast thus affected walks, the humour subsides. (L.)
nafaxa nihaA Pepedit; crepitum ventris emisit. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nafaxati Alr-iyHu The wind came suddenly. (L.)
nafaxato bihimu AlT-ariyqu ‡ The road cast [or brought] them suddenly [to a place]: from nfxt AlryH. (L.)

nafaxati AlD-uHaI, inf. n. nafoxN, ‡ The morning became advanced, and the sun high. (L, Ḳ.) You say also Antfx↓ Aln-ahaAru ‡ The day became advanced, the sun being high, (Ṣ, L,) an hour before noon. (L.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
5: see 8.
8. Antfx It (a thing, Ṣ, as a skin, Mṣb,) became inflated, or puffy; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) as also tnf-x↓: (A:) also, it became swollen; i. q. warima. (Ḳ, art. wrm.)
Antfx He became inflated, or filled, by food. (L.) See 1.
UinotifaAxu AlOahil-api ‡ The bigness [or swelling] of the new moons. Occurring in a trad. respecting the signs of the last day. (L.) [See Antfj.]
Antfx EalaI-a † [He became inflated against me; i. e.] he was angry with me. (TA.) And Antfx lahu † [He behaved angrily to him]. (TA in art. zHr.)
nafoxN [Flatulence.]
[And hence,] ‡ Boastfulness; arrogance; pride; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [inflation with pride]: pride was termed by Moḥammad nafoxu AlX-ayoTaAni. (TA, art. hmz.)
rajulN cuw nafoxK, as also cw nafoji, ‡ A boastful, arrogant, proud man; (Ṣ;) [a man inflated with pride].
nufuxN † A young man (TA) full of youthfulness [or youthful plumpness or vigour]; (Ḳ;) and so, without p, a damsel. (TA.)

nafoxapN and nufoxapN and nifoxapN Inflation of the belly (Ṣ, Ḳ) by food, &c. (TA.) You say bihi nfxpN He has an inflation of the body: (Ḳ:) and Oajidu nfxpF I experience an inflation of the body. (Ṣ.)
[And A flatulent humour of any kind: a meaning well known.]
Aln-afoxapu The blast [of the horn] of the day of resurrection. (L.)
nafoxapN A slight odour: differing from nafoHapN, which is a plenteous odour. (L.)

nafoxapu AlX-abaAbi ‡ The chief part of youth. (L.) nafoxapu Alr-abiyEi ‡ The time of the season called AlrbyE when the earth produces herbs, or herbage: (A:) or nufoxapu AlrbyE, and nifoxatuhu, the time of that season when vegetation has ended. (AZ:)
nufoxapN A disease that attacks a horse, and makes his testicles to swell. (L.)
See nuf-aAxN.

nafoxaMCu (applied to land, or ground, Ṣ) i. q. naboxaMCu: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or elevated and good or fertile ground, in which is no sand nor stones, producing a few trees; and so nahodaMCu, except that this latter is more flat and extensive: or soft land, in which is elevation: (L:) or tumid earth, that breaks in pieces when trodden upon: (TA, voce rax-aMCu:) pl. nafaAxiI-u: it has a form of pl. proper to substs, because it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (L.)
nafoxaMCu The upper part of the bone of the sAq [or shank, or tibia]. (Ḳ.)
nafiyxN One who is employed to blow a fire. (Ḳ.)
An inflation of a humour occasioned by disease, (T, Ḳ,) arising in any part: (T:) a humour; as also nafoxapN↓. (L.)
See nuf-aAxapN.
nuf-aAxapN A bubble upon water. (L, Ḳ [but in some copies of the Ḳ, for AlHajaApu is erroneously put AlHjArp.])

[The air-bladder of a fish;] an inflated thing in the belly of a fish, which is (as they assert, L,) its niSaAb [app. meaning its most essential part, or element,] by means of which it rises in the water, and moves to and fro. (L, Ḳ.)
A bladder of a plant (Ṣ, O, L, voce qataAdN, &c.) N. un. of nuf-aAxN (AḤn, in TA, voce EuX-arN.) [And in anatomy, A cell.]
maA biAld-aAri naAfixu DaramapK [There is not in the house a blower of a fire; i. e.,] there is not in the house any one. (Ṣ.)
naAfixN HiDonayohi [A man inflating, or puffing out, his sides;] inflated, and ready to do mischief, or evil. (L, from a trad.)
Oanofaxu A man, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and a horse, (L,) having inflated testicles: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) syn. of Mdaru. (Mgh, in art, Adr.)
Also, A beast of carriage having his pasterns inflated with wind: see nafixa. (L.)

dictScrap.title:
OunofuxaAnN / OunofuxaAnapN /
UinofixaAnN / UinofixaAnapN /
OunofuxaAniI-N / OunofuxaAniy-apN /
UinofixaAniI-N / UinofixaAniy-apN

entry.sense: rajulN OunofuxaAnN, and UinofixaAnN, and OunofuxaAniI-N, and UinofixaAniI-N, fem. with p {OunofuxaAnapN, UinofixaAnapN, OunofuxaAniy-apN and UinofixaAni-apN}, † A man full of fat; (Ḳ;) inflated with flaccid fat, and so rHl manofuwxN↓; pl. manofuwxuwan. (TA.)
minofaxN: see what follows.

minofaAxN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and minofaxN↓ (Mṣb) The instrument with which a fire is blown; (Mṣb, Ḳ:) a blacksmith's bellows: the thing with which a fire or other thing is blown: (L:) the thing into which one blows. (Ṣ.) See also kyrN
minofaAxu Alr-aAEiI The instrument [i. e. reed-pipe] of the pastor, with which he calls together the camels. (A, TA, voce XiyaAEN.)
manaAfixu AlX-ayoTaAni † The suggestions of the devil (TA.)
manofuwxN † Big-bellied; (Ḳ, TA;) [inflated in the belly].
Also, (Ḳ,) munotafixN↓, (TA,) ‡ Fat; as an epithet; (A, Ḳ;) [inflated, or swollen, with fat]. See OunofixaAnN.
manofuwxN ‡ A coward: so called because he swells out his lungs. (L.)
munotafixN ‡ A man inflated, or puffed, or filled, with pride, and with anger. (L.) See manofuwxN.

1. nafida, aor. _a {yanofadu}, inf. n. nafaAdN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nafadN, (L, Ḳ,) It (a thing, Ṣ, &c.) passed away and came to an end; became spent, exhausted, or consumed; failed entirely; ceased; syn. faniI (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and cahaba (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and AinoqaTaEa. (L, Mṣb.)

3. nAfdhu, (inf. n. munaAfadapN, L,) [He exerted his whole power, or ability, in contention, dispute, or litigation, with him: see munaAfidN:] he contended with him in arguments, pleas, or allegations, so as to put an end to his argument, and overcome him: (L:) or he contended with him before a judge; (IAth, L, Ḳ;) contended, disputed, or litigated with him. (Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., Uino naAfadotahumo naAfaduwk (Ṣ, L) If thou contend with them before a judge, they will so contend with thee: or if thou allege to them, they will allege to thee: (IAth, L;) but accord. to one relation, the verb is with q (Ṣ, L.) and accord. to another, the latter verb is with c, nAfcwk. (L.)

4. Anfdhu (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Astnfdhu↓ (A, L, Ḳ) and Antfdh↓ (Ḳ) He caused it to pass away or come to an end; spent, exhausted, or consumed, it; caused it to fail entirely; caused it to cease; made an end of it. (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
AnfdwA maA Einodahumo, and Astnfdwhu↓, They spent, exhausted, or consumed, what they had. (A, L.)
Astnfd↓ wusoEahu He spent, exhausted, or exerted, to the utmost his ability or power (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.)

Anfd Alaqowum The people came to that state that their travelling-provisions were exhausted, or had come to an end: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) or, (in the Ḳ, and,) their property had passed away and come to an end. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
Anfdt Alr-akiy-apu The well lost its water. (L, Ḳ.)
6. tnAfdwA They contended, disputed, or litigated, together. (A.) [See 3, and see also tnAfcwA, with c.]
8. Antfdhu: see 4,
He exacted, took, or received, it fully, or wholly (Ḳ)
Antfd mino Eadowihi He exacted the full, or utmost, rate of his running. Said with reference to a horse. (M, L.)
Antfd All-abana He drew forth the milk. (Ḳ.)

munaAfidN A man who exerts his whole power, or ability, in contention, dispute, or litigation, (Ṣ, L,) and who does so well, so as to put an end to the arguments, pleas, or allegations, of his adversary, and overcome him: (L:) who contends with his adversary in arguments, pleas, or allegations, so as to put an end to his argument. (A, L.) One says, layoXa lahu raAfidN walaA munaAfidN He has not an aider, or assistant, nor one who contends, &c. (A, TA.)
fiyhi munotafadN Eano gayorihi In him is that which renders thee in no need of any other. (Aboo-Saʼeed, T, L, Ḳ.*)
Uin-a fiI maAlihi lamunotafadN Verily in his wealth is ample provision. (AZ, T, L, Ḳ *)

tajadu fiI AlbilaAdi munotafadFA (in the TḲ mutanaf-adFA) Thou wilt find in the countries, or towns, a place to which to flee and in which to seek gain; syn. muraAgamFA wamuDoTarabFA (Ḳ.) See also munotafacN.
qaEada munotafidFA He set aside, or apart. (IAạr. L, Ḳ.)
1. nafaca, aor. _u {yanofucu}, (M, L,) inf. n. nafaAcN and nufuwcN, (M, L, Ḳ,) It went, or passed, through: (L:) or it went, or passed, through a thing, and became clear of it. (M, L, Ḳ.)
nafacotu I went, or passed, through. (L.)

nafaca Als-ahomu, aor. _u {yanofucu}, inf. n. nufuwcN and nafaAcN, The arrow perforated, transpierced, or pierced through, the animal at which it was shot, and went forth from it: (Mṣb:) or nafaca Als-ahomu Alr-amiy-apa, (M, L,) and nafaca minohaA, (Ṣ, L,) and fiyhaA, (M, A, L,) aor. _u {yanofucu}, (M, L,) inf. n. nafaAcN (M, A, L, Ḳ) and nufuwcN (A) and nafocN, (M, L, Ḳ,) the arrow penetrated into the inside of the animal at which it was shot, and its extremity went forth from the other side, or protruded from it, the rest remaining therein; the extremity of the arrow passed through the animal at which it was shot, the rest remaining therein; (M, L, Ḳ;) a part of the arrow passed through, or went forth or protruded from, the animal at which it was shot. (A, art. Srd.) See sahomN naAficN
nafacati AlT-aEonapu The wound made by a spear or the like passed through, or beyond, the other side (T, L.)
Aunofuco Eanoka Go thou from thy place; pass thou from it. (L.) [See also Eano.]
nafaca liwajohihi He went his way. (TA.)
nafad AlT-ariyqu ‡ The road was [a thoroughfare (see naAficN)] pervious, or passable, to every one in common. (Mṣb.)
hecaA AlT-ariyqu yanofudu UilaI makaAni kacaA [This road is a thoroughfare, along which every one may pass, to such a place]. (T, M,* L.)
nafaca Alamonzilu UilaI AlT-ariyqi ‡ The house, or abode, [was a thoroughfare, and] communicated with the road. (Mṣb.)
nafaca Alqawoma He passed through the people, and left them behind him; (T, M, L, Ḳ;) as also Oanofacahumo↓; (L, Ḳ;) or only the former is used in this sense (L.) See also the latter.

nafcahumu AlbaSaru ‡ The sight reached them, and extended beyond them: (Ks, L:) or, extended over them all: (AʼObeyd, L:) you say also, Oanofacahumu↓ AlbaSaru in the former sense (L:) [or The sight penetrated into the midst of them: see Oanofaca Alqawoma.]
nafaca raOoyuhu † His judgment was penetrating; syn. vafaba. (Ḳ in art vfb)
nafaca fiI AlOamori ‡ He acted, or went on, with penetrative energy, or with sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in the affair; syn. maDaI (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. mDI.)
nafaca AlkitaAbu UilaI fulaAnK, inf. n. nafaAcN and nufuwcN, ‡ [The letter passed to, came to, or reached, such a one]: (Ṣ, L:) [and in like manner, Alr-asuwlu the messenger: see 4.]
nafaca AlOamoru,and Alqawolu, † The command, or order, and the saying, was effectual; had effect; was, or became, executed, or performed; syn. maDaI. (Mṣb.)

nafaca AlEitoqu † [The act of emancipation had, or took effect; was, or became, executed. or performed; and in like manner, a covenant, contract, sale, &c.: see 4]. App. a met. expression, from nufuwcu Als-ahomi; because there is no retracting it. (Mṣb.)
yanofudu bayonanaA ‡ He shall judge between us, and make his command or order to have effect, or execute or perform it. (L.)
lahu nafaAcN fiI AlOumuwri ‡ [He has ability in affairs, to execute, or perform]. (A.)
2: see 4.

3. nAfchu † He cited him before a judge. It is said in a trad., An naAfacotahumo naAfacuwka If thou cite them before a judge, they will do the same to thee; meaning, If thou say to them, they will say to thee. Accord. to one relation, the verb is with q and d. (L.) [Accord. to another, it is with f and c.]

4. Anfc Als-ahoma, (A, Mṣb,) and nf-chu↓, (Mṣb,) He made the arrow to pierce, and go forth from, or to pass through, the animal at which it was shot: (Mṣb:) [or, to penetrate within the animal at which it was shot, and to protrude its extremity from the other side, the rest remaining within; accord. to the explanation of nafaca Als-ahomu in the M, L, Ḳ: or to penetrate the animal at which it was shot, and to protrude a part of it from the other side; accord. to the explanation of sahomN naAficN in the A, art. Srd.] You say also, Oanofacotu fiyhi Als-ahoma [I made the arrow to pierce, or penetrate, him, &c.] (A.)
ramayotuhu faOanofacotuhu I shot, or cast, at him, and pierced, or made a hole, through him. (Mgh.)
See 1.
Anfc AlOamora † [He brought to pass the command, or order; made it effectual; made it to have effect; executed or performed it: and in like manner, the saying: see 1].
† He executed, performed, or accomplished, the affair. (M, L, Ḳ.)

Anfc Alqawoma He became [or entered] among the people: (M, L:) in the copies of the Ḳ, explained by SaAra minohumo; but the correct reading is bayonahumo [as in the M and L]: (TA:) or he penetrated into them, and went, or walked, in the midst of them. (T, L, Ḳ.) See also nafaca Alqawoma.

Anfc kitaAbFA UilaI fulaAnK; (Ṣ, L;) and nf-chu↓, (A,) inf. n. tanofiycN; (Ṣ, L;) ‡ [He sent, or transmitted, a letter to such a one; caused it to pass to or to reach him]: and in like manner, rasuwlFA a messenger. (A.)
Anfc Eahodahu, inf. n. UinofaAcN † He made his covenant, or contract, or the like, to take effect; executed or performed it: [and in like manner, an act of emancipation: see 1.] (L, TA.)

6. tanaAfacuwA Uilayohi † They came to him, (namely, a judge,) and referred to him their cause, or suit, for judgment. When each party adduces his plea, or allegation, one says tnAfdwA, with d, unpointed. (Aboo-Saʼeed, T, L, Ḳ.*)

TaEonapN lahaA nafacN i. q. TaEonapN naAficapN; (Ṣ;) A wound having a passage through the other side; by nafacN being meant manofacN, or nufuwcN: (T, L:) pl. OanofaAcN. (A.) Keys Ibn-El-Khateem says (see Ḥam. p. 85),
TaEanotu Qbona Eabodi Alqayosi TaEonapa vaAYirK
lahaA nafacN lawolaA AlX-aEaAEu OaDaACahaA
(T, Ṣ, L) I pierced the son of ʼAbd-El-Keys with the wound of one making an angry assault, that had a passage through, which, but for the spirtling blood, would have made it show the light through him. (T, L [See also XuEaAEN.]) See also manofacN.

nafacN ‡ A place, or way, or means, of exit, escape, or safety; syn. maxorajN (T, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.) So in the saying OataI binafaci maA qaAla ‡ He effected a means of escape from [the natural consequences of] what he had said; i. e., biAlmaxoraji minohu. (T, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.) It occurs in a trad., where it is said, that unless a man who has published against a Muslim a charge of which he is clear do this, he is to be punished. (T, L.)

nafacN a subst., (M, L,) used in the sense of UinofaAcN: (T, M, L, Ḳ:*) nafacN OamorK signifying † [The making a command, or order, effectual; making it to have effect; to be executed or performed;] i. q. UinofaAcuhu: (T, L:) you say, Oamara binafacihi † [He commanded that it should have effect, or be executed or performed;] i. e., biUinofaAcihi: (M, L:) and qAm Almusolimuwna binafaci AlkitaAbi † [The Muslims accomplished the execution, or performance, of what was in the Scripture:] i. e. bUinfaAci maA fiyhi. (T, A, L.)
nafuwcN: see naAficN.
OamorN nafiycN † An affair arranged, or made easy. (L.) See also naAficN.
naf-aAcN: see naAficN.

sahomN naAficN [An arrow that perforates, transpierces, or pierces through, and goes forth from, or passes through, the animal at which it is shot; accord. to the explanation of the verb in the Mṣb: or, that penetrates into the inside of the animal at which it is shot, and of which the extremity goes forth from the other side, or protrudes from it, the rest remaining therein; accord. to the explanation of the verb in the M, L, Ḳ: or,] of which a part has passed through the animal at which it is shot: when the extremity only has passed through, it is termed SAridN; and when the whole of it has passed through, maAriqN. (A, art. Srd.)
TaEonapN naAficapN A wound made by a spear or the like passing through both sides: (M, L:) pl. TaEanaAtN nawaAficu. (A.) See also nafacN.
TariyqN naAficN ‡ A road which is a thoroughfare; (T, M, L, Ḳ;) [pervious;] not stopped up; (T, L;) along which every one may pass. (T, A, L, Mṣb.) See also manofacN.

naAficN sing. of nawaAficu, (Mṣb,) which signifies All the holes, or perforations, by which joy or grief is conveyed to the mind (of a man, Mṣb); as the two ear-holes, (IAạr, on the authority of Abu-l-Mekárim, T, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the two nostrils, and the mouth, and the anus: (IAạr, T, L, Ḳ:*) called by the doctors of practical law manaAficu, which is contr. to analogy: see manofacN. (Mṣb.)

naAficN and nafuwcN↓ and naf-aAcN↓ [but the second and third are intensive epithets] ‡ A man (M, L) penetrating, or acting with a penetrative energy, or sharp, energetic, vigorous, and effective, (maADK,) in all his affairs. (M, L, Ḳ.)
rajulN naAficN fiI Oamorihi ‡ A man penetrating, or acting with a penetrative energy, or sharp, vigorous, and effective, in his affair; (Ṣ, L;) and fI AlOumuwri in affairs. (A.)
Oamoruhu naAficN † His command, or order, is effectual; has effect; is executed, or performed; syn. maADK (Ḳ;) and obeyed; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as also nafiycN↓. (Ḳ.)
daAYirapN naAficapN A feather, or curl of hair in a horse's coat, of the kind which, when it is only on one side, is called haqoEapN, but which is on both sides. (AO, T, L.)
caA manofacu Alqawomi, and nafacuhomu↓; and hecihi manaAficuhumo, and OanofaAcuhumo, [This is the place of passage of the people, and these are their places of passage]. (A.)
hecaA AlT-ariyqu manofacN limaHal-i kacaA ‡ This road is a way along which every one may pass to such a place. (A.)
fiyhi manofacN llqawomi ‡ In it (the road) is a [free, or an open,] passage to, or for, the people. (T, L.) See also naAficN.

manoficN, in measure like masojidN, [or manofacN, agreeably with analogy, as it is written in copies of the T, A, L,] A place by which a thing passes through; [a thoroughfare; an outlet; a place of egress:] pl. manaAficu. (Mṣb.) See also naAficN.

munotafacN † Ample room, space, or scope, or liberty to act, &c.: (syn. saEapN, (M, L, Ḳ, TA,) and manoduwHapN: TA:) [ample means of escape: see also nafacN:] you say, Uin-a fiI celika lamunotafacFA Verily in that there is ample room, scope, or means [for action, or for escape]. (TA.) See also munotafadN.

1. nafara, (T, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanofiru}, (T, M, Ḳ,) and _u, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. naforN and nafaraAnN (M, Ḳ) or nufuwrN, (Mṣb,) said of a wild animal, (T, Mṣb,) a gazelle, (M, Ḳ,) or other beast, (M,) He took fright, and fled, or ran away at random; or became refractory, and went away at random; or ran away, or broke loose, and went hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness; syn. Xarada; (M, Ḳ;) as also Astnfr↓; (T, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so the former verb in speaking of a camel, or a beast: (L, art. Xrd:) you say, nafarati Ald-aAb-apu, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanofiru} and _u {yanofuru}, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. nufuwrN and nifaArN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and naforN: (A:) or this signifies the beast was, or became, impatient (A, Ḳ, TA) of or at a thing, (TA,) [or shied at it,] and retired to a distance; (A, Ḳ, TA;) and UisotinofaArN↓ signifies the same as nufuwrN: (Ṣ:) or nafara, inf. n. nifaArN [and nufuwrN], signifies he fled, and went away or aside or apart or to a distance. (M.)

[Hence, nafara, aor. _i {yanofiru} and _u {yanofuru}, inf. n. nufuwrN and nifaArN and naforN and nafiyrN, as used in the following phrases.] nafarotu mino hecaA AlOamori ‡ I shrank from this thing or affair; was averse from it; did not like or approve it. And nafara fulaAnN mino SuHobapi fulaAnK ‡ [Such a one shrank, or was averse, from the companionship of, or the associating with, such a one]. And nafarati AlmaroOapu mino zawojihaA ‡ [The woman was averse from her husband; or shunned or avoided him]. (All from the A.) And you say of a man's disposition, tanaf-ara↓ Eani AlHaq-i ‡ [It shunned, or was averse from, the truth] (Bḍ, lxvii. 21.)
Uil-aA nufuwrFA, in the Ḳur, [xvii. 43, and xxxv. 40,] means ‡ Save in aversion and nafiyrN is like nufuwrN: and the subst. is nafarN, with two fet-ḥahs. (Mṣb)
nafara AlX-aIoCu mina AlX-aIoCi inf. n. nifaArN [and nufuwrN], The thing receded, withdrew, removed, or became remote or aloof, from the thing. (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ.) [See also 3.]

Hence it is, I think, that nafara is used as signifying ‡ It became swollen, in the following words of a trad. of ʼOmar: taxal-ala rajulN fiI zamaAnihi biAlqaSabi fanafara fuwhu ‡ A man, in his time, picked his teeth with reeds, and in consequence his mouth became swollen: as though the flesh, disliking the disease, receded from it, and so became swollen. (AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ.*) You say also, nafarati AlEayonu, aor. _i {yanofiru} and _u {yanofuru}, inf. n. nufuwrN. ‡ His eye became inflamed and swollen: and so you say of other parts of the person. (M, Ḳ.*) And nafara AljuroHu, inf. n. as above, ‡ The wound became swollen: (T, Mṣb:) or it became so after healing. (W, i. 42.) And nafara Aljilodu ‡ The skin became swollen, (Ṣ, A,) and the flesh receded from it. (A.) [All these significations seem to be derived from the first in this art.: and so several others which follow.]
nafarotu UilaI Qll-ehi, inf. n. nifaArN, I betook myself to God by reason of fear, seeking protection. (IḲṭṭ)

nafaruwA, (Mṣb,) inf. n. naforN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) They became separated, or dispersed: (M,* Mṣb, Ḳ:*) and so nafarto, said of camels. (TA.) Hence, (M,) the saying, laqiytuhu qabola kul-i SayoHK wanaforK, (Ṣ, M, A.) a proverb, in which the last word is used tropically; (A;) explained in art. SyH, q. v. (Ṣ.) [And gaDiba mino gayori SayoHK walaA nafKro; explained in the same art.]

nafara AlHaAj-u mino minFI, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanofiru}, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. naforN (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nafarN (M) and nufuwrN (Ḳ) [and nafiyrN], The pilgrims removed from Minè. (Mṣb.) Hence, yawomu Aln-afori, and Aln-afari, and Aln-afuwri, and Aln-afiyri, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and layolapu Aln-afori, (Ṣ, TA,) and Aln-afari, (TA,) [The day of, and the night immediately preceding, the removing from Minè]; after the day called yawomu Alqar-i: (Ṣ;) [therefore. the twelfth of Dhu-l-Hijjeh:] or there are two days thus called: (Mṣb:) yawomu Aln-afori AlOaw-alu is [the day above mentioned,] the second of the days called Oay-aAmu Alt-aXoriyqi; (IAth, Mṣb;) and yawomu Aln-afor AlA-xiru, (IAth,) or Alv-aAniI, (Mṣb,) is the third thereof: (IAth, Mṣb:) the order is this; yawomu Aln-aHori, then yawomu Alqar-i, then yawomu Aln-afor AlOaw-alu then yawomu Aln-afori AlMxiru. (T, L)

nafaruwA fiI AlOamori, (Ṣ, M.) or liloOamori, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanofiru}. (M, Ḳ.) inf. n. nufuwrN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and nifArN (M, Ḳ) and nafiyrN; (Zj, M, Ḳ;) and tnAfrwA↓; (M, Ḳ;) They went, or went away, to execute the affair: (M, Ḳ:) and in like manner, fiI AlqitaAli to fight. (M.) And naqaruwA, alone, They went forth to war against unbelievers or the like. So in the Ḳur, is 82. waqaAlwA laA tanofiruwA fI AlHr-i qulo naArN jahan-ama OaXadN Har-aA [And they said, Go not ye forth to war against the unbelievers in the heat: say, The fire of hell is hotter]: and so in the same chap. v. 39: (Jel:) and in the same book, iv. 73. (Bḍ.) You say also, nafaruwA lahumo They went forth to fight them. (TA, from a trad.) And tafaruwA UilI AlHarob They hastened to the war, or to war. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] nafawuA maEahu; and Oanofaruwhu↓, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UinofaArN; (TA;) They aided and succoured them: (M, Ḳ:) or the former verb, alone, they, being asked to do so, complied, and went forth to aid. (TA.)
nafrabinaA: see 2.

2. naf-r, (T, M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. tanofyrN; (Mṣb;) and Anfr↓; (T, Ḳ;) and AXtnfr↓; (T, M, A, Mṣb;) He made (wild animals, T. Mṣb, or an antelope. Ḳ, or a beast of carriage. M,) to take fright, and flee, or run away at random: (Ḳ, TA:) or he made a beast of carriage to become impatient, and to retire to a distance: (A:) or he scared away; or made to flee, and go away, or aside, or apart, or to a distance: (so accord. to an explanation of the intrans. v. from which it is derived, in the M:) you say naf-arotuhu and Aisotanofarotuhu↓ and Oanofarutuhu↓: and in like manner, naf-ara Eanohu, and Oanofara Eanohu, [meaning, he scared away, or made to take fright and flee,, &c., from him or it:] (TA:) AlUinofaAru Eani AlX-aIoCi, and Alt-anofiyru Eanohu, and AlAisotinofaAru, all signify the same, [i. e., the scaring away,, &c. from a thing.] (Ṣ.) It is said in a trad. of Zeyneb, the daughter of Moḥammad, faOanofara bihaA AlmuXorikuwna baEiyrahaA Hat-aI saqaTato And the polytheists made her camel to take fright and run away at random with her, so that she fell. And in like manner you say, OunofirabinaA, and nufirabinaA, [or nuf-arabinaA Our camels were scared away with us; or made to take fright and run away at random with us: or] we were made to be persons having camels taking fright and running away at random. And tanofiyrN signifies The chiding camels or sheep or goats, and driving them from the pasturage. (TA.)

[Hence] baX-irwA walA tunaf-iruwA † [Rejoice people by what ye say. and] do not encounter them with [roughness and violence and] that which will incite them to nufuwr [i. e. flight or aversion]. (TA.) See the act. part. n., below.

[Hence also,] naf-iro Eanohu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tasnofiyrN. (TA.) † Give thou to him a laqab [meaning a nickname or name of reproach], (Ṣ,) or a laqb that is disliked: (Ḳ:) as though they held such to be tasofiyrN lilojin-i waAlEayoni Eanohu [a means of scaring away the jinn, or genii, and the evil eye, from him]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) An Arab of the desert said, When I was born, it was said to my father, naf-iro Eanohu: so he named me qunofud [hedge-hog], and surnamed me Oabw AlEad-MCi [father of the quick runner]. (Ṣ.)
3. [naAfaraA, inf. n. munaAfarapN, ‡ They shunned or avoided each other; regarded each other with aversion. But perhaps this signification is only post-classical.]
[And hence, ‡ They (two things) were incongruous, or discordant, each with the other. But perhaps this signification, also, is only post-classical. See also 6.]
4. Oanofara see 2, in several places.
OanofaruwA Their camels took fright and ran away at random, (nafarat, Ḳ, TA,) and became separated or dispersed. (TA.)
See also 1, last signification.
5. tnf-r Eani AlHaq-i: see 1.
6. [tnAfrwA ‡ They shunned or avoided one another; regarded one another with aversion. But perhaps this signification is only post-classical.]
[And hence, tnAfrt AlOaXoyaMCu ‡ The things were incongruous, or discordant, one with another. But perhaps this signification, also, is only post-classical. See also 3.]
tnAfrwA fiI AlOamori, or liloOamori: see 1, towards the end. See also tanaAfaraA in the Ḳ: and compare 6 in arts. nfd and nfc.

10. Uisotanofarahumo He (the Imám) incited, and summoned or invited them to go forth, lijihaAdi AlEaduw-i to war against the enemy: (T, Mgh:) or imposed upon them the task of going forth to war, light and heavy: [see Ḳur, ix. 41:] (A:) or he demanded, sought, or desired, of them aid. (M,* Ḳ, TA.)
See also 2. in three places.
And see 1, in two places, near the beginning.
naforN: see naAfirN, of which it is a quasi-pl.:
and nafiyrN:
and nafarN.

niforN an imitative sequent to EiforN, (T, M, Ḳ,) and so is nafirN↓ to EafirN, (Ṣgh, Ḳ, but omitted in some copies of the Ḳ,) and niforiyapN↓ to EiforiyapN, (T, M, Ḳ,) and niforiytN↓ to EiforiytN, (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and nufaAriyapN↓ to EufaAriyahN, (T, M, Ḳ,) and niforiytapN↓ to EifriytapN; (Ḳ;) denoting corroboration. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense:
nafarN A number of men, from three to ten; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also naforN↓ and naforapN↓ and nafiyrN↓: (Ṣ:) or to seven: (so in a copy of the Mṣb, [but probably sbEp is a mistake for tsEp nine: this appears likely from what here follows:]) or a number of men less then ten; (AZ, T, M, Ḳ;) as also nafiyrN↓; (Ḳ;) and so rahoTN; (AZ, T;) and some add, excluding women: (TA:) accord. to Fr, (Ṣ,) a man's people or tribe consisting of his nearer relations; as also naforapN↓; syn. rahoTN, (Ṣ, IAth,) and EaXiyrapN: (IAth:) [see also naforapN:] accord. to Kr, (M,) all the men or people: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, you say, heWulaMCi EaXarapu nafarK, i. e. these are ten men: but one does not say, EiXoruwna nafarFA, nor more than EaXarap: and Abu-l- ʼAbbás says, that nafarN, like qawomN and rahoTN, has a pl. signification, without any proper sing.; and is applied to men, exclusively of women: (T:) it is a quasi-pl. n.: (TA:) and its pl. is OanofaArN; (M, Ḳ;) occurring in a trad., in the phrase OaHadN mino OanofaArinaA, which IAth explains as meaning any one of our people; syn. qawominaA: (TA:) and nafiyrN↓, occurring, in the accus. case, in the Ḳur, xvii. 6, is, accord. to Zj, a pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of nafarN, like EabiydN and kaliybN. (M.) [See also nafiyrN, below.] Imra-el-Keys says, describing a man as an excellent archer,
fahowa laA tanomiI ramiy-atuhu
maA lahu laA Eud-a mino nafariho , (Ṣ,) And he is such that the animal shot by him does not go away after it has been shot and then die. What aileth him? May he be killed, so as not to be numbered among his people. The latter hemistich is a proverb. (Meyd.) The poet here utters an imprecation against the man, but in so doing praises him; as when you say, of a man whose action pleases you, maA lahu qaAtalahu Qll-ehu and OaxozaAhu Qll-ehu [q. v.]. (Ṣ.) The rel. n. is nafariI-N↓. (Sb, M.)
[Accord. to the Mṣb, it is also a simple subst. from nafara: and app. as signifying especially Aversion.]

entry.sense: nafirN: see niforN.
naforapN: see nafiyrN.

A man's near kinsmen; syn. OusorapN (T, Ḳ) and faSiylapN; (Ḳ;) who are angry on account of his anger; (Ḳ;) as also nuforapN↓, mentioned by Ṣgh and others, (TA,) and nufuwrpN↓ (T. Ḳ) and naAfirapN↓ (A,* Ḳ) and nafarN↓: (T:) and nufuwrapN signifies a man's near kinsmen (Ousorap) who go forth with him to war when an event befalls him or oppresses him severely or suddenly. (TA.) You say, jaMCanaA fiI naforatihi and nafarihi↓, (T, TA,), &c., (TA,) He came to us among his near kinsmen, (T, TA,), &c. (TA.) And, galabato nufuwratunaA nufuwratahumo Our near kinsmen overcame their near kinsmen. (T, TA.) See also nafarN, in two places: and see nafiyrN.

hom.sense: nuforapN (Ṣgh, Ḳ) and nufarapN↓ (Ḳ) A thing that is hung upon a child for fear of, (Ḳ,) or to repel, (Ṣgh,) the evil eye. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
See also naforapN.

entry.sense: nafariI-N: see nafarN, last sentence but one.
niforiyapN and niforiytN and niforiytapN: see niforN.

nifaArN a subst. from nafarati Ald-aAb-apu. Ex. fiI Ald-aAb-api nifaArN [In the beast of carriage is a disposition to take fright and run away at random]. (Ṣ.) And in like manner, from nafara said of a wild animal. (Mṣb.)
nafuwrN: see naAfirN.

nafiyrN A people hastening to war, or to some other undertaking: an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Mṣb:) or a people going to execute an affair: (Ṣ:) or a people going with one to fight; as also naforapN↓ [q. v.] and naforN↓: (M, Ḳ:) each is a noun having a pl. signification: (M:) or the first and last signify a company of men: and the pl. of each is OanofaArN: (M:) or the first, (Ṣ,) or all, (Ḳ,) a people, (Ṣ,) or company, (Ḳ,) preceding in an affair: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the first, those of a man's people who go forth with him to war: or it is a pl. [or quasi-pl.] of nafarN, signifying men assembled to go to the enemy: (Bḍ, xvii. 6:) or aiders, or assistants. (M.) [See nafarN, in two places.] You say, jaMCato naforapu baniI fulaAnK, and nafiyruhumo, The company of the sons of such a one, that came forth to execute an affair, arrived. (Ṣ, TA.) nafiyru qurayoXK means Those of Kureysh who went forth to Bedr to defend the caravan of Aboo-Sufyán, (M,) which was coming from Syria. (T.) Hence the proverb, fulaAnN laA fiI AlEiyri walaA fiI Aln-afiyri [Such a one is neither in the caravan nor in the company going forth to fight]: applied to him who is not regarded as fit for a difficult undertaking: because none held back from the caravan and the fight except him who was crippled by disease and him in whom was no good; (TA:) or the original words of the proverb are lA fiI AlEiyri walaA fiI Aln-afiyri: and these words were first said by Aboo-Sufyán, with reference to the Benoo-Zuhrah, when he found them turning back towards Mekkeh; and, accord. to Aṣ, are applied to a man who is held in low and little repute. (Mgh.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 500.]
nufuwrapN: see naforapN, in three places.
nufaAriyapN: see niforN.

naAfirN [and nafuwrN↓] and musotanofirN↓ signify the same; [i. e., Taking fright, and fleeing, or running away at random: or being, or becoming, impatient, of or at a thing, and retiring to a distance: or fleeing, and going away or aside or apart or to a distance: or the second, being of an intensive form, signifies, as also yanofuwrN↓, that does so much or often; or wont or apt to do so:] (TA:) and naforN is a pl. of naAfirN, (Ḳ,) or [rather] a quasi-pl., like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN, and zaworN of zaAYirN. (M.) You say, daAb-apN naAfirN, and nafuwrN↓, [A beast that takes fright and runs away at random:, &c.:] (M, Ḳ:) accord. to IAạr, one should not say naAfirapN (M) [unless using it as an epithet applied to a broken pl. of a subst., as will be seen below]. It is said in a proverb, kul-u Oazab-a nafuwrN↓ [Every one, of camels, that is hairy on the face is wont to take fright and run away at random: see art. zb]. (M.) You say also ZaboIN yanofuwrN↓, (M, Ḳ,*) in some copies of the Ḳ, nyfwr, (TA,) A gazelle that takes fright and flees much or often; or that is wont to do so. (M, Ḳ.*) And it is said in the Ḳur, [lxxiv. 51,] kaOan-ahumo HumurN musotanofirapN↓ far-ato mino qasowarapK, i. e., naAfirapN, [As though they were asses taking fright and running away at random, that have fled from a lion:] and (accord. to one reading, T) musotanofarapN↓, (T, Ṣ,) meaning, made to take fright and run away at random; (T;) or frightened, or scared. (Ṣ.)

OanaA naAfirN mino hecaA AlAmr ‡ I shrink from this thing or affair; am averse from it; do not like or approve it. And hiIa naAfirapN mino zawojihaA ‡ [She is averse from her husband; she shuns or avoids him]. (A.)
nawofarN: see art. nylwfr.
naAfirapN: see naforapN.
munaf-irN act. part. n. of 2, q. v.
† One who encounters people with roughness and violence [and that which incites them to flight or aversion: see 2]. (TA, from a trad.)
musotanofirN: see naAfirN, in two places.
musotanofarN: see naAfirN.
yanofuwrN: see naAfirN, in two places.

1. nafaza, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanofizu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. nafazaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nafozN (Mṣb, TA) and nufuwzN, (TA,) He (an antelope) leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also nf-z↓: (A:) or did so in his running: (Aṣ, TA:) or did so and alighted with his legs spread: when he alights with his legs together, the action is termed qafozN: (TA:) or did so after putting his legs together: (AZ, TA:) or leaped upwards with all his legs at once and put them down without separating them: (Mṣb:) or raised his legs together and put them down together: or ran at the utmost vehement rate of the running termed UiHoDaAr. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2: see 1.
nf-zhu, (Ḳ,) or nf-zthu, (Ṣ, A,) He, or she, danced, or dandled, him, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) namely, a child; (Ṣ, A;) as also nq-zth. (TA, art. nqz.)

entry.sense: 6. tnAfzwA They (children) contended together in leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding, in play. (A, Ḳ.)
