nafozapN An antelope's running by reason of fright. (AA, TA.)
nafuwzN (Ṣ) and yanofuwzN↓ (Ḳ) An antelope that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [in one or other of the manners described above,] much, or vehemently. (TA.)
naAfizapN, sing. of nawaAfizu, (TA,) which signifies The legs of a beast of carriage: (Ḳ, TA:) but the word commonly known is nawaAqizu, with q. (TA.)
yanofuwzN: see nfwz.

hom.sense: 1. nafusa, aor. _u {yanofusu}, inf. n. nafaAsapN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nifaAsN and nafsN (Ḳ) and nufuwsN; (TA;) and Oanofasa↓, (M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. UinofaAsN; (A, Mṣb;) It was, or became, high in estimation, of high account, or excellent; (M, Mṣb, TA;) [highly prized; precious, or valuable;] and therefore, (TA,) was desired with emulation, or in much request: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and ↓the latter verb, said of property, it was, or became, loved, and highly esteemed. (TA.)

nafisa bihi, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanofasu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. nafasN (M) [and app. nafosN as will be shown below] and nafaAsapN and nafaAsiyapN, which last is extr., (M, TA,) He was, or became avaricious, tenacious, or niggardly, of it, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) because of its being in high estimation, or excellent. (Mṣb.) Hence the saying in the Ḳur, [xlvii. 40,] faUin-amaA yaboxalu Eano nafosihi [app. meaning He is only avaricious from his avarice.] (TA.) You say, nafisa Ealayohi biAlX-aIoCi, (M,) or Eanohu [in the place of Elyh], (TA,) He was, or became, avaricious,, &c., of the thing, towards him, or withholding it from him. (M, TA.) And nafisa Ealayohi AlX-aIoCa, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA,) and biAlX-aIoCi, (M,) inf. n. nafaAsapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) He was, or became, avaricious,, &c., of the thing, towards him, and thought him not worthy of it, and was not pleased at its coming to him: (TA:) or [simply] he thought him not worthy of it: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also nAfshu↓ fiyhi; of which last verb we have an ex. in the phrase tunaAfisu dunoyaA, used by a poet in speaking of the tribe of Kureysh, meaning either tunaAfisu fiI dunobaA [they think others not worthy of worldly good]. or tunaAfsu Oahola dunoyaA [they think the possessors of worldly good unworthy thereof]. (M.) [See also 3, below.] You say also, nafisota EalaI-a bixayorK, (A, Ḳ,) or bixayorK qaliyl, (Ṣ,) and nafisota EalaI-a xayorFA kaviyrFA, (A,) inf. n. nafosN and nafaAsapN, (A,) Thou enviedst me (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) good, (A, Ḳ,) or a little good, (Ṣ,) and much good, (A.) and didst not consider me worthy of it. (A.) And fulaAnN maA yatanag-asu EalayonaA Alganiymapa waAlZ-afara [app. meaning Such a one does not envy us the spoil and the victory.] (A, in continuation of what here immediately precedes.) And maA hecaA Aln-afasu What is this envying? (A, TA.)

nufisato; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and nafisato, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) as some of the Arabs say, (Mṣb.) aor. _a {yanofasu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ:) inf. n. nifaAsN and nifaAspN (Ṣ, M) and nafasN, (M, TA,) or the first of these ns. is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) ‡ She (a woman) brought forth; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) and nufisato waladFA [she brought forth a child]: (Th, M:) and nufisato biwaladihaA [she brought forth her child]. (A.) You say also, wariv fulaAnN hecaA qabola Oano yanofasa fulaAnN, meaning, Such a one inherited this before such a one was born. (Ṣ.)

Also, both these verbs, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the latter, nafisato, only, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or the latter is the more common, (Ḳ.) the former, which is related on the authority of Aṣ, not being well known, (Mṣb,) ‡ She (a woman) menstruated. (Az, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [In the CK, a confusion is made by the omission of a w before the verb which explains this last signification.] This signification and that next preceding it are from nafosN meaning “blood.” (Mgh.)
nafasotuhu binafosi ‡ I smote him with an [evil or envious] eye. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
2. nf-shu fiyhi, or bihi: see 4.

nf-s kurobatahu, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and nf-s Eanohu kurobatahu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tanofiysN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [quasi-inf. n.] nafasN, (Ḳ,) ‡ He (God) removed, or cleared away, his grief, or sorrow, or anxiety: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ *:) and nf-s Eanohu signifies the same; (M, Mgh;) and He made his circumstances ample and easy; (M, TA;) and he (a man) eased him, or relieved him, syn. raf-aha: (Ṣ, TA:) and also, this last phrase, he granted him a delay: the objective compliment being omitted: and naf-isoniI is used as meaning grant thou to me a delay: or, elliptically, naf-iso karobiI or gam-iI [remove thou my grief,, &c.]. (Mgh.)

[Hence] Harofu tanofiysK, applied to the prefix sa [and its variants sawofa, &c.], meaning A particle of amplification; because changing the aor. from the strait time which is the present, to the ample time, which is the future. (Mughnee, in art. s.)
nf-s Alqawosa ‡ He cracked the bow: (Kr. M:) [see 5:] accord. to ISh, he put (HaT-a) its string [upon the bow]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. nAfs fiI AlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) inf. n. munaAfasapN and nifaAsN, (Ṣ,) He desired the thing, [or aspired to it.] with generous emulation; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tnAfs↓: (Ḳ:) and nAfs SaAHibahu fiyhi [he vied with his companion in desire for it]: (A:) or tnAfswA↓ fyh signifies they desired it [or aspired to it]: (Ṣ:) or they vied, one with another, in desiring it: or they desired it with emulation; syn. farAgabawA: (A, TA:) [and yunanaAfsu fyh it is emulously desired, or in request; or in great request:] or munaAfasahN and tanaAfusN↓ signify the desiring to have a thing, and to have it for himself exclusively of any other person; from nafiysN, signifying a thing “good, or goodly, or excellent, in its kind:” (TA:) and tanaAfasonaA celika AlOamora and tnAfsnA fyh we envied one another for that thing, and strove for priority in attaining it. (M.) See also nafisa Ealayohi AlX-aIoCa, with which naAfasahu fiyhi is syn. (M.)

hom.sense: 4. Anfs: see nafusa, in two places.
Anfshu It (a thing, TA) pleased him, (Ḳ, TA,) and made him desirous of it: (TA:) or became highly esteemed by him. (IḲṭṭ.)
OanofasanI fiyhi He made me desirous of it; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) as also taf-asaniI fyh, (IAạr, M, TA,) or bihi. (So in my copy of the A.)
maA Oanofasahu How powerful is his evil, or envious, eye! (Lḥ, M.)

5. tnf-s [He breathed] is said of a man and of every animal having lungs: (Ṣ:) [or it signifies] he drew (Aisotamad-a) breath: (M:) or [he respired, i. e.] he drew breath with the air-passages in his nose; to his inside, and emitted it. (Mṣb.) You say also, tnf-s AlS-uEadaMCa [He sighed: see also art. SEd]. (Ṣ.)
‡ He (a man) emitted wind from beneath him. (TA.)

Also, (TA,) or tnf-s fiI AlUinaMCi, (Ḳ,) ‡ He drank (Ḳ, TA) from the vessel (TA) with three restings between draughts, and separated the vessel from his mouth at every such resting: (Ḳ, TA.) and, contr., the latter phrase, † he drank [from the vessel] without separating it from his mouth: (Ḳ, TA:) which latter mode of drinking is disapproved. (TA.)
Also tnf-s † He lengthened in speech; he spoke long; for when a speaker takes breath, it is easy to him to lengthen his speech; and tnfs fiI AlkalaAmi signifies the same. (TA.)

‡ It (said of the day, M, A, and of the dawn, A, and of other things, M) became extended; (M;) it became long; (M, A;) or, said of the day, accord. to Lḥ, it advanced so that it became noon: (M:) or it increased: (Ṣ:) and it extended far: and hence it is said of life, meaning either it became protracted, and extended far, or it became ample: (M:) and, said of the dawn, it shone forth, (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and extended so that it became clear day: (Fr, TA:) or it broke, so that things became plain in consequence of it: (TA:) or it rose: (Mujáhid:) or its dusty hue shone at the approach of a gentle wind. (Bḍ, lxxxi. 18.) You say also, tnf-s bihi AlEumuru ‡ [Life became long, or protracted,, &c., with him]. (A.) And tnf-st dijolapu † The water of the Tigris increased. (TA.)
tnf-s Almawoju ‡ The waves sprinkled the water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
tnf-st Alqawosu ‡ The bow cracked. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) It is only the stick that is not split in twain that does so; and this is the best of bows. And tnf-s in the same sense is said of an arrow. (M.)
[tnf-s Ealayohi AlX-aIoCa app. signifies the same as nafisa Elyh AlXIC, q. v.]

entry.sense: 6: see 3, throughout.

hom.sense:
nafosN The soul; the spirit; the vital principle; syn. ruwHN: (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) but between these two words is a difference [which must be fully explained hereafter, though ISd says, that it is not of the purpose of his book, the M, to explain it]: (M:) in this sense it is fem.: (Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OanofusN and [of mult.] nufuwsN. (M, Mṣb.) You say, xarajato nafosuhu [His soul, or spirit, went forth]; (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so jaAdato nafosuhu. (Mṣb.) And a poet says, not Aboo-Khirásh as in the Ṣ, but Hudheyfeh Ibn-Anas, (IB,)
najaA saAlimN wAln-afosu minohu biXidoqihi
walamo yanoju Uil-aA jafona sayofK wamiYozaraA
i. e., [Sálim escaped when the soul was in the side of his mouth; but he escaped not save] with the scabbard of a sword and with a waist-wrapper. (Ṣ.) In the same sense the word is used in the saying. fiI nafosi fulaAnK Oano yafoEala kacaA wakacaA [but this seems rather to mean, It is in the mind of such a one to do so and so]. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M.) Some of the lexicologists assert the nafos and the ruwH to be one and the same, except that the former is fem., and the latter [generally or often] masc.: others say, that the latter is that whereby is life; and the former, that whereby is intellect, or reason; so that when one sleeps, God takes away his nfs, but not his rwH, which is not taken save at death: and the nafos is thus called because of its connexion with the nafas [or breath]. (IAmb.) Or every man has nafosaAni [two souls]: (I’Ab, Zj:) nafosu AlEaqoli [the soul of intellect, or reason, also called Aln-afosu Aln-aATiqapu (see ruwHN)], whereby one discriminates, [i. e., the mind,] (I’Ab,) or nafosu Alt-amoyiyzi [the soul of discrimination], which quits him when he sleeps, so that he does not understand thereby, God taking it away: (Zj:) and nafosu Alr-uwHi [the soul of the breath], whereby one lives, (I’Ab,) or nafosu AlHayaApi [the soul of life], and when this quits him, the breath quits with it; whereas the sleeper breathes: and this is the difference between the taking away of the nfs of the sleeper in sleep and the taking away of the nfs of the living [at death.] (Zj.) Much has been said respecting the nafos and the ruwH; whether they be one, or different: but the truth is, that there is a difference between them, since they are not always interchangeable: for it is said in the Ḳur, [xv. 29 and xxxviii. 72,] wanafaxotu fiyhi mino ruwHiI [And I have blown into him of my spirit.]; not mino nafosiI: and [v. 116,] taEolamu maA fiI nafosiI [to be explained hereafter]; not fiI ruwHiI, nor would this expression be well except from Jesus: and [lviii. 9,] wayaquwluwna fiI Oanofusihimo [And they say in their souls, or within themselves]: for which it would not be well to say fiI OarowaAHihimo: and [xxxix. 57,] Oano taquwla nafosN [That a soul shall say]; for which no Arab would say Oano taquwla ruwHN: hence, the difference between them depends upon the considerations of relation: and this is indicated by a trad., in which it is said that God created Adam, and put into him a nafos and a ruwH; and that from the latter was his quality of abstaining from unlawful and indecorous things, and his understanding, and his clemency, or forbearance, and his liberality, and his fidelity; and from the former, [which is also called Aln-afosu AlOam-aArapu, q. v., in art. Amr,] his appetence, and his unsteadiness, and his hastiness of disposition, and his anger: therefore one should not say that nafosN is the same as ruwHN absolutely, without restriction, nor ruwHN the same as nafos. (R.) The Arabs also make the discriminative nafos to be two; because it sometimes commands the man to do a thing or forbids him to do it; and this is on the occasion of setting about an affair that is disliked: therefore they make that which commands him to be a nfs, and that which forbids him to be as though it were another nfs: and hence the saying, mentioned by Z, fulaAnN yuWaAmiru nafosayohi ‡ [Such a one consults his two souls, or minds]; said of a man when two opinions occur to him. (TA.) [binafosiI fulaAnN is an elliptical phrase sometimes used, for binafosiI fulaAnN mafodiI-N, which see in art. fdI.]

† A thing's self; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, TA;) used as a corroborative; (Ṣ, TA;) its whole, (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M, TA,) and essential constituent: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M, A, Ḳ, TA:) pl. as above, OanofusN and nufuwsN. (M.) You say, raOayotu fulaAnFA nafosahu † I saw such a one himself, (Ṣ,) and jaMCaniI binafosihi [or, more properly, HaMCaniI huwa binafosihi (see, under the head of bi, a remark on that preposition when used in a case of this kind, redundantly,)] He came to me himself. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And waliIa AlOamora binafosihi [He superintended, managed, or conducted, the affair in his own person]. (Ḳ, in art. bXr, &c.) And Had-ava nafosahu [He talked to himself; soliloquized]. (Mṣb, in art. blw;, &c.) And qatala fulaAnN nafosahu † [Such a one killed himself]: and Oaholaka nafosahu † made his whole self to fall into destruction. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, M.) And hence, (TA,) from nafosu AlX-aIoCi signifying caAtuhu, (M,) the saying mentioned by Sb, nazalotu binafosi Aljabali † [I alighted in the mountain itself]: and nafosu Aljabali muqaAbiliI † [The mountain itself is facing me]. (M, TA.) [Hence also the phrase] fiI nafosi AlOamori [meaning † in reality; in the thing itself]: as in the saying, qal-alahu fiI nafosihi waUino lamo yakuno qaliylFA fiI nafosi AlOamori † [He held it to be little in his mind though it was not little in reality]. (Mṣb, art. ql.) The words of the Ḳur, [v. 116,] taEolamu maA fiI nafosiI walaA OaEolamu maA fiI nafosika mean † Thou knowest what is in myself, or in my essence, and I know not what is in thyself, or in thine essence: (Bḍ, Ḳ:) or Thou knowest what I conceal (M, Bḍ, Jel) in my nfs [or mind], (Bḍ, Jel,) and I know not what is in thyself, or in thine essence, nor that whereof Thou hast the knowledge, (M.) or what Thou concealest of the things which Thou knowest; (Bḍ, Jel;) so that the interpretation is, Thou knowest what I know, and I know not what Thou knowest: (M:) or nfs is here syn. with Einod; and the meaning is, taEolamu maA EinodiI walaA OaEolamu maA Einodaka; (Ḳ,* TA;) [i. e., Thou knowest what is in my particular place of being, and I know not what is in thy particular place of being; for] the adverbiality in this instance is that of makaAnap, not of makaAn: (TA:) but the best explanation is that of IAmb, who says that nfs is here syn. with gayob; so that the meaning is, Thou knowest gayobiI [my hidden things, or what is hidden from me, and I know not thy hidden things, or what Thou hidest]; and the correctness of this is testified by the concluding words of the verse, Uin-aka Oanota Eal-aAmu Alguyuwbi [for Thou art he who well knoweth the hidden things]: (TA:) [and here it must be remarked that] AlEayobu, which occurs afterwards in the Ḳ as one of the significations of Aln-afosu, is a mistake for Algayobu, the word used by IAmb in explaining the above verse. (TA.)

† A person; a being; an individual; syn. XaxoSN; (Mṣb;) a man, (Sb, Ṣ, M, TA,) altogether, his soul and his body; (TA;) a living being, altogether. (Mgh, Mṣb.) In this sense of XxS it is masc.: (Mṣb:) or, accord to Lḥ, the Arabs said, raOayotu nafosFA waAHidapF † [I saw one person], making it fem.; and in like manner, raOayotu nafosayoni vinotayoni † [I saw two persons]; but they said, raOayotu valaAvapa OanofusK † [I saw three persons], and so all the succeeding numbers, making it masc.: but, he says, it is allowable to make it masc. in the sing. and dual., and fem. in the pl.: and all this, he says, is related on the authority of Ks: (M:) Sb says, (M.) they said valaAvapu OanofusK, (Ṣ, M,) making it masc., (Ṣ,) because they mean by nfs “a man,” (Ṣ, M,) as is shown also by their saying nafosN waAHidN: (M:) but Yoo asserts of Ru-beh, that he said valaAvu OanofusK, making nfs fem., like as you say valaAvu OaEoyunK, meaning, of men; and valaAvapu OaXoxuSK, meaning, of women: and it is said in the Ḳur, [iv. l, &c.,] Aal-aciI xalaqakumo mino nafosK waAHidapK † [who created you from one man], meaning, Adam. (M.) You also say, maA raOayotu vam-a nafosFA † I saw not there any one. (TA.)

† A brother: (IKh, IB:) a copartner in religion and relationship: (Bḍ, xxiv. 61:) a copartner in faith and religion. (Ibn-ʼArafeh.) † It is said in the Ḳur, [xxiv. 61,] faUicaA daxalotumo buyuwtFA fasal-imuwA EalaI Oanofusikumo And when ye enter houses, salute ye your brethren: (IB:) or your copartners in religion and relationship. (Bḍ.) And in verse 12 of the same chapter. biOanofusihimo means † Of their copartners in faith and religion. (Ibn-ʼArafeh.)

‡ Blood: (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [or the life-blood: in this sense, fem.:] pl. [of pauc. OanofusN and of mult.] nufuwsN: (IB:) so called [because the animal soul was believed by the Arabs, as it was by many others in ancient times, (see Gen. ix. 4, and Aristotle, De Anim. i. 2, and Virgil's Æn. ix. 349.) to diffuse itself throughout the body by means of the arteries: or] because the nafos [in its proper sense, i. e. the soul,] goes forth with it: (TA:) or because it sustains the whole animal. (Mgh, Mṣb.) You say, saAlato nafosuhu ‡ [His blood flowed]. (Ṣ.) And nafosN saAYilapN ‡ [Flowing blood]. (Ṣ, A, Mgh.) And dafaqa nafosahu ‡ He shed his blood. (A, TA.)
‡ The body. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

† [Sometimes it seems to signify The stomach. So in the present day. You say, laEibato nafosuhu, meaning He was sick in the stomach. See gavato nafosuhu, in art. gvI; and macirato maEidatuhu and nafosuhu, in art. mcr.]
† [The pudendum: so in the present day: in the Ḳ, art. HXw, applied to a woman's vulva.]
[From the primary signification are derived several others, of attributes of the rational and animal souls; and such are most of the signification here following.]
† Knowledge. (A.) [See, above, an explanation of the words cited from ch. v. verse 116 of the Ḳur-án.]
† Pride: (A, Ḳ, TA:) and self-magnification; syn. Eiz-apN. (A, Ḳ.)
† Disdain, or scorn. (A, Ḳ.)
† Purpose, or intention: or strong determination: syn. him-apN. (A, Ḳ.)
† Will, wish, or desire. (A, Ḳ.)
[Copulation: see 3, art rwd.]
[† Stomach, or appetite.]

‡ An [evil or envious] eye, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, TA,) that smites the person or thing at which it is cast: pl. OanofusN. (TA.) [See 1, last signification.] So in a trad., in which it is said, that the namolap and the Humap and the nafos are the only things for which a charm is allowable. (TA.) You say, OaSaAbato fulaAnFA nafosN ‡ [An evil or envious eye smote such a one]. (Ṣ.) And Moḥammad said, of a piece of green fat that he threw away, kaAna fiyhaA saboEapu OanofusK, meaning, ‡ There were upon it seven [evil or envious] eyes. (TA.)
† Strength of make, and hardiness, of a man: and † closeness of texture, and strength, of a garment or piece of cloth. (M.)

Punishment. (A, Ḳ.) Ex. wayuHac-irukum Qll-ehu nafosahu, (Ḳ,) in the Ḳur, [iii. 27 and 28, meaning, And God maketh you to fear his punishment]; accord. to F; but others say that the meaning is, Himself. (TA.)

A quantity (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) of qaraZ, and of other things, with which hides are tanned, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) sufficient for one tanning: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or enough for two tannings: (TA:) or a handful thereof: (M:) pl. OanafusN. (M.) You say, habo liI nfosFA mino dibaAgK [Give thou to me a quantity of material for tanning sufficient for one tanning, or for two tannings,, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

nafasN [Breath;] what is drawn in by the airpassages in the nose, [or by the mouth,] to the inside, and emitted, (Mṣb;) what comes forth from a living being in the act of tanaf-us. (Mgh:) or the exit of wind from the nose and the mouth: (M:) pl. OanofaAsN. (Ṣ, M, A. Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
A gentle air: pl. as above. (M, Mṣb.) You say also, nafasu Alr-iyHi [The breath of the wind]: and nafasu Alr-awoSapi the sweet [breath or] odour [of the meadow, or of the garden,, &c.]. (TA.)
[Hence, app., its application in the phrase] nafasa Als-aAEapi [The blast of the last hour; meaning,] the end of time. (Kr, M.)
[Hence also, † Speech: and kind speech: (see an ex. voce OamolaHa:) so in the present day.]
[And † Voice, or a sweet voice, in singing: so in the present day.]

A gulp. or as much as is swallowed at once in drinking: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) but this requires consideration; for in one nafas a man takes a number of gulps, more or less according to the length or shortness of his breath, so that we [sometimes] see a man drink [the contents of] a large vessel in one nafas, at a number of gulps: (L:) [therefore it signifies sometimes, if not always, a draught, or as much as is swallowed without taking breath:] pl. as above. (Ṣ.) You say, UikoraEo fiI AlUitaMCi nafasFA Oawo nafasayoni ‡ [Put thou thy mouth into the vessel and drink] a gulp, or two gulps: [or a draught, or two draughts:] and exceed not that. (Ṣ;) And Xarbotu nafasFA waOanofaAsFA ‡ [I drank a gulp, and gulps: or a draught, and draughts]. (A.) And fulaAnN Xariba AlUinaMCa kul-ahu EalaI nafasK waAHidK ‡ [Such a one drank the whole contents of the vessel at one gulp or at one draught]. (L.)

‡ Every resting between two draughts: (M, TA:) [pl. as above.] You say, Xariba binafasK waAHidK ‡ [He drank with one resting between draughts]. (A.) And Xarba bivalaAvapi OanofaAsK ‡ [He drank with three restings between draughts]. (A. Ḳ.) [And hence,] XaraAbN cuw nafasi ‡ Beverage in which is ampleness, [so that one pauses while drinking it, to take breath,] and which satisfies thirst. (IAạr, Ḳ.) And XaraAbN gayoru ciI nafasK ‡ Beverage of disagreeable taste, (A, Ḳ,*) changed in taste and odour, (Ḳ,) in drinking which one does not take breath (A, Ḳ) when he has tasted it; (Ḳ;) taking a first draught, as much as will keep in the remains of life, and not returning to it. (TA.)
[And hence it is said that] nafasN signifies † Satisfaction, or the state of being satisfied, with drink; syn. diI-a. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
[Hence also.] ‡ Plenty, and redundance. So in the saying Uin- fiI AlmaMCi nafasFA liI walaka [Verily in the water is plenty, and redundance, for me and for thee]. (Lḥ, M.)
‡ A wide space: (TA:) ‡ a distance (A.) You say, bayona Alfar yqayon nafasN ‡ Between the two parties is a wide space. (TA.) And bayoniI wabayonahN nafasN ‡ Between me and him is a distance. (A.)

‡ Ample scope for action, &c.; and a state in which is ample scope for action, &c., syn. sEpN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and fusoHapN, (A, Ḳ,) in an affair. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.) You say, lak fiI hecaA nafasN [There is ample scope for action, &c. for thee in this.] (Mgh.) And Oanota fiI nafis mino Oamorika ‡ [Thou art in a state in which is ample scope for action, &c. with respect to thine affair.] (Ṣ, M.) And UiEomlo waOanota fiI nafasK mino Oamorika ‡ Work thou while thou art in a state in which is ample scope for action, &c. (fiI fusoHapK wasaEap) with respect to thine affair, before extreme old age, and diseases, and calamities. (TA.) See also nufosapN.

‡ Length. (M.) So in the saying zidonI nafasFA fiI OajaliI ‡ [Add thou to me length in my term of life]: (M:) or lengthen thou my term of life. (TA.)
You say also, fiI Eumurihi mutanaf-asN↓ ‡ [In his life is length: see 5]. (A, TA.)

The pl., in the accus. case, also signifies † Time after time. So in the saying of the poet,
EayonaI-a juwdaA EaborapF OanofaAsaA
[O my two eyes, pour forth a flow of tears time after time]. (Ṣ.)

nafasN is also a subst. put in the place of the proper inf. n. of naf-asa; and is so used in the two following sayings, (Ḳ, TA,) of Moḥammad. (TA.) laA tasbuw-uA Alr-iyHa faUin-ahaA mino nafasi Alr-aHomeni, i. e. ‡ [Revile not ye the wind, for] it is a means whereby the Compassionate removes grief, or sorrow, or anxiety, (Ḳ, TA,) and raises the clouds, (TA,) and scatters the rain, and dispels dearth, or drought. (Ḳ, TA.) And Oajidu nafasa rab-ikumo mino qibali Alyamani ‡ I perceive your Lord's removal of grief,, &c., from the direction of El-Yemen: meaning, through the aid and hospitality of the people of El-Medeeneh, who were of El-Yemen; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e., of the Ansár, who were of [the tribe of] El-Azd, from El-Yemen. (TA.) It is [said by some to be] a metaphor, from nafasu AlhawaMCi, which the act of breathing draws back into the inside, so that its heat becomes cooled and moderated: or from nafasu Alr-iyiH, which one scents, so that thereby he refreshes himself: or from nafasu Alr-awoDapi. (TA.) You also say, maA liI nafasN, meaning, ‡ There is not for me any removal, or clearing away, of grief. (A.)
It is also used as an epithet, signifying † Long; (AZ, Ḳ;) applied to speech, (Ḳ,) and to writing, or book, or letter. (AZ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: nufosapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) with damm, (Ḳ,) [in a copy of the Ṣ, nafosapN,] † Delay; syn. maholapN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) and ample space, syn. mut-asaEN. (TA.) Ex. laka fiI hecaA AlOamori nufosapN † [Thou shalt have, in this affair, a delay, and ample space]. (Ṣ, Mgh,* TA.) See also nafasN.

nufasaMCu (Th, Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and nafasaMCu and nafosaMCu (M, Ḳ) ‡ A woman in the state following childbirth: (Ṣ, M,* Mgh,* Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or bringing forth: and pregnant: and menstruating: (Th, M:) and naAfisN signifies the same; (Mṣb;) and so manofuwsapN↓: (A:) [see nufisato:] dual nufasaAwaAni; the fem. C being changed into w as in EuXaraAwaAni: (Ṣ:) pl. nifaAsN, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as EiXaArN is pl. of EuXaraMCu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the only other instance of the kind, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nufaAsN, (M, Ḳ,) which is also the only instance of the kind except EuXaArN, (Ḳ,) and nuf-aAsN, and nuf-asN and nufasN (M) and nufusN (M, Ḳ) and nufosN (Ḳ) and nufasaAwaAtN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and [accord. to analogy, of naAfisN,] nawaAfisu. (Ḳ.)
nafosaAnN, or nafosaAniI-N: see nafuwsN.
nafosaAniI-N: see nafosiI-N:
and nafuwsN.
nifaAsN ‡ Childbirth (Ṣ, Ḳ) from nafosN signifying “blood.” (Mṣb, TA.) See nufisato.
[And The state of impurity consequent upon childbirth. See 5, in art. El.]
Also, ‡ The blood that comes forth immediately after the child: an inf. n. used as a subst. (Mgh.)

A poet says, (namely, Ows Ibn-Hajar, O, in art. Trq,)
lanaA SaroxapN vum-a UisokaAtapN
kamaA Tar-aqato binifaAsK bikiro
[We utter a cry; then keep a short silence; like as when one that has never yet brought forth experiences resistance and difficulty in giving birth to a child, or young one]; meaning, biwaladK. (Ṣ.)
nafuwsN An envious man: (M, TA:) ‡ one who looks with an evil eye, with injurious intent, at the property of others: (M, A,* TA:) as also nafosaAnN↓, (TA,) or nafosaAniI-N↓. (A.)

nafiysN A thing high in estimation; of high account; excellent; (Lḥ, M, Mṣb, TA;) highly prized; precious; valuable; and therefore (TA) desired with emulation, or in much request; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) good, goodly, or excellent, in its kind; (TA;) and naAfisN↓ signifies the same, (M,) and so does munofisN↓, (Lḥ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and manofuwsN↓: (Ḳ:) it signifies thus when applied to property, as well as other things; as also manofisN↓: (Lḥ, M:) and, when so applied, of which one is avaricious, or tenacious: (M:) or munofisN↓, so applied, abundant; much; (Ḳ;) as also munofasN↓: (Fr, Ḳ:) and naAfisN↓, a thing of high account or estimation, and an object of desire: (TA:) this last is also applied, in like manner, to a man; as also nafiysN: and the pl. [of either] is nifaAsN (M, TA) You also say, OamorN manofuwsN fiyhi↓, meaning, A thing that is desired. (M.) And XaIoCN mutanaAfasN↓ fiyhi A thing emulously desired, or in much request. (A.)

Also, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] Much property; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and so munofisN↓. (Ṣ.) You say, lifulaAnK munofisN and nafiysN Such a one has much property. (Ṣ.) And maA yasur-uniI bihecaA AlOamori manofisN and nafiysN [Much property does not rejoice me with this affair]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: naAfisN: see nafiysN, in three places.
See also nufasaMCu.
‡ Smiting with an evil, or envious, eye. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)

The fifth of the arrows used in the game called Almayosir; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) which has five notches; and for which one wins five portions if it be successful, and loses five portions if it be unsuccessful: (Lḥ, M:) or, as some say, the fourth. (Ṣ.)
hecaA Oanofasu maAliI This is the most loved and highly esteemed of my property. (Ṣ, TA.)

bal-agaka Qll-ehu Oanofasa AlOaEomaAri ‡ [May God cause thee to attain to the most protracted, or most ample, of lives: see 5]. (A, TA.) And daAruka Oanofasu mino daAriI ‡ Thy house is more ample, or spacious, than my house: (M:) and the like is said of two places: (M:) and of two lands. (A.) And hecaA Alt-awobu Oanofasu mino hecaA ‡ This garment, or piece of cloth, is wider and longer and more excellent than this. (M.) And vawobN Oanofasu Alv-awobayoni ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, the longer and wider of the two garments, or pieces of cloth. (A.)

entry.sense: munofasN: see nafiysN.
munofisN: see nafiysN, throughout.

hom.sense: manofuwsN: see nafiysN, in two places.

‡ Brought forth; born. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., maA mino nafosK manofuwsapK Uil-aA waqaco kutiba makaAnuhaA mina Aljan-api Oawi Aln-aAri ‡ [There is not any soul born but its place in Paradise or Hell has been written]. (Ṣ.)
manofuwsapN applied to a woman: see nufasaMCu.
‡ Smitten with an evil, or envious, eye. (M.)

entry.sense: [mutanaf-asN A place of passage of the breath.]
fI Eumurihi mutanaf-asN: see nafasN.
See also saHarN.
mutanaf-isN [Breathing;] having breath: (TA:) or having a soul: (so in a copy of the M:) an epithet applied to everything having lungs. (Ṣ, TA.)
gaAYiTN mutanaf-isN ‡ A depressed expanse of land extending far. (A, TA.)
OanofN mutanaf-isN ‡ A nose of which the bone is wide and depressed; or depressed and expanded; or a nose spreading upon the face: syn. OafoTasu. (A, TA.)
XaIoCN mutanaAfasN fiyhi: see nafiysN.

hom.sense:
1. nafaXa, (Ṣ, A,) aor. _u {yanofuXu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. nafoXN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He separated, or plucked asunder, or loosened, a thing, with his fingers, so that it became spread, or sparse, or dispersed; (A, Ḳ;) as also nf-X↓, inf. n. tanofiyXN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the latter has an intensive signification: and accord. to some, the former signifies he separated a thing not difficult to separate, such as cotton and wool: or he pulled wool until its parts became separated, or plucked asunder, or loosened: (TA:) or he spread, or dispersed, a thing. (MF.)
You say, nafaXotu AlquTona and AlS-uwfa [I separated or plucked asunder, or loosened, with my fingers,, &c., the cotton and the wool]. (Ṣ, A.) nafoXN is likewise syn. with nadofN [the separating and loosening cotton by means of a bow and a wooden mallet]. (TA.) You also say, nafaXa Alr-aTobapa, inf. n. as above, meaning, He separated what was collected together, or compacted, in the [kind of trefoil called] rTbp. (TA.) And, of a cock, (T, Ṣ, in art. bwl.) or of a HubaAraI, (Ḳ, in that art.,) when about to fight, (T, Ḳ. ibid.,) nafaXa buraAYilahu [He ruffled the feathers around his neck]. (T, Ṣ, Ḳ, ibid.)
It is also intrans syn. with AntfX, q. v. (TA.)

[And hence,] nafaXati Alganamu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and AlUibilu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) accord. to IDrd the former only, but accord. to others the latter also, and in like manner one says of all beasts, though mostly of ganam, (TA,) aor. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and _i, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nafoXN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or nufuwXN, (Ṣ,) or both: (TA;) and nafXt, aor. _a {yanofaXu}; (IAạr. Ṣgh, Ḳ;) The sheep or goats, and the camels, pastured by night without a pastor: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or without the knowledge of a pastor (TA:) or dispersed themselves by night: (A:) or dispersed themselves and pastured by night without knowledge [of the pastor]: or the sheep or goats entered among seed-produce: (TA:) occurring in the Ḳur, xxi. 78: (Ṣ, TA:) the subst. is nafaXN, signifying their dispersion of themselves and pasturing by night without a pastor. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first signification.

4. AnfX Alganama, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) and AlUibila, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He (the pastor) sent the sheep or goats, and the camels, (Ḳ,* TA,) or left them, (Ṣ, TA,) to pasture by night without a pastor; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) neglecting them: (TA:) or to disperse themselves by night. (A.)

5. tanf-Xt Alhir-apu, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and AntfXt↓, (Ṣ, A,) The cat bristled up her hair. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And in like manner you say of a hyena. (A, TA,*) And tnf-X Ald-iyku, (A,) or AlT-aAiYru, (Ḳ,) and AntfX↓, (A, TA,) The cock, (A,) or bird, (Ḳ,) ruffled, (A,) or shook, (Ḳ,) his feathers, as though he feared, (A, Ḳ,) or threatened, (A,) or trembled. (Ḳ.)

8. AntfX i. q. nafaXa used intransitively. [signifying It (a thing, or cotton, and wool, and the like,) became separated, or plucked asunder, or loosened, with the fingers, so that it became spread, or sparse, or dispersed;, &c., being] quasi-pass. of nafaXa used transitively. (TA.) See also munotafiXN. And see 5, in two places.

hom.sense: nafaXN Wool. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

[Hence, app., the saying,] Uino lamo yakuno XaHomN fanafaXN, [lit., If there be not fat, then let there be wool;] meaning, † If there be not action, then [let there be] a show of action: (IAạr, Az, L:) or the last word signifies a little milk. (Meyd, cited by Freytag: see his Arab Prov., i. 70:) it also signifies, [and perhaps in the above saying,] ‡ abundance of speech or talk, and of pretensions. (MF.)
See also 1, at the end.
And see: naAfiXN.
naf-aAXN † Proud and boastful. or one who praises himself for that which is not in him; or who says that which he does not. (TA.)
A kind of layomuwn [or citron; the limon sponginus sugosus Ferrari; (Delile, Floræ Aegypt. Illustr., no. 749)] of the largest size, (TA.)

entry.sense: naAfiXN, applied to a camel [and to a sheep or goat]. fem. naAfXpN, Mṣb, part. n. of 1. (Mṣb, TA.) You say, UibilN naAfiXapN, Mṣb, and nafaXN [quasi-pl. p. of naAfiXN] (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nifaAXN (Mṣb) and nuf-aAXN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuf-XN [pls. of naAfXN] (TA) and nawaAfiXN [pl. of naAfiXpN], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [and in like manner EanamN,] Camels [and goats] pasturing by night without a pastur: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or dispersing themselves and pasturing by night without knowledge [of the pastor] (TA:) nafaXN are only by night; but hamalN, by night and by day (Ṣ,)

EihonN manofuwXN (Ṣ) Wool of ramous colours separated and loosened by means of bow wooden mallet: (Bḍ, Jel, ei. 4.) and in like manner, quTonN musotafiXN↓ [cotton that is separated, or plucked asunder, or loosened, with the fingers, so that it becomes spread, or dispersed., &c., See 1 and 8]. (TA, voce hay-baAnN,) See also musotafXN, below.
munotafiXN: see manofuwXN.
OamapN munotafivapu Alt-aEari A female slave having shaggy or dishevelled hair: (A;) XaEotMCu. (Ḳ)
munotafivN is likewise applied to anything Swollen, or humid, and loose or flaccid or soft within; as also mutaE-XN↓. (Az, Ḳ.)

You say also OanofN munotfiXN ‡ A nose short in the maArin [is soft part], and spreading upon the face, [like the nose of the zanojiI-]: (A:) and OaronabapN munotafivapN has the like signification; as also mutanaf-ivapN↓; (TA;) or in means are cad of a nose spreading upon the face: (Ḳ:) and mutabaf-iXu↓ Almunoxiryoni, in like manner, wide in the two nostrils. (TA.) See also munataf-isN.
mutanaf-iXN: see munotafiXN, in three places.

hom.sense: 1. nafaDa, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanofuDu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. nafoDN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He shook (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) a thing, (Mgh, Mṣb,) or a garment, or piece of cloth, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) in order that what was upon it, of dust, &c., might fall off (Ṣ,* A,* Mgh, Ḳ,*) or to remove from it dust and the like; (Mṣb:) he took a thing with his hand, and shook it, or shook it violently, to remove the dust from it: (TA:) and in like manner a tree, in order that what was upon it [of face or of leaves] might fall of; (Ṣ, A;) [as, for instance,] a tree of the kind called EiDAh, to shake off its leaves. (TA) You say also, nafaDa Eanahu AlgubaAra and Alt-uraAba [He shook off from it the dust]. (A.) And nafaDatu Alwaraqa mino AlX-ajarap. inf. n. as above, [He shook off the leaves from the tree;] be made the leaves to fall from the tree. (Mṣb,) And nafoDN also signifies The sprinkling or scattering in drops, (syn. raX-N,) water and blood, (A, Ḳ, in art. rX,) and tears, (Ḳ, ibid.):, &c. (A, ibid.)
[Hence,] nafaDatohu AlHum-aI (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) ‡ The fever made him to shiver, or tremble (Aṣ, TA)

And nafaDati AlmaroOapu, (Ḳ,) or nafDato kariXahaA, (Ṣ,) or nafaDato waladahaA mino baTonhA, (A,) The woman have many children; was prolific (Ṣ, Ḳ. TA) And nafaDat AlUibilu † The she-camels brought forth, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) all of them: (L;) and AnfDt↓ signifies the same. (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And nafaDati Ald-aHaAjapu bayoDahA ‡ [The hen laid her eggs. or all her eggs]. (A. TA.)

[Hence also,] faAma yanafuDu AlkraI † [He arose, shaking off drowsiness]. (A. TA.) And nafaDa AlOasofaAma Eanohu waQsotaSaH- ‡ [He shook off maladies from him, and recovered from his sickness]; i. e. his health became in a sound state. (A. TA.) And nafaDa mino maraDihi (A,) inf. n. nufuwDN, (TA, Ḳ,) ‡ He recovered, or became free, from his disease. (A, Ḳ,* TA.)
And nafaDotu lahu maA fiI jiraAbiI † I showed him what was in my heart. (Er-Rághib, TA, in art. Xkw and XkI.)

And nafaDa AlT-ariyqa ‡ He cleared the road of robbers, and intercepters of travellers: ‡ he guarded the road. (A. TA. [The latter signification is shown by an explanation or the act. part. n.]) It is said in the trad. of Aboo-Bekr and the cave [in which Moḥammad was hiding himself], OanaA OanafuDu maA Hawolaka ‡ I will guard what is around thee, and go round about to try if I can see a pursuer. (TA.) You say also, nafaDa AlmakaAn, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (TA.) inf. n. nafaDN (Ṣ, TA.) and AstnfDhu↓, and tnf-Dhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) ‡ He looked trying to see all that was in the place: (Ṣ;) or he looked at all that was in the place so as to know it. (Ḳ) And hence nafaDa signifies ‡ He searched to the at most. (L.) And UicaA takal-amut nahaArFA faQnofuDo waUicaA takal-amota layolFA faQxofiDo (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA) ‡ When thou speakest by day, look aside, or about, to try if thou see any one whom thou dislikest; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and when thou speakest by night, lower thy voice. (TA.) And AstnfD↓ Alqawoma ‡ He looked at the people, or company of men, endeavouring to obtain a clear knowledge of them; or considered, or examined, them repeatedly, in order to know them. (TA.)
The saying of El-ʼOjeyr Es-Saloolee,
UilaI malikK yasotanofiDu↓ Alqawoma Tarofuhu
means ‡ [To a king whose eye] looks at the people, or company of men, and knows who among them has the right on his side: or looks to see in whom among them is mental perception, sagacity, intelligence, forecast, or skill in affairs, and which of them is of the contrary description: (TA:) [or] fulaAnN yasotanofiDu↓ Tarofuhu Alqawoma means ‡ [The eye of] such a one makes the people, or company of men, to tremble, by reason of his awfulness. (A, TA.)
You also say, AlUibilu tanofuDu AlOaroDa † The camels traverse the land. (IAạr.)
And nafaDa AlquroMna, (IAạr,) or Als-uwara, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanofuDu}, inf. n. nafoDN, (IAạr,) ‡ He read, or recited, (IAạr, Ḳ,) the Ḳur-án, (IAạr,) or the chapters thereof. (Ḳ.)

And nafaDonaA HalaAYibanaA, inf. n. nafoDN; and AisotanofaDonaAhaA↓; ‡ We milked our milch beasts to the uttermost, not leaving any milk in their udders: (TA:) and AntfD↓ AlfaSiylu maA fiI AlD-aroEi ‡ the young camel sucked out all that was in the udder. (A, TA.)

[It is also used intransitively in the following exs., as well as in some instances given above. Thus nafaDa AlX-ajaru app. signifies The trees shook off, or dropped, their leaves or fruit. (See an ex. voce EatiyqN, last sentence but one.)]

[And hence] one says, nafaDa maA fiI Aljul-api [app. meaning What was in the palm-leaf basket became exhausted; like nafida; or it may be syn. with AntfD]; (A, Ḳ;) or jamiyEu maA fiyhaA [all that was in it; which shows that mA in the former instance is virtually in the nom. case]. (TA.) See also 4, in two places.

And nafaDa AlS-ibogu, (ISh, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. nafoDN, (ISh, TA,) or nufuwDN, (TA,) ‡ The dye (ISh, Ḳ, TA,) of a red or yellow garment, or piece of cloth, (ISh, TA,) lost somewhat of its colour. (ISh, Ḳ, TA.) And hence, (Mgh,) nafaDa Alv-awobu, (A, Mgh,) aor. _u {yanofuDu}, (A,) inf. n. nufuwDN, (A, Mgh,) ‡ The garment, or piece of cloth, lost its dye: (A:) or lost somewhat of its colour, of redness, or yellowness: (Mgh:) or the colour of its dye faded away so that there remained nothing but the trace. (TA.) nafoDN, accord. to the lawyers, signifies † The being scattered, strewn, strewed, or dispersed: and accord. to [the Hanafee Imám] Moḥammad, the non-transition of the trace of the dye to another thing: or its exhaling a sweet odour. (Mgh [but it seems that the particle lA, which I have rendered “non,” is inserted by mistake in my copy of the Mgh.])

nafaDa Alz-aroEu, (Ḳ,) or nafaDa Alz-aroEu sabalFA, (TA,) † The seed-produce put forth the last of its ears. (Ḳ, TA.) And nafaDa Alkaromu † The grape-vine opened its bunches, or racemes. (Ḳ.) [See also 8.]

entry.sense: 2. nf-D, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. tanofiyDN, (TA,) He shook a garment, or piece of cloth, and a tree, much, or vehemently, in order that what was upon it might fall off. (Ṣ, TA.*)
Said of a horse, i. q. raf-aDa, q. v. (TA in art. rfD.)
4. OanofaDati Aljul-apu i. q. nafaDa↓ maA fiI Aljul-api, (A, Ḳ,) or jamiyEu maA fiyhaA: (TA:) see 1.

AnfDwA originally signifies They shook their provision-bags, in order that the dust or the like might fall from them. (A.) And hence, (A,) ‡ Their travellingprovisions became consumed, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, TA,) and their wheat, or food; (M, TA;) like OaromaluwA; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,* TA;) as though they shook their provision-bags in order that the dust or the like might fall from them, because of their being empty; (TA;) as also nafaDuwA↓: (Ḳ:) or AnfDwA, (Ḳ,) or, as IDrd says, AnfDwA zaAdahumo, making the verb trans., (TA,) They consumed their travellingprovisions. (IDrd, Ḳ.) And ‡ Their camels, or the like, (OamowaAluhumo,) died, or perished. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) UinofaADN [the inf. n.] also signifies † The suffering hunger, or famine: and want. (TA.)
AnfDt AlUibilu: see nfDt.
5. tnf-D AlmakaAna: see 1.

hom.sense: 8. AntfD It (a thing, Mgh, Mṣb, or a garment, or piece of cloth, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, and a tree, Ṣ, A) shook, or became shaken, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that what was upon it, of dust, &c., fell off, (Mgh,) or so that the dust and the like became removed from it. (Mṣb.) Hence the saying in a trad., yanotafiDu bihi AlS-iraATu, i. e. [The bridge extending over hell will shake with him so that he will fall from it: or] will shake him, or shake him violently, or [app. a mistake for and] make him to fall. (Mgh.)
‡ He trembled, quaked, or shivered: said of a man, and of a horse. (A, TA.)
† It (a grapevine) became beautiful and bright in its leaves: (Ḳ:) [as though its dust became shaken off.]
It is also used transitively: see 1, latter half: and see 1, in three places.

entry.sense: 10. AstnfD Alqawomu ‡ The people, or company of men, sent forth a nafiyDap, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) or party of scouts: (TA:) or sent forth nafaDap, or persons to clear the roads of robbers and of intercepters of travellers, or to guard the roads. (A, L, TA.)
AstnfD AlmakaAna: and Alqawoma: see 1, in four places.
AstnfDhu also signifies ‡ He extracted, educed, or elicited, it. (A, Mgh,* Ḳ.) You say, AisotanofaDotu maA Einodahu ‡ I extracted, educed, or elicited, what he had. (A, TA.*)

And hence, (Mgh,) AstnfD ‡ He performed the act of cleansing termed AisotinojaMC, (Mgh, Ḳ,) with three stones, (Mgh,) or with the stone: (Ḳ:) or this is from nafaDa Alv-awoba; because the person who performs this act shakes off from himself what is annoying, with the stone; i. e., removes it. (TA.) You say also, AstnfD Alc-akara ‡ He took extraordinary pains in cleansing, or he cleansed entirely, (UisotaboraOa,) the penis from the remains of the urine; as also AntfDhu↓; (Ḳ;) and AntfD↓ [alone]: (TA:) and ↓this last, he sprinkled some water upon his pudendum after the ablution termed wuDuwoC. (TA in art. nSH.)
[Hence also,] AstfDnA HalaAYibanaA: see 1.

hom.sense: nafaDN What has fallen, of the produce of a tree; (TA;) what has fallen, of leaves, and of fruit: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a thing that one shakes [or has shaken] off: (T in art. crI:) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) like qabaDN in the sense of maqobuwDN, (Ṣ, TA,) and hadamN in the sense of mahoduwmN: (TA:) and (Ḳ, TA) what has fallen, (TA,) of grapes, [in the CK we find Hab-u AlEinabi for Hab-i AlEinabi, the reading in other copies of the Ḳ,] when they are found (yuwjadu [in the CK yuWoxadu, thus, with x, and with the unpointed d,]) one with another, (Ḳ. TA,) or cleaving one to another: (L, TA:) or what has fallen, of dates, at the feet of the palm-trees: (M, TA:) or what has fallen, of fruit, at the feet of trees; as also OanaAfiyDu↓: (A:) or ↓this last signifies leaves that are shaken off upon the nifaAD, q. v.; as also nifaADN↓ [which is app. pl. of nafaDN, like as jibaAlN is pl. of jabalN]: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) the sing. of AnAfyD is OunofuwDapN↓. (TA.) [See also nufaADapN.]
qwomN nafaDN [app. quasi-pl. of naAfiDN↓, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN,] ‡ A people, or company of men, whose travelling-provisions have become consumed. (ISh.)

nufoDapN ‡ The shivering, or trembling, attending a fever termed Aln-aAfiD; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also nufaDahN↓ (Ṣgh, Ḳ) and nufaDaMCu↓. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also nif-iDaI.] The subst. [from these words, which seems to indicate that they are inf. ns. or from nafaDatohu AlHum-aI, which precedes them in the Ḳ,] is nafaADN↓ [app. signifying ‡ A shivering, or tremour, attending that fever]. (Ḳ.)
† A rain which falls upon a piece of land and misses another piece. (Ṣ.) [In the O and Ḳ in art. Ehd, written nafoDap.]

entry.sense: nafaDapN: see nafiyDapN, in two places.
nufaDapN: see nufoDapN.
nafaDaI: see nif-iyDaI.
nufaDaMCu: see nufoDapN.

hom.sense: nafaADN: see nufoDapN:
and see nufaADN.
nufaADN: see nufaADapN.

Also, and nafaADN↓, ‡ The failure of travelling-provisions; i. e. their being consumed: or dearth, or drought: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the latter of the words, and of the explanations, on the authority of Th. (Ṣ.)
Hence, AlnfADu yuqaT-iru Aljalaba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a proverb, meaning, ‡ The failure of provisions, (TA,) or dearth, or drought, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) causes the camels, driven or brought from one place to another, to be disposed in files for sale, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in order that their owners may buy provisions with their price. (TA.)
nifaADN: see nufaADapN: and nafaDN.

A piece of cloth upon which the leaves of the samuru and the like fall, it being spread, (Ḳ, TA.) and the tree being beaten with a staff, or stick: (TA:) pl. nufuDN: (Ḳ:) and [in like manner] minofaDN↓ and minofaADN↓ signify a garment of the kind called kisaMC, upon which the nafaD [or leaves or fruit of a tree] fall: (A, TA:) or minofaDN↓ signifies i. q. minosafN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. a vessel (wiEaMC) in which dates [and grain] are shaken to remove the dust, &c. (TA.)
A garment of the kind called UizaAr worn by boys: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (TA.) You say also, maA Ealayohi nifaADN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) meaning He has not upon him any clothing. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
nafuwDN ‡ A woman having many children: prolific. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
rajulN nafuwDN lilokalaAmi ‡ A man who considers, examines, or studies, speech, or language, or does so repeatedly, in order to obtain a clear knowledge of it. (TA.)

entry.sense: nufaADapN What has fallen in consequence of shaking to cause something upon it to fall; (Ṣ;) what has fallen from a thing so shaken; (IDrd, Ḳ;) whatever it be; as, for instance, of leaves; and mostly, of leaves of the samur in particular, when collected and beaten off [or rather beaten off and collected] in a garment, or piece of cloth; (IDrd, L, TA;) [like nafaDN, q. v.;] and nufaADN↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and nifaADN↓ also. (Ḳ.) And What remains in one's mouth, of a siwaAk [or tooth-stick], and is spit out; or a particle broken off therefrom, remaining in the mouth, and spit out; i. q. nufaAvapu siwaAkK, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and DuwaAzatuhu. (IAạr.)

nafiyDapN ‡ A company sent forth into the land to see whether there be in it an enemy, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or not, (Ḳ,) or any [cause of] fear; (Ṣ;) like TaliyEapN; (Ṣ, TA;) as also nafaDapN↓; [pl. of naAfiDN↓, like as TalabapN is of TaAlibN:] (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the former signifies men going before an army as scouts, or explorers: (Aṣ, in TA, voce HaDiyrapN:) or men who explore a place thoroughly: and also, a single person: (AʼObeyd, in TA, ibid.:) or a scout, or scouts, stationed on a mountain or other elevated place: (TA:) or one who guards the road: (A, TA:) or a company [of men]: (TA:) and ↓the latter, persons who clear the roads of robbers and of intercepters of travellers; or who guard the roads; (A, TA:) the pl. of the former is nafaAYiDu; (Ṣ;) which also signifies persons who throw pebbles in order to know if there be behind them anything that they dislike, or an enemy. (Ḳ.)

Also, the pl., † Lean, or emaciated, camels; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord to AA, as occurring in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, in which he says,
tuloqiI Aln-afaAYiDu fiyhi Als-ariyHaA , (Ṣ, TA,) In which the lean, or emaciated, camels cast the shoes; meaning that these have become dissundered; or, as Akh says, the thongs so called [by which their shoes are fastened], these being dissundered; fyh referring to the road; but some read, fiyhaA, referring to the roads, mentioned before: (TA:) Aṣ reads nfAYD, as well as AA: (Ṣ, TA:) but others read the word with q, as pl. of niqoDN, and signifying “jaded” camels: (so in a copy of the Ṣ:) or nfAYD signifies camels which traverse the land. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
The sing. is also said to signify Waters where there is not any one. (IAạr, Sh; both in the TA. voce HaDiyrapN, q. v., and the former also in this art.)
nif-iDaI Motion: and tremour; or shivering; as also nifiD-aI↓ and nafaDaI↓. (O, Ḳ.) [See also nufoDapN.]

hom.sense: naAfiDN † A fever attended with shivering, or trembling: (Ṣ, A.* Ḳ:) of the masc. gender: (ISd, Ḳ:) but applied as an epithet to Hum-aI [which is fem.] (TA.) Contr. of SaAlibN. (Ṣ, in art. Slb.) You say, Oaxacatohu Hum-aI naAfiDK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Hum-aI binaAfiDK, (Ḳ,) which is the more approved form, (TA,) and Hum-aI naAfiDN, (Ḳ,) the latter word being sometimes thus used as an epithet; the second meaning ‡ Fever took him, or affected him, with [a shivering, or trembling, or] violent shivering or trembling; (TA;) [and the first and third, fever attended with shivering, or trembling, took him, or affected him.]
and nafaDN
vawobN naAfiDN ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, which has lost its dye: (A:) or which has lost somewhat of its colour, of redness, or yellowness. (Mgh.)

entry.sense: OunofuwDapN: pl. OanaAfiyDu: see nafaDN, in three places.
munofiDN, (A,) or mnfDp [i. e. munofiDapN], (TA,) ‡ A hen that has laid her eggs, or all her eggs, (nafaDato bayoDahaA, A, TA,) and desisted, (A,) or become weary. (TA.)
minofaDN: see nifaADN, in two places.
minofaADN: see nifaADN.
manofuwDN ‡ Made to shiver, or tremble, by fever (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. nafiTato yaduhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or kaf-uhu, (Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanofaTu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. nafaTN and nafiyTN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and nafoTN; (Ḳ;) or, accord. to AZ, nafaTto, aor. 2, inf. n. nafoTN and nafiyTN; (TA;) His hand became blistered, or vesicated; it had water, or fluid, between the skin and the flesh; (AZ, Mṣb;) i. q. majilato; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also tnf-Tt↓: (Ṣ:) or it became ulcerated by work. (Ḳ.)

nafaTato aor. _i {yanofiTu}, inf. n. nafiyTN (ADk, Ṣ, Ḳ) and nafoTN. (TA,) She (a goat) did what was like sneezing (navarato [app. meaning scattered forth moisture or the like]) with her nose: (ADk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or sneezed. (Ḳ.) It is said in a proverb, laA tanofiTu fiyhi EanaAqN meaning † Blood-revenge will not be taken for him; i. e. for this slain person. (TA.)

Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanofiTu}, inf. n. nafiyTN, (Ṣ,) It (a cookingpot, qidorN,) boiled, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and poured forth [some of its contents], (Ṣ,) or so that it threw forth what resembled arrows; (TA;) a dial. var. of nafatato. (Ṣ.)

nafaTa, aor. _i {yanofiTu}, † He was angry: or he burned with anger: as also tnf-T↓. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, Uin-a fulaAnFA layanofiTu gaDabFA, (Ṣ, TA,) ‡ Verily such a one burns with anger: (TA:) or it is like yanofitu [meaning boils with anger; or makes a noise like coughing, in anger; or blows, in anger]: (Ṣ:) [for the inf. n.] nafaTaAnN signifies the doing what resembles coughing: and blowing, on an occasion of anger: and so nafataAnN. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanofiTu}, inf. n. nafiyTN, said of an antelope; AlS-abiI-u in the Ḳ, being a mistake for AlZ-aboIi, as in the TṢ and L, (TA,) † He uttered a sound, or cry. (TṢ, L, Ḳ.)
† He (a man) spoke, or talked, unintelligibly; (Ḳ, TA;) as though by reason of his anger. (TA.)
nafaTati Qsotuhu † His anus emitted wind with a sound. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3: see 6.
4. AnfT It (work) caused the hand to become blistered, or vesicated: or caused it to become ulcerated. (Ḳ.) [See 1, first sentence.]
5: see 1, in two places.
6. Alqidoru tanaAfaTu [for tatanaAfaTu, in the CK tunAfiTu↓,] The cooking-pot throws forth foam; (Ḳ;) a dial. var. of tanaAfatu [q. v.] (TA.)

hom.sense: nafoTN, accord. to the T, Pustules which come forth upon the hand, in consequence of work, full of water, or fluid; (Mgh;) blisters, or vesicles, upon the hand; a contraction of nafiTN↓; which is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of nafiTapN↓, sometimes contracted into nafoTapN↓; and sometimes nafiTaAtN is used as pl. of nafiTapN: (Mṣb:) or nafiTapN↓ signifies [simply] a pustule; as also nafoTapN↓ and nifoTapN↓; (Ḳ;) and the lawyers call it naf-aATapN↓, from this word as signifying “a place whence nifoT issues,” or it may be [originally] an intensive act. part. n. (Mṣb.)

Also, and nafiTN↓, (Mṣb,) or nafiTapN↓ and nafoTapN↓ and nifoTapN↓, (Mgh, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) The small-pox: (Mgh, Ṣgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) accord. to Z, nfZ↓ [so in the TA, without any syll. signs,] signifies, in the dial. of Hudheyl, the small-pox in children and in sheep or goats. (TA.)
See also what next follows.

entry.sense: nifoTN and nafoTN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former of which is the more chaste, (ISk, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) or, as some say, the latter, (Mṣb,) or the latter is a mistake, (Aṣ, Ḳ,) [Naphtha: and petroleum: both so called in the present day:] a certain oil, (Ṣ,) well known, (Ḳ,) with which camels are smeared for the mange, or scab, and galls on the back, and tikes; it does not include what is termed kuHayol: (ISd, TA:) or, accord. to AḤn, i. q. kuHayolN: accord. to AʼObeyd, i. q. qaTiraAnN; but AḤn denies this; and says that it is an exuding fluid (HilaAbap) of a mountain, [found] in the bottom of a well, with which fire is kindled: (TA:) the best is the white: it is a dissolvent; and opens obstructions; removes the colic; and kills worms that are in the vulva, when used in the manner of a suppository. (Ḳ.)
nafiTN: see nafoTN, throughout.
nafoTapN: see nafoyTN, throughout.
nifoTapN: see nafoTN, throughout.
nafiTapN: see nafoTN, throughout:
and see also nafiyTapN.
nafaATapN [accord. to the CK, but erroneously, nafaATN]: see naf-aATapN, in two places.

kaf-N nafiyTapN A hand ulcerated by work: or blistered, or vesicated; having water or fluid, between the skin and the flesh: and naAfiTapN↓ signifies the same; and so manofuwTapN↓; (Ḳ;) of which last, however, ISd says, it is thus related by the lexicologists; but there is no way of accounting for it in my opinion; for it is from OanofaTa. (TA.) [Golius also mentions nafiTapN↓ as signifying A hand affected with pustules; on the authority of Meyd; and it is agreeable with analogy.]
naf-aATN A thrower of nifoT [or naphtha]: pl. naf-aATapN↓, [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] (Mṣb,) and naf-aATuwna. (Mgh.)

naf-aATapN A place whence nifoT [or naphtha] is extracted; (El-Fárábee, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also nafaATapN↓; (Ḳ;) but the former is the more known; (TA;) a place where it is generated; a mine, or source, thereof; a word similar to mal-aAHapN (Mgh, Mṣb) and qay-aArapN: (Mgh:) pl. naf-aATaAtN. (Mṣb.)
A kind of lamp made to give light by means thereof; as also nafaATapN↓; (Ḳ;) but the former is the more known. (TA.)

An instrument with which nifoT is thrown; (Mgh;) an instrument of copper, or brass, in which nifoT is thrown, (Ḳ, TA,) and fire; (TA;) a qaAruwrap of nifoT, which is thrown: (Mṣb:) pl. as above. (Mgh.) You say, xaraja Aln-af-aATuwna biOayodiyihmu Aln-af-aATaAtu [The throwers of naphtha went forth, having in their hands the instruments with which to throw it]. (Mgh.)
See also naf-aATN.
And see nafoTN.
kaf-N naAfiTapN: see nafiyTapN.
ragowapN naAfiTapN Froth, or foam, having bubbles: (Az, Mṣb:) pl. nawaAfiTu (TA.)
manofuwTapN: see nafiyTapN.

hom.sense: 1. naqaba, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, inf. n. naqobN, He perforated, pierced, bored, or made a hole through, or in, or into, anything: like vaqaba. (TA.) He made a hole through a wall. (Ṣ.)
naqaba sur-apa Ald-aAb-api, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, He (a farrier) perforated the navel of the beast in order that a yellow fluid might issue forth. (Ṣ.) See manoqabN.

naqaba AlEayona, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, inf. n. naqobN, He performed, upon the eye, what is called AlqadoHu in the language of the physicians; i. e., a remedial operation for the black fluid that arises in the eye: from the phrase next following: (IAth:) [but this is not a good explanation: the meaning is he performed upon the eye the operation of couching, for the cataract: so in many Arabic works, ancient and modern: (IbrD:) the couching-needle is called miqodaHN, and Uiborapu AlqadoHi, in the present day].
naqaba HaAfira Ald-aAb-api He (a farrier) pierced a hole in the hoof of the beast, in order to extract what had entered into it. (IAth.)

naqabatohu nakobapN, (aor. _u {yanoqubu}, inf. n. naqobN, TA,) A misfortune, an evil accident, or a calamity befell him, (Ḳ,) and overcame him, or afflicted him; like nakabatohu. (TA.) [In the CK, for OaSaAbatohu, is put AvAbth.]

naqaba fiI AlOaroDi, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, and Anqb↓ and naq-b↓, He went, or went away, through the land, or country: (Ḳ:) [in the CK and some MṢ. copies of the Ḳ, we afterwards find naqiba fiI AlbilaAdi with kesr to the q, explained as signifying he proceeded, or journeyed, through the lands:] Anqb↓ he proceeded, or journeyed, through the country: (IAạr:) nq-bwA fiI AlbilaAdi [Ḳur, l. 35,] they proceeded, or journeyed, through the lands, seeking for a place of refuge: (Ṣ:) or they traversed the lands, and journeyed through them, much,, &c.: (Fr.:) or they went about and about, and searched, &c. (Zj.) naq-abotu↓ fiI AlMfaAqi, in a verse of Imra-el-Ḳeys, I journeyed through the tracts of the earth, and came and went. (TA.)

naqiba AlbaEiyru, aor. _a {yanoqabu}, or naqiba Huf-u AlbEyri, (L, TA,) and Anqb↓, (L,) The camel walked barefooted, syn. HafiIa, (L, Ḳ,) until his feet became worn in holes: (TA:) or naqiba AlbEyr, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Anqb↓, (Ḳ,) the camel's feet became thin, [or were worn thin; which is also a signification of HafiIa]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naqibato OaqodaAmunaA Our feet became thin in the skin, and blistered, by reason of walking. (L.)
naqaba Alxuf-a, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, He patched the boot; repaired it by patching. (Ḳ.) Also, He made the boot thin: he made [or wore] holes in it. (Mṣb.)

naqiba Alxuf-u, aor. _a {yanoqabu}, (inf. n. naqabN, TA,) The boot became lacerated, or worn through, in holes. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) [And in like manner The sole of the foot of a camel or of a man: see below: and see an ex. voce OaZal-u.]

naqaba, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, inf. n. naqobN, He (a horse) put his feet together in his running (fiI HuDorihi, [for which Golius and Freytag appear to have read fI xaSorihi,] K,) not spreading his fore feet, his running being [a kind of] leaping. (TA.)

naqaba Eani AlOaxobaAri, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, He scrutinized, investigated, searched into, examined into, or inquired into, the news; (Ḳ;) and, in like manner, anything else: (MF:) [as also nq-b↓: see the phrase nq-bwA fI AlblAd, explained above:] or he told, announced, or related, the news. (Ḳ.)
Uin-iI lamo OuWomaro Oano Oanoquba Eano quluwbi Aln-aAsi Verily I have not been commanded to scrutinize and reveal what is in the hearts of men. (TA, from a trad.)

naqaba EalaI qawomihi, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, inf. n. niqaAbapN, He acted as the naqiyb over his people; was their nqyb: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but of a man who was not nqyb, and has become so, you say naquba, with damm, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, inf. n. naqaAbapN, with fet-ḥ, He became nqyb; (Fr., Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also naqiba, aor. _a {yanoqabu}: (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ:) or nqAbp with kesr is a subst.; and with fet-ḥ, an inf. n.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like wilaAyapN and walaAyapN: so says Sb. (Ṣ.)
naqaba Alv-awoba, aor. _u {yanoqubu}, inf. n. naqobN, He made the piece of cloth into a nuqobap. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

3. naAqabotuhu, inf. n. niqaAbN; as also laqiytuhu; I met him face to face: or without appointment, (Ḳ,) and unintentionally: (TA:) or unexpectedly. (Ṣ.) nqAbFA is in the accus. case as an inf. n.; or as a word descriptive of state. (TA.)
waradotu AlmaACa niqaAbFA, (Ṣ,) or laqiytu AlmAC nqAbA, (Ḳ,) I came upon the water unexpectedly, without seeking for it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1.
Anqb His camel's feet became thin; [or were worn thin;] (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or were worn in holes by walking. (TA.)
He became a door-keeper, or chamberlain; Arab. HaAjib: (Ḳ:) or he became a naqiyb. (L, Ḳ, &c.)

entry.sense: 5: see 8.
8. Antqbt (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb) and tnq-bt↓ (Mṣb) She (a woman) veiled her face with a niqaAb (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb.)
tnqb↓ biEimaAmatihi: see txt-m.

naqobN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuqobapN↓ (Ṣ) A hole, perforation, or bore, (Ḳ,) in, or through, a wall, (Ṣ,) or anything whatever: (TA:) or a large hole, perforation, or bore, passing through a thing; such as is small being termed vaqobN, with v: (Mgh, in art. vqb:) pl. of the former nuquwbN (Mṣb) and OanoqaAbN and niqaAbN. (TA, and some copies of the Ḳ.)

naqobN (Ḳ) and naAqibapN↓ (Ṣ) An ulcer that arises in the side, (Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ,) attacking the inside of the body, (Ṣ, ISd,) and having its head inwards; (ISd;) [as also naq-aAbapN↓, for] naq-aAbaAtN signifies ulcers that come forth in the side and penetrate into the inside. (TA voce cubaAlN.) See nuqobN.

naqobN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuqobN↓ (Ḳ) and manoqabN↓ and manoqabapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A road (or narrow road, TA,) in a mountain: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) a road between two mountains: (IAth:) pl. (of the first and second, TA,) OanoqaAbN (a pl. of pauc., TA,) and niqaAbN; (Ḳ;) and of the third and fourth, manaAqibu. (TA.) See also manoqabapN.

nuqobN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and naqobN↓ (Ḳ: but the former is the more common: TA) and nuqabN↓ (Ḳ) [the first is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is nuqobapN (q. v.), of which it is called in the Ṣ the pl.: but nuqabN is the pl. of nuqobapN:] Scab, [or scabs,] (Ḳ,) absolutely: (TA:) or scattered scabs (Ṣ, Ḳ,) when they first appear: (Ṣ:) Aln-uqobapu is the first that appears of the scab; and is so called because the scabs perforate the skin: you say, of a camel, bihi nuqobapN: (Aṣ:) the first that appears of the scab, in a patch like the palm of the hand, in the side of a camel, or on his haunch, or his lip: then it spreads over him until it covers him entirely. (ISh.) Moḥammad, denying that any disease was transmitted from one thing to another, and being asked how it was that a nuqobap spread in camels, asked what transmitted the disease to the first camel. (TA.)

fulaAnN yaDaEu AlhinaMCa mawaADiEa Aln-uqobi ‡ [Such a one puts the tar upon the places of the scabs]: said of one who is clever, or skilful, and who does or says what is right. (A.) [See also qaAlabN]
naqibN, and, as a fem. epithet, naqobaACu↓, A camel whose feet have become worn in holes, [or worn thin,] by walking. (TA.) See the verb.
The former may also signify Having the scab, or what first appears thereof. (TA.) See nuqobN.
nuqabN: see nuqobN.

hom.sense: nuqobapN A mark, trace, or vestige: ex. Ealayoh nuqobapN Upon him, or it, is a mark, &c. (T.)
See naqobN.

nuqobapN † Rust, (Ḳ.) upon a sword or the head of an arrow or a spear: (M:) or naqb [i. e. nuqobN↓, q. v., a coll. gen. n., of which nuqobapN is the n. un.; or nuqabN, pl. of nuqobapN;] signifies ‡ traces of rust upon a sword or an arrow head or a spear-head, likened to the first appearances of the scab. (A.)
nuqobapN The face: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the parts surrounding the face. (L:) pl. nuqabN. (TA.)

nuqobapN A garment resembling an UizAr, having a sewed waistband or string, (HujozapN maxiyTapN: so in the Ṣ, M, L: whence it appears that the reading in the Ḳ, Hjzp muTyfapN, is erroneous: TA: [F having, it seems, found muHiyTapN written in the place of muHiyTapN:]) without a nayofaq [which is the part turned down at the top, and sewed, through which the waistband passes], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) tied as trousers, or drawers, are tied: (Ṣ:) or a pair of trousers, or drawers, having a waistband, but without a part turned down at the top, and sewed, for the waistband to pass through: if it have this, (i. e, a. nyfq,) it is called sarAwiylu: (TA;) or a piece of rag of which the upper part is made like drawers, or trousers: (L;) or a pair of drawers, or trousers, without legs. (M, voce UinobN, TA,)
nuqobapN The state, or condition; quality, mode, or manner; state with regard to apparel, &c.; external form, figure, feature, or appearance; of any thing: syn. hayoYapN. (T.)
nuqobapN Colour. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
farasN Hasanu Aln-aqobapi A horse of beautiful colour. (TA.)
See also naqiybapN.

entry.sense: niqobapN A mode of veiling the face with the niqaAb: (Ḳ:) pl. niqabN. (TA.)
Uin-ahaA laHasanapu Aln-iqobapi (Ṣ) Verily she has a comely mode of veiling her face with the nqAb. (TA.)

hom.sense: niqaAbN [A woman's face-veil;] (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a veil that is upon [or covers] the soft, or pliable, part of the nose; (AZ;) [not extending higher:] a woman's veil that extends as high as the circuit of the eye: (Mṣb:) it is of different modes: Fr says, When a woman lowers her nqAb to her eye, it [the action] is termed waSowaSapN; and when she lowers it further, to [the lower part of] the circuit of the eye, it [the veil] is called nqAb; and if it is on the extremity of the nose, it is [properly] called lifaAmN: (T:) the nqAb, with the Arabs, is that [kind of veil] from out of which appears the circuit of the eye: and the meaning of the saying in a trad. Aln-iqaAbu muHodavN is, that women's shewing the circuits of the eyes is an innovation; not that they used not to veil their faces: the [kind of] nqAb which they used reached close to the eye, and they showed one eye while the other was concealed; whereas the [kind of] nqAb, which only shows both the eyes [without their circuits] was called by them waSowaSapN [a mistake for waSowaASN] and turoquEN: [in the original, wAlnqAb lA ybdwmnh Al-A AlEynAn wkAn Asmh Alx: but the w before kAn is erroneously introduced, and perverts the sense, which is otherwise plain, and agreeable with what is said before:] then they innovated the [veil properly called] nqAb: (AʼObeyd:) pl. naqubN. (Mṣb.)
niqaAbN and minaqabN↓ A road through a rugged tract of ground: (Ḳ:) the former word used both as a sing and a pl. (TA.)

niqaAbN (a strange form of epithet, MF,) ‡ A man of great knowledge; very knowing: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or possessing a knowledge of things, or affairs: or, as also minEqabN↓, mentioned by I Ath and Z, a man possessing a knowledge of things, who scrutinizes or investigates them much; who is intelligent, and enters deeply into things. (TA.)

nqaAbN The bello, Hence the proverb, faroxaAni fiI niqaAbK [Two young birds in one belly]: applied to two things that resemble one another, (Ḳ.) In like manner one says kaAnaA fiI nqAb waAHd [They were in one belly]; meaning they were like each other, (A.)
naqiybN i. q. manoquwbN, A thing perforated, pierced, bored. or having a hole made through, or in. or into it. (TA.)
naqiybN A musical reed, or pipe. (Ḳ.)
The tongue of a pair of scales, or balance (Ḳ.)

A dog having the upper part of his mindpipe (galoSamatuhu: so in the Ṣ, Ḳ or having his windpipe, Hanojaratuhu: so in the A) perforated, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in order that his cry may be weak: a base man performs this operation on his dog, in order that guests may not hear its cry. (Ṣ: and the like is said in the L.)

naqiybu quwomK The intendant, superintendent, overseer, or inspector, of a people; he who takes notice, or cognisance, of their actions, and is responsible for them; i. q. Eariyfuhumo and XaAhiduhumo and Damiyuhumo: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like OamiynN and kafiylN: (Zj:) their head, or chief: (TA:) like EariyfN [q. v.]; i. e., one who is set over a people, and investigates their affairs: (L:) or, as some say, the greatest, or supreme, chief of a people: so called [from naqaba “he scrutinized, or investigated,”] because he is acquainted with the secret affairs of the people, and knows their virtues, or generous actions, and is the way by which one obtains knowledge of their affairs: (TA:) pl. nuqabaACu. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: niqaAbapN The office of naqiyb. (Sb: see 1.)

hom.sense: naqiybapN Mind: syn. nafosN. (Ṣ, Ḳ,) You say fulaAnN mayomuwnu Alnqybpi Such a one is of a fortunate mind, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) when the person referred to is fortunate in his affairs, succeeding in what he seeks after, or strives to accomplish: (ISk, Ṣ:) or when he is fortunate in his counsel, or advice: (Th, Ṣ:) or the phrase signifies such a one is fortunate in his actions, and in gaining what he seeks. (TA.) See also what follows. naqiybapN is also said, in the Ḳ, to signify the same as EaqolN (understanding, intellect, or intelligence); but, says SM, I have not found this in any other lexicon: only I have found the word explained in the L as signifying yumonu AlfiEoli (good fortune attending, or resulting from, an action): so probably EaqolN is a mistake for fiEolN. (TA.)
Also, Counsel, or advice. (Ḳ.) See above.
Also, Penetration of judgment; acuteness; sagacity. (Ibn-Buzurj, Ḳ.)

Also, Nature; or natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other quality: (Ḳ:) i. q. naqiymapN and EariykapN and TabiyEapN. (T, art. Erk.) Agreeably with this explanation, the phrase above mentioned is rendered in the T, in art. Erk, Such a one is of a fortunate nature, or natural disposition: (TA:) or it signifies, in this phrase, as also nqymp, i. q. lawonN, Colour, complexion, species, &c. (IAạr.) Also huwa Hasanu Aln-aqiybapi He is of a good nature, or natural disposition: and in like manner, fulaAnN fiI manaAqiba↓ jamiylapK Such a one is a person of good dispositions, or natural qualities. (L.)

naqiybapN A she-camel having a large udder: (ISd, Ḳ:) having her udder bound up with a cloth or the like, on account of its greatness and excellence: but AM says this is a corruption, and that the correct word is vqybp, with v, meaning a she-camel “abounding with milk.” (TA.)

entry.sense: naq-aAbapN: see naqobN.

naAqib and naAqibapN [the former omitted in some copies of the Ḳ] A disease that befalls a man in consequence of long sluggishness, or indolence: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, the ulcer that arises in the side. (TA.) See naqobN.

OanoqaAbN, a pl. without a sing., The ears: (M, Ḳ,) or, accord. to some, its sing. is nuqobN. (TA.) El-Katámee says,
kaAnato xuduwdu hijaAnihin-a mumaAlapF
OanoqaAbuhun-a UilaI HudaMCi Als-uw-aqi
[The cheeks of their white camels were with their ears inclined to the singing of the drivers]. But OanaqFA bihin-a, “by reason of their pleasure,” is also read, for OanoqaAbuhun-a: (TA:) [so that the meaning is The cheeks of their white camels were inclined, by reason of their pleasure. to the singing of the drivers].
manoqabN The navel: or [a place] before it: (Ḳ:) where the farrier makes a perforation in order that a yellow fluid may issue forth: (Ṣ:) so in a horse. (TA.)
See naqobN.
minoqabN An iron instrument with which a farrier perforates the navel of a beast of carriage (Ṣ, Ḳ) in order that a yellow fluid may issue forth. (Ṣ.) See manoqabN, and niqaAbN.

hom.sense: manoqabapN: see naqobN.

A narrow way between two houses, (L, Ḳ,) along which one cannot pass. (L.) It is said in a trad., that one does not possess the right of pre-emption (AlX-ufoEap) with respect to a mnqbp; and this word is explained as signifying a wall: syn. HaAYiTN: [and so in the Ḳ:] or a way between two houses, as though it were perforated from one to the other: or a road, or way, over an elevated piece of ground. (L.)

manoqabapN A virtue; an excellence; contr. of mavolabapN: (Ṣ:) a cause of glorying: (Ḳ:) generosity of action, or conduct: (L:) a [good] disposition, or natural quality: [see naqiybapN:] (TA:) a memorable, or generous action, and [good] internal quality: (A:) pl. manaAqibu: (TA:) rjulN cuw manaAqiba A man of memorable, or generous, actions, and [good] internal qualities. (A.)

entry.sense: 1. naqata, [aor. _u {yanoqutu},] inf. n. naqotN, He took out, or extracted, marrow [from a bone]. (Ḳ.) Az, quotes, from Aboo-Turáb, on the authority of Aboo-'Ameythel, nuqita AlEaZomu, and nukita, The marrow of the bone was taken out, or extracted. (L.) And J says, naqat-u Almux-a aor. _u {yanoqutu}, inf. n. naqotN, is a dial. form of naqawotuhu, meaning, I took out, or extracted the marrow [from a bone]: as though they had changed the w into t. (L.) But it is said in a marginal note in the Ṣ, Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee says, What I remember to have heard is naqavotu AlEaZoma, aor. _u {yanoqutu}, inf. n. naqovN, I took out, or extracted, the marrow from the bone; and so Uinotaqavotuhu, with the three-pointed v; and naqayotuhu, and Uinotaqayotuhu, and naquwotuhu. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. naqava, aor. _u {yanoquvu}; and nq-v↓, (inf. n. tanoqiyvN, Ṣ,) and Antqv↓; He hastened, was quick. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
xarajotu Oanoquvu I went forth hastening. (Ṣ.)
xaraja yanoquvu Als-ayora, and yanotaqivu↓, He went forth hastening in his pace. (TA.)
naqava, Hadiyvahu [aor. _u {yanoquvu},] He mixed, or confounded, his discourse, like as one mixes food. (Ḳ.)
naqavahu biAlkalaAmi, [aor. _u {yanoquvu},] (and Antqvhu↓, TA,) He hurt him by words. (Ḳ.)
naqava AlOaroDa, aor. _u {yanoquvu}, inf. n. naqovN. He dug up the earth with a hoe or shovel. (AZ.)
naqava XayoYFA; (or, accord. to the TA. Eano XaIoCK,) and Antqv↓, He dug up the earth from a thing. (Ḳ.)
naqava AlEaZoma (aor. _u {yanoquvu}, inf. n. naqovN, TA;) and Antqvhu↓; and tnq-vh↓; (TA;) He took out, or extracted, the marrow from the bone. (Ḳ.) See also naqata. (TA.)

naqava, inf. n. naqovN; and nq-v↓, inf. n. tanoqiyvN; He removed a thing. Ex. laA tunaq-ivu miyrtanaA She used not to remove our wheat, or provision, nor to take it forth, nor scatter it; but kept it faithfully. (TA, from a trad.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
5. tnq-v He endeavoured to make a woman incline to him, and to render her affectionate to him: (Ḳ:) as though he drew forth her love, like as one draws forth the marrow from a bone. (TA.)
tnq-v DayoEatahu i. q. taEah-adahaA. (TA.)
See 1.
8: see 1.
naqovN Malicious, or mischievous, misrepresentation; calumny; slander. (IAạr.)
naqaAvi (in measure like qaTaAmi) The hyena. (Ḳ.)
naqiyvapu AlbiYori i. q. nabiyvatuhaA. (TA voce qaAHapN, in art. qwH.)

1. naqaHa XayoYFA, aor. _a {yanoqaHu}, (inf. n. naqoHN, TA,) He peeled, or barked, a thing; peeled off, stripped off, or removed, its outer covering. (Ḳ, TA.) naqaHa AlEuwda, (Mṣb,) or AlEaSaA, (T,) aor. _a {yanoqaHu}, inf. n. naqoHN, (Mṣb,) He pared, or trimmed, the stick, or staff, by cutting off its knots: (T, Mṣb:) and in like manner you say of anything from which you pare off somewhat. (T.)

naqaHa AljicoEa, inf. n. naqoHN; (Ḳ;) and nq-Hhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoqiyHN; (Ṣ;) He pared off the knots of the palm-trunk: (Ḳ:) or he pruned, or trimmed, the trunk of the palm-tree, by cutting off the stumps of the branches, or by cutting off the superfluous branches. (Ṣ.)
naqaHa, (TA,) and AnqH↓, (Ḳ,) He stripped off the ornaments of his sword [to sell them] in a time of dearth and poverty. (Ḳ, TA.)

naqaHa AlEaZoma, aor. _a {yanoqaHu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. naqoHN; (TA;) and nq-Hhu↓, (inf. n. tanoqiyHN, Ṣ;) and AntqHhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He extracted the marrow from the bone: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or nq-Hh has an intensive signification. (Mṣb.)
naqaHa XayoYFA He separated what was good from what was bad of the thing. (Mṣb.)
2. nq-H AlX-iEora, inf. n. tanoqiyHN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AnqHhu↓, inf. n. UinoqaAHN; (Ḳ;) ‡ He trimmed, pruned, or put into a right or proper state, poetry, or verses. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nq-H AlkalaAma ‡ He scrutinized the language, and examined it well: or he put it to rights, or trimmed it, and removed its faults, or defects. (TA.)
See 1.
4: see 1 and 2.

5. tnq-H XaHomuhu, (Ḳ,) or XaHomu Aln-aAqapi, (Ṣ,) or XaHomu naAqatihi, (TA, &c.,) ‡ His fat, (Ḳ,) or the fat of the she-camel, (Ṣ,) or the fat of his she-camel, (TA, &c.,) became little in quantity, or diminished, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) or partially went away. (A.)
8: see 1.
xayoru AlX-iEori AlHawoliI-u Almunaq-aHu ‡ [The best of poetry is that which is a year old, and trimmed, or pruned]. (Ṣ.)

1. naqaxa, aor. _a {yanoqaxu}, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. naqoxN (Ṣ, L) and nuqaAxN, (L,) He struck, smote, or beat. (Ḳ.) naqaxa raOosahu He struck his head with a staff, or sword, or some other hard thing: or he struck his head so that the brain came forth: (L:) or he broke his head so as to disclose the brain; as also naqafa. (Ṣ, L.) naqaxa dimaAgahu He broke his brain. (Ḳ.)
Also, naqaxa (L) and Antqx↓ (L, Ḳ) He extracted marrow (L, Ḳ) from a bone. (L.)
naqaHa AlEaTaXa bibarodihi † It (sweet water) broke, [or abated, or allayed,] thirst, by its coolness, or coldness. (L, from a trad.)
8: see 1.

nuqaAxN Sweet water; that has no saltness; (AO, Th, Ṣ;) that strikes (yanoqaxu) the heart (or almost does so, L) by its coldness: (Ṣ:) or cold, or cool, and sweet, and clear, water: (Ḳ:) or sweet water, that breaks [or abates or allays] (yanoqaHu, i. e. yakosiru,) thirst by its coolness, or coldness: (L, from a trad.:) or abundant water which a man makes to well forth in a place where was no water. (ISh.)
Also, Pure, mere, unadulterated, or genuine. (T, Ḳ.)
hecaA nuqaAxu AlEarabiy-api (Fr) ‡ This is pure Arabic; or the purest, choicest, best, or most excellent, of Arabic. (Fr, A.)
Also nuqaAxN Sleep in health and safety. (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naqada Ald-araAhima (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb) aor. _u {yanoqudu}, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. naqodN (L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tanoqaAdN; (L, Ḳ;) and AntqdhA↓ (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tnq-dhA↓; (L, Ḳ:) He picked, or separated, the money, or pieces of money, (Lth, L, Ḳ,) and put forth the bad; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) he picked, or separated, the good money from the bad: (A:) he examined the money, or pieces of money, to pick, or separate, the good from the bad: (Mṣb:) and the verbs are used in the same sense with respect to other things than pieces of money. (Ḳ.)
[naqada, aor. _u {yanoqudu}, inf. n. naqodN, q. v. infra, He gave cash, or ready money; paid in cash, or ready money. Often used in this sense.]

naqadahu Alv-amana, aor. _u {yanoqudu}, inf. n. naqodN; He gave him the price in cash, or ready money: (L:) or simply he gave him the price; as also naqada lahu Alv-amana: (A:) and naqadahu Ald-araAhima, and naqada lahu Ald-araAhim, he gave him the money, or pieces of money. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.)
[Hence, from the first meaning,] naqada AlkalaAma, [and AlX-iEora,] and so He picked out the faults of the language, [and of the poetry;] syn. naAqaXahu. (TA.)
Ainotaqada↓ AlXiEora EalaI qaAYilihi ‡ [He picked out the faults of the poetry and urged them against its author.] (A.)

naqadahu binaZarihi, and naqada Uilayohi, aor. _u {yanoqudu}, (L,) inf. n. naqodN (L, Ḳ) ‡ He looked furtively at, or towards it: (L, Ḳ:*) and so nqdh biEayobihi: (L:) and nqd biEayonihi Alyh he continued looking furtively at, or towards, it: you say also, maA zaAla baSaruhu yanoqudu UilaI celika [his gaze ceased not to be furtively directed at, or towards, that]: as though likened to the look of a man picking, or separating, what is good from what is bad: (A:) and maA zaAla yanoqudu baSarahu UilaI AlX-aIoCi he ceased not to look at, or towards, the thing. (Ṣ, L.)
