yaqida, (Ṣ, L,) [aor. _a {yanoqadu},] inf. n. naqadN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and, as some say, naqada; (Ṣ, L;) It (a tooth, Ṣ, L, Ḳ, and a horn, T, L, and a hoof of a horse or the like, L,) became eroded, (T, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and much broken: (L, Ḳ:) and it (the hoof of a horse or the like) sealed off, part after part: (Ṣ, L:) it (the trunk of a tree) became wormeaten. (L.)

entry.sense: 3. nAqdhu ‡ He reckoned with him to the utmost, syn. naAqaXahu, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) fiI OamorK in, or respecting, an affair, (Ṣ, L,) [picking out his faults].
4. Anqd It (a tree) put forth its leaves. (L, Ḳ.)
5: see 1.

hom.sense: 8. Antqd Ald-araAhima He received the money, or pieces of money; (Lth, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and Alv-amana the price. (A.)
See 1.
Antqd It (a worm) ate the trunk of a tree, and rendered it hollow. (L.)
He (a boy) grew up into manhood. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: naqodN [properly an inf. n. used in the sense of a pass. part. n., and thus signifying “paid,” Cash, or ready money: or simply money]. You say naqodN jay-idN [Good cash, or ready money: or good money]: pl. nuquwdN jiyaAdN. (A.) Alt-aqodaAni signifies Silver and gold money; dirhems and deenárs. (TA in art. ErD.)
naqodN Payment in cash, or ready money; contr. of nasoyYapN: (L, Ḳ:) the giving of naqod [i. e., cash, or ready money]: (Ḳ:) [an inf. n.: see 1].
Ald-irohamu naqodN The piece of money is of full weight, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,*) and good. (Ṣ, L.)

hecihi miAYapN naqodu Aln-aAsi [This is a hundred, ready money of the people] is a phrase used by the Arabs, in which l is meant to be understood [before Aln-As: i. e. AlnAs is for liln-aAsi; and naqodu for naqodN, as an epithet of mAYp; you may also say naqoda AlnaAs, making nqd a denotative of state; but] the epithetic mode of construction is that which prevails in this case. (Sb, L.)
naqodN.

The saying of the poet,
latunotajan-a waladFA Oawo naqodaA
means She will certainly bring forth a she-camel, which shall be a permanent acquisition for breeding, or a male, which shall be sold: for they seldom kept the male camels. (Th, L.)

dictScrap.title:
nuqodN / nuqodapN
nuqodN / nuqodapN
nuqadN / nuqadapN
naqadN / naqadapN

entry.sense: nuqodN (Lḥ, L, Ḳ,) and nuqudN↓ (Ḳ) and nuqadN↓. (Lḥ, Az, L,) the form most frequently heard by Az from the Arabs, (L,) or naqadN↓, (Ḳ,) [coll. gen. n.] A certain kind of tree, (Lḥ, L, Ḳ,) accord. to AA, of the description termed xuwSap, having a blossom resembling the bahoramaAn, i. e. the EuSofur [or bastard-saffron]; (AḤn, L;) its blossom is yellow, and it grows in plain, or soft, grounds: (Az, L:) n. un. with p; (Ḳ;) nuqodapN (Lḥ, Ṣ, L) and nuqudapN (TA) and nuqadapN (Lḥ, L) and naqadapN. (TA.)
Also nuqodapN↓, (L,) or niqodapN↓, (IAạr, L, Ḳ,) The karawoyaMC [or caraway]. (IAạr, L, Ḳ.)
See naqidN.
niqodN: see naqidN.

naqadN [a coll. gen. n.] A kind of sheep, of ugly form; (Ḳ;) a kind of sheep of El-Bahreyn, having short legs and ugly faces: (Ṣ, L:) or a kind of small sheep of El-Ḥijáz: (L:) or, simply, lambs: (A, L:) [see an ex. in a prov. cited voce XaAma in art. Xym:] n. un. with p {naqadapN}: (Ṣ, L:) applied alike to the male and female: (L:) pl. niqaAdN, and [quasi-pl. n.] niqaAdapN. (L, Ḳ.) Aṣ says, that the best of wool is that of naqad. And one says, Oacal-u mina Aln-aqadi [More abject, or vile, than the sheep called nqd]. (Ṣ, L.)
Also, † The lower sort of people. (L.)
See nuqodN and naqidN.

naqidN, (L,) or niqodN↓, (Ḳ,) Slow in growing up into manhood, and having little flesh: (L, Ḳ:) [and so nuqodN↓, accord. to the CK: but wyuDm- is there put by mistake for wbiDam-K: and the former, (Ṣ, L,) or naqadN↓, (Ḳ,) a boy despised and little in the eyes of others, that scarcely grows up into manhood; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) sometimes thus applied. (Ṣ, L.)]
naqidN A horn eaten, or eroded, at the root. (L.) See also naqida.
nuqudN and nuqadN and nuqodapN and niqodahN: see nuqodN.
nuqaAdapN The choice part of a thing. (JK.)
huwa mino nuqaAdapi quwomihi ‡ He is of the best of his people. (A.)
naq-aAdN A shepherd who tends the kind of sheep called naqad: (L, Ḳ:) or a possessor of skins of that kind of sheep. (Th, L.)
See naAqidN.

naAqidN [One who picks, or separates, money, and puts forth the bad; who picks, or separates, good money from bad:] who examines money, to pick, or separate the good from the bad: [as also naq-aAdN↓:] pl. nuq-aAdN (Mṣb) [and naqadapN].
huwa mino naqadapi AlX-iEori and mino nuq-aAdihi, ‡ [He is one of those who pick out the faults of poetry]. (A.)

Oanoqadu The hedge-hog; Alqunofucu; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) a proper name, like OasaAmapu applied to the lion: (Ṣ:) as also AlOanoqadu; (Ḳ;) but some disallow the prefixing of the art.; (TA;) and AlOanoqacu. (L.) Hence the saying, baAta bilayoli Oanoqada, (Ṣ, L,) or bilayolapi Oanoqada, (A, L,) He passed the night of the hedge-hog; i. e. sleepless: (L:) because the hedge-hog remains sleepless (and sees, L) all night: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and OasoraI mino Oanoqada [A greater journeyer by night than the hedge-hog]. (A, L.)
Oanoqadu layolK A calumniator; a slanderer; as also qunofucu layolK. (L, art. qnfc.)
Also, AlOanoqadu (L, Ḳ,) and AlUinoqidaAnu↓ (Ḳ) The tortoise: (L, Ḳ:) or the latter, the male tortoise: (Lth:) as also with c. (TA.)
AlUinoqidaAnu: see preceding sentence.

1. naqica, aor. _a {yanoqacu}, inf. n. naqacN; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or naqaca, (A, L,) aor. _u {yanoqucu}, (L,) inf. n. naqocN; (A, L;) He became safe, in safety, saved, or liberated; he escaped. (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
naqocFA laka Safety to thee! Said to a man stumbling. (A, Ḳ.)
See also 4.
2: see 4.

4. Anqchu, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UinoqaAcN; (Ḳ;) and Astnqchu↓; and tnq-chu↓; (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) and nq-cN↓, inf. n. tanoqiycN; and naqacahu↓, [aor. _u {yanoqucu},] inf. n. naqocN; (Ḳ;) He saved, rescued, or liberated, him or it, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from such a one, (Ṣ, L,) and from evil. (Mṣb.)
5: see 4.

naqacN A thing that one has saved, rescued, or liberated; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like nafaDN and qabaDN; (Ṣ, L;) as also naqiycN↓ and naqiycapN: (L:) a man saved, or rescued, or liberated: (L:) also, a horse taken from another people: (L:) or a camel, &c. taken by, and then recovered from, the enemy; as also naqiycapN and naqiycN; pl. naqaAYicu: (A:) or naqiycapN↓ signifies a horse saved, or rescued, or liberated, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and taken, (Ṣ, L,) from the enemy; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) pl. naqaAYicu: (Ṣ, L;) or the sing. of nqAYc, signifying horses saved, or rescued, or liberated, from the hands of men, or of the enemy, is naqiycN↓, without p: (IAạr, L:) and, accord. to El-Muffaddal, (L,) naqiycapN↓ signifies a coat of mail, diroEN; (L, Ḳ;) because it saves the person wearing it from the sword: (L:) and Az says, I have read in the handwriting of Shemir, that it signifies a coat of mail saved, or rescued, from the enemy. (L.) You say also, huwa naqiycapu buWosK, and humo naqaAYcu buWosK, He is saved, or rescued, from distress, or adversity; and they are, &c. (A.)
maA lahu XaqacN walaA naqacN He possesses not anything. (Ḳ.)
naqiycN and naqiycapN: see naqacN.
Also the latter, A woman having had a husband. (Ḳ.)
AlOanoqacu [or Oanoqacu, without the art.,] The hedgehog; Alqutofucu: (Ḳ;) as also with d. (TA.)

1. naqara, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoquru}, inf. n. naqorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He (a bird) pecked, or picked up, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a grain, (Ṣ,) or grains, (A, Mṣb,) from this place and that, (A, Ḳ,) biminoqaArihi with his beak. (A.) [Accord. to the TA, the addition “from this place and that,” which is found in the Ḳ and A, and in one place in the Ṣ, seems to be unnecessary. And Antqr↓ signifies the same: see 8, in art. qb.]

[Hence, because of the sure aim with which a bird pecks a thing,] the same verb, having the same [aor. and] inf. n. signifies, ‡ It (an arrow) hit the butt. (Mṣb.) And He (an archer) hit the butt, without making his arrow to pass through, partly or wholly. (TA.)
[Hence also,] † He took [or picked] a thing, as, for instance, food, with the finger. (TA.)

Also, (M, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, TA,) He struck a thing (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ,* TA,) with a thing: (IḲṭṭ, TA:) [generally, he struck, knocked, or pecked, a thing with a pointed instrument, like as a bird strikes a thing with its beak:] he struck [or pecked] a mill-stone, or a stone, &c., with a minoqaAr [which is a pick, or a kind of pickaxe; i. e., he wrought it into shape, and roughened it in its surface, with a pick]. (M, TA.)

[Hence,] ‡ He wrote [or engraved writing] fiI HajarK upon a stone. (A, Ḳ.) Whence the saying, Alt-aEoliymu fiI AlS-igari kaAln-aqori EalaI AlHajari [or, as in a verse of Nifṭaweyh, fiI AlHajari, i. e., Teaching in infancy is like engraving writing upon stone]. (TA.)

He struck [or fillipped] a man's head, and in like manner a lute, and a tambourine, with his finger. (TA.) You say also Oanoqara↓ Oucunahu, meaning, He struck [or fillipped] his ear with his finger. (AA, in TA, art. nTb.)

[Hence,] naqara, [aor. _u {yanoquru}, inf. n. naqorN, as appears from what follows;] and Oanoqara↓; ‡ [He made a snapping with his thumb and middle finger;] he struck his thumb against the end of the middle finger and made a sound with them. (A.) [And in like manner the former verb used transitively; as in the following instance:] waDaEa Tarafa UibohaAmihi EalaI baATini sab-aAbatihi vum-a naqarahaA [‡ He put the end of his thumb against the inner side of his first finger, then made a snapping with it]. (TA.) See also naqorN, below.

[Hence also,] naqara biAld-aAb-api, (T, A, TṢ,) or biAlfarasi, (Ṣ,) aor. _u {yanoquru}, (TA,) inf. n. naqorN; (T, Ṣ, TṢ;) and Oanoqara↓, (A, TṢ,) inf. n. UinoqaArN; (TṢ;) ‡ He made a [smacking or] slight sound, to put in motion the [beast or] horse, by making his tongue adhere to his palate and then opening [or suddenly drawing it away]: (Ṣ:) or he struck with his tongue the place of utterance of the letter n and made a [smacking] sound [by suddenly withdrawing his tongue]: (A:) naqorN signifies the making the end of the tongue to adhere to the palate, then making a sound [by suddenly withdrawing it]: (M, Ḳ:) or one's putting his tongue above his central incisors, at the part next the palate, then making a smacking sound [so I render vum-a yanoqur]: (TA:) [the sounds thus described, which are nearly the same, are commonly made by the Arabs in the present day, in urging beasts of carriage:] or an agitation of the tongue (Ḳ, TA) in the mouth, upwards and downwards: (TA:) or a sound, (so in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) or slight sound, (so in the TṢ [as mentioned in the TA] and in some copies of the Ḳ) by which a horse is put in motion: (TṢ, Ḳ:) or naqara bilisaAnihi, accord. to IḲṭṭ, signifies he struck his palate with his tongue to quiet the horse: but this is at variance with what is said by Az, J, and ISd, and requires consideration. (TA.)
A poet, (Ṣ,) Fedekee El-Minkaree, (Ḳ,) i. e., ʼObeyd Ibn-Máweeyeh, of the tribe of Teiyi, (TA,) uses Aln-aquro for Aln-aqoru, meaning Aln-aqoru biQloxayoli [The smacking with the tongue to urge the horses]: pausing after the word, at the end of a hemistich, he transfers the vowel of the r to the q, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) agreeably with the dial. of certain of the Arabs, (TA,) that the hearer may know it to be the vowel of the [final] letter when there is no pause; (Ṣ;) like as you say, hecaA bakoru and mararotu bibakiro: but this is not done when the word is in the accus. case (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and if you choose, you may make the final letter quiescent in pausing, though it is preceded by a quiescent letter. (Ṣ.)

Hence also, faUicaA nuqira fiI Aln-aAquwri [Ḳur, lxxiv. 8,] ‡ For when the horn shall be blown: (Ṣ,* A,* Bḍ, Ḳ:) from naqorN signifying ‡ the making a sound: originally, striking, which is the cause of sound. (Bḍ.) See also naAquwrN, below.

Also, naqara He bored, perforated, or made a hole through or in or into, a thing: (TA:) or he did so with a minoqaAr: (Ṣ:) and, inf. n. naqorN, he hollowed out, or excavated, a piece of wood. (Mgh, Mṣb.) nuqirN and Ainotaqara↓, (so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or Ounotuqira↓, (so in other copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) both in the pass. form, (TA,) said of stone and of wood and the like, signify alike, (Ḳ,) It was bored, or perforated, or it had a hole made through or in or into it: (TA:) [and it was hollowed out.] You say, naqara AlbayoDapa Eani Alfaroxi, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoquru}, inf. n. naqorN, (TA.) He made a hole in the egg [so as to disclose the young bird]. (Ḳ.) And naqarat Alxayolu, (A,) and Antqrt↓ bHwAfrhA nuqarFA, (Lth, Ḳ,) The horses made hollows in the ground with their hoofs. (Lth, A, Ḳ.) And in like manner, Antqrt↓ Als-uyuwlu nuqarFA The torrents left hollows in the ground, in which water was retained. (TA.)

Hence, naqara Eani AlOamori; (Mṣb;) and nq-r↓ Eanohu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoqiyrN; (Ṣ;) and nq-rhu↓; and tnq-rhu↓: and Antqrhu↓; (Ḳ;) ‡ He searched or inquired into the thing; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and endeavoured to know it: (TA;) and so naqara Eani lxabari ‡ he investigated the news, and endeavoured to know it. (A.) [And hence,] nq-r↓ Als-ahoma bayona UiSobaEayohi. (Ḳ, in art. Hn,) or EalaI AlUibohaAmi, inf. n. tanoqiyrN, (Ḳ, in art. dwm,) [He tried the sonorific quality of the arrow by turning it round between his fingers, or upon his thumb: see Han-aAnN, and dar-a Als-ahomu, and see also 4, in art. dwm: or] nq-r Als-ahoma signifies he made the arrow to produce a sharp sound [by turning it round between his fingers, or] upon his thumb. (TḲ, in art. dwm.)
2: see 1, last two sentences.

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in three places, in the first half.

Anqr Eanohu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UinofaArN, (TA,) He refrained, forbore, abstained, or desisted, from it or him; he left or relinquished, it or him. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.) Hence the saying, Darabahu famaA Oanoqara Eanohu Hat-aI qatalahu He beat him and left him not until be killed him. (TA.) And hence the saying of I’Ab, maAkaAna Qll-ehu liyunoqira Eano qaAtili QlomuWomini, i. e., God will not leave the slayer of the believer until He destroy him (Ṣ, TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, last signification.
8: see 1, latter part, in four places.

naqorN ‡ A slight sound that is heard in consequence of striking the thumb against the middle finger [and then letting them fly apart in opposite directions, passing each other]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or the snapping with the fingers or with the thumb and middle finger, or with the thumb and first finger; as also naqyrN↓: n. un. of the former with p {naqorapN}.] One says, maA OavaAbahu naqorapN ‡ [He did not reward him with even a snap of the fingers;] meaning, with anything: (Ṣ, Ḳ [in the former of which it is implied that nqrp thus used is from naqorN in the first of the senses explained above;]) not used thus save in a negative phrase. (Ṣ.) A poet says,
wahun- HaraI Oal-aA yuvibonaka nqorapN
waOanota HaruI biAln-aAr Hiyna tuviybu
‡ [And they are fit, or worthy, not to reward thee with anything, and thou art fit for, or worthy of, the fire of hell when thou rewardest]. (Ṣ.) Or the right reading in both these instances is nuqorapF↓, with damm. (TA.) [See nuqorapN.] One says also, lamo yakotarito liI biqadur naqorap UiSobaEK ‡ [He did not care for me so much as a snap of a finger]. (A.) [See also an ex. voce in a verse cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. XOw.] I'Ab, in explanation of the words of the Ḳur, [iv. 123,] walaA yuZolamuwna naqiyrFA, put the end of the thumb against the inner side of his first finger, then made a snapping with it (vum-a naqarahaA), and said, This is what is termed naqiyrN↓; [denoting the lit. meaning to be ‡ And they shall not be wronged a snap of the fingers.] (TA.) But see nuqorapN, below.

Also, A sound, or slight sound, by which a horse is put in motion: (TṢ, Ḳ:) as also naqiyrN↓: (TA:) or the former has one or other of the different significations assigned to it above, in the explanations under the head of naqara biAld-aAb-api. (Ḳ, &c.)
niqorN: see nuqorapN.
naqorapN: see naqorN, in four places.

nuqorapN A small hollow or cavity in the ground: (Ṣ:) or a hollow or cavity in the ground, not large: (Mṣb:) or a hollow or cavity in the ground in which water stagnates: (TA:) or a round wahodap [or hollow] in the ground, (Ḳ, TA,) not large, in which water stagnates: (TA:) pl. nuqarN (A, Ḳ) and niqaArN: (Ḳ:) naqiyrN↓ also signifies a hollow, or cavity, in the ground; and its pl. is OanoqirapN. (Ṣ.)

Hence, (Ṣ.) The place where the qamaHoduwap [or occiput] ends, in the back part of the neck; (Ḳ;) i. e., the hollow in the back of the neck; (TA;) what is called nuqorapu AlqafaA; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) i. e., the hollow where the brain ends: the cupping in that part occasions forgetfulness: (Mṣb.) [and any similar hollow as the pit of the stomach: and a dimple: accord. to present usage; and in this sense it is used in the A, Ḳ, and TA, voce faHoSapN.]
The cavity, or socket, of the eye. (Ḳ.)

Foramen and; syn. vaqobu AlAisoti: (Ḳ:) but in the L it is said that nuqorapu Alwariki signifies the hole, or perforation, that is the middle of the haunch; [app. meaning the sacro-ischiatic foramen: see AlfaAYilu, in art. fyl: but perhaps it may sometimes mean the socket of the thigh-bone; for nuqorpN signifies any socket of a bone.] (TA.)

The little spot [or embryo] upon the back of a date stone, (AHeyth, Ḳ,) which is as though it were hollowed. (TA,) and from which the palm-tree grows forth: (AHeyth;) as also naqyrN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and niqorN↓ (Ḳ) and OunoquwrN↓. (Ṣgh, Ḳ) You say, maA OavaAbahu nuqorapN, (El-Basáir, TA,) and naqiyrFA↓, (A,) lit., [He did not reward him] with even a little spot on the back of a date-stone; (A, El-Basáïr;) meaning, ‡ with the meanest thing. (El- Basáïr.) [In the Ṣ and Ḳ, mA AvAbh naqorapN: see naqorN.] And maA OaEonaI Ean-iI nuqorapN ‡ He did not stand me in stead of the meanest thing. (A.) Lebeed says, bewailing the death of his brother Arbad.
walayosa Aln-aAsu baEodaka fiI naqiyrK↓
lit., [And the people, after thee, are not worth] a little spot on the back of a date-stone; meaning, labosuwA baEodaka fiI XaIoCK ‡ [after thee they are not worth anything]. (Ṣ.) And hence, accord. to ISk [and the Jel], the saying in the Ḳur, [iv. 123.] walaA yuZolamuwna naqiyrFA [And they shall not be wronged even as to a little spot on the back of a date-stone.] (TA.) Hence also, [in verse 56 of the same chap.,] laA yuWotuwna Aln-aAsa naqiyrFA ‡ They would not give men a thing as inconsiderable as the little hollow in the back of a date-stone. (Jel.) See also naqorN.
The place in which a bird lays its eggs: (Ḳ:) pl. nuqarN. (TA.)

hom.sense: naqiyrN: see naqorN, in three places.
What is bored, or perforated; and what is hollowed out, or excavated; (maA nuqiba, TA, and maA nuqira, Ḳ, TA;) of stone, and of wood, and the like. (Ḳ, TA.)

A piece of wood, (Mṣb,) or a block of wood, (OaSolu xaXabapK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or a stump, or the lower part, (OaSol,) of a palm-tree, (T,) which is hollowed out, and in which the beverage called nabiyc is made; (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the nbyc whereof becomes strong: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a stump, or the lower part, (ASl,) of a palm-tree, which it was a custom of the people of El-Yemámeh to hollow out, then they crushed in it ripe dates and unripe dates, which [with water poured upon them] they left until fermentation had taken place therein and subsided: (AʼObeyd:) or a stump, or the lower part, (ASl,) of a palm-tree, whereof the middle was hollowed out, then dates were put in them, with water, which became intoxicating nbyc: (IAth:) the word is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., that Moḥammad forbade Aln-aqiyr, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* TA,) meaning, the nbyc thereof. (TA.)
A trunk of a palm-tree, hollowed out, and having the like of steps made in it, by which one ascends to gurf [or upper chambers]. (Ḳ. [See also EajalapN.])
See also nuqorapN, throughout.

entry.sense: nuqaArapN The quantity [of grain] which a bird pecks, or picks up. (Ḳ.) See 8, in art. qb.
What remains from the boring, or excavating, (naqor,) of stones: like nujaArapN and nuHaAtapN. (TA.)
naq-aArN An engraver: or, accord. to Az, one who engraves stirrups and bits and the like: and one who bores (yanoquru) mill-stones. (TA.)
‡ One who investigates, scrutinizes, or examines, and endeavours to know, affairs, and news. (TA.)
nAaqirN act. part. n. of naqara.

‡ An arrow that hits, (Mṣb,) or has hit, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) the butt, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the eye of the target: (A:) if it do not hit the butt it is not so called: (Ṣ, TA:) [but see a phrase following:] pl. nawaAqiru. (A, Mṣb.)

[Hence,] OaxoTaOato nawaAqiruhu ‡ [lit., His arrows that were wont to hit the butt missed]; meaning, he did not continue in the right course. (TA.) [And hence,] naAqirapN ‡ A calamity; (Ḳ, TA;) pl. nawaAqiru. (TA.) One says, ramaAhu Ald-ahoru binaAqirapK, and binawaAqira, ‡ Fortune smote him with a calamity, and with calamities. (TA.)

Also, naAqirapN ‡ A right argument, allegation, evidence, or the like; syn. Huj-apN muSiybapN: in the Ḳ, a w is incorrectly inserted between these two words: but the pl., nawaAqiru, is afterwards correctly rendered in the Ḳ. (TA.) One says, OatatoniI Eanohu nawaAqiru ‡ There came to me, from him, speech which displeased me, or grieved me: or right arguments, or the like, (Ḳ, TA,) like arrows hitting the mark. (TA.) In the L, ramaAhu binawaAqira ‡ He cast at him words that hit the mark. (TA.)

naAquwrN ‡ A horn in which one blows; syn. SuwrN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in the Ḳur, lxxiv. 8, the horn in which the angel shall blow for the congregating at the resurrection: the blast there mentioned is said to be the second blast: Fr. says that it is the first of the two blasts. (TA.)
OunoquwrN: see nuqorapN.
minoqarN: see minoqaArN.
munaq-aru AlEayoni, (Ḳ,) and munotaqaruhaA↓, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) or munotaqiruhaA↓, (CK,) Having the eye sunken. (Ḳ.)

minoqaArN The beak of a bird; that which is to a bird as the mouth to a man; (Mṣb;) because it pecks, or picks up, with it: (TA:) or of a bird which is not one of prey; that of a bird of prey being called minosarN: (Fṣ, and Ṣ in art. nsr, and MF:) therefore the explanation in the Ḳ, which is, the minosar of a bird, is incorrect: (MF:) [and the dual signifies the two mandibles of a bird; used in this sense in the TA, art. Sgw:] pl. manaAqiyru. (Ṣ.)
Hence, (TA,) The fore part of the xuf- [app. meaning the foot of a camel, not a boot]. (Ḳ.)

[A kind of pickaxe; or a pick, by which a mill-stone, or the like, is pecked, or wrought into shape, and roughened in its surface; (see 1;)] an iron instrument like the faOos, (A, Ḳ,) slender, round, and having a xalof [or pointed head], (TA,) with which one pecks, (yunoqarubihaA, A, Ḳ, TA,) and cuts stones, and hard earth; (TA;) used [also] by a carpenter: (Ṣ:) and minoqarN↓ signifies [app. the same, or nearly the same,] i. q. miEowalN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [the former is applied in the present day to a chisel:] pl. of the former, manaAqiyru; (Ṣ;) and of the latter, manaAqiru. (TA.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
kaOaroHaMCi raqodK zal-amatohaA AlmanaAqiru
[Like mill-stones of Rakd (a mountain so called) which the minkars have rounded]. (TA.) See zal-ama.
munotaqaru AlEayoni, or munotaqiruhaA: see munaq-ar.

niqorisN [Arthritis, or gout: or, specially, podagra, or gout in the foot or feet:] a certain disease, well known; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) a swelling and pain in the joints: (Az, TA:) or in the leg or foot: (TA:) or in the joints of the ankles and the toes: (Ḳ:) or a swelling in the joints of the foot, and mostly in the great toe, a property of which is that it does not collect thick purulent matter, nor exude moisture, because it is in a member not fleshy: and of the same kind are arthritis, or pain of the joints, (wajaEu AlmafaASili,) and sciatica, or hip-gout, (Eiroqu Aln-asaA,) but differing in name because differing in state. (Mṣb.)

1. naqaza, (Ṣ, A,) aor. _u {yanoquzu}, (Ṣ, TA,) and _i, (TA,) inf. n. naqozN and naqazaAnN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nuqaAzN, (TA,) He (an antelope, Ṣ and A) leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) as also nq-z↓, (M, TA,) in his running, (Ṣ,) or on his nawaAqiz, i. e., his legs: (A:) or he (generally referring to a raven or crow, or a sparrow, or locust, or the like,) leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded, upwards; he hopped: (TA:) or he put his legs together in leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding: when the legs are spread, the action is termed nafozN. (IDrd, TA.)

hom.sense: 2: see 1.
Also, inf. n. tanoqiyzN, He made to leap, jump, spring, or bound: (Ṣ:) and nq-zt she (a woman) danced, or dandled, her child; (Ḳ,* TA;) as also nf-zt. (Ṣ, &c., art. nfz.)

entry.sense: nawaAqizu, [pl. of naAqizapN,] The legs of an antelope, (A,) or of a beast of carriage. (Ḳ.) See also naAfizapN.

hom.sense: 1. naqasa It (a naAquws) sounded. (TA.)

naqasa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) or naqasa Aln-aAquwsa, (Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoqusu}, inf. n. naqosN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) He struck, or beat, the nAqws, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) biAlowayiyli with the wbyl. (Mgh, Ḳ.) You say, naqasati Aln-aSaAraI and Antqst↓ The Christians struck, or beat the nAqws. (A.) It is said in a trad., that the Muslims were near to doing so, (kaAduwA yanoqusuwna, Ṣ, TA,) or used to do so, (kaAnuwA yanoqusuwna, Mgh,) until ʼAbd-Allah Ibn-Zeyd dreamed of the [mode of calling to prayer termed] OacaAn. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. nq-s dawaAtahu, inf. n. tanoqiysN, He put ink (niqos) into his receptacle for ink. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
8: see 1.
niqosN Ink; syn. midaAdN [which is a more common term]; (A, Ḳ;) that with which one writes: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. OanoqusN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OanoqaAsN. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

naAqwusN The thing which the Christians strike, or beat, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) to notify the times of prayer, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) as a sign for commencing their prayer; (Mṣb;) being a piece of wood, long, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and large (Ḳ,) [suspended to two cords, (Golius,)] with another which is short, [with which the former is struck, or beaten,] and which is called wabiylN: (A, Ḳ:) pl. nawaAqiysu (Ṣ, TA) and nuqusN, as though the A in the sing. were imagined to be suppressed in forming the latter pl. (TA.)
[Hence, in the present day, applied to A bell: and particularly to the bell of a church or convent.]

hom.sense: 1. naqaXa, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yanoquXu}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. naqoXN. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He variegated a thing; or decorated or embellished it; syn. namonama; as also AntqX↓: (M:) [he charactered in any manner a coin, &c.:] and he engraved, agreeably with modern usage: he coloured a thing with two colours, (Ḳ,) or with colours; (A, Ḳ;) and nq-X↓, (Ṣ,) inf. n. tanoqiyXu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) signifies the same. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

naqaXa fI xaAtamihi kacaA, and EalaI faS-i xaAtamihi, (A,) inf. n. as above, (Ḳ,) [He engraved upon his signet-ring such a thing, and upon the stone of his signet-ring: and naqaXa also signifies he marked with a cutting or a pointed instrument: he sculptured a thing in any manner.]
naqaXa Alr-aHaA ‡ He pecked the mill-stone with a minoqaAr; syn. naqarahaA. (A, TA.)

naqaXa, inf. n. as above, also signifies He, or it, scratched, lacerated, or wounded in the outer skin. (TA.) They said, kaOan-a wajohahu nuqiXa biqataAdapK [As though his face were scratched, or lacerated, by a tragacanth-bush]; syn. xudiXa: relating to hatefulness, and austerity or moroseness of countenance, (M, TA,) and anger. (M.)

naqoXu AlEicoqi signifies The striking the raceme of dates with thorns, in order that the dates may ripen: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or and their consequently ripening. (AA.) And one says, nuqiXa AlEicoqu, meaning, The raceme of dates had specks apparent in it, in consequence of ripening. (Ṣ.)

And [hence, perhaps,] naqoXN is used as ‡ syn. with jimaAEN (Ṣ, A, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) accord. to AA, (Ṣ,) or IAạr; (Ṣgh;) naqaXa signifying ‡ Inivit puellam. (T, Ḳ.) [This signification is mentioned in the A among those which are proper; but in the TA it is said, to be tropical.]

Also naqaXa, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (M, TA,) and so the inf. n., (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He extracted, or drew, or pulled, out, or forth, a thorn (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) from his foot, (Ṣ, M,) with the minoqaX or minoqaAX; (Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as also AntqX↓: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) thought by AʼObeyd to be from AlmunaAqaXapu; but others say the reverse: (TA:) and in like manner, bones from a wound in the head: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and he plucked out (Ṣ, A,) hair, (A,) with the minoqaAX; (Ṣ, A;) as also AntqX↓. (A.) A certain poet says, (namely, Yezeed Ibn-Maksam [?] EthThakafee, O in art. Xwk,)
laA tanoquXan-a birijoli gayorika XawokapF
fataqiI birijolika rijola mano qado XaAkahaA
[Do not thou by any means extract from the foot of another a thorn, and so preserve, by (risking) thy foot, the foot of him who has pierced himself therewith]: the [former] b is put in the place of Eano: he says, do not thou extract from the foot of another a thorn and put it in thy foot: (TA:) or mano XaAkahaA means who has entered among the thorns. (Ṣ and O, in art. Xwk.) And it is said in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, Eavara falaA QnotaEaXa waXiyka falaA QnotaqaXa [May he stumble, and not rise again; and may he be pierced with a thorn, and not extract the thorn]: (M, TA:*) the words meaning an imprecation. (TA.) See also 8, below.

[Hence,] naqaXa, aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (Ḳ,) He cleared the nightly resting-place of sheep or goats from thorns and the like, (Ḳ,) or from what might hurt them, of stones and thorns and the like. (TA.)
Hence also, naqaXa Eani AlX-aIoCi, (TḲ,) inf. n. as above, (IDrd, Ḳ,) He explored the thing to the utmost. (IDrd, Ḳ, TḲ.)
[Hence also,] maA naqaXa minohu XayoYFA † He did not obtain from him anything: but the word commonly known is nataXa. (M, TA.) See also 8.

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.

3. nAqXhu, (Mṣb,) or nAqXhu AlHisaAba, (Ṣ,* M, A,) and fiI AlHisaAbi, (A,) inf. n. munaAqaXapN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and niqaAXN, (M, TA,) He did the utmost with him, or went to the utmost length with him, in reckoning, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so as to omit nothing therein: (AʼObeyd:) AʼObeyd thinks that naqoXN signifying the “extracting” a thorn from the foot is from this; but others say the reverse; that the primary signification of munaAqaXapN is the extracting a thorn from the body with difficulty; and that it then became [conventionally regarded as] a proper term in the sense of doing the utmost, or going to the utmost length, in reckoning; as observed by MF. (TA.) It is said in a trad., mano nuwqiXa AlHisaAba Eud-iba, (Ṣ,) or halaka, (M,) He with whom the utmost is done in reckoning (Ṣ, M,) is punished, (Ṣ,) or perishes. (M.) See also 4.
[Hence,] nAqX AlkalaAma † He picked out the faults of the language; syn. naqadahu. (TA, art. nqd.)
4. AnqX ElI gariymihi He went to the utmost length against his debtor. (IAạr, Ḳ.) See also 3.
5: see 8, last signification.

hom.sense: 8. AntqX: see 1, first signification.
Also, (Ḳ,) or AntqX EalaI faS-ihi, (Lth, A,) He ordered (Lth, A, Ḳ) the naq-aAX [or engraver], (Lth, Ḳ,) to engrave upon the stone of his signet-ring. (Lth, A, Ḳ.)
He extracted, or drew, or pulled, out, or forth, a thing; (Ḳ;) such as a thorn and the like: (TA:) syn. with naqaXa, as shewn above; see 1, in three places. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ.)
[Hence,] He (a camel) struck the ground (Ṣ, Ḳ) with his fore leg, (Ṣ,) or with his foot, (Ḳ,) on account of something entering into it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e., to beat out a thorn or the like.]

[Hence also,] ‡ He chose, or selected, a thing. (M, A, Ḳ.) You say, of a man who has chosen (A, L) a man, (A,) or a thing, (L,) for himself, jaAda maA QnotaqaXahu linafosihi ‡ Good, or excellent, be that which he has chosen for himself: (A, L:) or, accord. to the O, when a man has chosen for himself a servant (xaAdimFA [which suggests that this may be a mistranscription for jaAda maA]) UinotaqaXota hecaA linafosika [thou hast chosen this for thyself]. (TA.) [Hence also.] AntqX minohu Haq-ahu ‡ [He took from him his right, or due]. (A.) And AntqX jamiyEa Haq-ihi, and tnq-Xhu↓, ‡ He took from him the whole of his right, or due, not leaving thereof anything. (M, TA.) See also 1, last signification.

naqoXN [an inf. n. (see 1) used as a simple subst.: or in the sense of a pass. part. n. in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: Variegation; or variegated work: decoration, embellishment, a picture; or decorated, or embellished, or pictured, work: broidery: tracery: (significations well known: see naq-aAXN:)] engraved work upon a signet: [and any sculptured work:] pl. nuquwXN. (A.) Also The impress of a signet. (Mgh, in art. xtm.) And A mark, or trace, upon the ground; as, for instance, of ashes. (AHeyth.)
See also manoquwXN.

entry.sense: nuqoXN: see manoquwXN.

niqaAXapN The art, or occupation, of the naq-aAX, (M, Ḳ, TA,) who does variegated, or decorated or embellished, work; (M;) of him who does what is termed naqoX: (TA:) [and of him who engraves upon signet-rings: and of him who does any sculptured work.]

naq-aAXN One who does variegated, or decorated or embellished, work; (M;) who does what is termed naqoX: (TA:) and one who engraves upon the stones of signet-rings: (Lth, Ḳ:) [and one who does any sculptured work.]
minoqaXN: see minoqAXN.
munaq-aXN: see manoquwXN, first sentence.
Xaj-apN munaq-iXapN: see manoquwXN, last signification.

minoqaAXN An instrument with which variegated, or decorated or embellished, work is done: pl. manaAqiyXu: (M:) [and an instrument with which engraving, or any sculptured work, is done: so in the present day.]

Also, [A kind of tweezers;] an instrument with which one extracts, or draws or pulls out or forth, thorns; as also minoqaXN↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) [of which latter the pl. is manaAqiXu, occurring below:] and with which one plucks out (Ṣ, A) hair. (A.) [Hence the saying,] Aisotaxorajotu Haq-iI minohu biAlmanaAqiXi ‡ I wearied myself in extorting my right, or due, from him. (A.)

hom.sense: manoquwXN A garment, or piece of cloth, (A,) or other thing, (TA,) [variegated; or decorated, or embellished: charactered in any manner, as a coin, &c.: (see 1:)] coloured (A, TA) with two colours, (TA,) or with colours; (A, TA;) as also munaq-aXN↓. (A, TA.)
[A signet-ring engraved: and anything sculptured. (See 1.)]

EicoqN manoquwXN A raceme of dates struck with thorns, and consequently ripened: (AA:) [or having specks apparent in it, in consequence of ripening: (see nuqiXa AlEicoqu:)] and busorN manoquwXN full-grown unripe dates pricked with thorns in order that they may ripen: (M, TA:) and ruTabN manoquwXN fresh ripe dates soaked with water; syn. rabiyTN: (Ṣgh, TA:) called by the vulgar mEcb [app. muEac-abN]; (TA;) as also naqoXN. (Ḳ [accord. to some copies; and in the TA: accord. to other copies of the Ḳ, nuqoXN; but expressly said in the TA to be with fet-ḥ.])

Xaj-apN manoquwXapN A wound in the head from which bones are extracted: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and Xaj-apN munaq-iXapN↓ a wound in the head from which bones are removed; (AA, El-Ghanawee, Aboo-Turáb;) i. q. munaq-ilapN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: laTamahu laToma AlmunotaqiXi, (Ṣ,) or laTomapa AlmunotaqiXi, (Ḳ,) [He gave him a violent slap, like the slap of the camel striking the ground with his fore-leg, or with his foot, on account of something entering into it:] from UinotaqaXa, said of a camel, as explained above. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naqaSa, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoquSu}, (M, Mṣb,) inf. n. nuqoSaAnN (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and naqoSN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the former of these two only, the latter being the inf. n. of the trans. verb, (MṢ,) and naqiySapN (M) and tanoqaASN, (Ḳ,) [which last is an intensive form,] said of a thing, (Ṣ, M,) intrans., (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) It lost somewhat, decreased, diminished, lessened, wasted, waned, or became defective or deficient or incomplete or imperfect, after having been whole or complete or perfect: (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb, TA:) or he, or it, lost, or suffered loss or diminution, (A, Ḳ,) with respect to lot or portion: (Ḳ:) and AntqS↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so does tnq-S↓; (TḲ, [probably from the TA,] art. Oafn;) and so does tnAqS↓: (TA:) [or this last signifies it lost somewhat, decreased,, &c., gradually; contr. of tzAyd.] It is said in a trad., (Mgh,) XahoraA EiydK laA yanoquSaAni, (Mgh, Ḳ,) i. e. Ramadán and Dhu-l-Hijjeh, (Mgh,) meaning, Two months of festival are not defective virtually (fiI AlHukomi) though they be defective in number [of days]; (Ḳ;) i. e. let no doubt occur in your hearts when ye fast nine and twenty days [instead of thirty]; nor if there happen a mistake respecting the day of the pilgrimage, will there be any deficiency in your performance of the rites thereof: (TA:) or, as some say, two months of festival will not be defective in one and the same year; but Et-Taháwee disapproves of this explanation: some say that the meaning is, that though they be defective, or one of them be so, yet their recompense will be complete. (Mgh.) It is also said in a trad., Uin-a AlEamala fiI EaXori ciI AlHij-api laA yanoquSu vawaAbuhu Eam-aA fiI Xahori ramaDaAna [Verily the deed that is done on the tenth of Dhu-l-Hijjeh, the recompense thereof will not fall short of that which is in the month of Ramadán: for naqaSa Eano kacaA means It fell short of such a thing.] (Mgh.) [On the expression fiI Aln-uqoSaAni, as used in grammar, see gafiyrN.]

naqaSahu, (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoquSu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. naqoSN, (MṢ,) [and accord. to the TḲ tanoqaASN and nuqoSaAnN also, which last, however, is said in the MṢ to be an inf. n. of the intrans. verb only,] He made it to lose somewhat, decreased it, diminished it, curtailed it, lessened it, wasted it, impaired it, took from it, or made it defective or deficient or incomplete or imperfect, after it had been whole or complete or perfect; (Mṣb;) he made it (i. e. a share, or portion) defective or deficient: (Ḳ:) [the pronoun often relates to a man: see an ex. in art. Dwz, and another in art. wks:] this is the [most] chaste form of the verb, and is that which occurs in the Ḳur.: (Mṣb:) AnqShu↓ also signifies the same; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and so does nq-Shu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoqiySN: (TA:) but these two are of weak authority, and do not occur in chaste language: (Mṣb:) and AntqShu↓ signifies the same: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or this last signifies he took from it by little and little; as also tnq-Shu↓. (M,* TA [in the latter of which this is plainly said of both of the last two verbs; but in the M, it seems rather to be said of tnq-Sh only.]) [See an ex. of the verb followed by mn voce TarafN. You say also, naqaSa minohu kacaA He cut off from it such a thing.]

naqaSa is doubly trans.: (Mṣb:) you say naqaSahu Haq-ahu, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. naqoSN; (A, Mgh;) and in like manner, AntqShu↓ Haq-ahu; (M, A,* Mgh,* TA;*) He diminished, or impaired, to him his right, or due; endamaged him; or made him to suffer loss, or damage, or detriment, in respect of it; curtailed him, abridged him, deprived him, or defrauded him, of a portion of it; (Mṣb,* TA;) contr. of OawofaAhu: (TA:) [and he abridged him, deprived him, or defrauded him, of it altogether; for naqaSahu Oaholahu wamaAlahu signifies sometimes He deprived him of his family and his property altogether: as appears from the following ex.:] nuqiSa Oaholahu wamaAlahu wabaqiIa farodFA [He was deprived of his family and his property, and remained alone]. (T, art. wtr.) AinotiqaASu↓ AlHaq-i also signifies The denying, or disacknowledging, the right, or due. (TA.)
See also 5.

entry.sense: 2: see naqaSahu.
4: see naqaSahu.

hom.sense: 5. tnq-S: see naqaSa.
tnq-Shu: see naqaSahu.

He attributed to him defect, or imperfection; i. e. to a man; (M;) as also AntqShu↓, and AstnqShu↓: (M, TA:) he attributed or imputed to him, charged him with, or accused him of, a vice, fault, or the like; detracted from his reputation; censured him; reproached him; spoke against him; impugned his character; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also AntqShu↓: (A:) [and naqaSahu signifies the same; for] IḲṭṭ says, that nqS↓ [app. nuqiSa], inf. n. naqiySapN, signifies TEn Elyh [app. TuEina Ealayohi]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 6: see naqaSa, where two meanings are assigned to it.

hom.sense: 8. AntqS: see naqaSa.
AntqShu: see naqaSahu, in four places.
See also 5, in two places.

entry.sense: 10. AstnqS Alv-amana He (the buyer, Ṣ) asked, demanded, or desired, a diminution, a lessening, a lowering, or an abatement, of the price. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
See also 5.
naqoSN: see 1.

Weakness of intellect: (M, TA:) and weakness with respect to religion and intellect. (TA.) You say, daxala Ealayohi naqoSN fiI diynihi waEaqolihi [There came upon him a weakness in his religion and his intellect]: but one should not say nuqoSaAnN↓ [in this case]: (Ḳ:) app. because Aln-aqoS is “weakness;” whereas Aln-uqoSaAnu is only “a going away [of part of a thing] after [its having been in] a state of completeness.” (TA.)
nuqoSaAnN: see 1:
see also naqoSN, in two places.

It also signifies The quantity that is gone, or lost, of a thing that is decreased or diminished or lessened. (Lth, A, Ḳ.) You say, nuqoSaAnuhu kacaA wakacaA The quantity that is gone, or lost, of it is such and such. (TḲ.)

hom.sense: naqiySapN: see 1.

A defect, an imperfection, a fault, a vice, or the like; syn. EayobN: (Ṣ, TA:) or a low, or base, quality, property, natural disposition, practice, habit, or action; (Ḳ, TA;) of a man: (TA:) or a weak quality,, &c.: (IDrd, Ḳ, TA:) but the attribution of weakness to a quality, &c., requires consideration: and it seems that what is meant by lowness, or baseness, is what leads to naqoS: (TA:) [manoqaSapN↓, also, accord. to the A, seems to be syn. with naqiySapN in one or another of the senses explained above; but its primary signification is probably a cause of naqoS, like as that of maboxalapN is a cause of buxol, and that of majobanapN a cause of jubon: the pl. of naqiySapN is naqaAYiSu: and that of manoqaSapN is manaAqiSu.] You say, maA fiyhi naqiySapN and manoqaSapN↓ [There is not in him any defect, imperfection, fault, or vice,, &c.]: and fulaAnN cuw naqaAYiSa and manaAqiSa [Such a one has defects,, &c.]. (A, TA.)

As a subst. from tanaq-aSahu and AinotaqaSahu and AisotanoqaSahu, [or, accord. to IḲṭṭ, as an inf. n. from nuqiS, and therefore from naqaSahu also, (see 5,)] it signifies The attributing to a man defect, or imperfection: (M:) the attributing or imputing to men, charging them with, or accusing them of, vices, faults, or the like; censuring them; reproaching them; speaking against them; impugning their characters. (Ḳ.) A poet says,
falawo gayoru OaxowaAliI OaraAduwA naqiySatiI
jaEalotu lahumo fawoqa AlEaraAniyni miysamaA
[But if others than my maternal uncles had desired to attribute to me defect,, &c., I had set a brand upon them above the noses]. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: naAqiSN act. part. n. of 1.
dirohamN naAqiDN signifies A dirhem deficient in weight; (Mṣb;) light and deficient: and nuq-aSN occurs as pl. of nAqS thus applied, agreeably with analogy. (Mgh.)
[Hence, fiEolN naAqiSN meaning An incomplete, i. e. a non-attributive, verb: opposed to fiEolN taAm-N.]
manoqaSapN: pl. manaAqiSu: see naqiySapN, in four places:
and see also naqoSN.
manoquwSN pass. part. n. of naqaSahu. (A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. naqaDahu, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yanoquDu}, (M, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. naqoDN, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He undid it; took it; or pulled it, to pieces: untwisted it: unravelled it: unwove it: dissolved it: broke it: or rendered it uncompact, unsound, or unfirm,: after having made it compact, sound, or firm: (JK, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) namely a building, or structure: and a rope, or cord: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) and silk, or flax: (TA:) and cloth: (L:) and ‡ a compact, contract, or covenant; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and † a sale: (Mgh:) and † other things; (A, Ḳ, TA;) such as † an affair, or a case; and † the state of a place through which the invasion of an enemy is feared: (TA:) contr. of Oaboramahu, (M, A, Ḳ, TA,) as relating to a building or structure, and to a rope or cord, (A, Ḳ, TA,) and to a compact or contract or covenant, &c.: (Ḳ, TA:) or i. q. Hal-a baromahu, as relating to a rope or cord, and to a compact or contract or covenant: (Mṣb:) or i. q. hadamahu, as relating to a building or structure: (TA:) or the inf. n. signifies UifosaAdu maA Oaboramota, as relating to a building or structure. (JK, TA,) and to a rope or cord, (JK,) and to a compact or contract or covenant. (TA.) [It is said in the Ḳ, that Aln-aqoDu is the contr. of AlUiboraAmu, like AlUinotqaADu and Alt-anaAquDu: but this is a glaring mistake; and seems to be a corruption of the following passage in the M: Aln-aqoDu Did-u AlUiboraAmi naqaDahu yanoquDuhu naqoDFA waQnotaqaDa watanaAqaDa, which is meant indicate that AntqD and tnAqD are quasi-passives of naqaDahu: and in like manner, the passage in the A, Aln-aqoDu fiI AlbinaMCi waAlHaboli wagayorihi Did-u AlUiboraAmi waQnotaqaDa wanataq-aDa, indicates that AntqD and tnq-D are quasi-passives of naqaDahu. Further, it should be observed that naqaDahu, as relating to a building, is not well explained by hadamahu; for you say, naqaDa AlbinaMCa mino gayori hadomK, (mentioned in the Ṣ and A, &c., in art. qwD,) meaning He took to pieces the building without demolishing, or destroying.]

[Hence,] naqaSa fulaAnN watarahu [lit. Such a one undid, or untwisted, his bow-string]; meaning ‡ such a one took, or had taken, his blood-revenge. (A, TA.) And Ald-ahoru cuw naqoDK waUimoraArK [lit. Time, or fortune, has a property of untwisting and twisting tightly]; meaning ‡ that which time, or fortune, [as it were] twists tightly, [or makes firm.] it, at another time, [as it were] untwists, or undoes. (TA.) And naqaDotu maA Oaboramahu ‡ I annulled [what he confirmed, or made firm]. (Mṣb.) And yanoquDu Ealayohi ‡ [He undoes, or annuls, or contradicts, what he (another) has said]; said of a poet replying to another poet. (Lth, A, Ḳ.)

nqD Alsqf, [i. e., app., naqoDu Als-aqofi,] also signifies tHryk xXbh [i. e. taHoriyku xaXabihi, The moving, or shaking, of the pieces of wood, or rafters, of the roof]. (TA. [But perhaps the phrase to be explained is naq-aDa↓ Als-aqofu, and the explanation, correctly, taHar-aka xaXabuhu, i. e. The pieces of wood, or rafters, of the roof moved, or shook, (for this, I am informed, is agreeable with modern usage,) app. so as to produce a sound: see also 5.])
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2: see 4, in two places:
and 5; and see 1, next before the last break.

3. AlmunaAqaDapu fiI Alqawoli is ‡ The saying that which is contradictory in its meaning [or meanings; as though one of its meanings undid, or annulled, the other]: (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA:) from naqoDu AlbinaMCi: and meaning ‡ the contending with another in words, [or in contradiction,] each rebutting what the other said. (TA.) You say, nAqDhu fiI AlX-aIoCi, inf. n. munaAqaDapN and niqaADN, ‡ He contradicted him in, or respecting, the thing. (M, TA.*) And qulotu lahu niqaADFA ‡ I contradicted him with respect to his saying, and his satirizing of me. (M, TA.) And nAqD OaHadu AlX-aAEirayoni AlOaxara ‡ [One of the two poets contradicted the other]. (A.) And nAqD qawoluhu Alv-aAniI AlMw-ala ‡ [His second saying contradicted the first]. (A, TA.) And nAqD Mxiru qawolihi AlOaw-ala ‡ [The last part of his saying contradicted the first]. (Mgh.) [See also 6.]

hom.sense: 4. AnqD AlkamoOapa, (M, Ḳ, TA.) and AnqD EanohaA. (M, TA,) He removed the crust of earth from over the truffles: (M:) or he extracted, or took forth, the truffles from the earth. (Ḳ, TA.)
AnqDt AlOaroDu The earth showed [or put forth] its plants, or herbage. (M, TA.)

AnqD also signifies It produced, made, gave, emitted, or uttered, a sound, noise, voice, or cry: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, TA:) and [particularly] a slight sound like what is termed naqorN: (Ṣ, TA:) said of a joint of a man, (M, Ḳ,) and of the fingers [when their joints are made to crack], and of the ribs, (A,) [see also 5,] and of a camel's saddle, (A, TA.,) and of a cupping-instrument when the cupper sucks it, (TA,) [&c., (see naqiyDN,)] and of an eagle, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and of a hen (Ṣ, A) on the occasion of her laying eggs, (A,) and of a chicken, (M, A, Ḳ,) and of an ostrich, and of a quail, and of a hawk, and of a scorpion, and of a frog, and of the [kind of lizard called] wazag, and of the wabor [or Syrian hyrax], (M, Ḳ,) and of a young camel, the sounds of which are denoted by UinoqaADN and katiytN, as those of a camel advanced in age are by qaroqarapN and hadiyrN: (Ṣ:) or UinoqaADN relates to animate things; and naqoDN↓, inf. n. of naqDa, aor. _u {yanoquDu} and _i {yanoqiDu}, to inanimate things. (M, Ḳ.) [Accord. to the A, whether said of animate things or of inanimate, it is proper, not tropical, but accord. to what is said in the TA voce naqiyD, it is properly said of animate things, and tropically of inanimate; though, if any such distinction exist, the reverse seems to me to be more probable.]

You say also, AnqD biAld-aAb-api, (Ḳ,) or biAloHimaAri. (Lth,) or, as Aṣ says, (M, TA,) biAlEayori, (M,) or biAlbaEiyri, (TA,) and biAlfarasi, (M, TA,) He made a sound to the beast of carriage, (M, Ḳ,) or to the ass, (Lth, Aṣ, M,) or to the camel, (Aṣ, TA,) and to the horse, (Aṣ, M, TA,) at the two sides of his tongue, after making it cleave to the roof of his mouth, (Lth, M, Ḳ, TA,) without removing its extremity from its place, (Lth, TA,) in order to chide the beast: (L:)
or AnqD bihi signifies i. q. naqara bihi [q. v.]; (Aṣ, M, A, TA;) the object being a [camel such as is called] qaEuwd; (A;) or whatever be the object. (Aṣ, M, TA.) And AnqD biAlomaEozi, (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) or biAlEanozi, (M, A,) He called the goats, (Ṣ, Ṣgh, Ḳ,) or the she-goat; (M, A;) accord. to AZ, (Ṣ, Ṣgh,) or Ks. (M, L.) And AnqD bihi He made a sound to him like as when thou makest a smacking with the tongue to a sheep or goat, [in the TA, kmA tnqr AlXAp, for which I read kamaA tanoquru biAlX-aApi,] deeming him ignorant. (TA.) And He made a clapping to him with one of his hands upon the other, so as to cause a [sound such as is termed] naqiyD to be heard. (El-Khaṭṭábee.)

AnqD OaSaAbiEahu (M, A, Ḳ) He made a sound, or sounds, [app. a cracking of the joints,] with his fingers: (M:) [and so naq-aDahaA↓, inf. n. tanoqiyDN: (see faroqaEa:)] or he struck with his fingers in order that they might make a sound, or sounds: (Ḳ:) if it mean cracking of the joints (faroqaEap), it is disapproved; but if clapping, it is not. (TA.) And AnqD AlEiloka He caused the [kind of gum called] Elk to make a sound, or sounds; [i. e., in chewing it, as many women do;] the doing of which is disapproved. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ. [But in the Ṣ and L, it said that UinoqaADu AlEiloka signifies taSowiytuhu, which does not necessarily indicate that the former verb is transitive.])

Hence, (Ṣ, M, TA,) AnqD AlHimolu Zahorahu (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ *) The load made his back to sound by reason of its weight: (M:) or pressed heavily upon him, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that his back was heard to make a sound such as is termed naqiyD; (M, Ḳ;* i. e. the sound of the camel's saddle when it becomes infirm by reason of the weight of the load; (Bḍ, xciv. 3;) or a slight sound, as when a man makes a smacking with his tongue (yunoqiDu) to his ass, in driving him: TA:) or oppressed his back by its weight: (Mṣb:) or rendered him lean, or emaciated; jaEalahu niqoDFA, i. e. mahozuwlFA. (Ibn-ʼArafeh, Ḳ.) Thus in the phrase Al-aciI OanoqaDa Zahoraka, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in [xciv. 3, of] the Ḳur. (Ṣ, M.)

entry.sense: 5. tnq-D: see 8.

AlOaroDu Eani AlkamoOapi The earth clave, or cracked, or burst, from over the truffles; (Ṣ, A,* TA;) syn. tafaT-arato. (Ṣ, TA.) In all the copies of the Ḳ, we find tnq-D Ald-amu, explained by taqaT-ara; [as though meaning The blood was made to drop, drip, or fall in drops;] but how likely is this to be a mistranscription. (TA.) [The right reading of the phrase is probably tnq-D AlkamoCu; and of the explanation, tafaT-ara; and if so, the phrase is like OanoqaDa AlkamoCu, and naq-aDa, explained above: see 4, second sentence.]

tnq-D Alaboytu The house, or chamber, became cleft, or cracked, in several places, so as to cause a sound to be heard (Ḳ, TA.) And tnq-D is also said of a building, [app. in the same sense,] like naq-aDa↓. (TA.) [See naq-aDa Als-aqofu, in 1, next before the last break.] You say also, tnq-Dt EiZaAmuhu ‡ His bones made a sound [app. in being broken]. (IF, Ḳ, TA.) [See also 4.]

hom.sense: 6. tnAqD: see 8.

tanaAquDN also signifies ‡ Mutual contradiction, or repugnancy; contr. of tawaAfuqN. (O, TA.) You say, fiI kalaAmihi tanaAquDN (A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) ‡ [In his speech is contradiction, or repugnancy, between different parts;] one part of his speech necessarily implies the annulment of another part; (Mṣb;) his second saying contradicted (naAqaDa) his first. (TA.) And tanaAqaDa AlqawolaAni, (A, Mgh,) or AlkalaAmaAni, (Mṣb,) ‡ The two saying, or sentences, contradicted each other; or were mutually repugnant; as though each undid the other; (Mṣb;) [they annulled each other.] And tnAqD AlX-aAEiraAni ‡ [The two poets contradicted each other.] (A, TA.) And tnAqD maEonaAhu ‡ Its meaning was contradictory. (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.)

[It is also used transitively:] you say, tanaAqaDaA AlbayoEa † They two mutually dissolved the sale: as though compared with the saying taraMCawuA AlhilaAla, meaning “they [together] saw the new moon;” and tadaAEawuA Alqawoma, meaning “they [together] called the people;” and tasaMCaluwhumo, meaning “they [together] asked them;” notwithstanding that tnAqD is [properly] intransitive. (Mgh.) And tanaAqaDuwA Euhuwdahumo † [They mutually dissolved, or broke, their compacts, contracts, or covenants]. (T, voce tnAkvwA.)

entry.sense: 8. AntqD quasi-pass. of naqaDahu [It became undone; taken, or pulled to pieces: untwisted: unravelled: unwoven: dissolved; broken: or rendered uncompact, unsound, or infirm, after it had been made compact, sound, or firm]: (M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) as also tnq-D↓, (A,) and tnAqD↓: (M, TA:) [respecting the first and last, see a remark upon a mistake in the Ḳ, following the first sentence in 1: but AntqD afterwards occurs in the Ḳ used properly in the phrase maA QnotaqaDa mina AlbunoyaAni:] i. q. Ainotakva: (Ṣ:) said of a building, or structure: and of a rope, or cord: (A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) [and of silk, or flax: and of cloth: (see 1:)] and ‡ of a compact, contract, or covenant: (TA:) [and of a sale: (see 1:)] and ‡ of other things. (A, TA.)

[Hence,] AntqDt AlqaroHapu ‡ The wound, or ulcer, became recrudescent. (IF,* A.) And AntqD AljuroHu baEoda buroYihi † The wound became in a bad, or corrupt, state, after its healing. (Mṣb.) And AntqD AlOamoru baEoda QlotiYaAmihi (A,* Mṣb, TA) ‡ The affair, or case, became in a bad, or unsound state, after it had been in a sound state. (Mṣb.) And AntqD Oamoru Alv-agori baEoda sad-ihi † [The state of the place through which the invasion of an enemy was feared became unfortified, after its being fortified, or closed]. (TA.) And AntqDt AlT-ahaArapu † The state of purity became annulled. (Mṣb.) And AntqD Ealayohi AlX-iEoru ‡ [The poetry became undone, annulled, or contradicted, by a reply against him: see yanoquDu Ealayohi]. (A, TA.)
11. AnqAD- It (a wall) cracked, without falling down; like UinoqaD-a. (Ḳ in art. qD.) [See also UinoqaADa, in art. qyD.]
nuqoDN: see niqoDN, in two places.

hom.sense: niqoDN i. q. manoquwDN↓ [Undone; taken, or pulled, to pieces: untwisted: unravelled: unwoven: dissolved; broken:, &c. (see 1:)] (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) like nikovN (Ṣ, TA) in the sense of manokuwvN: (TA:) as also nuqoDN↓; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and naqaDN↓: (Ṣgh:) but El-Ghooree allows only the first: (Mgh:) Az, however, mentions only the second; (Mṣb;) which signifies as above, applied to a building, or structure; (M, Mgh;) or what has become taken, or pulled, to pieces, (maA QnotaqaDa,) of a building, or structure; (Ḳ;) as also the first: (TA:) or naqoDN signifies maA naqaDota what thou hast undone; taken, or pulled, to pieces; untwisted; [&c.]: (M:) and what is undone, of [the stuff of the tents called] Oaxobiyap, and of [the garments called] Oakosiyap, and twisted a second time; (M, Ḳ;) as also naqaDN↓; (Ḳ;) and nuqaADapN↓: (L:) or this last signifies what is undone of a hair-rope: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) the pl. of niqoDN is OanoqaADN [a pl. of pauc.], (M,) and of the same, (Mṣb,) or of nuqoDN↓, (Mgh, Mṣb,) nuquwDN. (Mgh, Mṣb.)

‡ Emaciated, or rendered lean, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) by travel; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) upon which one has journeyed time after time: (O:) Seer says, as though travel had unknit its frame; (M, TA;) thus indicating it to be tropical: (TA:) applied to a male camel, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and to a horse, (M.) and to a female camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the female is termed niqoDapN: (M, Ḳ:) pl. OanoqaADN, (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ,) only, (Sb, M,) both of the masc. and fem.; in the latter, the p being imagined to be elided; (M;) and naqaAYiDu is [also said to be] a pl. of niqoDN signifying jaded, applied to a she-camel. (So in a copy of the Ṣ in art. nfS.)
[See an ex. in a verse cited voce sad-N.]

The place, (Ṣ,) or crust of earth, (M, Ḳ,) that becomes broken from over truffles; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) for when they are about to come forth, they break asunder the surface of the earth: (O:) pl. [of pauc.] OanoqaADN and [of mult.] nuquwDN. (M, Ḳ.)

Accord. to the Ḳ, i. q. nifoDN; but the latter is a mistranscription; (TA;) Honey that has in it [worms of the kind called] suws; wherefore it is taken, (M, Ḳ in art. nfD,) and pounded, (Ḳ, ubi supra,) and the place of the bees is smeared (yulaT-axu [in a copy of the M yuTobaxu, which is doubtless a mistranscription,]) therewith, together with myrtle (Ms) and the bees then come to it, and deposit their honey in it; (M, Ḳ, ubi supra;) on the authority of El-Hejeree: (M:) or the dung of bees in the place where they deposit their honey: (IAạr, AḤn, Ḳ, ubi supra:) or the bees that have died therein. (Ṣgh, Ḳ, ubi supra.)
See also naqiyDN.

entry.sense: naqaDN: see niqoDN, in two places.

hom.sense: naqiyDN ‡ A contradictor: applied to a man: fem. with p {naqiyDapN}. (M, TA.) You say [also], caA nqyDu caAka ‡ This is a contradictor [i. e. the contrary] of that: (A, TA:) [or this is inconsistent with that: for] Aln-aqiyDaAni laA yajotamiEaAni walaA yarotafiEaAni [what are termed nqyDAn cannot be coëxistent in the same thing, nor simultaneously nonexistent in the same thing]; as existence itself and nonexistence, and motion and rest. (Kull, pp. 231, 232) You say also, hecihi qaSiydapN naqiyDu qaSiydapi fulaAnK ‡ [This poem is a contradictor of the poem of such a one]. (A.) And Aln-aqiyDapu in poetry is ‡ That by which one undoes or annuls or contradicts [what another poet has said]: (Ṣ:) or naqiyDapu AlX-iEori consists in a poet's putting forth poetry, and another poet's undoing or annulling or contradicting it, by putting forth what is different therefrom: (Lth, Ḳ,* TA:) the subst is naqiyDN: [or rather this seems to be an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant, and syn. with naqiyDapN:] and the act of the two is termed munaAqaDapN↓: the pl. of naqiyDapN is naqaAYiDu: (TA:) you speak of the naqaAYiD of Jereer and El-Farezdaḳ. (A, TA.)

A sound, noise, voice, or cry; (Lth, Ṣ, M, O, Ḳ:) as also niqoDN↓ accord to the Ḳ; but this is an enormous error: (TA:) the former, of the joints (Lth, M, Ḳ) of a man, (M,) [a meaning also assigned to niqoDN in the Ḳ,] and of the fingers, and of the ribs, (Lth, M, A,) and of camels' saddles, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a camel's saddle, (M, O, Ḳ, [but in CK, for Alr-aHol, we find Alr-ijol, the foot,]) and of camels' litters, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of tanned skins, (Ḳ,) or of a tanned skin, (M,) and of a bow-string, (M, Ḳ,) and of nisoE [q. v.] (O, Ḳ,) when new, (O,) and of the sucking of a cupping-instrument; (Ḳ;) [in all these senses said in the TA to be tropical; but see 4;] and also the former, (Ṣ, M, TA,) in the Ḳ, erroneously, the latter word, (TA,) of an eagle, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and of chickens, and of an ostrich, and of a quail, and of a hawk, and of a scorpion, and of a frog, and of the [kind of lizard called] wazag, and of the wabor [or Syrian hyrax;, &c., see 4] (M,)

entry.sense: nuqaADapN: see niqoDN.
naqiyDapN: see naqiyDN.
manoquwDN: see niqoDN.
munaAqaDapN: see naqiyaDN.
munotqiDN i. q. mutray-iEN, [Refraining.] see art. ryE.

1. naqaTa AlkitaAba, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or AlHarofa, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanoquTu}, inf. n. naqoTN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He pointed, or dotted. [the book, or writing, or] the letter, or word, with the diacritical points or point; and with the syllabical points or point, by which are shown the pronunciation and division of syllables and the desinential syntax; syn. OaEojamahu; as also nq-Thu↓: (Ḳ:) and nq-T↓ AlmSaAHifa, inf. n. tanoqiyTN, [he so pointed the copies of the Ḳur-án.] (Ṣ.)
2: see 1, in two places.

nf-T vawobahu biAlz-aEofaraAni waAlmidaAdi, inf. n. tanoqiyTN, [He made speaks, or small spots, upon his garment, with saffron, and ink;] (Lth;) and nq-T EalaI vawobihi [signifies the same]. (A, TA, in art. rqT.) And naq-aTati AlmaroOapu wajohahaA waxad-ahaA biAls-awaAdi tataHas-anu bicelika [The woman made specks, or small spots, upon her face, with black, beautifying herself thereby]. (TA.)
[And hence,] ‡ It (a place) became seattered with spots, or portions, of herbage. (Ḳ, TA.)
naqoTapN inf. n. un. of 1, [A single act of pointing,, &c.] (Mṣb.)

nuqoTapN A diacritical point of a letter or word: [a syllabical point thereof: see 1:] (Ḳ:) [a point, dot, speck, speckle, or small spot: a mathematical point; i. e.] the extremity of a line: (TA:) pl. nuqaTN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and niqaATN. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence, one says, maA QxotalafaA fI nuqoTapK They two did not differ respecting so small a thing as a point of a letter or word. (TA.) And [hence] the vulgar say, when they admire one, huwa nuqoTapN fiI muSoHafK † [He is like a point, or stop, in a copy of the Ḳur-án; because the stops in the Ḳur-án are generally ornamented, and often very beautifully, with gold and colours]. (TA.)

† [Any very small thing, that may be likened to a point, dot, or speck. Hence,] ʼAlee is related to have said, AlEilomu nuqoTapN Uin-amaA kat-arahaA AljaAhiluwna † [Science, or knowledge, is a very small thing: only the ignorant have made it to be much]. (TA.) And you say, OaEoTaAhu nuqoTapF mino EasalK ‡ [He gave him a drop, or very small quantity, of honey]. (TA.)

‡ [A portion of a thing, or some of a number of things, in a separate, or scattered, state, here and there] You say, maA baqiIa mino OamowaAlihimo Uil-aA nuqoTapa ‡ There remained not of their possessions [aught] save some palm-trees and a portion of seed-produce here and there. (IAạr, TA) And fiI AlOaroDi niqaATN mina AlkalaUi, and nuqaTN minohu. ‡ In the land are scattered spots, or portions, of herbage. (Ḳ,* TA.)
† A thing: an affair; a matter: a case; an event; an action. (TA.)
nuqayoTapN dim. of nuqoTapN. (TA.)
naq-aATN One who points copies of the Ḳur-án, &c.; i. e. adds the diacritical and other points. (Ṣ,* TA.)
kitaAbN manoquwTN (Mṣb, TA) A book, or writing, pointed with the diacritical, or other, points. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. nakaOa AlqaroHapa. (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nakoCN, (Ṣ,) He peeled off the scab from the sore (Ṣ, Ḳ,) before it was healed, and it became moist in consequence. (Ḳ.) [See also nakaI.]
nakaOa AlEaduw-a, and fiI AlEaduw-i, dial. form of nakaI [q. v.] (Ḳ.) By some rejected. (TA)
nakaOahu Haq-ahu (like rakaOhu, TA), inf. n. nakoCN, He paid him his due. (Ḳ.)

hun-iYta walaA tunokOo, (Ṣ,) and tunoka, (TA,) and tunokhu (Ṣ, for tunoka or tunokOo, TA), Mayest thou be made to have enjoyment in that which thou hast received, and not experience pain! (Ṣ) Mayest thou gain what is good, and may harm not befall thee! (T:) or, with the latter of the two verbs without _u. (tnk), may God not make thee discomfited (AHeyth, L.) [Accord. to AHeyth. as mentioned in the TA, the latter verb in this proverb is written tanokaho and tunokaho; but the right reading is doubtless tunoka and tunokaho: this is shown by the explanation there following.]
8. AntkOt AlqaroHapu The scab peeled off from the sore before it was healed, and it became moist in consequence. (A, TA.)
AntkO minohu Haq-ahu (like AzdkO, TA) He received from him his due. (Ḳ, TA.)
nukaOapN and zukaOapN One who pays his debts, and does not put off. (Ḳ.)
nakaOapu AlT-urovuwvi, and nukaOapu, dial. form of nakaEap [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

1. nakaba Eanohu, aor. _u {yanokubu}, inf. n. nukuwbN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nakobN; and nakiba, aor. _a {yanokabu}, inf. n. nakabN: (M, L, Ḳ;)
and nk-b↓, (inf. n. tanokiybN, TA;) and tnk-b↓; (Ḳ;) He deviated, or turned aside, or away, from it, (Ḳ,) from the road, (Ṣ,) or from another thing. (TA.) [You say] nk-bhu↓ AlT-ariyqa, (AlTryq being put in the accus. case, inf. n. tanokiybN, TA,) and [Eani AlTryqi] nk-b bihi, He deviated, or turned aside, or away, with him from the road; led him, or caused him to turn, aside, or away, from the road. (Ḳ.)
[So] nk-bh↓, inf. n. tanokiybN, He turned aside, or away, from him, and separated himself from him. (Ṣ.)
tnk-bh↓ He went. or turned, aside, or away, or apart, from him; avoided him; went, or removed, to a distance, from him. (Ṣ.)
tnk-b↓ Ean-aA He turned aside, or away, from us. (TA.)
nakaba Eano Tariyqi AlS-awaAbi, aor. _u {yanokubu}, inf. n. nukuwbN; and nk-b↓ Eani AlSwAb; † He deviated from the right course of action, &c. (Az.)
nakabati Alr-iyHu, aor. _u {yanokubu}, inf. n. nukuwbN, The wind blew obliquely, in a direction between [the directions of] two [cardinal] winds. (Ḳ.) See nakobaACu.
nakaba, aor. _u {yanokubu}, inf. n. nakobN, He threw, cast, or flung. (Ḳ, TA.)
nakaba bihi He threw him down (Ḳ) EalaI AlOaroDi upon the ground. (TA.)
nakabahu Ald-ahoru, aor. _u {yanokubu}, inf. n. nakobN and nakabN, † Fortune overcame him, or afflicted him: or smote him with an evil accident, a disaster, an affliction, or a calamity. (Ḳ.)
nukiba † He was overcome, or afflicted, by fortune: or was smitten by fortune with an evil accident, a disaster, or the like. (Ṣ, TA.) See nakobapN.
nakaba AlUinaACa, (aor. _u {yanokubu}, inf. n. nakobN, TA,) He [threw down, i. e.] poured out the contents of the vessel: (Ḳ:) but only said of what is not fluid; as dust and the like. (TA.)

nakaba kinaAnatahu, inf. n. as above, He inverted, or inclined, his quiver, (Ṣ,) so as to pour out the arrows contained in it: (TA:) or he scattered the contents of his quiver. (Ḳ.) [See also nakata.]

nakabatohu AlHijaArapu, aor. _u {yanokubu}, inf. n. nakobN, The stones wounded him, and made him bleed, [in the foot]. (Ṣ.) nkbt AlHjArp rijolahu The stones wounded his foot, and made it bleed: or hit, or struck, or hurt, it. (Ḳ.) Aln-akobu is when a stone wounds, &c., a nail, a hoof, or a camel's foot. (TA.)
nukibato UiSobaEuhu His toe was hit, or hurt, by the stones. (TA.)
nakiba, aor. _a {yanokabu}, inf. n. nakabN, He (a camel) had a disease in the shoulder-joint, or in the shoulder-blade, and in consequence halted. (Ṣ.) See nakabN.
nakiba, aor. _a {yanokabu}, inf. n. nakabN, He (a man) had a pain in his shoulder-joint. (TA.)
nakaba EalaI qawomihi, aor. _u {yanokubu}, inf. n. nikaAbapN (Ṣ) and nukuwbN, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) ‡ He was, or acted as, manokibN over his people: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or was Eariyf over them. (M.)

entry.sense: 2. nik-bh, inf. n. tanokiybN, He removed, or put aside, or away, or out of the way, him, or it. Thus it is both trans. and intrans. (Ḳ.) See 1.
nak-ibohu Ean-aA Put him away from us; put him out of our way. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. tnk-b (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Antkb↓ (Ḳ) He threw his bow, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or his quiver, (Ḳ,) upon his shoulder; he shouldered it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
tnk-b EalaI qawosK He leaned upon a bow: and, in like manner, upon a staff. (TA, from a trad.)
See 1.

entry.sense: 8: see 5.
nakobN i. q. nakobaACu, q. v.
See also nakobapN.
nakabN An inclining in a thing: (Ṣ:) or what resembles an inclining in a thing. (M, Ḳ.)

A halting in a camel (ISd, Ḳ) by reason of a pain in his shoulder-joint: (ISd:) or a disease which attacks camels in the shoulder-joints, in consequence of which they halt: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or only in the shoulder-joint. (El-'Adebbes, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nakobapN A hurt [of the foot] by a stone, causing a bleeding: or a hit by a stone [upon the foot]. Ex. layosa duwna hecaA AlOamori nakobapN walaA cub-aAHN There is not in the way of the attainment of this thing a hurt [of the foot] by a stone, &c., nor a crack in the inside of the foot. (IAạr, ISd.) [See also cb-AH.] Hence nakobapN in the sense immediately following. (TA.)
‡ A misfortune; an evil accident; a disaster; an affliction; a calamity: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) as also nakobN↓: (Ḳ:) pl. of the former nakabAatN; (Ṣ;) and of the latter, nukuwbN. (Ḳ.)
nukobapN A heap of corn, not measured nor weighed: syn. SuborapN. (Ḳ.)

nakiybN The circuit (daAYirap: in some copies of the Ṣ, dAbrp: but this, as IḲṭṭ says, is a mistake; and the former is the correct word: TA) of a hoof, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of a camel's foot. (Ṣ.) See manokawbN.
Aln-ukayobaACu: see Oanokabu.

hom.sense: Oanokabu Eani AlHaq-i, and naAkibN↓ Eanohu, ‡ A man deviating from the right course of action, &c. (A.)

nakobaACu [fem. of Oanokabu] an epithet applied to Any wind that blows obliquely, taking a direction between [the directions of] two [cardinal] winds: (TA:) a wind that blows obliquely, deviating from the direction whence blow the right (Alquw-am [or the cardinal]) winds: (Ṣ:) or a [particular] wind that blows obliquely, and takes a direction between [the directions of] two [cardinal] winds; (Ḳ;) which destroys the camels and sheep, &c., and restrains the rain: (TA:) or a wind that blows in a direction between that of the east, or easterly, wind, (AlS-abaA,) and that of the north, or northerly, wind, (AlX-amaAl): (AZ, Ḳ:) that between the south, or southerly, and east, or easterly, winds, being called jirobiyaACu: (AZ:) [but see this word, and see below:] or what are termed nukobu Alr-iyaAHi [nukobN being pl. of nkbAC] are four: (IAạr, Th, Ṣ, Ḳ:) namely, first, the nkbACu AlS-abaA waAljanuwbi the wind that blows in a direction between that of the east, or easterly, and that of the south, or southerly, wind; also called AlOazoyabu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) which is a very thirsty wind, that dries up much the leguminous plants; but Et-Tará- bulusee, in the Kf, and Mbr and IF, assert that the Azyb is the jnwb; not its nkbAC: (TA:) second, the nkbACu AlS-abaA waAlX-amaAli the wind that blows in a direction between that of the east, or easterly, and that of the north, or northerly, wind; also called AlS-aAbaypu, and called also Aln-ukayobAaCu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a diminutive meant to convey the opposite of a diminutive sense; for they find this wind to be very cold; (Ṣ;) it is very boisterous and very cold; unattended by rain or by any good: (TA:) third, the nkbACu AlX-amaAli waAld-abuwri the wind that blows in a direction between that of the north, or northerly, and that of the west, or westerly, wind; also called AljirobiyaACu; and termed nay-iHapu AlOazoyabi the opposite wind to the Azyb; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a cold wind; (Ṣ;) and sometimes attended by a little rain; but Ibn-El-Ajdábee asserts that the jrbyAC is the XmAl: (TA:) fourth, the nkbACu Aljanuwbi wAld-abuwri the wind that blows in a direction between that of the south, or southerly, and that of the west, or westerly, wind; also called Alhayofu; (in the CK, Alhayafu;) and termed nay-iHapu Aln-ukayobAaCi the opposite wind to the nkybAC; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) a hot wind (Ṣ) and very thirsty. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-Kubás, the tract whence blows the nkbAC [by which he means only the wind that blows from the north-east or thereabout] is that extending between the point where rises the ciraAE [or the asterism composed of the stars α and β of Gemini, E. 33° N., in central Arabia; or α and β of Canis Minor, E. 7° N., in the same latitude] and the pole-star: and the tract between the pole-star and the point where sets the crAE is the tract whence blows the XmAl. Sh says, Each of the four [cardinal] winds has its nkbAC, which is called in relation to it: that of the SbA is that which is between it and the XmAl; [blowing from the north-east, or thereabout;] and it resembles it in gentleness; sometimes having sharpness, or vehemence; but this is seldom; only once in a long space of time: that of the XmAl is that which is between it and the dbwr; [blowing from the north-west, or thereabout;] and it resembles it in coldness: it is called AlXmAlu AlX-aAmiy-apu: each of them is called by the Arabs XAmy-p: that of the dbwr is that which is between it and the jnwb; blowing from the point where sets suhayol [or Canopus; i. e., Ṣ. 29 degrees W., in the latitude of central Arabia]; and it resembles it in its violence and boisterousness: and that of the jnwb is that which is between it and the SbA; [blowing from the south-east, or thereabout;] and it is the wind most resembling it in its softness and in its gentleness in winter. (L.)
The pl. of nkbAC is nukobN, as shown above. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) [See also tab-uwEu AlX-amosi, in art. tbE.]
dabuwrN nkb [app. nakobN↓, originally an inf. n., used as an epithet, and therefore applicable without p to a fem noun] i. q. nakobAaCu; [app., The nkbAC of the dbwr, a southwesterly wind]. (TA.)

Oanokabu A camel having a disease in the shoulder-joint, or in the shoulderblade, and in consequence halting: (Ṣ:) a camel that walks on one side, or inclining, or as though he walked on one side. (L.)
faAmapN nakobaACu An inclining pulley: and qiyamN nukobN inclining pulleys. (TA.)
Oanokabu † Overpowering, or oppressive; unjust, or tyrannical. (Ṣ, TA.)

Ald-ahoru Oanokabu laA yulib-u † Fortune abounds with evil accidents, or disasters, or afflictions, or calamities; i. e. it deviates much, or often, from the right course: it will not remain in one state: or, accord. to one relation, Aldhr Ankv Alx. A proverb. (TA.)
Oanokabu A man not having with him a bow. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

manokibN (masc., Lḥ, Ḳ) The shoulder; i. e. the place of junction of the os humeri and the scapula, (Ṣ, Ḳ.) in a man, &c.; (ISd:) the place of junction of the os humeri and the scapula and the [tendon called] Habolu AlEaAtiqi, in a man and a bird and any other thing. (TA.) [It seems to be regarded by some as originally signifying “a place of deflection:” but] Sb denies its being a noun of place, because, were it so, it would be manokabN: he does not allow it to be included in the class of maToliEN, because this is extr. Pl. manaAkibu. rajulN Xadiydu AlmanaAkibi, signifies A man having a strong shoulder: as though the sing. were applied to denote each part of the joint, and the pl. to denote the whole. (TA.)
haz-uwA manaAkibahumo ‡ [They shook their shoulderjoints;] i. e., they rejoiced, or were joyful, or happy. (TA.)

xiyAarukumo Oalayonukumo manaAkiba fiI AlS-alaApi † [The best of you are the most easy of you in the shoulder-joints in prayer:] meaning. those of you who keep [most] still therein: or, as some say, those who [most readily] give room to such as enter the rank in prayer. (TA, from a trad.)
manokibu Alfarasi The star β in Pegasus. (El-Ḳazweenee, &c.)
manokibu AljawozaACi The bright, and very great star, a, in the right shoulderjoint, of Orion. (El-Ḳazweenee, &c.)

manokibN ‡ The side of anything; or a lateral, or an adjacent, part, quarter, or tract, thereof: (Ḳ:) pl. manaAkibu: ex. sironaA fiI mnkbK mina AlOaroDi We proceeded, or journeyed, along a side, or lateral part, of the land: and, in like manner, mina Aljabali of the mountain: (TA:) so in the Ḳur, lxvii. 15, the pl. signifies the sides, &c., of the earth: (Fr:) or its roads, accord. to some: (TA:) or its mountains: (Zj:) which last signification in this case is preferred by Az: (TA:) or the sing. signifies an elevated place, or part, of the earth or land. (Ṣ.)

AlmanaAkibN ‡ The feathers next after the qawaAdim; [which latter are the anterior, or primary, feathers of a bird's wing;] (Ḳ;) the feathers of the wing of a vulture or an eagle that are next after the qwAdm, which are the strongest and most excellent of the feathers; (TA:) four [feathers] in the wing of a bird, next after the qwAdm (Ṣ.) [the four secondary feathers of the wing:] in the wing of a bird are twenty leathers: the first of them are those called AlqwAdm; the next, AlmnAkb; the next, AlxawaA fiI: the next, AlOabAhiru; the next, AlkulaI. (L.) It is a word without a sing. (Ḳ.) ISd says, I know not a sing. to it; but by analogy it should be manokibN. (TA.)
rAaXa sahomahu bimanaAkiba ‡ He feathered his arrow with feathers such as are described above. (TA.)

manokibN ‡ EariyfN i. q. The intendant, superintendent, &c., of a people or an aider, helper, or assistant, of a people: (Ḳ:) or the assistant of an Eryf: (Mṣb:) one below an Eryf: (IAth:) or the chief of the EurafaACu [pl. of Eryf]; (Lth, Ṣ:) there being over so many ErfAC a mnkb. (Lth [see EariyfN.]) pl. manaAkibu. (TA.)

entry.sense: minokaAbN Eani AlHaq-i [† One who deviates much from the right course of action, &c.] (TA.)
manokuwbN † Overcome or afflicted, by fortune: or smitten with an evil accident, or the like. (Ṣ, TA.) See nukiba.
yanokuwbN [like yaHomuwrN in measure: in the CK, manokuwbN:] A road deviating from the right course or direction. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. nakata, aor. _u {yanokutu}, inf. n. nakotN, (or nakata AlOaroDa biqaDiybK, [&c.,] TA.) He struck the ground with a stick, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or with his finger, (M,) so that it made a mark, or marks, upon it, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with its extremity; an action of one reflecting, or meditating, and anxious. (TA.) [Thus our Saviour seems to have done in the case of the woman taken in adultery: see Ṣ. John viii. 6 and 8.]
Also, He struck the ground with pebbles. (TA.)
Hence, ‡ He reflected, or meditated, and talked to himself (TA, from a trad.)
nakata, aor. _u {yanokutu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nakotN, (Ḳ,) He (a horse) bounded (nabaA, Ṣ, Ḳ) from the ground, (Ṣ,) in running. (TA.)
nakatahu He threw it down upon the ground. (TA.)
nakata kitaAbatahu He scattered the contents of his quiver. (TA.) [See nkb.]
TaEanahu fanakatahN He thrust him, or pierced him, and threw him down upon his head. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

nukita It (a cooked bone, containing marrow,) was struck with the edge of a cake of bread, or with some other thing, to cause the marrow to fall out. (TA.) nukita AlEaZomu The marrow to the bone was taken out, or extracted. (Aboo-'Ameythel.) Mentioned in art. bqt, q. v. (TA.)

nakata fiI kalAamihi and fiI qawolahi, [aor. _u {yanokutu}, inf. n. nakotN? (in the TA, the verb is written without the syll points, but the form commonly known in the present day, and occurring in many late works, is nk-t↓, inf. n. nanokiytN; ‡ He made use of nice, or subtile, sayings, expressions, or allusions, such as are termed nukat, pl. of nukotap)]. (A.)
nakatu fiI AlEilomi bimuwaAfqahi fulaAnK Oawo muxaAlafapi fulaAni He alluded (OaXaAra) [with respect to science, to the agreement of such a one, or the disagreement of such a one]. (L)

entry.sense: 2. nk-t Alr-uTabu, inf. n. tanokiytN, The dates began to ripen [and to become speckled]. (Mṣb.)
See 1.
8. Antkt He was thrown down upon his head; or fell down upon his head, having been thrust, or pierced. (Ṣ, Ḳ *)
nakotN: see nukoyapN.

hom.sense: nukatapN A point; a dot; a speck; a minute spot; i. q. nuqoTapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. nukatN, (Mṣb, &c.) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) and nikaAtN, (Ḳ,) deviating from analogy, and, accord. to some, nukaAtN, in which the A is said to be added liloUiXobaAEi, or to render the sound of the fet-ḥah full, like ruxaAlN (TA:) the last of these pls. has been heard [from the classical Arabs]; (Esh-Shiháb, in the Expos. of the Shifà;) or it is vulgar. (Mṣb.)

nukotapN [A small spot, or mark,] resembling dirt upon a mirror: (Ḳ:) nukotapN sawodaACu A small [black] mark, like a spot, or dot, resembling dirt upon a mirror or a sword or the like (L, from a trad.)
nukotapN [A spot in the eye;] what resembles a waqorap in the eye. (L.)

[nakotN↓ seems to be a quasi- pl. of nukotapN, like as naqoTN is said to be (by some persons in the present day) of nuqoTapN, and to signify Any small spots, or specks, in a thing, differing therefrom in colour. Such I suppose to be meant by the words in the L, kl- naqoTK fI XIC xAlf lwnh nakotN.]
