nukotapN ‡ A nice, subtile, subtilely excogitated, quaint, facetious, or witty, saying, expression, or allusion, (laTiyfap) that makes an impression upon the heart; from Aln-akotu [the striking the ground with a stick, &c., so as to make a mark, or marks, upon it with its extremity]: also, a question educed by reflection, [biAlt-afak-uri, as the passage here translated is given in the Kull, p. 362, but in the TA bAlnql, which is an evident mistake, as might be shown by many authorities,] which makes an impression upon the heart, on hearing or considering which one generally makes marks upon the ground with the finger or the like: (El-Fenáree's Expos. of the Telweeh:) a nice, or subtile, saying, expression, or allusion, that requires one to reflect, and [induces one] to make marks upon the ground with a stick or the like: (from a scholium quoted by De Sacy, Anthol. Gr. Ar., 303:) [a nice, subtile, abstruse, or mystical, point, or allusion: the point of a saying or sentence, especially one that is difficult to be understood: a conceit expressed in words difficult to be understood: a quaint conceit: a point of wit: a facetious saying or allusion: pl., generally, nukatN].
jaACa binukotahK ‡ [He uttered a nice, or subtile, saying, expression, or allusion, &c.]. (A.)

entry.sense: nakiytN Spoken against; having his reputation wounded. (TA.)
nak-aAtN (and munak-itN↓ TA) ‡ One who speaks much, or frequently, against others; who wounds the reputations of others, much, or frequently. (Ḳ.)
zayodN nak-aAtN fiI AlOaEoraADi Zeyd is one who wounds the reputations of others much, or frequently. (TA.)

naAkitN A distortion in a camel's elbow, so that it lacerates his side: (El-'Adebbes El-Kinánee, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the cutting of a camel's side by his elbow: (L:) or [that fault in a camel] when his elbow makes a mark, or marks, upon his side: in this case you say, bihi nAktN: but when it makes an incision, or incisions, in his side, you say bihi HaAz-N: (IAạr) or nAkt is similar to naAHizN, i. e. the elbow's striking, and making a mark, or marks, upon the edge of the callous lump beneath his breast; in the case of which you say bh nAkt: (Lth:) and nearly the same is said in the A. (TA.)
manokuwtN A cooked bone, containing marrow, that is struck with the edge of a cake of bread, or with some other thing, to cause the marrow to fall out. (TA.)
munak-itN: see nak-aAtN.
ruTabapN munak-itapN, A date beginning to ripen [and to become speckled]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
ZalafapN manotakitapN The extremity of the curved piece of wood termed Hinow in the kind of saddle called qatab, and in that called UikaAf, when it is short, and wounds the side of the camel. (TA.)
1. nakava, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanokuvu}, (Ḳ, Mṣb,) and _i, (Ḳ,) inf. n. nakovN, (TA,) He undid [the threads of] a garment of the kind called kisaAC, &c.: (Mṣb:) he undid, or untwisted, a rope. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nakava Als-iwaAka, aor. _u {yanokuvu}, inf. n. nakovN; He, or it, made the head of the tooth-stick to be uncompacted, disintegrated, disunited, or seperated, in its fibres: and so the verb signifies with respect to other things. (TA.) [See also 8.]
nakava, (aor. _u {yanokuvu} and _i {yanokivu} K, inf. n. nakovN, TA,) ‡ He dissolved, violated, or broke, a covenant, or compact, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or an act of inauguration, &c. (TA.)
nakava Eani AlOamori i. q. nakaSa (Aboo-Turáb, in TA, art. nkS.)
5: see 8.
6. tanaAkavuwA Euhuwdahumo ‡ They mutually dissolved, or broke, their covenants, or compacts; syn. tanaAqaDuwhaA. (Ḳ.)
8. Antkv It (a garment of the kind called kisaAC, &c., Mṣb, or a rope, Ṣ, Ḳ) was undone, or untwisted. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
Antkv Als-iwaAku [so accord. to the TA: in the Ḳ, nakava↓:] (TA:) and tnk-v↓, (TA, in art. XEv,) The head of the tooth-stick became uncompacted, disunited, or separated, in its fibres. (TA.)
Antkv [He was, or became, emaciated, or lean; he (a camel) became lean after having been fat. See 4, in art. rOI.]
Antkv ‡ It (a covenant, or compact, Ṣ and Ḳ, or an act of inauguration, &c., TA,) was dissolved, violated, or broken. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
Antkv mino HaAjapK UilaI OuxoraI, (Ḳ,) or liOuxoraI, (Ṣ,) ‡ He turned from a thing that he wanted to another thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) having desired, or sought, the former. (TA.)

nikovN What is undone, to be spun again, (A, Mṣb,) of the garments called Oakosiyap, and of the stuff of the tents called Oaxobiyap: (A:) pl. OanokaAvN: (Mṣb:) or threads of an old and worn-out stuff, of wool or hair, untwisted, and mixed with new wool [or hair], and beaten with maTAariq, and spun a second time: or old and worn-out thread of wool or common hair or the soft hair called wabar; so called because it is untwisted, and twisted again: (TA:) it is when the old and worn-out materials of the garments called Aksyp (and of the tents called Axbyp, Ṣ) are undone, to be spun again. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [SM seems to have understood, from the expl. in the Ṣ and Ḳ, that nikovN is an inf. n.; for he adds,] the subst. is nakiyvapN↓: (TA:) [i. e., this last word has the signification assigned above to nikovN, from the A and Mṣb].
haIi tagozilu Aln-ikova, and nakiyvN, She spins what has been undone, to be spun again, &c. (A.)
HabolN nikovN, and nakiyvN↓, (TA,) and OanokaAvN, and manokuwvN↓, (Ḳ,) A rope undone, or untwisted, (Ḳ, TA,) at its end. (TA.)
nukaAvN Pustules which come forth in the mouths of camels: (Ḳ:) as also lukaAvN. (TA.)
A disease in the nakafataAni of a camel, which are two prominent bones by the fat parts of the two ears: it is also called nukaAfN. (TA.)
nakiyvN: see nikovN.
nukaAvapN The broken particles of the end of a siwaAk [or tooth-stick], remaining in the mouth. (Ḳ.)
Also, What is undone, or untwisted, of the end of a rope, (Ḳ,) &c. (TA.)
nakiyvahN: see nikovN.
Subst. from Antkv AlHabolu [What is undone, or untwisted, of a rope]. (TA.)
‡ Breach of promise; syn. xulofN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. qaAla fulaAnN qawolFA laA nakiyvapa fiyhi Such a one said a saying in which was [intended] no breach of promise. (Ṣ.)
‡ A difficult, or an arduous, affair, or case, in which a people dissolves, or breaks, (tanokuvu) [its covenants, or compacts]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A great affair. (TA.)

The utmost of one's endeavour, or effort: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) power, or strength: (Ḳ:) pl. nakaAYivu. (TA.) Ex. balaga fulaAnN nakiyvapa baEiyrihi Such a one exerted the utmost endeavour, or effort, [or power, or strength,] of his camel, in journeying. (Ṣ.) [See also najiyvapN.]
nakiyvapN Nature; natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other property. (Ḳ.)

Alnakiyvahu † The mind; the soul; syn. Aln-afosu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called because the vexation of those things of which it is in need dissolve (tanokuvu) its powers, and old age destroys it: the p is added because it is a subst. (TA.) Ex. fulAanN Xadiydu Aln-akiyvapi Such a one is strong in mind. (Ṣ.) Pl. nakaAYivu. (TA.)
nak-aAvN One who undoes, or untwists, thread, and twists it again, or, to twist it again. (TA.) [See nikovN.]
nak-aAvN liloEahodi ‡ One who is wont to dissolve, violate, or break, his covenant, or compact. (TA.)
manokuwvN: see nikovN.
manotakivN Emaciated; lean: (Ḳ:) a camel that has been fat, and has become lean. (TA.)

1. nakaHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _i {yanokiHu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and _a, (Ḳ,) the latter agreeable with analogy, but by some rejected, and the former contr. to analogy, but more common, and the form used in the Ḳur, (TA,) the only instance of an aor. of this form from a verb having H for its last radical letter, except ynTH and ymnH and ynDH and ynbH and yrjH and yOnH and yOzH and ymlH, (ISd,) [and yDH] inf. n. nikaAHN (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) and nakoHN; (ISd, Ḳ;) Inivit feminam:
and (sometimes, Ṣ) he married, took in marriage, or contracted a marriage with, a woman: as also AstnkH↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) [and nAkH↓, inf. n. munaAkaHapN:] used only with reference to a man: (ISd:) but Th uses it with reference to flies: (TA:) J says, that it is sometimes used in the latter sense; but accord. to the Mṣb it is more commonly so used; (MF;) and it is used only in this sense in the Ḳur: (TA:) IF and others say, that it signifies coitus; and coitus without marriage; and marriage without coitus: (Mṣb:) [but] in the Time of Ignorance, when a man demanded a woman in marriage he said, AinokiHiyniI; and when he desired fornication, he said, saAfiHiyniI. (TA, in art sfH.) It is disputed whether it be proper or tropical in these two senses; or proper in one, and tropical in one: (MF:) it is said to be from nakaHahu Ald-awaI, or from tanaAkaHati AlOaXojaAru, or from nakaHa AlmaTaru AlOaroDa; and if so, it is tropical in both the above senses; and the opinion that it is so is confirmed by this, that the signification of marriage is not understood unless by a word or phrase in connexion with it, as when you say nakaHa fiI baniI fulaAnK [he took a wife from among the sons of such a one]; nor is that of coitus unless by the same means, as when you say nakaHa zawojatahu [inivit conjugem suam]; and this is one of the signs of a tropical expression. (Mṣb.)
nakaHato She married, or took a husband. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nakaHa AlmaTaru AlOaroDa The rain became commingled with the soil: (Mṣb:) or, rested upon the ground so as to soak it; syn. UiEotamada EalayohaA: (Ḳ:) as also naAkahaA↓. (L.)
nakaHahu Ald-awaI The disease infected him (xaAmarhu), and overcame him. (Mṣb.)
nakaHa Aln-uEaAsu Eayonahu ‡ Drowsiness overcame his eye; (Ḳ;) as also naAkahaA: and in like manner AstnkH↓ Aln-awomu Eayonahu sleep overcame his eye. (TA.)
3: see 1.
4. AnkHhu AlmaroOapa He married the woman to him. (TA.)
OanokaHahaA He married the woman; i. e. gave her in marriage. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OanokiHuwA AlHaSaI OaxofaAfa AlUibili ‡ [Accustom ye the feet of the camels to pebbles]. (A.)
6. tnAkHwA They intermarried; contracted marriages together. (Commencing a trad. in the Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer.) [And tanaAkaHaA Se invicem futuerunt: see 6, in art. rdf]
tanaAkaHati AlOaXojaAru The trees became drawn, or connected, together. (Mṣb.)
nikoHN and nukoHN↓ substs. from OanokaHahaA, [The act of giving a woman in marriage]. (Ḳ.)

[These two words are properly quasi-inf. ns, of OanokaHa, signifying as explained above; and, like inf. ns., may be used as epithets, meaning A giver of a woman in marriage, correlative to xiTobN.] It was a custom, in the time of paganism, for a man to come to a tribe asking for a woman in marriage; and he would stand up in their assembly, and say xiTobN, i. e., I have come as an asker of a woman in marriage; whereupon it would be said to him nikoHN, meaning We marry her to thee, or give her to thee in marriage, [or, more lit., we are givers of her in marriage: for an inf. n. or quasi-inf. n. used as an epithet is used without variation as sing., dual., and pl.; and masc. and fem.]. nukoHN↓ was also said: but nikoHN is here said for the sake of resemblance to xiTobN. (L.) You say hw nikoHuhaA He is the person who gives her in marriage: and hiIa nikoHatuhu She is the person whom he gives in marriage. (Lḥ, L)

nikoHN and nukoHN↓, [and, accord. to Lth and ISh, nikiHN: see UibidN:] are also two words by which the [Pagan] Arabs used to take women in marriage: (Ṣ:) [meaning A giver of a woman in marriage]. (MF, in art. xTb.) A man used to say to Umm-Khárijeh, in asking her in marriage, xiTobN, and she used to reply nikoHN: hence the saying OasoraEu mino nikaAHi Oum-i xaArijapa [Quicker than the marriage of Umm-Khárijeh]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See xiTobN].
nukoHN: see nikoHN.
nukaHN: see nakaHupN.

rajulN nukaHapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nukaHN↓ (Ḳ) A man who marries much, or often: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) AZ explains the former by Xadiydu Aln-ikaAHi, [app. meaning vehement in coitus,] and mentions as its pl. nukaHaAtN: (TA:) [and nak-aAHN↓ (A, TA, art. tys, &c.) signifies the same.]
nak-aAHN: see nukaHapN.

naAkiHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and naAkiHapN, (Ḳ,) the latter occurring in poetry, (TA,) A woman married; (TA;) having a husband. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) Ex. hiIa naAkiHN fiI baniI fulAanK She has a husband among the sons of such a one. (Ṣ.)
manokaHN and manokiHN and manokuwHapN: see manaAkiHu.

manaAkiHu Women, or wives; syn. nisaMCN: (Ḳ:) a pl. having no sing.; or its sing. is manokaHN↓; [or manokiHN↓, which occurs in the Ṣ and Ḳ, art. Elv, evidently as signifying a wife; as though being a place of nikaAH;] or manokuwHapN↓. (TA.)
Uin-a AlmanaAkiHa xayorahuA AlOabokaAru [Verily the best of women to take in marriage are virgins]. A proverb. (TA.)
1. nakida, aor. _a {yanokadu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. nakadN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) It (a man's life) was, or became, hard, or strait, and difficult. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
nakida It (a she-camel's milk) became deficient. (R.)
nakida It (water) became exhausted. (A.)
nakidati Alr-akiy-apu The well came to have little water. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

nakida, aor. _a {yanokadu}, inf. n. nakadN, He was, or became, unpropitious, and mean: (L:) he became hard, or difficult: (Mṣb:) he gave little: or gave not at all: you say also nakida biHaAjatinaA he was niggardly of that which we wanted. (L.)
nakada HaAjatahu, aor. _u {yanokudu}; (Ḳ;) or nakadahu HaAjatahu, (L,) He withheld from him, or refused him, his want. (L, Ḳ.)

nakadahu, aor. _u {yanokudu}, He withheld from him, or refused him, what he asked: or [in the CK, and] the same, (Ḳ,) or nakadahu maA saOalahu, aor. _u {yanokudu}, inf. n. nakodN, (L,) he gave him not save the least of what he asked. (L, Ḳ.)
nukida, [in measure] like EuniIa, He had many askers and gave little. (Ḳ.)
2. nak-ada EaTaMCahu biQloman-i He impaired his gift by reproach. (A.)
nk-d wasoqahu He spent, or exhausted, what he possessed, in consequence of frequent petitions. (A.)
nk-dhu He vexed, distressed, or troubled, him; (Gol, from Meyd.) [as also nk-d Ealayohi].
3. nAkdhu He treated him, or behaved towards him, with hardness, harshness, or ill-nature. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
4. saOalahu faOanokadahu He asked of him, and found him hard, or difficult, (A, L,) and mean, or niggardly: (L:) or found him to have only what was scanty, or little. (L.)
Talaba minohu HaAjapF faOanokada He sought, or desired, of him a thing that he wanted, and he was niggardly. (A.)
5. tnk-d [He became vexed, distressed, or troubled]. (A.) See Bḍ, in lxviii. 25: and see 1.
6. tnAkdA They treated each other with hardness, harshness, or ill-nature. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
nakodN: see nukodN, and nakidN.
nukodN and nakodN↓ Scantiness of a gift; (L, Ḳ;) and its not being enjoyed, or found pleasant, by the receiver. (L.)
See what follows.
nakadFA lahu wjaHadFA, and nukodFA↓ lh wjuHoduA, [May God decree straitness, or difficulty, to him, and poverty]: forms of imprecation. (L.)
nakadN Anything that brings evil upon the person whom it affects. (L.) See nakidN.
Water little in quantity. (L.)

laA yaxoruju Uil-aA nakidFA, in the Ḳur, [vii. 56,] accord. to the common reading, or nakadFA↓, accord. to the reading of the people of El-Medeeneh, or, as it may be read, accord. to Zj, nakodFA↓ and nukodFA↓, means, accord. to Fr, It [the herbage] will not come forth save with difficulty: (L:) or, scantily and unprofitably. (Beyd.)

nakidN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and nakadN↓ and nakodN↓ and Oanokadu↓ (L, Ḳ) A man who is unpropitious, (L, Ḳ,) and mean, (L,) and hard, or difficult: (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and a people you term OanokaAdN and manaAkiydu (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and nukudN and nukodN. (A.)
nakidN and Oanokadu↓ A man that brings evil upon others. (L.)
nakaAdN Hardness, or difficulty, in a man. (A.) See nakida.
OaraDuwna nikaAdN Lands possessing little goods. (L.)
naAkidN: see Oanokadu.

nakodaMCu A she-camel abounding with milk; (IF, L, Ḳ;) as also naAkidN↓: (L:) a she-camel that has no young one living, and therefore abounding with milk, because she does not suckle; (L; Ḳ;) so nakodaMCu miqolaAtN, of which the pls. occur in a verse of El-Kumeyt cited voce Xaxaba: (Ṣ:) also, contr., a she-camel having no milk: (IF, A, Ḳ:) or having little milk; as also naAkidN↓: and both words, a she-camel whose young one has died: (L:) pl. (of both words, L) nukodN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) See also makodaMCu.
Oanokadu Unfortunate; unlucky. (Ṣ.) See nakidN.
munak-adN: see manokuwdN.
manokuwdN A small, or scanty, gift; (A, L, Ḳ;) as also munak-adN↓ (A.)
manokuwdN A man having many askers and giving little: (TA:) or a man pressed with petitions; as also maEoruwkN and maXofuwhN and maEojuwzN. (IAạr, L.)

jaMCahu munokidFA He came to him unwelcomely: or, empty: or, as Th says, it is correctly munokizFA, from nakarati AlbiYoru, though Oanokaza as meaning “his wells became exhausted,” has not been heard. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. nakirahu: see 4, in several places.
nakura, inf. n. nakaArapN, [He was, or became, ignorant: or perhaps only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is used: see nakaArapN, below.]

[And, contr., He possessed cunning; meaning both intelligence with craft and forecast; and simply intelligence, or skill and knowledge: or perhaps only the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is used: see nakorN.]
It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, munokar [app. here meaning disapproved; or bad, evil, abominable, or foul; or disallowed]. (A.)
Also, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. nakaArapN, (TḲ,) or nukorapN, (TA,) It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, difficult, hard, arduous, or severe. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: 2. nk-rhu, (inf. n. tanokiyrN, Mṣb,) He changed, or altered, him or it, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) to an unknown state, (Ṣ, TA,) so as not to be known; (TA;) [he disguised him or it.] It is said in the Ḳur, [xxvii. 41,] nak-iruwA lahaA EaroXahaA Alter ye her throne so that it may not be known to her. (TA.) See also 4, last signification but one.
[In grammar, He made it (a noun) indeterminate.]

3. nAkrhu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. munaAkarapN, (A, Ḳ,) He strove, or endeavoured, to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent, him; or he practised with him mutual deceit, guile, or circumvention; syn. xaAdaEahu and daAhaAhu: the inf. n. is also explained by muraAwagapN as well as muxaAdaEapN [both of which signify the same]. (TA.)

Hence, (TA,) He contended with him in fight; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in war, or hostility. (A, Ḳ.) It is said of Moḥammad, by Aboo-Sufyán (Ṣ, TA) Ibn-Harb, (TA,) lamo yunaAkiro OaHadFA Uil-aA kaAnato maEahu AlOahowaAlu, (Ṣ, TA,) meaning, He did not war with any one without being aided by terror [cast into the hearts of his opponents]. (TA.) And one says, bayonahumaA munaAkarapN Between them two is war, or hostility, (A, TA,*) and fighting. (TA.)

hom.sense:
4. Ankrhu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. UinokaArN; (Mṣb, &c.;) and nakirahu↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yanokaru}, (L,) or it does not admit the variations of tense like other verbs, (IḲṭṭ, Mṣb,) it is not used in the future tense, nor in commanding nor in forbidding, (Lth,) inf. n. nakarN (Ḳ) and nukorN and nukuwrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nakiyrN; (Ḳ;) and Astnkrhu↓; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) and tnAkrhu↓; (M, Ḳ;) signify the same; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) i. e., He ignored, was ignorant of, did not know, failed to know, or [rather] was unacquainted with, it (i. e. a thing, or an affair, IḲṭṭ, Ḳ) or him (a man, Ṣ); syn. jahilahu; (Kr, Ḳ;) or contr. of Earafahu: (Ṣ,* IḲṭṭ, Mṣb:) [see also nakaArapN:] some, however, say, the nakira has a more intensive signification than Oanokara: and some, that nakira has for its objective complement an object of the mind; and Oanokara, an object of the sight: (A, TA:) or [the converse is the case;] nakira has for its objective complement an object of the sight; and Oanokara, an object of the mind: (Kull, p. 81:) [but both forms seem to have been generally used indiscriminately.] El-Aạshà says,
waOanokaratoniI wamaA kaAna Al-aciI nakirato
mina AlHawaAdivi Uil-aA AlX-ayoba waAlS-alaEaA
[And she did not know me; and the accidents which she did not know were none others than hoariness, and baldness of the fore part of the head]. (Ṣ, TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xi. 73,] nakirahumo↓ waOawojasa minohumo xiyfapN [He knew not what they were, and conceived a fear, or a kind of fear, of them]: (TA:) nakirahumo here signifies Oanokarahumo: (Jel:) or it means Oanokara celika minohumo [q. v. infra]. (Bḍ.)

Oanokarahu also signifies He denied, or disacknowledged, it; (L, art. jHd; [and this signification, as well as the first, may be meant to be indicated by those who say that Oanokarahu signifies the contr. of Earafahu;]) [and so nakirahu↓; for] UinokaArN signifies i. q. juHuwdN, (Ṣ, TA,) and so nukoraAnN [which is an inf. n. of nakirahu]. (TA.) [In this sense it is doubly trans.:] you say, Oanokarotuhu Haq-ahu, meaning, I denied, or disacknowledged, to him his right. (Mṣb.) The cause of UinokaAr with the tongue is UinokaAr with the mind, but sometimes the tongue denies, or disacknowledges, (yunokiru,) a thing when the image thereof is present in the mind; and this is lying; as is the case in the following passage of the Ḳur, [xvi. 85,] yaEorifuwna niEomapa Qll-ehi vum-a yunokiruwnahaA [They confess, or acknowledge, the favour of God; then they deny, or disacknowledge, it]. (B.) See also nakiyrN.
Also, He deemed it strange, extraordinary, or improbable. (MF, voce EajabN.)
[Also He denied, or negatived, it.]
[He disbelieved it.]

[And He disapproved it; he disliked it; he deemed it, or declared it to be, bad, evil, abominable, or foul; he disallowed it: so accord. to explanations of the pass. part. n., q. v. infra; and accord. to common usage of classical and of modern times.] It is said of Abraham, when the angels came to him, and he saw that their hands did not touch the meat which be had brought to them, nakirahumo, meaning, Oanokara celika minohumo [He deemed that conduct of their's evil, or disapproved it: or, perhaps, he did not know what that conduct of their's was, or what it indicated]: nakira↓ and Oanokara and Astnkr↓ [of which last see an ex. voce tahima] signify the same. (Bḍ, xi. 73.) And you say, Oanokarotu Ealayohi fiEolahu, meaning, I blamed, or found fault with, his deed, and forbade it; I disapproved and disallowed his deed. (Mṣb:) [and I manifested, or showed, or declared, disapproval, or disallowance, of his deed: and in like manner, Oanokarotu Ealyohi, elliptically; fiEolahu, (his deed,) or qawolahu, (his saying;) or the like, being understood; like Eay-ara Ealayohi for Eay-ara Ealayohi fiEolahu or the like: see nakiyrN.]

UinokaArN also signifies The changing [a thing; like tanokiyrN]: (T, Mṣb, TA:) or the changing what is munokar [here app. meaning disapproved: see nakiyrN, which is syn. with it, but is a simple subst.]. (Ṣ, TA.)

maA Oanokarahu How great it his cunning! meaning both his intelligence, and craft, and forecast; and simply, his intelligence, or skill and knowledge. (TA.) And maA kaAna Oanokarahu How great was his cunning,, &c. (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tnk-r He, or it, changed, or altered, himself, or itself; or became changed, or altered; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA;) to an unknown state: (Ṣ, TA:) [he assumed an unknown appearance: he disguised himself; or became disguised:] he became changed or altered in countenance by anger so that he who saw him did not know him: (Ḥar, p. 144:) or tanak-urN signifies the changing, or altering oneself, or itself; or becoming changed, or altered; from a state which pleases one to a state which one dislikes. (T, Ḳ.)
Uiy-aAka waAlt-anak-ura Avoid thou evil disposition. (Mgh.)

tanak-ara liI fulAanN Such a one [became changed, or altered, in countenance to me by anger so that I did not know him; or] met me in a morose manner (A, TA.) [In art. Xnf in the Ḳ, tanak-arahu occurs.]
6. tnAkrhu: see 4, first signification.
tnAkr He feigned ignorance. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
tnAkrwA They acted with mutual hostility. (TṢ, A, Ḳ.)
10. AXtnkrhu: see 4, first signification, and also in the latter part.

AisotinokaArN also signifies The inquiring respecting, or seeking to understand, a thing, or an affair, which one disapproves; (Ḳ, TA;) when one disapproves confirming, or establishing, the opinion expressed by an inquirer, or disapproves that his opinion should be contrary to what he has expressed. (TA.)

hom.sense: nakorN: see nukorN.
See also nakirN.

nukorN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nakorN↓ [but the former is the more common] and nakaArapN↓ (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and nakoraMCu↓ (A, Ḳ) Cunning; meaning both intelligence mixed with croft and forecast; and [simply] intelligence, or sagacity, or skill and knowledge; syn. dahaMCN; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and fiTonapN. (A, Ḳ.) See also nakura. You say of a man who is intelligent and evil, or cunning, maA OaXad-a nukorahu, and nakorahu↓ [How great is his cunning,, &c.!] (Ṣ.) And faEalahu mino nukorihi, and nakaAratihi↓, He did it of his cunning,, &c. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, Uin-iI laOakorahu Aln-akaArapa fiI Alr-ajuli Verily I hate cunning (Ald-ahaMCa) in the man. (TA.)

entry.sense: nakarN [app. Difficulty, hardness, arduousness, or severity;] a subst. from nakura, in the sense of SaEuba [It was difficult, &c.]. (IḲṭṭ, TA.)
nakurN: see nakirN, in two places.

nakirN and nakurN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nukurN↓ and munokarN↓, (Ḳ,) epithets applied to a man, Possessing cunning; or intelligence mixed with cunning and forecast; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and [simply] intelligent, or skilful and knowing: (Ḳ:) and so, applied to a woman, nukurN↓ (Ḳ) and nakorN↓ (L, TA [but this is probably a mistake for nukurN↓]) and nakoraMCu↓, but Oanokaru is not applied to a man in this sense, (Az, TA,) nor is munokarapN to a woman: (TA:) pl. of the first and second (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and third, (Ḳ,) OanokaArN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and of the last, manaAkiyru: (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, applied to men, munokaruwna; and to other things, manaAkiyru [which is irreg.]. (Az, TA.)
Also, nakirN and nakurN↓ One who disapproves what is bad, evil, abominable, or foul; expl. by Oal-aciI yunokiru Qlomunokara: pl. as above. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: nukurN: see nukorN, and munokarN.
See also nakirN, in two places.

entry.sense: nakarapN a subst. from UinokaArN, (Ḳ,) with which it is syn., [app. signifying (like nakirapN) Ignorance: or denial: or disapproval, or the like]. (TḲ,) like nafaqapN from UinofaAqN. (Ḳ.) It is said, in a certain trad, kunota liI OaXad-a nakarapF, (TA,) i. e. UinokaArFA, (TḲ,) [Thou wast to me most ignorant., &c.]

nakirapN Ignorance,, &c., (UinokaAr,) of a thing; (TA;) contr. of maEorifapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so nakaArapN↓; syn. jahaAlapN; as in the phrase fiyhi nakaArapN [In him is ignorance]. (A.) See also nakarapN.
[As contr. of maEorifapN, it is also, in grammar, an epithet applied to a noun, signifying Indeterminate, or indefinite.]

hom.sense: nakoraMCu: see munokarN.
A calamity: (Ḳ:) rigour, or severity, of fortune; (A, TA;) as also [its dim.] nukayoraMC. (TA.)
See also nukorN.
And see nakirN.

nakiyrN i. q. UinokaArN [in the sense of Denial]. (Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur, xlii. 46. famaA lakumo mino nakiyrK And there shall be for you no [power of] denial of your sins. (Bḍ, Jel.) And one says, Xutima fulaAnN famaA kaAna Einodahu nakiyrN [Such a one was reviled and he had no denial to make]. (A.)
[Also, i. q. UinokaArN in the sense of Disapproval, or the like: and manifestation thereof. See what here follows.]

Also, i. q. UinokaArN in the sense of The changing [a thing]: (T, Mṣb, TA:) or the changing what is munokar [here app. meaning disapproved]: (Ṣ, TA:) a simple subst. (T, TA.) The words of the Ḳur, [xxii. 43 and lxvii. 18,] fakayofa kaAna nakiyri are explained as signifying And how was my changing [of their condition]! (TA:) or the meaning is, and how was my manifestation of disapproval of their conduct, (UinokaAriI Ealayohimo,) by changing favour into trial, and life into destruction, and a flourishing condition into a state of ruin! (Bḍ, xxii. 43.) In [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, it is said that nakiyrapN [but in a MṢ. copy I find nakiyrN and so in the CK] is a subst. from tanak-urN as signifying the changing, or altering, oneself, or itself; or becoming changed, or altered; from a state which please one to a state which one dislikes: but a different statement is found in the T: [see above.] and nkyrp is not mentioned by any authority. (TA.)
A strong fortress. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) See nukorN.
See also munokarN.
nakaArapN: see nakirapN.
See also nukorN.

entry.sense: Oanokaru Worse, and worst; more, and most, evil, abominable, or foul. So it is explained as occurring in the Ḳur. [xxxi. 18,] Uin- Oanokara QloOaSowaAti laSawotu AlHamiyri [Verily the most abominable of voices is the voice of asses]. (TA.)
See also nakirN: and the fem., nakoraMCu, see above.

hom.sense: munokarN contr. of maEoruwfN: (Ḳ:) [an explanation including several significations, here following.]

[Ignored, or unknown; as also manokuwrN↓, for] manokuwrN is syn. with majohuwlN [the pass. part. n. of the verb by which Oanokarahu is explained by Kr and in the Ḳ]; (TA;) and musotanokarN↓ signifies the same. (L.) For the pls. of munokarN, see nakirN.
[Denied, or disacknowledged. (See the verb.)]
[Deemed strange, extraordinary, or improbable, (See again the verb.)]

Any action disapproved, or disallowed, by sound intellects; or deemed, or declared, thereby, to be bad, evil, hateful, abominable, foul, unseemly, ugly, or hideous; or pronounced to be so by the law because the mind deliberates respecting the regarding it as such: and thus it is used in the Ḳur, ix. 113 [and other places]: (B, TA:) or anything pronounced to be bad, evil, hateful, abominable, or foul, and forbidden, and disapproved, disliked, or hated, by the law: (TA:) a saying, or an action, unapproved, not approved, unaccepted, or not accepted, by God: (KT:) unbecoming, indecent, or indecorous. (KL.) See maEoruwfN, voce EurofN. munokarN and nukorN↓ and nukurN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nakoraMCu↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb Ḳ) are all syn., (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and are used as epithets in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] signifying a bad, an evil, a hateful, an abominable, a foul, an unseemly, an ugly, or a hideous, [and a formidable,] thing or affair [or action or saying or quality,, &c.]: (Mṣb:)
[in this sense, its pl. is munokaraAtN and manaAkiyru; as will be seen below:] nukorN↓ is contr. of EurofN [which is syn. with maEoruwfN]. (TA.) You say fiyhimu QlomaEoruwfu waQlomunokaru, and AlEurofu wAln-ukoru, [In them are good and evil qualities.] And humo yarokabuwna QlomunokaraAti, and AlmanaAkiyra, [They commit bad, evil, abominable, or foul, actions.] (A.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xviii. 73,] laqado jiYota XayoYFA nukorFA [Verily thou hast done a bad, an evil, an abominable, or a foul, thing]. (Ṣ.)
The name of one of two angels, the other of whom is named nakiyrN; (Ṣ;) who are the two triers of [the dead in] the graves. (ISd, Ḳ.)
See also nakirN.

entry.sense: manokuwrN: see munokarN, first signification. The pl. is manaAkiyru, [which is also a pl. of munokarN,] accord. to Sb, who mentions it because, accord. to rule, the pl. of a sing. of this class is formed by the addition of w and n for the masc., and A and t for the fem. (Abu-l-Ḥasan, TA.)
xaraja mutanak-ir-FA He went forth disguised; or changed in outward appearance, or state of apparel. (TA.)
musotanokarN: see munokarN, first signification.
TariyqN yanokuwrN A road, or way, in a wrong direction. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. nakasahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yanokusu}, inf. n. nakosN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He turned it over, or upside down; inverted it; reversed it; changed its manner of being, or state: (Sh, Mṣb:*) he turned it over upon its head: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) and he turned it fore part behind; made the first part of it to be last; or put the first part of it last: (Sh:) and nk-shu↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) inf. n. tanokiysN, (Ṣ,) signifies the same; (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ;) or has an intensive sense. (TA.) You say, nukisa Als-ahomu fiI AlkinaAnapi The arrow was turned, or put, upside down in the quiver. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xxxvi. 68,] wamano nuEam-irohu nanokusohu fiI Alxaloqi, or, accord. to the reading of 'Ásim and Hamzeh, nunak-isohu↓; meaning, And him whom We cause to live long, We cause him to become in a state the reverse of that in which he was, in constitution; so that after strength, he becomes reduced to weakness; and after youthfulness, to extreme old age. (TA.)

nakasotu fulaAnFA fiI celika AlOamori † I made such a one to enter again into that affair, or state, after he had got out of it. (ISh.) [Hence the saying in the Ḳur, xxi. 66,] vum-a nukisuwA EalaI ruWuwsihimo † Then they were made to return to their disbelief: (Jel:) or ‡ then they reverted to disputation, after they had taken the right course by means of consulting together; their return to falsity being likened to a thing's becoming upside down: and there are two other readings; nuk-isuwA↓, and nakasuwA; the latter meaning nakasuwA Oanofusahumo: (Bḍ;) or † then they reverted from what they knew, of the evidence in favour of Abraham. (Fr.)

[And hence,] nakasahu, and nakasahu UilaI maraDihi, ‡ [It made him to fall back into his disease.] (TA, in art. hyD.) And nukisa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or nukisa fiI maraDihi, (A, TA,) inf. n. nukosN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nakosN (TA, [but see what is said of this below]) and nukaAsN, (Sh, Ḳ,) ‡ He relapsed into his disease, after convalescence, or after recovery, but not complete, of health and strength: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or the disease returned to him; [he relapsed into the disease;] as though he were made to turn back to it. (Mṣb.) You say, Oakala kacaA fanukisa ‡ [He ate such a thing, and relapsed into his disease]. (A, TA.) And taEosFA lahu wanukosFA, and sometimes one says, nakosFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in this case, (Ṣ,) for the sake of mutual resemblance, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or because nakosFA is a dial form [of nukosFA], (Ṣ,) [meaning, † May he fall upon his face, or the like, (see art. tEs,) and relapse into disease: or] may he fall upon his face, and not rise after his fall until he fall a second time: and in like manner you say, taEasa waQnotakasa↓. (Mṣb, art. tEs.) [See also 8.] You say also, nukisa AljuroHu † [The wound broke open again; or became recrudescent]. (Ṣ, in arts. Erb and HbT, &c.)

And nakasa AlT-aEaAmu wagayoruhu daMCa AlmariyDi ‡ The food, &c., made the disease of the sick man to return. (Ḳ.) And nakasa AlxiDaAba EalaI raOosihi ‡ He put the dye upon his head repeatedly, or several times. (A, TA.*)
Also nakasa [or more probably nukisa] † He (a man) became weak and impotent. (Sh, in TA.) And nukisa Eano nuZaraAYihi, like EuniIa, † He fell short of his fellows; was unable to attain to them. (TA.)

nakasa raOosahu, and nk-shu↓, (TA,) [and nakasa alone, (see naAkisN,)] and nk-s↓, (L, TA, art. bqr,) and Antks↓, (TA,) [and in like manner tnk-s↓, said of a flower-stalk in the M and Ḳ, voce qiXobN,] He bent, or inclined, his head; (TA;) he lowered, or stooped, his head; bent, or hung, it down towards the ground; absolutely; or by reason of abasement. (So accord. to explanations of the act. part. n., below.)
2: see 1, throughout.
5: see 1, last sentence.

8. Antks quasi-pass. of nakasahu; (Ṣ, A, TA;) [and therefore signifying It became turned over, or upside down; became turned over upon its head; became inverted; became reversed; became changed in its manner of being, or state; it became turned fore part behind; its first part was made to be last, or was put last:] he fell upon his head. (Ḳ.) This last signification [understood figuratively] it is said to have in the phrase taEasa waQnotakasa, a form of imprecation, meaning, † May he be disappointed, or fail, of attaining his desire: for he who is overthrown in his affair (man Qnotakasa fiI Oamorihi) is disappointed of attaining his desire, and suffers loss. (TA.) [See also 1, where this form of imprecation is differently explained.]
Also, i. q. nak-asa raOasahu. (TA.) [See 1, last signification.]
nikosN An arrow having its notch broken, and its top therefore made its bottom: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OanokaAsN (A, TA) and [of mult.] nukusN. (A.)
A head, or blade, of an arrow, &c., having its tongue (sinox) broken, and its point therefore made its tongue: (Ḳ:) pl. OanokaAsN. (TA.)
A bow of which the foot is made [of] the head of the branch; as also manokuwsapN↓. This peculiarity is a fault. (Ḳ.)

A child such as is termed yatonN [born preposterously, feet foremost; but yatonN is an inf. n., and I have not found it used as an epithet anywhere but in this instance]; (Ḳ;) i. q. manokuwsN; and mentioned by IDrd; but he says that it is not of established authority. (TA.)

‡ Low, or ignoble; base; vile; mean, or sordid: See a verse cited voce OaX-aEala: (A:) ‡ one who falls short of the utmost point of generosity; (Ḳ;) or of courage and generosity: (TA:) † weak; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man: (Ṣ:) † short: (AḤn:) pl. OanokaAsN. (A, Ḳ.)
See also munak-isN:
and nukusN.
nukasN, [app. pl. of nikosN,] † Old men tottering by reason of age (mudorahim-uwna) after attaining to extreme old age. (Ḳ.)

naAkisN Lowering his head; bending, or hanging, down his head towards the ground; [absolutely;] (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [or] by reason of abasement: (TA:) pl. [properly naAkisuwna; (see Ḳur, xxxii. 12;) and sometimes] nawaAkisu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) used [only] in poetry, (Ṣ, TA,) by reason of necessity, (TA,) and anomalous, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like fawaArisu. (Ṣ.) El-Farezdaḳ says,
waUicaA Alr-ijaAlu raOawoA yaziyda raOayotahum
xuDuEa Alr-iqaAbi nawaAkisa AlOaboSaAri
[And when the men see Yezeed, thou seest them depressed in the necks, lowering the eyes]: (Ṣ:) thus the verse is related by Fr and Ks: Akh says, that it is allowable to say nawaAkisi AlOaboSaAri, after the manner of the phrase Hujoru Dab-K xaribK; [see art. xrb;] and Aḥmad Ibn-Yaḥyà adds I in relating it; saying nawaAkisiI AlOaboSaAri. (TA.) [See the remarks on fawaArisu, pl. of faArisN.]

munak-isN A horse that does not raise, or elevate, his head, (Ṣ, IF, Ḳ,) nor his neck, when running, by reason of weakness: (IF, Ḳ:) or that has not reached the other horses (Lth, Ḳ) in their heat, or single run to a goal; (Lth;) i. e., by reason of his weakness and impotence; as also nikosN↓. (TA.)
waladN manokuwsN A child [preposterously brought forth]; whose feet come forth before his head. (A, Mṣb, and so in a copy of the Ṣ.) See also nikosN.
TawaAfN manokuwsN A circuiting of the Kaabeh performed in a way contrary to the prescribed custom, by saluting the black stone and then going towards the left. (Mgh.)

qaraOa AlquraMna manokuwsFA He read or recited, the Ḳur-án, beginning from the last part thereof, (Ḳ,) i. e. from [the commencement of the latter of] the muEaw-icataAni [or last two chapters], (TA,) and ending with the faAtiHap [or first chapter]; contrary to the prescribed mode: (TA:) or beginning from the end of the chapter, and reading it, or reciting it, to its beginning, invertedly; (Ḳ;) a mode which AʼObeyd thinks impossible; and therefore he holds the former explanation to be the right: (TA:) each of these practices is disapproved, excepting the former in teaching children, [in which case it is generally adopted in the present day,] (Ḳ,) and [in teaching] the foreigner the [portion of the Ḳur-án called the] mufaS-al; an indulgence being granted to these two only because the long chapters are difficult to them: but if any one knows the Ḳur-án by heart, and intentionally recite it from the last part thereof to the first, this is forbidden: and if we disapprove this, still more is the reciting from the end of the chapter to the beginning disapproved, if the doing this be possible. (TA.)
manokuwsN also signifies ‡ Suffering a relapse into disease, after convalescence; or after recovery, but not complete, of health and strength. (Ḳ.)
manokuwsapN applied to a bow: see nikosN.

1. nakaXa AlbiYora, (Ṣ, A,) or Alr-akiy-apa, (Ḳ,) aor. _i {yanokiXu} (Az, Ṣ, ISd, Ḳ) and _u {yanokuXu}, (IDrd, Ḳ,) inf. n. nakoXN, (A,) He entirely exhausted the water of the well: (Az, Ṣ, A:) and (A) he extracted what was in the well, of black fetid mud (HamoOap [in some of the copies of the Ḳ, xabiyoYap, which is a mistranscription,]) and of clay: (A, Ḳ;) as also UinotakaXahaA↓ (Ṣgh, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, falaAnN baHorN laA yunokaXu (Ṣ, Ḳ *) † [Such a one is] a sea, or great river, which will not be entirely exhausted, nor will diminish. (Ḳ.) And Einodahu XajaAEapN laA tunokaXu (Ṣ, TA.) ‡ He has courage which will not be exhausted: said of ʼAlee, by a man of Kureysh. (TA.)

And nakaXa AlX-aIoCa He consumed the thing; made it come to an end, fail, cease, perish, or come to nought: (A, Ḳ:) and the same, (ISd, A,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) or nakaXa minohu, (Lth, Ḳ,) he made an end of the thing; or ceased from it, having finished it. (Lth, ISd, A, Ḳ; but in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, faziEa is put by mistake for faraga, in this explanation. TA.) One says, UinotahawoA UilaI EuXobK fanakaXuwhu They came at last to herbage, and consumed it. (Ṣ,* TA.) And lumoEapN maA tunokaXu [A piece of herbage beginning to dry up] that is not extirpated, or cut off entirely with its roots. (Ḳ.)
nakoXN also signifies † The scrutinizing or investigating, or searching or examining or inquiring into, affairs. (TA.) [You say, app., nakaXa Eani AlOumuwri, meaning, He scrutinized,, &c., affairs.]
And nakaXaAnN is like nakoXN [but in what sense is not said]. (TA.)
8: see 1, first sentence.
nak-aAXN † A man who scrutinizes or investigates, or searches or examines or inquires into, affairs; (TA;) as also minokaXN↓. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
minokaXN: see nak-aAXN.
minokaAXN a dial. form of minoqaAXN, but of weak authority. (TA.)
manokuwXN A receptacle of the kind called safaT of which the contents have been taken out. (TA.)
huwa manokuwXN mina AlmanaAkiyXi † [He is one of those who are empty, or devoid of good]: a phrase denoting vituperation. (TA.)

1. nakaSa Eani AlOamori, (A, Ḳ,) [aor. _i {yanokiSu}, and sometimes _u, as will be shown below,] inf. n. nukuwSN (Ṣ, IF, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nakuSN (A, Ḳ) and manokaSN (Ḳ) and nakaSaAnN, (MA,) He receded, retired, or drew back from the thing, or affair, refrained, forbore, abstained, or desisted, from it; recoiled from it, shrank from it, or drew back from it in awe or fear; (Ṣ, IF, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also nakava Eanohu. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) You say also, nakaSa EalaI Eaqibayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or ElI Eaqibihi, (A,) aor. _u {yanokuSu} (Ṣ, Mṣb) and _i {yanokiSu}, (Ṣ,) or the latter only, (Ṣgh, TA,) or the former is allowable, (Zj, TA,) He turned back from a thing to which he had applied himself; (IDrd, Ṣ,* A,* Mṣb,* Ḳ, TA;) meaning a good thing; and sometimes an evil thing; (IDrd, TA;) or meaning particularly a good thing; or extr. with respect to an evil thing. (Ḳ.) [See the Ḳur, xxiii. 68.] Hence AntkS↓ [as syn. with nkS], though we have not heard it. (Mgh.)
8: see above {1}.
HaZ-uhu naAqiSN wajad-uhu naAkSN ‡ [His lot, or portion, is decreasing, or deficient, and his good fortune is receding]. (A, TA.)

manokaSN, (O, B, Ḳ,) like maqoEadN, (TA,) [in the CK, erroneously, munak-aS,] A place to which one removes, withdraws, or retires afar off, syn. mutanaH-FI. (O, B, Ḳ.) El-Aạshà says, praising 'Alkamah Ibn-'Olátheh,
OaEaloqamu qado jabaratoniI AlOumuwru
Uilayoka wamaA kaAna liI manokaSu
[O 'Alkamah, affairs have compelled me to have recourse to thee, and there was not for me any place to which to retire.] (TA.)
namaON and namoCN Little live. (Kr, Ḳ.) [See also nim-apN.]
namotN A certain plant, having a fruit that is eaten. (L, Ḳ.) The only explanation given by several lexicographers. (TA.)

namuwcajN (Ḳ, Mṣb, &c.) and OanomuwcajN; which latter is said to be a corruption in the TṢ and the Ḳ; but this is denied by El-Khafájee and by Mṭr; and learned men, in early and in late times, have constantly used the word Anmwcj without any expression of disapproval; Z and El-Ḥasan Ibn-Rasheek El-Keyrawánee, two leading lexicologists, having even named thereby books written by them; (MF;) vulgo namuwnah [which is a Persian word]; (TA;) A model, an exemplar, a pattern, or a likeness of a thing, after the similitude of which a thing is made: (Mṣb:) a model, or likeness, of a thing; (Ḳ;) i. e., a thing that is made in the form, or after the fashion, of another thing, that the mode of the latter may be known thereby: (TA:) a thing which shows the mode, or quality, or qualities, of another thing: (Mṣb:) an arabicized word, (Ḳ,) from [the Persian] namuwdaho.

hom.sense: 1. namira, aor. _?, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. namarN, (Ṣ,) [It was, or became, spotted like a leopard or panther: see also 5:] it (a cloud, or collection of clouds,) became of the colour of the namir [leopard or panther], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) spots being seen in their interstices. (Ṣ.)
See also 5, in three places.
2. nm-r, inf. n. tanomiyrN, † He, or it, changed, or altered, and rendered morose, his face. (T.)
See also 5, in two places.

entry.sense:
5. tnm-r [He made himself like a leopard or panther, in diversity of colours: see also 1]. ʼAmr Ibn-Maadee-Kerib says,
qawomN UicaA labisuwA AlHadiI
da tanam-aruwA HalaqFA waqid-aA
[A people who, when they put on armour of iron mail,] make themselves like the leopard or panther (namir) in the diversity of colours of the iron [rings] and the thongs. (Ṣ.)
nimorN: see namirN.

hom.sense: namirN: see Oanomaru, throughout.

namirN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and nimorN, (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is a contraction of the former, (Mṣb,) or a dial. form, (TA,) [The leopard;] a certain wild beast, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) well known, (A, Ḳ,) more malignant than the lion, (T, M, Mgh, Mṣb,) and bolder, (Mṣb,) so called because of his numar [or spots], (M, Ḳ,) being of divers colours, (M,) called in Persian Palanoko: (Mgh:) fem. with p {namirapN}: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OanomurN (M, Ḳ) and OanomaArN, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and [of mult.] numuwrN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) held by Th to be pl. of nimorN, (M,) and numuwrapN (Mṣb, and so in some copies of the Ḳ) and numurN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which occurs in poetry, and is anomalous, perhaps a contraction of numuwrN, (Ṣ,) and not mentioned by Sb, (M,) and numorN, (M, Ḳ,) which is the most common in occurrence, but, accord. to Th, he who uses it makes the sing. Oanomaru, (M,) and nimaArN, (M, Ḳ,) held by Th to be pl. of nimorN, (M,) and nimaArapN. (Ḳ.) As the namir is one of the most abominable and malignant of wild beasts, one says, labisa fulaAnN lifulaAnK jiloda Aln-amiri, meaning, ‡ Such a one became changed, or altered, to such a one; or met him in a morose manner: (IB:) or became very rancourous, or malicious, towards him. (TA.) The kings of the Arabs, when they sat [in judgment] to slay a man, used to attire themselves in skins of the namir, and then give orders for the slaying of him whom they desired to slay. (IB.)
See also namiyrN, throughout.

entry.sense: numorapN A spot, or speck, of any colour whatever: pl. numarN. (M, Ḳ.)

namirapN A garment of the kind called burodap, of wool, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) striped, (TA,) worn by the Arabs of the desert: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or a garment of the kind called Xamolap, (M, Ḳ,) or kisaMC, (A, Mgh, Mṣb,) having white and black stripes, or lines, (M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) worn by the Arabs of the desert: (A, Mṣb:) and a garment of the kind called Hibarap; (M, Ḳ;) so called because of the diversity of the colours of its stripes: (M:) or any mYozar, of those worn by the Arabs of the desert, that is a striped Xamolap: (IAth:) or a striped UizaAr of wool; (TA;) pl. nimaArN: (IAth, Mṣb:) it is an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Saạd, nabaTiI-N fiI Hubowatihi OaEoraAbI-N fiI namiratihi OasadN fiI taOomuwratihi [A Nabathean in his hubweh (a long piece of cloth, or the like, wound round the back and legs of a person sitting with his thighs against his belly); an Arab of the desert in his nemireh; a lion in his den]. (Ṣ.)
See also Oanomaru.

maMCN namiyrN (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and namirN↓, (M, Ḳ,) Wholesome water, whether sweet or not sweet: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or sweet and wholesome water: (T, A:) or wholesome in satiety: (TA:) or copious: (Ibn-Keyrán, M, Ḳ:) or increasing in quantity, syn. naAmK, (Aṣ, T, TA,) or zaAkK, (Ḳ,) whether sweet or not sweet: (T, TA:) or increasing in quantity in the beasts [app. meaning while they drink], (zaAkK fiI AlmaAXiyap naAmK, T, M,) whether sweet or not sweet. (M.) [As zaAkK is coupled with naAmK, app. as an explicative adjunct, in the T and M, I think that I have here rendered it correctly: otherwise I should have supposed it to mean, perhaps, pure.]
HasabN namiyrN, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) and namirN↓, (M, Ḳ,) ‡ i. q. zaAkK [see above]: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) pl. OanomaArN. (M.)

Oanomaru Spotted white and black: (M, Ḳ:) or in which is black and white; applied to a wild beast; as also namirN↓: (A:) fem. namoraMCu; (M, A, Ḳ;) applied to a ewe or she-goat: (A:) pl. numorN: (A:) also Oanomaru a horse, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and an ostrich, (Ḳ,) variegated like the namir, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) having one spot white and another of any colour: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. as above: (TA:) or, applied to an ostrich, in which is blackness and whiteness: pl. as above: (Ṣ:) and a lion in which is dust-colour and blackness: and munam-arN↓ a bird having black spots; also sometimes applied as an epithet to a horse such as is termed birocawon. (TA.) Also, A collection of clouds of the colour of the namir, spots being seen in their interstices: (Ṣ:) or having black and white spots: (TA:) and namirN↓ signifies a collection of clouds having marks like those of the namir: or small portions near together: n. un. with p: (M:) or namirapN↓ signifies a small portion of a cloud: and its pl. [or rather the coll. gen. n.] is namirN. (Ḳ.) It is said in a proverb, OariniyhaA namirapF OurikahaA maTirapF [Show thou it to me spotted like the leopard, I will show it to thee raining]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) alluding to an event which one certainly knows will happen when the symptoms thereof appear: (Meyd, Ḳ, TA:) originally said by Aboo-Dhu-eyb El-Hudhalee: (TA:) namirap is here like xaDirFA in the Ḳur, vi. 99, for OaxoDara: (Akh, Ṣ:) by rule, it should be namoraMCa, (Ḳ, TA,) fem. of Oanomaru. (TA.)
See also namirN.

munam-arN: see Oanomaru. [In the TA, voce HibarapN, it is applied as an epithet to a garment of the kind called burod: and in the Ḳ, voce HabiyrN, to a cloud, or collection of clouds: in the former case, it app. signifies striped, (see namirapN,) or, as in the latter case, spotted.]

hom.sense: 1. namasahu, aor. _u {yanomusu}, inf. n.namosN, He concealed it; namely, a secret. (Ṣ.) See also 2.

He spoke, or discoursed, secretly to him, or with him; he acquainted him with a secret; (Ṣ;) as also naAmsahu↓, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. munaAmasapN (M, A) and nimaAsN. (M.) You say, maA OaXowaqaniI UilaI munaAmasatika [How great is my desire, or longing, for thy secret discourse!] (A, TA.)
[And it seems to be indicated in the M, that namasa, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies He became a confidant, or acquainted with another's secrets.]

[Hence, perhaps,] namasa bayonahumo, inf. n. as above; (IAạr:) and Oanomasa↓ bynhm, (IAạr, Ḳ,) inf. n. UinomAsN; (IAạr;) He created discord, or dissension, among them, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and incited them one against another, or went about among them with calumnies. (IAạr.) See also 2.

namisa, aor. _a {yanomasu}, inf. n. namasN, It (clarified butter, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, or oil, M, and perfume, and the like, A, and anything sweet or good, M) became bad, or corrupt, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) so as to be slimy, ropy, or viscous; (TA;) became altered (M, TA) and bad, in the manner described above: (TA:) and nam-asa↓, said of [the preparation made of churned milk called] OaqiT, it became stinking, or fetid. (TA.) See also 2, below.

2. nm-s Ealayohi AlOamora, (A,* TA,) inf. n. tanomiysN, (A, Ḳ,) He concealed from him the thing, or affair; or made it dubious, or confused, to him; syn. lab-asahu. (A, Ḳ,* TA.) See also 1, first signification.
nm-s biSaAHibihi He calumniated his companion; syn. nam-a bihi. (A.) See also 1.
nm-s XaEaruhu His hair became befouled by oil. (M) See also 1, last sentence.
3. naAms He (a hunter) entered a naAmuws. i. e., lurking-place, or covert. (Ḳ.) See also 7.
nAmshu: see namasahu.

entry.sense: 4. Anms bayonahumo: see lamasa bynhm.
5. tnm-s He (a hunter) made for himself a naAmuws, i. e., lurking-place, or covert. (A.)
tunum-isa bihi: see naAmuwsN.

7. Uin-amasa, of the measure UinofaEala, (Ṣ, CK [in some copies of the Ḳ, AftEl, which is a mistake.]) He concealed himself: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or An-ms fiI AlX-aIoCi signifies he entered into the thing (M, IḲṭṭ) and concealed himself. (IḲṭṭ.) See also one of the explanations of naAmuwsN, in which this verb occurs. and see 3.

nimosN [The ichneumon; so called in the present day;] a certain small beast. (IḲt, El-Fárábee, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) broad, as though it were a piece of qadiyd [or salted or sun-dried flesh-meat]. (Ṣ) found in the land of Egypt, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) one of the most malignant of wild animals, (M,) that kills the [kind of serpent called] vuEobaAn: (IḲt. El-Fárábee, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the keeper of vines or palm-trees or seed-produce (Aln-aAZirN) takes it for his use, when he is in vehement fear of serpents of the kind above mentioned: for it attacks them, making itself thin and slender as though it were a piece of rope; and when it winds itself upon them, they draw back their breath vehemently, and it take their breath; thus the serpent becomes inflated in its inside, and is cut asunder: (TA.) or i. g. Aibonu EirosK [the weasel]: (IḲt, TA:) or a certain small beast, resembling the cat, generally frequenting gardens; accord. to IF, also called dalaqN [q. v.]; (Mṣb;) the beast called dalaho [the Persian original of dalaqN]; [see Aibonu miqoraDK, in art. qrD;] called nms from nam-asa in the first of the senses explained above: (A;) or i. q. ZaribaAnN: (El-Mufaddal Ibn-Selemeh, TA:) from these various sayings, it appears that several species are called by this name: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OanomaAsN (TA) and [of mult.] numuwsN. (Mṣb.) You say, fiI Aln-aAsi OanomaAsN [app. meaning, Among men are some that are malignant as the animals called AnmAs]. (A. TA.)
namasN The odour of milk, and of grease or gravy; as also nasamN. (M.)

namisN, applied to clarified butter, (A,) or oil, (M,) and perfume, and the like, (A,) and anything sweet or good, (M,) Bad, or corrupt, (A, TA.) so as to be slimy, ropy, or viscous; (TA;) altered. (M, TA.) and had, in the manner described above: (TA:) and munam-isN↓, applied to OaqiT, [see 1, last signification,] stinking, or fetid. (TA,)
nam-aAsN: see naAmuwsN.
naAmuwsN A secret: (Seer, M:) [pl. nawaAmiysu.]

[Hence, app., rather than from the Greek νόμος as some have supposed,] Revelation. So in a trad respecting fines for bloodshed: in which it is said, qaDayota fiynaA biAln-aAmuwsi [Thou hast pronounced judgment respecting us according to revelation]. (Mgh.) [Bat see a remark on this signification in what follows.]
[And hence,] The law of God. (KT.)

[And from the first,] An evasion, artifice, or expedient, by which a man conceals himself; expl. by maA yan-amisu bihi Alr-ajulu mina AlUiHotiyAli; (Ṣ;) or maA tunum-isa bihi mina AlUiHotiyaAli (Ḳ [but here, app., tunum-sa is a mistake for tan-amisu:]) deceit; guile; circumvention. (A, TA.) You say, fulaAnN SaAHibu naAmuwsK, and nawaAmiysa, Such a one is a person of deceit,, &c., and of deceits., &c. (A, TA.) And hence the phrase nawaAmiysu AlHukamaMCi [app. meaning The artifices of the wise men]. (TA)
[Also, in post classical writings, A man's honour, or reputation which should be preserved inviolate; syn EiroDN.]
[The remaining significations I regard as being derived from those above mentioned; supposing a prefixed noun to be understood; in some instances, SaAHib, or cuw; in others, makaAn, or maHal-]

A confidant; one who possesses, or is acquainted with, secrets, or private affairs; (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) of a king, (Mgh, TA,) or governor, or prince, (A,) or other man; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, TA;) whom are acquaints with his private affairs, and distinguishes by revealing to him what he conceals from others: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) or one who possesses, or is acquainted with, secrets, or private affairs, of a good nature: (Ḳ, TA:) and jaAsuwsN signifies one who possesses, or is acquainted with, secrets, or private affairs of an evil nature. (TA.) [The author of the Mgh thinks that the second of the significations mentioned above, i. e. “revelation,” is derived from this; a prefixed noun (such as kitaAb, perhaps,) being understood.] Hence, (Mgh,) Aln-Amuwsu, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or Aln-aAmuwsu AlOakobaru, (A, TA,) is applied to [The angel] Gabriel; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, A, &c.) by the people of the scriptures; [meaning, the Christians, and perhaps, the Jews also;] (Ṣ, Mgh;) because God has distinguished him by communicating to him revelations and hidden things with which no other is acquainted. (TA.)
A repository (wiEaMC) of knowledge. (M.)
Skilful; intelligent. (Ḳ,* TA.)
One who enters into affairs with subtle artifice. (Aṣ, Ḳ.*)
A calumniator: syn. nm-aAmN; (Ḳ;) as also nam-aAsN↓. (A, Ḳ.)
A liar. (M.)

The burking-place, or covert. (qutorap, q. v.,) of a hunter, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) in which he lies in wait for the game: (TA:) sometimes written with C [naOomuwsN;] but for what reason [says ISd] I know not. (M.)
A snare: syn. XarakN: (Ḳ:) because it is concealed beneath the ground. (TA.)
The covert. or retreat. of a lion; as also naAmuwsapN↓. (Ḳ.)
The chamber. or cell, of a monk. (TA, Ḳ,* voce taOumuwrN)
naAmuwsapN: see naAmuwsN, last signification but one.
Oanomasu Of a dusky, or dingy, colour, (Ḳ,) [like the nimos, or ichneumon.]
Hence, [its pl.] numosN is applied to [A certain species (namely the kudoriI-)of] the kind of birds called qaTFA. (Ḳ.)
munam-isN: see namisN.
munaAmisN Entering a naAmuws [or hunter's lurking. place]. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. namiXa, aor. _a {yanomaXu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. namaXN. (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, speckled with white and black: or marked with sports upon the skin differing from it in colour. (Ḳ.) See namaXN below.
namaXahu, inf. n. namoXN, He variegated it; or decorated, or embellished, it: (TA;) [as also nm-Xhu↓, but app. in an intensive sense, for its inf. n.] tanomyXN is syn. with tadobiyjN. (TA.)
[And hence, app.,] † He mixed, or confounded, it, e. g., good speech with bad; as also ↓the latter of these two words. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
namoXN A mark, trace, vestige, or relic. (TA.)

namaXN White and black specks (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ) in a colour: (TA:) or spots in the skin differing from it in colour; (IDrd, A, Ḳ;) sometimes in horses, and mostly in such as are of a sorrel colour. (TA.)
Lines, or streaks, of variegations or decorations in variegated or figured cloth, &c. (Ḳ.)
Whiteness in the roots, or lower parts, of the nails, which goes away and returns. (TA.)

namiXN Speckled with white and black; applied to a bull; (TA:) and so OanomaXu↓; (Mgh, TA;) applied to a man. (Mgh.) You say, vaworN namiXN, meaning, A wild bull, which has specks (Ṣ, TA) and lines. or streaks. (TA.)
And vaworN namiXN AlqawaAYimi A bull having black lines, or streaks, in the legs. (A.) And EanozN namoXaMCu↓ A she-goat that is black speckled with white, or white speckled with black. (TA.)
sayofN namiXN ‡ A sword in which are diversified wavy streaks. (A, Ḳ,* TA.)
baEiyrN namiXN A camel having in his foot a mark that becomes distinctly shown upon the ground, without any mark thereon made artificially; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) and so bEyr nahiXN. (Ibn-'Abbàd, TA.)
OanomaXu: fem. namoXaMCu: see namiXN, in two places.
2. tanomiyTN signifies The directing, or guiding, to a thing. (Ḳ.) You say, mano nam-aTaka EalaI hecaA AlX-aIoCi Who directed thee, or guided thee, to this thing? syn. dal-aka Ealayohi. (Ibn-ʼAbbád.)

hom.sense: namaTN The facing, or outer covering, (ZihaArap,) of a bed (T, Mgh, Ḳ) upon which one sleeps, (Mgh,) or of a thing that is spread upon the ground to sit or lie upon, (T, Ḳ,) whatever it be: (Ḳ:) or a sort of carpet or other thing that is spread upon the ground: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and a woollen cloth (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) which is thrown over the [kind of vehicle called] hawodaj, (Mgh, Ḳ,) having a fine nap, or pile, (TA,) of some colour; what is white being seldom or never so called: (Mṣb:) or a sort of dyed cloth, like zawojN, these names being seldom or never applied but to what is coloured red or green or yellow; what is white not being called namaTN: (Az, L:) and a cloth that is spread beneath a horse's saddle: (Meyd, as cited by Golius:) some say, that it is a receptacle like the safaT: (Ḥar, p. 273 [but this I think doubtful:]) pl. OanomaATN [properly a pl. of pauc. but used also as one of mult.] (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nimaATN. (IB, Ḳ.)

A body of men (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) whose case is one; i. e. a class of men. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., (Ṣ, Mgh,) of ʼAlee, (Mgh,) xayoru hecihi AlOum-api Aln-amaTu AlOawosaTu The best of this people is the middle body thereof (Ṣ, Mgh) whose case is one; i. e. the middle class thereof: (Ṣ, in which is added, yuloHaqu bihimu Alt-aAliI wayurojaEu Uilayohimu AlgaAliI [he who falls short shall be made to reach them, and he who exceeds the due bounds shall be brought back to them:]) AʼObeyd says, (Mgh, TA,) the meaning of this saying of ʼAlee is, (TA,) that he disliked the exceeding of the due bounds and the falling short (Mgh, TA) in religion. (TA.)

A way: (Mṣb, TA:) a way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, conduct, or the like; (Mgh, Ḳ;) as also AnmT↓: (TA [so there written, without any syll. points:]) a tenet, or body of tenets, belief, creed, opinion, or persuasion, which one takes to, or holds: (Mgh, TA:) a kind, or way, of speech. (TA.) You say, Uilozamo hecaA Aln-maTa keep thou to this way. (TA.) And takal-amuwA EalaI namaTK waAHidK They spoke according to one way, course, mode, or manner,, &c. (Mgh.)

‡ A sort, or species, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a thing, (Ḳ,) of goods or commodities, of learning or. science, &c. (TA.) You say, EinodiI mataAEN mino hecaA Aln-amaTi ‡ I have goods of this sort, or species. (Mgh.) And hecaA mino namaTi hecaA ‡ This is of the sort, or species, of this. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: namaTiI-N: see OanomaATiI-N.
AnmT: see namaTN.

OanomaATiI-N [A maker, or seller, of OanomaAT, pl. of namaTN:] a rel. n. from namaTN; as also namaTiI-N↓: (Ḳ, TA:) the former [from the pl.,] like OanoSaAriI-N: the latter from the sing., agreeably with analogy. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. nahiYa, aor. _a {yanohaOu}; and nahuWa, aor. _u {yanohuOu}; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and nahuWa; (as in one copy of the Ṣ;) inf. n. nahoCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nahaON (Ṣ) and nahaMCapC (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuhuwoCapN (Ḳ) and nuhuwoCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nahaAwapN, (the last dev. from rule); (Ḳ;) It (flesh-meat) was not, or did not become, thoroughly cooked. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

maA OubaAliI maA nahiYa mino Dab-ika walaA maA nDija [I care not what is insufficiently cooked, of thy Dab-, nor what is thoroughly cooked: i. e. I care not whether evil or good befall thee]. (Ṣ,* TA,) A proverb. (TA.)
Xariba Hat-aI nahaOa, aor. _a {yanohaOu}, He drank till he was full. (Ḳ,* TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AnhO (Ṣ, Ḳ) inf. n. UinohaMCN, (Ṣ,) He insufficiently cooked flesh-meat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He did a thing not firmly, not soundly, not thoroughly. (Ḳ.)
nuhuwoCN The state of being not thoroughly cooked. (TA.)
nahiIoCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and munohaON↓ (Ṣ) Insufficiently cooked flesh-meat. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naAhiYN Satiated with food and with drink. (IAạr.)
munohaON: see nahiIoCN.

1. nahaba Aln-ahoba aor. _a {yanohabu}, and _u; and nahibahu, aor. _a {yanohabu}; (inf. n. nahobN; TA;) and Anthbh↓; [and nAhbh↓;] He took the spoil, plunder, or booty. (Ḳ.) AlAinotihaAbu↓ is The taking of spoil, plunder, or booty, by whomsoever will: you say Oanohaba↓ Alr-ajulu maAlahu [the man allowed, or gave, his property to be taken as spoil], faQnotahabuwhu↓, and nahabuwhu, and naAhabuwhu↓, which all signify the same, [and they took it as spoil]. (Ṣ.)
nahabahu Alkalobu, aor. _a {yanohabu}, The dog seized him (a man) by the tendon of his heel. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nahabuwhu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and nAhbwh↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. munaAhabapN; (TA;) ‡ They carped at him in their speech, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, with their tongues, and spoke roughly, harshly, or coarsely, to him: [as though they plundered him of his good name]. (A.)
3: see 1.
nAhb Alfarasu Alfarasa, inf. n. munaAhabapN, ‡ The [one] horse emulated, or contended with, the [other] horse in running. (TA: and agreeably with this the inf. n. is explained in the Ṣ and Ḳ.)

Used not only with reference to a horse. The Rájiz says,
naAhabotuhumo binayoTalK jaruwfi
[I emulated them, or contended with them, with a bucket that took up much water]. (Ṣ.) See also 6.

4. Anhb Alr-ajulu maAlahu (Ṣ) The man allowed, or gave, his property to be taken as spoil, plunder, or booty. (TA.) It is doubly trans.: you say Oanohabotu zabodFA AlmaAla [I allowed Zeyd to take the property as spoil]. (Mṣb.) See 1. Anhbhu fulaAnFA He offered it, or exposed it, to such a one, [to be taken as spoil]. (TA.)
6. tnAhb AlfarasaAni ‡ The two horses emulated, or contended with, each other. (TA.) See also 3.
tanaAhabaA AlmaMCa i. q. tajaAXaEaAhu, q. v. (TA, in art. jXE.)

tanaAhabati AlUibilu AlOaroDa ‡ The camels took much of the ground with their legs: (Ḳ:) [app. meaning, took wide strides over it: not, as rendered by Golius, “multum pulveris pedibus suis rapuerunt;” nor, as rendered by Freytag, “multum terræ pedibus abstulerunt”].

AlUibilu yanohabona Als-uraI, and yatanaAhabonahu, [The camels perform the night-journey with large strides]: and [in like manner] tnAhbti AlOaroDa. Camels that do so are termed UibilN nawaAhibu. (A.)
8: see 1.
Anthb Alfarasu AlX-awoTa ‡ The horse gained the winning-post; or won the race. (Ḳ, TA.)

hom.sense:
nahobN Spoil; plunder; booty; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also nuhobapN↓: (TA, art. xls:) ex. OataI lahu binahobK he came to him with, or brought to him, spoil: (TA:)
pl. nihaAbN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuhuwb: (Nh, &c.:) nuhobaI↓ also signifies the same; and thus is similar to nuHolaI, meaning EaTiy-apN: and also signifies what is allowed, or given, to be taken as spoil, plunder, or booty; and thus is similar to EumoraI and ruqobaI; (IAth;) and so nuhobapN↓ (Mṣb) [and nuhayobaI↓ and nuh-ayobaI↓:] a man, named Fizr, said of some goats which he drove forth, hiIa Aln-uh-ayobaI, or Aln-uhayobaI, accord. to different readings; meaning that it was not allowable to any one person to take of them more than one (TA:) or nahobN signifies what is taken as spoil, plunder, or booty; or so taken by whomsoever will, of what is allowed to be so taken: syn. maA Qnotuhiba: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) and nuhobaI↓, what is allowed to be so taken; syn. Uisomu maA Ounohiba: (Ṣ:) or what is taken as spoil, plunder, or booty; syn. Uisomu maA nuhiba. (So in one copy of the Ṣ.)
[Hence] nahobN An incursion made into an enemy's territory for the sake of acquiring spoil, plunder, or booty; and a spoiling, or plundering. (TA.)

OaHorazotu nahobiI waOabotagiI Aln-awaAfila, in a trad. of Aboo-Beker, means I have accomplished what I had to perform of the prayers termed Alwitoru before my sleeping, lest the occasion for my doing so should slip from me; and when I awake, I perform the prayers termed AlnwAfl. (TA.) [He termed the wtr prayers nahobN because he performed them before the right time.]
nahobN ‡ A kind of rakoD [i. e., app., of running, with reference to a horse]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: nuhobapN and nuhobaI↓ (Lḥ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nuhayobaI↓ and nuh-ayobaI (Ḳ) Spoil, plunder, or booty; a thing taken as spoil: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and also Spoliation; a taking of spoil, plunder, or booty: (Mgh:) substs. from nahaba: (Ḳ:) and substs. in the sense of AinotihaAbN: (Lḥ, Mgh:) nuhobaI↓ is explained in the Towsheeh as signifying the taking of a Muslim's property by force: it is said, [of Moḥammad,] in a trad., that he seattered some articles of property, and the people did not take them; so he asked them why they did not take; and they replied Oawalayosa qado nahayota Eani Aln-uhobaI [Hast thou not forbidden spoliation?]; but he said Uin-amaA nahayotu Eano nuhobaI AlEasaAkiri [I have only forbidden soldiers' spoliation]. (TA.) See nahobN.
nuhobaI: see nahobN and nuhobapN.
nuhayobaI: see nahobN and nuhobapN.
nuh-anobaI: see nahobN and nuhobapN.
UibilN nawaAhibu [pl. of naAhibN and naAhibahN]: see 6.
minohabN A horse that excels in running: (Ḳ:) and in like manner an ass. (TA.)
manohuwbN What is sought, or sought after, quickly: syn. maToluwbN muEaj-alN. (Ḳ.)

1. nahata, aor. _i {yanohitu}, [contr. to analogy,] inf. n. nahiytN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuhaAtN (Ḳ) He cried out, or uttered a cry: (TA:) [see UinohatiI EalayohaA voce bahata:] he uttered the kind of sound termed zaYiyr; [i. e., he (a lion, TA) uttered a sound from his chest; or roared:] (Ḳ:) or he uttered a sound lower than that which is termed zYyr: (Ṣ:) or he breathed hard; or emitted the voice, or the breath, with a moaning; i. q. zaHara, (Ḳ,) and TaHara: (TA:) or he uttered a sound from his chest on an occasion of distress. (TA.)

Aln-ah-aAtu and Alminohatu↓ and Almunohitu↓ (thus the last is written accord. to the Ḳ, but it occurs in a verse written Almunah-itu↓, TA, and in this latter manner it is written in the L,) The lion. (Ḳ.)
OasadN nah-aAtN, (Ṣ, L,) and munah-itN↓, (L,) [A lion uttering frequently a low growl]. (Ṣ, L.)
HimaArN nah-aAtN ‡ An ass that brays much, or frequently. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
rajulN nah-aAtN ‡ A man that breathes hard; or emits the voice, or the breath, with a moaning. (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) See muTal-iHN.
Aln-aAhitu The throat; the guttur: (Ḳ:) so called because the sound termed nahiyt proceeds from it. (TA.)
Alminohatu, and Almunohitu, and Almunah-itu: see Alnah-aAtu.

hom.sense: 1. nahaja, (Ḳ, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yanohaju}, inf. n. nuhuwjN; (Mṣb;) and Anhj↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) It (a road, or way, Ṣ and Mṣb, and an affair, TA,) became manifest, plainly apparent, or open; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb,) and so, with respect to a road, Astnhj↓. (Ḳ.)
nahaja, (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb,) and Anhj↓, (Ḳ, Mṣb,) He, or it, rendered (a road, Ṣ and Mṣb, and an affair, TA,) manifest, plainly apparent, or open: (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb:)
UiEomalo EalaI maA nahajotuhu laka Do according to that which I have made manifest to thee. (Ṣ.)
nahaja, aor. _a {yanohaju}, (inf. n. nahojN; TA,) and Anhj↓, It (attrition, TA) wore out, or rendered worn out, a garment. (Ḳ.)

nahija, aor. _a {yanohaju}; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and nahaja, (Ḳ,) but this is disallowed by AʼObeyd, (Ṣ,) and nahuja, and Anhj↓; (Ḳ;) It (a garment) became old and worn out: (Ḳ:) or Anhj↓ signifies it began to become warn out: (Ṣ:) and it became old and worn out, but without being rent in several parts. (TA.) Anhj fiyhi AlbilaI [The effect of] attrition spread through it. (IAạr.)
nahaja AlT-ariyqa He went along the road. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nahija, aor. _a {yanohaju}, inf. n. nahaju; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and nuhija, inf. n. nahojapN; (ISh;) this inf. n. also mentioned by Lth, who knew no verb belonging to it; (L;) and nahaja, aor. _i {yanohiju}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. nahiyjN; (L, in art. OnH;) and Anhj↓, inf. n. UinohaAjN; (L;) He was out of breath; breathed short, or unintermittedly; panted: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) by reason of violent motion: said of a man, and of a beast of carriage, (L,) and of a dog. (T.) One says, fulaAnN yanohaju fiI Aln-afasi famaA OadoriI maA Oanohajahu↓ Such a one is out of breath. or breathes short, or unintermittedly, or pants for breath, and I know not what hath caused him to be so, or to do so. And it is said in a trad., raOaI rajulFA yanohaju He saw a man breathing short, or unintermittedly, or panting for breath, by reason of fatness, and putting forth his tongue, from fatigue or the like. (Ṣ.)
4. Darabahu Hat-aI Anhj He beat him until he became stretched along: or, until he wept: (TA:) [but probably bkI “he wept” is a mistake for baliIa he became worn with the beating].

Anhj He, or it, caused him (a man, Ṣ, and a beast of carriage, TA) to be out of breath, or to breath short, or unintermittedly, or to pant for breath. (Ṣ, TA.) [See an ex. voce nahija.] He rode a beast of carriage so as to cause it, or until he caused it, to be out of breath,, &c., (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and to become fatigued, or jaded. (TA.)
See 1, throughout.

entry.sense: fulaAnN yasotanohiju sabiyla fulaAnK, (Ṣ.) or Tariyqa fulaAnK, (Ḳ.) Such a one follows the way of such a one. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

nahojN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nahjN↓ (L) and manohajN↓ and minohaAjN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A manifest, plainly apparent, or open, road, or way: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and so TariyqN naAhijapN↓: (TA, from a trad.:) pl. of the first nahojaAtN and nuhujN and nuhuwjN: (L:) [and of the third manaAhij].
TuruqN nahojahN Manifest roads, or ways. (L.)
And nahoju AlT-ariyqi [The plain, or open, track of the road]. (M, Ḳ, in art. sn.)
nahajN: see nahojN.
TariyqN naAhijapN: see nahojN.
manohajN and minohaAjN: see nahojN.

hom.sense: 1. nahada, aor. _u {yanohudu}, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and _a, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. nuhuwdN, (Ṣ, L, &c.,) It (a girl's or woman's breast) was, or became, swelling, prominent, or protuberant: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or became full. (Munjid of Kr.) [See also kaEaba, and faluka; and see also naAhidN.]
nahadato, aor. _u {yanohudu}, and _a; and nh-dt↓, (inf. n. tanohiydN, TA,) She (a woman [or girl]) came to have swelling, prominent, or protuberant, breasts. (L, Ḳ.)
nahadati Alqirobapu The skin became nearly full. (A.)
nahadati Ald-alowu AlmiloCa, inf. n. nahodN, The bucket became nearly full. (AʼObeyd, L, TA.)

nahada, (M, L, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanohadu}, (L,) inf. n. nuhuwdN, (M, L,) and nahodN, (L,) He (a man) rose; (M, L;) i. q. nahaDa; (Ḳ;) or the latter signifies “he rose from sitting;” whereas the former signifies “he rose under any circumstances.” (M, L.)
nahada lahu, (L,) and Uilayohi, (Th, L,) He rose to him. (Th, L.)

nahada liloEaduw-i, (AʼObeyd, L, Ḳ,) and UilaI AlEaduw-i, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yanohadu}, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) and _u, (Mṣb,) inf. n. nahodN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and nahadN, (Ḳ,) He attacked, or assaulted; or rose and hastened and went forth to, or towards, the enemy; (Ṣ,* L, Mṣb;) i. q. nahaDa: (Ṣ, L:) he directed his course towards the enemy, and commenced fighting with them. (AʼObeyd, L, Ḳ.)
nahada, (IḲṭṭ,) inf. n. nuhuwdN, (Ḳ,) It (a thing, IḲṭṭ) went, or went away, (maDaI,) in any case. (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ.)
nuhuwdN also signifies The being strong. (TA.)

nahuda, aor. _u {yanohudu}, inf. n. nuhuwdapN, He (a horse) was, or became, large and tall: (Ṣ, L:) or bulky and strong: or goodly in body and limbs, and tall: (L:) or goodly, large in body and limbs, fleshy and tall. (Ḳ.)
nahada, and Anhd↓, He honoured (EaZ-ama) a gift. (IḲṭṭ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, near the beginning.

hom.sense: 3. nAhdhu, inf. n. munaAhadapN, i. q. naAhaDahu; (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He attacked or assaulted him, or rose and hastened and went forth to or towards him, in war; he directed his course towards him, and commenced fighting with him. (M, L.)
nAhdhu, inf. n. munaAhadapN, He contended or disputed with him, in an absolute sense. (TA.)
naAhadahumo, [inf. n. munaAhadapN,] He contributed with them to the expenses of a journey or an expedition, clubbing with them, i. e. sharing equally with each of them. (L.) See also 6.

nAhdhu, inf. n. munaAhadapN, He played with him at the game in which one puts forth as many of his fingers as he pleases, and the other does the like; he played with him at the game of morra; the inf. n. expl. by musaAhamapN biAlOaSaAbiEi, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and muxaArajapN, q. v. (TA.)
4. Anhd He filled a tank or cistern, (Ṣ, L,) and a drinking-bowl, (A,) and a vessel, (L, Ḳ,) so that it overflowed: (L:) or nearly filled it. (A, L, Ḳ.)
naAqapN tunohidu AlUinaMCa A she-camel that fills the vessel [with her milk]. (IAạr, L.)
Anhdhu He made him, or it, to rise. (L.)
See 1.

entry.sense: 5. tnh-dt He sighed; breathed with an expression of pain, grief, or sorrow; or uttered a prolonged breathing. (TA.)

hom.sense: 6. tnAhdwA They attacked or assaulted one another, or rose and hastened and went forth to or towards one another, in war; they directed their courses one towards another, and commenced fighting. (A, Mṣb.)

tnAhdwA; (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Ḳ;) and nAhdwA↓, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. munaAhadapN; (Mṣb;) They clubbed, i. e. contributed equally to, the expenses which they had to incur, (Ṣ, Mgh, L, Ḳ,) on the occasion of a journey, (Ḳ,) or an expedition against an enemy; (L;) or contributed equal shares of food and drink: (ISd, L:) the first who instituted this practice is said to have been Hudeyn Er-Rakáshee: (TA:) or they contributed, each giving his share, for the purchase of wheat, or food, for their eating in common. (Mṣb.)
tnAhdwA AlX-aIoCa They took the thing and shared it between them. (L.)
tnAhdwA They played together the game of morra, described in one of the explanations of naAhadahu. (Ṣ, TA, art. xrj.)
nahodN A high, or elevated, thing: (L, Ḳ:) as a shoulder-joint, (L,) and a horse. (TA.)
A girl's or woman's breast: so called because of its prominence, or protuberance: (Mṣb:) [pl. nuhuwdN].
kaEovabN nahodN A pubes swelling forth, or prominent: opposed to hayodabN. (L.)
XaAb-N nahodN A strong, bulky, youth, or young man. (L, from a trad.)
nahodN A generous man, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) who aims at means of acquiring eminence, or nobility. (Ṣ.)
nahodN A horse large and tall: (Lth, Ṣ, L:) or bulky and strong: or goodly in body and limbs, and tall: (L:) or goodly, large in body and limbs, fleshy, and tall: (Ḳ:) fem. with p {nahodapN}. (L.)
nahodu AlqacaAli, and AlquSayoraI, A horse large and prominent in the back of the head, and, in the short ribs. (Lth, L.)
Aln-ahodu and Aln-aAhidu↓ The lion: (Ḳ:) from nuhuwdN in the sense of nuhuwDN and quw-apN. (TA.)
nahodN Aid; assistance. (L.) See nihodN.
TarHa nahodahu maEa Alqawomi He aided, or assisted, the people. (L.)
Also, He contributed with the people to the expenses of a journey or expedition, sharing equally with each of them. (L.) See also 3.
And see nahiydN.

entry.sense: nihodN (L, Ḳ) and sometimes nahodN↓, (Ḳ,) or the latter signifies the action described in the following explanation, (L,) A contribution, or that which is contributed, to the expenses of a journey, equally shared by each member of the party: (L, Ḳ:) or a contribution that is made for an expedition against an enemy, by a clubbing, i. e. an equal sharing of the expenses, so that there shall be no defrauding of one by another, and no obligation of one to another. (IAth, L.) See 3 and 6. You say, haAti nihodaka Give thou thy contribution to the expenses of the journey, or expedition, equally with thy companions. (L.)

nahodaAnu or nahodaAnN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) fem. nahodaI and nahodaAnapN, (L,) A tank or cistern, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and bowl, (Ṣ, A, L,) or vessel, (L, Ḳ,) full, but not yet overflowing: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or full so as to overflow: (L:) or nearly full: (A, L:) or filled high: (L:) or two-thirds fall. (Ḳ.)
nuhaAdu miAYapK The amount, or number, of a hundred. (Ḳ.)

nahiydN Fresh butter that is not thin: (Ṣ, L:) or thin butter: (Ḳ:) or fresh butter of which the milk has not been quite thick and fit for churning: or a large lump of fresh butter; as also nahiydapN↓ and nahodN↓: (L:) or nahiydapN↓ signifies fresh butter made of milk that has not become thick and fit for churning, and which is therefore little in quantity, and sweet: (AḤát, L:) or zubodapN nahiydapN fresh butter expressed from a skin by squeecing it. (L, art. zgd.)
nahiydapN: see nahiydN.
The hearts of the grains of colocynths, boiled until thoroughly cooked and thick, and then having a little flour sprinkled upon them, after which they are eaten. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)
naAhidN A girl's breast that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant: pl. nawaAhidu; which denotes more than fawaAliku. (AʼObeyd, L.)

Also, and naAhidapN↓ (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and munah-idN↓, (L, Ḳ,) or munah-idapN, (as in the TA,) A girl, or woman, having swelling, prominent, or protuberant, breasts: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or a woman whose breasts have become full: (Munjid of Kr:) pl. nawaAhidu. (Mṣb.)
naAhidN A boy nearly come to the age of puberty. (A.)
naAhidN Attacking or assaulting, or rising and hastening and going forth to or towards an enemy: pl. nuh-aAdN. (Mṣb.)
See nahodN.
naAhidapN: see naAhidN.

nahodaMCu [fem. of Oanohadu] An elevated sand, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) like a compact hill, fertile, producing trees: (L:) or a tract of ground such as is called nafoxaMCu, but more flat and extensive: (L, art. nfx:) it is used as an epithet; but not the masc. Oanohadu. (L.)
huwa Oanohadu Alqawomi He is the strongest and hardiest of the people. (R.)
munah-idN: see naAhidN.

hom.sense: 1. nahara, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yanoharu}, (Mṣb,) It (water) ran upon, or along, the ground, (Ṣ, TA,) and made for itself a nahor [or channel like that of a river]. (Ṣ.) See also 10.
It (anything, as in one copy of the Ṣ, or anything copious, as in another copy of the Ṣ and in the TA) ran, or flowed; (Ṣ, TA;) as also Astnhr↓, (Ṣ,) or Anthr↓. (TA.)
