It (blood) flowed with force: (Mṣb:) and Oanohara↓ it (blood) flowed (Ḳ, TA) like a river: (TA:) and the latter also, it (a vein) flowed and would not stop; (Ḳ, TA;) meaning, it flowed like a river; (TA;) as also Anthr↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA:) and Anhr↓ also signifies the same said of the belly; (TA;) or it (the belly) became loose, or relaxed; or it discharged itself; (JK;) as also Anthr↓. (JK, Ḳ.)
nahara, (Ṣ, Ḳ.) aor. _a {yanoharu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. nahorN, (TA,) He (a man, Ṣ) dug a nahor [or channel for a river]: (Ṣ, TA:) he made a nahor [or river] to run, or flow. (Ḳ, TA.)
nahra, inf. n. nahorN, He made an inroad or incursion, or inroads or incursions, into the territory or territories of enemies, in the day-time. (TA.)

naharahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. _a {yanoharu}, inf. n. nahorN; (TA;) and Anthrhu↓; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.;) He chid him; he checked him, restrained him, or forbade him, with rough speech; syn. zajarahu, (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or zabarahu, (as in another copy of the Ṣ,) bikalaAmK galiyZK: (Mgh:) be addressed him with chiding speech, (JK, A,) forbidding him from doing evil. (JK. [in the TA, citing the last explanation from the T, Eano xayorK is erroneously put for Eano Xar-K.]) It is said in the Ḳur, [xciii. 10,] waOam-aA Qls-aAYila falaA tanoharo [And as for the beggar, thou shalt not chide him, or address him with rough speech]. And in a trad., mani Qnotahara SaAHiba bidoEapK malaOa Qll-ehu qalobahu OamonFA wiUiymaAnFA waOam-anahu Qll-ehu mina AlfazaEi QloOakobar [Whoso chideth, or checketh with rough speech, the author of an innovation in religion, God will fill his heart with security and faith, and God will preserve him from the greatest terror]. (TA.)
4. Anhr: see 1. in three places.

‡ He made blood to flow: (Ṣ:) or to appear and flow: (Ḳ:) or to flow amply and copiously: (Mgh:) or to flow with force: (Mṣb:) or he poured it forth copiously. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Oanohiri Ald-ama bimaA XiYota Uil-aA maA kaAna mino sin-i Oawo ZufurK [Make thou the blood to flow,, &c., with what thou pleasest, except with what is made of a tooth or a talon.] (Mgh, Mṣb.) The issuing forth of the blood from the place of slaughter is likened to the flowing of water in a river. (TA.)
† He made it wide; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a spear-wound or the like, (Ṣ, TA,) or a nahor [or channel of a river], as is implied in the Ḳ, but in other lexicons as in the Ṣ. (TA.)
He was, or became, in day-time: (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA:) he entered upon day-time: (MṢ:) from Aln-ahaAru. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 8: see 1, in five places.
It (a river [in the CK Aln-ahora is put by mistake for Aln-ahoru]) took a place, (JK,) or a settle place, (Ḳ,) for its channel. (JK, Ḳ.)
It (a thing) became wide. (Ṣ.)

nahorN and naharN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) A channel in which water runs: (A, Ḳ:) so most say: or the water itself [that runs therein; i. e., a river; a rivulet; a brook; a canal of running water]: (TA:) or a wide channel in which water runs: originally, the water [that runs therein]: (Mgh:) or properly, wide running water: and by a secondary application, which is tropical. ‡ the trench or channel [in which it runs]: (Mṣb, TA *:) pl. [of pauc.] OanohurN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) a pl. of the former, (Mṣb,) and OanohaArN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a pl. of the latter, (Mṣb,) [but used as a pl. of either, both of pauc. and of mult. and the most common of all the pls.,] and nuhurN, (Mṣb, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) with two dammehs, a pl. of the former, (Mṣb,) or nuhorN, (as in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA,) and nuhuwrN, (IAạr, Ḳ.) You say, jaraI Aln-ahoru [The river ran, or flowed]; like as you say, jaraI AlmiyzaAbu. (Mṣb.) And nahorN kaviyr AlmaMCi [A channel of running water having much water]. (A.) And naharN↓ is also used in a pl. sense: as in the Ḳur, [liv. 54], fiI jan-aAtK wanaharK [In gardens and among rivers], i. e., OanohaAri; like the phrase in the Ḳur, [same chap. verse 45,] wayuwal-uwna Ald-ubora, (Fr, Ṣ.) meaning AlOadobaAra, (Fr, TA:) but it is otherwise explained. (Ṣ.) See naharN below.

hom.sense: naharN: see nahorN, in two places.

Amplitude: (Ḳ:) or light and amplitude: so, accord. to some, in the Ḳur, liv. 54, differently explained above: see nahorN, (Ṣ, TA.) or, accord. to Th, nahar is a pl. [or rather quasi pl.] of nuhurN, which is a pl. of nhaArN. (TA.)
nahirN Much, (TA;) as also nahyrN↓; (Ḳ, TA;) both applied to water. (TA.)
A wide nahor [or river, or channel in which water runs]. (Ḳ.)

raxulN nahirN A man of day-time; syn. SaAHibu nahaArK; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) who makes inroads or incursions into the territories of enemies therein: (Ṣ:) or who works therein: (A:) a kind of rel. n.; as is shown by the ex.
lasotu bilayoliI-K walekin-iI nhirN
laA Oudoliju All-ayola walekino Oabotakiro
[I am not one of the night-time, but I am one of the day-time; I do not journey in the night, but I go forth early in the morning]: as though he said nahaAriI-↓. (Sb.) The verse is correctly related as above; not as it is given in the Ṣ. (IB.)
See also Oanoharu.

entry.sense:
nahaArN Day; or day-time; contr. of layolN: (Ṣ, TA:) or broad daylight, (Mgh,) from sunrise to sunset: (Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) this is the original signification: (TA;) or this is the signification in the vulgar conventional language: but in the classical language it signifies the time from the rising of the dawn to sunset: (Mṣb:) or the light between the rising of the dawn and sunset: (Ḳ:) and so accord. to the lawyers: (TA:) in the trads., it is the whiteness of the nhAr, and the blackness of the lyl; and there is nothing intervening between the lyl and the nhAr: but sometimes the Arabs amplified, and applied nhAr to the time from the clear shining of the dawn to the setting [of the sun]: (Mṣb.) or (so accord. to the TA. but in some copies of the Ḳ, and) the spreading of the light [which is a cause] of sight and its dispersion: (Ḳ:) in this explanation in the L, in the place of waQfotiraAquhu we find waQjotimaAEuhu [and its collecting together]: (TA:) it is also syn. with yawomN; and is so when used without restriction in the non-fundamental sciences of religion, (AlfuruwE,) as in the phrases Sumo nahaArFA [fast thou a day] and UiEomalo nahaArFA [work thou a day]: and it may be so used, or in its proper classical sense, when prefixed to yawom, governing the latter in the gen. case: (Mṣb:) it has no proper dual, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and no proper pl., (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like EacaAbN and saraAbN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the former of which, however, has a pl. assigned to it [by Zj and] in the Ḳ, namely, OaEocibapN; (MF;) [and respecting the latter see XaraAbN, with X;] [for] nhAr is a name applied to every yawom [or day]; and layolN, to every layolap [or night]: one does not say nahaArN wanahaAraAni, nor layolN walayolaAni: but the sing. of nhAr is yawomN (TA.) and the dual, yawomaAni, (Mṣb, TA:) and the pl., Oay-aAmN. (Mṣb:) and the contr. of ywomN is layolapN, so says Az, on the authority of AHeyth: (TA:) or it has pls.: namely, OanohurN, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) a pl. of pauc., (Ṣ,) in some lexicons OanohirapN, (TA,) [also a pl. of pauc.,] and nuhurN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a pl. of mult. (Ṣ) [See also naharN.] Ibn-Keysán cites the following ex.,
lawolaA Alv-ariydaAn lamutonaA biAlD-umuro
variydu layolK wavriydN biAln-ahuro
[Were it not for the two thereeds (or messes of crumbled bread moistened with broth), we had died of leanness: the thereed of night, and thereed in the day-times]. (Ṣ.)
nahiyrN: see nahirN.
nahaAriI-N: see nahirN.
Food that is eaten in the beginning of the day. (TA.)
nahaArN Oanoharu, and nahrN↓, [A bright day:] in each of these phrases the epithet has an intensive effect, (Ḳ,* TA,) as the epithet in layolN Oaloyalu. (TA.)
manoharN The place of a river. (T, TA.)
A place which the water hollows out in a nahor [or channel of a river]. (Ḳ.)
A cleft, (Ḳ, TA,) or hole, (TA,) in a fortress, passing through [the wall], whence water runs. (Ḳ, TA,) or by which water enters: (TA:) pl. manaAhiru. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. nahaza, aor. _a {yanohazu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. nahozN, (Mṣb, TA,) He rose to take a thing with his extended hand. (Mṣb, JK, TA.) He took a thing with his extended hand. (JK, TA.) See also 3 and 8.
nahaza AlX-aIoCu The thing became near. (Ḳ.) See also 3, in two places.

3. nAhzhu, inf. n. munaAhazapN, He strove with him, or made haste, to outstrip him; to be, or get, before him; to precede him. (TA.) You say, nAhz AlS-ayoda He made haste to get before the game, or object of the chase, (Ḳ, TA,) and seized it before its escape. (TA.) And naAhazotuhumu AlfuraSa [I strove with them, or made haste, to be before them in taking, or seizing, the opportunities, or the turns for drawing water or the like]. (Ṣ, A.) A poet says,
naAhazotuhumo binayoTalK jaruwfi
[I strove with them, or made haste, to be before them in drawing water with a capacious bucket]. (Ṣ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He approached it; drew near to it; nearly attained to it; (Ḳ, TA;) as also nahazahu↓. (TA.) You say, nAhz Albuluwgu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and AlHuluma, (A, TA,) He (a boy, Ṣ, Mṣb) approached, drew near to, or nearly attained to, puberty. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) And nAhz Alxamosiyna [He approached, or nearly attained to, the age of fifty]. (A, TA.) And nAhz lilofiTaAmi, (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (Mṣb,) He (a child) approached, or drew near to, the [time of] weaning; (A, Mṣb;) as also nahaza lahu↓, (Mṣb, TA,) aor. _a {yanohazu}. (Mṣb.)
See also 8.

entry.sense: 6. tnAhzA They strove together, or made haste, each to be, or get, before the other. (Ḳ.) You say, humaA yatanaAhazaAni UimaArapa baladi kacaA They strive together, or make haste, each to be before the other in obtaining the government of such a town, or country. (Ṣ,* TA.) And tanaAhazuwA AlfuraSa [They strove together, or made haste, to be before one another in taking, or seizing, the opportunities, or the turns for drawing water or the like: see 3.] (A.)

8. Anthz AlfuroSapa He took, or seized, [or availed himself of,] the opportunity; syn. AigotanamahaA: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or he arose and hastened to be before another, or others, in taking, or seizing, the opportunity; or simply he hastened to take it. (Mṣb.) You say, AnotahizohaA qado Oamokanatoka qabola Alfawoti [Take thou, or seize thou, it; (meaning the opportunity;) for it hath become within thy power; before the escape thereof]. (TA.) And Ainotahizo faqado OaEoraDa laka [Take thou, or seize thou, the opportunity; for it hath offered itself to thee]. (A, TA.) Also, AnotahazahaA He took it, or them, [but to what the pronoun refers is not shown,] with his extended hand, from a near spot; and so naAhazahaA↓. (TA.) And Anthz AlX-aIoCa He accepted the thing, and hastened to take it with his extended hand. (TA.)
nuhozapN An opportunity; a time at which, or during which, a thing may be done or had; syn. furoSapN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

A thing that offers itself to one as a prey, or spoil. (JK, L.*) You say, fulaAnN nuhozapu Almuxotalisi [Such a one is the prey of the snatcher]; meaning, such a one is the prey of every one. (L.) And hecihi nuhozapN faQxotalisohaA [This is a thing that offers itself as a prey, therefore snatch thou it.] (A.)
naAhizN Approaching, or near, to the time of weaning; applied to a boy; (JK, Mṣb, TA;) and to a girl; (TA;) or the epithet applied to the latter is with p {naAhizapN}. (JK, Mṣb.)

1. nahasahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanohasu} (Mṣb, Ḳ, MṢ) and _i {yanohisu}; (Mṣb;) and nahisahu, aor. _a {yanohasu}; (Fr, Ḳ;) inf. n. nahosN (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and nuhosN; (TA;) He (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb) took it (namely flesh or flesh-meat) with his fore teeth, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) to eat it, (Mṣb,) and plucked it off; (A, Ḳ;) as also Anthshu↓: (Ṣ:) and he ate it off from a bone (taEar-aqahu) with his fore teeth: (Lḥ, TA:) or he pulled it off with the central incisors, to eat it: (TA:) and he took it with the fore part of his mouth; as also Anthshu↓: (A:) or he took it with his mouth: (IAth, TA:) or he took it with his mouth to bite it and make a mark upon it without wounding it: (TA, art. nhX:) and he (a dog, and any animal having a canine tooth,) bit it: or seized it, and then pulled it, or pulled it vehemently, or rent it with his teeth: but there is a difference of opinion respecting this verb in all its significations: some say that it is with the unpointed s; and thus, only, it is mentioned by ISk, who says, I heard El-Kilábee say, of a dog and of a wolf and of a serpent, Anthshu↓ and nahasahu; (Mṣb;) [and J says, the nahos of the serpent is the same as its nahoX;] (Ṣ;) you say nahasatohu AlHay-apu in the sense of nahaXatohu [the serpent bit him]: (Z, Ṣgh:) others say that the verbs are with s and X throughout; and thus says IF on the authority of Aṣ: Az cites Lth as saying that nahoXN, with the pointed X, signifies taking, or reaching, from a distance, like the nhX of the serpent; and nahosN, with the unpointed letter, the seizing upon flesh, or flesh-meat, and pulling it, or pulling it vehemently, or rending it with the teeth: Th says that the latter is with the extremities of the teeth; and the former, with the teeth [absolutely], and with [those that are termed] the OaDoraAs: IḲooṭ says, like Lth, that one says of the serpent (AlHay-ap), nahaXatohu, with the pointed X; and of the dog and wolf and hyena, nahasahu, with the unpointed letter. (Mṣb.)
8: see 1, in three places.
nuhuwsN: see nah-aAsN, in two places.
nahiysN: see manohuwsN, in two places.

nah-aAsN A dog that is wont to bite; (Mṣb;) and nahuwsN↓, applied to a she-camel, signifies the same; (TA;) and the latter, a lion that bites a thing when able to do so: (IKh:) or the former, a dog that is wont to seize, and then pull, or pull vehemently, or rend with his teeth. (Mṣb.)
A wolf. (TA.)
manohasN A place from which a thing [such as herbage, &c.] is taken with the mouth and eaten: (Ḳ,* TA:) pl. manaAhisu. (TA.) You say, OaroDN kaviyrapu AlmanaAhisi Land abounding in such places. (TA.)
minohasN: see nah-aAsN.

manohuwsN A man having little flesh; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) [as though it were partly eaten off the bones;] as also nahiysN↓. (TA.) You say also, manohuwsu Alqadamayoni, (A, Ḳ,) or AlkaEobayoni, (TA,) A man (TA) having little flesh upon the feet, (A,* Ḳ,* TA,) or upon the ankles. (TA.) And waZyfN nahiysN↓ [A shank of a quadruped] light of flesh. (TA.) See also manohuwXN.

1. nahaXahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yanohaXu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. nahoXN, (Ṣ,) i. q. nahasahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e. He took it with his mouth to bite it and make a mark upon it without wounding it: [&c.:] (TA:) or he took it (namely flesh or flesh-meat) with his fore teeth: (Ṣ:) and so accord. to some, AnthXhu↓. (Ṣ.) And It [a serpent or scorpion] bit him; or stung him; syn. lasaEahu: (Ḳ:) you say, nahaXatuhu AlHay-apu the serpent bit him. (Ṣ.) And He (a dog, TA) bit him, or it; (Ḳ;) as also nahasahu. (TA.) Or He took it with his [teeth that are called] OaSoraAs: whereas nahasahu signifies he took it with the extremities of the teeth: (Ḳ:) or nahoXN is less then nahosN; the latter signifying the taking, or reaching, with the mouth; but the former, the taking, or reaching, from a distance, like the nhX of the serpent. (Lth, TA.) [For other observations on these two verbs, see art. nhs.]
nahaXahu Ald-ahoru faQHotaAja (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ) ‡ Time, or fortune, bit him, so that he became in want. (TA.)
nahaXato wajohahaA She (a woman) seized the flesh of her face with her nails. (TA.)
nahaXahu also signifies † He, or it, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied him. (IAth.)

nuhiXa, inf. n. as above, † He became emaciated, or lean: and OunotuhiXato↓ OaEoDaAdunaA † our arms from the elbow upwards became emaciated: (TA:) and nuhiXato EaDudaAhu † his arms from the elbow upwards became slender, (ISh, Ḳ, [but in the CK duq-atA is put by mistake for daq-ataA]) and their flesh became little. (ISh.)
8: see 1, in the first and last sentences.
nahoXN: see manuhuwXN.
nahiXN: see manohuwXN, in five places.
As an epithet applied to a camel, i. q. namiXN, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) as explained in art. nmX. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
nahiyXN: see manohuwXN.

manohuwXN † A man harassed. distressed, fatigued, or wearied: (Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ:) ‡ bitten by time, or fortune, so as to be in want, (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) † and emaciated, or lean: or having little flesh, even if fat: or light; as also nahoXN↓ and nahiXN↓ and nahiyXN↓. (TA.) Applied to the pudendum muliebre, † Having little flesh; as also nahiXN↓. (TA.) And in like manner, manohuwXu Alfaxicayoni † Emaciated, or lean, in the thighs. (TA.) And manohuwXu Alqadamayon † A man having little flesh upon the feet. (IAạr, Ḳ.) And nahiXu↓ Alyadayoni ‡ A man, (TA,) or a beast of carriage, (Ṣ,) light in the arms, or fore legs; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as though from nahoXu↓ AlHay-api: (Ṣ:) and so nahiXu AlqawaAYimi↓ ‡ light in the legs, (Ḳ, TA,) in passing along, and having little flesh upon them; (TA;) as also nahiXu AlmuXaAXi↓. (Ṣ * TA.) [But see also muXaAXN.]
munotahiXapN A woman scratching her face in affairtion or misfortune. (Ḳ, TA.) Such Moḥammad cursed. (TA.)

1. nahaDa, aor. _a {yanohaDu}, inf. n. nuhuwDN (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nahoDN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) He rose, or stood up. syn. AirotafaEa, (Mṣb,) or qaAma, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Ḳ,) Eano makaAnihi from his place; (Mṣb;) as also AnthD↓, syn. qaAma: (IAạr:) or the former, he quitted a place: and he rose from it: (M, TA:) or he rose from sitting; thus differing from nahada, which signifies “he rose” under any circumstances: (M, L, in art. nhd:) [and he rose and went: or he rose and hastened, as shown below:] and AnthD↓, he was, or became, made, or excited, to rise, or stand up; quasi-pass. of OanohaDahu. (Ṣ.) You say, nahaDa Uilayohi He rose, or stood up, to him: (Mgh.) and liOamorK [to do, or perform, an affair] (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) And nahaDa UilaI AlEaduw-i He [rose and] sped, or hastened. to, or towards, the enemy. (Mṣb.) [See also nahada.] And nahaDonaA UilaI Alqawomi and nagaDonaA Uilayohimo [We rose and sped, or hastened, to. or towards, the people, or company of men:] both signify the same. (Abu-l-Jahm El-Jaafaree.) And AnthDwA↓ and tnAhDwA↓ signify the same as nahaDuwA liloqitaAli [They rose and sped, or hastened, to fight, or to the fight]. (TA.)
‡ It (a plant) stood erect; or became strong and erect. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

‡ It (a bird) spread, or expanded, its wings to fly. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.) You say, faroxN EaAjizu Aln-uhoD [A young bird lacking the power of spreading its wings to fly]. (A, TA.) [See an ex. in a verse of El-Hoteíäh cited in the first paragraph {1} of art. xlf.]

nahaDato nafosuhu (Ḳ in art. jXO., &c.) and nahaDato nafosuhu Uilayohi (Ṣ in the same art, and A in art. jhX, &c.) signify [the same. i. e.] jaXOato † [His said, or stomach, heaved,, &c.] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ. in the arts. above mentioned.)

nahaDa AlX-ayobu fiI AlX-abaAbi ‡ [Hoariness a rose in youth] (A, TA.) Aṣ cites the following verse from an anonymous poet:
tanotahiDu↓ Alor-iEodapu fiI ZuhayoriI
mino laduni AlZ-uhori UilaI AlEuSayori
† [Tremor arises in my little back from the time of noon to the little evening.]. (TA.)
3. nAhDhu, (Ṣ, A, &c.,) inf. n. munaAhaDapN, (TA,) He rose with him, or against him, and withstood him, or opposed him, in contention; syn. qaAwamahu; (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ;) namely his adversary. (A, Mgh.)

4. AnhDhu He made him, or excited him, to rise, or stand up. (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ, TA:) or he roused him. or put him in portion to rise. (TA.) You say also, UinotahaDotuhu↓ liloOamori, [if this be not a mistranscription for OanohaDotuhu,] I made him to rise to [do, or perform,] the affair. (Mṣb,) And AnhDhu EalaI AlX-aIoCi † He strengthened him to rise, and do, or perform, the thing. (TA.)
AnhD Alqirobapa: He nearly filled the water-skin [so as to make it rise]. (Ḳ. TA.)
OanohaDati Alr-iyHu Als-aHaAba ‡ The wind bore and drove along the cloud, or clouds. (TA.)

6. tnAhDwA fiI AlHarobi (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ) They rose, one with another, or one against another, and withstood, or opposed, one another. in war. or battle: (Mgh,) or each party of them rose and hastened (nahaDa) to, or towards, the other, in war. or battle. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) See also 1.

hom.sense: 8: see 1. in four places:
and see 4.

entry.sense: 10. AstnhDhu liOamori kacaA He ordered him, or commanded him, to rise to [do, or perform,] such an affair. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*) [And AstnhDhu fiI OamorK He sent him on an affair, to perform it.]

nahoDapN [inf. n. of un. of 1, A single act of rising,, &c.: and] a motion, or movement: pl. nahaDaAtN. (Mṣb.) You say, jaMCato minohu nahoDapN, (A, TA,) or kaAnato minohu nahoDapN, There was (a rising, or) a motion, or movement, on his part. (Mṣb,) limHal- kacaA [to such a place], (A TA,) or UilaI kacaA [to, or towards, such a thing]. (Mṣb.) And huwa kviyru Aln-ahaDaAti [He is a person of frequent risings, or motions or movements]. (A, TA.)
Also, † Power, or ability; and strength. (TA.)
nuhoDapN [The act of rising, or standing up: or the state of being made, or excited, to rise, or stand up] a subst. from AlUinotihaADu (TA.)
[One who frequently rises; or who frequently rises from, or quits, his place:] quick on motion. (Expos. of the Moʼallaḳát, printed at Calcutta, p 73)
huwa nah-aADN niheWulaMCi ‡ [app. He is wont to rise with these, for their assistance. see naAhiDapN]. (A, TA.)
huwa nah-ADN bibazolaMCa: see art. bzl.
naAhiDN [act. part. n. of 1, Rising, or standing up:, &c.].
† Energetic, sharp, vigorous, or effective in his agency, or work. (TA.)

‡ A young bird whose wings have became complete, (Ṣ, A, Mgh.,) or whose wing has became complete, (Ḳ,) and which has risen, (Ṣ,) or is able. (A, Mgh,) or ready, (Ḳ,) to fly: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ:) or that has spread its wings to fly: or that has raised itself to quit its place applied by some particularly to the young or the eagled. (TA.) pl. nawaAhiDu. (A, Mgh.) [See also EaAtiqN.]

naAhiDapu rajulK ‡ A man's people, (L,) or the sons of his father or ancestor, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) who rise for him, (O,) or with him. (Ḳ,) or with whom he rises, in a case that grieves him, (L,) or who are angry for him, (Ṣ,) or who are angry by reason of his anger, and rise to aid him: (TA:) and his people, (A,) or servants, (Ḳ,) or those, (Ṣ,) who undertake, or manage, his affairs: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or his aiders, or assistants. (A, in art. Zhr) You say, maA lifulaAni naAhiDapN ‡ Such a one has not any (Ṣ, A) people, (A,) or servants, (TA,) who undertake, or manage, his affairs. (Ṣ, A, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. naMCa, aor. yanuwoCu, inf. n. nawoCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and tanowaMCN, (Ḳ,) He rose, or arose, with effort and difficulty. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naMCa biHimolihi He rose with his burden with effort and difficulty. (TA:) he rose with his burden oppressed by its weight. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
tanuwoCubiEajiyzatihaA She rises with her buttocks oppressed by their weight: said of a woman. (Ṣ.)
naMCa biSadorihi He arose. [App. said originally, if not only, of a camel.] (TA.)
naACa bihi and AnAChu↓, It (a burden) oppressed him by its weight, and bent him, or weighed him down. (Ṣ, Ḳ,)
tanuwoCu bihaA EajiyzatuhaA Her buttocks oppress her by their weight: said of a woman. (Ṣ.)
naMCa He was oppressed by weight, (Ḳ,) and fell down: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) thus the verb bears two [partially] opposite significations. (Ḳ.)
naMCa bijaAnibihi † He behaved proudly. (TA, art. mT.)

naMCa Aln-ajomu, aor. yanuwoCu, inf. n. nawoCN; and AstnAC↓ and UisotanoOaI (Ḳ; the latter being formed by transposition, TA) The star, or asterism, [generally said of one of those composing the Mansions of the Moon,] set (accord. to some), or rose (accord. to others), aurorally, i. e. at dawn of morning. (TA.) See nawoCN. [It seems that nAC is used in both these senses because the star or asterism appears as though it were nearly overcome by the glimmer of the dawn.]
naMCa, (Ḳ,) formed by transposition from naOaI, (TA,) or a dial. form of this latter, (Ṣ, TA,) He, or it, was, or became, distant; removed to a distance; went far away. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nAC bihi [It rendered him distant, or removed him to a distance]. (TA.)
maA saMCaka wanaMCaka (Ṣ) [see explained in art. swO]: nACk is here used for OanaMCaka, in order to assimilate it to sACk; (Ṣ;) like as they say hanaOaniI wamaraOaniI, for OmoraOaniI. (TA.)

entry.sense: 3. nAwOhu, inf. n. munaAwaOapN and niwaMCN, He contended with him for glory; vied with him. (Ḳ.)
He acted hostilely towards him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Sometimes without C; but originally with C; being derived from naMCa Uilayoka and nuWotu Uilayohi. (Ṣ.)
4: see 1.

hom.sense: 10. AstnAC binajomK [He prognosticated rain, &c. by reason of the rising or setting of a star or an asterism aurorally, i. e., at dawn of morning: or he regarded a star or an asterism as a nawoC]. (L.) It is said, laA tasotaniYu AlEarabu biAln-uHuwmi kul-ihaA [The Arabs do not prognosticate rain, &c. by reason of the auroral rising or setting of all the stars, or asterisms: or do not regard all the stars or asterisms as OanowaA]. (Sh, L.) UisotanoOawoA AlwasomiI-a, the C being transposed, They expected, or looked for, the rain called AlwsmI, [from the auroral rising or setting of a star or an asterism]. (AḤn.)
UisotanaMCahu † He sought, or asked a gift, or present of him. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: nawoCN, pl. OanowaMCN and nuwMnN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A star, or an asterism, verging to setting: or the setting of the star, or asterism, in the west, aurorally, i. e., at dawn of morning, and the rising of another, opposite to it, at the same time, in the east: (Ḳ:) or the setting of one of the stars, or asterisms, which compose the Mansions [of the Moon (see manaAzilu Alqamari)], in the west, aurorally, i. e., at dawn of morining, and the rising of its raqiyb, which is another star, or asterism, opposite to it, at the same time, in the east, each night for a period of thirteen days: thus does each star, or asterism, of those Mansions, [one after another,] to the end of the year, except Aljabohap, the period of which is fourteen days: (Ṣ:) [or it signifies the auroral rising, and sometimes the auroral setting, of one of those stars, or asterisms; as will be shown below: I do not say “heliacal” rising because the rising here meant continues for a period of thirteen days]. Accord. to the T, nwC signifies the setting of one of the stars, or asterisms, above mentioned: and AḤn says, that it signifies its first setting in the morning, when the stars are about to disappear; which is when the whiteness of dawn diffuses itself. (TA.) AʼObeyd says, I have not heard nwC used in the sense of “setting,” “falling,” except in this instance. (Ṣ.) It is added, [whether on his or another's authority is doubtful,] that the [pagan] Arabs used to attribute the rains and winds and heat and cold to such of the stars, or asterisms, above mentioned as was setting at the time [aurorally]; or, accord. to Aṣ, to that which was rising in its ascendency [aurorally]; and used to say, muTironaA binawoCi kacaA [We have been given rain by such a nwC]; (Ṣ;) or they attributed heat [and cold] to the rising or the star or asterism, and rain [and wind], to its nawoC [meaning its setting]. (AḤn, Ḥar, p. 216.) This the Muslim is forbidden to say, unless he mean thereby, “We have been given rain at the period of such a nwC;” God having made it usual for rain to come at [certain of] the periods called AnwAC. Again, AʼObeyd says, The AnwAC are twenty-eight stars, or asterisms; sing. nwC: the rising of any one of them in the east [aurorally] is called nwC; and the star, or asterism, itself is hence thus called: but sometimes nwC signifies the setting. Also, in the L it is said, that each of the abovementioned stars, or asterisms, is called thus because, when that in the west sets, the opposite one rises; and this rising is called Aln-wC; but some make nwC to signify the setting; as if it bore contr. senses. (TA.) [El-Ḳazweenee mentions certain physical occurrences on the occasions of the AnwAC of the Mansions of the Moon; and in each of these cases, except three, the nwC is the rising, not the setting. Two of the excepted cases are doubtful: the passage relating to the third plainly expresses an event which happens at the period of the auroral setting of AlS-arofap; namely the commencement of the days called Oay-aAmu AlEajuwzi; corresponding, accord. to El-Makreezee, with the rising of Alfarogu Almuqad-amu, the rqyb of AlSrfp: and it is said in the Ṣ, art. Ejz, on the authority of Ibn-Kunáseh, that the Ay-Am AlEjwz fall at the period of the nwC of AlSrfp. (The auroral setting of AlSrfp, at the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, happened about the 9th of March O. Ṣ.; and this is the day of the N. Ṣ., the 26th of February O. Ṣ., on which commence the Ay-Am AlEjwz accord. to the modern Egyptian almanacs.) Hence it appears, that sometimes the setting, but generally the rising, was called the nwC. Moreover, the ancient Arabs had twenty-eight proverbial sayings (which are quoted in the Mir-át ez-Zemán, and in the work of El-Ḳazweenee) relating to the risings of the twenty-eight Mansions of the Moon: such as this: UicaA TalaEa AlX-araTaAno UisotawaI Alz-amaAno “When Esh-Sharatán rises, the season becomes temperate:” or, perhaps,]

[“the night and day, become equal.” (If this latter meaning could be proved to be the right one, we might infer that the Calendar of the Mansions of the Moon was in use more than twelve centuries B. c.; and that for this reason AlXrTAn was called the first of the mansions; though it may have been first so called at a later period as being the first Mansion in the first Sign of the Zodiac. But I return to the more immediate object which I had in view in mentioning the foregoing sayings.) I do not find any of these sayings (though others, I believe, do) relating to the settings. Hence, again, it appears most probable, that the rising, not the setting, was generally called nwC.]

[In many instances,] AlOanowaMCu signifies The Mansions of the Moon [themselves]; and nawoCN, any one of those Mansions: and they are also called nujuwmu AlmaTari [the stars, or asterisms, of rain]. (Mgh, in art. xTO.) IAạr says that the term nwC was not applied except in the case of a star, or asterism, accompanied by rain: (TA:) [see exs. under xaT-a and xaT-aOa: but most authors, it seems, apply this term without such restriction: it is sometimes given to certain stars or asterisms, which do not belong to the Mansions of the Moon; as will be seen below: and it is applied, with the article, especially to Alv-uray-aA].

Accord. to AZ, as cited by AM, the first rain is that called AlwasomiI-u: the AnwAC of which are those called AlEaroquwataAni AlmuWax-arataAn, the same, says AM, as Alfarogu AlmuWax-aru, [the 27th Mansion of the Moon, which, about the period of the commencement of the era of the Flight, (to which period, or thereabout, the calculation of AZ, here given, most probably relates,) set aurorally, (for by the term nwC AZ means a star or asterism, at the setting of which rain usually falls,) in central Arabia, on the 21st of Sept. O. Ṣ, as shewn in the observations on the mnAzl Alqmr in this lexicon]:
then, AlX-araTu, [one of the XaraTaAni, the 1st Mansion, which, about the period above mentioned, set aurorally on the 17th of Oct.]: then, Alv-uray-aA, [the 3rd Mansion, which, about that period, set on the 12th of Nov.]. Then comes the rain called AlX-atawiI-u: the AnwAC of which are AljawozaACu [meaning AlhaqoEapu, the 5th Mansion, which, about the period above mentioned, set aurorally on the 8th of Dec.] then, Alc-iraAEaAni, [i. e. Alc-iraAEu AlmaqobuwDapu and Ald-iraAEu AlmabosuwTapu; the former of which, about the same period, set anti-heliacally on the 3rd of January, the proper relative time of the setting of the 7th Mansion; and the latter, on the 16th of January, the proper relative time of the setting of the 8th Mansion;] and their navorap, [the 8th Mansion, which, about that period, set aurorally on the 16th of Jan.]: then, Aljabohapu, [the 10th Mansion, which set aurorally, about that period, on the 11th of Feb.] In this period the XtwI rain ends; and that called Ald-afaYiI-u (q. v.) begins, and [after this] AlS-ayofu. All the rains from the wsmI to the dfYI are called rabiyEN. Then, [after the dfYI,] comes the Sayof: the AnwAC of which are Als-imaAkaAni (AlOaEozalu and Alr-aqiybu); [the former of which is, accord. to El-Ḳazweenee, the 14th Mansion, which, about the period above mentioned, set aurorally on the 4th of April: the latter seems to be the rqyb of Alvry-A (see rqyb): i. e. AlUikoliylu, the 17th Mansion, which, about the same period, set aurorally on the 13th of May]; a period of about forty days. Then comes AlHamymu. [see this word, said by some to be] a period of about twenty nights, commencing at the [auroral] rising of Ald-abaraAn, [at the epoch of the Flight about the 26th of May, O. Ṣ.,] which has [little rain, or none, and is therefore said to have] no nwC. Then comes Alxaryfu [a period of little rain]: the AnwAC of which are Aln-asoraAni [or the two vultures, Aln-asoru AlwaAqiEu and Aln-asoru AlT-aAYiru, which, in central Arabia, about the period above mentioned, set aurorally on the 24th of July, O. Ṣ., both together]: then, AlxDr, [which I have not been able to identify with any known star or asterism, in the TT with SH written above it, to denote its being correctly transcribed]: then, AlEaroquwataAni AlOuwlayAni, the same says AM, as Alfarogu Almuqad-amu, [the 26th Mansion, which, about the same period, set on the 8th of Sept.]. (T, TT, TA.*)

[Hence,] nawoCN [also means † The supposed effect of a star or asterism so termed in bringing rain, &c.: whence the phrase laA nawoCa lahu It has no effect upon the weather; said of a particular star or asterism: see AlbuTayonu.]

[Also. Rain consequent upon the annual setting or rising of a star so termed † so in many instances in Ḳzw's account of the Mansions of the Moon.] And ‡ Herbs, or herbage: so called because regarded as the consequence of what is [more properly] termed nwC: [i. e., the auroral setting or rising of a star or asterism, or the rain supposed to be produced thereby.] Ex. jaf-u Aln-awoCu The herbage dried up. (IḲt.) Also, ‡ A gift, or present. (Ḳ.)

OanowaOu More, or most, acquainted with the OanowaMC (Ḳ, and some copies of the Ṣ) [See nawoCN, It is an anomalous word, though of a kind of which there are some other examples, for it has no verb] and, by only, a noun of this class is not formed but from a verb. (TA)
musotabaMCN † One of whom a gift, or present, is sought, or asked, (Ḳ.)
1. nubotuhu, aor. yanuwbu inf. n. nawobN; and Ainotabotuhu↓; I came to him by turns, (TA,)

AinonaAbahumo↓, inf. n. AinotiyaAbN, He came to them time after time, (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The Hudhalee (Aboo-Sahm Usámeh, TA,) says,
Oaqab-a TariydK binuzohi AlfalaApi
laA yaridu AlmaACa Uil-aA QnotiyaAbaA . (Ṣ) Slender in the belly, an object of the chase, in a part of the desert far from roster and pasture; he will not come to the water otherwise than time after time. The port is describing a wild ass. (IB.) Accord to one relation, the last word is AiYotiyaAbaA. meaning “coming by night.” (Ṣ,)
[Also, AntAb↓, app., He did a thing time after time; did a thing by turns. (See munotaAbN.)]
naAba, aor. yanowbu inf. n. nawobN, He drove camels early in the morning to the water, and was [again] at the water in the evening, going to it [thus] time after time (IAạr)

naAba UilaI Qll-eh; (Ḳ;) and AnAb Uilayohi↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UinaAbapN; (TA:) obedience He returned from disobedience to obedience to God, he returned unto God [repenting]: he repented; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the latter, he returned unto God; syn. rajaEa (Mṣb:) or nAb signifies he kept to obedience unto God: [this is given in the Ḳ as another and distinct signification of nAb:] and AnAb signifies as before explained or he returned to the performance of God, command; not departing from anything thereof: or be returned time after time: the In. signification, accord. to the Kesh-sháf and AḤei, is he entered upon the good turn. (TA, where for Alxyl read Alxyr.)

naAba Ean-iI, aor. yanuwbu, inf. n. nawobN and manaAbN (Ṣ, Ḳ: but the former inf. n. which is mentioned by Th, is omitted in some copies of the Ṣ) and niyaAbapN (Mṣb: [the only inf. n. there mentioned:] but this last, though also mentioned in the L, is rejected by Th and the other early authorities as not belonging to the classical language of the Arabs: TA) He supplied my place; served for me; acted in my place or stead, or as my substitute, lieutenant, deputy, factor, or agent; (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) fiI kacaA in such an affair. (Mṣb.)
naAba Eanohu [and naAba manaAbaha] It (a thing) supplied its (another thing's) place. (TA.)

naAbahu OamorN, aor. yanuwbu. (Ṣ.) inf. n. nawobN and nawobapN; (Ḳ, TA;) and UinotaAbahu↓; (Ṣ;) a thing, or an event, [generally a misfortune, or an evil accident,] befell him; betided him; happened to him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
3. nAwbhu, (inf. n. munaAwabapN, TA,) He did [or tock] a thing with him, each taking his turn: syn. EAqbh. (Ḳ.)
naAwabotuhu, inf. n. manaAwabapN i. q. saAhamotuhu [q. v., here signifying I shared with him: see 6]. (Mṣb.)

4. Oanabotuhu Eanohu. (Ḳ,) and Asotanabotuhu↓, (TA.) I made him to supply his [another's] place to act in him place or stead, or as his substitute, lieutenant, deputy, factor, or agent; (Ḳ, Mṣb;) fiI kacaA in such an affair. (Mṣb.)
See 1.
OataAniI fulaAnN famaA Oanabotu lahu Such a one came to me, and I cared not for him, or paid any regard to him. (A.)

6. tanaAwabonaA AlxaToba, and AlOamora, We performed the affair, or business, by turns; or turn after turn. (T.) humo yatanaAwbuwna Aln-awobapa fiymaA bayonahumo fiI AlmaACi wagayorihi [They took turns in the case of a thing that was between them; in the case of water, &c.] (Ṣ.)
tanaAwabuwA Ealayohi They did it by turns; this person doing it one time: and that, another. (Mṣb.)

tanaAwabuwA, as also tnAzlwA and tTAEmwA, They (a people on a journey) ate with or of the tent of, [meaning, of the food of.] this man on one occasion of alighting, and another man on another occasion of alighting; each one of them having his tarn to supply the food of one day. (ISh.)

tanaAwabawA EalaI AlmaACi, (Ḳ,) or tnAwbwA AlmACa, (L,) They shared the water among themselves [by turns] by means of the HaSaAp Alqasomi, (Ḳ,) or Almaqolpu: (L;) which is a pebble that is put into a vessel: then as much water as will come the pebble is poured into the vessel: this is done by persons on a journey when they have little water; and thus they divide it into shares. (Ḳ, arts. qsm and mql.)
AlmanaAyaA tatanaAwabunaA Deaths come to us by turns; to each of us in his turn. (TA.)
8: see 1.

hom.sense:
Aln-awobN What is a day's and a night's journey distant from one: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) what is a night's journey distant is called Alqarabu: originally in the case of going to water: (Ṣ:) or what is three days' journey distant: or what is two leagues (farosaxaAni) distant; or three. (TA.)
Lebeed says,
UiHodaI baniI jaEofarK kalifotu bihaA
lamo tumosi min-iI nawobFA walaA qarabaA
[I have become enamoured of one of the descendants of Jaạfar: she has not become a day's and a night's journey (or three days' journey or two eagues,) distant from me, nor a night's journey distant]. (Ṣ.) Or nwb signifies [in these words of the poet] near, so that he might visit her repeatedly; and qrb and nwb are synonymous: (IAạr:) or qrb [is used by him to signify that at such a distance] he might come to her once in three days. (AA.)
nawobN Strength: (Ḳ:) as also nawobpN↓: ex. OaSobaHota laA nawobapN laka Thou hast become without strength: and tarakotuhu laA nawobN lahu I left him without strength. (TA.)
nawobN Nearness. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nawobN a pl. (or rather a quasi. pl. n., TA) of naAYibN: (RA, Ḳ:) [but in what sense I do not find: app., as the act. part. n. of naAba “it befell, &c.”]

nubN Bees: pl. of naAYibN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) from nawobapN “a turn that falls to a man at a certain time,” accord. to Aṣ: or so called because they feed and return to their place: (Ṣ:) and if so, the sing. is nAYb: (TA:) or so called because they are of a colour inclining to black; (Ṣ, from AʼObeyd; or, as in some copies of the Ṣ, A'Obeydeh;) or as likened to the nation of negroes called Aln-uwbapu: and if so, the word has no sing. (TA.) See also luwbN.

Aln-uwbu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Aln-uwbapu↓ (Ṣ) [The Nubians;] a nation of the Negroes [or rather Ethiopians]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the latter is the name of their country; an extensive country south of Upper Egypt. (Ḳ, TA.)
nwbiI-N↓ [A Nubian;] an individual of the nation above mentioned. (Ṣ.) See luwbapN.
Oasowadu nuwbiI-N↓: see luwbiI-N.

entry.sense: nawobapN A turn which comes to one, or which one takes; the time at which, or during which, anything is, or is to be, done, or had, in succession; an opportunity: (Ṣ,* Ḳ, MF:) pl. nuwabN, (Ṣ,) which is extr. [with respect to analogy.] (TA.) See nawobN.

nawobapN and niyaAbapN↓ A coming to water, &c., one time, or turn, after a former time, or turn. This is the meaning of the words in the following phrases, mentioned [but not explained] in the Ṣ and Ḳ: jaACato nawobatuka and jACt niyaAbatuka, Thy time, or turn, to came to water, &c., in succession, has arrived: (TA:) pl. of the former word nuwabN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
nawobapN An assembly, a company, troop, or congregated body, of men. (Ḳ.)
nuwbapN: see nuwbN and naAYibapN.
niyaAbapN: see nawobahN.
xayorN naAYibN Abundant good, (Ḳ,) that comes again and again [by turns]. (A.)
Hum-aI naAYibapN A quotidian fever. (Ṣ.)
naAYibapN Guests coming time after time. (TA, from a trad.)
See nuwbN.
naAYibN One who supplies the place of another; who acts in his place or stead, or as his substitute, lieutenant, deputy, factor, or agent: pl. nuw-aAbN. (Mṣb.)

naAYibapN What befalls, betides, or happens, that is afflictive, distressing, difficult, or unfortunate: pl. nawaAYibu and nuwabN; the latter of which is extr.: (TA:) or rather this latter is pl. of nuwbapN, which is syn. with nAYbp, (MF,) a subst. from naAbahu OamorN, (Ṣ,) [and therefore signifying an accident, or a casualty, &c.; and as such this pl. is not extr., but analogous:] an evil accident; a misfortune; a disaster; a calamity; an affliction: pl. nawaAYibu: (Ṣ:) only signifying what is evil: (Mṣb:) or, accord. to some, an accident, whether good or evil: ex. Lebeed says,
nawaAYibu mino xayorK waXar-K kilaAhumaA
falaA Alxayoru mamoduwdN walaA AlX-ar-u laAzibu
[Accidents of a good nature, and of an evil, both of them; and neither is the good prolonged, nor the evil constant]: or what befalls, betides, or happens, to a man, of difficult, arduous, distressing, or afflictive, events, or affairs, and accidents: [a difficulty, or difficult affair] in a trad. respecting Kheyber it is said, qasamahaA nuSofayoni nuSofFA linawaAYibihi waHaAjaAtihi wanuSofFA bayona Almusolimiyna [He divided it into two halves; half for his own difficulties, or difficult affairs, and wants, and half among the Muslims]. (TA.)
manaAbN A road to water. (Ḳ.)
manaAbN ‡ i. q. marojiEN: ex. Uilayohi manaAbiI ‡ [To him is my recourse]. (A.)
munaAbN pass. part. n. of 4, A person made to supply another's place;, &c. (Mṣb.)

Oamoru munaAbN fiyhi An affair in which a person is made to supply another's place; in which a person is made to act in the place or stead of another person; or as another's substitute. (Mṣb.) See the verb.
manuwbN Eanohu A person whose place is supplied by another; in whose place or stead, or as whose substitute, another person acts. (Mṣb.)
OamorN manuwbN fiyhi An affair in which a person supplies the place of another; in which a person acts in the place or stead of another, or as another's substitute. (Mṣb.) See the verb.
muniybN, from AnAb AlI Qll-eh, Repenting,, &c. (TA.)
muniybN act. part. n. of 4, A person making another to supply his or another's place;, &c. (Mṣb.)
See the verb.

muniybN Copious rain: and good rain, of the [rain termed] rabiyEN: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to En-Naḍr Ibn-Shumeyl, copious rain (maTarN jawodN) is termed mnyb: and you say, OaSaAbanaA rabiyEu SidoqK mnybN [There fell upon us an excellent, copious rain, of such as is termed rbyE; meaning] good rain, but inferior to what is termed jwd; but this is an excellent rain if followed by other rain. (TA.)
munotaAbN act. part. n. of 8.
[Coming by turns:, &c.]
Visiting. (RA.)
Doing a thing time after time: doing a thing by turns. (TA.)

1. naAta, aor. yanuwtu, inf. n. nawotN, He (a man) moved from side to side in walking; as also naAta, aor. yaniytu: (L:) or he so moved by reason of weakness, or infirmity: (Ḳ:) or, by reason of drowsiness, like as the sailor turns the vessel from side to side. (L.)
naAtN i. q. naAsN Mankind; or men: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like OakoyaAtN for OakoyaAsN; the s being changed into t [see art. s], accord. to the dial. of certain of the Arabs; as related by Az. (Ṣ.)

nuwtiI-N [and naw-aAtN↓] A sailor upon the sea, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) who turns about the ship in the sea: (TA:) pl. of the former nawaAtiI-u, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [and of the latter] naw-aAtuwna. (TA.) Accord. to J, from the language of the people of Syria: accord. to others, an arabicized word [from the Greek ναύτης]. (TA.)
naw-aAtN: see nuwtiI-N.
nawovapN i. q. HamoqapN. (L.)

1. naAHati AlmaroOapu, aor. tanuwHu, inf. n. nawoHN and niyaAHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and nuwaAHN, (L, Ḳ,) or this is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and niyaAHapN, (A, L, Ḳ,) or this also is a simple subst., (Ṣ, Mṣb, [and as such it is also mentioned in the Ḳ,]) and manaAHN (Ḳ) and manaAHapN, (L,) [The woman wailed]. You say naAHato EalaI Almay-iti, (Mṣb,) and EalaI zawojihaA, and naAHatohu, (L, Ḳ,) but nAHt Ealayohi is preferred, (TA,) [She wailed for, or bewailed, the dead, and, her husband]. Also, naAHa ElI Almy-t. (A.) naAHa and AstnAH↓ are syn. (L, Ḳ.) [In the Ṣ it is implied that it is tropical: see naAYiHap: but in the A it is said to be proper.]
naAHati AlHamaAmapu, (L,) inf. n. nawoHN, (L, Ḳ,) The pigeon cooed (L, Ḳ) in a plaintive or wailing manner. (L.) Some say that this is tropical; but most, that it is proper. (MF.)
AlT-ayoru tanuwHu [The birds warble plaintively.] (A.)
3. nAwH baEoDuhaA baEoDFA One of them was opposite to, or faced, another. Said of mountains, and in like manner of winds. (Ṣ, L.)
5. tnw-H It (a thing) moved about, hanging down; it dangled. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
6. AlT-ayoru tatanaAwaHu [The birds warble plaintively, one to another]. (A.) See an ex. in art. fwH, conj. 6.
tnAwHti Alr-iyaAHu The winds blew violently [as is generally the case when they blow from opposite directions]. (TA.) See an ex. voce shw.
tnAwHA They two were opposite, one to the other; they faced each other. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say so of two mountains, and of two winds. (Ṣ, L.)
AstnAH He (a wolf) howled, (L, Ḳ,) and was listened to and followed by other wolves. (L.)
He (a man) wept and induced another, or others, to weep: (Ḳ:) or he wept so as to induce another, or others, to weep. (L.)
nawoHN: see naAYiHapN.
nawoHapN and nayoHapN↓ Strength; force. (L.)
nayoHapN: see nawoHapN.
nuwaAHN: see niyaAHapN.
niyaAHapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and nuwaAHN↓ (Mṣb) substs. from naAHati AlmaroOapu, q. v. [A wailing, or bewailing a dead person].
nuw-aHN: see naAYiHapN.
nay-iHapu riyHK OuxoraI A counterwind, or wind which is the opposite, of another wind. (Ṣ, A. L.) One that blows transversely with respect to another is called the nasiyjap of the latter. (Ṣ, L.)
naw-aAHapN: see nAYiHapN.
Aln-awaAHiI: see naAYiHapN.

naAYiHapN [A wailing woman]: (Mṣb:) pl. nawaAYiHu and naAYiHaAtN: and you also say nisaMCN nawoHN↓, and OanowaAHN, and nuw-aHN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) nawaAYiHu is an epithet applied to women who assemble in a manaAHap: and manaAHapN↓ (also) and nawoHN↓ signify women who assemble together for the purpose of mourning. (L.) nawaAYiHu are so called from Alt-anaAwuH, signifying “the being opposite, one to another:” (Ṣ:) [if so, it is app. a tropical term: but accord. to the A, AltnAwH, as above explained, is tropical]. Also naw-aAHapN↓ [A woman who wails much, or frequently; who is in the habit of wailing: a professional wailing woman]. Ex. hiIa naw-aAHapu baniI fulaAnK [She is the professional wailing woman of the sons of such a one]. (A.)
HamaAmapN naAYiHapN. and naw-aAHapN↓, A pigeon that cooes in a plaintive or wailing manner. (L.)
nawaAYiHu also signifies Standards, or ensigns, opposite one to another, in battle. (L.)
Also, Swords. In this sense, it occurs written Aln-awaAHiI↓, by transposition. (Ks, L.)
A place of nawoH [or wailing for a dead person]: (Mṣb:) pl. manaAHaAtN and manaAwiHu. (A, L.) Ex. kun-aA fiI manaAHapi fulaAnK [We were in the place of wailing of, or for, such a one]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See naAYiHapN.

The winds called Aln-ukobu: [see nakobaMCu:] so called because they are opposite, one to another: they blow in times of drought, when rains are scanty, and when the air is dry, and the cold severe. (L.)
1. nAxa: see 10.

2. naw-axa Qll-ehu AlOaroDa TaruwqapF lilomaMCi † God made, or may God make, the land capable of receiving the water [of the rain so as to be impregnated, or fertilized, or soaked, thereby]: expl. by jaEalahaA mim-aA tuTiyquhu. (Ṣ.)
See 4.

4. AnAx (Ṣ, L, Mṣb) and nw-x↓ (L, Mṣb) He (a man) made a camel to lie down upon his breast [with his legs folded, as is done on the occasions of mounting and dismounting, &c.] (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.) Also tnw-x↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and AnAx (Ḳ) and AstnAx↓ (L) He (a stallion-camel) made a she-camel to do so in order that he might cover her: (Ṣ, Ḳ.) or made her do so and then covered her. (L.)
AnAx bihi AlbalaMCu waAlc-ul-u ‡ [Trial, or affliction, and abasement, befell him]. (A.)
5: see 4.
and 10.

Also, AstnAx (Ṣ, L, Mṣb) and tnw-x↓ (L, Mṣb) He (a camel) lay down upon his breast [with his legs folded]. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.) Also, AstnAxt and tnw-xt↓ She (a camel) did so in order to be covered by the stallion. (Ḳ.) It is said that one should not use, in the sense of the quasi-pass. of the trans. v. AnAx, the form naAxa↓, nor AnAx↓: (Mṣb:) but the authors on verbs mention AnAx in a neuter sense; and IAạr says, that one says AnAx, but not nAx: (MF:) or IAạr says, tnw-x↓ AlbaEiyru, but not nAx nor AnAx: (L:) [and F says, that] one should not say, in the sense of AstnAxt and tnw-xt↓ as explained above, either nAxt or AnAxt. (Ḳ.)
nawoxapN A remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling, in a place. (L, Ḳ.)
naAYixapN A distant land: (Ḳ:) or it is [correctly] naAYixapN, with b. (TA.)
manaAxN: see munaAxN.

munaAxN A place in which camels are made to lie down upon their breasts, [with their legs folded]; (Mṣb:) a place where they so lie; (Ḳ;) a nightly resting-place of camels. (Mṣb, voce muraAHN) to a trad. in which it occurs, accord to one relation it is manaAxN↓. (TA.)
Also, A time at which camels so lie. (MF.)
Also, pass. part. n. of AnAx; and used as an inf. n. of that verb, like UinaAxapN. (MF.)
hecaA munaAxu sawoCK ‡ This is a disagreeable place. (A.)
Almuniyxu The lion. (Ḳ)

hom.sense: 1. naAra intrans., in the sense of OanaAra: see the latter, in two places.
naAruwA Aln-aAra: see 5.
nurotu AlbaEiyra ‡ I made a mark upon the camel with a hot iron. (M, Ḳ.) See naArN.
2. nw-r, intrans., in the sense of OanaAra, from Aln-uwru: see 4, in two places.

nw-r biAlfajori, (Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. tanowiyrN, (Mṣb,) He performed the prayer of daybreak when the dawn had become light (Mgh, Mṣb:) ‡ or when the horizon had become bright: (TA:) tanowiyru Alfajori, without bi is an amplification. (Mgh.) tanowiyrN as a subst. from this verb, see below.
nw-r, trans. in the sense of OanaAra, from Aln-uwru: see 4. in three places.

nw-r, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) inf. n. tanowiyrN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) It (a tree. Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, and a plant, Mṣb) blossomed, or flowered it put forth its nawor; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also OanaAra↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) originally Oanowara, (TA,) See also 4.
It (seed-produce) attained to maturity: (Ḳ:) [see an ex. in a verse cited in art. smw, conj. 3:] tanowiyrN, the inf. n. of the verb in this sense, has a pl. tanaAwiyru. (TA.)
nw-rhu He smeared him or it with nuwrap. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
nw-r ciraAEahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanowiyrN, (TA,) He pricked his fore-arm with a needle, and then sprinkled nawuwr, [q. v.] upon it. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

4. AnAr, (inf. n. UinaArapN, Mṣb,) It (a thing) (Ṣ, Mṣb) gave light; or shone; or shone brightly; (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as also nw-r↓, (Lḥ, Ṣ,* A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanowiyrN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and AstnAr↓; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and naAra↓, (A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yanuwru, (Mṣb,) inf. n. naworN, (Ḳ, TA,) or nuwrN, (as in a copy of the A,) or niyaArN: (Mṣb;) and tnw-r↓: (Ḳ:) nw-r (Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and AnAr (Mgh, Mṣb) and AstnAr, (Mṣb,) said of the dawn, signify as above; (Mgh, Mṣb;) or its light appeared. (Ṣ,* Ḳ)
[Hence,] naArati↓ Alfitonapu, aor. tanuwru, Sedition, or discord, or the like, happened and spread. (Mṣb.)

[Hence also,] AnAr and Oanowara, (Ḳ.) the latter being the original form; said of a plant; (TA;) It became beautiful: and it became apparent. (Ḳ, TA.) And Oanowarati AlX-ajarapu The tree became beautiful in its verdure: or, as some say, put forth its blossoms or flowers. (TA.) See also 2.

AnAr and nw-r↓ He made to give light; to shine; or to shine brightly. (Mṣb.) Alt-anowiyru↓ and AlUinaArapu signify the same. (Ṣ.) You say, AnAr Als-iraAja, and nw-rhu↓, (A,) and nw-r↓ AlmiSobaAHa, (Mṣb,) He made the lamp to give light; or to become bright. (Mṣb.)
AnAr AlmakaAna He illumined, or lighted, the place; (Ḳ;) i. e., put light [or a light] in it. (TA.)
[Hence,] AnArhu ‡ He elucidated it; rendered it apparent or plainly apparent, conspicuous, manifest, or evident; (TA;) as also nwr-hu↓. (A, TA.*)
And hence, AnAr Qll-ehu burohaAnahu ‡ God taught him, or dictated to him, his proof. (TA.) 7:17 AM 30/01/035: see 4, first signification.

tnwr-wA Aln-aAra mino biEiydK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and naAruwhaA↓, (Ḳ,) They looked at the fire, or endeavoured to see it (tabaS-aruwhaA,) from afar: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or tnw-r Aln-aAra he looked at the fire, or endeavoured to see it, (tabaS-arahaA) and repaired towards it: (A:) or he came to the fire: it has this signification as well as the first. (TA.)

tnw-r Alr-ajula, and AlmaroOapa, He looked at the man, and the woman, at or by a fire, from a place where the latter did not see him; he stood in the dark to see the man, and the woman, by the light of the latter's fire, without the latter's seeing him; tanaw-urN being like taDaw-uWN. (TA.)
See also 8.
10: see 4, first signification.
AstnAr bihi He sought the aid of its light: (TA:) or of its rays. (M, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: naArN a word of which the meaning is well known; (M, Ḳ;) [Fire; not well explained as signifying] the flaming, or blazing, (lahiyb,) that is apparent to the sense: (TA:) its A is originally nuwayorapN: (Ṣ, TA:) it is fem.: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb:) and sometimes masc.: (AḤn, M, Ḳ:) and the dim. is OanowaArN, with w because it is the original medial radical, (Ṣ,) and with p {naArapN} because nAr is fem.: (Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] OanowurN, (Ṣ, M, L,) in the Ḳ OanowaArN, [which is a mistake, though this is also said to be a pl. of nAr,] (TA,) and [of mult.] niyraAnN [which is the most common form] (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and nuwrN (AAF, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and niyarapN and niyaArN, (M, Ḳ,) and OanoyaArN also occurs, in the phrase naAru AlOanoyaAri, in a trad. respecting the prison of hell; this phrase, if correctly related, perhaps meaning naAru Aln-iyiraAni, and AnyAr being originally OanowaAr. (IAth.) Aln-aAru is also applied to The fire of hell. (TA:) The Arabs say, in cursing their enemies, OaboEada Qll-ehu daArahumo waOawoqada naArFA Oavarahumo [May God make their abode distant, and kindle a fire after them!] And it was a custom of Arab women, as related by IAạr, on the authority of El-'Okeyleeyeh, when they feared evil from a man, and he removed from them, to kindle a fire behind him, with the view of causing his evil to depart with him. (T.)

naAru Qlomuhaw-ili A fire which the Arabs used to kindle, in the time of ignorance, on the occasion of entering into a confederacy: they threw into it some salt, which crackled (yufaq-iEu) when the fire burned it: with this they frightened [one another] in confirmation of the swearing. (T.)
naAru AlHubaAHibi has been explained in art. Hb.
naArN also signifies simply Heat. (TA.)
Also, ‡ [The fire, meaning] the evil, and excitement, or rage, or war; as also naAYirapN↓. (TA.) You say, Oawoqada naAra AlHarobi ‡ [He kindled the fire of war]. (A.)

Also, ‡ Opinion; counsel; advice. (IAạr, T, Ḳ.) So in the trad., laA tasotaDiyWuwA binaAri AlmuXorikiyna, (T,) or bnAr Oaholi AlX-iroki, (Ḳ,) ‡ [Seek ye not to enlighten yourselves by the counsel of the polytheists; i. e.,] seek ye not counsel of the polytheists. (IAạr, T, A.*)

Also, ‡ Any brand, or mark, made with a hot iron, upon a camel; (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also nuwrapN↓ (M, Ḳ) and nuwrN↓: (TA:) pl. as above: (M:) or the pl. is niyaArN, and the pl. of the nAr that burns is niyraAnN. (IAạr, Th, T.) The Arabs say, maA naAru hecihi Aln-aAqapi ‡ What is the brand, or mark, of this she-camel, with which she is burned? (T, Ṣ, A.*) And they say, in a proverb, bijaAruhaA naAruhaA (T, Ṣ) Their origin is indicated by their mark with which they are burned. (T.) The Rájiz says,
Hat-aI saqawoA MbaAlahumo biAln-aAri
waAln-aAru qado taXofiI mina AlOuwaAri
[Until, or so that, they watered their camels because of the brand that they bore: for the fire, or the brand, sometimes cures of the heat of thirst]: (T, Ṣ:*) he means, that, when they saw their marks with which they were burned, they left the water to them. (Ṣ. For another reading of this verse, see bi.) See also najorN.

naworN Blossoms, or flowers, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a tree, and of a plant: (Mṣb:) or white blossoms or flowers; the yellow being called zahorN; (M, Ḳ;) for they become white, and then become yellow: (M:) and naworapN↓ and nuw-aArN↓ signify the same as naworN: (M, Ḳ:) or [rather] naworN and nuw-aArN signify the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) [but the former is often used as a generic n., signifying a kind of blossom or flower: though both are coll. gen. ns.;] and naworapN is the n. un. of naworN, like as tamorapN is of tamorN; (Mṣb;) and nuw-aArapN is the n. un. of nuw-aArN: (Ṣ, M, L:) and the pl. of naworN is OanowaArN. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

nuwrN Light; syn. DiyaMCN, (Ṣ,) or DawoCN; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) whatever it be; (M, A, Ḳ;) contr. of ZulomapN: (Mṣb:) or the rays thereof: (M, A, Ḳ:) accord to Z, DiyaMCN [with which DawoCN is syn.] is more intense than nuwrN: in the Ḳur, x. 5, the sun is termed DyAC, and the moon nwr: and it is said that DyAC is essential, but nwr is accidental [light]: (TA:) it is of two kinds, the light of the present world and that of the world to come; and the former is either perceived sensibly, by the eye, and this is what diffuses itself from luminous bodies, as the sun and moon and stars, and is mentioned in the Ḳur, x. 5, referred to above; or perceived by the eye of the intellect, and this is what diffuses itself of the divine lights, as the light of reason and the light of the Ḳur-án; of which divine light mention is made in the Ḳur, v., former part of verse 18, and xxiv., latter part of verse 35; and both of these in common are spoken of in the Ḳur, vi. 1 and xxxix. 69: that of the world to come is mentioned in the Ḳur in lvii. 12 [and lxvi. 8]: (B:) the pl. is OanowaArN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and niyraAnN; (M, Ḳ;) the latter mentioned by Th: (M:) and naworaAny-apN↓ signifies the same as nuwrN. (TA.) As nwr is a convenience of the pious in the present world and the world to come, it is said in the Ḳur, [lvii. 13,] AunoZuruwnaA naqotabiso mino nuwrikumo [Wait ye for us that we may take of your light]. (B.) [See also ZulamopN.]
It is also applied to Moḥammad: (T, M, Ḳ:) it is said by Aboo-Is-hak to be so applied in the Ḳur, v. 18. (T.)

And That which manifests things, (Ḳ, TA,) and shows to the eyes their true or real state: and therefore Aln-uwr is applied in the Ḳur, vii. 156, to ‡ that [revelation] which the Prophet brought. (TA.)

Aln-uwru is also one of the names of God; meaning, accord. to IAth, He by whose light the obscure in perception sees, and by whose guidance the erring is directed aright: or the Manifest, by whom is every manifestation. And Oall-ehu nuwru Als-amewaAti waQloOaroDi [in the Ḳur, xxiv. 35,] means God is the enlightener of the heavens and of the earth: like as fulaAnN giyaAvunaA means mugiyvunaA: (TA:) or, as some say, the right director of the inhabitants of the heavens and of the inhabitants of the earth. (T.)
See also naArN, last signification.
naworapN: see naworN.

hom.sense: nuwrapN: see naArN, last signification.

I. q. hinaMCN [a word well known to mean Tar, or liquid pitch, or a kind thereof; but I do not know this signification as applying to nuwrapN, nor, app., did SM, for he has made it to be the same with that which here next follows, from the T]. (M, Ḳ:) or a kind of stone burned and made into kilos [or quick-lime] and used as a depilatory for the pubes: (T:) or lime-stone; syn. Hajaru Alkilosi: and by a secondary and predominant application, a mixture of quick lime (kls) with arsenic, or orpiment, (zironiyx,) and other things, used for removing hair: (Mṣb:) [a depilatory composed of quick lime with a small proportion (about an eighth part) of orpiment: it is made into a paste with water, before application; and loosens the hair in about two minutes; after which it is immediately washed off: thus made in the present day:] some say that it is an Arabic word; and others, that it is arabicized. (Mṣb) See 8.

entry.sense: naworaAniy-apN: see nuwrN.
nay-irN Giving light, shining, bright, or shining brightly; (A, Mṣb;) as also muniyrN↓ and musotaniyrN↓ (A) [and naAYirN↓.]

Beautiful in colour, and bright; as also muniyrN↓ and Oanowaru↓: (TA:) or the last signifies [simply] beautiful; (Ḳ;) or conspicuous and beautiful. (TA.) It is said of Moḥammad. kaAna Oanowara↓ Almutajar-adi: He was beautiful and bright in the colour [of what was unclad] of his body. (TA.)

nawuwrN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or naWuwrN, (T, M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or both, the former being the original form, (Ṣ, TA,) i. q. niylajN [i. e. Indigo-pigment]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or niylanojN; [which appears from what follows to be the right reading, though both nylj and nylnj are used in the present day for the purpose described in explanations of nwwr, to give a greenish colour to the marks made in tatooing;] (Mṣb;) i. e., (so accord. to the Ṣ and Mṣb; but in the Ḳ, and) the smoke [meaning the smokeblack] of fat, (IAạr, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) that adheres to the Tasot, (IAạr, T,) with which the punctures made in tatooing are dressed, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or filled in, (M,) that they may become green; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) or with which the women of the Arabs of the time of ignorance tattooed themselves: (T:) i. q. gunojN [q v.]; (IAạr, T:) or, accord. to to Lth, the smoke [or smoke-black] of the wick, used as a collyrium or for tatooing; but, [says Az,] I have not heard that the women of the Arabs used this as a collyrium in the time of ignorance nor in the time of El-Islám; their using it for tatooing, however, is mentioned in their poems: (T:) or lamp-black; the black pigment (niqos) prepared from the smoke of the lamp; used for tattooing. (Comm. on the Moʼallaḳát, printed at Calcutta, p. 143.)

Also, A kind of small stone, resembling Uivomid, which is bruised, or brayed, and then taken up, like as medicine is by the lip. (M.) [The same is found in the Ḳ, excepting that, in this latter lexicon, the explanation is less full, and All-ivapu is substituted for AlX-afapu, the reading in the M.]
nuw-aArN and nuw-aArapN: see naworN.

hom.sense: naAYirN: see nay-irN.
‡ Apparent or plainly apparent. conspicuous, manifest, or evident; as also muniyrN↓. (Thus the pl. fem. of each of these is explained in the TA.)
fitonapN naAYirapN Sedition, or discord, or the like, happening and spreading. (Mṣb.)

And naAYirapN alone, Sedition, or discord, or the like: (Mṣb:) or sedition, or discord, or the like, happening: (TA:) and rancour, malevolence, or spite. (T:) enmity, or hostility, (T, Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and violent hatred. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) See also naArN. You say, saEayotu fiI UiTofaMCi Aln-aAYirapi I laboured in stilling the sedition, or discord, or the like. (Mṣb.) And bayonahumo naAYirapN Between them is enmity, or hatred, and violent hatred. (A, Mṣb.)
One who occasions evils among men. (T.)

entry.sense: Oanowaru: see nay-irN, in two places.
caA Oanowaru mino caAka [This is lighter, or brighter, than that], (TA.)

tanowiyrN The time when the dawn shines, or becomes light. (T, Mgh.) You say, Sal-aI Alfajora fiI Alt-anowiyri He performed the prayer of daybreak when the dawn shone, or became light. (Mgh.) See also 2.
manaArN [originally manowarN] A place of light; as also manaArapN↓. (M. Ḳ.)

A sign, or mark, set up to show the way: (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) and a thing that is put as a limit or boundary between two things; (M, Ḳ;) or between two lands, (Aṣ, T,) made of mud or clay or of earth: (Aṣ, TA:) pl. manaAviru [respecting which see manaArapN]. (A.) It is [also used as a coll. gen. n.; as, for instance, where it is] said, in a trad., laEana Qll-ehu mano gay-ara manaAra AlOaroDi May God curse him who alters the marks of the limit between two lands: (T, TA:) or it may mean manaAra AlHarami the boundary-marks of the Haram [or sacred territory of Mekkeh], which [it is said] were set up by Abraham. (T, TA.*) And it is said in another trad, Uin-a liloUisolaAmi SuwFI wamanaArFA ‡ Verily there are to El-Islám signs and ordinances whereby it is known. (TA.)
See also SawomaEapN.
The middle, or main part and middle, or part along which one travels, (maHaj-ap,) of a road. (M, Ḳ.)
muniyrN: see nay-irN, in two places.
See also naAYirN.
manaArapN, originally manowarapN; (A, Ḳ;) see manaArN.

A stand for a lamp; a thing upon which a lamp is put: (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) of the measure mafoEalapN. with fet-ḥ (Ṣ, Mṣb) to the m; (Ṣ:) but by rule it should be with kesr, because it is an instrument (Mṣb.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses it, for the sake of metre, in the place of miSobaAH, in likening a bright spear-head, without rust, to a lamp. (M.)
Also, A candle having a siraAj [or lighted wick]. (T.)
[A pharos, or lighthouse.]

The mená reh [or turret of a mosque, whence the English term “minaret,” so written in imitation of the Turkish pronunciation,] upon which the time of prayer is proclaimed; (Ṣ, Mṣb:) syn. miYocanapN, (Ḳ, TA,) vulgarly maOacanapN [which is the form given in the CK]. (TA.)
[Any pillar-like structure. (See zuronuwqN.)]
[The perch of a hawk, or falcon. (See marobaON.)]
The pl. is manaAwiru and manaAYiru: he who uses the latter likens the radical letter to the augmentative; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) like as they say maSaAYibu, which is originally maSaAwibu (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
musotaniyrN: see nay-irN.

1. naAsa, aor. yanuwsu, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. nawosN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and nawasaAnN, (M, A, Ḳ,) It (a thing, Ṣ, M, as a look of hair, and an carring, A) moved to and fro; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) it was in a state of commotion, and moved to and fro, (M, TA,) hanging down; (TA;) it dangled, or hung down and was in a state of commotion or agitation. (M, Mṣb [but in the M, the verb in this last sense has only the former of the two inf. ns. assigned to it, though the other equally helongs to it.]) You say also, naAsa luEaAbuhu His slaver flowed and was in a state of commotion. (M.) [See also 5]

4. AnAshu He made it to move to and fro; (Ṣ, A;) he made it to be in a state of commotion. (M, Ḳ, TA,) and to move to and fro, (M,) and to hang down; (TA;) he made it to dangle, or to hang down and be in a state of commotion or agitation. (M.) It is said in a trad. (Ṣ, M. TA.) of Umm-Zarạ, (Ṣ, TA,) OanaAsa mino HuliI-K OucunaI-a [He made my two ears to move to and fro,, &c., with ornaments]; (Ṣ, M, TA;) meaning, that he ornamented her two ears with [ear-rings of the kinds called] qiraTap and Xunuwf, which moved to and fro, &c., in them. (TA.)
5. tnw-s It, (a branch of a tree,) being blown by the wind, became shaken thereby, so that it moved much to and fro; as also tnw-E (TA.) [See also 1.]

hom.sense: naAsN is applied to Men, and to jinn, or genii; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but its predominant application is to the former: (Mṣb:) it is said by some to be applied to both in the former of the last two verses of the Ḳur, Ql-aciI yuwasowisu fiI Suduwri Aln-aAsi mina Aljin-api waAln-aAsi [who suggesteth what is vain in the breasts of people of the jinn and mankind]; unless by it be meant Aln-aAsiI [the forgetting]; or mn Aljn-p wAlnAs is added in explanation of a preceding word, AlwasowaAs, or of AlcI, or it is in dependence upon ywsws; (Bḍ;) [but what corroborates the first explanation is the fact that] men and jinn are both termed rijaAl in the Ḳur, lxxii. 6; and the Arabs used to say, raOayotu naAsFA mina Aljin-i [I saw people of the jinn]: (Mṣb:) it is a pl. of UinosN, (Ḳ,) originally OunaAsN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a pl. which is rare [as to form]; (Ḳ;) or OunaAsN is pl. of UinosaAnN; (M, art. Ons;) and nAs has the article Al prefixed to it, (Ṣ, M,) but not as a substitute for the suppressed C, because, were it so, it would not be found prefixed to the original, OunaAsN, whereas it is found prefixed to this latter: (Ṣ:) this derivation, however, from OunaAsN, contradicts its belonging to art. nws: (MF;) [but some hold that it does belong to this art.; and the form of its dim., to be mentioned below, favours their opinion: Fei says,] it is a noun applied to denote a pl., like qawomN and rahoTN; and its sing. is UinosaAnN, from a different root: it is derived from naAsa, aor. yanuwsu, signifying “it hung down and was in a state of commotion:” and [agreeably with this derivation it is said that] its dim. is nuwayosN: (Mṣb:) some, again, said that Aln-aAsu is originally Aln-aAsiI. (L, TA, voce UinosN.) See also UinosN, throughout.
See also nuwaAsN.

entry.sense: [naAsuwtN Human nature; humanity; as also UinosaAniy-apN: probably post-classical: opposed to laAhuwtN, q. v., in art. lyh.]
nawasaAtN: see nuwaAsN.

nuwaAsN A [lock of hair such as is called] cuWaAbap, that moves to and fro: (Ḳ, in explanation of cuw nuwaAsK the name of a king of El-Yemen:) or nuwaAsapN↓ has this signification: (A:) [the former, therefore, is a coll. gen. n., and this is indicated in the Ṣ; and the latter is its n. un.:] and nawasaAtN↓ signifies i. q. cawaAYibu, [pl. of cuWaAbapN,] because they move about much. (TA.)

What hangs to the roof, (M, A, &c. [a signification assigned in the Ḳ to naAsN, probably through the careless omission of the word Aln-uwaAsu by an early transcriber,]) consisting of smoke, (A, TA,) [or soot,] &c. (TA,) The word in the T and O, as well as in the A [and M], is nuwaAsN. (TA.)
The web of a spider: because of its fluttering. (M.)
nuwaAsapN: see nuwaAsN.
naw-aAsN, applied to man, (Ṣ,) Quivering (muDoTaribN), and flaccid, or flabby. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
naAYisN act. part. n. of 1. Ex. xuyuwTN naAYisapN Threads dangling or hanging down and moving about. (TA.)

naAwuwsN, (M, Mṣb,) or naAWuwsN, (Mgh,) Burialplaces of Christians: (M:) or a burial-place of Christians: (Mgh, Mṣb:) [De Sacy observes, that En-Nuweyree and El-Makreezee constantly use this word in speaking of the burial-places of the ancient kings of Egypt, and that it is from the Greek ναος: (“Relation de l'Égypte par Abd-allatif;” p. 508:) Freytag, on the authority of Meyd., explains it as signifying a coffin in which a corpse is enclosed: and ʼAbd-el-Laṭeef applies the expression naAwuwsN mino HajarK to the sarcophagus in the Great Pyramid: (see “Abdollatiphi Hist. Æg. Comp.;” p. 96:)] if Arabic, (M,) of the measure faAEuwlN: (M, Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. nawaAwiysu. (Mgh, TA.)

hom.sense:
1. naAXahu, aor. yanuwXu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) inf. n. nawoXN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He took it, or reached it, absolutely, or with the hand, or with the extended hand; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also tnAwXhu↓, (A, TA,) inf. n. tanaAwuXN; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and AntAXhu↓, (A, TA,) inf. n. UinotiyaAXN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it is also written with C; (A, Ḳ, TA, in art. nOX;) and so is tanaAwuXN. (Mṣb, and Ḳ in art. nOX.) And He took him, or reached him, to seize his beard, or his head. (ISk, Ṣ.) You say, naAXahu nawoXapF xafiyfapF [He reached him with a feeble, or slight reach, with his spear or the like]. (A.) And Alr-imaAHu tanuwXuhu The spears reach him: occurring in a poem of Dureyd Ibn-Eṣ-Ṣimmeh. (TA.) And AlZ-ibaMCu tanuwXu AlOaraAka [The antelopes reach and take with their mouths of the trees called ArAk]; as also tanotaAXuhu↓. (A.) And Aln-aAqapu tanuwXu bifiyahA AlHawoDa [The she-camel reaches and takes with her mouth of the water of the drinking-trough]. (TA.) A poet says, (ISk, Ṣ,) namely, Gheylán Ibn-Horeyth Er-Raba'ee, (TA,)
fahoIa tanuwXu AlHawoDa nawoXFA mino EalaA
nawoXFA bihi taqoTaEu OajowaAza AlofalaA
And she reaches and takes of the drinking-trough, from above it, a copious draught by means of which she traverses [the middles of the] waterless deserts without needing other water. (Ṣ.) You say also, nuXotu mina AlT-aEaAmi XayoYFA I obtained somewhat of the food. (TA.) And AlwaSiy-apu nawoXN mina AlmaEoruwfi [The testament is a means of an attaining of benefit]: i. e., the testator gives [for yatanaAwalu in my original I read yunaAwilu] to the legatee without diminishing his property [during his own life]. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xxxiv. 51,] waOan-aI lahumu Qlt-anaAwuXu↓ mino makaAnK baEiydK meaning, [But how shall] the attaining of belief [be possible to them from a distant place, i. e.,] in the world to come, when they have disbelieved in him [namely Moḥammad] in the present world? in which passage some read [Alt-anaAWuXu,] with C. (Ṣ.) [See art. nOX.] Accord. to Ibn-ʼAbbád, in this instance, AltnAwX↓ signifies Returning. (Ḳ,* TA.) And ʼÁïsheh said of her father, faQnotaAXa↓ Ald-iyna binaEoXihi Uiy-aAhu And he restored the religion, and laid hold upon it and took it from the abyss into which it had fallen; [by his exalting it;] in which instance, also, the verb is sometimes pronounced with C. (TA.)
naAXa bihi, aor. as above, He clung, or clave, to him, or it. (TA.)
nuXotuhu xayorFA, (Lth, Ṣ,) inf. n. nawoXN, (Lth,) I made him to attain good; (Lth, Ṣ;) and Xar-FA evil. (Lth.)

entry.sense: 3. naAwaXuwhumo biAlr-imaAHi, [inf. n. munaAwaXapN, They reached, or thrust, them with the spears, in near, but not close, conflict, being in like manner reached, or thrust, by them,] (A, Mgh,) is from tanaAwuXN in the first of the senses assigned to it above: (Mgh:) munaAwaXapN, in conflict, is the reaching one another [with spears or other weapons] (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ) when the two parties are near [but not close]: (ISk, Ṣ, TA) and is like muhaAwaXapN, i. e., conflicting. (TA.) See also 6.
nAwX AlX-aIoCa He mixed with [or engaged in] the thing. (IAạr.)
6: see 1, in three places.

tanaAwaXuwhumo biAlr-imaAHi They [reached or] thrust them with the spears, [in near, but not close, conflict,] being in like manner [reached or] thrust by them: (Mṣb:) tanaAwuXN is the reaching one another with the spears [or other weapons] when the two parties are not close together. (TA.) See also 3.
8: see 1, in three places.

AntAXhu also signifies he caused him to come, or go, forth (Ḳ, TA) from a place of destruction: or he took, led, or drew, him forth therefrom: (TA:) and he saved him, or rescued him, from destruction. (A,* TA.)
nawuwXN Strong: (Ḳ:) a man possessing might, or strength, courage, valour, or prowess: (Ṣ, TA:) as also naWuwXN, q. v. (TA.) [In two copies of the Ṣ, I find the latter only, with C].

1. naASa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yanuwSu, (M,) inf. n. nawoSN and manaASN (M, Ḳ) and maniySN (M) and nawiySN (Ḳ) and niyaASN, (Ḳ, accord. to the TA,) or niyaASapN, (accord. to a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, and accord. to to the CK,) and nawaSaAnN, (Ḳ,) He put himself in motion: (Ḳ:) or he put himself in motion and went away. (M, TA.)
You say, maA yanuwSu fulaAnN liHaAjatiI Such a one does not put himself in motion for [the accomplishment of] my want. (TA.) And maA bihi nawiySN There is not in him strength (Ṣ, M) and motion [or activity], (Ṣ, TA.)
naASa liloHarakapi, inf. n. nawoSN and manaASN, He prepared himself for motion. (M, TA.)
naASa Uilayohi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. nawoSN, (TA,) He rose to him. (Ḳ.)

naASa, aor. yanuwSu, inf. n. nawoSN, He turned aside, or away: (M, TA:) he drew back, receded, retreated, or retired; (Ṣ, Ḳ *;) as also AstnAS↓: (Ṣ:) he fled; or turned away and fled: (TA:) he escaped, and outwent: (Mṣb:) and, inf. n. maniySN and manaASN, he escaped; or became safe, or secure: (M:) and accord. to IB, nuwSN, with, damm, [app. as an inf. n.,] also signifies the act of fleeing. (TA.) You say, naASa Eani AlOamori He turned aside, or away, from the thing, or affair; he declined from it; he avoided it; as also laASa. (Aboo-Turáb, TA.) And naASa Eanohu, inf. n. nawoSN, He removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance, and separated himself, from him, or it. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And naASa Eano qironihi, (Ṣ, A,) aor. yanuwSu, inf. n. nawoSN and manaASN, (Ṣ,) He fled, or turned away and fled, from his opponent, or adversary, (Ṣ, A,) and eluded him, (Ṣ,) or removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance, from him. (A) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xxxviii. 2,] walaAta Hiyna manaASK, meaning, When it was not a time of fleeing: (Az, TA:) or when it was not a time of drawing back and fleeing: (Ṣ, TA:) or when it was not a time of seeking, or petitioning, and of being aided, or succoured. (M, TA.)
3: see jur-apN.
10: see 1, in three places.
nawoSN A wild ass; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) because he ceases not to raise his head, going to and fro, like one running away at random. (Lth, Ḳ.*)

naAYiSN Raising his head, and running away at random: (M:) or a wild ass raising his head, and going to and fro, like one running away at random: (Lth, Ḳ *:) and maniySN↓ a horse raising his head. (TA.)

hom.sense: manaASN A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, preservation, or concealment: a place of refuge: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) a place to which one flees; (Ṣ;) a place of safety or security. (A.)
See also 1, throughout.

entry.sense: maniySN: see naAYiSN.

1. naATahu, aor. yanuwTu, inf. n. nawoTN, He suspended it; hung it. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, nuTotu Alqirobapa biniyaATihaA [I suspended the water-skin by its nyAT, q. v]. (TA.) And niyTa Ealayohi AlX-aIoCu The thing was suspended to him, or it: and nuwTa Elyh: (TA:) or nuw-iTa↓ Ealayohi, (Ṣ; accord. to two copies: the pronoun relating to a camel when loaded.) And niyTa bihi AlX-aIoCu The thing was attached to, or connected with, him, or it. (TA.) It is said in a trad, maA OaxaconaAhu Uil-aA EafowFA bilaA sawoTK walaA nawoTK i. e. [We took him not save with case;] with neither beating, [lit. with neither whip,] nor hanging [or clinging]. (TA.) And in a proverb, kul-u XaAhK birijolihaA satunaATu [Every sheep, or goat, shall be hung by its hind leg]: i. e. every one who commits a crime shall be punished for it: or, accord to Aṣ, one ought not to punish for a crime, or an offence, any but the committer thereof. (TA.) And Hassán Ibn-Thábit says,
waOanota daEiI-N niyTa fiI Mli haAXimK
kamaA niyTa xalofa Alr-aAkibi AlqadaHu Alfarodu
[And thou art an adopted person, who is connected with the family of Háshim, like as the single drinking-cup is connected behind the rider]. (TA.) See also XaAqa, in art. Xwq.
2: see 1.
8. AntAT It was, or became, suspended, or hung; it hung; (Ḳ, TA;) bihi to him, or it. (TA.)

[And hence,] ‡ It was, or became, distant, or remote, or far-extending. (Ṣ, TA.) You say, AntATt AlmafaAzapu, and, by transposition, UinotaTat, ‡ The desert extended far; [as though it were connected with a desert like it; (see niyaATN;)] it was far-extending. (TA.) And AntATt AlmagaAziI ‡ The places of war were distant, or far-extending: from niyaATu AlmafaAzapi, meaning “the far extent of the desert:” or from AlnawoTu. (TA.) And AntATt Ald-aAru ‡ The house, or place of abode,, &c., was distant. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)
