nawoTN A thing, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) whatever it be, (Ṣ,) that is suspended, or hung, from another thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Ḳ:) and particularly a thing that is put, or hung, upon a camel, (EilaAwapN,) between two halves of a load, byn Eidolayoni, (Ḳ,) or, as AʼObeyd says, bayona AlEuwdayoni [which, if not a mistranscription, app. means between the two staves of the saddle]; (TA:) the ElAwp being thus called because it is suspended (tunaATu) to the load: (Z, TA:) and a small [receptacle of palm-leaves, of the kind called] jul-ap, (Az, Ṣ, Ḳ,) containing dates (Ṣ, Ḳ) and the like, (Ḳ,) which is suspended from a camel, (Ṣ,) being hung, by its handles, from the saddle of the camel of burden: (Az, TA;) such, says Az, I have heard thus called by the people of El-Bahreyn: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OanowaATN (Ṣ. Ḳ) and [of mult.] niyaATN (Az, Ḳ;) the former is pl. of nawoTN in the general sense first mentioned above: and also signifies what is suspended (nuw-iTa, as in two copies of the Ṣ, or nuwTa, as in the TA) upon the camel when he is loaded: (Ṣ, TA:) and i. q. maEaAliyqu [things suspended to a beast of burden; such as the qumoqumap and the qirobap and the miToharap]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is said in a proverb EaATK bagayori OanowaATK Taking [or reaching to take] without there being there anything suspended; which is like the saying “Driving by singing without having a camel” (Ṣ, L, [See also art ETw.]) And in another proverb. Uino OaEoyaA AlbaEiyru fazidohu nawoTFA [If the camel be fatigued, add thou to him an appendage to his full load] meaning, if he be slow and inobsequious in his pace, do not thou lighten his burden: (Ḳ:) accord. to Aṣ, Uino OaEoyaA fazidohu nawoTFA is a proverb relating to the pressing a niggardly man. (TA.)

caAtu OanowaATK the name of A particular tree, (Ṣ, TA,) of great size, (Ṣ,) which was worshipped in the time of ignorance, said by IAth to be the name of a particular gum-acacia-free (samurap) to which the believers in a plurality of gods used to suspend their weapons, and around which they used to circuit. (TA.)
Aln-awoTu Almucabocibu occurs in a trad. as meaning The leg of a rider, from fatigue or some other cause, ever dangling, or moving to and fro. (TA.)

niyaATN The loop-shaped handle (Eurowap) of a qirobap [or water-skin]: (Mṣb:) the [appendage called] muEal-aq [q. v.] of a bow; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) by which it is suspended: (Ḳ, voce xaTama:) and of a qirobap: [by which it is suspended;] (see 1, second sentence;) and of anything. (Ḳ.)
See also XiyaAqN.

Also (Ṣ, Mṣb [in the Ḳ, “or,” which is evidently a mistake,]) Aln-iyaATu [i. e. niyaATu Alqalobi The suspensory of the heart;] a vein, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or a thick vein, (Ḳ,) [app. the ascending aorta,] by which the heart is suspended (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) from, (mino, Ṣ, Mṣb [or possibly this may mean forming a part of,]) or to, (UilaI, Ḳ,) the watiyn, [which seems here to signify the descending aorta, or, accord. to the second rendering of mn, suggested above, the aorta altogether,] (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the cutting, or severing, of which causes death; (Ṣ, Mṣb;)
as also nayoT↓: (Ṣ:) pl. [of pauc.] OanowiTapN and [of mult.] nuwTN, with damm, (Az, Ḳ,) because the I in niyaATN is originally w: the latter is allowable when the number is not meant [to be limited to a few]: or, accord. to some, there are two things thus called: the upper being that of the heart: and the lower, the faroj. (Az, L.) [Hence,] AlmuqaT-aEapu Aln-iyaATi (Ḳ, and so in a copy of the Ṣ, excepting that the former word is there without the article,) is applied to ‡ The Oaronab [or female hare], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like muqaT-aEapu AlOasoHaAri, (Ṣ,) as an appellation of good omen, i. e. as meaning that her nyAT will be severed: or, as some say, AlmuqaT-iEapu Aln-iyaATi, (Ḳ, and so in some copies of the Ṣ, excepting that the former word is there without the article,) as meaning that, by reason of her swiftness, her nyAT, or [as in the A,] the nyAT of [every one of] the dogs [that pursue her], will be severed. (Ḳ.) Hence also the saying, ramaAhu Qll-ehu biAln-ayoTi↓, meaning [God smote him, or may God smite him,] with death. (Ṣ.) [See also art. nyT.] [Hence likewise,] Aln-iyaATu is applied to ‡ Two stars [app. s and t of Scorpio] between which is qalobu AlEaqorabi [which is the star and of that constellation]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA.)

Also, i. q. AlfuWaAdu [which generally means The heart; but is probably here used in one of its other senses, namely, the appendages of the œsophagus, consisting of the liver and lungs and heart]. (Ḳ.)

niyaATu AlmafaAzapi ‡ The far extent of the desert: (TA:) or of the way thereof; as though it were connected with another desert, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) hardly coming to an end. (Ṣ, TA.) [Thus,] AlbaEiydu niyaATuhu, applied to the Ḥijáz, means AlbaEiydu muEal-aquhu † [i. e. Whereof every connected part, or appendant tract, is far-extending]. (Ḥam, p. 659). The Rájiz, El-ʼAjjáj, says,
wabalodapK baEiydapi Aln-iyaATi
majohuwlapK tagotaAlu xaTowa AlxaATiI
† [Many a region far extending, unknown, rendering unapparent the trace of the stepping of the stepper]. (Ṣ and O in the present art. and in art. gwl.)
Aln-aAYTu: see niyaATN.

tanaw-uTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like takar-umN, (Ḳ,) and tunaw-iTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) with damm to the t (Ḳ) and fet-ḥ to the n (TA) and kesr to the w, (Ḳ,) or tanaw-iTN, (as in some copies of the Ṣ,) and tunuw-iTN, (TA, voce tubuX-irN,) A certain bird, that lets down strings from a tree, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and weaves its nest like an oilflask, suspended to those strings, (Ḳ,) then produces her young therein; and hence its appellation: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) a certain bird, like the qaAriyap in blackness, [or rather in dinginess,] that constructs its nest between two twigs, or branches, or upon one twig, or branch, making its nest long, so that a man cannot reach its eggs until he introduces his arm to the shoulder-joint: or, accord. to Aboo-ʼAlee, a certain bird, that suspends pieces of the bark of trees [formed into strings], and makes its nest at their extremities, to protect itself from serpents and men and car- [or young ants, or small red ants]: (TA [see also SaAfirN:]) called in Persian kiyPuwo: (Ḳzw:) n. un. with p {tanaw-uTapN}. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., vol. iii., p. 499.] Hence the proverb, OaSonaEu mino tanaw-uTK [More skilled in fabricating than a tnw-T]. (Meyd.)
tanowuATN What is hung (Ṣ, Ḳ) from, (Ṣ,) or upon, (Ḳ,) the [kind of vehicle called] hawodajN, for ornament: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the implements, or apparatus, &c., that are hung upon a horse. (Ḥam, p. 249)

And hence, ‡ Adventives; or persons who introduce themselves among a people, and live among them, not being of their race; and persons whose fathers are free men, or Arabs, and whose mothers are slaves, and who have become conjoined with the genuine and pure Arabs, not being of them: for cuw Alt-anowaATi; [or cawuw Alt-anowaATi;] the latter of these two words being originally an inf. n.: or it may be an inf. n. used as an epithet. (Ḥam, ibid.) [See also manuwTN.]
manaATN A place of suspension, or hanging. (Mṣb.)

[Hence the saying,] fulaAnN min-iI manaATa Alv-uray-aA ‡ [Such a one is with respect to me as though he were in the place of suspension of the Pleiades]; i. e., in distance: (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ * [in the Ḳ, hcA is put for fulaAnN; and in the CK, manATu is erroneously put for mnATa]:) or the meaning is, in such a station: the prep. being understood, as in cahabotu AlXaOoma and daxalotu Albayota: Z says, humo min-iI manaATa Alv-uray-aA ‡ [they are, &c.] by reason of their elevated state. (TA.)
manuwTN Suspended; hung. (Ḳ.) You say, hecaA manuwTN bihi This is suspended, or hung, to him, or it. (Ḳ.)

[Hence the saying,] hecaA rajulN manuwTN biAlqawomi † This is a man adventive to the people; one who has introduced himself among them, and lives among them, not being of their race: (Ḳ,* TA:) or i. q. daEiI-N [one whose origin, or lineage, is suspected;, &c.]: (Ḳ:) and manuwTN mucabocibN is also applied to a person of this latter description who betakes himself to a people; the latter epithet being added to denote that he knows not to whom to assert himself related, like the wind wavering to the right and left. (TA.) [See also tanowaATN.]

munotaATN ‡ Distant, or remote; and far extending. (TA.) You say, munotaATu AlmaHal-i ‡ Whose place of abode is distant. (TA.) And gaAyapN munotaATapN ‡ A distant goal, or scope; or a far-extending space. (TA.)

1. naMCa, aor. yaniIoCu, (so in the Ṣ, Nh, L, Mṣb; but in some copies of the Ḳ, ynACu, [which appears to be put by mistake for the inf. n. in the acc. case];) inf. n. naIoCN, (Ṣ,) and naI-N, without C, and nawoCN, (Sh,) It (flesh meat, &c.) was not, or did not become, sufficiently cooked; it was insufficiently cooked: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) (like nahiYa:) or it was untouched by fire; [i. e., raw]. (L.)
It (a thing) was not firmly, not soundly, not thoroughly, done. [See 4.] (TA.)
2: see 4.

4. AnAC AlOamora He did the thing not firmly, not soundly, not thoroughly. ny-O↓ AlAmr, accord. to the Ḳ, signifies the same: but this is unknown, and not authorized by transmission [from the Arabs of the classical ages], and therefore not mentioned by IM nor by other leading lexicographers: the correct phrases are [when the verb is intrans.] nAC AlAmru [and AllHmu], and [when it is trans.] AnAC AllHma [and AlAmr]: the forms of the verb being like baAna and OabaAna. (TA.)
AnAC, (Ṣ, incorrectly written in the Ḳ OanoyaOa, TA,) inf. n. UinaMCapN, He insufficiently cooked flesh-meat [&c.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
niIoCN Flesh meat, &c. insufficiently cooked: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or untouched by fire; [i. e., raw]. (L.) It was also pronounced by the Arabs niI-N; but the original word is with C. (TA.)
Wine untouched by the fire: cooked [or mulled] wine being called naDiyjN, (TA [written niI-N, without C]).
Pure [and sweet] milk: sour milk being called nDyj: or milk just drawn from the udder, before it is put into the skin. (TA [written niI-N, without C.])
naI-N [for naIoCN] Fat, as contradistinguished from flesh, [which is app. called naDiyjN]. (TA.)
nuyuwoCN and nuyuwoCapN The state of being insufficiently cooked: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of being untouched by fire; [i. e., rawness]. (L.)
1. naAbahu, aor. yaniybu, He hit him on his nAb, i. e., his canine tooth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
2. naAbahu He bit the wood of the arrow, to know whether it were strong or weak, and made an impression upon it with his canine tooth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
ny-b fiyhi He (a beast of prey) made an impression upon him with his canine tooth: he fixed his canine teeth in him. (TA)
ny-bt She (a camel) became extremely old: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) became what is termed a nAb. (A.)
ny-b and tny-b↓ † It (a plant) put forth its root. (Ḳ.) Also signifying the same with reference to white, or hoary hair. The root is thought by ISd to be thus likened to a canine tooth. (TA.)
Zaf-ar fulaAnN fiI kacaA wanay-aba ‡ Such a one clung to, caught to, or took fast hold upon, such a thing: [lit., stuck his nails and dog-teeth into it]. (A.) See also Zaf-ara.
5: see 2.

naAbN [originally nayabN, The canine tooth, or dog-tooth; or eye-tooth; the tusk, or tush; or the fang; of certain animals:] one of the teeth; (Ṣ;) the tooth that is [next] behind the rabaAEiyap, [or next but one to the central pair of incisors:] (M, Ḳ.) [In this sense, the word is masc.:] the tooth thus called is masc., when thus called: [though if you call it sin-N, it is fem.:] but nAb when fem. signifies “an old she-camel” (Mṣb:) or, accord. to the M and Ḳ, it is fem. only in each of the above senses without distinction. (TA.) Sb says, that the Arabs observed the pronunciation termed imáleh (UimaAlap) in the case of nAb in the nom. [as well as in the acc. and gen., in which latter case this pronunciation is agreeable with analogy on account of the final kesreh,] likening its ‡ to that in ramaI, [in which it is expressed in writing by I,] because it is changed from I: but this is extr. That is, this pronunciation of ‡ changed from I or w is only observed [regularly] when the said A is a final radical letter; and specially in verbs: the instances of this kind that occur in nouns are extr.; and more so are those in which the A changed from I is a medial radical letter. (TA.) [But the restriction to the case of verbs is inconsistent with what is said by Ibn-Málik and other high authorities: and so, too, is the restriction to the case of a final radical letter.] Pl. OanoyubN (Lḥ, Ḳ) and OanoyaAbN [both pls. of pauc.: but the latter is used as a pl. of mult.:] and nuyuwbN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the latter contr. to analogy, (Ṣ,) because [naAbN is originally nayabN, and] a word of the measure faEalN does not [regularly] assume the measure faEuwlN in the pl.; (TA;) to which should be added niyuwbN, a dial. var., as in the case of every pl. of the measure fuEuwlN of which the medial radical letter is I: (M, F:) and pl. pl. OanaAyiybu. (Ḳ, TA.) Ibn-Seenà says that no animal has both a nAb and a horn. (Mṣb.)

naAbN An aged she-camel: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) not applied to a male camel: (Ṣ;) so called because of the length of her lush; (Ṣ;) by synedoche; the whole being called by the name of a part: (TA:) as also nayuwbN↓; (Ḳ;) accord. to some copies of the Ḳ, nay-awbN; but this is a mistake: (TA:) pl. of the former OanoyaAbN and nuyuwbN (Ḳ) and niybN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or these are pls. of both the former of sing. (Ḳ. accord. to some copies; and TA.) Sb is of opinion that niybN is pl. of nAb, and says that the Arabs have made it of the measure fuEolN [as it is said to be in the Ṣ, for it is originally nuyobN,] like as they have the pl. of daArN, disliking the sound of nuyuwbN, because the I is with ḍammeh, and preceded by ḍammeh, and followed by w. It is also said to be pl. of nayuwbN↓; as it is related, on the authority of Yoo, that certain of the Arabs say SiydN and biyDN, as pls. of SayuwdN and bayuwDN, agreeably with the dial. of those who say rusolN [instead of rusulN]; namely, the tribe of Temeem but their not saying nuyubN, like as they say SuyudN and buyuDN, is an argument in favour of the opinion of Sb.
laA OafoEalu celika maA Han-ati Aln-iybu [I will not do that as long as aged she-camels yearn towards their young ones i. e., I will never do it]. A proverb. (Ṣ.)

The dim. of naAbN is nuyayobN, without p, because nAb, as applied to an aged she-camel, is like an epithet: (Ṣ:) or rather this formation of the dim. without nAb is a dev. from constant rule. (MF.) Sh says, that some of the Arabs make the dim. of nAb to be vuwayobN, because many an A such as that in nAb is changed from w: [or rather, this is generally the case:] but this, says Ibn-Es-Sarráj is an error on his part [who does so]. (Ṣ.) This apparently means, that Ibn-Es-Sarráj accuses Sh of an error; but such is not the case: for Sb himself says “but this is an error on their part;” i. e., on the part of the Arabs who say nwyb for nyyb (IB.)
naAbu qawomK ‡ The lord, master, or chief, of a people: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OanoyaAbN. (TA.)
EaD-atohu OanoyaAbu Ald-ahori, and nuyuwbuhu, [‡ The dog-teeth of fortune bit him]. (A.)
AnyAb are likewise met. assigned to evil, or mischief. (TA.)
nayuwbN: see naAb.
nuy-abN [as though pl. of naAYibN or naAYibapN] an epithet added to nuyuwbN as signifying “canine teeth.” to render the signification intensive, or energetic. (TA.)
Oanoyabu Having a large, or thick, canine tooth, (Ḳ,) that does not bite a thing without breaking it. (Th.)

1. naAta, aor. yaniytu, inf. n. nayotN; as also naAta, aor. yanuwtu, inf. n. nawotN; (L, Ḳ;) He (a man) moved from side to side in walking (L, art nwt:) or he so moved by reason of weakness, or infirmity: (Ḳ:) or, by reason of drowsiness. (L, art. nwt, q. v.)

1. naAra Alv-awoba, aor. yaniyruhu, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. nayorN; (T, M, Ḳ;) and ny-rhu↓, (T, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) inf. n. tanoyiyrN; (T;) and AnArhu↓, (T. Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) and hanaArahu, (Ṣ, M, TA,) like OaraAqa and haraAqa, (Ṣ,) aor. of the latter yuhaniyruhu (M, TA,) inf. n. UihonaArapN, (M,) or hinaArapN; (TA;) He made, or put, to the piece of cloth a nyr; (T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) i. e., an Ealam [or ornamental border]; (T, Ṣ,* M,* A, Mgh, Ḳ,* TA;) syn. OaEolamahu: (A:) and a woof; (Ṣ,* A, Mgh, TA;*) syn OaloHamahu; (A;) contr. of OasodaAhu and sad-aAhu (Mgh.)
huwa yusad-iI AlOumuwra wayuniyruhaA (A) or yusodiI (TA) ‡ [He commences things, or affairs, and completes them].
2: see 1.
4. AnArhu and hanaArahu: see 1, throughout.
nayorN: see niyrN.

hom.sense: niyrN The Ealam [or ornamental border] of a piece of cloth: (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) pl. OanoyaArN. (M, Ḳ) It is related that ʼOmar disliked it, (TA,) and that he forbade it. (T, TA.)

Hence, ‡ The side (Tur-ap) of a road: (T:) or the side (jaAnib) and wide or widening part (Sador), of a road. (so in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA: but in some copies of the former, “or” is put in the place of “and:”) or the conspicuous part of a road: (Ṣ:) or the conspicuous furrowed part of a road. (M, A, Ḳ.)
The unwoven end (hudob) of a piece of cloth. (Ibn-Keysán, M, Ḳ)

The woof of a piece of cloth. (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.) When cloth is woven with a double woof, (EalaI niyrayoni,) it is more close in texture and more lasting. (Ṣ.) vawobN cuw niyrayoni signifies A piece of cloth strongly woven, with a double woof: (A:) or a piece of cloth woven with double thread: (T:) and [in like manner] vawobN munay-arN↓ a piece of cloth woven with a double woof; (Lḥ, M, Ḳ;) i. e., with a double thread: (TA:) also called dayaAbuwc, (T, TA,) an arabicized word; (TA;) in Persian duwo Puwdo, or duwo buwdo, (as in different copies of the Ḳ,) or duwo baAfo. (T.) This mode of weaving is termed mutaMCamahN, which is the making the woof of a double thread, and putting two threads together upon the Haf-ap [which here means the yarn-beam, on which the warp is rolled]. (T.)

Hence, naAqapN daAtu niyrayoni ‡ A she-camel having an accession of fat upon former fat: (T:) or having, upon her, layers (SaHaAYif) of fat; as also caAtu OanoyaArK: (A:) or advanced in years, yet having some remains of strength; (M, Ḳ;) and sometimes the epithet is applied in like manner to a woman: (M:) and naAqapN caAtu OanoyaArK a she-camel having thick flesh. (TṢ.) Also, rajulN cuw niyrayoni ‡ A man whose strength is double the strength of his companion: (Ṣ:) or strong and firm. (A.) And raOaIN cuw niyrayoni ‡ Right opinion or counsel. (A.) And HarobN caAtu niyrayoni ‡ Violent war. (T, A.)

The canes (qaSab) and threads (xuyuwTap) [in a loom], when they are put together: (M, Ḳ:) [it is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p, as appears from what here follows:] niyrapN↓ is a subst., signifying the threads and canes, (xuyuwTap and qaSabap, [or warp and, app., cane-roll, on which the warp is rolled when put into the loom, and from which it is gradually unrolled as the work proceeds,] when they are put together: when they are separate, the threads are called xuyuwTapN; and the cane, qaSabapN, or, if a staff, EaSFA: AZ, Sh, T:) niyrapN is also explained as signifying one of the implements of the weaver, with which he weaves; namely, the transverse piece of wood [in the loom; the same as is described above]. (T.) In the following verse of an unknown poet,
taqosimu Ousotiy-FA lahaA binayori↓
wataDoribu Aln-aAquwsa wasoTa Ald-ayori
[She divides warp that she has with cane-rolls, and beats the nákoos in the midst of the convent], the author may mean biniyrK, and may have altered the word by necessity; or nayorN↓ may be a dial. form of niyru. (M.) One says of a man who neither harms nor profits, maA Oanota bisataApK walaA luHomapK walaA niyrapK ‡ [lit. Thou art not a warp nor a woof nor a cane-roll]. (T.) [See also a similar saying voce Haf-apN.]

[The yoke of a bull;] the piece of wood that is upon the neck of the bull, together with its apparatus: (M, Ḳ:) or the piece of wood that is placed transversely upon the necks of the two bulls (T, Ṣ) yoked together for ploughing: (T:) called niyru Alfad-aAni: (Ṣ:) pl. [of pauc.] OanoyaArN and [of mult.] niyraAnN: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) of the dial. of Syria. (M.)

entry.sense: niyrapN: see niyrN.
muniyrN act. part. n. of 4: see 1.
[Hence the saying,] lasota fiI hcaA AlOamori bimuniyrK walaA muloHimK ‡ [Thou art not in this affair a commencer nor a finisher: or a person who will do harm nor one who will profit]. (TA.)
munay-arN: see niyrN.
‡ A skin that is thick (A, Ḳ, TA) and strong, (TA,) like a piece of cloth with a double woof. (A, TA.)

nayosaAnu [vulg. niysaAn] The seventh of the Greek [or Syrian] months; (Ḳ;) [corresponding to April, O. Ṣ.] It is [said to be] a property of the water of its rain, that dough kneaded with it ferments without other treatment. (TA.)
1. naATa, aor. yaniyTu, inf. n. nayoTN, It was, or became, distant, or remote, or far-extending; as also AntAT↓. (Ḳ.) [See the latter in art. nwT.]
8: see 1.
nayoTN: see niyaATN, in art. nwT, in two places.

Death: or a bier: or the term of existence: (Ḳ:) or the death which God connects (yanuwTuhu) [with one]: (IAạr:) and if so, the I is interchangeable with w, (IAth, TA,) the word being originally nayowiTN, then nay-iTN, and then nayoTN: (TA:) if a contraction, it is like hayonN and hay-inN, and layonN and lay-inN. (Az, TA.) You say, ramaAhu Qll-ehu biAln-ayoTi, meaning [God smote him, or may God smite him,] with death: (Ṣ, in art. nwT, and TA:) or [may God smite him] with the death which He connects [with him]; as also ramaAhu Qll-ehu binayoTihi. (IAạr.) And OataAhu nayoTuhu His term of existence came to him. (TA.) And rumiIa fulaAnN fiI nayoTihi Such a one was cast into his bier; meaning, when he died. (TA.) See TinoCN.
niyaATN: see art. nwT.
naAYiTN: see art. nwT.

niyluwfarN, (Mṣb,) and nayoluwfarN, (Mṣb, and so in the CK,) or nayolawofarN, (so in copies of the Ḳ, and so accord. to the TA,) or, as some say, nayonuwfarN, or nayonuwofarN, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) [The nymphæa, or lotus of Egypt and of Syria;] a certain well-known plant; (Mṣb;) a kind of sweet-smelling plant, which grows in stagnant waters, (Ḳ, TA,) called by the people of Egypt bXnyn, [i. e. baXoniyn,] and by the vulgar nawofar; (TA;) [both of which last names are now given in Egypt to the nymphæa lotus, or white lotus, found in the neighbourhoods of Rosetta and Damietta; and the former, also, or perhaps both, to the nymphæa cærulea, or blue lotus, found in the same parts, and, until within a few years, in a lake on the north of Cairo, called Birket er-Ratlee, whence I have twice procure roots of this plant:] nylwfr [written in Persian niyloParo and niyluwParo and niyluwbaroko, &c.] is a Persian word (OaEojamiy-apN), and is said to be composed of niyl, [or indigo,] with which one dyes, and the name for a wing, [i. e., Paro;] as though “winged with niyl [or indigo];” because the leaf is as though its two wings were dyed [with indigo]: (Mṣb:) the plant so called is cold in the third degree, moist in the second degree, emollient, good for cough and for pains of the side and lungs and chest; when its root, or lower part, (OaSol,) is kneaded with water, and used as a liniment, several times, it removes the disease called Albahaq; and when kneaded with zifot, it removes the disease called daMCu Alv-aEolabi: (Ḳ, TA:) an excellent beverage is also prepared from it. (TA.) The imám Bedred-Deen Mudhaffar, son of the Kádee of Baalabekk, says, in his book entitled Suroor en-Nefs, that it is of many species; whereof [one or more] in Syria, used in perfume; and a species in Egypt, blue; and that its temperament is cold and moist in the second degree; that the smelling it is useful against hot diseases, and anxiety; and its juice in like manner; and that the beverage prepared from it is useful as a remedy for cough and roughness [of the throat] and pain of the side and chest, and is a laxative. The author of the Irshád and that of the Moojiz also mention, that the beverage prepared from it is an exception from other sweet beverages inasmuch as it does not become converted into yellow bile, which is wonderful; and its oil is more cold and moist than that of violets; and there is no flower more cold and moist than it. Er-Rázee, too, says that the smelling it is one of the causes of weakening the generative faculty, and that the beverage is one of the causes of stopping it; [for which purpose, or as an antiaphrodisiac, it is used in the present day by some of the women of Cairo;] notwithstanding which, it rejoices the heart, and is useful for palpitation of the heart. This art. is omitted by J and Ṣgh and the author of the L. (TA.)
nayonuwfarN, or nayonawofarN: see art. nylwfr.
